name: Εμμανουήλ Γλέζος (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am aware of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure, which require 40 signatures to put an issue up for debate. But I am also addressing the President's wideness and any democratic background to remind him of the famous lesson of the Homeric era: 'what has he raised?' that, that is, every citizen had the right to cause a 'market', a popular assembly. And I ask: When there are the huge issues in Greece, one concerning the crisis and the other concerning debts from Germany, why should I wait for 40 signatures and not have the right, as an MEP, to propose? Ultimately, the House will decide.

name: El Presidente. –
text: Mr Glezos, it is not an issue which has absolutely anything to do with this debate, but we take a good note.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Iuliu Winkler, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Union system for the self-certification of due diligence in the supply chain of importers responsible for tin, tantalum and wolfram, its minerals and gold originating in conflict and high-risk zones (COM(2014)0111 – C7-0092/2014 – 2014/0059(COD)) (A8—0141/2015)

name: Iuliu Winkler
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, the draft regulation that we will be debating today aims to break the link between mineral extraction and trade and the financing of armed conflict. It sets up an EU system of self—certification of importers of 3Ts and gold, modelled on the OECD due diligence guidelines for responsible supply chains of minerals from conflict-affected areas.  What the conflict-affected areas are, entrepreneurs will receive guidance to establish, but this regulation does not tell them. This is not country-specific: it is conflict-specific, if I may put it that way, so it does not deal with any specific country or region.  Let me emphasise that our aim here is to build a coalition of responsible stakeholders in the interests of the people and the local communities in conflict-affected areas. Responsible sourcing of minerals from those areas is a very complex challenge. The objective of the EU approach is to break the link between economic activity and transparently—managed industry and trade, and conflict financing and conflict fuelling.  Parliament has called on the Commission to take action on this issue. Therefore, last March the Commission came up with the draft regulation and the joint communication to accompany it.  Let me take this opportunity to thank Commissioner Cecilia Malmström, the coordinators in Parliament’s Committee on International Trade (INTA), Committee on Development and Committee on Foreign Affairs, the shadow rapporteurs, all colleagues and all the stakeholders involved in the debate in the past months, for the great amount of work invested in this.  My objective as rapporteur is to contribute and draw up an efficient regulation which has to be coherent with the integrated EU approach, an approach which is built on three pillars: a trade regulation which is setting up the supply chain due diligence self-certification mechanism; accompanying measures to assist European Union companies in their uptake of the self-certification system, firstly and with a special focus on European SMEs; and accompanying measures on the ground to be deployed through political, diplomatic and development cooperation specially designed to support capacity-building, better governance and, first of all, education of all the stakeholders involved.  In order to achieve these effects and Parliamentʼs intentions, trade regulation has to be efficient and workable. The compromise voted in INTA, which is on the table for the vote tomorrow, is a compromise that fulfils this objective. It provides the voluntary responsibility-based approach with mandatory due diligence obligations for EU smelters and refiners, and also importers of minerals. It takes on board existing experience and incorporates already—functioning self-certification mechanisms, so it takes on board a great deal of work which has already been done by industry initiatives by providing the possibility of recognition for already established and OECD-compatible schemes.  It introduces the European ʽresponsible importerʼ label for the importers under the regulation and it draws up a list of responsible European importers. It introduces voluntary labelling for companies operating in the downstream European certification of responsibility, which is introduced also under the regulation proposed. This proposal, voted in INTA, respects the principles of prudent and proportionate legislating. It does not unilaterally impose obligations on EU companies; it respects and ensures a consistent uptake of the minerals market towards responsible conflict-free certification.  This proposal also focuses specially on the large number of European SMEs involved. It protects these SMEs with the right incentives and assistance, and does this under the umbrella of the COSME programme. It includes a strong and clear review clause that provides for the possibility to assess the effects of the regulation on the ground. The review also provides the opportunity to accommodate evolutions in the OECD due diligence framework regarding additional minerals beyond 3TG as they are elaborated by the OECD.  The proposal also avoids the risk of trade diversion, disengagement from conflict areas, unwanted but de facto embargoes effects, and any surge in smuggling and illegal trade with a negative price effect on the market. It does all this because it provides a functional and workable implementing framework for the regulation.  I believe that the proposal voted in the INTA Committee and tabled in this plenary fulfils the objective of the integrated EU approach, so I ask Members to support this proposal in the vote tomorrow.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this is an important occasion to debate a very important issue, namely how to eliminate conflict minerals from our supply chains. By doing so, we will reduce the great hardship, endless wars and human rights abuses that have traditionally come with them. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Winkler, the Committee on International Trade (INTA), the other committees and all the Members who have been active in working on this issue.  One of the challenges in trade policy is to harness the potential of our economies while creating effective systems to avoid negative consequences, like the one we are discussing today. This challenge is particularly acute in developing countries, and the issue of conflict minerals is one of the most glaring examples.  On the one hand, we do need a global market-based approach to raw materials that provides developing countries with a vital source of stable income through trade in natural resources. On the other hand, we need to break the link between minerals and conflict, the most obvious example of which is the conflict in the Great Lakes region in Africa. The situation there is horrific. Millions of people have been killed and millions more injured and traumatised since the outbreak of the first Congo war in the mid-1990s. While Congo is the most dramatic example of the phenomenon, it is not the only one. Therefore, following calls for action by the United States, the G8 and this Parliament, based on the work of the OECD, the Commission developed, jointly with the High Representative, an integrated approach. The draft regulation we are discussing here today is only one of its components. I insist on this integrated approach because it is crucial to understand – and I know you all do – that there is no silver bullet to deal with this problem. It is by nature multidimensional and extremely complicated. So we must look at it from different angles – development, political, the trade perspective – all at the same time.  The size of Europe’s trade footprint is such that businesses here must play their part. The EU is amongst the world’s largest importers of tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold ores and concentrates, with a share of almost 35% of global trade. The EU is also a relatively large importer of tin, tantalum and tungsten and gold metals which presently represent almost 25% and 15% of global trade respectively.  But precisely because of our importance in trade, we can also make things worse if we do not approach it in the right way. If we impose a mandatory scheme without making sure that the conditions on the ground in the conflict regions are right in order to support the implementation of such a system, we do run a high risk of further disrupting global supply chains and driving them away from Africa altogether.  We also risk creating trade diversion, resulting in prejudice against individual countries, or even the whole continent, and that would lead to plummeting prices for minerals from certain origins. We can also risk continuing to have thriving underground markets in conflict and high-risk areas and a prosperous smuggling sector. We can also create a severe shortage in the EU for companies that are – most of the time – willing, but unable, to check their supply chains effectively, and we will have achieved nothing on the ground since we will have placed fragile mining areas and local communities under additional pressure from international markets.  If you do not believe me, you can have a look at the situation in the Great Lakes region since the US mandatory scheme in the Dodd-Frank Act came into effect. The difficulties there are described in United Nations reports year after year. The Commission proposal has taken these key considerations into account, following an in-depth impact assessment exercise. Our plan is focused, proportionate and designed to complement the other components of the integrated approach.  Our proposal focuses on smelters and refiners. Until they know where they source their minerals from, we cannot reasonably ask the majority of downstream companies to know. Many of them might be tempted to lie. It will include responsible smelters and refiners in the EU and worldwide on a white list and consequently a ‘name and shame’ system for those that do not appear on it. There are no more than 40 smelters in the EU. How many of them do you think are able not to appear on that list? There will be a lot of pressure from you, from NGOs and from other business. I would argue not a single one. Moreover, the Commission proposal sets up an enforcement structure to be deployed by Member States’ competent authorities to ensure that operators claiming to be responsible are truly so. It also includes a strong review clause to open the possibility for switching – in a staged manner – to a mandatory approach in the event that the current proposal does not deliver. It operates in parallel to the EUR 20 million package that the High Representative and the Commission have announced to further support capacity building in conflict regions. So I think this voluntary, incentives-based approach, integrated for responsible sourcing, is the most appropriate one to achieve the common goal that we have here. I thank you for this possibility to debate it and am looking forward to the debate.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta
text: draft opinion of the Committee on Development. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Tomorrow's vote on the Wincler report, of which I was an opinion-giver on behalf of the Committee on Development, gives Members of the European Parliament the opportunity to take an important first step towards breaking the link between mineral extraction and trade and the financing of armed groups, militias and wars. The creation of a responsible trade in minerals in the EU countries offers hope for improving the situation of the inhabitants in those regions from which these minerals are extracted. Therefore, it is important to flow information at different stages of the supply chain: from extraction to the final product. In my opinion, I have proposed commitments for the top of the chain, particularly refiners, smelters and importers, and due diligence for the bottom of the chain in line with OECD guidelines. It is necessary to take into account the situation of small and medium-sized enterprises, which often do not have sufficient resources. From the point of view of the Committee on Development, accompanying measures are very important to continue cooperation with developing countries. I welcome the fact that the Commission is allocating 20 million to accompanying actions, and I hope that it will present a draft of these actions shortly.

name: Daniel Caspary
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the I hope that, in all the deliberations that we will be making in the coming hours and days leading up to the vote, we will focus on the people in the conflict regions. We need regulation that helps the people on the ground quickly. We do not need regulation that never comes into force, which may please one or the other political activist in Europe better, but which will ultimately not reach the people. We need something that passes through Parliament and the Council quickly and arrives on the ground. Congratulations to the Commission for the comprehensive approach! I think it is important that you have once again attached importance, Commissioner, to the fact that it is not just a question of legislation alone, but also of the accompanying measures. In our Committee on External Trade, we have sharpened up a little bit and made certain areas binding, e.B. for melting. But I think we should also learn from the negative experiences of other states. I believe that the Dodd-Frank Act was not only positive for the people on the ground. The rapporteur and also the Commissioner have mentioned this: it is a de facto partial embargo against Congo. It has led to small mines being closed in some areas today, the employees there no longer having any income, us driving families into illegality, the increase in smuggling, the fact that we have new dependencies. And that is precisely what we do not want from our European legislation. We should also learn from the mistakes of others. That is why I would like us to adopt the legislation somewhat readjusted, as we decided today in the Committee on External Trade. I would be grateful if we could support them together. I call on the Council not to let the dossier fall asleep, but also to let it pass quickly. And I would like to send out an explicit signal of our group's willingness: if, contrary to expectations, nothing turns for the better on the ground in two or three years' time, then we are happy to talk about the next steps. But we should not now throw out the baby with the bathwater and deprive the local people of their livelihoods. Unfortunately, this is the opposite.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Malmström is right: this is an important occasion and we cannot squander it, we cannot squander it with a bluff from Parliament. You know perfectly well that there is, as my fellow Members know, a link between mineral extraction and the financing of armed militias, and this link must be broken because breaking it would mean cutting off the economic funding that feeds the guerrillas. Breaking this link would also help limit the odious violence against women and children who are used by warlords as slaves to work in mines. In order to do this, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we need compulsory traceability of minerals throughout the production and trade chain. We Socialists are not prepared to support a fetish regulation, a bluff, a buffet on the cheeks of the lords of death and major financial interests. In view of tomorrow's vote on the table, there is already a possible compromise solution which represents a balance between the different positions of the political groups and which also takes into account the legitimate needs of small and medium-sized enterprises and micro-enterprises. I therefore appeal to all my fellow Members, beyond all political colours, to ensure that the credibility of the whole Parliament is at stake. We are facing an important turning point with regard to Africa and other parts of the world: let us not waste this opportunity.

name: Emma McClarkin
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, tomorrow we have big decisions to make in order to stop the fuelling of conflict through the extraction of, and trade in, minerals and metals in conflict areas around the world. While we cannot agree on the form of the EU’s approach and which direction it should take, at least we can agree that this is a problem that must be overcome. Unfortunately, in my view, there is a real risk that by going in a certain direction we make matters worse for those on the ground. This is not what we want to do. While there are differences between the US Dodd-Frank Act and the mandatory measures being proposed by some groups, my concern is that the effects of a full mandatory approach will have similarly cumbersome requirements, particularly for the downstream supply chain. The response of many European companies, following the implementation of these requirements, will be to source elsewhere, creating de facto embargoes to the detriment of innocent miners and their families. Evidence from the Congo already points to this very problem. So my alternative proposals are clear. We have established that there is a pinch point in the supply chain where there is a very realistic opportunity to determine the source of the minerals. A political compromise in the committee vote led to a mandatory approach being taken for this critical part of the supply chain, and I am happy to support it. Whether we like it or not, further down the supply chain it becomes more and more unfeasible for companies to prove where minerals used in finished products have come from. This does not mean that attempts cannot in fact be made to find verification, and they are already being made through many industry schemes which we should recognise and also encourage. But as long as we adopt a strong review clause, which I believe we have done in our committee vote, it gives us the opportunity to assess the impact of our legislation and particularly to take into consideration the voluntary uptake for the scheme for downstream companies and the impact that it has really had on the ground. If changes need to be made at that point, then we will make them in full possession of the facts, rather than rushing into creating a top-down scheme that may do more harm than good. At this point we will see what works, what does not work, and what more needs to be done to eliminate the use of these minerals and metals to fund conflict worldwide. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I have one simple question: do you consider that the European Union, rather than, for example, the United Nations, is the best forum in which to deal with this matter?

name: Emma McClarkin (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – That is a very interesting question that you have posed to us. I am concerned that there are colleagues in this House that are more concerned about the Parliament’s credibility than they are about the livelihoods of these people and the condition of their lifestyle on the ground in conflict areas. Some people may want to vote for a mandatory scheme. They will sleep well at night and they will have a nice press release – not considering the full impact of what it is going to have on the ground. This is what we need to focus on if we are really to be credible parliamentarians here in the big European Parliament.

name: Marielle de Sarnez
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, we all have a common goal in this Chamber: we want to break the link between mining and armed conflict. And we have a wish: that our Parliament should come together as widely as possible around ambitious legislation, which can be applied, come into force and make a real difference in conflict zones. This legislation will therefore have to be supported by the Commission and the Council in the long run. For the European Parliament, traceability must be mandatory for all key players in the sector; that is the meaning of our vote in the INTA committee. If we continue to adopt this approach tomorrow, any importer of minerals, smelters or european refineries will now have to certify that their imported ores are clean, that they do not come from a conflict zone. At the same time, European SMEs will receive financial assistance to establish traceability of these minerals and then be granted a "conflict-free" label. We have an appointment clause and, after three years, we will be able to take stock of these regulations and assess very concretely what has or has not worked. The Commission will therefore be able - this is the meaning of the amendment I will table tomorrow - to increase the obligations, including that of informing, and we will also be able to increase the number of minerals affected by this legislation. This European legislation can then serve as a model to create positive momentum in other parts of the world. As my colleagues have said, we have lessons to learn from the Dodd-Frank Act. We know that, in fact, an embargo has taken place on the mines in southern Congo, and that this is not going in the right direction. I believe that our legislation and our approach can serve as a model and that at the international level of the United Nations, we will have to agree on the issue of natural resources, which belong to the planet, to the people of the countries and which therefore must be taken into account in a sustainable way. As you will have understood, Commissioner, we have an ambitious and proactive approach, but I hope that this approach will be implemented in order to make a real difference on the ground.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Let us once again see why we want to pass this law: people are becoming victims of conflicts that are fought over raw materials, or at least financed by the sale of raw materials. The profit chain of the perpetrators extends as far as the European Union. This regulation is intended to help bring transparency to the procurement channels of the manufacturing industry, thereby ending or at least making it more difficult to do business with war, rape and child labour. To this end, one, this law – Mrs Malmström, Mr Caspary, ladies and gentlemen – must be effective. Let us listen to Denis Mukwege, let us listen to many experts from the conflict regions, to church representatives, even to business circles! They all say that voluntary commitment by companies is not enough; there is an urgent need for a binding regulation for the entire supply chain. However, the draft of the INTA Committee, which was narrowly adopted by a majority, would require only 20 European smelters to cooperate. In other words, 80% of the raw materials for conflict sold from Congo alone would have no effect on this regulation, because the smelting takes place mainly in Asia. We can still make this regulation binding on the entire processing chain. Amendments to this are now again before the Plenary. It is time to finally make concrete work for the victims of the atrocities of the conflicts. And this is where the ring for the root cause of conflict, which we are all talking about, closes, in the face of refugee dramas in the Mediterranean and elsewhere. At least I want to be able to say – and this is not a populist statement, but a specific responsibility of Parliament – that the EP works to ensure that people are not forced to leave their homeland.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Wars are often about raw materials. They may not start because of it. They may start to have an ideological difference of opinion, but they often go on longer because of raw materials. Governments and rebels finance themselves and so you come to the chicken-or-egg question: is the raw material the cause of the war or is the war caused by the raw material? What is clear is that raw materials finance wars. If you take that away, and we've done that before, you take the funding away and you might stop the war. Think of what we've done with garden furniture. Hardhout is currently certified, not voluntary, but mandatory. Think of what we've done in the diamond trade. That's not a voluntary arrangement. That is a mandatory arrangement. We have seen in recent years that voluntary rules are never observed. European companies have been able to comply with oecd guidelines for the certification of conflict mineral products since 2011. They don't do it! The Commission's proposal, which is now on the table, voluntary self-certification, will therefore have the same flaws as all other voluntary systems. The Proposal of the Committee on International Trade limits it to only 20 European smelters and refineries and does not take the large quantities. You all have phones. You have it all in front of you, you work with it every day. There are no phones that are produced in Europe. They are all produced in China. These types of devices will not be covered by European legislation and that means that no consumer can ask: where do this stuff come from? And Chinese companies will not have to abide by our European rules. This is about war in Congo, about women being raped, about children working in mines. We can counter that. This is not about the German car industry and their problems with bureaucracy!

name: Tiziana Beghin
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this telephone is dirty with blood, this computer is dirty with blood, all the technology we use is dirty with blood and it is because the minerals we use in components and electronics are extracted in countries of war where, as we have said, they finance human rights abuses, killings and mutilation. We have worked to create a compulsory, responsible and effective system that allows us to know exactly which products are blood-stained and which are not. This is a system that does not weigh on small and medium-sized enterprises but obliges the electronics multinationals to come to terms with their responsibilities. This system is not a bureaucratic burden, it is a system that forces all of us to open our eyes. Ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow we will have an important vote: we will vote on a regulation and if we have the courage to do so in the right way, perhaps we will not save the world but, of course, we will help to make it a better place.

name: Steeve Briois (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this draft regulation sets out a laudable principle, that of not encouraging the financing of armed groups that participate in guerrilla and terrorist activities. However, it will result in unilateral sanctioning european companies importing minerals from conflict zones. Indeed, this new regulation will significantly increase their processing costs. And we can even anticipate a certain boomerang effect thus favouring the importation of processed goods from third countries containing disputed minerals from extraction in conflict zones.  The race to supply rare metals is underway. We must not be naïve and hope that any regulation will dry up the financing channels of armed groups. Apart from satisfying our good conscience, this draft regulation will not address any peacekeeping issues. Finally, before regulating in the name of morality, let the European Union first control the use of its funds in certain areas! I am thinking, in particular, of the diversion by the Polisario Front, a pro-independence militia, of funds allocated to humanitarian aid for the Tindouf camp in Western Sahara.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we need to break the link between minerals and conflict and thus we need a regulation that will be enforceable and adequate. We need mandatory certification for smelters and refiners and we also need to put pressure on smelters and refiners that are outside the EU. That is why in the Committee on Development we also included the importers in the mandatory certification. However, going beyond that could be counterproductive, because it will be a burden not only for EU industries, but also for industries in the developing world. That is what we need to bear in mind here. We cannot actually restrict access to the EU market for them, which could be a consequence of such extensive regulation. So excessive regulation could really harm the economies of the developing world and could actually cost jobs there. That should not be the aim of EU regulation. On the contrary, I think we need to focus on an enforceable and appropriate regulation that puts forward an obligatory certification for smelters and refiners and, as I said, also puts pressure on those who are the outside the EU – which is the majority – by including the importers in that obligatory system. In that way I think we will have an enforceable system that gives added value in the effort to break the link between minerals and conflict.   (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Dear Mr. Stier, thank you for accepting the blue card. You talked about the need to label products and spoke essentially about the need for traceability of the product. Do you agree with me that these wars can really be broken and by marking and monitoring the traceability of products and all ores and minerals, you know exactly what's going on in that market? Because if we know the traceability of oranges and bananas, I guess we can, then we can do these precious minerals.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear colleague, I really think it is possible to come to one compromise, that is what we have been working on. For example, in the Development Committee we have reached just such a compromise that has put emphasis on having a system that can establish this traceability, that it can simply have even those importers involved who will thus also have to certify their activities. However, my argument was that if we went beyond that, e.g. in the Development Committee it did not go with the mandatory system beyond that, it could be counterproductive. So we have to keep this system in mind, but we have to really break that link between minerals and conflicts.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Mr President, the question we must ask ourselves today is: why do the vast majority of people living in resource-rich areas continue to be deprived of the income necessary for their development but, above all, continue to be victims of horrific crimes, massacres, rapes of women and children? Ten years ago, in the context of the Mapping report on the Democratic Republic of Congo, the United Nations was already saying that the abundance of natural resources in the Democratic Republic of Congo and especially the lack of regulation and accountability in this sector had clearly contributed directly to widespread violations and that state or private companies, domestic or foreign, could bear a heavy responsibility for these crimes that were committed in the country. This situation is not limited to the Democratic Republic of Congo. Around the world, there is general talk of the curse of resources that enrich the North and impoverish the South.  It is to end this curse of resources that we call for transparent and responsible management of the trade of resources. In 2010, a step was taken with the passage of the Dodd-Frank Act in the United States. This law requires U.S. companies to provide detailed information about their supply to the sites. And, contrary to what my colleague, Mrs de Sarnez, says, this Dodd-Frank act has brought change to the countries of origin. Even if it took time, it led to changes. Under pressure, Europe is taking up this issue. In 2010 and 2011, the European Parliament voted in favour of transparency in the ore of conflict zones, in order to break the link between the savage exploitation of conflicts and conflicts. In 2013, the Commission proposes a regulation but, contrary to Parliament's ambition, this regulation is timid, if not unambitious, by its voluntary nature. Twenty years have already passed since the UN report, and we are still debating it today. Millions of deaths today are involved. Our group calls for an ambitious settlement immediately, which requires all companies using 3TGs throughout the european supply chain to submit to the duty of information.  This binding option for the entire supply chain is, as Dr. Mukwege says, the only political gesture capable of placing respect for human rights above the economic interest of some. It is a matter of our European credibility.

name: Marietje Schaake (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, it is essential that trade policies are a key element in broader EU foreign policy goals, such as conflict resolution, human rights and development. That is why we need effective measures to break the link between the world’s most terrible conflicts and the role the trade in minerals plays in them; a link that currently leads from war to our living rooms.  We must make a clear distinction between legitimate mining and trading in blood-stained minerals globally. For our Group, the Commission proposals – which were mostly voluntary measures – did not go far enough. We put forward amendments with mandatory schemes for smelters and refiners, which are the key players in this market and cover most of the global market. We also called for support mechanisms for small and medium-sized enterprises in their efforts to ensure due diligence and compliance, because consumers deserve transparency. Through a review, we ensure that adequate enough mechanisms are in place to make sure that we accomplished in practice what we hope to accomplish now with this regulation. There are important lessons to be learned from the past, such as from the Dodd-Frank Act which unintentionally led to Congo-free instead of conflict-free implications and hurt many people in their legitimate work and livelihoods. We should not hurt people with our good intentions. So meanwhile, while we focus on these important trade measures, let us look at the bigger picture too and keep an eye on all measures that are needed to end conflict all over the world, especially in the Great Lakes regions.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, 80% of companies do not control their supplies or reveal whether there are minerals from unstable areas in their products, where extraction fuels conflict and violence. Human rights violations, such as child labour, sexual violence and disappearances of people, are infamy common in the extractive industry. It is therefore necessary to have a strong regulation in this area, at the level of this Human Rights Champion Europe. A mandatory framework is needed for the entire supply chain, ensuring transparency and traceability of the product throughout the process and not only in the initial phase. This Parliament should therefore abandon hypocrisy and lack of coherence, because, without obligation for the entire supply chain, this initiative will only serve to cleanse the conscience of some of you, but not to tackle the problem at the root. We must also take responsibility for what our companies do in third countries, and to do so we need to act courageously and politically willingly. I hope that we will all support the amendments which call for traceability, which are fundamental to transparency and, moreover, so that consumers – people – can decide and know what they are consuming.

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner Malmström and many colleagues have pointed out the great damage caused by conflict minerals in the world and the extent to which human rights are being violated. The problem is that the legislative proposal, as it came from the Commission and as it came from the Committee on Trade, simply does not fit with this problem, with these serious violations of human rights. Because self-commitments do not help. Voluntary certifications are already possible, but only 12% of companies use this option at all. And those who do use it only because they want to export to the US market. We now finally need binding rules for all and for the entire supply chain. Only binding rules for all create equal competition. We make ourselves ridiculous when we say to the people on the ground: Yes, you have a hard time in your life. Yes, there are human rights violations. And what do we want to do about it? We rely on the voluntary nature of companies! I think we are a Parliament: we should legislate, not recommend action. There are a number of amendments to this, and I very much hope that a majority of colleagues will find themselves who support this, so that something can really change on the ground and so that we do not hope that at some point some companies will finally put human rights before profit. This has never worked before.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, it is of course utterly reprehensible that in conflict zones armed groups force innocent people to extract minerals. But let us not forget the role that the EU has played in creating the poverty, particularly in Africa, that engenders armed groups and makes illegal trading in metals so attractive in the first place. The EU is fully complicit – and I wish people would realise this – and the EU should stop its protectionist and destructive trade policies that impoverish the African continent and thus create the context in which the trade in conflict metals flourishes. Further, and predictably, the EU is behind the pace in cracking down on conflict minerals. The United States has already acted, and indeed the Dodd-Frank Act was passed and enacted in July 2010, four years ago. It is this US law that has already reduced funds to groups that thrive on conflict minerals by almost two thirds. I want to see an end to the exploitation and the use of conflict minerals, but the best way forward is a scheme, headed by the United Nations and working with individual African countries, not a scheme under EU control. The EU’s track record in Africa is wholly underwhelming.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are invited to discuss and decide on the proposal by the European Parliament and the Council to establish an EU system of self-certification for the supply chain of responsible importers of tin, tantalin and tungsten, as well as gold, coming from conflict and high-risk areas, where conflicts between state, para-state, terrorist and other groups are daily. Which company, whose purpose is profit, will admit that the minerals it imports have been mined in respect of the human rights of workers, that they have not been procured from organisations selling them for the purchase of arms and that the money received by these countries is intended for the development and well-being of their population. They will all self-certise that the minerals they import meet the standards set by the European Union. You forgot in the proposal to include the bloody diamonds and oil that the Islamic Caliphate sells at low prices in order to find willing customers and use the profits to equip terrorists. We are obliged to vote against the proposal because it is moving in the wrong direction.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is clear that we must recognise the great emotional burden that this issue places and that in some way affects confrontation. It is clear that we are all, without distinction, against armed groups, against the markets for death, against the introduction of materials or elements arising from this situation and these conflicts. But, at the same time, we have a great responsibility: we must take on the burden of evaluating, deepening and mediating against a new system and with regard to the effects that this new system must have. It is clear that we must seek the best solution. Perhaps, or rather certainly, it is not enough to identify only at source foundries and refineries; perhaps the number that has been identified is certainly not enough. We must go further, we must impose the obligatory requirement that, in relation to those who have to self-certify in the sector, then there should be a reference to that self-certification, so that there is legitimacy, transparency and truthfulness with regard to what the system must be. But I believe that the rapporteur, Mr Winkler, has worked in this direction, that he is working in this direction. I strongly support the action he has taken.  I believe that we must not stop talking at this time, in these minutes, because we have various obligations: above all, we have an obligation not to bring in products of death, but we also have an obligation to support a system, our small and medium-sized enterprises, which are already burdened, which are overburdened with taxes, which are overburdened with bureaucracy, which are overburdened with a system that would certainly not allow them to achieve the best possible conditions in order to be able to participate in a market that we recognize very much. often do not have very clear rules. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria Arena (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, I would like to ask Mr Cicu a question: do you think the United States has less attention for its companies than the Europeans? Do you think mandatory legislation in the United States was detrimental to U.S. companies? No. The legislation we are proposing today does not harm European companies. So what are your arguments about what the United States has done and what we need to do? Why does it take Europe 20 years to make a move when the United States is taking a year to make that arrangement? Give me an argument, Mr. Cicu.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: answer to a "blue card" question. Mr Arena, you should know better and more about what has happened in the United States. In the United States, after imposing compulsory self-certification, there has been the collapse of the system of small and medium-sized enterprises. In the United States they have had to further reform and review this system. So it is a problem that still exists and we cannot help but take it into account.  We are against merchants of death. We are against a reference that stems from these conflicts, but we are also in favour of our small and medium-sized enterprise, which needs to understand better and more how to proceed in its own system. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD)
text: "blue card" question. Mr Cicu, you referred to Dodd-Frank: do you agree with us that the system we have proposed is not a European Dodd-Frank? Could you explain to me how ( for a small and medium-sized enterprise, given that we have estimated and estimated that with the OECD guidelines – nothing we invented – the bureaucratic burden would be reduced to about 2 hours of work per year compared to a compulsory system, that if small and medium-sized enterprises wanted to adopt it would cost around EUR 13 500) how, with a compulsory system, we would protect small and medium-sized enterprises more. enterprises, in your opinion?

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: answer to a "blue card" question. I agree with you, Mr President. Beghin: I believe that we need to improve and we must help to improve, but I do not think that with positions that are, as it were, without the possibility of mediation and confrontation, we will be able to improve.  So the great truth is that you, like me, who live in the Italian reality, know that our small and medium-sized entrepreneurs, who are micro-entrepreneurs, have to queue long lines to pay their tax bulletins every day, they must realize the condition that they cannot have an accountant who supports their procedures, they have to carry out the failure and closure every day of their business life.  Today we simply want to try to understand what the best way to support mediation can be. We are not saying that there must be no proper protection of what then means avoiding armed conflicts and deaths, but at the same time we ask that there be self-certification .....  (The President cut the speaker off)

name: David Martin (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I think what Africa wants is not more bleeding hearts but actually some serious action. What we are hearing from the centre and the right of this House is, frankly, just more bleeding hearts. As Maria Arena rightly said, while for countries like Australia, Canada and Norway resources have been a great boon and have helped their economies enormously, for Africa resources have been a curse. Today, and tomorrow in the vote, we have a chance to turn that curse into a blessing. We can make an enormous contribution to stopping the exploitation of Africa’s miners and workers by local rebel groups on the one hand and, on the other hand to stopping their exploitation by unscrupulous European traders who do not know – or do not care – where the raw materials come from.  We need a mandatory due diligence scheme from the start to the end of the supply chain. In the world’s biggest market we have a duty to the people of Africa mining these minerals for our smart phones, and to our citizens in Europe who are asking for this change. Voluntary guidelines have been in place for years and 80% of European companies are ignoring these guidelines. Due diligence is not working. Anything short of a full mandatory scheme would be a failure and, frankly, a shame on this Parliament.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Martin! If I have just understood you correctly between the lines, then you are insinuating to our page in the House that we have no interest in the people on the ground. I reject that. It's all about the people! That is why I would like to ask you: share the recognition that we in the European Parliament adopted three regulations in the last parliamentary term, in which we in the European Parliament expressed very clearly what we wanted, but which then got stuck in the Council, because perhaps we wanted too much in some details, and that we should perhaps learn from this mistake and not repeat it. , what happened to the 'made-in' regulation, what happened to the IPI, the instrument for opening up the market in public procurement, and what happened to the regulation on the revision of trade defence instruments? We want to help people and not hide behind great decisions in Parliament that never come true.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Mr President, what we have heard from the other side is an attack on due diligence as if due diligence is something new that does not work and we have to look after our industry. But we have had due diligence in the food sector, we have had it in the financial sector, and we have had it in the timber sector. Due diligence does indeed work. What I find, what I pity, is that people on the other side of this House are trying to make excuses as to why due diligence would not work in this situation. I fear, even now, that they are more interested in looking after European interests than actually dealing with the problem in Africa.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE).
text: Mr President, Dr Mukwege, our Sakharov Prize, has urged us to introduce strict controls on the exploitation of the minerals that finance conflicts. I have to tell you, Commissioner, mr rapporteur, that what you are proposing is not at all consistent with this plea. He spoke at length about the dramatic collateral effects of our passivity and the false arguments of feasibility or bureaucracy that you mobilize to do nothing. Limiting the obligation to comply with the duty of care to smelters, refineries and importers of minerals and metals without the slightest duty of information for the 879,000 downstream companies - that is, 99% of the companies concerned - has more disadvantages than benefits for European companies. What for? Because, without any obligation, downstream companies will always have the choice of buying conflict minerals from other international operators not covered by the regulation, or even sourcing through the illegal trafficking channel. There is therefore a major economic reason - which some obviously do not want to understand - for European companies to impose at least a duty to inform all companies. That is the meaning of the amendment I tabled on the bill. It is enough for these companies to declare the identity of their direct suppliers, they are not asked for audits or reports. It is therefore a minimal constraint, without any bureaucratic overload, painless for SMEs. In doing so, a differentiated treatment is applied that provides much greater requirements for smelters, refineries and importers of minerals and metals, and a simple duty of information for others. Supporting this amendment would allow an overwhelming majority of Parliament to make substantial progress... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, there is an urgent need to use the weapons of human and environmental law in a trade that is most opaque and dirty in the world, based on the overexploitation of human beings and the underground and on the plundering of the wealth of parts of Africa, such as the Great Lakes, which are accompanied by criminal abuses against the populations that these traffickers encourage and finance. To suggest that those who plunder the African continent in this way will comply with a voluntary certification framework is at best naivety, at worst criminal complicity. There must therefore be a mandatory and binding mechanism, with ethical, social, moral and environmental standards. Human, quite simply. Otherwise, it is exploitation, a form of colonial domination, that will prevail. That is why we need to strengthen the text further in the sense of certification that is mandatory for all players in the production, supply and processing chain and which applies to all minerals.

name: Yannick Jadot (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, we were all there when Dr Mukwege recounted the horror of what was happening in his country, the horror of the consequences of blood ores. I think we've probably all had a tear. We were all outraged, but what have we become since then? We have a European Commission that is doing the minimum and we have a Parliament that is becoming cynical. We cannot, in the name of the instrumentalization of administrative measures, not combat the horror that prevails in a number of regions.  The due diligence system as it is built is precisely a system that must be applied to the entire supply chain, precisely to reduce costs, and precisely to ensure traceability. The due diligence system is precisely a system that focuses on the strongest, most involved, most of the responsibility.  So let's stop being cynical, act and let's not wait for tv reports to scandalize us and finally act. For once we can act to save people without companies bearing a high cost, let's do it!

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I have a few points to make. First of all, the scope of the regulation should stay untouched; we should not go beyond the fight for proposed minerals and metals. Secondly, I also support the proposed definitions of minerals and metals. As for the idea of certification, it must be ensured that the certification within each jurisdiction is recognised.  The lack of mutual recognition can lead to a double reporting obligation. I should emphasise that impositions on European companies covered by the regulation – excessive legal obligation – can lead to the loss of competitiveness in relation to businesses operating outside of the EU. Obviously, the main objective of the draft regulation is to reduce the financing of armed groups and to prevent the security forces from profiting from the exploitation of these minerals from high-risk areas. But the proposed measure to achieve this objective must support and further promote the responsible sourcing of these minerals, and we should exclude companies from financing the previously mentioned companies. This cannot, however, be done at the expense of the law-abiding European companies. We have to make sure that those who abide by the law are not affected in a negative sense.

name: Bernd Lange (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We live in a time of globalised value chains, and I think that from a value-based trade policy, we must ensure that these globalised value chains run fairly. This does not happen with voluntary action, as we have just seen in textile production. We need binding requirements for companies so that fair conditions also prevail. When I look at the fact that we are only claiming liability from 20 melts and refineries – and this is, incidentally, a correct approach, because that is the bottleneck – and not of the remaining 400, there is a glaring imbalance here. We need a clear commitment from production to melts to be sure that production is fair. Ladies and gentlemen, let us also be honest: we know that the Council always reduces Parliament's design power. That is why: no precipitous obedience, but a self-confident Parliament towards the Council, so that we can also achieve something!

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr There is a direct link between the minerals used in our mobile phones and the extreme sexual violence in eastern Congo. Denis Mukwege, who was mentioned earlier here, was awarded parliament's Sakharov Prize for Human Rights. Everyone then applauded his struggle to restore women's bodies and their dignity. But now that we have the opportunity to take a concrete political decision that can reduce these conflicts and rapes, then his recommendations for mandatory certification of minerals are ignored. A law on mandatory certification would mean that businesses and consumers do not help finance war and rape when we buy computers and mobile phones. I think everyone out there expects that from this Parliament. That's what we want.  The EU claims to be a peace project – yes, now it is up to the evidence. If you are serious, you cannot vote in favour of the bill that is now on the table. Sometimes you have to choose: the interests of big business or human rights and women's lives. My group and I choose human rights and women's lives. We need mandatory certification at all stages that apply to all minerals.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, we really need a regulation that has the entire supply chain covered, and it must be a mandatory code, because we know what happens when the voluntary code has already been in place in the EU since 2010. So this regulation would not change the current situation very much. It is often the case that it is good to start on a voluntary start and move towards binding legislation. Right now, we are in a situation where it is good to introduce legislation that is binding on all actors. In fact, contrary to what has been said here, such a mandatory system covering the entire production chain would make it easier for smaller companies, because then they could more easily demonstrate that their products meet these ethical sustainability standards, because the information in the whole chain would then be readily available. This would put European actors on the same footing as others. Ladies and gentlemen, how can we resist this? We should listen to the most progressive companies that talk about how much business opportunities are included in ethics and sustainability.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – I cannot support the POSITION of the INTA Committee. If I compare the increased administrative burden on those European mineral and metal processing enterprises with the suffering of millions of people, I have nothing to think about. Last Friday, 28 children died in Nigeria from poisoning from water contaminated with illegal gold mining. The children weren't even five years old. Five years ago, more than 400 children died in the same area as a result of lead poisoning. Certification should be compulsory and cover the entire supply network from mining companies to the final processor and should cover all raw materials. Yesterday we talked about financing development aid. Tomorrow we will be discussing refugees on the shores of Europe fleeing wars, violence and poverty. If we are unable to adopt truly effective legislation, we will unnecessarily boast that the European Union is the largest donor of development policy.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: "blue card" question. Mr Záborská, I liked your tear-jerking speech. I wanted to ask you what you will vote for and what your group will vote for, both on the text presented and on the amendments that will be tabled by colleagues on compulsory ity at all levels.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – I will certainly approach that vote responsibly. Negotiations are still ongoing and I will consider my vote on the basis of the results of these negotiations.

name: Seb Dance (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we need to recognise the fact that we are massively behind the curve on this. Both in the US and China they have recognised the need for mandatory schemes, and I applaud the fact that many on other sides of this House have changed their mind and have a firm view on this. But we need to be clear that it would be utterly ludicrous to subject just 19 or 20 European companies to this scheme, not least because the SMEs that we are talking about would be excluded from the additional public trust and confidence that this scheme would bring. The OECD due diligence guidelines are not onerous, and application throughout and across the supply chain would create a level playing field for all businesses and all companies. We do this for timber, we do this for diamonds. I do not believe that it is too much to ask us to do the same for these minerals.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The European Union now has the opportunity to take an important step towards breaking the link between the extraction of minerals and the financing of armed groups. Dr Denis Mukwege has reminded us of the tremendous importance of the export of conflict minerals for the people of his homeland. The proposal we are now discussing concerns, among other things, mandatory legislation for refineries and importers. Almost all minerals are purchased by companies in Europe and go through these very channels. Targeting those parts of the supply chain will therefore be an accurate measure that enables companies to act ethically right, while safeguarding jobs and growth. We in Parliament should take a tougher stance than the Commission, but at the same time allow for constructive negotiations with the Council, which in turn is a prerequisite for the important legislation on conflict minerals to become a reality.

name: Linda McAvan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I want to make it absolutely clear that what the Committee on Development supported is not what is on the table now from the Committee on International Trade (INTA). What is on the table now has been rejected by many people. You all have a letter here from over 140 Catholic bishops; you have seen the letter from Dr Mukwege; you have seen the letter from the NGOs: they are saying that the INTA proposals are not good enough. They should be rejected and replaced by the amendments. So do not delude yourselves, on the other side of the House, into thinking that you are doing what the people want in the DRC, in the Great Lakes, in the conflict zones. If you support the INTA Committee, you are doing what the business lobbyists want in this House. If we vote tomorrow along the lines of the INTA Committee, we will have a fig leaf of legislation which pretends to do something, but which actually achieves nothing at all. So I plead with you, do not listen to those who tell you that you are doing what the people in DRC want. They have been here, they have told us what they want: they want proper regulation throughout the supply chain. That is what we need to support.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, tomorrow Parliament is in danger of adopting a hypocritical text that does not protect those who suffer serious violence and exploitation for the trade in minerals from conflict zones.  Unfortunately, Madam President, what had to be done to ensure that this proposal became effective and coherent was not done. It was not done by those who armored a pharisaic text and it was not even done by those who, with the best intentions, failed to propose solutions that would have helped to achieve the final objective. More and better needed to be done by providing for a mandatory regulation with clear certification and traceability procedures for all those who import these raw materials into Europe, while limiting the impact on those downstream of the chain and avoiding unnecessary bureaucratic burdens on micro-enterprises. We need a legal framework that really helps to break the unacceptable link between trade in these resources and the financing of armed groups within the broader framework of a coherent cooperation policy.  There is still time to avoid writing a page that is not worthy of the history of this Parliament.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Mr President, as this Parliament’s rapporteur on corporate social responsibility, I view this legislation on conflict minerals as a test of Europe’s claim to be a leader on responsible business. It was disappointing that the Commission proposal was weaker than the equivalent Dodd-Frank Act in the United States, and it is right that Europe should at least match it. Europe says we support the UN Guiding Principles on business and human rights, but voluntary self-certification is not enough. Our amendments seek to broaden the scope, to end the anomaly that the law would cover blood gold but not blood diamonds, to include not just raw materials but products made out of them, to recognise that Europe is responsible for a quarter of this trade worldwide, but that this proposal covers only one in 2 000 of our companies affected. To the Christian Democrats, I would say that 70 bishops wrote a letter supporting our position, not yours, as does Christian Aid. You voted for a Sakharov Prize winner, and he asked you to vote for our position. Today, I hope you will use your conscience to vote with us. I have seen the victims of this evil trade in the Democratic Republic of Congo and in Colombia, and I am going to vote to end their suffering.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, our Sakharov Prize, Dr Mukwege, has already been mentioned in this debate. What does he tell us? It tells us about the need for ambitious regulation to break the link between minerals and conflicts. That was last year. Last month, with the resolution commemorating the dramatic collapse of The Rana Plaza in Bangladesh, we called for legally binding legislation on the duty of care, traceability and transparency of the entire supply chain, to improve working conditions, health and safety of workers. Tomorrow we will have the opportunity to bring our words and actions into line by adopting a text that will guarantee a fully responsible supply of the European market, with a real and positive impact on the ground. That is why I call in particular on our liberal and EPP colleagues to be consistent in voting on the amendments we have tabled, to make the European Union take the path towards greater protection of human rights and human beings, in accord with its principles and values.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D).
text: Mr President, since the beginning of this debate, we have all denounced the deeply inhumane nature of the mineral trade, but we cannot just denounce. What our African friends expect from us, in particular, is that we act, act concretely and empower ore importers.  However, the text of the Committee on International Trade is insufficient. That is why we are fighting to harden this text. We cannot be satisfied with a voluntary and only voluntary mechanism. More needs to be done, which is why there is a requirement to create a duty of care for all businesses throughout the supply chain, from extraction to marketing. Hence also the debate to open the scope of the regulation to other minerals because these questions will arise. Hence, of course, the need not to confine itself to the founders and refiners alone, but to go further.   I think this debate is more than symbolic. Europe's response must be up to the challenge. Others have done so, starting with the United States, as has already been said. We have a historical responsibility. Tomorrow, in the vote, let's seize it. Let us live up to the idea of the European Union that our partners are making.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – We are talking about a very pressing issue because we have heard that, on the one hand, people, women, young people, are taking advantage of the extraction of ore itself. On the other hand, the huge profits from this trade, in fact the only resur, that Africa has, also fall into the hands of criminal terrorist organisations. I therefore support the effort to make order in this area so that, as we have heard, Europe, which is also a major consumer of these raw materials, makes its contribution and makes it clear that it wants clarity and transparency in this area. We will ensure this transparency in such a way that the revenue from these ores will also come to the people of Africa. Yesterday we talked about development aid to Africa. And I think that if we regulate this area of raw materials trade today and tomorrow in the vote, we also take a major step in development aid to those who need development aid the most.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for once, we here have the opportunity to change something of that unjust world against which we have made a thousand pointless resolutions. Please do not waste it on oblivious ly or on a false fear of damaging the economy. The right way forward, including for businesses, is for responsible trade, it is to make it compulsory not only for foundries and refineries, which we have identified here as the weak link in the chain. And if they then let patience down, but we leave everything else intact. Mrs Malmström, I remember you ten years ago in this Parliament as a colleague who is always on the front line, fighting for human rights, for the protection of women and against all violence against children. Well, to your passion for human rights, I appeal for you to have more courage, more imagination on this dossier for which you have a direct responsibility. I find it difficult to recognise it behind those words of the integrated approach, the impact assessment, the review clause, the usual bureaucratic formulae that we always use to shield against non-choices and which are often just useless and empty, especially in the face of violence and the difficulty of this situation. We do not use a solution that is fresh water compared to problems. You are right, it depends on the change in local conditions, but those will certainly not change with voluntarism.  So, please, let's do something more effective. I say this to Parliament, to colleagues who are also sensitive to the appeals of NGOs, to bishops, to the appeals of their consciences, and I say this to you too, Commissioner, I expect more from you.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the world's conflicts and civil wars, and especially in Africa, are largely done in order for the warring parties to get their hands on the rich sources and raw materials of the region. That's why we're talking about bloody diamonds, that's why we're talking about a death trade. The legislative proposal we are debating does not prohibit the purchase of ores from war zones. Secondly, it promotes through the certification system the purchases of ores from war zones which it considers supposedly legitimate. We must act immediately and decisively here and now. We must impose a mandatory system. It should concern all natural resources and not the four ores. ISIS earns huge sums selling oil. Thirdly, it must concern all the companies involved. Fourthly, it must concern the whole chain of companies involved. Fifthly, it must also concern the conditions of extraction because there is a violation of human and labour rights in mining, there are no safety conditions, child labour is exploited. This is a decisive intervention by the European Parliament. Thanks.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, you have worked hard, Commissioner, on this proposal, but I would like to stress that the traceability of these products must be mandatory. This must be a global attitude, and I look forward to an ethical and coherent attitude from the Council and the European institutions to extend this movement around the world. There are lives at stake, children who need to change the shovel with which they dig in the mine for pencils and notebooks at school. Because the emotions we live here with Dr. Mukwege's allegations must become concrete and forceful facts.  And I call for public support, at the local, state and European levels, of the campaigns that many organisations carry out so that citizens, so that consumers demand to know, as they say in Basque, "zure mugikorrak ezkutatzen duena" ("what your mobile hides") so that we can expose and exclude from the market those who do business on the blood and pain of human beings.  Commissioner, you have spoken of a review clause if the voluntary system does not work. Why do we not anticipate the failure of the voluntary system by applying this obligation, thus giving the image that European citizens expect of us? Let's not miss this opportunity.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, in recent years the persistent global shortage of raw materials has become visible. Important mineral resources with limited distribution on a planetary scale are in supply deficit. And it is not by chance that some of the greatest reserves are in countries devastated by internal conflicts, interferences, permanent violations of their sovereignty and territorial integrity, almost always with the complicity of international organizations and foreign powers interested in maintaining control of resources. This is the case of the Great Lakes region. It is therefore important to discuss mechanisms for the certification of importers of minerals from conflict and high-risk areas, creating traceability mechanisms to identify raw materials originating in these areas. But these mechanisms have obvious limits that become even clearer when we look at this proposal for a regulation, a proposal that only covers a portion of the minerals marketed and does not go beyond the first link in the value chain, deliberately forgetting the myriad of final and intermediate products where these raw materials are incorporated. It is a perverse proposal that will solve nothing, and may also create new problems.

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. All of you were impressed last year when Dr Denis Mukwege, a doctor from the Democratic Republic of Congo, received the Sakharov Prize, the prize for trying to heal, physically and psychologically, with his team thousands of women who have been victims of mass rape in the brutal conflict over blood minerals in his homeland. Ten days ago, on Europe Day in the European Parliament in Brussels, he called on us to actually adopt a comprehensive law here. We are also committed to him and to the women of the Democratic Republic of Congo. We need a compulsory duty of care for all, not only for imports of raw materials, but also for all products, for the entire supply chain. Give yourself a jolt, all those who just want to agree to the Trade Committee! Say no to the fig leaf of legislation proposed by the Committee on Trade! Say 'yes' to all these amendments that we have tabled so that this law will make it really possible to protect women in the future from being victims of rape in these brutal wars over blood minerals.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, how many times have we been moved to see the pictures on television of the wars in Africa, how many times have we talked about blood diamonds, how many times have we talked about bloody raw materials!  Tomorrow we will be in this Parliament to vote on this issue, and we will probably do so hypocritically, at least a part of this Parliament will do so on the grounds of absurd excuses. Because when I hear 'burdens on small and medium-sized enterprises', which are non-existent burdens, when I hear about micro-enterprises, which are excluded from the proposals that have been made, it means that we are finding absurd excuses, which want to continue to justify blood and death. I believe that tomorrow's vote is an historic vote, one of those votes that are recorded, so it is a call to the conscience of each of you. Tomorrow we decide whether we want to turn the page and seriously combat a problem that has been under discussion for ten years or whether we want to continue with this hypocritical attitude.  Well, I hope that tomorrow we will take seriously the words of Dr Mukwege – to whom we awarded the Sakharov Prize – who came to say, last week in the European Parliament, that this proposal is an insufficient proposal and that what is coming out of the INTA Committee is not good enough to be able to deal with a problem of this size. Tomorrow we have this possibility, ladies and gentlemen: let us be consistent and not just move in front of the television.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the House very much for this important debate. Parliament has today, as over the last year, contributed greatly to raising awareness of this very important issue. That awareness and that public pressure has also made many of the global mineral supply chains increasingly aware of the need to set due diligence standards as part of their corporate social responsibility. This debate shows that we all share the same goals. We need to break the link between conflict trade minerals and the terrible violence that we have all witnessed, which affects so many children, women and men. We need to promote transparent, responsible mineral supply chains so that we can keep the money out of the hands of rebel groups; so that we can ensure that the revenue from this trade is available for good governance, for health, for schools and for other vital public services; and so that we can encourage economic growth that provides conflict-affected areas with hope for a better future. In the Commission proposal we do address the upstream part of the supply chains, and with the accompanying measures we have set aside EUR 20 million: this money is to improve the conditions on the ground but also to help companies – especially small and medium-size companies – to be able to do the checks, the audits and the traceability because that is not easy today. We should not fool ourselves. It is not easy even for the best meaning company to be fully sure of where all its supplies come from. So this is to support them in doing this.  We also create an EU list of due diligence for the downstream companies with a possibility to name and shame, and I am quite confident – and this has strengthened in me after this debate – that most, if not all, companies will be on that list. If this is not effective there is a review clause to push further. I think there has been a lot of work going on in this Parliament and I would like to pay tribute to the work in the Committee on International Trade and others to improve the Commission proposal, to make it even stronger, to make a proposal that we can be proud of here in the European Union and so that we can also achieve our goals while learning from some of the experiences in the past. The Commission will certainly look forward to working with Parliament on this in the future.

name: Iuliu Winkler
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, there is a very important consensus across this Chamber and it is that of supporting the best interests of the people and of the local communities in conflict areas. Their interest is in stopping mineral extraction from financing conflict, but their interest is also in the enforcement of law-abiding and transparent industry and trade to be the basis of sustainable local development.  The interests of people and communities caught in war and conflict cannot be served by an EU regulation alone; that is why we need an EU integrated approach. Whether something is right or wrong, good or bad, cannot be reduced to mere permissibility under a regulation. What we need is to develop a culture of responsibility and to educate all the stakeholders. We need individual responsibility when engaging stakeholders; we need to distinguish clearly between experts and activists.  While the taking—over of best practice is a good thing, to take over a failed practice, namely the mandatory Dodd-Frank Act, is a bad idea. Unilateral action provokes unilateral response, de facto embargoes produce de facto prohibitions, and prohibitions have never worked, as we know very well.  We have on the table the proposal from the Committee on International Trade (INTA). That is an effective and workable proposal; it has been carved out with responsibility. The INTA proposal is capable of being the strong fundament of the EU’s integrated approach to breaking the link between minerals and conflict, so please support this proposal tomorrow.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 20 May 2015, at 12.00 p.m. Written Declarations (Rule 162)

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. At this last plenary session, the important dossier concerning the proposal for a regulation on the establishment of a European system of self-certification for importers of certain minerals or metals originating in conflict and high-risk areas, so-called conflict minerals, was discussed and voted on.
