The debate and subsequent vote focused mainly on a particular point that proved controversial: extending traceability obligations (self-certification) not only to foundries, refineries and importers of certain minerals, but also to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) that are part of the supply chain. This has been considered by many to be essential in order to make effective the traceability obligations imposed on the main players in the supply chain, which would otherwise be easily circumvented. A company would have every interest, and the real possibility, of accessing the most advantageous black market if it were to act on a voluntary basis in declaring and guaranteeing the origin of the minerals. The debate was very heated and emotional and some, hiding behind a phantom administrative burden for SMEs, wanted to oppose the traceability obligation for SMEs as well. Fortunately, and thanks also to the work of the 5-star Movement, the result of the vote was positive, avoiding such absurdity.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament must vote on a regulation to establish a self-certification mechanism for tantalum, tin, tungsten and gold importing companies. It is known that the trade in these minerals causes serious conflicts for the control of their farms and causes considerable environmental damage. If the intention is laudable, the Socialist Group wants this self-certification mechanism to be mandatory and applies to all companies present throughout the supply chain. As Parliament's position adopted in the Committee on International Trade is currently set, only 5% of companies in this sector would be subject to this verification mechanism, namely refineries and smelters. Right-wing and far-right parties are taking refuge behind spurious arguments for refusing to extend the scope to all businesses. Traceability cannot be effective, both in terms of economic information and transparency due to citizens. If Europe is to dry up the sources of financing for armed groups and to help people in sub-Saharan Africa forced to flee their war-fighting countries, Parliament must ensure the traceability of information related to the trade in conflict minerals.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. – We all know that not making a decision is the worst decision. That is why I believe that we should vote for the regulation in question. We must be careful how we ensure the safety of the use of ores, at the same time we must calculate the impact on SMEs. In order to do this we need to take into account the frequency of certificates, audits and ex-post verification. If it is found that the administrative burdens and costs will be very high, we need to see how we support SMEs. If the impact is found to be very high, I believe that a declaration of conformity on their own responsibility may also be enough if importers from each Member State will source exclusively from compulsory certified sources. At the same time, we cannot compare SME losses with people's lives. I agree with the establishment of the single competent authority at EU level for the establishment of uniform procedures. If, however, it is found that we need to extend the scope throughout the chain, then we can request a review.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – Many constituents have been in touch, asking this Parliament to vote for a strong EU law to break the link between mineral extraction and the financing of armed groups in areas of conflict. Profits from so-called ‘conflict minerals’ are being used to fuel further violence and killing. The Commission proposal seeks to combat this outrage with a voluntary scheme, but this has been tried and failed in the past. I call upon colleagues to vote for a mandatory scheme, similar to that already adopted in the United States. To be effective, the law must ensure full coverage of the supply chain. This approach would give accountability and binding regulation on everything from mine to consumer – whether it be the process of extracting the minerals, or the manufacture of the smartphones or laptops that they end up in. It is essential that companies in the supply chain are covered, so that we can be sure that the goods we all use as consumers are included. I urge my fellow MEPs to vote for an effective law, and I hope that such an approach can be agreed on by the Member State government ministers, with the Parliament and Commission, so it can be put into practice.

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – Conflict minerals are so-named because they are sourced in opaque or illegal practices in unstable areas of the world. For example, in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold are sourced in conditions of extreme exploitation, violence and slavery.  According to the International Peace Information Service, armed groups are present at more than half of all mining sites in the DRC, where the local population is coerced into working in the mines and controlled by rape and violence. These minerals are present in our phones, our cars, even our food cupboards. We are complicit in modern—day slavery unless we take action now.  A voluntary scheme of self-certification will not work. The EU can be a powerful force in using soft power and trade to improve the lives of the most vulnerable, and we cannot pretend a voluntary system is enough. The upcoming vote can and should strengthen existing laws and I urge my fellow MEPs to be part of that force. Binding rules for firms involved in the production and trade of minerals are crucial for keeping conflict minerals out of Europe. This is our contribution to the fight against modern—day slavery.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. – The proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council covers crucial aspects of security and peace in the world. The extraction of natural minerals, especially in conflict-affected countries in the so-called third world, can lead to controversy. History shows that the exploitation of rare fossils is often linked to conflicts, including the use of force. Therefore, this regulation, which attempts to break the link between the illegal exploitation of minerals and international disputes, deserves to be examined again. The main objective of our legislation on this issue must be to foster peace and stability in the world's highest risk areas. In this context, a project establishing an EU certification system for importers who wish to develop responsible imports of rare metals into the European Union is of positive importance. This means requiring compliance with specific standards in international relations in line with the OECD recommendations. However, the recommendations unequivocally refer to the obligation to ensure careful security in the mineral supply chain from conflict-affected areas in order to eliminate any potential risk of human rights violations. That is what we are seeing today. When creating new international legislation, we must recognise the OECD references as one of the most important. Support is ed by the Commission's proposal, the so-called 'don't harm' principle. The Union must take leadership in this area in order to have a more effective impact on the peaceful way of resolving conflicts.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the decision taken on the digital single market.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this opportunity to present the Digital Single Market strategy to you today. It is the fruit of six months of constructive work within the Commission and with all of you in the European Parliament. During this time I had many contacts with various parliamentary committees. They expressed their support for building a Digital Single Market for Europe. We all recognise its importance and the benefits that it will bring for people and business, for creating economic growth and employment. Our strategy has a clear timetable, with 16 ambitious initiatives based around three interlinked policy pillars: better access for consumers and businesses to digital goods and services across Europe; and high—quality infrastructure that works smoothly across Europe. We also need to create the right and fair conditions in the underlying environment, preparing for the future to maximise the growth potential of the digital economy. I will highlight a few initiatives under each pillar. An urgent first task is to secure and guarantee free movement of goods and services in a unified digital space and to improve online access generally. The Digital Single Market aims to boost cross-border e-commerce by encouraging SMEs to sell across borders.  One of our first initiatives will be to bring rules for online purchases more into line across the European Union. People could save EUR 11.7 billion per year if they could choose from a full range of EU goods and services when they shop online. The Digital Single Market is also about modernising today’s copyright system. We want to improve people’s access to cultural content online while opening new opportunities for creators and the content industry. This will also promote cultural diversity.  We will present legislative proposals before the end of 2015 to reduce the differences between national copyright regimes and allow for wider online access to works across the European Union. Then, under its second pillar, the strategy will look to improve conditions for digital networks and services to underpin the Digital Single Market. The Commission will propose an ambitious reform of EU telecoms rules. This will include more effective spectrum coordination. It will also tackle regulatory differences around EU national markets and create better incentives for investments in high-speed broadband. The Commission will also conduct a comprehensive analysis of the role of online platforms. It will focus on transparency, liability and equal conditions for competition. Lastly, we will build a solid foundation for long-term growth. Europe needs to take full advantage of the digital economy where data is becoming all-important and where people have the skills needed to fill new jobs. They must also have trust and confidence when they go online. Common standards and interoperability are essential to make the best of fast-growing sectors such as cloud computing, and the Internet of Things. We also need them in the context of promoting e—government services around Europe and a more inclusive e-society. Together, these initiatives form a realistic roadmap for us to work together over the next four and a half years. They will prepare Europe for a bright digital future. They will help people and companies to get the best from the online world. I want Europeans to have better protection when buying online, lower cost for deliveries, more choice and better access to content, goods and services from other EU countries. With the Digital Single Market strategy, the Commission is looking at opportunities that our citizens could enjoy to help us create a vibrant, creative digital economy and society in Europe. For businesses, the Commission will focus on bringing opportunities for them to create new innovative products for a single market of 500 million people, not 28 splintered national markets. European companies and industries must be at the forefront of the digital revolution using the Digital Single Market to scale up, not to move out. We need equal conditions for all to compete openly and fairly in this digital market. Every company, large or small, plays by the same rules: no discrimination, no favouritism.  I do not have enough time now to go into the details of each initiative that we are planning. However, one thing I do want to say is that they must be taken together as a coordinated and balanced package. If we only succeed in putting half of them into effect, then we will not end up with a true Digital Single Market. I look forward now to your comments and views. Thank you very much for your attention.

name: Françoise Grossetête
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, thank you to our Vice-President for the presentation of this long-awaited digital single market strategy. We must be aware that we are experiencing a new industrial revolution of considerable magnitude because everything will be digital. Indeed, digital technology will irrigate the entire economy, industry, trade, education, health, but also land use planning or the way of living together. It must therefore be given great importance, without wasting time.  The development of the digital single market will indeed create growth for all our countries and also contribute to reducing inequalities between citizens, provided that the widest possible access to the internet is available, wherever we are in Europe.  This sector is changing fast, no one will wait for us. Either Europe is on the bandwagon or we will be doomed to become a mere digital colony, and this is not desirable either for our companies, who want to be able to invest in trust, or for our fellow citizens, who also expect Europe to better protect their data and real cybersecurity. I would like to make three points. First of all, digital is creation. Europe must be digital creator and not just a consumer, that is, as you said, Mr Vice-President, that it must support the authors' markets and guarantee copyright. It is therefore necessary to intelligently anticipate future innovations. Then the training. The digital skills of students and employees must be increased while supporting digital entrepreneurship and start-ups. It is essential that this strategy takes into account what has already been done on this issue of training, which was one of the seven objectives of the European digital agenda. Finally, the networks. The observation is made by you, the European Commission: we must create this framework for private investment in networks. This is essential because we must have as much ambition as possible for this digital single market.

name: Marju Lauristin
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, firstly, on behalf of the Socialists and Democrats I would like to congratulate Vice—President Ansip and his team for the work done, but it is only the beginning. It is not all about the digital single market; it is the digital society in Europe that we are talking about today. The Socialists and Democrats support strongly this development because it is a way for growth. It is a way for new jobs, for quality jobs. The impact of the digital single market on the labour market is at the core of our interest and our concern, because we know very well that there are huge opportunities, but also huge risks. It is not only about consumption, it is about the digitalisation of the traditional industries and creating new services, which means there is also a need for creation of new skills. We know that there is a shortage of skilled labour in this area. At the same time, there are a lot of people who will lose their jobs and will need retraining. So we hope that the Commission will bring us not only the legislation needed for new services and new technologies, but also ways to invest in education, in retraining and in the development of human resources. When we look at the digital scoreboard, then huge inequalities between regions are there; between different social groups, in terms of access as well as skills. So the Socialists and Democrats are very much concerned to ensure that these inequalities do not grow, but will be covered in our new developments. We call on the Commission to make new efforts for new legislation, as well as for new research in this area. All of these impacts – the social impact and the impact on the labour market – need deep assessment so that we will be conscious and will not have unexpected negative risks. We hope that we will go all together; we saw last night and see today that the Parliament is unanimous in supporting the development. We have to be optimistic and enthusiastic, but we also have to be knowledgeable and conscious of all the risks it brings.

name: Vicky Ford
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, unlocking the benefits of the Digital Economy is key to driving competitiveness, jobs and growth. The single market is meant to make it easy to trade across 28 countries, and it must be fit for purpose in the digital age. The Commission strategy is good in parts, but needs more work in others. We need to focus on practical solutions to break down barriers to trade, to remove unnecessary red tape and to encourage investment. We must make it easier, not harder, for innovation to flourish, and be mindful that the digital market is a global market. Building a fortress around Europe will not work.  We should listen to what users are asking for. Businesses want it to be easy to set up and sell on line to 500 million consumers with lower costs and simple secure systems so that they get paid. Consumers want to be able to trust that their purchases will arrive and that faulty goods can be returned, replaced or refunded. Platforms in the shared economy are growing because businesses and consumers want to use them, and people do want to be able to shop wherever they are and take their films, books and music with them when they travel. But enabling portability must not create a back door for piracy. Creators do need to know that their work, their copyright, has value and can be enforced. Security is key, especially for parents who want to know that their children are safe online.  Researchers want to unlock the benefits of big data – huge benefits for medicine, for the environment, for the economy – but individuals also want to know that their data is safe. Then there is the call for more modern manufacturing and more modern infrastructure. In all of this, investors in enterprises want legal clarity and the certainty of a level playing field. The digital economy must be fair, transparent and open. In Europe, sometimes our grand plans do stall, and many times small steps reach a destination faster. Top-down legislation, heavy-handed bans and centralised controls – we know how these can put a handbrake on innovation and investment. So let us make sure our actions are targeted and be wary of unintended consequences. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mrs Ford, you mentioned the strategy of the Commission, but do you not think that the Commission could do more for the implementation of the digital single market? The strategy, in my opinion, is weak on maximising the growth potential of digital.

name: Vicky Ford (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – The strategy is good in parts, and we must unlock the benefits, but as in all areas of European legislation, it is pointless just passing laws in this House if they do not work on the ground and if they cannot be enforced back in the Member States. We need to focus on unlocking growth, and that means also removing unnecessary legislation where we do not need it. So let us be targeted in our actions.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the Digital Single Market strategy is a good text, it is an ambitious text, but it could have been even better. It seems that it is already a compromise text in some parts and has been weakened a little bit since your previous statements, Commissioner. The action plan includes far more reviews and initiatives than new legislative proposals and new ideas, such as making privacy by design into EU law, or finally introducing a single EU telecoms operator.  It should do even more to create a level playing field for all European businesses, especially SMEs, which are limited by the Amazons and eBays of the world and have to pay a lot to sell beyond our national borders. That said, the ALDE Group welcomes it and also welcomes the action plan. It does include many items that are vital to us – removing geo—blocking, reforming the parcel delivery system in Europe and supporting 24-hour e—government. But we call on the Commission to deliver on everything in the action plan and to do so quickly. Speed is of the essence. Any delays will only give time for the Member States to come up with excuses to block this strategy. Any delays will only push us further behind the US and others. Any delays will only further harm our attempts to build trust among businesses and consumers in the Digital Single Market. My Group has a slogan: ‘Think digital by default’. I am glad that the Commission has now started to do just that. The strategy is a good opening act, but let it not be the final one.

name: Dennis de Jong
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – There will be many more opportunities to speak to the Commissioner about the individual proposals and we will be happy to do so. From my group, we will pay particular attention to the interests of SMEs and the interests of SMEs. Today in this plenary debate, I would like to give you more general considerations. Then I look back at the first time I was on the Internet myself. That was a whole new world, it was an open world and a free port. I could connect with people elsewhere in the world. I could also create my own website. I could be creative on the Internet myself. Now we are 20 years on. When I look at what is happening now, we see governments on the one hand, intelligence agencies that want to know a lot about us and who don't want that internet so freely anymore. We also see large companies. We know the Commission that Google is taking on. But we also have companies like Amazon, Facebook. It is increasingly becoming the internet of the multinationals. I hear - and I agree - that innovation is of great importance to the European economy. And that includes the Internet. But then the Internet must remain the place for creativity and innovation, and this can only be done if the Internet is free and open. I respect the Commission's action against Google. But keep going, take on the other multinationals and make sure that the Internet remains open for small businesses, for innovation and for people, so that we can get creative with each other.

name: Michel Reimon
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for his work The strategy presented is a one-way move in many areas. But I do not have a very important aspect: better access for consumers to goods and services has been presented – not a word about democracy, not a word about access to knowledge and opinions. That is why we should be concerned first and foremost with a digital strategy and with the Internet! The World Wide Web was developed in Europe, and it was a marketplace, if you like, an exchange place, for opinions and knowledge, and not just a commercial place. That is the direction in which it should go. The development of a free infrastructure should be particularly important to us. What has been presented, for example in the area of geoblocking and copyright, is going in the wrong direction. As a Parliament, we must be the first to work hard to ensure that all citizens throughout Europe have access to all news, knowledge and opinions. We have to be more offensive! I do not know how a digital single market will take place without a telecommunications market, without net neutrality. If the negotiations stall, that is certainly not a good example, it is not a good symbol for the future.

name: David Borrelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our objective in achieving a digital single market must be to enable citizens and businesses to benefit fully from it. The opportunities for the European Union are immense and the consistent removal of the many barriers that still exist could prove to be a real driving force for innovation and investment in the digital economy. We therefore welcome an inclusive multiannual strategy and welcome the three pillars, but be ware of the timetable for implementing and implementing the measures outlined in the package. In this area, in fact, even more than in others, it is essential that the legislative process is in step with the times. And if, to date, only 7% of Europe's small and medium-sized enterprises sell beyond the borders of their own country and only 15% of consumers buy online in a country other than their own, it is clear that there is a long way to go.  Developing the potential of e-commerce represents a new frontier for European businesses and the effects for consumers will be tangible: lower prices, wider choice and a higher quality of goods and services. It is necessary to simplify and clarify transactions between the different Member States: all too often, in fact, entrepreneurs and consumers give up because of certain complexities. And this is just one of the things that we can work on together to make sure that industries and citizens make full use of the potential of new digital services and goods. Building an environment conducive to the creation of new jobs and the revival of the European economy today also involves breaking down the barriers that limit the digital market on our continent. The next important step is now the European Council of 25 and 26 June, because we all know that in order for this to happen, the Member States must play their part by investing in ICT and digital services. An example? Italy invested only 4.9% of its gross domestic product in 2014. More can and must be done.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI).
text: Mr President, transforming European society is the arrogant conclusion of the Commission perched very high, far from the concrete realities of our compatriots. In the text, I have noted almost fifty times the preferred language element of our Commissioners-designate: national barriers. Not holding their legitimacy from any people, it is obviously difficult for them not to despise the nations.  I also noted the inconsistency of your numbers. Just one example: in the Commission's communication, you announce an additional EUR 415 billion for the GDP of the European Union, whereas in your bible, which is the study on the cost of non-Europe, you announced 520 billion euros in gain.  One hundred billion difference between the two texts. Where did they go? Are you becoming realistic? In conclusion, you want to transform European society by breaking national borders, whether material or immaterial, for that matter. This is your real enemy: the nation. Your chimerical project can't find an echo anywhere. While we recognize the importance of the digital market and the economic potential it represents, it should never be believed to promise the moon.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Commissioner, i would like to begin by thanking the On the one hand, it may seem to us that the borders of the European Union are slowly disappearing. We can move freely across borders, including work in other Member States. In many countries we use the single currency, the euro. Our companies can do business across borders without paying customs tariffs for a long time, and so on. We can even use our mobile phones virtually anywhere in the world without limitation.  However, there is one area where we do not have the apparent disappearing of its boundaries, and that is precisely the digital area. Why? Because we're totally shattered there. For example, I have a subscription to internet television in Latvia, which I can watch anywhere in Latvia, but as soon as I crossed the state border, I no longer have access to this service. Why? Why is it that, for example, when buying a ticket for a ferry between Estonia and Finland, the price for the same service varies depending on whether you enter from an Estonian website or from a Finnish website? What the European Commission is offering is to create a single digital market so that we can cross the boundaries of this divide, because of course, if we are – and we are – 500 million citizens in Europe, we can benefit and force our competitiveness if we are really united in this important area as well. Thanks for the attention!

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: – The digital economy is growing just seven times faster than our ordinary economy and could therefore really be a lever to ensure that we create quality jobs and really prepare our society for digitisation. Unfortunately, and we know this, Europe is not doing a good job on this point. We are limping behind some very other important players in the world. There's some good news, but also some less good news today. The good news is that you are coming up with an initiative on the digital single market, which is good and important. We support that. Your analysis and your problem sketch are correct, but we expect a little more action. We really want to invest in infrastructure that provides access to everyone. We want our society to be prepared for e-commerce and e-governance, but above all also for people's privacy to be respected and thus to become a process that benefits every citizen in Europe. We want to see a little more action for this.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR).
text: – Last week we finally got an insight into the long-awaited plan for a more digital Europe proposed by Commissioner Ansip. From the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, we can see - and we have heard many testimonies in our committee - that there is indeed still a great deal of work to be done to create this internal digital market.  We see that there are still far too many barriers that make it difficult, or sometimes impossible, for consumers and producers to take advantage of the many digital opportunities that exist. I am thinking, for example, of a Netflix subscription. Someone who buys a Netflix subscription in Belgium cannot yet benefit from this in all Member States, which is a pity and surpassed today. We also see that many companies still face a great deal of administrative and financial burden, because they often have to abide by the consumer rights of the 28 different Member States. These thresholds must therefore be removed as soon as possible. Your plan contains broad objectives and does want to address some of these thresholds, but In my opinion the plan is far too broad and lacks concrete action points. I fear that this will lead us to pursue the facts on important points. It is important to engage in constant dialogue with stakeholders throughout the process, because they are ultimately the ones who know best where the problems lie. Finally, I believe that the biggest challenge will be to guarantee consumer rights without, however, affecting the competitiveness of our companies.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, we are very fortunate to have such a bright Commissioner in a very important post in an area that is going to be the future of Europe. However, Commissioner, let us be very pro-active and not reactive. For example, Uber is a great service from America and there are now so many fighting back against it, so many states – including the big country that we are in right now – fighting this company that allows young people to work and make a fair living by working hard. That is what applications and the Digital Single Market will achieve for Europe: letting young people work and be rated by what they do. People can order their services, so let us be proactive, let us allow young people to earn a fair living – and ‘fair’ is whatever they are worth. Whatever work they do, however good they are. That is what being fair is – it is not what states tell you ʽfairʼ is, or the red tape and the bureaucracy that we propose. Let the digital single market be a revolution. Good luck to you, Commissioner. We support you. Let us all work and focus.

name: Cornelia Ernst (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the What we want, of course, are fair rules, for the movement of goods and services on the one hand and for citizens in the digital single market on the other. But the art of fugue is how the balance is shaped, to what extent it exists between market development and citizens whose free access is guaranteed, to what extent net neutrality is secured. That is the question! And we think there are two things that need to be repackaged. The first is to create a copyright reform worthy of the name. To this end, the catalogue of restrictions must be opened up and made binding in order to actually remove the patchwork of exceptions and restrictions in the European Union. This is the only way to achieve a truly meaningful harmonisation of copyright and not by following the money. However, there is no such consequence in the paper. And the second idea is that geo-blocking should only be abolished in unjustified cases. We say that geo-blocking must be abolished in general, because it is fundamentally unjustified because it prevents Internet users from having cross-border access to cultural content everywhere. We want clarity here. We do not see that in the paper at the moment, and there is still a great deal to be done in this respect.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Vice—President for his proposals. I think this is a very good step forward. It is not the first step, by the way, to creating the Digital Single Market, and I would like to bring our attention to the fact that, to create the Digital Single Market, we need to pass legislative acts. That is what we need to do, and therefore the Council – which I cannot see here – is an important partner to work with to create this Digital Single Market. What I can see at the moment is that, on the Telecoms Single Market, on the Network and Information Security Directive and on the Data Protection Regulation – all three of which are fundaments for building the next step of the digital single market – the Council is not coming along with general approaches, with positions, which are negotiable for us as a Parliament. So I think that we need to insist first of all on the adoption of these legislative acts and then proceed with further measures. I think that you have made some good points, but there needs to be clear legislation, concrete formulations, about what you mean – for example – on platform neutrality and on geo-blocking; that is not enough, please try to improve the concreteness of these proposals.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD).
text: – The EU’s arrogant disregard for small businesses is staggering, and that arrogance has a disproportionate impact on the UK.  The UK is now the EU’s second largest economy, largely because of the growth of small businesses. In the UK we have a VAT threshold for small businesses, including digital ones, so that they are not suffocated by VAT regulations. The EU’s obsession with harmonising tax has led it to force the UK to abandon VAT thresholds for some online businesses. Not content with burdening business with complicated rules, the online disclosure requirements are impossible for small businesses to comply with. The EU has now given small businesses outside the EU a competitive advantage over UK businesses. It is imperative that the UK regain that competitive edge. The UK should freely trade with the EU, but should not be a vassal state of this institution.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI).
text: Mr President, the European Union therefore has a great ambition: to establish a digital single market. If we want to remain powerful players in the world of tomorrow, we must not be content, as you do, to give priority to online consumers. We must also promote and encourage the development of our producers, a task that is otherwise more delicate but totally neglected.  We also know that fraudsters in the digital world will use the most fragile and least structured countries to develop fraudulent activities from these countries to all other countries in the European Union. Non-payment of VAT in internet commerce is already a scourge. This includes the classification of samples or the allocation of IP numbers located abroad via applications. There is an urgent need for action before tax revenues truly collapse. Finally, forcing France to raise VAT on the digital book from 5.5% to 20% is scandalous. This measure imposed on the forceps by Brussels in order to make the single digital market possible already shows the deviation of this project. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Dear Mrs. Le Pen, thank you for accepting the blue card. I wanted to ask a gentleman from the EFDD something similar, because there is often talk of the United Kingdom and France.  You mentioned, in this case, quite specifically the manufacturers that need to be protected, not just consumers. You often speak out against the uniqueness of the European Union, so I ask you if you agree with me that this case of the Digital Single Market is something that will help French manufacturers of premium products very well and in this way small French manufacturers will be able to be present on the world market through digital market and trade?

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, sir, you have sold us this in all the areas that the European Union has affected and, in all of these areas, unemployment has been the consequence, but also the despair, the deindustrialisation and the collapse of our power. Look what happened. I gave the typical example of the digital book: the digital book had a VAT of 5.5%, it rises to 20% precisely to obey the injunctions of Brussels. You can see that it is not such a measure that will help anyone, quite the contrary.

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I too, of course, welcome the fact that the Commission has finally decided to present a horizontally agreed approach for the development of this Digital Single Market. But even when Jean-Claude Juncker promised during the election campaign that the digital single market should be one of his priorities, it was obvious that this would of course have to reopen many open legislative construction sites in the European single market. And so we find a whole range of issues in this Digital Single Market Strategy, on which we have tried to reach an amicable settlement with the Member States in recent years or even decades. I am not talking at all about the outstanding issues of network and information security, data protection and the internal telecoms market, where, unfortunately, we do not seem to be getting as far as we in Parliament would like to do. Nor am I talking about consumer rights, which are mentioned again in this Digital Single Market Strategy. It is the case that this digital internal market strategy makes it clear that the horizontal importance of the internal market will simply have to go into depth, and that we will thus provoke the resistance of the Member States in many places. That is why we must ensure that, not only at The Commission level, but also in the European Parliament, we work together across all committees to win majorities to ensure that all European citizens can benefit from this digital single market. If we succeed in this, Europe will also be able to grow closer together through this project. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
text: blue card question. – Thank you for the interesting speech and, in particular, for the end, where you said that all people should benefit from this digital single market.  In fact, only Marju Lauristin has so far drawn attention to the fact that there is indeed a threat that some citizens will be marginalised. If, for example, registration at a health centre or enrolment in a school takes place digitally, some people will be excluded as a result of this digital revolution. What ideas do you have as a representative of the largest parliamentary group on this growing inequality that the digital revolution may bring?

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you, Mrs Jaakonsaari. Indeed, I believe that our common objective must be that the digital single market is a project from which not only a few businesses, but all citizens, can benefit, no matter how they wish to be integrated into the Digital Single Market and want to be integrated. But I believe that we should not discuss individual services alone and compare the video-on-demand service with a television station and others. Rather, we should try to impose the idea that all citizens, all workers and all companies have a level playing field. And I am very curious to see what further ideas we in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection will develop in this regard.

name: Evelyne Gebhardt (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Finally, the Commission has woken up to take care of the digital revolution we are experiencing in the global world. And that's a good thing! However, I must honestly say that I was a little surprised when I read your text, because some of the statements are quite nebulous and in many sentences either this or the opposite can be read out. I really would ask you to be much more specific on these issues very quickly. I was also astonished that some areas of the internal market, which is also a focus of your strategy, have been completely omitted. I am thinking in particular of the share economy – Uber, Lyft, Airbnb and others, where a revolution in the labour market is also taking place. It would really make sense to know what the European Commission is actually planning in these areas.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The Digital Single Market is an opportunity for consumers and for small and medium-sized enterprises. I therefore welcome the call for existing hurdles to be removed. However, I not only want national hurdles to be removed, but I also want a healthy sense of proportion in the establishment of new rules at EU level. SMEs, and not the interests of multinationals, may be the focus of this digital single market, as the Commission and a number of parliamentarians are trying to shape it. I know from committee work that Vicky Ford and others are exemplary in their commitment to SMEs. But there is still a lot of work to be done here. Only yesterday we debated the different VAT rates for print and online products. If we really had the interests of SMEs in mind, we would have been in favour of simplification and less bureaucracy. We should understand that the opportunities of a digital single market lie in diversity and diversity, diversity and rich supply. And that is where SMEs are indispensable. In my opinion, however, the EU would also have the comprehensive task of ensuring reliable data security. The Member States obviously cannot do this, or they cannot do so alone, as current scandals in my own country are just revealing. Only when this indispensable prerequisite is secured as far as possible, i.e. according to the current state of the art, am I prepared to think about e-government as a further step.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate Commissioner Ansip on the digital strategy. It clearly sets out our priorities, which are: building trust, fostering innovation and taking down barriers. Digital is everywhere. It affects every part of our society and economy. There is, however, a lot to be done to overcome the fears associated with digital life. People trust each other more than ever, by sharing their cars, by sharing their flats, but also sharing content and accessing content online. But they also need to know that their communication is secure. Therefore, I am very worried about the recent talk about creating a backdoor to the encrypted software. This will greatly undermine the trust in e—commerce, but also in the economy as a whole. So my question is this: how does that fit into the digital market strategy? This certainly needs to be answered. Thank you Commissioner. I look forward to cooperating with you on the implementation of the strategy.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, let me start by quoting one great statesman: ' When it moves, tax it. If it's still moving, start regulating it. If it stops moving, start subsidize it." This is how US President Ronald Reagan characterized the government's approach, and it seems to me to be exactly the European Union's approach when it comes to the digital market and the Internet.  The Internet is a free and dynamic environment, and it seems to me that you want to ruin it now. The Internet makes life easier for millions of people and opens up business opportunities. It is a growing market from which one great innovation after another emerges. Why is that? Precisely because your regulatory appetites for this market have not yet fully hit. So please leave it alone.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work The digitisation of the economy is essential to increase Europe's competitiveness in an international context and to create employment. Digitisation, in particular through Industry 4.0, will make it possible to increase Europe's gross domestic product by EUR 1 250 billion over the next ten years, to create 3.8 million new jobs – skilled jobs – and to ensure that the European ICT economy remains among the world's market leaders. Inaction, not a digital strategy, will cause Europe to fall behind. Industrial growth will fall by 10%. Europe has lost a great deal of pace here in recent years, and competitiveness has been lost. Today, only eight of the top 100 high-tech companies are headquartered in Europe. That needs to change. To do this, Europe needs action. What to do? Investments in robust infrastructure, i.e. broadband expansion as a key technology for the industrial Internet, a focus on R&D and innovation, in particular 5G standards, investment in education, new curricula for IT professionals, setting industrial standards and a European cloud.

name: Sabine Verheyen (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I warmly welcome the Commission's digital single market strategy. It is a good first mark to adapt European regulations to the realities of today's technological developments. However, it needs to be deepened and fleshed out in many areas. The Digital Single Market is essential for the economic development of the European Union, but it has just as great potential to preserve and disseminate cultural creative content. The Internet has radically changed the way we consume content. Therefore, the legal requirements must be adapted to technological changes in such a way as to facilitate legal access to online content, including across borders or from abroad. However, we must take a special approach to this. For some European artistic and creative sectors, the territorial principle is at the heart of their financing structures and thus the prerequisite for diversity in creativity, for the production of new European content, especially for small and medium-sized producers, for special cultural films that are adequately adapted to their respective markets. We need to strike a balance between copyright-protected rights and consumer demand to consume digital content across national borders. I agree with the Commission: portability is essential, but without destroying the economic framework for professional creation of creative content. A complete abolition of the territorial principle in every area would seriously jeopardise European cultural diversity. The result would be a concentration on some large producers and mainstream offerings, which we certainly do not want. That is why we must take special care in this regard. On the subject of AVMD, I would like to call on the Commission to include more closely the issue of platform regulation and to find regulations in the area of access and discoverability. The diversity of cultural and audiovisual offerings must be accessible and discoverable for all European citizens, especially if equipment manufacturers, network operators or content providers already pre-sort the content offered.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. You have given me a very nice list of aspects to consider when designing the digital single market, but I have missed it, or at least I have not heard it speak out on the issue of taxation. The cross-border nature of this sector is quite strong. I ask: Can you agree to a single internal market for VAT?

name: Sabine Verheyen (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – Especially in the field of cultural content, it makes absolutely no sense in my view that print products, for example, are taxed differently from online products. We must establish equivalence here. To achieve this, we need changes in the VAT Directive. I hope that the Commission will tackle this as quickly as possible, particularly in this area.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is a serious digital lag in Europe in relation to the development of the world's major economies. It is therefore a good thing that we are on the road to creating a single market in order to offer traditional businesses, start-ups and citizens the ease of accessible and innovative services that we do not have today, in order to create a cross-border market without unjustified geoblocking and without obstacles or barriers that are now inadmissible and harmful. In addition to accessibility, service innovation is important. We need real Community coordination – I am thinking of the spectrum, Commissioner – by supporting ICT producers, focusing on interoperability and standardisation, and we need a recipe that can exploit, also in terms of development and industrial application, all the potential for growth, something that we have not done in recent years. But the Commission's strategy must be strengthened in terms of vision: the bar of objectives must be raised, especially in order to prepare for confrontation with those Member States that are obtusely jealous of their internal markets, as we are bitterly seeing in the trialogue on the telecommunications market, which is stationary and risks missing an important basis for this new strategy.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The declared objective of the Digital Single Market is to fully exploit the potential of European industry and enable consumers to have better access to goods and services. These are very important objectives, but Europeans are not only producers of goods and consumers, and digital techniques are not only about trade in goods, but also about cultural content that relates to our national-individual identity. And in the field of culture, the principle of competitiveness, efficiency cannot simply be adopted – the principle that a stronger winner, that mass consumption decides. In the field of culture, we cannot give up the state mecenate, the protection of identities, the promotion of our cultures, including territorial copyright. We must also be aware that the development of the internet also has negative cultural effects – leading, for example, to linguistic impoverishment, loss of ability to read long compact texts, etc. This, too, should be taken into account in the European Digital Strategy.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). Mr President, the Commission's Strategy for the Digital Single Market gives impetus to this highly profitable field for business groups with the cutting edge of e-commerce and the integration of new technologies into industrial sectors. The Commission and Google dispute is fiercely competing between monopolies over market dominance. The European Union earmarks EUR 21 billion for infrastructure, research and innovation, all plundered from popular income. Exploitative forms of flexible employment and teleworking are being extended with thousands of redundancies. The highly controlled electronic forms of trade will further monopolize the market, wipe out the small ones. Tax avoidance will be intensified, and monitoring of all aspects of life by huge databases will also be intensified.  The only way for the people to enjoy technological achievements is to get rid of the shackles of the European Union and monopolies by establishing their own power and economy.

name: Lara Comi (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I welcome the Juncker Commission, which is giving so much emphasis to the digital single market, which is a fundamental and very important objective for growth and jobs in Europe. The communication adopted a few days ago shows a potentially very incisive strategy. I very much agree with the actions aimed at improving competition and those which move in the direction of common taxation, which is what we have often set ourselves in the Committee on the Internal Market.  This plan is ambitious and will create a modern society and will undoubtedly have a positive impact not only on better access to digital goods and services in the various sectors, including health, transport or energy, but also on the creation of the new jobs that we so much need and are really focusing on as the European Union. You see, my hope is that the Commission, Parliament and the Council will be able to do real teamwork with a great sense of responsibility. There are many interests involved, and that is also a risk that we have, because we really must be a Europe and not show that the interests of individual countries have the upper hand over collegiality, otherwise everything we have done in recent years will have served absolutely no purpose.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission's proposal on the digital single market is very important but, in my opinion, it is overly unbalanced in favour of consumption rather than digital citizenship, the strengthening of cultural and creative production and content and therefore cultural diversity and educational challenges. The prerequisite for a digital single market for the cultural and creative industry is that the adaptation of certain aspects of copyright goes hand in hand with the revision of the e-commerce directive to define roles, responsibilities, tax regime for the over-the-top, distinguishing between those who are in fact competitors and not mere intermediaries, together with the revision of the Audiovisual Media Services Directive and enforcement , to safeguard Europe's cultural biodiversity, which is also competitiveness. I appreciate, however, that Commissioner Oettinger – and I hope Vice-President Ansip also agrees – has opened a much closer dialogue with those working in the sector in Cannes in recent days, involving Parliament's Committee on Culture and saying precisely that the rightly recalled individual portability, copyright and territoriality are compatible. On the educational front, we ask that through the ongoing investment plan we invest in ultrabroadband to connect schools, for the recovery of the digital divide and for the skills of teachers.

name: Sajjad Karim (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the Commissioner has very correctly identified some of the core issues that we must address: better access across the European Union and high—quality infrastructure. Certainly in my constituency in the north-west of England, in Cumbria, we are seeing the benefits of broadband connectivity provided through the European Union. There is so much else that has been put forward here that must be delivered, but from a citizens’ viewpoint, this is a crucial test for the European Union. However, we are already behind. As far as our citizens are concerned, so many of them are already frustrated. When they pass through actual borders they do it seamlessly, but every time they do so we reinforce a virtual border for them in real terms. When the law is an ass, people will find a way around it. That is what we must do: ensure that they do not have to do that. Recent telecoms experience dictates to us that time is indeed of the essence. So many of our new start-ups are crying out for their vision to be fulfilled through the Digital Single Market. Please allow us to deliver that for them and do not allow it to be constrained by the short-sightedness and small-mindedness that some of the contributors demonstrated in this debate today.

name: Jerzy Buzek (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mr Ansip, i would like to thank you for your comments. The digital single market is certainly a great step towards a future digital union, because we imagine that we could propose a digital union later in this term. From the point of view of the ITRE Committee, which I lead, the most important thing is actually 3-4 things in the Commission communication.  Firstly, the implementation of the Internet of Things and cloud computing will be crucial for the competitiveness of industry. Standardisation or interoperability will indeed give us an economy of scale and allow Europe to win a global competitive battle. Finally, very important online platforms. First, it is good to understand their operation, their meaning, and then regulate and create a special framework for such actions. And here I fully agree with the Commission, but, Mr Vice-President, we still have trouble with the telecommunications market. The package is neither implemented nor concluded yet, and that is the basis of our common digital market and both the retention of roaming charges and the spectrum issue. I appeal to all my fellow Members, to the Member States, to finally take a decision on this matter. Because how can we talk about the common digital market if the telecoms package is not completed. And I also appeal to all my colleagues from different committees – we have 10-11 committees implemented in the digital single market – we need to respond quickly and efficiently to the Commission's communication.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Digital Single Market brings opportunities, but also new challenges. A digital labour market will develop, changing working hours, forms of work and working methods. Here, too, the Commission must do its homework: we need answers and rules at an early stage. This is not just about qualifications, it is about new forms of employment, about a new form of social protection, about new ways of protecting workers and enforcing workers' interests. And we are already seeing the challenge today. Today, Amazon employs people – workers, employees, the self-employed – from all over the world. You enter into employment contracts that last minutes. People are spread all over the world, and there is no way of asserting common interests. And there must be no blueprint to put aside the people who are supposed to buy in this internal market and their rights in the end. We do not just need deregulation, we also need new rules.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Vice-President of the Commission, the Digital Single Market undoubtedly has enormous potential to support the Economic Growth of the European Union and create new jobs. I guess we can all agree on that. You need to appreciate the effort you put into it. I see positive steps in the strategy presented, others would certainly be well to work on. Overall, I think we could do even more for businesses and citizens in the Digital Single Market. In the strategy, you rightly place emphasis on removing barriers and binding regulation. But our experience says we should stay careful. Of course, it will depend on the specific proposals that you submit at a later date. I would like to underline the fundamental problem that we are repeatedly encountering, which concerns the lack of broadband infrastructure, which is crucial for further development.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I warmly welcome the Commission's communication, in which it presented the Strategy for a Digital Single Market in Europe. The Commission has, in a case, given itself its own work programme, with which it will now develop further initiatives here. What is specifically envisaged will now be worked out in the coming weeks and months. I would just like to say that I am in a weeding of what concrete proposals are now being made. We will certainly discuss these intensively in Parliament. I welcome the fact that you have raised a great many issues that are important to consumers – whether it is a uniform right to buy, whether it is data protection, you want to eliminate geo-blocking, you want to reduce shipping costs within Europe. These are all very important initiatives for consumers. Commissioner, Mr Vice-President, I would ask you to discuss and negotiate another matter with us here: the abolition of roaming charges in the European Union. This is not the specific subject of this package. However, once the negotiations are under way within the framework of the trialogue, we can use any support to the Member States. I would also ask you to do everything you can to support us so that we can soon have a Europe free of roaming! My final point is that I think that the issue of Industry 4.0 is not enough in your communication. I would be grateful if you could say two or three sentences afterwards. We have 26 million unemployed in the European Union. I welcome the way in which jobs are created, including in view of our traditional industries, which must also pave the way for digitisation.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Economically, the most successful are those countries that succeed in combining a creative economy with a corresponding social model. Creativity – and thus the digital European single market – needs a certain degree of social security in order to develop. However, I do not say a word about the Commission's communication of 6 May about the social dialogue, and so you should pay more attention to it. Namely, what does this mean for the employees now, what impact can be expected here? Is there not also a very high risk of precarious employment or of high-quality jobs being transformed into much worse, atypical? I think that the digital European internal market has wonderful opportunities that we should face up to. And the Commission should also pay attention – and not believe that it happens automatically – what this means for employees, and to include this in this whole strategy.

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE).
text: – Firstly, the subject of the common digital market is today– it seems to me – a leading theme both in the European Commission, in the European Parliament, and in the Council. As jacques Delors, the great head of the European Commission, was said to have had the driving force behind the creation of a common European market, the Juncker Commission introduced the subject of the digital single market, and let it be the engine of a stronger merging of the Union and more dynamic action. May this also be a strong message for Europeans. This is an extremely political topic. The theme of the common market and the digital common market cannot be shared in the 21st century. We have one common European market , whether in digital form or in physical form. That is why I join all those who say: we will help the Commissioner, please strengthen us in the fight against the Council, so that we can finally deal with topics that have already become a symbol of the European Union, such as the unfortunate abolition of roaming. Let's take the lead in sharing economies, otherwise we're going to have 28 different legislations that we're going to try hard to merge.  Last subject: I agree with my camaradero on the left: digital exclusion is a great challenge. Everyone must also be included in the digits, otherwise our economy and our stronger political integration will not move forward.

name: Clare Moody (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Digital Single Market only means something if people have access to the internet, and there are two very distinct examples of people’s experiences in my constituency. A six-year EU-funded project is just coming to an end in Cornwall. This has meant that the county has had an incredible experience wth the roll-out of superfast broadband. For example, 40% of fibre-to-the-premises (FTTP) connections in the UK are in this single county; 2 000 jobs have been created or safeguarded; 83% of SMEs say time and money has been saved as a consequence; and 58% of SMEs say they are growing as a result of this project. In the neighbouring county, they have had a very different experience as a consequence of not having that combined funding that Cornwall has received. Please look at these experiences and the difference effective EU funding can make for consumers, businesses and schools across the EU.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, is féidir a rá, is dócha, go bhfuil na moltaí seo ag teacht beagáinín déanach ach is fearr déanach ná riamh. Tá súil agam gur féidir linn na moltaí seo a chur i bhfeidhm chomh luath agus is féidir ar mhaithe le lucht gnó agus saoránaigh na hEorpa. It is estimated that a properly functioning Digital Single Market could create 3.8 million jobs and bring EUR 415 billion into the European economy. Obviously, we all welcome that and want it to happen, and certainly these proposals are a step in the right direction and can be implemented as soon as possible.  One area I would like to focus on, though, is education. The fact that there are so many high-tech jobs lying idle in Europe at the minute because of unqualified personnel is an indictment of the educational system, especially at the third-level and in universities, who like to see themselves as leaders. Certainly I welcome the fact that they are stepping up to the plate now, but from now on they need to be ahead of the curve, not behind it, if we are to create a Digital Single Market.  I particularly welcome movements such as CoderDojo, a voluntary group which is helping to create the programmers and the coders of the future. Education – from kindergarten to third-level – is vital for the creation of the market.  Finally, I welcome the points made about copyright, broadband and roaming. As Ms Grossetête said, the future is going to be digital, so let us get with the digital game.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the creation of a digital single market is one of europe's most important growth potential. We have an area of 500 million inhabitants, but it is actually divided into 28 separate regions. This is demonstrated by the fact that only 15% of Europeans buy electronic services in another Eu ropean country and only 7% of companies currently sell their services across borders. This is not in the interests of consumers or businesses either. The Commission's policy on the creation of a digital single market is a good one. It raises the very right points, a few of which I would particularly like to rush. The second has been VAT in this debate yesterday. It is very important that electronic services are treated at least equally, but rather they are even given priority over traditional services. The second issue is copyright. Here I encourage bold and modern reform on the part of the Commission. We still have a lot of old-fashioned remnants of copyright, including old equipment charges, i.e. cassette charges, which at the moment no longer correspond to today's internet time.

name: Ева Паунова (PPE).
text: – Everyone here knows perfectly well the basic rules of the game – when we promise something, we have to fulfill it. When we declare that the interest of citizens is clear, we must respect it. The large number of topics included in the strategy blur its focus and create the prerequisites for it to fail or not to be fully implemented. We must not allow ourselves to find ourselves in a similar situation as roaming charges, an issue that, if it does not find a quick solution, could lead to a false start to the whole strategy.  Not to live up to citizens' expectations is to risk not only our own integrity, but also the chance of the European Union becoming a global digital power. It is citizens and businesses who sell and buy online from different Member States. They are users of optimised public e-services and new education models.  In order to be trusting, we need quick, adequate and transparent solutions for working copyright, for the shared economy and for geo-blocking. The single digital market is a machine with many different parts – a mechanism that cannot work at full speed if each part of it is not in working order and in sync with the others. The European Commission, the European Parliament and the governments of the Member States must therefore, with common efforts, ensure that this mechanism works efficiently and irresusably.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, it is time for Europe to grab the opportunity of the digital revolution to create jobs without spending taxpayers’ money. The Digital Single Market strategy is really welcome and now we look forward very soon to a concrete proposal that must aim at boosting an open, free and global internet. It is about creating a level playing field for our companies. It is not about creating digital sovereignty or a European cloud. We must compete with simple, modern and clear rules, providing legal certainty and protecting integrity, not by raising walls to keep out the rest of the world. Europe can never work to segment the internet. People in Europe should be able to enjoy digital products regardless of where they are physically. Why can you take a telephone across borders, but not the mobile services that you bought on it?  Fifteen years ago I started an e-commerce company and I have suffered the fragmentation that thousands of other companies are also suffering in Europe. It is time to create a single market for parcel delivery, to remove the difference in VAT regimes, and to harmonise further the different rules on consumer rights.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the present and future competitiveness of the Union has a lot to do with achieving a digital single market, but I nevertheless want to say that intellectual property is not a problem. It is the legal structure on which a sector is based that contributes more than 4% of gross domestic product, creator of employment and which is home to world leaders in the cultural and publishing industry. Europe lost foot in the electronics industry. We can't lose foot in the content industry. Not only would the industry be at risk: our own cultural identity would be at stake. Let us therefore build a digital union on solid foundations that ensures equal access, the inclusion of all citizens and the development of cultural, creative and innovative industries.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR) –
text: Mr. President, I support removing the barriers that divide us from the establishment of the Digital Single Market and the digitisation of the European economy so that globally it is as competitive and resistant as possible to the challenges posed by the future. We will have to be brave and determined, because removing these barriers will indusize the revenues of large telecom operators, but also of states. The cost of adapting to the digital era in which we live must not only be paid by the private sector, but member states would also have to stimulate this process by reducing taxes on digital services.  Europe's high level of digitalisation will change the structure and therefore the future needs of our labour market, and resistance should be expected from that point of place.  That is why I think we need a comprehensive development strategy to have solutions for those citizens who are not benefited by digitalisation at the moment.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, dear Vice-President, I congratulate you on your courage, because in this matter of the digital single market — as is the case in other sectors — we are again going to come across the Council's narrow gaze and its obsession with borders. And just remember the shameful veto of roaming suppression. We say that there are no borders, but ask companies that aspire to operate at European level on the rail market or let us reflect on the effects of the delay in the construction of the single sky. We stand for something very simple: a stable legal framework, equal opportunities, net neutrality and support for innovation. This creates opportunities for creativity, imagination and capacity, and also for many of the young people who are now looking for a job and do not find it in the old economy. There are opportunities for our diversity, also that which it produces in unofficial languages, to open up to the world and to carry out the digital revolution, which will also promote more democratic European governance. Good luck and have all our support.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank you cordially for this very fruitful debate. I got a clear message from this debate: we need change and that change is digital.  Time is very limited, but I will try to respond to as many questions as possible. I would like to start with Marju Lauristin. Yes, I agree. Some people will lose their jobs, but digital is creating many more jobs than it is destroying. But we have to help those people who lose their jobs to find new ones. We have to pay much more attention to the lifelong learning process.  The cost of non-Europe in a digital sense is huge. According to the latest analyses prepared by the European Parliament, the cost of non-Europe in this sense is EUR 415 billion. I am afraid that if we do not act immediately, this cost of non—Europe will even increase in the future.  The Commission is planning to make all its proposals during this year and next. We do not want to leave those proposals to the end of our mandate. There is a sense of urgency in the Commission too. I would also like to ask you to speed up those processes.  Data protection reform, the Network and Information Security (NIS) Directive, and the Telecoms Single Market package are essential building blocks for a Digital Single Market. A date for the end of roaming is something our people are really expecting to get from those negotiations. I would like to ask you to push for an end to roaming in the European Union. I would like to state that very clearly. (Applause) The European Commission is also asking for end dates for roaming in the European Union.  I would like to respond to Kaja Kallas’s question. I have also followed the discussions in the Estonian press and I would like to state very clearly that in the Commission we never had – and we do not have – any kind of plans to create backdoors for identification systems. There is no basis for that kind of rumour. Trust is a must and we do not want to destroy the people’s trust by creating backdoor identification systems. If there are any backdoors, sooner or later somebody will misuse them anyway. There were many questions about copyright, the principle of territoriality and the abolishing of geo-blocking. We have to allow our people to have cross—border access to digital content and the portability of the content. We have to allow cross-border access to digital content, to movies, music, e—books etc. We have to allow the portability of digital content to our people. When we talk about copyright reform, we do not want to change, with this Digital Single Market strategy, the release window system, such as six months for movies in cinemas. It is up to the industry to say for how long a period of time they would like to keep those movies in cinemas. If six months, then six months, if 16, then 16, if 60 months, then once again it is up to the industry and not up to the Commission to say for how long a period of time the producers would like to keep their movies in cinemas. It is a question about entrepreneurial freedom as I understand it.  Regarding DVDs, once again it is up to the industry to say for how long a period they would like to keep those movies on DVD. But when it comes to video on demand, I would like to ask for cross-border access to the content and for portability of the content. Today, everybody knows that piracy is free; you do not have to pay. I am sorry to say that many people are using those possibilities. According to public opinion polls as many as 68% of film viewers in Europe use so-called free downloads; 20% of internet users in the European Union are using VPNs. So we have to tackle piracy, but first we have to provide legal access to digital content for our people.  Thank you very much once again for this very fruitful debate. The Digital Single Market is not the finishing line. The Digital Single Market strategy is not the finishing line. They are just starting points. I look forward to having fruitful cooperation with all of you over the next four and a half years.  (Applause)

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. – The strategy highlights geo-blocking or discrimination against the place of residence that I have warned about on several occasions. As many as 24% of EU households have access to some online content. In my view, this is a direct discrimination against certain consumers. In Croatia, about 25% of consumers buy online, which is about 20% less than the European average, and we can explain this as one of the consequences of discrimination in the digital market.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. The Presentation by the Commission of the new European strategy for a digital single market is undoubtedly an important first signal for smart growth in Europe, using the opportunities offered by new technologies, but it will have to be followed by very ambitious initiatives at legislative level.  We believe that the digital revolution can mark a turning point for the quality of life of European citizens and at the same time represents an opportunity to make our economy more competitive. Firstly, I believe it is essential to promote digital innovation in our traditional companies, particularly manufacturing companies; We also have a duty to create an environment favourable to European start-ups, so that they cannot find a development space only overseas.
