Finally, we must promote a strong digitalisation in the APs so as to offer citizens and businesses more efficient and less expensive services. All this will only be possible if we accompany these objectives with a strong investment in human capital and infrastructure.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I would like to congratulate Commissioner Ansip on the work done initiating regulation for the future Digital Single Market in Europe. The development of the digital market offers great opportunities for growth, also measured by new jobs. This entails great opportunities, but also many challenges.  Digitising traditional industries and creating new services also means developing new skills. The fast-growing Internet of Things and online platforms require expertise, and with the current shortage of skilled labour in this area, adequate facilities for this type of education urgently need to be created. For young people who choose this type of profession, as well as for those who have lost their jobs and are forced to retrain. I hope that the Commission will draw up such a plan for investing in education and the development of human resources, together with an analysis of its impact on society and its impact on the labour market.  However, I wonder how credible we will be to society, after we announced a year ago that roaming charges would end by the end of 2015, but this issue is stuck in the Council and Parliament cannot get a specific answer.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. –  Digital performance in the EU varies greatly, the best performers rank almost twice as high as at the lower end. The digital single market strategy and the accompanying legislation have to reduce existing barriers to a minimum. This cannot happen unless Member States commit themselves to preferential investment in digital solutions – e-government, e-health, e-commerce, digital signatures. A supportive and customer-friendly legal and structural framework is needed at EU level as well as at national level both for citizens and businesses.  To provide for cross-border e—European solutions, the Commission has to come forward with ambitious legislative proposals. Only 7 % of SMEs sell cross-border. Lack of trust among sellers and buyers is based on prejudices, high delivery prices and complicated tax systems. Providing a minimum commonality in rules would change the picture. Online content – music, newspapers, books – must be made available for customers. Ironically it is practically impossible to purchase any audiovisual products online from another EU Member State. Europeanising copyright and ending geo-blocking must happen.  I call on the Commission and the Member States to tear down these protective walls and enable a genuine e-Europe! Every EU citizen should have the option to be paperless in doing business, sign documents online, use e-prescriptions valid everywhere and buy goods online regardless of location. This is what the EU is supposed to be!

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Thank you to the Commission for presenting the Digital Single Market Strategy. This is an important step towards exploiting the potential of digital technologies and creating new opportunities for Europeans in various areas such as employment, innovation and consumer policy. In the process of creating the Digital Single Market, it should be ensured that it serves all Union citizens, including the elderly, the disabled, the financially vulnerable or those who are underrepresented in the labour market. Only such a market will allow the creation of a knowledge-based society that develops evenly, for the benefit of all citizens. Current social and social priorities must be reflected in the digital world. We must also ensure consumer protection and freedom of establishment in the digital age.  These challenges need a clear and personalised action plan and training for different social groups to meet their expectations, needs and new opportunities for growth in the digital age. The plan must include ensuring internet access for every European, guaranteeing online protection by improving the security of new technologies and electronic communications, and creating a competitive and fair environment for digital services. It is also important to ensure coherence between the Digital Single Market Strategy, the EU 2020 Strategy and the Juncker Plan. These key EU projects should be coherent and complementary.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Digital Agenda must be a priority for the European Union. Only through investment in innovation and new technologies can Europe remain a leader in the world economy. Unfortunately, today, national bureaucracy and regulations are hindering the development of top companies at European level and expressing the real potential of European digital entrepreneurs.  The European Union has the human resources and innovative ideas that can lead to technological progress worldwide, but in order to do so, it must facilitate the connecting entrepreneurs and creative people with the financial resources capable of enabling their ideas to be implemented. I like to think that in such a context my country, Romania, can become a central actor at European level and a regional leader in new technologies. To do this, the EU needs to raise awareness of the importance of new technologies, develop digital-friendly investment programmes, create an unrestricted digital market, but also facilitate the training and education of the population, regardless of generation or region, in the development of these skills either at the usual or professional level.  For a true digital revolution at European level we need to combat inequalities of access and skills so that the whole population and the European economy understand the benefits of new technological developments.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – The IT and communications sector (ITC) is growing extremely fast and creating 120 thousand new jobs per year. At the same time, there is a shortage of ITC specialists in Europe. I believe that the first obstacle to a European Digital Single Market is the need to combine skills with real labour market needs. In order to take full advantage of the opportunities of interconnected e-services, it is necessary to stimulate the development of digital skills, which significantly increases the chances of young people finding a job. Statistics show that 40% of the EU workforce does not have adequate digital skills and 14% do not have them at all. The results of the Digital Economy and Society Index (DESI) are also alarming. In Bulgaria, for example, only 1.3% of Bulgarians aged 20 to 29 are graduates in science, technology, engineering and mathematics. Only 54% of them regularly use the Internet and have a fixed broadband connection. Addressing these challenges is the cornerstone of building a Digital Single Market.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing. – The strategy presented is to prepare Europe for its expected digital future. With regard to the creation of the Digital Single Market, I welcome the proposed measures. E-shopping must be based on clear and binding rules to make it easier for consumers to choose services and goods. In order to increase confidence in cross-border trade, it is necessary to simplify and make delivery cheaper, but also to facilitate the possibility of complaints and to ensure law enforcement. It is high time to put an end to persistent discrimination on grounds of nationality, not only in the case of so-called geo-blocking, but in general in access to goods and services. I have been drawing the Commission's attention to this for a long time. But the digitisation of society is far from just about the internal market. We're hearing about hundreds of thousands of new jobs. But do we know how many will be lost? How will the status of workers change? How to prevent the exclusion or discrimination of those for which the digital environment is too complex? On these important issues, the Social Democrats do not have much answers to the strategy.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. - I support the Digital Single Market as it lays the groundwork for the continued development of a sector that has already significantly improved the quality of life of European citizens but whose potential has not been fully exploited. A common European approach is a guarantor of achieving this objective. Since technology is used in all segments of life, from private to business use, it is crucial to create a market that will allow freedom of movement of goods, persons, services and capital, and where individuals and companies can easily access and carry out online activities in conditions of fair competition. In doing so, it is necessary to achieve a high level of protection of personal data. I also think it is essential that Europe becomes a world leader in the digital economy, and will achieve this goal by creating a Digital Single Market that will enable european companies to develop globally. I support the 3 pillars of the decision, which state the need to eliminate key differences between online and offline worlds in order to break the barrier on the way to cross-border online activity. In addition, high-speed, secure and reliable content infrastructures and services are needed, supported by the right regulatory conditions for innovation, investment and fair competition. Investments in ICT infrastructure and technology, research and innovation are also required to improve industrial competitiveness, as well as better public services, inclusion and skills.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The European single market must be a real opportunity for consumers to have access to goods and services that are sometimes not directly available in their country of residence or that are more expensive than abroad. It is also a boon for small, medium and large companies that can expand their customer base. However, they must respect European rules.  One can wonder, for example, about the situation of Disneyland Paris, which discriminates against European consumers. The company charges you 32% more if you are wrong to be German and almost 40% more if you are Italian. There are still many obstacles to this digital market, I am counting on the Commission to take effective measures, so is its credibility in this sector where we are lagging behind. A first step is an investigation into Eurodisney's illegal and anti-European practices.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. We need an integrated strategy and clear, clear legislation so that the digital revolution that shapes our world can secure our fundamental values and make use of the changes brought about by development for all European citizens. As a politician of the MSZP, and also a member of the political leadership of the European Internet Foundation, I actively support the European Commission's proposal for a single digital market. However, in order to create, as the Social Democrats see it, a digital environment that allows cross-border cooperation, with the necessary guarantees, and guarantees the rights of consumers and citizens at the same time, we need not only a single digital market, but a digital union. Europe must play an active role in the digital revolution, Hungary also have an interest in being part of the digital union. Progressive innovations that have gained ground as a result of the digital revolution are making significant changes in the functioning of almost all sectors, such as tourism, which has a significant impact on the European economy. As Vice-Chairman of the European Parliament's Committee on Transport and Tourism, I therefore consider the debate on the creation of a Digital Union to be of the utmost importance.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We do not deny progress, much less the enormous potential of the digital revolution in its ability to significantly improve the day-to-day life of people and economic operators. We doubt the ability of capitalist society to reverse the benefits of technological advances for peoples and workers. The advances of the digital economy open the door to a vast set of new activities in the area of services. But they also involve the destruction of many jobs, which are becoming obsolete with the emergence of these new technologies. Only a planned economy at the service of peoples and workers will be able to impose logics of sharing, which will allow everyone to benefit equally from these advances. With this model, it will once again be the big companies accumulating the huge profits generated by these new technologies, benefiting to this the legislative environmental conducive to the exploitation, provided in a servile way by the current governments and the current institutions of the European Union.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " The common digital market, the internet is above all a gigantic business, and it is not impersonal at all, belonging to specific individuals and specific business groups. Europe is clearly not keeping up with the regulations behind the new technologies. That doesn't surprise me much. What is also at issue in yesterday's debate, however, is worrying. We all agree, for example, that VAT on e-books should be at the preferred rate. As Minister of Culture, I have for many years demanded a re-qualification of readership on new media (including the press) together with fellow ministers from many EU countries. The result: we are still at the same point. How are we to deal with content blockades built on, after all, the dismantled yet existing borders in Europe, when simple issues take so many years of work? Turtles the pace of the creation of the digital single market is not optimistic. I know that the result of the current work is to be regulations ending in almost a dozen new pieces of legislation. Let us not create a situation of omnipotent expectations. Let us deal with the matter: the transmission of parcels, the reception of TELEVISION signals regardless of where they are received, let us end the issue of roaming services, let us combat the exclusion of citizens in access to certain internet services, but one by one. At the same time, let us remember about cybersecurity and the fact that this business has owners. They should be visible partners, beneficiaries, but they should also be quality guarantors.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – Creating the Single Digital Market (MDU) is not a choice between a yes and a no. The Digital Union will develop more or less flat and perfect. The key is to define how.  Will it be created under the pressure of reality, giving advantage to competitors of European companies, or will we be able to create favourable contexts in anticipation, so that the Union can lead market niches such as health services, energy efficiency, cultural content, intelligent mobility or others that are critical to the competitiveness of our economy and to the sustainability of our social state? This is the key question to which the Commission and governments have only one way of answering, acting with a humanistic vision and not with a technocratic approach.  The Digital Union needs laws and infrastructure, but that will do no good if we do not guarantee access. In the creation of the Digital Union there will be no second chance to cause a winning dynamic. It takes vision and ambition. A European programme to empower citizens and small businesses for the Digital Single Market is the way to touch everyone and mobilize everyone to the challenge.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to refer to Article 11, paragraph 2, of our regulation, which provides that Members' behaviour is inspired by mutual respect, is based on the values and principles defined in the fundamental texts of the European Union and preserves the dignity of Parliament.  However, when an MEP verbally and then physically attacks journalists by beating them, as Mr Gollnisch did two weeks ago with regard to reporters from the Petit Journal de Canal, he is violating the dignity of Parliament and undermining our dignity.  I hope, Madam President, that in the Office of this Parliament we will have the opportunity to react because this fact cannot be switched to blue, even if it is marine.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Madam President, I am also referring to Article 11 quoted by my colleague. I believe that my colleague has committed - but he has some excuses - a defamation of me because I have not beaten anyone rigorously.  This is what has happened: I am - and we are - often the object of so-called journalists who betray a little the rules of their profession and who, for example, surprise private correspondence by telephotoly photographing the personal letters or missives that we can write in the Chamber and which, as in the event to which our colleague alludes , seek to spy on our private conversations with microphones. I would like to say that for the past 33 years I have been courteously answering the questions - including the most intrusive and often the most hostile - that all journalists ask me. I answer their questions in front of their microphones. But the spy microphones, it's true, I spit them out with my umbrella and I break them! To the good of hearing, hi!

name: President. –
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Guy Verhofstadt (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, first of all my apologies to all colleagues that I have to intervene in the case of this request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity of Mr Uzpaskich, but Mr Uzpaskich has sent a letter to President Schulz and I want to speak in support of referral back to the Legal Affairs Committee.  The reason, very briefly, is the following: in the Legal Affairs Committee they got two sentences of something that Mr Uzpaskich said about justice in his country; but the recording contains far more than that. Those two sentences have been taken out of context, because in what he said he makes reference to what the President of Lithuania had said about the justice system in the country. So my only plea to the plenary is to refer the matter back to the Legal Affairs Committee so that the Legal Affairs Committee can listen to the whole recording and not only to the two sentences that were sent by the Lithuanian authorities; that is my request.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: – We will vote on his immunity in the case of Mr Uspasic – these are only statements. I think this is an extremely important matter. A Member of the European Parliament may not be punished for any statements. There's immunity for that.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as rapporteur for this report, I would like to stress that we have examined this issue in depth in the Committee on Legal Affairs. This is a conduct which is linked to mr Uspaskich's parliamentary role as a Member of the European Parliament.  This is a vilification of Parliament's judiciary, so it was not considered appropriate to maintain Mr Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity because the conduct was neither related to his mandate nor was there any evidence to support fumus persecutionis.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, a vote was being taken and while that vote was being taken you gave a political commentary on that vote. I do not think that is right.

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to request that the vote on the draft legislative regulation be postponed under Rule 61(2) of the Rules of Procedure.

name: President. –
text: That concludes the vote.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the explanations of vote.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the codification of Regulation (EEC) No 2481/72 of 19 December 1972 on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. A new Regulation aims to unify several acts held between the two parties over the years.  As it is a matter relating, without content, to the legal certainty of EU acts on relations between the signatory parties, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This text aims to endorse the proposal adopted by the Commission on this subject. These safeguards have different commercial defence advantages and provide uniform conditions. However, safeguards must remain a national jurisdiction and not be subject to supranational power. Although the measures proposed are mostly positive, I cannot vote in favour of this text and choose to abstain.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ To be consistent with previous votes, I supported the UKIP position and voted against this report. The UK should be in charge of its own trading relationship with Switzerland and therefore I opposed this proposal to codify Regulation No 2841/72.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because this proposal is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. The purpose of the proposal is to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This is a simple codification of the Council's Regulation (ESC) 2841/72. This new regulation replaces the various incorporated acts and completely preserves its substance.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report concerns the European Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on safeguard measures under the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. Its objective is to codify the Council of 19 December 1972 to a constant law and without substantial change in the substance of Regulation No. 2841/72. If this does not bring anything new on the substance, it must be thought that safeguard measures must remain the competence of the Member States. It is up to sovereign Member States to decide their international trade policy and not a supranational entity. Nevertheless, since Switzerland is a partner in Europe and a country bordering France, I abstain on this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I think the report we are voting on is balanced and unreissued. I believe that the safeguard measures in the EU-Switzerland agreement are useful to both parties and, since this agreement does not cause problems for our production sectors, I wanted to support this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. For the sake of simplification and clarity of EU law, in order to make it more accessible and understandable to the citizen, I voted in favour of this Regulation codating Council Regulation (EEC) No 2841/72 of 19 December 1972 on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. The proposal is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without any substantial modification thereof.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The codification report by Andrzej Duda promotes the codification of European Union legislation. As a result, the repeal and replacement of eu acts to be consolidated by a single act will be taken by a single legislative decision, provided that the changes do not contain any substantive amendments. This procedure facilitates the coordination of legislative processes on the basis of a better law-making agreement between the European Parliament, the European Commission and the European Council and contributes to making it more transparent to EU citizens.  I voted in favour of this report because I consider it essential to improve the quality of legislation and simplify legislation.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe that the decision to codify this regulation is in line with the objectives of simplification and better regulation that the Union must pursue in order to get closer to its citizens.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 There is a deep historical, cultural, linguistic and commercial link between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation. Switzerland exports 57% of its production to the Union and imports 78% of its total annual goods and services from the Union. By turnover, Switzerland is the Union's third largest economic partner, after the United States and China and ahead of Russia and Japan. In addition, more than one million EU citizens live in Switzerland and 230,000 carry out frontier work, and around 430,000 Swiss citizens live and work in the States of the Union. It follows from this that all efforts to consolidate and improve economic and cultural integration between these realities are positive because of the beneficial effect they have on both sides, but this cannot be separated from improving tax transparency, police cooperation in the prosecution of crimes, including financial ones, and ensuring the free movement of workers. , which cannot risk being limited by the referendum on immigration, the negative consequences of which would mainly fall on the Swiss Confederation itself.  We hope that Switzerland will seriously continue along the path of growth and development together with the Union, and we will do everything necessary to make this possible.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The report focuses on the European Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on safeguards under the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. It is a simple codification that allows for a commercial defence. However, this codification must be the responsibility of each sovereign state and not of the European Union. That is why I abstained on this vote.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation, as this is intended exclusively to codify Regulation No 17. This free trade agreement between the Swiss Confederation and the European Communities represents a legal framework for the development of economic relations between the two parties, and the safeguard measures provided for are the instruments used in the context of the increase in imports and the resulting effects. In view of the fact that the Consultative Working Party on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission considers that the proposal in question is limited to a simple codification of the existing texts, without any substantive changes thereto, I believe that this report must be supported in order to better function the unification and uniformisation process.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of a purely codification intervention. There is nothing to change as to the substance of a measure in respect of which we therefore maintain a positive opinion. Safeguard measures in the EU-Switzerland agreement are potentially a useful tool for both parties. It goes without saying that the agreement with the Swiss Confederation is certainly not a trade agreement that causes problems for our productive sector.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The codification of legislation is a kind of compilation of different European regulations that address the same theme. The aim of codification is to simplify and make European legislation more accessible. I voted in favour of this report on the codification of the safeguards provided for in the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation.  In view of the fact that, according to the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts and does not provide for any substantial changes, I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of it.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report. This vote was merely concerned with technical matters and it was not connected to the content but was instead concerned with codification. Codification of legal texts is an important tool as it leads to greater legal certainty and clarity.  This is important as, if you do not codify the text, the former several amended versions of the texts stay. Codification, is, in a nutshell, a simplification.   Any proposal that provides greater legal clarity and transparency should be welcomed as it is the complex nature of such texts which frequently leads to unnecessary legal challenges, often at the taxpayers’ expense.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The UK should be in charge of its own relationship with Switzerland and we are thus against the EU regulating it on our behalf. The regulation deals with aspects of the trade relationship between the EU and Switzerland. UKIP’s consistent position is that such matters should be entirely within the remit of Her Majesty’s Government and the UK Parliament.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The dossier concerns the codification of the amendments to the Regulation on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. In order to ensure legal certainty and the updating of the regulation in question, I therefore voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report for several reasons. First of all, it would be essential to clarify the very concept of a safeguard measure, which is a trade defence measure whose interest emanates from a national jurisdiction. The measures in this report are good in themselves; however, the decision must remain national.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure codifies existing texts, without any substantial changes, concerning the safeguard measures provided for in the agreement with the Swiss Confederation and is therefore of a technical nature. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As you know, the agreement with the Swiss Confederation aims to consolidate and deepen existing economic relations, while respecting fair conditions of competition. With this in mind, this proposal for the codification of the Regulation on safeguard measures is intended solely to bring the existing regulations together in a single regulation in order to provide legal certainty applicable.  Therefore, since the codification does not change to any extent the substantive nature of the agreement, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report outlines that the Consultative Working Party, consisting of the respective legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, agreed that the proposal is a straightforward codification of existing texts, without any change in their substance. Codification of agreements that have been amended on multiple occasions is important so as to ensure that they are accessible and clear to citizens. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the report on the codification of Regulation (EEC) No 2481/72 of 19 December 1972 on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. A new Regulation aims to unify several acts held between the two parties over the years.  As it is a matter relating, without content, to the legal certainty of EU acts on relations between the signatory parties, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since it is a technical dossier which codifies the legal texts on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement with the Swiss Confederation.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to codify the Council's Regulation (EEC) 2841/72 on safeguard measures under the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation, which regulates the modalities for the implementation of safeguard clauses and precautionary measures under Articles 22-27 of the agreement between the European Economic Community and Switzerland. The implementation of these bilateral safeguard clauses requires uniform conditions and authorizes the Commission to adopt immediately applicable enforcement actions where, in duly justified cases as well as in the case of export aid with a direct and immediate impact on trade, compelling reasons for urgency require it. Considering that this report proposes a simple codification of existing legislation without substantial amendments, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Union has close political and economic relations with Switzerland. Economic and trade relations between the EU and the Swiss Confederation are governed by a free trade agreement signed in 1972. In the interests of clarity and transparency of the law, the European Parliament has carried out a simple codification, without substantive change, of the safeguard measures provided for in this agreement. Access to the rule of law will therefore be simplified and the implementation of the agreement improved.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on the report on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on safeguard measures under the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. The safeguarding of national sovereignty is a priority for me. However, this proposal implies the limitation of imports of a product by supranational institutions. On the contrary, I consider trade policy to be one of the areas of regality that should remain in the hands of the state alone.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I am happy to support this report as it simply codifies existing texts without any substantial change.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 This codification is a positive step in the ongoing process of creating more supervision in European legislation.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against the codification of all the texts, because we are not given the opportunity to intervene in the substance of these provisions, which means that we must accept them as they stand.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. The purpose of this proposal is the codification of Council Regulation (EEC) No 2841/72 of 19 December 1972 on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation in order to provide greater clarity and accessibility to EU law. The conclusions of the Legal Services of the three institutions confirm that the codifications are correct and that, therefore, this coding proposal will give greater clarity and effectiveness to the provisions contained in the Agreement.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 After examination of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council which aims to codify the Regulation on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation, it is noted that the proposal is effectively limited to a pure and simple codification, without amending the substance of the acts subject to it.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on this issue because I believe that such a decision must remain the responsibility of national bodies, especially when we know the importance of cross-border relations between France and Switzerland.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this report is to codify previous legislation on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. In 1987, the European Commission decided to ask its services that all acts should be codified no later than 10 amendments in order to make EU legislation more accessible and easier to understand by the ordinary citizen, which would allow it new opportunities and the possibility to benefit from the specific rights granted to it. This objective cannot be achieved as long as there is a scattering of numerous provisions, amended on several occasions, often substantially, which requires a reading of both the original act and the acts amending it. For this reason, and in order to ensure the clarity and transparency of the law, it is necessary to codify the rules which have been frequently changed. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein, fully preserving the content of the codified acts and introducing only the formal changes required by the coding process itself. This is therefore an eminently technical change.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this speech. This is only a mere codification for the safeguard measures in the EU-Switzerland agreement which are potentially a useful tool for both parties.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the codification of all the texts, because we are not given the opportunity to intervene in the substance of these provisions, which means that we must accept them as they stand.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as the proposal fully preserves the content of the act being codified.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I would like to thank Mr Duda for his report on the proposal for a regulation on the safeguard measures provided for in the agreement with the Swiss Confederation. This type of parliamentary act, which Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs carries out in close cooperation with the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the three institutions, is an important instrument for the advancement and updating of Community law, enabling the existing texts to be codifying.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Duda report, given it simply concerns a codification to take into account changes in the relationship between the EU and Switzerland.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on the safeguard measures in the agreement with the Swiss Confederation.  It was really just a codification, but I believe that safeguard measures, in that they are commercial defences against possible unfair competition, are rendered sterile by the European Union.  The practice shows that the European Union does little to defend the interests of its Member States in the face of the actions of third countries.  This prerogative should therefore fall within the exclusive competence of the Member States, in order to better protect our economy and our jobs.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my Labour colleagues, supported this report on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement with the Swiss Confederation as the proposal is a straightforward codification of existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. The proposal is of a technical technical nature aimed at codifying existing legislation.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour since the proposal is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without any substantial modification thereof.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on safeguards provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation, as codification contributes to the clarity and certainty of EUROPEAN Union law, and underlines the importance of bringing Union law closer to all citizens and its transparency. I believe that the European Union must ensure a simpler and more efficient finding and understanding of its legal acts, and I believe that codification is heading in this direction.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This proposed regulation by the European Parliament and the Council concerns safeguards under the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. This proposal echoes that adopted by the Commission on the same subject. These safeguards contain various advantages, such as a form of protectionism, and put in place uniform conditions. However, safeguards must remain a national jurisdiction and are by no means a supranational power. Although some of the proposed measures are very positive, the substance of the text is not acceptable. So I preferred to abstain.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Andrzej Duda's report on safeguards under the agreement between the EEC and the Swiss Confederation. As part of the effort to simplify European law, the aim here is to codify a set of existing provisions on the subject, in order to integrate them into a single, clearer and simpler text. This report was adopted by a very large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the european Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on safeguard measures under the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. The proposal deals with the modalities for the implementation of the safeguard clauses and precautionary measures provided for in Articles 22-27 of the agreement between the European Economic Community and Switzerland, signed in Brussels on 22 July 1972. It is therefore limited to a codification of existing texts, without altering the substance.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. The report is a codification of existing legislation with the aim of making it more accessible and easier to understand. I support this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it is simply a codification to take into account changes in the relationship between the EU and Switzerland.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr Duda's report on the codification of existing texts, on the basis of the examination of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council codifying Council Regulation (EEC) No 2841/72 of 19 December 1972 on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. This report on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on safeguard measures under the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation aims to codify the Council of 19 December 1972 with a constant right and without substantial change in the substance of regulation (EEC) No. 2841/72 of the Council of 19 December 1972.  While this proposal for codification does not bring anything new on the substance, it must be remembered that policies on safeguard measures, i.e. trade defences, must remain within the competence of the Member States and not remain in the hands of the European Commission, whose harmful policy on international trade is known. This is all the more important because it is a country bordering France. So I decided to abstain.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained because if the safeguard measures are legitimate, since they are trade defence measures, I believe that they should be the sovereignty of each state and not of the European Union.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on the proposal on the safeguard measures in the agreement with the Swiss Confederation. It is a matter of codifying them. But I cannot support that kind of initiative. Indeed, since a safeguard measure is a trade defence measure, it must of course remain a national competence. The European Union seeks to subject Member States to its decisions.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because it is merely a codification of the clean-up agreements and therefore the substance does not change.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ It is in the interest of the European Union that all documents be transparent and accessible so that citizens can understand them more easily. That is why, where necessary, EU documents are codified. The Commission's proposal to codify the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation concerns the amendment of the existing text without affecting the content of the Agreement. An agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation was signed in 1972 with a view to developing economic relations by ensuring a level playing field and removing existing barriers to free trade. I support The Report of MeP Andrzej Duda, which is based on the opinion of the advisory groups of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on this report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and Switzerland because it is not sufficient and comprehensive.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the adoption of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council codifying Regulation (EEC) No 2841/72 of the Council of 19 December 1972 on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. I note that the proposal is a straightforward codification of existing texts, without any change in their substance.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote: although it is good, this measure should remain the responsibility of the Member States and should not be decided at European level. That is why we abstained.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to initiate the codification of the Council Regulation on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation.  It is of great importance to preserve in full the substance of the acts codified and brought together, making the formal changes necessary for the codification work, so as to make European legislation simple and clearly worded, comprehensible and accessible to all citizens.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. As this is a pure codification without any change in content, I have approved this draft.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Codification consists of grouping normative texts of various natures into collections concerning a given subject with the aim of simplification, clarity and transparency. The Commission's proposal is to codify the safeguards regulation on the Association Agreement between the EU and the Swiss Confederation.  It should be remembered that association agreements are only intended to impose free trade on our neighbours. These undemocratic technocratic procedures prevent Europe from practising solidarity protectionism, which is the ecological and social emergency of our time. So even if it is only a technical report, I am voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EEC) No 2841/72 of 19 December 1972 on the protective measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. This proposal fully preserves the content of the codified acts, but merely gathers them and only with the formal changes required by the codification process itself.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerns the codification of texts regarding the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. Therefore I voted in favour of this report as codification of European legislation is essential for transparency and citizen involvement in EU decision-making.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the Duda report on Safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement with the Swiss Confederation.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Successive amendments to Council Regulation (EEC) No 2841/72 justify the codification of the Council for reasons of certainty and legal clarity. The Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation, hereinafter referred to as the 'Agreement', signed on 22 July 1972, lacks rules for the implementation of the safeguard clauses and precautionary measures provided for in Articles 22 to 27 of the Agreement. The application of the bilateral safeguard clauses of the Agreement requires uniform conditions for the adoption of safeguard measures, measures which should comply with Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 of the European Parliament and the Council. I voted in favour of this amendment because I believe that the Commission should adopt implementing acts immediately applicable if, in duly justified cases relating to the situations referred to in Articles 24, 24a and 26 of the Agreement or in the case of export aid having a direct and immediate impact on trade, urgent requirements so require.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The aim of this report on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on safeguard measures under the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation is to codify the Council of 19 December 1972 with a constant right and without substantial change in the substance of regulation (EEC) No. 2841/72.  While this proposal for codification does not bring anything new on the substance, it must be remembered that policies on safeguard measures, i.e. trade defences, must remain within the competence of the Member States and not remain in the hands of the European Commission, whose harmful policy on international trade is known. This is all the more important because it is a country bordering France. Therefore, I cannot vote in favour of this text. So I decided to abstain.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it is simply to give Parliament’s consent to the Union acceding to this Convention, which has already been ratified by the Member States individually.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the safeguard measures in the bilateral agreement between the EEC and the Swiss Confederation. It is a purely technical codification text aimed at simplifying the existing law and carrying the same legal consequences as the original version. The aim of this agreement is to regulate the trade relations between the two institutions.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this report on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation, convinced that the privileged relationship that the European Union and Switzerland have been able to build in recent years has so far had beneficial effects on the economy of both contracting parties. Specifically, the opinion of the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of Parliament, the Council and the Commission considered, since the proposal is limited to re-codification of the texts, to proceed by common accord with the reformulation by not identifying any legal obstacle. However, it is important to stress, in addition to the full legal conformity of the proposal for a regulation, also the political and economic value of the union between the European Union and Switzerland, not forgetting that one of the countries that benefits most is Italy. In the hope that trade relations will remain flourishing in the future, and that certain protectionist demands on the Swiss side will not be followed up, we reiterate our approval of a legally formal but politically significant act.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation as it clarifies a number of procedural mechanisms governing the relationship with the Swiss State.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the safeguard measures because they are essentially mere codifications of existing measures and the other aspects also seem worthy of support, since neither the European Union or its Member States nor Switzerland, as contracting parties, are unfairly penalised.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported.  This proposal is limited to the codification of existing legislation without any substantive changes.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. The law must be clear and transparent. Citizens must be able to make proper use of the specific rights conferred on them. It is therefore essential to make EU legislation simpler, clearer and more accessible. It should be noted that the new regulation will not change the content of the codified legislation, but only changes to the form necessary for codification will be made.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒in 2012 Council Regulation No. 2841/72/EEC on the safeguards laid down in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation was adopted on 19 December 1972 and changed on several occasions.  Back in 1987, the Commission established a rule that, after a dozen amendments to a particular act, it must be codified, thus contributing to greater certainty of the correct application of the act. The basic Regulation has been amended in the section relating to the rules in trade, including the implementation of the safeguard clause and the safeguards laid down in the Agreement. The implementation of bilateral safeguard clauses in the Treaty requires uniform conditions for the adoption of safeguards. This means that those measures need to be adopted in accordance with Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 of the European Parliament and the Council as of 16 February 2011 on the establishment of rules and general principles concerning member states' control mechanisms over the exercise of the Commission's implementing powers.  It is an act that has meaning in regulating trade between the EU and the Swiss Confederation. Due to the need for its correct application both between countries and stakeholders to which this Regulation has the legal effect, I consider the proposed codification necessary because it contributes to greater legal certainty of the application of the act.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. This is a codification of safeguards. These are trade defence measures that must remain a national jurisdiction, not a supranational one, although, on the merits, I would not necessarily be opposed to them. That is why, refusing to recognise the Competence of the European Union in this matter but not wanting to oppose these measures head-on, I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Since, according to the Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes, I support Rapporteur Duda's proposal to adopt a position at first reading, taking on a Commission proposal adapted in line with the recommendations of the Advisory Group on legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support MeP Andrzej Duda's report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on safeguards provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation, as the Advisory Group of legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission pointed out that the proposal is limited to codifying existing texts without substantive changes. The purpose of this proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EEC) No 2020/2013. 2841/72 of 1972, which has been subject to amendments several times. The new regulation will replace the various acts enshrined in it. This proposal transfers the content of codifying acts and consolidates them into a single act only with the formal amendments necessary for codification, which contributes to transparency and transparency.  The European Parliament hereby supports a simplification that will make Union law clearer and more accessible to citizens of the European Union. I welcome the continued efforts of parliament's professional services, the Council and the Commission in codification procedures.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation because, according to the opinion issued on 17.9.2014 by the Consultative Group of Legal Services of the EP, EC, and Council, the proposal for a regulation is simply a codification of the existing texts , without any major changes.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I have expressed my support for the codification of the regulation on safeguard measures under the agreement with the Swiss Confederation. This inter-institutional procedure simplifies and clarifies the existing regulation.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 At the meeting of 10 July 2014, the Advisory Group, composed of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, reviewed the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council, which codifies Council Regulation (EEC) No 2841/72 of 19 December 1972 on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. It concluded, then, by common agreement, that the proposal under question should be based on a pure and simple codification of the existing texts, without substantive amendments. I voted, therefore, in favor.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. I and my colleagues supported the report on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on safeguard measures under the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the Committee on Legal Affairs considers that the proposal in question contains no substantive amendments other than those identified as such in the proposal, and that it is based on the pure and simple codification of the existing texts, without substantive amendments, there would be no reason to vote against.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. For the sake of simplification and clarity of EU law to make it more accessible and understandable to the citizen, I voted in favour of this Regulation codating Council Regulation (EEC) No 2841/72 of 19 December 1972 on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. The proposal is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without any substantial modification thereof.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The Council Regulation (EEC) 2841/72 between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation having been amended several times and substantially, it was necessary, in the interests of clarity and rationality, to codify it. That is the reason for the vote that took place yesterday in the plenary session.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal on the safeguard measures provided for in the agreement with the Swiss Confederation. The proposal presented to plenary is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because safeguard measures in the EU-Switzerland Agreement are potentially a useful tool for both parties.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report deals with the codification of Regulation (EEC) No 2481/72 of 19 December 1972 on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. A new Regulation aims to unify several acts held between the two parties over the years.  Although it presents itself as a matter relating, without content, to the legal certainty of EU acts on relations between the signatory parties, I have chosen to abstain in the vote because, in substance, these agreements are concluded to satisfy the interests of large multinationals and always harm most people on both sides.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We supported the report on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement with the Swiss Confederation as the proposal contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of adopting a resolution on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation, as the proposal proposed a clear and simple codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Taking into account the Commission's proposal addressed to the European Parliament and the Council, Interinstitutional agreement of 20 December 1994 on the accelerated method of work for the formal codification of legislative texts, and the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs (A8-0145/2015), I support this Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on safeguards provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation (codification).

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which is a codification to take into account changes in the relationship between the EU and Switzerland.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on safeguards provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation, since according to the Advisory Group of legal services of the European Parliament, Council and The Commission, that proposal is limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes and refers to the rules for the implementation of the safeguard clause and the safeguards laid down in Articles 22-27 of the Agreement between the European Economic Community and Switzerland , signed on 22 June 1972.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as it was only a codification of the legislation currently in force.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The codification of all the texts does not allow intervention in the substance of those provisions.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation (codified text). As an alternate member of the delegation responsible for relations with Switzerland and Norway and delegated to the EU-Iceland Joint Parliamentary Committee and the EEA Joint Parliamentary Committee, I consider it particularly important to draw attention to the fact that the amendments will make cooperation more effective. One of the main elements of this is the system of bilateral safeguards, the implementation of which requires that safeguard measures be adopted under uniform conditions. I think it is important to note that the European Parliament's work in the consultation process contributes in a tangible way to making the legislation more effective in a way that the electorate understands.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of My Colleague Duda's report and I am therefore in favour of the european Parliament and the Council's proposal for a regulation on safeguards under the agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the codification of the Agreement with Switzerland, as this is a technical requirement and this is the recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Although the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation signed an Association Agreement on 22 July 1972, the modalities for the application of the safeguard clauses and precautionary measures provided for in Articles 22 to 27 of the Agreement should be laid down. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the codification of Regulation (EEC) No 2481/72 of 19 December 1972 on safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. A new Regulation aims to unify several acts held between the two parties over the years.  As it is a matter relating, without content, to the legal certainty of EU acts on relations between the signatory parties, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims to codify Council Regulation (EEC) No 2841/72 of 19 December 1972 on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein, fully preserving the content of the codified acts and introducing only the formal changes required by the coding process itself. We have nothing to owe.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. As this is a pure codification without any change in content, I have approved this draft.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution on the EEC and Swiss agreement.  As is apparent from the competent legal services, this text does not provide for substantial amendments.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this report is the codification by the Council of Council Regulation (EEC) No 2841/72 of 19 December 1972 on the safeguard measures provided for in the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation. In 1987, the Commission decided to ask its services for all acts to be codified no later than 10 amendments, expressing the objective of making EU legislation more accessible and easier for ordinary citizens to understand. This objective cannot certainly be achieved as long as there is a scattering of numerous provisions, amended on several occasions, often substantially, which requires a reading of both the original act and the acts that alter it. The European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed, through an interinstitutional agreement of 20 December 1994, on an accelerated procedure that can be used for the rapid adoption of codified acts. The new Regulation will replace the various acts integrated therein, fully preserving the content of the codified acts, introducing only the formal changes required by the coding process itself. So we abstained.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it is an authorisation for the Council to conscover, on behalf of the Union, the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional access Services or based on such access. The Convention, promoted by the Council of Europe, refers to audiovisual and information society services which are subject to payment or conditional access, especially from the point of view of illegal reception for commercial purposes, which may also cause problems for public television and broadcasting services. These public services are of particular interest to us and we believe that they should be subject to special protection, so we consider that the Convention does not adequately address this aspect. However, its celebration is a positive step in ending illegal access to audiovisual services. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This draft legislative resolution aims to approve the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access And Conditional Access Services. By introducing administrative criminal sanctions, the convention aims to combat the piracy of encrypted television set-top boxes and to reduce the wide disparity between states. However, this convention is open to the participation of the European Union, which amounts to certifying the legal personality of the European Union. I therefore voted against this draft resolution.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Much of this convention duplicates Directive 98/84/EC, but in any case I believe that sovereign nations should legislate for themselves against piracy relating to conditional access services. This does not need to be enacted at European level and therefore I voted against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because the aim of this Convention is to extend the scope of the framework established by Directive 98/84/EC outside the Union in order to combat threats to protected services.

name: Janice Atkinson (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is the remit of the UK parliament to decide the rules, laws and regulations regarding so called ‘protected services’ such as the TV and radio. The UK parliament is much better placed to decide on legislation that protects, for example, the BBC than the European Parliament.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal. Directive 98/84/EC provides a common EU-wide legal basis for combating illegal measures that allow unauthorised access to pay-TV services and the effective protection of such services. Such protection means that any commercial activity relating to installations which enable the services to be used without the supplier's authorisation or before it is paid is unlawful and imposes penalties. Back in 1999 The Council launched the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Services based on conditional access and conditional access services. If the Convention were signed by the EU, this should encourage its ratification by more Member States of the Council of Europe and thus extend the legal protection of services based on conditional access beyond the EU.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report must have the European Parliament adopt the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the EU, of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access And Conditional Access Services. It is in fact a legal framework applicable to all EU Member States to combat illegal schemes that allow unleased access to and protection of pay-TV services. This convention takes up the essence of the 1998 directive. This directive was extended in 2001 to other non-EU countries within the framework of the Council of Europe. In addition, the EU takes Article 207 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (FUE Treaty) on the Common Trade Policy as a legal basis, even though the EU is not a member of the Council of Europe. So I voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with what is said in the Svoboda report, which analyses the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access Services. I believe that it is important to establish a European legal framework to combat un authorised access to television services provided for a fee: this legislation aims to protect radio, TV and web broadcasts. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the EU's ratification of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional access Services or based on such access, which will extend the scope of the legal framework established by Directive 98/84/EC and thus effectively combat infringements which infringe protected services. The need for extensive and effective protection of these services is particularly relevant, as many non-EU European States can provide shelters for the development and dissemination of conditional access-based service piracy devices, as no sanctions for this very specific type of piracy activity are provided in their legal system. It was therefore appropriate with this Convention to extend the scope of the provisions of Directive 98/84/EC and to create a common and effective framework at European level for the protection of those services. This Directive created a framework common to the EU as a whole to combat illicit devices that enable un authorised access to and effectively protect payment television services. This protection covers both traditional television and radio broadcasting and Internet transmission.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Parliament supports the conclusion of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Services based on conditional access and conditional access services. As early as 1999, the Council of Europe launched this European Convention, as comprehensive and effective protection of services based on conditional access and conditional access services is necessary. This Convention extends the Directive adopted by the Council and the European Parliament in 1998, which provides for a common legal basis for the fight for illegal measures available to the European Union as a whole against illegal measures which allow unauthorised access to pay-TV services and the effective protection of such services. Protection also applies to traditional television and radio broadcasting and their webcast. Many European countries outside the European Union can become a haven for the improvement and distribution of services based on conditional access, piracy measures, where their legal framework does not provide for sanctions for these very specific piracy activities. The application of the provisions of Directive 98/84/EC should therefore be extended and a common and effective system of protection for those services should be established at European level.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access and Conditional Access Services is an improvement on the excellent Directive 98/84/EC.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The ratification of this convention is open to the European Union, which amounts to approving the recognition of the legal personality of the European Union. Totally opposed to this recognition, which is the prelude to the creation of a genuine European federal state, I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the European Convention for the Legal Protection of Conditional Access Services and Conditional Access Services.  This Convention aims to ensure greater protection of conditional access services and conditional access services. Taking into account existing technological developments, as well as the fact that a number of European states, which are not part of the European Union, can be an enabling environment for the creation and development of conditional access-based service piracy devices, the Convention drawn up by the Council of Europe provides a broader legal framework for eliminating any illicit intent , over a wider area.  I welcome this initiative because it contributes to effectively combating threats to protected services.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of the Council's decision to approve the text of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access Services. In the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market, the text was adopted almost unanimously. The procedures for reaching this Convention began in 1999, when the Council authorised the European Commission to negotiate its contents in the Council of Europe. In practice, it is a text that seeks to establish a European legal framework to combat un authorised access to television services provided for a fee. These rules protect radio, television and Internet broadcasting.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted in favour of the Council's decision to approve the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access and Conditional Access Services. The Convention establishes a legislative framework to combat illegal schemes allowing unauthorized access to pay-TV services. There was an urgent need to reach an agreement to prevent the numerous frauds in this area. Our businesses must be protected and the principle of intellectual property respected. I voted in favour of the Council's decision.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access and Conditional Access Services.
