In the present case, I consider that: - many European States which are not members of the Union may provide refuge for the improvement and dissemination of conditional access service piracy arrangements, since their legal system does not provide for sanctions for that very specific piracy activity. It is therefore necessary to extend the provisions of the 1998 directive and to create a common and effective framework at European level for the protection of these services; - the Convention effectively extends the scope of the framework provided for in Directive 98/84/EC beyond the Union by combating threats to protected services; the conclusion of the Convention should therefore be approved; - the European Court of Justice, by judgment of 22 October 2013, ruled that the correct legal basis was Article 207 TFEI on the common commercial policy. As long as this case was pending, it was not possible to sign or approve the conclusion of the Convention on behalf of the Union; - as it is now possible, I voted for the conclusion of the Convention.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of this European Convention is to protect operators and providers of paid radio, television and online services against the illegal reception of such services. The Convention completes a similar Directive of the European Community by extending protection to the whole of Europe, and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access and Conditional Access Services would involve the recognition of the EU's legal personality, which would give the EU quasi-state status and represent a further step towards federalism. As a patriot, I support the sovereignty and will of the people. Therefore, I cannot be in favour of a European federal state.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 98/84/EC on the protection of conditional access services and conditional access services has established a common legal framework applicable throughout the Union for combating illegal devices allowing unauthorised access to television services offered against payment and effectively protecting those services. This protection extends both to conventional television and radio broadcasts and to broadcasts via the Internet.  In 1999, the Council of Europe began drafting a European convention on this subject and it was therefore necessary to extend the rules of the directive at European level and to create a common framework. The negotiations, conducted by the Commission on behalf of the EU, led to the adoption of the Convention in 2001. However, its adoption was blocked by a case pending between the Commission and the Council before the Court of Justice concerning the legal basis for the decision on signature. Following the Court's ruling, the Council adopted a new decision in April 2014. With this measure, Parliament approves the conclusion of the Convention. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access and Conditional Access Services complements and supplements European Directive 98/84/EC establishing a common legal framework applicable throughout the Union to combat illegal devices allowing unauthorised access to television services offered against payment and effectively protecting such services. I believe that the Accession of the European Union to this Convention would effectively expand the scope of the framework provided for in the directive mentioned above beyond the European Union, strengthening legal protection against threats to protected services.  Therefore, despite the difficulties in applying the procedural provisions in the Council of Europe, I have decided to vote in favour of this draft resolution on the grounds of the complementarity of the two reference texts.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This Convention on the legal protection of services based on, or consisting of, conditional access, created a common legal framework applicable throughout the EU for combating illicit devices which allow for unauthorised access to television services offered against payment and effectively protecting such services. As the Convention would effectively extend the scope of the framework provided by Directive 98/84/EC outside of the Union and thereby combat threats to protected services, I think that Parliament has to give its consent to the conclusion of the Convention, and I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access and Conditional Access Services. Recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access and Conditional Access Services.  I voted in favour because this report concerns the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access Services or Conditional Access Services and recommends that Parliament give its approval to the conclusion of the Convention. In 1999, the Council of Europe began to draw up a European Convention on the Legal Protection of These Services and the Commission represented the European Union during the negotiations. The Convention has the effect of extending the protection regime beyond the EU's borders.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the report as it is an authorisation for the Council to concover, on behalf of the Union, the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional access Services or based on such access. The Convention, promoted by the Council of Europe, refers to audiovisual and information society services which are subject to payment or conditional access, especially from the point of view of illegal reception for commercial purposes, which may also cause problems for public television and broadcasting services. Such public services are of particular interest to us and we believe that they should be subject to special protection, so we consider that the Convention does not adequately address this aspect. However, its celebration is a positive step in ending illegal access to audiovisual services. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This file is aimed at strengthening Directive 98/84/EC on the legal protection of services based on conditional access. This directive created a common legal framework applicable throughout the European Union for combating illicit devices which allow for unauthorised access to television services offered against payment and effectively protecting such services. This protection covers both television and radio broadcasting services and transmission by Internet. It was therefore necessary to extend the provisions of the 1998 Directive and to create a common and effective framework at European level for the protection of these services. The convention effectively extends the scope of the framework provided by Directive 98/84/EC outside of the European Union and thereby combat threats to protected services, hence I voted in favour of this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to approve the ratification of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access and Conditional Access Services. Considering that it is necessary to provide legal protection to all services whose remuneration depends on conditional access, i.e. subordinating access to the protected service to prior individual authorisation, and that it is equally important to combat any commercial activity relating to equipment that allows or facilitates access to services without authorisation or payment from the supplier and to put in place sanctions. , I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access and Conditional Access Services is based on the directive of the same name adopted by the European Union in 1998. Parliament's approval of the Council's decision on the Convention will finally allow for a common regulatory framework across the European continent to sanction the means of illegally accessing television and radio content. I welcome Parliament's vote in the direction of an effective fight against piracy. He stresses that television and radio services are not free of rights as long as they are available on the internet.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has agreed to the conclusion of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access and Conditional Access Services. This convention protects electronic paid services from piracy by prohibiting any commercial activity in the manufacture, distribution or advertising of smart cards and other devices to circumvent the protected access of paid television, radio and internet services. The Union already had a directive on this issue, but the ratification of the Convention allows it to take part in a larger set of states and to comply with the same rules as its council of Europe neighbours.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the recommendation on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access And Conditional Access Services. Once again, the Union wishes to be given a role which I consider to be reserved only for States. In order to preserve our national sovereignty, I voted against yet another attempt by the Union to regulate our markets.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I am happy to support this proposal as the Convention, in fact, extends the scope of the framework provided by Directive 98/84/EC to the field outside the Union, thereby combating threats to protected services.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly support this recommendation as it is essential for the proper functioning of the European integration process to combat the illegal misuse of radio and television services and the transmission of data over the internet. This does not only harm our economy, but also leads to indirect harm to the safety of citizens.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against this project as we believe that, under the pretext of the so-called fight against piracy, agendas aimed at censoring and promoting the interests of the major media are being promoted at the same time. Piracy in all its forms can be combated by existing legislation. But the crux of the problem, with regard to the piracy of subscription services, lies in the very principle of subscription services. That is to say, public goods for which the taxpayer often pays (e.g. football) are asked to pay again to enjoy them.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. This Council Decision relates to Directive 98/84/EC on the legal protection of conditional or access-based access services, which created a common legal framework applicable throughout the Union to combat devices en allowing un authorised access to television, broadcasting and internet television services.  This Convention was adopted in 2001 to be fully compatible with the Directive. However, before the Council could ask the Parliament to give its approval to this Convention, the European Commission took the case to the Court of Justice of the EU on the grounds that the Council had misused the legal basis of the Decision on the signing of the Convention (rather than using Article 207 TFEU, as proposed by the Commission, the Council had used Article 114 TFEU).

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation, because it implies full recognition of the legal personality of the European Union, to which I am totally opposed.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the adoption by the European Parliament of the Convention on the legal protection of services which are based on or consist of conditional access. By adopting Directive 98/84/EC, the EU exercised its competence in the areas covered by the Convention, except in Articles 6 (Loss Measures) and 8 (International Cooperation), which cover topics such as international cooperation, civil procedure and confiscation measures. The Convention should therefore be approved by both the EU and its Member States. The Convention is the object of information society services and broadcasting services provided for remuneration and which are based on or consist of conditional access. The purpose of this Convention is to make illegal, within the territory of the Parties, a number of activities (identified in Article 4) that allow unauthorized access to protected services, as well as to approximate the laws of the Parties in this field. Understanding the scope and general purposes of the Convention and generally accepting them, we consider that the matter under this report is not exempt from other consequences, which go beyond those set out in the text of the Convention.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of the text of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access Services. The text of the Convention provides for the establishment of a European legal framework to combat un authorised access to television services provided for a fee.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this project as I believe that, under the pretext of the so-called fight against piracy, agendas aimed at censoring and promoting the interests of the major media are being promoted at the same time. Piracy in all its forms can be combated by existing legislation. But the crux of the problem, with regard to the piracy of subscription services, lies in the very principle of subscription services. That is to say, public goods for which the taxpayer often pays (e.g. football) are asked to pay again to enjoy them.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Council was able to adopt a decision on 14 April 2014 on the signing on behalf of the Union of the Convention, but since the new legal basis concerns matters falling under exclusive competences of the Union, the possibility to conclude the Convention of behalf of the Union was questioned. As a consequence, the draft Council decision, for which the consent of Parliament has been requested, now includes an annex in which the Union declares that it fully recognises the objectives pursued by the Convention, but also expresses its concern regarding the application of those procedural provisions, on the basis of its exclusive competence. Taking into account that it is not possible to renegotiate the Cconvention in order to address this problem – which in any event falls within the field of external representation of the Union, for which the Council and the Commission are primarily responsible – and with reference to the fact that the Convention would effectively extend the scope of the framework provided by Directive 98/84/EC outside of the Union and thereby combat threats to protected services, I voted in favour of giving consent to the conclusion of the Convention.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, after the Council's approval, was asked for approval with regard to the conclusion by the EU of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access and Conditional Access Services. It is a convention that combats hacking and electronics, while protecting operators in the sector and consumers. That is why I voted 'yes' to the recommendation.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. Mr Swoboda has given us an important report which I wholeheartedly approved, which refers to the conclusion of a new Convention on Conditional Access Services. With this conviction, it will be possible to extend the scope of the legal framework of the fundamental 1998 directive regulating the fight against illegal devices capable of retransmissioning television services. With the Convention, the prevention of such abuses will also be stronger at international level; it is an important signal to defend legitimate consumer rights on an ever-increasing scale.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I welcome the outcome of today's vote by the EP to conclude a convention on the legal protection of services based on or consisting of conditional access, creating a common legal framework for the protection of services covering both classic television and radio broadcasts and those over the internet.  The legal systems of many non-EU countries in Europe do not cover the consequences of improving and disseminating pirated devices based on conditional access. Therefore, the extension of the provisions of the 1998 Directive and the creation of a common and effective European framework for the protection of these services is paramount.  As the Court of Justice has established, the appropriate legal position for the decision to sign the Convention is Article 207 TFEU on a common commercial policy falling under the exclusive competence of the Union. For this reason, the possibility of concluding a Convention on behalf of the Union has been called into question because it is not a member of the Council of Europe. Nevertheless, I agree with the rapporteur that the conclusion of this Convention should be agreed and the framework provided for in Directive 98/84/EC should be extended to an area outside the Union, thereby combating threats to protected services.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Svoboda report giving Parliament’s consent to the Union acceding to this Convention, which has already been ratified by the Member States individually.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my Labour colleagues, supported this report as it gives Parliament’s consent for the EU accede to this Convention, which has already been ratified by the individual Member States.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft European Convention on the Legal Protection of Services based on Conditional Access and Conditional Access Services on behalf of the European Union, as such a decision is based on European Union legislation and is not contrary to the case-law of the Court of Justice of the European Union.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the signature, on behalf of the Union, of the European Convention on the Redress of Services based on conditional access or services providing conditional access, as this gives consent for the conclusion of an agreement that will allow smooth continuation of work in this area. Consent is also in line with the position of the ALDE Group. The need for the Consent of the European Parliament further strengthens democratic processes within the European Union and its credibility.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This draft legislative resolution aims to approve the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access And Conditional Access Services. Administrative criminal sanctions will be put in place to combat the piracy of encrypted tv set-top boxes and to reduce the great disparity between states. This convention also amounts to certifying the legal personality of the European Union, which in my view remains unacceptable. I voted against this draft resolution for all these reasons.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Pavel Svoboda's report on the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access Services, which makes it possible to combat piracy of audiovisual, radio and paid services on the internet more effectively. It also brings the different laws closer together between Member States in this area. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access And Conditional Access Services. The main purpose of this recommendation is to provide legal protection to all services whose remuneration depends on conditional access, i.e. subordinating access to the protected service to prior individual authorization.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. The report provides for better protection of radio and TV services from unauthorized access. In the spirit of the high standards relating to copyright, I am voting in favour of this motion.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it simply gives Parliament’s consent to the Union acceding to this Convention, which has already been ratified by the Member States individually.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I supported Mr Svoboda's report on the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access and Conditional Access Services. In view of the great disparity that exists today in the European States in the field of legislation on the protection of these services, I am convinced of the need to pursue a common policy aimed at harmonising legislation in this area.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. This report aims to get the European Parliament to adopt the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the EU, of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access And Conditional Access Services. It is in fact a legal framework applicable to all EU Member States to combat illegal schemes that allow unleased access to and protection of pay-TV services. In fact, this convention takes up the essence of the 1998 directive on the subject. Since some European states are not members of the EU, the EU wanted to extend the directive to these countries, which was done in 2001 within the framework of the Council of Europe. However, I formally challenge the possibility of the EU concluding this convention on behalf of the Union, denying it any legal personality. Moreover, the legal basis chosen by the ECJ is that of Article 207 of the FUE Treaty on the Common Trade Policy, an area under the exclusive competence of the EU, even though the EU is not a member of the Council of Europe. I have decided to vote against this text.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. In 1999, the Council of Europe undertook the drafting of a European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional or Access-Based Access Services. Many non-EU European states could provide shelters for the development and dissemination of piracy devices for services based on conditional access, since no sanctions for this very specific type of piracy activity were provided in their legal system. It was necessary to extend the scope of the provisions of the 1998 Directive and to create a common framework at European level. The Convention, adopted in 2001, is fully compatible with the Directive. For this reason, I voted in favour of the conclusion of the Convention.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the centralist regulation of these matters. If TV companies feel damaged by some software or devices, they cannot enforce product regulation, but they have to go to court.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ With the emergence of new technologies, piracy is advancing and poses a major problem in the Member States. We should warn about the consequences of piracy and the use of copied products and services. The quality of pirated products is well below standard, and it deprives the creative community that creates them of the reward for work and effort.  This problem requires the actions of state institutions, administration, business sector, but also consumers. By using the Services illegally, consumers are at risk of identity theft and possible criminal charges. In most Member States, awareness-raising activities are being launched to combat and combat the consequences of piracy. I supported Swoboda's recommendation on a convention dealing with services related to broadcasting and information societies offering their services for compensation and based on conditional access and stating what should be considered an infringement. The signing of the Convention supports a common policy of protection of these services and legislation that prevents illegal activities related to conditional access services through sanctions.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Services based on or consisting of conditional access, because it creates an integrated framework for combating the movement of illegal devices that make it possible to unauthorised access to television services provided for payment.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Accepting this convention would mean recognising the European Union as a legal personality, which we strongly oppose. So I voted against it.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against illicit devices allowing unauthorised access to television services offered against payment and the protection of such services is of paramount importance to the Union. This protection extends both to conventional television and radio broadcasts and to broadcasts via the Internet. It is necessary to avoid the creation of shelters for the improvement and dissemination of piracy devices for conditional access services and to create a common and effective framework at European level for the protection of these services. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the proposal for the conclusion of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional access services or based on such access.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. As the report on the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Access Controlled Services and Access Control Services is a protection against unauthorised access to radio and TV services, I have given my assent to it.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Conditional access refers to a system by broadcasting to limit access to certain channels, programs or services to one or more subscribers or users. It combines broadcasting or transmission equipment, reception devices or communication terminals, set-top boxes, decryptors with individual identification support (subscription card, IP address control, software and updated database, etc.). A directive on the legal protection of conditional access services was adopted in 1998. It prohibits any commercial activity in the manufacture, distribution or advertising of smart cards and other devices to circumvent protected access to paid television, radio and internet services. In order to extend the provisions of the 1998 directive and to create a common and effective framework at European level, the Council of Europe drafted a European convention on conditional access services in 2001. The report proposes to approve this convention. I'm voting for.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Directive has created a common legal framework for the whole of the European Union for the fight against illicit devices allowing unauthorised access to paid television services and for the effective protection of such services. The protection covers both classical television and radio broadcasting and internet broadcasting. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation as it will lead to the creation of a common and effective framework at European level that will combat illicit devices that hack into conditional access services.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Svoboda Report in order to give my consent to the European Convention on the legal protection of services based on, or consisting of, conditional access.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Council decision relates to Directive 98/84/EC of the European Parliament and the Council of 20 November 1998 on the legal protection of services based on or consisting of conditional access, which created the legal framework common to Member States on measures to combat illicit devices providing unauthorised access to protected services. This protection includes broadcasting and broadcasting services, via internet, television and radio. Having overcome the contentious dispute which has prevented the conclusion of the Convention so far, I approve the Draft Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the signing, on behalf of the European Union, of the European Convention on the legal protection of services based on or consisting of conditional access.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to have the European Parliament adopt the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the EU, of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access And Conditional Access Services. It is in fact a legal framework applicable to all EU Member States to combat illegal schemes that allow unleased access to and protection of pay-TV services. In fact, this convention takes up the essence of the 1998 directive on the subject. Since some European states are not members of the EU, the EU wanted to extend the directive to these countries, which was done in 2001 within the framework of the Council of Europe. However, I formally challenge the possibility of the EU concluding this convention on behalf of the Union, denying it any legal personality. Moreover, the legal basis chosen by the ECJ is that of Article 207 of the FUE Treaty on the Common Trade Policy, an area under the exclusive competence of the EU, even though the EU is not a member of the Council of Europe.  In these circumstances, I have decided to vote against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it is simply to give Parliament’s consent to the Union acceding to this Convention, which has already been ratified by the Member States individually.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access And Conditional Access Services. This report endorses the conclusion of this Convention, which aims to create an effective common framework at European level to combat illegal means of access to pay tv and radio services, particularly when transmitted via the internet.  The Council of Europe drafted its first text in 1999, which was challenged by the European Commission. The European Court ruled in favour of the Commission in an October 2013 ruling. The Council therefore adopted a new decision in April 2014, which was welcomed by the European Parliament.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this recommendation on the conclusion of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access and Conditional Access Services because we are strongly convinced of the need for the European Union to have a stable legal framework valid for all countries.  In our opinion, it is necessary that offences due to unauthorised access to pay-TV services should be treated clearly throughout the continent. It is no longer acceptable, at such an advanced stage of European integration, for some Member States to become free zones for the development and distribution of instruments that are used to circumvent the costs of watching a particular television or radio channel.  The Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access Services, adopted in 2001, is perfectly compatible with Community regulations and directives, and we agree with the position of the Council which co-signed the Convention on 14 April 2014.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the European Convention for the Legal Protection of Conditional Access Services and Conditional Access Services. The European Convention was adopted on 24 January 2001 and entered into force on 1 July 2003 and consists of a number of rules similar to Directive 98/84/EC. The approval of this recommendation sends a message of support for the Convention beyond the EU's borders.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. The security of digital data traffic is becoming increasingly important, and in this context the security of radio and television services is becoming increasingly the focus of public perception. This Convention is about the protection of such services from unauthorized access. As the regulation is about a real improvement in the level of protection, I have voted in favour of the agreement.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation, which establishes the European Parliament's agreement to the conclusion of the Convention on the Legal Protection of Audiovisual and Information Services which operate on the basis of conditional access. Among other things, the Convention provides for provisions for the production, importation, distribution, leasing, possession or maintenance of illicit material for commercial purposes, and is fully in line with the existing 98/84/EC directive on these same services. I have not seen a valid reason to oppose this agreement.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The draft resolution provides for the consent to the accession of the Convention on behalf of the EU. The Convention provides for the protection of services offered on television, radio and the Internet against equipment and activities which would allow access to services without payment of money. With the Convention, the EU is extending the scope of its regulation of the same nature across Europe and also sends a positive signal to other countries considering accession to the Convention.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the conclusion of the Convention, as a common and effective system of protection for these services needs to be established at European level. There should be an effective common legal framework for combating illegal measures that allow unauthorised access to pay-TV services and effective protection of such services. The comprehensive and effective protection of conditional access-based services and conditional access services is necessary, taking into account the specificity of these piracy activities.  It is necessary to harmonise the provisions of states on measures against unlawful measures which may unauthorised access to protected services, thus preventing illegal activities. Providers of conditional access services or services based on conditional access must have access to appropriate legal instruments and an effective redress mechanism must be established.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Council of Europe adopted the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Services based on Conditional Access or Services providing Conditional Access and entered into force on 1 July 2003.  Given that European legislation does not have jurisdiction over non-EU countries and given the fact that investments in the development of television, radio and internet services are only possible if clear and fair rules are respected and illegal and unauthorised access to those services is prevented, I supported the Council's decision to sign the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Services based on conditional access or services providing conditional access , as it creates an international legal basis for creating a common and effective framework for the protection of these services.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. To vote in favour of this convention would be to recognise the legal personality of the European Union. There is, of course, no question for me to comment on this because I consider that only States can be parties to conventions. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support colleague Swoboda's report on the draft Council decision on the signature, on behalf of the Union, of the European Convention on the Redress of services based on conditional access or services providing conditional access giving consent to the conclusion of the agreement. The Judgment of the European Court of Justice, the European Convention on the Redress of Services Based on Conditional Access or services providing conditional access and the Council Decision 2014/243/EU of 14 April 2014 on the signature, on behalf of the European Union, of the European Convention on the Redress of Services based on conditional access or services providing conditional access has already confirmed this position and there is no reason why the European Parliament should not give its consent to the conclusion of the agreement.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support fellow MEP Pavel Swoboda's report on the Recommendation on the Draft Decision of the Council on the Signature, on behalf of the Union, of the European Convention on the Redress of Services based on conditional access or services providing conditional access. After certain procedural difficulties, we will finally get a legislation framework that corresponds to the real state of multiple complex protection of services based on conditional access or services that provide conditional access. This decision relies on Directive 98/84/EC of 1998, which arose from the need to combat illicit devices that allow unauthorised access to television services without payment for them, and in addition to the protection of television services, it also implies the protection of radio services as well as transmission over the Internet. The legislation framework that already existed has been well complemented to suit modern conditions of issue, for example the Convention defines more closely the offence of producing illicit funds, in addition to providing a much clearer definition of sanctions established for activities defined as illegal.  Finally, I believe that the conclusion of the Convention will indeed send a strong signal and help extend the provisions of Directive 98/84/EC beyond the EU's borders, creating a comprehensive legislation on services based on a conditional approach applicable across Europe.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the conclusion of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access and Conditional Access Services following the judgment of the Court of Justice and the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In order to combat internet piracy and protect access to paid television, radio and internet services, I voted for Parliament's recommendation for the conclusion of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access And Conditional Access Services.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 20 November 1998, the Council and the European Parliament adopted Directive 98/84/EC on the legal protection of services based on or consisting of conditional access. At issue was the establishment of a common legal framework for the whole Union to combat illicit devices allowing unauthorised access to television services provided for consideration. This protection covers both classical television and radio broadcasting and internet broadcasting. On 24 January 2001, a Council of Europe Convention on This Matter was adopted in terms perfectly compatible with that Directive. It turns out, however, that, in the judgment of 22 October 2013, the Court held that the Council decision on the signature of the Convention was based on an incorrect legal basis (Article 114 TFEU instead of Article 207 thereof).  Following that decision, the Council then re-adopted the legal basis by adopting a new decision with a view to the adoption of the Convention on behalf of the Union. At the end of this procedure, this resolution is precisely to approve the european Parliament's adoption of this Convention. I voted in favour.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. MEPs adopted the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access and Conditional Access Services in plenary.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a Convention that stems from the time in which we live, relating to access to information and entertainment services (TV, radio and Internet) for payment. In essence, this Convention comes to find common legislation on a range of activities that allow unauthorised access to certain protected services. More specifically, this protection will consist of declaring as illegal all commercial activity related to equipment that allows or facilitate access to these services without authorization or payment to the provider of the same, establishing the appropriate penalties. It is about providing legal protection to service providers, while ensuring their quality.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the conclusion by the EU of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional access services or based on such access, which will extend the scope of the legal framework established by Directive 98/84/EC and thus effectively combat infringements which infringe protected services. The need for extensive and effective protection of these services is particularly relevant, as many non-EU European States can provide shelters for the development and dissemination of conditional access-based service piracy devices, as no sanctions for this very specific type of piracy activity are provided in their legal system. It was therefore appropriate to extend with this Convention the scope of the provisions of Directive 98/84/EC and to create a common and effective framework at European level for the protection of those services. This Directive created a framework common to the EU as a whole to combat illicit devices that enable un authorised access to and effectively protect payment television services. This protection covers both traditional television and radio broadcasting and internet transmission.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this Council decision, which relates to Directive 98/84/EC, which establishes a common legal framework applicable throughout the UNION to combat illegal schemes that allow unauthorized access to pay-TV services.  In 1999, the Council of Europe drafted a European convention on the legal protection of conditional access and conditional access services. As many non-EU European states could provide safe havens for the development or dissemination of hacking devices for such services, it was therefore necessary to create a common framework effective at European level for the protection of such services.  However, before the Council could ask Parliament to approve the convention, the Commission referred the matter to the Court of Justice on the grounds that the Council had based its decision on the signing of the convention on an erroneous legal basis. As long as the matter was pending, it was not possible to sign or approve the agreement on behalf of the Union. In October 2013, the Court issued a ruling in favour of the Commission, and the Council was forced to adopt a new decision in April 2014.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access and Conditional Access Services. This Convention was adopted in 2001, with the aim of creating an effective common framework at European level for the protection of these services from illegal devices allowing unauthorised access to pay-TV and radio services. However, Parliament was unable to approve the conclusion of the Convention, on behalf of the European Union, until 2013.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because the text, which was adopted almost unanimously in the Committee on Legal Affairs, seeks to establish a European legal framework, which is currently missing, in order to avoid un authorised access to paid radio and television services.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it is an authorisation for the Council to conscover, on behalf of the Union, the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional access Services or based on such access. The Convention, promoted by the Council of Europe, refers to audiovisual and information society services which are subject to payment or conditional access, especially from the point of view of illegal reception for commercial purposes, which may also cause problems for public television and broadcasting services. These public services are of particular interest to us and we believe that they should be subject to special protection, so we consider that the Convention does not adequately address this aspect. However, its celebration is a positive step in ending illegal access to audiovisual services. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of this report as it simply gives Parliamentʼs consent to the European Union acceding to this convention, which has already been ratified by the Member States individually.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Services based on conditional access or consisting of conditional access on behalf of the European Union, because before this resolution was adopted, European states that are not members of the EU could provide a refuge for the development or distribution of facilities for hacking these services.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Taking into account the recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs, Council Decision 2014/243/EU of 14 April 2014 and Directive 98/84/EC of the European Parliament and the Council of 20 November 1998, I support this Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the signature, on behalf of the Union, of the European Convention on the Redress of Services based on conditional access or services providing conditional access.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which gives Parliament’s consent to the European Union acceding to the European Convention on the legal protection of services based on, or consisting of, conditional access.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Many non-EU countries can provide "support" for the development and distribution of hacking devices into conditional access services, thus providing unauthorised access to protected services, especially if their legal system does not provide for sanctions against this very specific hacking method. Given that this directive provides for the extension of provisions beyond the EU's borders, which would create rules and a commonly effective framework that would be applicable throughout Europe, I supported the Report as it guarantees the protection of services based on conditional access or services providing conditional access.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal. Since I am in favour of the protection of private property, I do not consider it right that paid services in which the providers of those services have invested a large amount of own resources can be fraudulently accessed free of charge.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Pirate can be combated by existing legislation. The crux of the problem of the piratery of subscription services lies in the very principle of subscription services.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional Access And Conditional Access Services.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a Recommendation on the Council's draft decision to sign the European Convention on the Redress of Services based on conditional access or services providing conditional access. The Convention extends the legislative scope adopted by the Directive on the Legal Protection of Services, with which the Law on Electronic Media in the Republic of Croatia is harmonised, which regulates the rights and obligations of those persons engaged in the activities of providing radio or television services as well as services through electronic communications networks. The Convention extends the scope of legislative provisions to outside the Union or non-Member States, with a view to combating illegal devices that threaten the broadcasting of television, radio or other information society services. Countries outside the European Union may constitute genuine oases for the manufacture, distribution or sale of illicit devices that provide access to a protected service for commercial purposes, so I consider that the legal measures to be applied to such actions must be primarily preventive and effective in order to achieve the withdrawal of illegal devices from trade flows.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation on a draft Council decision on the legal protection of services based on conditional access or involving conditional access. The EU Council Decision creates a common legal framework in the EU to combat prohibited devices that allow unauthorised access to television services available for consideration. In the legislative process itself, there has been a different interpretation of the law between the Commission and the Council of the EU, which is about the signature of the Convention itself.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution, which states that the European Parliament must participate fully in the monitoring and implementation of human rights and all actions to correct inequality in their access. We find the adoption of two key pieces of legislation fundamental: the European Accessibility Act and the General Anti-Discrimination Directive, both being an essential part of the implementation of the UN Convention. The resolution also calls on Member States to reflect the obligations under article 12 of the UN Convention on National Laws and more specifically, as well as the right of all persons with disabilities to vote and be elected.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. This convention is open to the participation of the European Union. However, this is tantamount to recognising the legal personality of the European Union. I'm voting against it.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs that Parliament approve the conclusion of the Convention. It lays down a regulatory framework almost identical to Directive 98/84/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council on the legal protection of conditional access-based or access-based services.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This Convention creates a common European legal framework applicable throughout the Union to combat illicit devices that provide access to payment television services. It is important to vote in favour for the EU to approve this Convention.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it is an authorisation for the Council to conscover, on behalf of the Union, the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Conditional access Services or based on such access. The Convention, promoted by the Council of Europe, refers to audiovisual and information society services which are subject to payment or conditional access, especially from the point of view of illegal reception for commercial purposes, which may also cause problems for public television and broadcasting services. These public services are of particular interest to us and we believe that they should be subject to special protection, so we consider that the Convention does not adequately address this aspect. However, its celebration is a positive step in ending illegal access to audiovisual services. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the adoption by the European Parliament of the Convention on the legal protection of services which are based on or consist of conditional access. The Convention should be adopted by both the Union and its Member States. The Declaration on the division of powers between the Union and its Member States is included in the Annex to the Council Decision. The Convention is the object of information society services and broadcasting services provided for remuneration and which are based on or consist of conditional access. The purpose of this Convention is to make illegal, within the territory of the Parties, a certain number of activities allowing unauthorized access to protected services and bringing the laws of the Parties in this area closer together.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. As the report on the European Convention on the Legal Protection of Access Controlled Services and Access Control Services is a protection against unauthorised access to radio and TV services, I have given my assent to it.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation which provides the approval of the college, as decided by the committee responsible.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the adoption by the European Parliament of the Convention on the legal protection of services which are based on or consist of conditional access. By adopting Directive 98/84/EC, the EU exercised its competence in the areas covered by the Convention, except in Articles 6 (Loss Measures) and 8 (International Cooperation), which cover topics such as international cooperation, civil procedure and confiscation measures. The Convention is the object of information society services and broadcasting services provided for remuneration and which are based on or consist of conditional access. The purpose of this Convention is to make illegal, within the territory of the Parties, a number of activities (identified in Article 4) that allow unauthorised access to protected services, as well as to approximate the laws of the Parties in this field. Understanding the scope and general purposes of the Convention and generally accepting them, we consider that the matter under this report is not exempt from other consequences, such as the monopolistic concentration of services provided by telecommunications companies. We abstained.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to abstain in this vote as we do not show our opposition to the existence of a procedure within Parliament to suspend the parliamentary immunity of any Member or Member. However, given that Mr Viktor Uspaskich has stated his dissatisfpathy with this decision and that the matter concerns legal proceedings opened by accusations surrounding a controversial judicial case, I have also found no reason to vote in favour. I've finally decided to abstain.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. The lifting of Viktor Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity is being asked again this year. He is charged with contempt of court. According to Article 9 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union, members of the European Parliament enjoy the immunity recognized by members of their state's parliament.  However, Viktor Uspaskich was caught red-handed, which, in the Constitution of the Republic of Lithuania, allows him to be prosecuted. Moreover, it would appear that this time we cannot establish a fumus persecutionis according to which the proceedings were initiated with the intention of harming the political activity of the Member. I therefore voted in favour of lifting Viktor Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote was not a roll-call vote. Therefore, in the interests of democracy I believe that the public has the right to know how I voted on this issue. I voted to waive immunity in this case because the alleged offence does not relate to the role of MEP and there is no obvious clear injustice as regards this case. The request for referral back to committee from Mr Verhofstadt covered legal issues; two minutesʼ discussion is insufficient for me to determine how to vote on that. These matters should be treated with a degree of seriousness which the Rules of Procedure do not permit. I reluctantly followed the rapporteurʼs line on that vote.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting the immunity of this parliamentarian in accordance with the opinion of the committee on its merits.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Viktor Uspaskich is charged with contempt of court and there is no evidence in the record to conclude that the proceedings were initiated with the intention of interfering with the political activity of the parliamentarian. Therefore, it is important to lift Mr Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity so that the Lithuanian justice system can do its job.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. At the time of the alleged offence, Mr Uspaskich was a Member of the Lithuanian Parliament (Seimas). On 28 July 2013, Viktor Uspaskich reportedly told journalists interviewing him in the arrival hall of Vilnius airport that the judges who sentenced him on 12 July 2013 had been cowardly and criminal and had not shown independence.  However, this act is an offence under Article 232 of the Lithuanian Penal Code. Nevertheless, one can possibly make a connection with the presence of Mr Uspaskich in the second round of the presidential election in his country, so I abstained on the text because I had previously voted for the referral of this request to committee.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of suspending this Member's immunity in view of the request by the Attorney-General of the Republic of Lithuania in connection with a preliminary ruling investigation concerning an alleged offence committed in his country and that there is no evidence of a fumus persecutionis, that is to say, a well-founded suspicion that the judicial proceedings have been brought with the intention of causing political harm to the Member.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ In Article 9. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union states that MEPs on the territory of their state enjoy immunity recognised by members of that country's parliament. Since a request from a national authority may initiate proceedings to waive that immunity, I grant the application.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of this request because, in my opinion, the statements made by Mr S committee have been made in favour of this request. Uspaskich cannot be regarded as being expressed in the performance of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament and cannot therefore enjoy the cover provided by Article 8 of Protocol 7.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Uspaskich is accused of vilifying some Lithuanian judges who had previously convicted him of another crime. This is not covered by the protection provided for in the Rules of Procedure (among other reasons he was not a Member of the European Parliament at the time of the facts).

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This case concerned the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Viktor Uskpaskich, who is a Lithuanian MEP. The facts related to the alleged offence of ‘contempt of court officials’ and while this offence does feature in the Lithuanian criminal code, there are very concerning facts in some of the WikiLeaks cables on this case that one could interpret as being politically motivated, given also that the MEP concerned is a Lithuanian Russian minority language speaker. For the above mentioned reasons, I abstained on this vote.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Article 9 of Protocol 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union states that Members of the European Parliament shall enjoy on their national territory the immunities accorded to members of their country's Parliament. In this case, the accusations against Viktor Uspaskich do not concern an opinion expressed in the exercise of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament. There are no longer any elements to support fumus persecutionis. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Laura Ferrara.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text under discussion sets out the EP's reasons for requesting the waiver of Viktor Uspaskich's immunity. On 1 October 2014, the President announced, pursuant to Rule 9(1) of the Rules of Procedure, that he had received a letter from the Lithuanian Public Prosecutor's Office requesting the waiver of Mr Styrendt's parliamentary immunity. Mr Uspaskich.
