Furthermore, there is no reason to suppose that there is a fumus persecutionis. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the measure.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Aware that the events that led to the Lithuanian Government's request for the waiver of Viktor Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity prior to his election as a Member of the European Parliament, I have decided to vote in favour of this request.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Parliamentary immunity is not a Member’s personal privilege but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament as a whole and of its Members. The case in question does not have a direct and obvious connection with the Member’s performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament nor does it constitute an opinion expressed or a vote cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament for the purposes of Article 8 of Protocol No 7. I have thus voted in favour of the report to waive the immunity of the Member.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Viktor Uspaskich following the statements made by Uspaskich himself against the President and some members of the college of the criminal section of the Assize Court of Vilnius, who on 12 July 2013 had delivered the sentence against him. I believe that, as provided for in the Lithuanian Criminal Code, it must be the responsibility of those who publicly, orally or in writing, this the right of a court or judge to adjudicate in the context of his activities.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I have decided to abstain in this vote as we do not show our opposition to the existence of a procedure within Parliament to suspend the parliamentary immunity of any Member or Member. However, given that Mr Viktor Uspaskich has stated his dissatisfpathy with this decision and that the matter concerns legal proceedings opened by accusations surrounding a controversial judicial case, I have also found no reason to vote in favour. I've finally decided to abstain.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the request to lift Viktor Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity. Our mandates as MEPs impose exemplary exemplarity on us. Also, the immunity associated with it is intended only to allow free speech, without external pressure.  This does not induce or justify the possibility of making statements that fall under the yoke of the penal code of the State concerned. The allegations against Viktor Uspaskich do not concern his work as an MP and do not have the will to harm it. That is why the parliamentary immunity of MP Viktor Uspaskich must be lifted.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report as I am therefore opposed to parliamentary privileges and in particular to parliamentary immunity. Everyone is equal in the face of the law.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. I believe, in principle, that the European Parliament should, as a rule, waive the immunity of a Member when judicial authorities so require. Exceptions shall only be made where there is a clear risk of political or personal persecution.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. I agree to the waiver of Viktor Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity, since the crimes of which he is accused – humiliation of a court or judge due to the exercise of judicial functions by actions, oral or written statements, punishable by fine, detention or imprisonment for a maximum period of two years – were committed before his election to the European Parliament. Immunity is usually lifted when the crime does not in any way concern the performance of the duties of a Member, provided that there are no fumus persecutionis, i.e. sufficiently serious and precise suspicions that the reason for the legal action is to cause political harm to the Member concerned. Consequently, the criminal proceedings brought against Viktor Uspaskich are not linked to his current term as a member of the European Parliament.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 At the time of the alleged crime of which Viktor Uspaskich, a Lithuanian MEMBER of the European Parliament, is accused, he was a member of the Lithuanian parliament.  In July 2013, Viktor Uspaskich was answering questions from journalists at Victor's airport, when he allegedly described as cowards, criminals and puppets the judges who had found him guilty in a criminal case of which he had been targeted. Under Article 232 of the Lithuanian Penal Code, anyone who publicly humiliates a court or judge due to the performance of judicial functions shall be punished with a fine, detention or imprisonment for a maximum period of two years. It follows that this MEMBER claims to be discriminated against and persecuted in Lithuania for belonging to the Russophone minority in a country where anti-Russia sentiment rages among state institutions. Uspaskich said his party's home and she had been searched when she went to Russia for her mother's funeral.  The ALDE Group, to which Uspaskich belongs, asked the report to return to the Commission for consideration of new facts. Specifically, we asked that all uspaskich's statements be analyzed and not only the passage that had been analyzed and allegedly decontextualized. We supported this request.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of Viktor Uspaskich's application for waiver of parliamentary immunity as I am essentially opposed to parliamentary privileges and in particular to parliamentary immunity. Everyone is equal in the face of the law.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It appears that the alleged offence was committed before Viktor Uspaskich became a Member of the European Parliament and that pre-trial proceedings had already been initiated before he assumed his seat in the European Parliament. It follows that the criminal proceedings to be brought against Viktor Uspaskich are not connected with his current office as Member of the European Parliament. Finally, there are no sufficiently serious and specific grounds for suspecting that it is a case of fumus persecutionis. I therefore voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Viktor Uspaskich.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Viktor Uspaskich, given that the alleged offence does not relate to his role of MEP.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This waiver concerns an alleged offence committed before Mr Uspaskich became a Member of the European Parliament and the pre-trial proceedings had already been initiated before he assumed his seat in the European Parliament. Therefore, the criminal proceedings to be brought against Mr Uspaskich are not connected with his current position as an MEP.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the waiver of immunity for Viktor Uspaskich because there is no reason to believe that the law enforcement actions being carried out are linked to the political persecution of Viktor Uspaskich for his work in the European Parliament. The offence under investigation occurred before Mr Uspaskich became a Member of the European Parliament, and the pre-trial investigation began before he took office.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒I voted against the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on the application for the waiver of Viktor Uspaskich's immunity on the basis that such a decision constitutes a line of the ALDE Group. I also believe that it is necessary to ensure that a Member has unhindered work in the European Parliament, and that the process of waiving immunity should be based on objective analysis and concrete facts.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. Once again, Viktor Uspaskich faces justice in his country. He is now charged with contempt of court. According to Article 9 of Protocol 7 on EU privileges and immunities, European parliamentarians enjoy the same immunity as parliamentarians in their home state. Viktor Uspaskich has been the subject of a flagrant offence, which, in the Constitution of the Republic of Lithuania, allows him to be prosecuted. It therefore appears that the lifting of parliamentary immunity is not, in this case, politically motivated. For all these reasons, I have decided to vote for the lifting of Viktor Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Laura Ferrara's report on Viktor Uspaskich's request for the lifting of parliamentary immunity. This procedure, requested by the Member concerned, is a formality in order to enable the judicial authorities to carry out their investigative work.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. The allegations relate to a pure expression of opinion that Mr Uspaskich made when he was not yet a Member of the European Parliament. I therefore abstain from voting.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as I agree with the reasons of the proposal to waive immunity.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Ferrara's report on the request for the waiver of the immunity of Viktor Uspaskich. Since the events are prior to the election of Mr Uspaskich to the European Parliament, the Committee on Legal Affairs has recommended the waiver of immunity.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on Viktor Uspaskich's request to lift his immunity because I would have preferred the referral to committee, as Mr Verhofstadt had requested. The Lithuanian judiciary accuses Mr. Uspaskich of having stated that the judges who sentenced him on 12 July 2013 had been cowardly and criminal, and that they had not shown independence.  However, Mr Uspaskich maintains that the Committee was not properly informed of the exact context of his statements, that he would in fact have only quoted the President of Lithuania, and asks that the Committee be able to hear the recording of his statements.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on the lifting of immunity because the application is officially motivated by the fact that Mr. Uspaskich allegedly insulted a magistrate. This grievance therefore seems to me at first to be unrelated to the exercise of the European parliamentary mandate. But I cannot rule out that this is actually political persecution. For the record, I had voted against Mr Uspaskich's previous request to waive his immunity, which clearly considered itself to be a political persecution committed by Lithuania against one of its Russian-speaking nationals.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. Viktor Uspaskich is a Lithuanian member of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe and a member of the Regional Development Committee. A request to lift lawmaker Uspaskich's immunity has been requested by Lithuania's attorney general for an investigation into the alleged crime. Protocol No. 7 of the European Union states on the privileges and immunies that Members of the European Parliament are entitled to the kind of immunity that members of the national parliaments of the Member States have.  I supported the Report of Representative Ferrera, who on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs granted the waiver of the immunity of Representative Viktor Uspaskich, since there is no doubt that the proceedings were initiated with the intention of causing political damage. The Representative is charged with the commission of a criminal offence of contempt of court in accordance with Article 232 TE. Criminal Code of the Republic of Lithuania.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the waiver of Viktor Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity following the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted that the European Parliament should waive the immunity of Viktor Uspaskich for the reasons set out in the report.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with this report on the request for waiver of the immunity of Victor Uspaskich.  I am of the opinion that the Member should continue to enjoy immunity as a guarantor and I will continue to vote against these reports. The fact that this immunity exists is a guarantee for the independence of the European Parliament as an institution and not for the personal benefit of the Members who are part of it.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. As the conduct to be pursued is related to political activity, I have rejected the request for annulment.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report proposes the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Viktor Uspaskich, Lithuanian MEMBER of the ALDE. He is accused of having told the press that the judges responsible for his conviction in July 2013 had been cowardly and criminal and that they had not shown independence. That seems to be true.  Moreover, the procedure followed by the Lithuanian justice system still raises many questions. It should be noted that Viktor Uspaskich is Russian-speaking, a minority highly discriminated against by the Baltic, anti-Russian, current governments. In view of these doubts about the proper functioning of the Lithuanian justice system and in view of the protests of the person concerned who denounces a judicial harassment against him, I vote against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of the independence of the Mandate of the European Parliament is the responsibility of the European Parliament and that independence cannot be called into question. In accordance with Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties. The Lithuanian Attorney General has requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Viktor Uspaskich, a Member of the European Parliament, as part of a preliminary investigation into the alleged commission of a crime. Viktor Uspaskich is accused of having committed the crime of contempt by the court under Article 232 of the Penal Code of the Republic of Lithuania. There is no evidence of fumus persecutionis, i.e. reasoned suspicions that the legal action has been brought in order to politically harm the Member. I therefore voted in favour of the lifting of parliamentary immunity.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Viktor Uspaskich.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to lift the immunity of MP Viktor Uspaskich following the request of the Lithuanian prosecutor's office. He is accused of committing contempt of court during a discussion with journalists. He reportedly called the judges who sentenced him in 2013 "loose" and "criminals who had not shown independence". However, this prosecution is likely to be related to his presence in the second round of the presidential elections. On the other hand, the alleged facts are reported statements, which, in my view, should not be subject to prosecution. So I voted against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting Viktor Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity. Any request made to the President of the European Parliament by the authorities of a Member State to waive a Member's immunity is heard by the relevant parliamentary committee. I voted in accordance with the opinion of the committee.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the rapporteur's proposal from the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. On 28 July 2013, Viktor Uspaskich answered questions from various media outlets at Vilnius airport, describing the judges who, on 12 July 2013, in a criminal case against him, as cowards, criminals and puppets in a criminal case in which they found his guilt. In order to facilitate the investigation into the incident, I voted in favour of waiving the parliamentary immunity of Viktor Uspaskich.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas the Attorney General of Lithuania has requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Viktor Uspaskich, a Member of the European Parliament, as part of an investigation into an alleged crime; that Article 9 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union stipulates that Members of the European Parliament shall enjoy, 'on national territory, the immunities accorded to members of their country's Parliament'; that Article 62 of the Constitution of the Republic of Lithuania and the third paragraph of Article 22 of the Statute of the Seimas (Lithuanian Parliament) stipulate that criminal proceedings may not be brought against Members of the Lithuanian Parliament and that members of the Lithuanian Parliament may not be arrested or subject to any other measure having a restrictive liberty without the approval of the Seimas, except in cases of criminal offence; I voted in favour.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I respect the rapporteur's recommendation because, although prosecution is not related to the opinion expressed or the vote to serve as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the EIA, it is not related to the opinion expressed or to vote in the performance of its duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, and the alleged offence is clearly in no relation to the performance of my colleague Uspaskich's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, there is no reason to assume that the prosecution was brought with the intention of causing political harm to the member concerned (fumus persecutionis) because it was initiated before Mr Uspaskich became a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. I supported MP Laura Ferrara's report on the request to lift the immunity of MP Viktor Uspaskich. Parliamentary immunity is a remedy that protects the smooth functioning of Members and thus constitutes a necessary means of protecting parliament's independence. In order to be credible, it is important that parliamentary immunity is solely an instrument of protection against politically motivated persecution. In the case of Representative Viktor Uspaskich, the Committee on Legal Affairs found that it was not a prosecution brought with the intention of causing political harm to a Member. The Uspaskich MP is charged with the offence of contempt of court under the Criminal Code of the Republic of Lithuania for a statement he made to reporters on July 28, 2013 while he was a member of the national parliament. Given that Viktor Uspaskich was elected mep on 25 May 2014, the proceedings initiated have nothing to do with his duties as an MEP. I therefore agree with the Decision of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the waiver of immunity, as the remedy for the protection of citizens' representatives at EU level must not place Members above the law.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In this case, it seems to me to be an obligatory step to waive the immunity of Viktor Uspaskich, because Articles 8 and 9 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union clearly state that a Member of the European Parliament may enjoy immunity in the exercise of his mandate. Viktor Uspaskich was not a Member of the European Parliament at the time of the events in question and, consequently, immunity must be waived since the crime is in no way linked to the exercise of his mandate as a Member of the European Parliament, but predates. Furthermore, It does not seem to me that there are sufficiently serious and specific reasons to suspect that this is a case of fumus persecutionis.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 1 October 2014, the Lithuanian Attorney General requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Viktor Uspaskich, Member of the European Parliament, in connection with a preliminary investigation into the alleged commission of a crime of contempt of court on 28 July 2013 pursuant to Article 232 of the Criminal Code of the Republic of Lithuania. Under Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, Members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties. According to the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, Article 8 of the Protocol does not apply in this case, since Viktor Uspaskich was not a Member of the European Parliament at the time of the events. On that basis and on the basis of that report, I voted in favour of this decision to lift Viktor Uspaskich's immunity.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The lifting of parliamentary immunity is anything but a simple act and follows a very rigorous procedure. In the case of the Member of the European Parliament, immunity can generally be waived when the offence is absolutely not related to the exercise of the office of a Member of Parliament - and therefore falls under Article 9 of the Protocol on the privileges and immunities of the European Union. The same article also stipulates that immunity cannot be invoked in the case of flagrante delict and cannot also interfere with the right of the European Parliament to lift the immunity of one of its members. This derogation is logical and is most often justified either by the seriousness of the alleged facts or by the possibility of making the judicial decision quickly. This is not the case with the adoption of the Ferrara report this afternoon. It is simply a matter for the plenary to follow the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs, which had recommended that the European Parliament lift Viktor Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity, as requested by the Prosecutor General's Office of the Republic of Lithuania. This waiver of immunity will allow the MEP concerned to defend himself like any other citizen.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. It is a question of Lithuanian internal justice, unrelated to Viktor Uspaskich's deputy status.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of suspending this Member's immunity in view of the request by the Attorney-General of the Republic of Lithuania in connection with a preliminary ruling investigation concerning an alleged offence committed in his country and that there is no evidence of a fumus persecutionis, that is to say, a well-founded suspicion that the judicial proceedings have been brought with the intention of causing political harm to the Member.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the lifting of Mr Viktor Uspaskich's immunity, so that the Lithuanian justice system could continue its work, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, considering that the facts in question - contempt of an alleged magistrate - occurred before Mr Uspaskich sat in the European Parliament and therefore had no direct or obvious link with the exercise of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to abstain in this vote as we do not show our opposition to the existence of a procedure within Parliament to suspend the parliamentary immunity of any Member or Member. However, given that Mr Viktor Uspaskich has stated his dissatisfpathy with this decision and that the matter concerns legal proceedings opened by accusations surrounding a controversial judicial case, I have also found no reason to vote in favour. I've finally decided to abstain.

It follows that the criminal proceedings to be brought against Viktor Uspaskich are not connected with his current office as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ As MEP Viktor Uspaskich is charged with the offence of contempt of court in accordance with Article 232 TB. Criminal Code of the Republic of Lithuania, I support this Report because I consider that this proceeding was not initiated with the intention of causing political harm to that Representative. It is important to note that Articles 8 and 9 of the Protocol No. 7 I cannot apply on the privileges and immunity of the European Union to this case because Mr Uspaskich was not a Member of the European Parliament at the time of the alleged commission of the offence, and that offence does not relate to the opinions he expressed, nor to the votes in which he participated in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Viktor Uspaskich, a Lithuanian MEP.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In the report on the application for waiver of viktor Uspaskich's immunity, there is no evidence for fumus persecutionis, i.e. for reasonable suspicion that the proceedings were initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the member concerned. He accuses Viktor Uspaskich of committing a contempt offence under Article 232 of the Code of Justice. Criminal Code of the Republic of Lithuania.  The Attorney General of the Republic of Lithuania has requested the lifting of parliamentary immunity for a MEMBER of the European Parliament in connection with an investigation into an alleged crime prior to legal proceedings. Article 9 Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union states that Members of the European Parliament on the territory of their state enjoy immunity granted to Members of that State's Parliament. Article 62 Constitution of the Republic of Lithuania and Article 22(3) of the Constitution of the Republic of Lithuania. The Rules of Procedure of the Parliament of the Republic of Lithuania state that no criminal proceedings may be brought against members of the Parliament of the Republic of Lithuania and cannot be arrested or subjected to any other restrictions on personal freedom without the consent of the Parliament of the Republic of Lithuania except in cases of in flagrante delicto.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because I do not believe that the waiver of parliamentary immunity for Viktor Uspaskich is correct. 'Contempt of the Court' also certainly falls within the scope of freedom of expression, which is what parliamentary immunity should protect.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am therefore opposed to parliamentary privileges and in particular to parliamentary immunity. Everyone is equal in the face of the law.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting my colleague's immunity, a request shared even by the Member in question. It is normal for him to be able to explain himself to his national authorities.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The case of Viktor Uspaskich should be analysed in a wider context. There are good reasons to believe that this politician has repeatedly been harassed by the Lithuanian authorities due to his political opinion and immigrant origin. Against such a background I cannot vote in favour of the waiver of his immunity.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. As is often customary in the pleadings for suspension of the immunity of Members of Parliament, I voted in favour of that suspension in the case of Viktor Uspaskich.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have decided to abstain in this vote as we do not show our opposition to the existence of a procedure within Parliament to suspend the parliamentary immunity of any Member or Member. However, given that Mr Viktor Uspaskich has stated his dissatisfpathy with this decision and that the matter concerns legal proceedings opened by accusations surrounding a controversial judicial case, I have also found no reason to vote in favour. I've finally decided to abstain.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Immunity of members of the European Parliament is protected by Articles 8 and 9 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union. In order to benefit from immunity under Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, legal proceedings should relate to opinions or votes expressed by a Member of the European Parliament in the performance of his duties. Consequently, Article 8 of the Protocol does not apply, since Viktor Uspaskich was not a Member of the European Parliament at the time of the events. In view of the arguments set out, and pursuant to Article 9(3) of the Rules of Procedure, the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that the European Parliament withdraw Viktor Uspaskich's immunity. However, this MEP is said to be discriminated against in Lithuania for being "the Russian speaker"; his party's home held scans were searched when he travelled to Russia at his mother's funeral. name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report calls for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of the French Member to the European Parliament, Jerome Lavrilleux of the EFDD Group. Since the Member himself is in favour of suspension, I voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. The request to lift Jérôme Lavrilleux's parliamentary immunity concerns a judicial investigation into the financing of Nicolas Sarkozy's campaign during the 2012 presidential election. Jérôme Lavrilleux, deputy director of this campaign, should be questioned under police custody in order to establish his responsibility for the presumptions of false invoicing.  The lifting of his immunity is necessary for the French justice system to continue the judicial process. The facts that could be alleged against Jérôme Lavrilleux took place before the performance of his duties as an MEP. Moreover, we cannot suspect the existence of fumus persecutionis, as the judicial proceedings do not appear to have been initiated with the intention of harming the member's political activity. I therefore voted in favour of the request to waive immunity.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote was not a roll-call vote. Therefore, in the interests of democracy I believe that the public has the right to know how I voted on this issue. I voted to waive immunity in this case because the alleged offence does not relate to the role of MEP and there is no obvious clear injustice as regards this case.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting the immunity of this parliamentarian in accordance with the opinion of the committee on its merits.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In the case of Nicolas Sarkozy's campaign expenses during the 2012 French presidential election, better known as the Bygmalion case, French magistrates would like to take Jérôme Lavrilleux into custody for questioning. Jérôme Lavrilleux was Nicolas Sarkozy's campaign manager in 2012 and his questioning seems crucial to determining possible responsibilities within the campaign team.  In view of the presumptions against Mr. Lavrilleux and the fact that there is no evidence in the record that the procedure was initiated with the intention of harming the political activity of the parliamentarian, Parliament decided to lift the parliamentary immunity of the French Member so that the judiciary could do its job.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report calls for the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Jérôme Lavrilleux (UMP) following a request from the public prosecutor's office in connection with the financing of Nicolas Sarkozy's 2012 presidential campaign and the scandals of the "Bygmalion" affair. The alleged facts are numerous: forgery, use of forgery, breach of trust, attempted fraud, complicity in concealment and concealment of these crimes, illegal financing as well as concealment and complicity in concealment of this crime. However, they are foreign to his work as an MP and he is then likely to be subject to a waiver of immunity. Moreover, the seriousness of the alleged facts but also the exemplary nature of ours at a time when European citizens are increasingly losing confidence in politics encourage us to support this lifting of immunity. So I voted in favour of lifting it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of suspending this Member's immunity in view of the arrest of the chief prosecutor of the Paris Court of Appeal in relation to an ongoing judicial investigation for forgery, use of false documents, abuse of trust, attempted fraud, and complicity and concealment of such crimes, as well as for illegal financing of election campaign , concealment and complicity in that offence and in view of the that neither the charges relate to the functions of Member of the European Parliament, but derive from his previous post as deputy campaigner in the last French presidential elections, nor does the European Parliament have evidence of a fumus persecutionis, that is to say, a sufficiently strong and precise suspicion that the matter was raised with the intention of causing political harm to the Member.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the Attorney General of the Court of Appeal of Paris requested the waiver of the immunity of this Member of the European Parliament in the pre-trial investigation launched for the falsification of documents, the use of false documents, abuse of trust, attempted fraud, complicity in and concealment of these offences, unlawful financing of an election campaign, complicity in this criminal activity and concealment of this offence. The system of bogus invoices and accusations do not relate to the performance of Mr Lavrilleux's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, but to his previous duties on the presidential candidate's election team set up to take part in elections held two years before Mr Lavrilleux was elected as a Member of the European Parliament. Moreover, there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis, i.e. there are no substantiated suspicions that the proceedings were brought with a view to undermining the political reputation of a Member. The Committee on Legal Affairs proposes, after hearing Mr Lavrilleux's explanations, that his immunity should be waived.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ In Article 9. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union states that MEPs on the territory of their state enjoy immunity recognised by members of that country's parliament. Since a request from a national authority may initiate proceedings to waive that immunity, I grant the application.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this request with my vote because I believe that, in the lack of fumus perscutionis and since the provisions of Protocol No 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union cannot be applied, The immunity of Mr De Clercq is not being applied. Lavrilleux must be revoked.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. After the 2012 French presidential election, it became clear that Nicolas Sarkozy's campaign accounts far exceeded the legal limit on campaign spending that was imposed on all candidates. This justified the rejection by the National Commission of Campaign Accounts and Political Financing of the campaign accounts of candidate Nicolas Sarkozy. It is in this context that the French justice opened an investigation into the billing scheme which suggests that fictitious benefits were paid by the UMP when they were to be integrated into the campaign account.  Given the status of deputy director of Jérôme Lavrilleux, the French magistrates wish to question him under the regime of custody in order to establish possible responsibilities in the campaign team. As the alleged facts predate his election as an MEP and there is no evidence that the proceedings were initiated with the intention of harming his political activity, I voted in favour of the lifting of the immunity of The Member of Parliament Jérôme Lavrilleux.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Lavrilleux is charged with falsification, use of falsified documents, abuse of trust, attempted fraud, conspiring in such crimes and concealment of them as well as unlawful financing of an election campaign, concealment of that crime and conspiring in the same. This is not covered by the protections provided for in the Rules of Procedure (among other reasons he was not a Member of the European Parliament at the time of the events – election campaign French of 2012). I voted in favour of the request for revocation.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which relates to the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Jérôme Lavrilleux, who is an EPP French MEP. Since there is no fumus persecutionis (false discrimination and accusation) and since Jérôme Lavrilleux further accepted to waive his immunity, I voted in favour of waiving that immunity.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Jérôme Lavrilleux, former deputy campaign manager Nicolas Sarkozy during the 2012 French presidential election, is being investigated for misuse and falsification of documents, abuse of trust, attempted fraud, conspiring in such crimes and concealing them. He is also accused of illegally funding an election campaign, following fraud resulting from a billing device that had allowed the UMP party to bear amounts that should have been charged to candidate Sarkozy and declared on his behalf for the campaign. The false invoices would have served to feed alleged "hidden funds" of the campaign for about 32 million euros. As these charges are not related to the exercise of the mandate of a Member of the European Parliament, I voted in favour of the request for revocation.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. Personal immunity is intended to ensure the independence of Members in the performance of their duties. Mr Lavrilleux's presumption of false invoicing does not relate to the performance of his duties as an MEP but to activities carried out previously, prior to his election to the European Parliament. Moreover, the existence of fumus persecutionis cannot be established. So I voted to waive immunity.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text under discussion sets out the EP's reasons for the request to waive the immunity of Jérôme Lavrilleux. On 23 December 2014, the President announced, pursuant to Rule 9(1) of the Rules of Procedure, that he had received from the Minister of Justice French a letter requesting the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Jérôme Lavrilleux. Having examined the documents, the committee decided to submit to the EP the decision to waive immunity, considering that the allegations clearly have no relation to the post of Member of the European Parliament, but are linked to his previous position as Deputy Director of the election campaign at the last presidential elections in France.  Mr President, I would like to make a very important Lavrilleux is charged with forgery, use of falsified documents, abuse of trust, attempted fraud, conspiring in such crimes and concealment of such offences as well as unlawful financing of an election campaign, concealment of that crime and conspiring in it.  Furthermore, there is no reason to suppose that there is a fumus persecutionis. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the measure.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the fact that the alleged charges are not related to the office of Jérôme Lavrilleux as a Member of the European Parliament but to his previous post as Deputy Director of the election campaign at the last presidential elections in France, I voted in favour of this request for revocation.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Parliamentary immunity is not a Member’s personal privilege but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament as a whole and of its Members. The case in question does not have a direct and obvious connection with the Member’s performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament nor does it constitute an opinion expressed or a vote cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament for the purposes of Article 8 of Protocol No 7. I have thus voted in favour of the report to waive the immunity of the Member.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Jérôme Lavrilleux, former deputy director of the 2012 French presidential campaign, is being investigated for falsifying documents, using falsified documents, abusing trust, attempting to defraud, conspiring to commit such crimes and concealing them as well as unlawfully funding an election campaign, following fraud resulting from a billing device that had allowed presidential candidate Nicolas Sarkozy's party to bear amounts that should have been charged to the candidate and declared under his account for the campaign. I voted in favour of this withdrawal, and I believe that we must penalise those who unduly use public money to finance election campaigns.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The report calls for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of the French Member to the European Parliament, Jerome Lavrilleux of the EFDD Group. Since the Member himself is in favour of suspension, I voted in favour.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the request to waive Jérôme Lavrilleux's immunity. Each of the MEPs and, more generally, elected politicians owes the citizens full transparency. Public funding must be monitored from their origins to their destinations. This is of paramount importance to the confidence of citizens in their representatives and is one of the foundations of my political commitment. The alleged facts do not concern the parliamentary activity of the Member in question, his immunity must be waived.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report as I am therefore opposed to parliamentary privileges and in particular to parliamentary immunity. Everyone is equal in the face of the law.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. I believe, in principle, that the European Parliament should, as a rule, waive the immunity of a Member when judicial authorities so require. Exceptions shall only be made where there is a clear risk of political or personal persecution.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The Attorney General before the Paris Court of Appeal requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Jérôme Lavrilleux as part of a pending judicial investigation on suspicion of falsifying and using false documents, abuse of trust, attempted fraud, complicity in these offences and their cover-up, as well as unlawful financing of an election campaign and complicity in this offence and its cover-up. There are also suspicions of participation in a fictitious billing system for election campaign expenses. Parliament has not detected the existence of fumus persecutionis, that is to say, a sufficiently serious and reasoned suspicion that, at the origin of the judicial proceedings, the intention of harming the political activity of the Member is found. I therefore agree with the lifting of parliamentary immunity.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The French MEP, Jérôme Lavrilleux, is suspected of participating in a fictitious system of invoicing of expenditure of Nicholas Sarkozy's election campaign to the Presidency of France as part of a pending judicial investigation (on forgery and use of false documents, abuse of trust, attempted fraud, complicity in these offences and their cover-up, as well as illegal financing). The rapporteur considers that the accusations do not concern the situation of Jérôme Lavrilleux as a Member of the European Parliament and stems from his previous role as deputy director of election campaigning in the last presidential elections held in France; whereas the judicial procedure does not concern the opinions or votes expressed by Jérôme Lavrilleux in the exercise of his term as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the Protocol (7) on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union; and that Parliament has not detected a sufficiently serious and reasoned suspicion that, at the origin of the judicial proceedings, the intention to undermine the political activity of the Member is found. It therefore proposes to lift the immunity of Jérôme Lavrilleux. We follow the position of our Support Group to report.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the application for waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Jérôme Lavrileux as I am therefore opposed to parliamentary privileges and in particular to parliamentary immunity. Everyone is equal in the face of the law.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The charges are not related to the performance of Mr Lavrilleux’s duties as a Member of the European Parliament but related to his previous post in a presidential election campaign team set up for a vote that took place two years before Mr Lavrilleux was elected Member of the European Parliament. Furthermore, there is a lack of fumus persecutionis, which is to say there is no well-founded suspicion that the legal proceedings have been instituted with the intention of causing political damage to the Member. I therefore voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Jérôme Lavrilleux.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Jérôme Lavrilleux given that the alleged offence does not relate to the role of MEP.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The alleged charges are not related to the performance of Mr Lavrilleux’s duties as an MEP but concern his previous responsibilities as a member of a presidential election campaign team two years before he was elected an MEP. There is no well-founded suspicion that the legal proceedings have been instituted with the intention of causing political damage to the Member.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the waiver of the immunity of Jérome Lavrilleux because the accusations do not relate to the duties of a Member of the European Parliament, but to his activities as deputy director of the election campaign. The European Parliament has found no sufficiently serious and clear reason to believe that the case is being brought in order to undermine the work of a Member of the European Parliament in the European Parliament.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on a request to lift Jerome Lavrilleux's immunity, as Mr Lavrilleux is charged with specific offences, such as forgery, which is not linked to the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament in this particular case. In this case, Article 8 of the European Convention on The Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union cannot be applied.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. In 2012, Jérôme Lavrilleux was the deputy director of Nicolas Sarkozy's presidential campaign. However, Jérôme Lavrilleux is now one of the main suspects in a judicial investigation into the financing of Nicolas Sarkozy's campaign. The lifting of parliamentary immunity would allow Jérôme Lavrilleux to be heard in police custody in order to answer for the current suspicions. The aim is to allow the French justice system to continue the judicial process.  The events for which Jérôme Lavrilleux is suspected took place before his election to the European Parliament. Thus, I do not see the existence of fumus persecutionis, and therefore the lifting of parliamentary immunity does not appear to have been initiated with the intention of harming the member's political activity. I voted in favour of the request to lift The parliamentary immunity of Jérôme Lavrilleux.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Heidi Hautala's report on Jérôme Lavrilleux's request for the lifting of parliamentary immunity. This procedure, requested by the Member concerned, is a formality in order to enable the judicial authorities to carry out their investigative work.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of waiving Mr Lavrilleux's immunity, as the allegations are very serious. He is accused of falsifying and using forged documents, as well as infidelity, attempted fraud and illegally financing his campaign. It is in the interests of the integrity of Parliament and its Members to clarify this, which is why I support the motion.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as I agree with the reasons of the proposal to waive immunity.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Hautala's report on the request for waiver of mrs Jérôme Lavrilleux's immunity. Having analysed the matter, I followed the recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs, which recommended the waiver of immunity, considering that the facts in question are not related to his work as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. I voted to lift Jérôme Lavrilleux's parliamentary immunity in the context of an ongoing investigation for forgery, forgery, breach of trust, attempted fraud, complicity in concealment and concealment of these crimes, illegal financing and concealment and complicity in concealment of this crime. Mr. Lavrilleux is suspected of having participated in a system of false billing of expenses of Nicolas Sarkozy's presidential campaign in 2012. The alleged facts are not related to his position as an MEP. The proceedings against him do not concern opinions or votes cast by him in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and there is no sufficiently serious presumption that the proceedings were initiated with the intention of harming the Political Activity of the Member.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted to lift Mr Lavrilleux's immunity because the request is motivated by the fact that he was allegedly involved, as deputy director of Mr Sarkozy's 2012 presidential campaign, in setting up a system of false invoicing by the Bygmalion group. However, this alleged scheme of false invoicing and the presumptions against Mr Lavrilleux do not relate to the performance of his duties as an MEP but relate to the activities he carried out previously, when he was part of the campaign team formed in the context of the French presidential election which took place two years before his election to the European Parliament. Moreover, the existence of fumus persecutionis cannot be established, i.e. there is no evidence to suggest that the proceedings were initiated with the intention of harming Mr. Lavrilleux's political activity.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. I voted to lift Jerome Lavrilleux's immunity. Legal action was taken as part of an investigation into a false billing system linked to Mr Sarkozy's presidential campaign (Bygmalion case). Police conducted searches. People were heard, including Jérôme Lavrilleux, who was deputy director of Sarkozy's 2012 campaign. The charge relates to whether this system was not used to circumvent the rules limiting election expenses, the actual cost of the campaign would have exceeded the legally permitted ceiling.  Jérôme Lavrilleux served as deputy director of Sarkozy's campaign. That is why the French magistrates wish to question him under the regime of police custody. As Mr Lavrilleux's doubts are not relating to the performance of his duties as an MEP and there is no reason to suspect that the proceedings were initiated with the intention of harming Mr Lavrilleux's political activity, I support the request for the lifting of immunity.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. Jérôme Lavrilleux is a French member of the European People's Party Group and is a member of the Employment and Social Affairs Committee and the Delegation for Relations with Canada. During France's 2012 presidential election, he held the post of deputy campaign manager for Nicolas Sarkozy, suspected of costing more than the law allowed. The request to lift the immunity was submitted by the French justice minister so that a court in Paris could question Mp Lavrilleux and establish his responsibility as he is charged with participating in a system of issuing false invoices for campaign expenses, illegally financing an election campaign and concealing the crime. MEP Heidi Hautala on behalf of the Legal Affairs Committee granted the waiver of Immunity to MEP Jérôme Lavrilleux. I supported the waiver of immunity because the charges are not related to his or her duties as a Member of Parliament and the proceedings were not initiated with the intention of causing political damage.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Jérôme Lavrileux following the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted that the European Parliament should waive the immunity of Jérôme Lavrilleux for the reasons set out in the report.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for this waiver of immunity so that Jérôme Lavrilleux could be questioned by French magistrates about his involvement in the Bygmalion case and his responsibilities in the fraudulent financing of Nicolas Sarkozy's presidential campaign in 2012. We have, of course, supported this waiver of immunity.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with this report on the request for waiver of the immunity of Jérôme Lavrilleux.  I am of the opinion that the Member should continue to enjoy immunity as a guarantor and I will continue to vote against these reports. The fact that this immunity exists is a guarantee for the independence of the European Parliament as an institution and not for the personal benefit of the Members who are part of it.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. In France, after the 2012 presidential elections, candidate Nicolas Sarkozy found inconsistencies in the use of his campaign accounts. In his capacity as deputy campaign manager of Nicolas Sarkozy, Mr Lavrilleux is accused of forgery, the use of forged documents, infidelity, attempted fraud and, moreover, the illegal financing of the election campaign. That is why I voted accordingly.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report calls for the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Jérôme Lavrilleux, a French UMP MP. He is accused of having participated in a system of false billing of campaign expenses in connection with the presidential campaign of Nicolas Sarkozy in 2012 for a total amount of 18.5 million euros. The lifting of immunity is necessary to allow his hearing, in police custody, and his judicial supervision. In view of the agreement of the person concerned in favour of this measure in order to defend himself, I vote for the lifting of parliamentary immunity.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of the independence of the Mandate of the European Parliament is the responsibility of the European Parliament and that independence cannot be called into question. In accordance with Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties. The Attorney General at the Paris Court of Appeal requested the waiver of The Parliamentary Immunity of Jérôme Lavrilleux, as part of a pending judicial investigation on suspicion of forgery and use of false documents, abuse of trust, attempted fraud, complicity in these offences and their cover-up, as well as illegal financing of an election campaign and complicity in this offence and cover-up.  The accusations do not concern the situation of Jérôme Lavrilleux as a Member of the European Parliament and stem from his previous role as deputy director of the election campaign in the last presidential elections held in France. Parliament has not detected the existence of fumus persecutionis, that is to say, a sufficiently serious and reasoned suspicion that, at the origin of the judicial proceedings, the intention of harming the political activity of Mr Votei is therefore in favour of the waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report on the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Jérôme Lavrilleux.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Jérôme Lavrilleux.

name: Bernard Monot (NI)
text: In writing. Jérôme Lavrilleux is suspected of having organized a system of false invoices around the Bygmalion company, intended to cover up certain campaign expenses and, ultimately, to have the taxpayer take over the financing of Nicolas Sarkozy's 2012 presidential campaign.  The total malfeasation is reported to be worth almost 20 million euros, and is a clear attack on the equality of the candidates competing in the last presidential election. The UMP thanked him by electing him as an MEP in May 2014, with the parliamentary immunity that goes with it. Its responsibility, in order to be established by the courts, requires the lifting of this immunity, so it is necessary to vote on it.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This report aims to call for the lifting of Jérôme Lavrilleux's immunity following a request from the public prosecutor's office in connection with the financing of the 2012 presidential campaign of N. Sarkozy. The alleged facts (i.e., forgery, use of forgery, breach of trust, attempted fraud, complicity in concealment and concealment of these offences, illegal financing, concealment and complicity in concealment of this offence) are foreign to his activity as a Member of Parliament, so he is then likely to be subject to a waiver of immunity. Moreover, the seriousness of the alleged facts (vast system of false billing of campaign expenses), coupled with his passage to a confession live on a French television channel, pleads for his lifting of immunity. So I voted for it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting the parliamentary immunity of Jérôme Lavrilleux, who had expressed his request. Any request made to the President of the European Parliament by the authorities of a Member State to waive a Member's immunity is heard by the relevant parliamentary committee. I voted in accordance with the opinion of the committee.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the rapporteur's proposal from the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. European Parliament Member Jéréme Lavrilleux is strongly suspected of having forged documents, embezzlement, attempted fraud and illegal campaign financing. That is why I voted in favour of the deprivation of liberty at the expense of Jéréme Lavrilleux and I am in favour of the waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. Having regard to the fact that the Public Prosecutor of the Paris Court of Appeal has requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Jérôme Lavrilleux, a Member of the European Parliament, in connection with the ongoing judicial investigation into the allegations of falsification, use of falsified documents, abuse of trust, attempted fraud, conspiring to commit such crimes and concealing them, as well as unlawful financing of an election campaign, concealment of that crime and competition in it; that the French courts intend, in that context, to adopt a measure of deprivation or restriction of liberty against Jérôme Lavrilleux; that Article 9 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union provides that Members of the European Parliament shall enjoy, on their national territory, the immunities accorded to members of the Parliament of their country; I voted in favour.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. The scandal in which Mr. Lavrilleux is involved in France is extremely serious as it concerns the financing of Mr Sarkozy's presidential campaign, whose campaign accounts had been rejected by the Control Commission; it is important that the investigation can proceed and that the facts are clearly established. That is why I am in favour of this report, which recommends the lifting of immunity.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I respect the rapporteur's recommendation because, although the prosecution is not related to the opinion expressed or the vote to serve as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the EIA, it is not related to the opinion expressed or the vote to serve as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the EEA. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, and the alleged offence is clearly not in any connection with the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, there is no reason to assume that the prosecution was brought with the intention of causing political harm to the Member concerned (fumus persecutionis) because it was initiated before Mr Lavrilleux became a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported MP Heidi Hautal's report on the request to lift the immunity of Mp Jérome Lavrilleux. In the case of Representative Jérome Lavrilleux, the Committee on Legal Affairs found unanimously that it was not a prosecution initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the Member. Lawmaker Lavrilleux is suspected of participating in the 2012 presidential election campaign expenses system while serving as deputy campaign director for a presidential candidate. Given that Jérome Lavrilleux was elected MEP on 25 May 2014, the proceedings initiated have nothing to do with his duties as an MEP. I therefore agree with the Decision of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the waiver of immunity, as the remedy for the protection of citizens' representatives at EU level must not place Members above the law. Parliamentary immunity is a remedy that protects the smooth functioning of Members and thus constitutes a necessary means of protecting parliament's independence. In order to be credible, it is important that parliamentary immunity is solely an instrument of protection against politically motivated persecution.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The offence for which the waiver of Jérôme Lavrilleux's immunity was requested does not relate to the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament but to his previous post in the French presidential elections held two years before his election as a Member of the European Parliament. In the lack of fumus persecutionis, the request for revocation is perfectly valid in accordance with eu legislation.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 23 December 2014, the Attorney General before the Court of Appeal in Paris requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Jérôme Lavrilleux, Member of the European Parliament, in the context of a pending judicial investigation on suspicion of falsifying and using false documents, abuse of trust, attempted fraud, complicity in these offences and their cover-up, as well as unlawful financing of an election campaign and complicity in this offence and its cover-up. In order to benefit from the immunity provided for in Articles 8 and 9 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, the judicial procedure shall concern an opinion or vote expressed by a Member of the European Parliament in the performance of his duties. In the present case, the Committee on Legal Affairs concluded that such accusations did not concern the performance of Jérôme Lavrilleux's duties as an MEP and were related to the functions he previously held on the presidential candidate's campaign team. On these terms and on the basis of the JURI Committee report, I voted in favour of this Decision on the waiver of Jérôme Lavrilleux's immunity.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The lifting of parliamentary immunity is anything but a simple act and follows a very rigorous procedure. In the case of the Member of the European Parliament, immunity can generally be waived when the offence is absolutely not related to the exercise of the office of a Member of Parliament - and therefore falls under Article 9 of the Protocol on the privileges and immunities of the European Union. The same article also stipulates that immunity cannot be invoked in the case of flagrante delict and cannot also interfere with the right of the European Parliament to lift the immunity of one of its members. This derogation is logical and is most often justified either by the seriousness of the alleged facts or by the possibility of making the judicial decision quickly. This is not the case with the adoption of the Hautala report this afternoon. It is simply a matter for the plenary to follow the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs, which had unanimously recommended that the European Parliament lift the parliamentary immunity of Jérôme Lavrilleux, as requested by the Attorney General at the Paris Court of Appeal. This waiver of immunity will allow the MEP concerned to defend himself like any other citizen.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. It is a matter of French internal justice, unrelated to the status of Deputy of Jérôme Lavrilleux.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
