name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the lifting of Mr Jérôme Lavrilleux's immunity, so that the French justice system could continue its work, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, considering that the facts in question - a judicial investigation focusing on a system of false billing linked to Nicolas Sarkozy's 2012 election campaign - are not related to the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report calls for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of the French Member to the European Parliament, Jerome Lavrilleux of the EFDD Group. Since the Member himself is in favour of suspension, I voted in favour.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The alleged charges are not related to the performance of Mr Lavrilleux’s duties as a Member of the European Parliament but related to his previous responsibilities in a presidential election campaign team set up for a vote that took place two years before Mr Lavrilleux was elected a Member of the European Parliament. There is no well-founded suspicion that the legal proceedings have been instituted with the intention of causing political damage to the Member.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. Jérôme Lavrilleux is charged with document forgery, abuse of trust, attempted fraud, concealment and complicity in criminal offences, and unlawful financing of an election campaign in France. It should be taken into account that the charges against Jérôme Lavrilleux are not related to the performance of his or her duties as a Member of the European Parliament, but stem from his previous post as deputy campaign director in france's last presidential election and are not related to the expression of opinions and the vote of Members to serve in the European Parliament. On this basis, the Representative should prove his innocence in a court in France. I therefore support this report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Jérôme Lavrilleux.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. I supported jerome lavrilleux's immunity waiver report. The Chief Prosecutor of the Court of Appeal in Paris has requested that Jerome Lavrilleux, a MEMBER of the European Parliament, be lifted from his parliamentary immunity for an investigation into the proceedings charging him with forgery and use of documents, abuse of trust, attempted fraud and concealment of criminal offences and unlawful financing of an election campaign. In this regard, a judge in France would like to impose a measure of detention or other deprivation of liberty on Jerome Lavrilleux. Jerome Lavrilleux is suspected of participating in the system of issuing false invoices for election campaign expenses, therefore the charges jerome lavrilleux is charged with are not related to the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, but stem from his previous post as deputy campaign director in france's last presidential election. Prosecution is not related to the expression of an opinion or the vote of Jerome Lavrilleux to serve as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8(1) of the EIA. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union. Parliament found no evidence for fumus persecutionis, i.e. for a sufficiently serious and reasonable suspicion that the proceedings were initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the MEMBER concerned.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal because I agree that Jérôm Lavrilleux's role in the related false invoicing system should be investigated. Parliamentary immunity should not serve to cover up or make it difficult to investigate fraudulent crimes.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am therefore opposed to parliamentary privileges and in particular to parliamentary immunity. Everyone is equal in the face of the law.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting my colleague's immunity, a request shared even by the Member in question. It is normal for him to be able to explain himself to his national authorities.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of suspending the immunity of The Member of the European Parliament, Jerome Lavrilleux, as he is accused of illegal financing of election campaigns and, therefore, cannot enjoy immunity as a member of this House.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report calls for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of the French Member to the European Parliament, Jerome Lavrilleux of the EFDD Group. Since the Member himself is in favour of suspension, I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The charges do not concern the situation of Jérôme Lavrilleux as a Member of the European Parliament and stem from his previous role as deputy director of election campaigning in the last presidential elections held in France. The judicial procedure does not concern the opinions or votes expressed by Jérôme Lavrilleux in the exercise of his term as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the Protocol (7) on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union. Parliament has not detected a sufficiently serious and reasoned suspicion that, at the origin of the judicial proceedings, the intention to undermine the political activity of the Member is.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. In France, after the 2012 presidential elections, candidate Nicolas Sarkozy found inconsistencies in the use of his campaign accounts. In his capacity as deputy campaign manager of Nicolas Sarkozy, Mr Lavrilleux is accused of forgery, the use of forged documents, infidelity, attempted fraud and, moreover, the illegal financing of the election campaign. That is why I voted accordingly.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. EP Jérôme Lavrilleux is suspected of participating in a fictitious election campaign expenses billing system as part of a pending judicial investigation (forgery and use of false documents, abuse of trust, attempted fraud, complicity in these offences and their cover-up, as well as illegal financing of an election campaign and complicity in this offence and its cover-up), as a supporter of Sarkozy's election campaign to the Presidency of France. The rapporteur considers that the accusations do not concern the situation of Jérôme Lavrilleux as a Member of the European Parliament, since they stem from his previous duties as deputy director of the election campaign in the last presidential elections held in France and that the judicial procedure does not concern opinions or votes expressed by Jérôme Lavrilleux in the exercise of his term as a Member of the European Parliament , in the meaning of Article 8 of the Protocol (7) on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union. We voted in favour of lifting parliamentary immunity.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This request for suspension of parliamentary immunity from Janusz Korwin-Mikke (unenrolled far-right Polish MP) has been received for his assault on Micha-Boni, another Member of the European Parliament. That is why I have had no doubt and voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. On 11 July 2014, Mr Korwin-Mikke slapped a Polish MEP in public. Although the alleged events took place during the course of his duties as an MEP, they do not concern an opinion or a vote but an alleged attack on the physical integrity of a public servant. Mr. Korwin-Mikke himself asked for his immunity to be waived. So I voted for him.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote was not a roll-call vote. Therefore, in the interests of democracy I believe that the public has the right to know how I voted on this issue. I voted to waive immunity in this case because the alleged offence does not relate to the role of MEP and there is no obvious clear injustice as regards this case.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting the immunity of this parliamentarian in accordance with the opinion of the committee on its merits.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report calls for the lifting of Janusz Korwin-Mikke's parliamentary immunity.  On 11 July 2014, the Warsaw District Prosecutor's Office alleges that Mr Korwin-Mikke damaged the physical integrity of Mr Michael Boni by slapping him at an event in Warsaw - a meeting of newly elected Polish MPs in the European Parliament - during which the victim was performing his official duties in connection with his mandate as an MEP. Mr. Korwin-Mikke's conduct may constitute a misdemeanour under Article 222, paragraph 1 of the Polish Penal Code, as it would have been detrimental to the physical integrity of a civil servant. Mr Korwin-Mikke wished to have his immunity lifted, so I voted for this report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of suspending this Member's immunity in view of the president-general of the Republic of Poland having transmitted an application from the Warsaw District Prosecutor's Office calling for permission to initiate criminal proceedings against Janusz Korwin-Mikke for an alleged attack on the physical integrity of a public official and in view of the alleged criminal offence being unrelated or manifest to the exercise of the functions of the Member of the European Parliament and that Parliament has no evidence of a fumus persecutionis, that is to say, a sufficiently strong and precise suspicion that the matter has arisen with the intention of causing political harm to the Member.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the Prosecutor General of the Republic of Poland has forwarded a request from the Warsaw District Prosecutor for the prosecution of Janusz Korwin-Mikke, a Member of the European Parliament, for the criminal offence provided for in Article 222(1) of the Criminal Code of the Republic of Poland; whereas the case concerns, in particular, allegations of breach of the inviolability of the civil servant's body. According to the Warsaw District Prosecutor's Office, on 11 July 2014, Mr Korwin-Mikke violated the inviolability of the body of Michał Boni (Michał Boni) by hand-to-face at an event (a meeting of newly elected Polish MePs organised by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Poland) in Warsaw, where the victim was in the office of an official Member of the European Parliament. Mr Korwino-Mikke's conduct may be regarded as a criminal offence within the meaning of Article 222(1) of the Criminal Code of the Republic of Poland (Polish CC) (suspicion of breach of the inviolability of the body of a civil servant). Under Article 115(13)(2a) of the Polish CCC, a member of the European Parliament is a civil servant.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ In Article 9. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union states that MEPs on the territory of their state enjoy immunity recognised by members of that country's parliament. Since a request from a national authority may initiate proceedings to waive that immunity, I grant the application.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal to waive Therendt's immunity. Korwin-Mikke because I believe that the facts he committed are not protected by the rules on immunity of Protocol 7.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. Mr Korwin-Mikke has publicly slapped another Polish MEP, which is likely to constitute a crime punishable by the Polish penal code. He also asked the European Parliament for his own waiver of immunity. That is why I voted for the report calling for the lifting of Janusz Korwin-Mikke's parliamentary immunity.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 The MP allegedly slapped another Polish MP in July 2014 at a meeting of MEPs. I abstained.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which relates to the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke, who is a Polish NI MEP. The alleged facts are unconnected to the exercise of the office of MEP and the rules appear to be applied equitably and uniformly. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of the waiver of immunity.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 11 July 2014, Mr S.P. Mr Korwin-Mikke violated the physical integrity of another MEP, Mr Korwin-Mikke. Michał Boni, slapping him during a meeting of newly elected Polish MEPs organised by the Polish Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Since the alleged offence has no direct connection with the exercise of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament, Protocol No 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union cannot apply. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the request for waiver of immunity.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. Mr Korwin-Mikke has breached the physical integrity of another member of the European Parliament, which may constitute a crime under the Polish penal code. According to Mr. Korwin-Mikke's statements at his hearing, there is no indication of the existence of fumus persecutionis. The events took place when Mr Korwin-Mikke was already a Member of the European Parliament and in a clearly political context, the alleged offence and the prosecutions that follow are then unrelated to his mandate as an MEP. So I voted to waive immunity.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text under discussion sets out the EP's reasons for the request to waive the immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke. On 29 December 2014, the President announced, pursuant to Rule 9(1) of the Rules of Procedure, that he had received a letter from the Attorney General of Poland requesting the waiver of janusz Korwin-Mikke's parliamentary immunity. Having examined the documents, the committee decided to submit to the EP the decision to waive immunity, since the charges clearly have no relation to the office of Member of the European Parliament.  At the time of the events, Mr De Clercq said that it was not a good example of this. Mr Korwin-Mikke violated the physical integrity of Mr Korwin-Mikke. Michał Boni slapping him during an event in Warsaw – a meeting of newly elected Polish MEPs, organised by the Polish Ministry of Foreign Affairs – at which the party involved was exercising official functions related to the post of Member of the European Parliament.  Furthermore, there is no reason to suppose that there is a fumus persecutionis. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the measure.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Due to the fact that the events relating to this matter have nothing to do with janusz Korwin-Mikke's current position as AN MEP, I have decided to vote in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The alleged offence does not have a direct or obvious connection with the Member’s performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and nor does it constitute an opinion expressed or a vote cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union. I have thus voted in favour of the report to waive the immunity of the Member.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke, who was accused of physical injury to my fellow Member of the European Parliament, Michał Boni, having hit him in the face with his hand, while he was carrying out his official duties linked to his participation in a meeting of Polish Members of the European Parliament in the 8th parliamentary term, and since this behaviour was not related to the exercise of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This request to suspend the parliamentary immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke (unenrolled Polish far-right Member) has been received for his assault on Micha-Boni, another Member of the European Parliament. That is why I have had no doubt and voted in favour.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report as I am therefore opposed to parliamentary privileges and in particular to parliamentary immunity. Everyone is equal in the face of the law.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. I believe, in principle, that the European Parliament should, as a rule, waive the immunity of a Member when judicial authorities so require. Exceptions shall only be made where there is a clear risk of political or personal persecution.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has made an application to the EP for authorisation from the Warsaw District Prosecutor's Office to prosethis criminal proceedings against a Member of the European Parliament, Janusz Korwin-Mikke, for alleged ly breaching the physical integrity of a public official. The alleged acts do not have a direct or obvious link with the exercise of the duties of Member of the European Parliament by Janusz Korwin-Mikke, nor do they constitute opinions or votes expressed in the performance of her duties as a Member of the EP, and that Parliament has failed to find any evidence of fumus persecutionis. I agree with the waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I voted to lift Mr Janusz Korwin-Mikke's parliamentary immunity because he had previously requested it.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In December 2014, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of the European Parliament (EP) an application for authorisation submitted by the Warsaw District Prosecutor's Office that same month to proselate a Polish Member of the European Parliament, Janusz Korwin—Mikke. In July 2014, Janusz Korwin-Mikke allegedly tried against the physical integrity of Michał Boni (also an MEP), hitting him in the face during an event in Warsaw – in the event, a meeting with polish Members newly elected to the European Parliament, promoted by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Janusz Korwin-Mikke's conduct may constitute an offence under Article 222(1) of the Polish Penal Code, in so far as the physical integrity of a public official has allegedly been called into question. Under Article 115(13)(2a) of the Polish Penal Code, a Member of the European Parliament is a civil servant. In view of the arguments set out and in accordance with Article 9(3) of the Rules of Procedure, the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that the European Parliament withdraw Janusz's immunity. Korwin-mikke. We voted in favour.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the request for the waiver of Mr Janusz Korwin-Mikke's parliamentary immunity as I am therefore opposed to parliamentary privileges and in particular to parliamentary immunity. Everyone is equal in the face of the law.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Whereas the alleged offence does not have a direct or obvious connection with Mr Korwin-Mikke’s performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and nor does it constitute an opinion expressed or a vote cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union; whereas in this case Parliament has found no evidence of fumus persecutionis, which is to say a sufficiently serious and precise suspicion that the case has been brought with the intention of causing political damage to the Member concerned, I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Korwin-Mikke given that the alleged offence does not relate to the role of MEP.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the waiver of Mr Korwin-Mikke's immunity because there are not enough serious reasons to believe that the court has been seised in order to damage the political reputation of Mr Korwin-Mikke as a Member of the European Parliament, because the accusation made has nothing to do with his position as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on a request to lift Janusz Korwin-Mikke's immunity due to the alleged breach of the physical integrity of a public servant, namely Mr Michal Boni. Moreover, in this case it can be established that the offence committed is not related to the performance of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. Janusz Korwin-Mikke slapped a Polish MEP on 11 July 2014 in front of witnesses. These facts do not concern a political opinion but an alleged attack on the physical integrity of a civil servant in the performance of his or her duties as an MEP.  The procedure for lifting parliamentary immunity does not appear to have been politically motivated, there is no particular reason to object. In fact, Janusz Korwin-Mikke himself has called for the lifting of parliamentary immunity. I voted in favour of the procedure.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report of my colleague Kostas Chrysogonos on Janusz Korwin-Mikke's request for the lifting of parliamentary immunity. This procedure, requested by the Member concerned, is a formality in order to enable the judicial authorities to carry out their investigative work.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. Mr Korwin-Mikke punched Mr Micha' Boni, himself also a Member of the European Parliament, in the face at an event in Warsaw. Such behaviour, which is devoid of any collegiality or respect, must be punished, which is why I am voting in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as I agree with the reasons of the proposal to waive immunity.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Voting in favour of Mr Chrysogonos' report was my support for the request for the waiver of Janusz Korwin-Mikke's immunity. The Committee on Legal Affairs has recommended the waiver of immunity, noting that the facts in question are not related to his work as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The Warsaw District Prosecutor's Office alleges that on 11 July 2014, Mr. Korwin-Mikke violated the physical integrity of Mr. Michael Boni by slapping him at an event in Warsaw. It was a meeting of newly elected Polish MEPs in the European Parliament, organised by the Polish Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Kostas Chrysogonos' report states that "in view of the circumstances of this case and the statements made by Mr. Korwin-Mikke at his hearing, there is no indication of the existence of a fumus persecutionis. Indeed, while it is true that the above-mentioned events took place when Mr Korwin-Mikke was already a Member of the European Parliament and in a clearly political context, the alleged offence and the prosecutions that follow are clearly unrelated to his mandate as an MEP." I therefore voted in favour of lifting Janusz Korwin-Mikke's parliamentary immunity.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted to lift immunity because Mr Korwin-Mikke is being prosecuted for slapping another Polish MEP in public. He acknowledges the facts and asks for his immunity to be waived.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Janusz Korwin-Mikke is an independent Polish representative, a member of the Foreign Affairs Committee and the Delegation for Relations with the People's Republic of China.  The request for the waiver of immunity was forwarded to Parliament by the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland for violation of the Criminal Code initiated by the District Attorney's Office in Warsaw. It has been established that that offence is not directly linked to the performance of his or her duties as a Member of the European Parliament or that he is causing political damage.  I supported The Report of MeP Kostas Chrysogonos on the waiver of immunity for Mep Korwin-Mikke, who, at a meeting of newly elected Polish members of the European Parliament in Warsaw, struck Mr Michał Boni in the face with his hand and thereby violated his physical integrity.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the waiver of Janusz Korwin-Mikke's parliamentary immunity following the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted that the European Parliament should waive the parliamentary immunity of Mr Janusz Korwin-Mikke for the reasons set out in the report.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for this waiver of immunity. Janusz Korwin-Mikke is being prosecuted, at the initiative of the Polish prosecutor's office, for endangering the physical integrity of another Polish MP during an event in Warsaw in connection with the European mandate. Mr. Korwin-Mikke's conduct is a misdemeanor under the Polish penal code, and he himself has requested the lifting of his immunity. That is why we supported it.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with this report on the request for waiver of the immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke.  I am of the opinion that the Member should continue to enjoy immunity as a guarantor and I will continue to vote against these reports. The fact that this immunity exists is a guarantee for the independence of the European Parliament as an institution and not for the personal benefit of the Members who are part of it.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. As the conduct to be pursued is not related to political activity, I voted in favour of the request for annulment.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report calls for the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke, an unregistered Polish MP. He is accused of having damaged the physical integrity of Mr Michael Boni, also an MEP, by slapping him. While it is true that the above-mentioned events took place when Mr Korwin-Mikke was already a Member of the European Parliament and in a clearly political context, the alleged offence and the prosecutions that follow are clearly unrelated to his mandate as an MEP.  This character is obnoxious and irresponsible enough to have declared that "Hitler was not aware of the Holocaust" and to have spoken out against women's right to vote. A prospective partner of Ms Le Pen, this MP is a disgrace to Parliament. I'm voting to lift immunity.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of the independence of the Mandate of the European Parliament is the responsibility of the European Parliament and that independence cannot be called into question. In accordance with Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties. The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland has made an application to the EP for authorisation by the Warsaw District Prosecutor's Office to prosedate a Member of the European Parliament, Janusz Korwin-Mikke, concerning an infringement of Article 222(1) of the Polish Penal Code, specifying that the case relates to the alleged breach of the physical integrity of a public official. Parliament has failed to find any evidence of fumus persecutionis, that is, a sufficiently serious and precise presumption that the case was instituted with the intention of harming the political activity of the Member.  I therefore voted in favour of the lifting of parliamentary immunity.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report on the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke.

name: Bernard Monot (NI)
text: In writing. Mr Korwin-Mikke himself wished to have his immunity waived, and there was no reason to object.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This report calls for the lifting of MP Janusz Korwin-Mikke's immunity. He is accused of undermining the physical integrity of Michael Boni by slapping him during a meeting between newly elected Polish MEPs held in Warsaw. The alleged offences took place in the course of Mr. Korwin-Mikke's duties as a Member of Parliament. These acts are punishable by imprisonment under Polish law and therefore constitute a crime. Considering that Mr Korwin-Mikke himself has asked for the lifting of his parliamentary immunity, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted to lift Janusz Korwin-Mikke's parliamentary immunity. Any request made to the President of the European Parliament by the authorities of a Member State to waive a Member's immunity is heard by the relevant parliamentary committee. I voted in accordance with the opinion of the committee.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the rapporteur's proposal from the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. It has been proven that Janusz Korwin-Mikke violated the physical integrity of Micha' Boni on 11 July 2014 by slapping him in the face during an event in Warsaw. The conduct of Janusz Korwin-Mikke is a criminal offence under Article 222(1) of the Polish Penal Code. On the basis of this fact, I voted in favour of waiving parliamentary immunity.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. Whereas, pursuant to Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, Members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or prosecuted on the grounds of opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties; that, pursuant to Article 9 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, Members of the European Parliament enjoy on their national territory the immunities accorded to members of their country's Parliament; that, pursuant to Article 105(2) of the Constitution of the Republic of Poland, a Member may not be held to account criminally without the authorisation of the Sejm; I voted in favour.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. Mr. Korwin-Mikke himself requested that his immunity be waived in order to defend himself against the charges against him for slapping a public servant. In these circumstances, since the report calls for the lifting of immunity, I vote in favour.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I respect the rapporteur's recommendation because, although the prosecution is not related to the opinion expressed or the vote to serve as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the EIA, it is not related to the opinion expressed or the vote to serve as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the EEA. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, and the alleged offence is clearly in no relation to the performance of his or her colleague Korwin-Mikke as a Member of the European Parliament, there is no reason to assume that the prosecution was initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the Member concerned (fumus persecutionis) because it was initiated before Mr Korwin-Mikke became a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported MP Kostas Chrysogonos' report on the request to lift the immunity of Mp Janusz Korwin-Mikke. In this case, it is an alleged offence of breaching the physical integrity of a public servant charged with Janusz Korwin-Mikke during his time as a Member of the European Parliament. The Committee on Legal Affairs found unanimously that it was not a prosecution initiated with the intention of causing political harm to a Member, and that the alleged offence was not directly or manifestly linked to the performance of his or her duties as an MEP, nor was it concerning the opinion expressed or voting in the performance of his or her duties.  I therefore agree with the Decision of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the waiver of immunity, as the remedy for the protection of citizens' representatives at EU level must not place Members above the law. Parliamentary immunity is a remedy that protects the smooth functioning of Members and thus constitutes a necessary means of protecting parliament's independence. In order to be credible, it is important that parliamentary immunity is solely an instrument of protection against politically motivated persecution.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The legal rules of the European Parliament must also be applied in the case of Janusz Korwin-Mikke. Immunity is normally waived where the offence falls within the scope of Article 9 of the Protocol provided that there is no fumus persecutionis, i.e. the sufficiently serious and precise suspicion that the case is brought before a court with the intention of politically harming the Member concerned. The hearing in the Committee on Legal Affairs did not show that there was fumus persecutionis despite the fact that the events occurred at a time when Korwin-Mikke was already a Member of the European Parliament, but the alleged crime and subsequent prosecution have nothing to do with korwin-mikke's position as a Member of the European Parliament. The unanimous vote of the Committee on Legal Affairs also demonstrates this, hence my vote in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 29 December 2014, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke, Member of the European Parliament, in criminal proceedings for alleged violation of the physical integrity of a civil servant. Under Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, Members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties. According to the view of the Committee on Legal Affairs, although the facts occurred when Janusz Korwin-Mikke was already a Member of the European Parliament, in a political context the alleged offence cannot be considered to be related to the performance of the duties of a Member. On this terms and on the basis of the JURI report, I voted in favour of this decision to lift the parliamentary immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The lifting of parliamentary immunity follows a very rigorous procedure. In the case of the Member of the European Parliament, immunity can generally be waived when the offence is absolutely not related to the exercise of the office of a Member of Parliament - and therefore falls under Article 9 of the Protocol on the privileges and immunities of the European Union. The same article also stipulates that immunity cannot be invoked in the case of flagrante delict and cannot also interfere with the right of the European Parliament to lift the immunity of one of its members. This derogation is logical and is most often justified by the seriousness of the alleged facts and/or by the possibility of making the judicial decision quickly. This is not the case with the adoption of the Chrysogonos report this afternoon. It is simply a matter for the plenary to follow the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs, which had unanimously recommended that the European Parliament lift janusz Korwin-Mikke's parliamentary immunity, as requested by the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland for physical violence against another Member of Parliament. This waiver of immunity will allow the Polish justice system to make a firm decision against this individual accustomed to racist and anti-Semitic provocations.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a matter of Polish internal justice, unrelated to the status of Deputy of Janusz Korwin-Mikke.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of this Member's immunity in view of the alleged attack on the physical integrity of a public official and in view of the alleged criminal offence being not directly or manifestly related to the exercise of a public official. of the functions of the Member of the European Parliament and that Parliament has no evidence of a fumus persecutionis, that is to say, a sufficiently strong and precise suspicion that the matter has arisen with the intention of causing political harm to the Member.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting Mr. Janusz Korwin-Mikke, so that the Polish judiciary can continue its work, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, considering that the facts in question - allegedly impairing the physical integrity of a civil servant - have nothing to do with the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament and that the proceedings are not intended to interfere with Mr Korwin-Mikke's political activity.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This request for suspension of parliamentary immunity from Janusz Korwin-Mikke (unenrolled far-right Polish MP) has been received for his assault on Micha-Boni, another Member of the European Parliament. That is why I have had no doubt and voted in favour.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)

Indeed, although the facts occurred when Mr Korwin-Mikke was already a Member of the European Parliament and in an explicitly political context, the alleged offence and the ensuing prosecution clearly have nothing to do with the position of Mr Korwin-Mikke as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)

Protocol on the privileges and immunity of the European Union according to which Members of the European Parliament cannot be subjected to any form of examination, detention or judicial proceedings due to expressed opinions or voting in the performance of their duties, and there is no reason to assume that the procedure was initiated in order to cause political damage to that Member, I support this Report because the procedure relates to allegations of violation of the physical integrity of a public official, i.e. article 222, paragraph 1, of the Criminal Code of the Republic of Poland. I also believe that an MP should prove his innocence in a court in Poland.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of the Polish MEP Janusz Korwin-Mikke.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Attorney General of the Republic of Poland forwarded the request of the Warsaw District Attorney's Office for the authorisation to initiate criminal proceedings against MEP Janusz Korwin-Mikke for the offence referred to in Article 222(1) of the Code of Civil Procedure. Criminal Code of the Republic of Poland which is why I supported this request for waiver of immunity. In particular, the procedure relates to allegations of breaches of the physical integrity of a public servant. In accordance with Article 8 Members of the European Parliament may not be subject to any form of questioning, detention or judicial proceedings due to expressed opinions or voting in the performance of their duties. As confirmed at this hearing, the alleged offence is not directly or manifestly linked to korwin-mikke's performance as a Member of the European Parliament, nor is it concerning the opinion expressed or voting in the performance of his or her duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8(1) of the EEA. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union. There is no reason to assume, i.e. serious and reasonable enough suspicion, that the proceedings were initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the member concerned (fumus persecutionis).

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am therefore opposed to parliamentary privileges and in particular to parliamentary immunity. Everyone is equal in the face of the law.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting my colleague's immunity, a request shared even by the Member in question. It is normal for him to be able to explain himself to his national authorities.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of suspending immunity to MEP Janusz Korwin-Mikke, accused of assaulting an MP, which has no relation to his parliamentary activity and makes him unjustifiable to enjoy immunity.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. On 11 July 2014, Janusz Korwin-Mikke allegedly took action against the physical integrity of Michał Boni (MEP), punching him in the face during an event in Warsaw – in the event, a meeting with newly elected Polish Members of the European Parliament, promoted by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.  Janusz Korwin-Mikke's conduct may constitute an offence under Article 222(1) of the Polish Penal Code, in so far as the physical integrity of a public official has allegedly been called into question.  In view of the arguments set out, and pursuant to Article 9(3) of the Rules of Procedure, the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that the European Parliament lift the immunity of Janusz Korwin-Mikke.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 29 December 2014, the Attorney General of the Republic of Poland forwarded to the President of the European Parliament an application for authorisation lodged by the Warsaw District Prosecutor's Office on 19 December 2014 to proselate a Member of the European Parliament, Janusz Korwin-Mikke. On 11 July 2014, Janusz Korwin-Mikke allegedly attacked the physical integrity of Michał Boni (MEP), hitting him in the face during an event in Warsaw – a meeting with newly elected Polish MePs to the European Parliament, promoted by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Janusz Korwin-Mikke's conduct may constitute an offence under Article 222(1) of the Polish Penal Code, in so far as the physical integrity of a public official has allegedly been called into question. Under Article 115(13)(2a) of the Polish Penal Code, a Member of the European Parliament is a civil servant. In view of the arguments set out and in accordance with Article 9(3) of the Rules of Procedure, the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that the European Parliament lift Mr Korwin-Mikke's immunity. We've followed that position.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with this report on the request for waiver of the immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis.  I am of the opinion that the Member should continue to enjoy immunity as a guarantor and I will continue to vote against these reports. The fact that this immunity exists is a guarantee for the independence of the European Parliament as an institution and not for the personal benefit of the Members who are part of it.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. As the conduct to be pursued is not related to political activity, I voted in favour of the request for annulment.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report calls for the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis, a Greek EPP MP. He is accused of having committed financial irregularities between 2007 and 2012 within the football club PAOK of which he was president at the time. The alleged offence and the ensuing prosecution clearly have nothing to do with his mandate as an MEP. The person concerned agrees with the measure, so I vote to lift parliamentary immunity.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of the independence of the Mandate of the European Parliament is the responsibility of the European Parliament and that independence cannot be called into question. In accordance with Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties. The Deputy Prosecutor of the Supreme Court of Greece has requested the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis, a Member of the European Parliament, in connection with a possible legal action relating to an alleged offence. Theodoros Zagorakis is accused of being responsible for financial irregularities between 2007 and 2012 at the paok football club, of which he was president at the time. The alleged offence obviously has no relation to the seat of deputy held by Theodoros Zagorakis in the European Parliament, but is linked to his position as president of the PAOK football club. There is no reason to suspect that the intention behind the criminal proceedings is to undermine the political activity of the Deputy (fumus persecutionis), since the case was initiated several years before the Deputy took office. I therefore voted in favour of the lifting of parliamentary immunity.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report on the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)

name: Sophie Montel (NI)

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)

I voted in accordance with the opinion of the committee to lift the parliamentary immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the rapporteur's proposal from the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that the deputy prosecutor at the Supreme Court of Greece has requested the waiver of the immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis, Member of the European Parliament, in relation to a possible legal action concerning a hypothesis of crime; that Article 9 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union provides that Members of the European Parliament shall enjoy, on their national territory, the immunities accorded to members of the Parliament of their country; that Article 62 of the Constitution of the Hellenic Republic provides that, during the parliamentary term, members of parliament may not be prosecuted, arrested, detained or otherwise deprived of their liberty without the prior authorisation of parliament; I voted in favour.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)

Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, and the alleged offence is clearly not in any relation to the performance of his or her duties as a Member of the European Parliament, but concerns his function at the PAOK football club in Greece, there is no reason to assume that the prosecution was initiated with the intention of causing political damage to the member concerned (fumus persecutionis) because it was initiated before Mr Zagorakis became a Member of the European Parliament.

text: Written. ‒ I supported MP Andrzej Duda's report on a request to lift the immunity of fellow MP Theodoros Zagorakis. For fellow MEP Theodorus Zagorakis, who was accused of financial irregularities during his presidency of a football club in Greece from 2007 to 2012, the EP Legal Affairs Committee found that it was not a prosecution initiated with the intention of causing political damage to the MEP. Since the initiated proceedings have nothing to do with the performance of Theodoros Zagorakis as a Member of the European Parliament than with the function of president of the football club, I agree with the unanimous decision of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the waiver of immunity, since the remedy for the protection of citizens' representatives at EUROPEAN Union level must not place Members above the law. Parliamentary immunity is a remedy that protects the smooth functioning of Members and thus constitutes a necessary means of protecting parliament's independence. In order to be credible, it is important that parliamentary immunity is solely an instrument of protection against politically motivated persecution.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The alleged crime of which he is accused has no connection with the office of Member of the European Parliament of Theodoros Zagorakis, but is rather linked to his position as president of the PAOK football club and to facts prior to his election. Nor does it seem that we can talk about fumus persecutionis, that is, that the intention behind the criminal proceedings is to damage the political activity of the Member since the criminal proceedings were launched a few years before he took office in the European Parliament. That is why I voted in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 10 March 2015, the Deputy Prosecutor of the Supreme Court of Greece requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis, in the context of an action pending before the Court of First Instance of Thessaloniki concerning financial irregularities between 2007 and 2012 at the paok football club, at the time presided over by that member. Under Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, Members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties. According to the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs, the alleged offence has no relation to the position of Member of the European Parliament, but is linked to the position of Theodoros Zagorakis as president of the paok football club. Accordingly, and on the basis of the JURI report, I voted in favour of this decision to lift the parliamentary immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The lifting of parliamentary immunity follows a very rigorous procedure. In the case of the Member of the European Parliament, immunity can generally be waived when the offence is absolutely not related to the exercise of the office of a Member of Parliament - and therefore falls under Article 9 of the Protocol on the privileges and immunities of the European Union. The same article also stipulates that immunity cannot be invoked in the case of flagrante delict. This derogation is logical and is most often justified by the seriousness of the alleged facts and/or by the possibility of making the judicial decision quickly. This is not the case with the adoption of the Duda report this afternoon. It is simply a matter for the plenary to follow the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs, which had unanimously recommended that the European Parliament lift the parliamentary immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis, as requested by the Deputy Prosecutor of the Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic.  This waiver of immunity will allow the MEP concerned to defend himself like any other citizen knowing that the alleged offence is not related to his position as a Member of the European Parliament, but that it concerns his former position as president of the PAOK football club.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a matter of Greek internal justice, unrelated to the status of deputy of Theodoros Zagorakis.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of suspending this Member's immunity in view of the alleged financial irregularities between 2007 and 2012 at PAOK Football Club, of which he was president at the time. , and in view of the view that the alleged offence is unrelated to the office of Member of the European Parliament and that Parliament has no evidence of a fumus persecutionis, that is to say, a sufficiently strong and precise suspicion that the matter has arisen with the intention of causing political harm to the Member.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the lifting of Mr. Theodoros Zagorakis' immunity so that the Greek justice system could do its job, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, concerning allegations of financial irregularities committed when Mr Zagorakis was president of the PAOK football club; prosecutions unrelated to the performance of his duties as an MEP.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Theodoros Zagorakis as he is being investigated for having committed financial irregularities in Greece during his pre-European Parliament.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The alleged offence clearly has no link with Mr Zagorakis’s post as a Member of the European Parliament, but rather is connected to his position as President of the PAOK football club. We voted to waive the immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ MEP Theodoros Zagorakis was charged with financial irregularities during his presidency of the PAOK football club between 2007 and 2012. Since this offence is not related to the performance of the duties of Theodoros Zagorakis as a Member of the European Parliament, but to his function as president of the PAOK football club, the prosecution is not related to the expression of an opinion or a vote in the performance of his or her duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and that there is no reason to suspect that criminal proceedings have been initiated with the intention of causing political harm to a Member, I support this report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis, a Greek MEP.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. I supported this report on the waiver of Theodoros Zagorakis' immunity. Due to the alleged criminal part of Theodoros Zagorakis, the deputy state's attorney at the Greek Supreme Court requested the waiver of the mp's immunity. Zagorakis has been charged with financial irregularities during his presidency of the PAOK football club between 2007 and 2012, and his alleged criminal offence is clearly unrelated to his or her performance of his duties in the European Parliament and his expressed opinion or vote in the performance of official duties. Criminal proceedings were initiated several years ago, i.e. before Mr Zagorakis became a Member of the European Parliament and there is no reason in this regard that criminal proceedings were initiated with the intention of causing political damage.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal because, as the report on the proposal also states, the alleged offence clearly has no connection with the function of a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am therefore opposed to parliamentary privileges and in particular to parliamentary immunity. Everyone is equal in the face of the law.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting my colleague's immunity, a request shared even by the Member in question. It is normal for him to be able to explain himself to his national authorities.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of suspending the immunity of Greek MePs to the European Parliament Theodoros Zagorakis, as he faces a trial for his performance at the helm of the PAOK football club, that is, for an activity that has nothing to do with his work as an MEP.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Theodoros Zagorakis as he is being investigated for having committed financial irregularities in Greece during his pre-European Parliament.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Theodoros Zagorakis is accused of being responsible for financial irregularities between 2007 and 2012 at the football club PAOK, of which he was president at the time. The offence of which he is accused has nothing to do with the seat of a member of the European Parliament, but is linked to his position as president of the PAOK football club. The complaint does not concern opinions or votes cast in the performance of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament for the purposes of Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union. There is no reason to suspect that the intention behind the criminal proceedings is to undermine the political activity of the Member, since the proceedings were initiated several years before the Member took office. We voted for it.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. As the conduct to be pursued is not related to political activity, I voted in favour of the request for annulment.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Mr Theodoros Zagorakis is accused of being responsible for financial irregularities between 2007 and 2012 at the PAOK football club, of which he was president at the time. The rapporteur considers that the offence of which Theodoros Zagorakis is accused has nothing to do with his position as a Member of the European Parliament, but is linked to his position as president of the PAOK football club. It considers that the complaint does not concern opinions or votes cast in the performance of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament for the purposes of Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union. It also considers that there is no reason to suspect that the intention behind the criminal proceedings is to undermine the political activity of the Member, since the proceedings were initiated several years before the Member took office. It therefore decides to lift the immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis. We voted for it.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in this vote, because, although the procedure for consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee to deliver an opinion forms part of the normality of parliamentary activity and, in particular, the ordinary legislative procedure, voting in favour would imply the implicit recognition of the unequal importance attached in the Lisbon Treaty to institutions such as the Economic and Social Committee or the Committee of the Regions , as well as the secondary role of the European Parliament in many areas of the European Union in which it should appear at least as a co-decision on an equal footing with the Council.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. The consultation is just a smokescreen to mask the complexity of community institutional functioning. These committees have, until now, never proven their effectiveness or representativeness, let alone their expertise. However, the Union is still struggling to fund and consult them. Finally, these consultations are only aesthetic since they are never followed, rarely read. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As UKIP does not believe in Ecosoc, it was consistent to vote against this motion.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this request for consultation because the Committee of the Regions is an EU advisory body that brings us valuable expertise.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee. Where the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU provides for consultation of the Economic and Social Committee, the EP shall specify to the committee the time limit by which it is to deliver its opinion. Parliament shall approve the request to refer the matter to this committee for consultation without discussion.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Article 137 of the FUE Treaty provides that the Economic and Social Committee can be consulted on certain points. A commission can consult it on a general problem or on specific points. Requests for consultation by the Economic and Social Committee are subject to Parliament's approval without debate.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The European Union treaties provide for a consultation procedure with the European Economic and Social Committee. This request for consultation concerns the improvement of the 'functioning of the European Union by taking advantage of the potential of the Lisbon Treaty'. A program more than revealing and cynical since still denying the "No" of the French and the Dutch when they were consulted by referendum in 2005. Moreover, I think it would be better to abolish this institution (the EESC), which, like its French counterpart, has little use and activity but which costs the taxpayer dearly. So I voted against that request.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. I did not believe that consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee could provide real elements for improving the Union in relation to the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. As recommended by the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO) of this House, I voted in favour of requesting an official consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on two initiative reports which this parliamentary committee is preparing: 'Improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the possibilities of the Lisbon Treaty' and 'Possible amendments and adjustments to the current institutional configuration of the European Union'. It is relevant to know the opinion of the European Economic and Social Committee on these two issues in order to strengthen the recommendations that may be issued to improve the functioning of the EU and its institutional configuration.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒The European Parliament, as the representative body of European citizens, institutionalises cooperation with the European Economic and Social Committee according to the rules of procedure with a view to better functioning the EU.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this request for an opinion because I believe it is important to know the opinion of a body with great technical expertise such as the Economic and Social Committee, especially on a subject of great importance such as the improvement of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. This report deals with a request for consultation with an institution created by the Maastricht Treaty to represent civil society at European level. The European Economic and Social Committee, far from representing a civil society from twenty-eight Member States, is in fact a place of influence for many economic and associative lobbies. Finally, there is no evidence that the EESC is competent to give an opinion on matters relating to the functioning of the Union's institutions. I voted against it.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote to abstain against the request for consultation of the Economic and Social Committee. The Economic and Social Committee is a European institution which I would like to see erased. We do not believe that consultation can provide any interesting elements for improving the functioning of the European Union in relation to the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerned requests for opinions which are made in connection with two initiative reports, which are currently being drafted: – the Bresso-Brok report on ‘improving the functioning of the European Union building on the potential of the Lisbon treaty’  – the Verhofstadt report on ‘the possible evolutions and adjustments of the current institutional set up of the European Union’. The intention behind these initiative reports is to commence a debate regarding the future of the EU and possible Treaty changes in this context. It must be noted that these are matters that will undoubtedly prove controversial for my party. However, the request for opinions from the two institutions is a fundamental part of any democracy and, moreover, if we are to have a debate about the future of the EU, then as many stakeholders as possible should be heard in the process. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 On a dossier of such importance, it is important to request consultation of the social partners, who can provide interesting inputs and ideas, and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I rejected this proposal to endorse the European Economic and Social Committee's request for consultation on the theme of "improving the functioning of the European Union by harnessing the potential of the Lisbon Treaty". In the wake of the National Front, in fact, the usefulness and legitimacy of the EESC, a body created by the Maastricht Treaty and which merely swallows up European taxpayers' money to give simple advisory opinions on the decisions taken by the main institutions in Brussels.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, as provided for in Article 137 of its Rules of Procedure, was called upon to approve a request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on the theme "Improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon". The Economic and Social Committee may be consulted on general matters or on specific points. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with the rules of the Treaty of Lisbon, the Economic and Social Committee may be consulted by Parliament where it deems it appropriate, and it is for the parliamentary committees to require the European Economic and Social Committee to be consulted on general problems or on specific issues. I support the request of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs to consult the Economic and Social Committee on strengthening the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Lisbon Treaty. Given the nature of its composition and being the body par excellence that promotes participatory democracy and helps to strengthen the role of civil society organisations by establishing a structured dialogue, I believe that its auscultation will be an added value for discussion and reflection on the matter.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I abstained in this vote, because, although the procedure for consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee to deliver an opinion forms part of the normality of parliamentary activity and, in particular, the ordinary legislative procedure, voting in favour would imply the implicit recognition of the unequal importance attached in the Lisbon Treaty to institutions such as the Economic and Social Committee or the Committee of the Regions , as well as the secondary role of the European Parliament in many areas of the European Union in which it should appear at least as a co-decision on an equal footing with the Council.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this request as I believe that the European Economic and Social Committee, being one of the main EU institutions, should be consulted on the future report by the Committee on Constitutional Affairs that will deal with improving the functioning of the European Union and which will build on the potential of the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. As part of the ongoing reflection in the Parliamentary Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO) on possible improvements in the functioning of the European Union by harnessing the full potential of the Lisbon Treaty, this decision proposes to consult with the European Economic and Social Committee, representing economic and trade union actors in the European Union. Considering that the various stakeholders, economic and trade union actors, have their place in this debate, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The policy of grouping EU policies into a kind of European elite cartel, where the decision-making process is not the result of democratic processes, cannot be approved by us. The 'democratic' cloak of institutions and non-institutions simply exists as a pretext, but also as a mechanism for the consumption of Community funds necessary to combat poverty and to feed sustainable development

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The European Union could work far more effectively and discussion of this is to be welcomed. I believe that Wales could make a huge contribution to a more relevant and efficient EU if nations like ours had a greater and clearly—defined role. It would make the EU more democratic.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution. Indeed, I formally dispute the representativeness and usefulness of both the CDR and the EESC. They have no democratic legitimacy and also represent sumptuous and unnecessary expenses for European taxpayers.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We do not encourage any kind of illusions about the direction of 'strengthening the functioning of the EU' here in question. Even more so when this strengthening is defended 'on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon'. It does not mean anything other than an attempt to deepen the pillars of this capitalist integration: federalism, neoliberalism and militarism. A path that, in the face of the deep crisis facing the EU, the main political families – right and social democracy – have been rehearsing for some time. The intention is to take this deepening as far as possible, within the limits (already obviously broad, although not as broad as some new leaps, desired by some, could demand) of the Treaty of Lisbon, fleeing the public, democratic, scrutiny of peoples, particularly through referendums. For our part, we reaffirm our opposition to the Treaty of Lisbon and the need for its repeal. We reaffirm the proposal to enshrine the possibility of reversal of the Treaties by adapting the status of each country to the will of its people. We are not opposed to a consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee. But we are of course in mind - and here we denounce it - the sense of the background of this whole process.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I shall abstain in the vote on the request for consultation of the Economic and Social Committee because we have long considered this body to be completely superfluous.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The policy of grouping EU policies into a kind of European elite cartel, where the decision-making process is not the result of democratic processes, cannot be approved by me. I am voting against requests for consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee on 'Improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the possibilities of the Treaty of Lisbon'. The 'democratic' cloak of institutions and non-institutions simply exists as a pretext, but also as a mechanism for the consumption of Community funds necessary to combat poverty and to fuel sustainable development.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Economic and Social Committee cost the European taxpayer roughly EUR 120 million in 2014 and will do so again in 2015. This money could be put to far better use, especially at a time when governments across Europe are cutting down on expenditure. Rather than engage in consultations with the European Economic and Social Committee, we should abolish it.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I approve the request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on ‘Improving the Functioning of the European Union building on the potential of the Lisbon Treaty’.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Treaty of Lisbon marked a turning point for the European Union in a number of areas. In particular, it can undoubtedly be said that it has increased democratic participation and transparency. If much has been done, it is also true that great potential is still only left on paper. For all the potential to be exploited, however, it is necessary that the European institutions do not close down but, on the contrary, open up as much as possible to the greatest number of actors in civil society. That is why I voted in favour of the request for consultation of a body such as the European Economic and Social Committee, which will be able to give us an in-depth opinion containing ideas and proposals from consumers, farmers, workers and many other parts of civil society.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. The Economic and Social Committee has sent us a request for consultation on the important issue of 'Improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon'. I voted in favour of this request, which is rightly justified by the use of Rule 137 of Parliament's Rules of Procedure. I would like to thank Mr Schulz for starting the consultation procedure. It will be very important to involve the Economic and Social Committee, which is the direct representative of the European social, trade union and productive bodies, in this important process of discussion.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this request as I believe it is appropriate that the Economic and Social Committee be consulted regarding the improvement of the functioning of the European Union building on the potential of the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my Labour colleagues, voted in favour of the request for consultation of the Committee of the Regions on ‘Improving the functioning of the European Union building on the potential of the Lisbon Treaty’.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request to refer to the European Economic and Social Committee for consultation on improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the opportunities offered by the Treaty of Lisbon and possible changes and adjustments to the institutional framework of the European Union, as I believe that the social partners' views are very important in the planning of structural changes and adjustments under the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Vote for. Article 137 of the Regulation of the European Parliament provides the possibility of consulting different bodies of the European Union in order to improve the functioning of the Regulation.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a request to consult the European Economic and Social Committee on improving the functioning of the European Union based on the potential of the Lisbon Treaty, as I consider that in such an important area the voice of civil society organisations is essential to strengthen economic and social cohesion within the European Union and to strengthen the "presence" of the European institutions. I therefore believe that the European Economic and Social Committee can adopt a quality opinion that can contribute to concrete proposals and attitudes, improving the functioning of the European Union in the context of the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text to consult the European Economic and Social Committee on the theme 'Improving the functioning of the European Union by harnessing the potential of the Lisbon Treaty'. Indeed, the so-called European "comitology" is merely a smokescreen used to mask the inefficiency of its administration. These committees have, until now, never proven their effectiveness or representativeness, let alone their expertise, and yet the Union is still working to finance and consult them. Finally, these consultations are only aesthetic since they are never followed, rarely read.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal for the EESC consultation on improving the functioning of the EU. This consultation will provide avenues for better functioning of the European Union through the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Economic and Social Committee's request for consultation on the theme "Improving the functioning of the European Union by harnessing the potential of the Lisbon Treaty" on the basis of Article 304 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. I am very critical of the involvement of the Economic and Social Committee in this legislative project. Since I cannot see the added value of this institution's input, I am voting against this proposal.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as it is only a technical vote to allow for consultation.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Economic and Social Committee's request for consultation on 'Improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon'. In fact, pursuant to Rule 137 of the Rules of Procedure, where the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union provides for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee, the President shall initiate the consultation procedure and inform Parliament thereof.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on the theme 'Improving the functioning of the European Union by harnessing the potential of the Lisbon Treaty', because I question the legitimacy, representativeness and usefulness of this Committee. I have, together with other Members, tabled a motion for a resolution to abolish this costly body. Is it also necessary to recall that the Lisbon Treaty, when it was still called the European constitution, was rejected by French voters ten years ago?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the request for consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee on "Improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the possibilities of the Treaty of Lisbon, because this request is legitimate and is provided for by the relevant provisions of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament.
