In addition, this consultation process with the European Economic and Social Committee contributes to deepening the democratic functioning of the EU itself.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against it. The European Economic and Social Committee is one of the many bodies created by the Maastricht Treaty, and is supposed to represent civil society. We question the legitimacy, representativeness and usefulness of these advisory bodies. We are therefore against a consultation with this Committee.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the Request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on "Improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon". It is good that a committee should be able to request that the Economic and Social Committee be consulted on both general and more specific matters. This system, like that of not discussing requests for consultation, tends to improve an integrated procedure.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against this motion because I believe that the involvement of the Economic and Social Committee in this legislative proposal would have no added value and I strongly oppose the UNanimity of the EU's extension of competences.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Under Article 137 of the Regulation, a committee may request that the European Economic and Social Committee be consulted on general issues or specific issues. The AFCO Commission has asked for an opinion on the Bresso-Brok report on "improving the functioning of the European Union building on the potential of the Lisbon Treaty". The request was therefore forwarded to Parliament for approval. But the AFCO committee did not find it useful to inform its colleagues about the reasons for this referral. To denounce these methods, I vote against.

name: Joëlle Mélin (NI)
text: In writing. The so-called European "comitology" is just a smokescreen used to mask the inefficiency of its administration. These committees have, until now, never proven their effectiveness or representativeness, let alone their expertise, and yet the Union is still working to finance and consult them. Finally, these consultations are only aesthetic since they are never followed, rarely read. So I voted against it.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the requested consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee as civil society involvement is vital to provide legitimacy if any decision is to be made regarding the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported the request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on ‘Improving the functioning of the European Union building on the potential of the Lisbon Treaty’.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the european economic and social committee's request for consultation on 'Strengthening the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon', as I consider it vitally important to monitor and study its path and future solutions. As the Committee wishes to strengthen the functioning of the EU within the last Treaty, I vote in favour of this request for consultation.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The European Union treaties provide for a consultation procedure with the European Economic and Social Committee. For example, a commission may request that it be consulted on a variety of topics.  In this case, the request for consultation concerns the improvement of the 'functioning of the European Union by taking advantage of the potential of the Lisbon Treaty'. A whole program... Firstly, I reject the very existence of the EESC, which, like its French 'colleague', does not shine through its usefulness or activity despite a cost which the European taxpayer would do well, but which, moreover, is more Europeanist than the other EU institutions (the debate then turning between those who think that more Europe is needed, and those who think that much more Europe is needed).  Secondly, the subject concerns the Lisbon Treaty, adopted in France by a procedure disavowing the 2005 referendum on a similar constitutional treaty.  I could only vote against that request.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported because I consider a more efficient functioning of the EU to be important.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 As an alternate member of the committee initiating the consultation request, I voted for all the consultations proposed to discuss the future of the European Union, its proper functioning and the exploitation of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. In the end, I voted against this motion because the involvement of the Economic and Social Committee, whose raison d'etre is in any case questionable, will, in my view, bring little success in the specific case and will only contribute to the extension of the procedure.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanking the rapporteur for his work, I confirm my support for the request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. I recognise the European Economic and Social Committee as an advisory body of the European Union, including the European Parliament, as an important body whose opinion is essential to hear, consider and discuss when analysing or proposing new frameworks for a better functioning of the European Union, to which the Lisbon Treaty has given significant opportunities. As the members of the Committee come from among employers, workers and other interest groups and represent a bridge of a kind between the institutions of the European Union and civil society, insofar as the Committee's contribution to these matters is even more important in order to hear the voice of all those concerned (in)indirectly and the stakeholders to be influenced by them when seeking change. I therefore welcome the request to consult this Committee in planning and considering options to improve the Lisbon Treaty and the necessary changes that should allow for the creation of a legal framework so that the European Union and all its institutions function more efficiently and serve all citizens of the European Union.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. At all levels, local, national European, economic and social (and sometimes environmental) councils are illegitimate and irresponsible institutions that cost a fortune and do not defend the public interest. They should be considered and certainly not continue to be sworn in. Moreover, only sovereign peoples should be allowed to decide on institutions. It is scandalous that we are trying to "optimize" the treaties, that is to say to overinterpret them in order to do without asking the peoples for the approval of the developments that technocrats want to impose on them. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee on improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Lisbon Treaty, according to Article 37 of the Lisbon Treaty. Protocol of the European Parliament. The functioning of the European Union can only be improved through the involvement of all stakeholders, and the European Economic and Social Committee plays one of the key roles in this process.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposed request to consult the EESC on improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Lisbon Treaty, as it is also important to include bodies whose members represent a wide range of economic, social and cultural interests and whose main task is to bridge the gap between the European institutions and 'organised civil society'.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, under Title V (Relations with other institutions and bodies), clearly state in Article 137 that if the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union provides for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee, the procedure must be initiated. This case is one of those in which the Economic and Social Committee is to be consulted, so I voted in favour of the request.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the European Economic and Social Committee's request for consultation on the theme 'Improving the functioning of the European Union by harnessing the potential of the Lisbon Treaty' in order to hear the arguments of this body.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Economic and Social Committee (EEC) was established in 1957 as a discussion body on single market issues. The EEC gives European interest groups, including trade unions, employers' associations and farmers' associations, the opportunity to officially comment on eu legislative proposals. The opinions issued are addressed to the main European institutions, in particular the Council, the Commission and the European Parliament. With this request for consultation, provided for in Article 137 of the Rules of Procedure, it is intended to collect the views of representatives of employers, workers and other European interest groups on strengthening the functioning of the European Union under the Treaty of Lisbon. I voted in favour.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Article 137 of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, it is only a request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. As recommended by the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO) of this House, I voted in favour of requesting an official consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on two initiative reports which this parliamentary committee is preparing: 'Improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the possibilities of the Lisbon Treaty' and 'Possible amendments and adjustments to the current institutional configuration of the European Union'. It is relevant to know the opinion of the European Economic and Social Committee on these two issues in order to strengthen the recommendations that may be issued to improve the functioning of the EU and its institutional configuration.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. As I supported the European Economic and Social Committee's request for consultation on the theme 'Improving the functioning of the European Union by harnessing the potential of the Lisbon Treaty', I voted in favour of this report.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee because I believe it is essential that the issue of improving the functioning of the European Union be addressed by consulting the body that most represents the European social and productive bodies.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I abstained because I do not believe that consultation can provide any interesting elements for improving the functioning of the European Union in relation to the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: György Schöpflin (PPE)
text: Writing. – As the People's Party Coordinator of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, I think it is important that other EU institutions can express their views and proposals for the report entitled 'Improving the functioning of the European Union by exploiting the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon'. Under Rule 137 of the Rules of Procedure and Procedure, the European Parliament has the opportunity to consult on these important issues. I therefore voted in favour of the request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee, following the popular line.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in this vote, because, although the procedure for consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee to deliver an opinion forms part of the normality of parliamentary activity and, in particular, the ordinary legislative procedure, voting in favour would imply the implicit recognition of the unequal importance attached in the Lisbon Treaty to institutions such as the Economic and Social Committee or the Committee of the Regions , as well as the secondary role of the European Parliament in many areas of the European Union in which it should appear at least as a co-decision on an equal footing with the Council.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of the request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on ‘Improving the functioning of the European Union building on the potential of the Lisbon Treaty’.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the European Parliament's closer cooperation with the European Economic and Social Committee. Thanks to these consultations, the EP receives expert advice through opinions on proposed EU legislation not only from employers, but also from workers and other population groups. This cooperation thus allows for better connection, of us, of politicians, with civil society organisations in our countries. I consider the consultation on exploiting the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon to be very beneficial, as it can help us to improve the functioning of the EU as a whole.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support this request to consult the European Economic and Social Committee on improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Lisbon Treaty, as I believe that there needs to be interinstitutional dialogue to better fulfil the provisions of the Lisbon Treaty and to take into account the expert opinion of the institutions. All this can contribute to improving the functioning of the system.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this request for consultation of the Economic and Social Committee in relation to improving the functioning of the European Union building on the potential of the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the request for consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee on "Improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Lisbon Treaty" and on "Possible changes and adjustments to the current institutional structure of the European Union". The European Union faces enormous challenges such as millions of unemployed, increasing migration, demanding global competition and a loss of confidence in policy's ability to find solutions. The Union now needs to prepare the Union with a successful reform plan for the future of Europe and enable it to meet the challenges ahead by improving Europe's competitiveness in order to grow and more jobs and to re-gain citizens' trust. The Lisbon Treaty was conceived as a step forward in achieving greater transparency and democracy of decision-making processes, reflecting the Treaty's commitment to a closer communion of the peoples of Europe, where decisions are taken as openly and closely as possible to the citizen, by strengthening the role of the European Parliament and national parliaments, allowing for more democratic and transparent procedures for the adoption of Union acts, which are necessary in view of the impact of these acts on citizens and businesses , but only if the EU institutions respect each other's competences, the procedures laid down in the Treaties and the principle of loyal cooperation.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The policy of grouping EU policies into a kind of European elite cartel, where the decision-making process is not the result of democratic processes, cannot be approved by us. The 'democratic' cloak of institutions and non-institutions simply exists as a pretext, but also as a mechanism for the consumption of Community funds necessary to combat poverty and to fuel sustainable development.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of consulting the European Economic and Social Committee in shaping the institutional future of the European Union, because the EESC has demonstrated in its operation that it is making a useful contribution to the development of common European solutions, particularly in the wake of the crisis, by integrating and directly representing the perspectives, interests and knowledge of the various economic operators. I consider this particularly important in the current period of economic governance and, in particular, in order to properly assess and enforce the economic aspects of member states outside the euro area. I have also taken into account the fact that the Treaty of Lisbon itself designates an important role for the European Economic and Social Committee, and I believe that it may also be useful to analyse and validate aspects other than those of government, council and political actors in order to realise the potential of the new institutional structure.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Economic and Social Committee's request for consultation on the theme 'Improving the functioning of the European Union by harnessing the potential of the Lisbon Treaty'.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The National Front has always questioned the legitimacy, representativeness and usefulness of the European Economic and Social Committee, as well as the Committee of the Regions, two bodies of the European Union (not institutions) created by the Maastricht Treaty, which are supposed to represent civil society and local authorities. Moreover, consulting them on institutional issues is unthinkable. I'm voting against it.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. It is necessary to approve this request for consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee in accordance with Article 137 of the Rules of Procedure of this house.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in this vote, because, although the procedure for consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee to deliver an opinion forms part of the normality of parliamentary activity and, in particular, the ordinary legislative procedure, voting in favour would imply the implicit recognition of the unequal importance attached in the Lisbon Treaty to institutions such as the Economic and Social Committee or the Committee of the Regions , as well as the secondary role of the European Parliament in many areas of the European Union in which it should appear at least as a co-decision on an equal footing with the Council.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We have deep reservations about the direction of 'strengthening the functioning of the EU' here. Even more so when this strengthening is defended 'on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon'. It does not mean anything other than an attempt to deepen the pillars of this capitalist integration: federalism, neoliberalism and militarism. A path that, in the face of the deep crisis facing the EU, the main political families – right and social democracy – have been rehearsing for some time.  The intention is to take this deepening as far as possible, within the limits (already obviously broad, although not as broad as some new leaps, desired by some, could demand) of the Treaty of Lisbon, fleeing the public, democratic, scrutiny of peoples, particularly through referendums. We reaffirm our opposition to the Treaty of Lisbon and the need for its repeal. We reaffirm the proposal to enshrine the possibility of reversal of the Treaties by adapting the status of each country to the will of its people.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against this motion because I believe that the involvement of the Economic and Social Committee in this legislative proposal would have no added value and I strongly oppose the UNanimity of the EU's extension of competences.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In no reference to the possibility of appeal by consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee, we reaffirm our full opposition to the Treaty of Lisbon and its implementation, considering that it, like other instruments of European capitalist integration, should be repealed. That's why we abstained.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in this vote, because although the procedure for consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee to issue an opinion is part of the normality of parliamentary activity and, in particular, the ordinary legislative procedure, voting in favour would imply the implicit recognition of the unequal importance attached in the Lisbon Treaty to institutions such as the Economic and Social Committee or the Committee of the Regions , as well as the secondary role of the European Parliament in many areas of the European Union in which it should appear at least as a co-decision on an equal footing with the Council.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. I do not recognize the legitimacy or expertise of these committees, the effectiveness of which has yet to be demonstrated. Inaction and procrastination remain a key word for these European officials, belonging to an administration whose cost to the taxpayer continues to rise. These committees publish heavy reports that no one takes into account. By my vote against, I intend to denounce the functioning of this European bureaucracy.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As UKIP does not believe in Ecosoc, it was consistent to vote against this motion.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this request for consultation because the EESC is an EU advisory body that brings us valuable expertise.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee. Where the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU provides for consultation of the Economic and Social Committee, the EP shall specify to the committee the time limit by which it is to deliver its opinion. Parliament shall approve the request to refer the matter to this committee for consultation without discussion.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This vote relates to the European Economic and Social Committee's (EESC) request for consultation on "possible changes and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the EU". Rather, an independent assembly or independent experts should be called upon to deal with the issue rather than the much too one-sided and pro-European EESC. Moreover, I think it would be better to abolish this institution (the EESC), which, like its French counterpart, has little use and activity but which costs the taxpayer dearly. So I voted against that request.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. Since I do not believe that consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee can provide concrete evidence of the possible development of the current structure of the EU, I abstained.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒The European Parliament, as the representative body of European citizens, institutionalises cooperation with the European Economic and Social Committee according to the rules of procedure with a view to better functioning the EU.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this request for an opinion because I believe it is important to know the opinion of a body with great technical expertise such as the Economic and Social Committee, especially on a subject of great importance such as the evolution and corrections of the current institutional structure of the European Union.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. This report deals with a request for consultation with an institution created by the Maastricht Treaty to represent civil society at European level. The European Economic and Social Council, far from representing a civil society from twenty-eight Member States, is in fact a place of influence for many economic and associative lobbies. Finally, there is no evidence that the EESC is competent to give an opinion on matters relating to the functioning of the Union's institutions. I voted against it.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote to abstain against the request for consultation of the Economic and Social Committee. The Economic and Social Committee is a European institution which I would like to see erased. We do not believe that the consultation requested can provide any interesting information on the possible evolution of the current structure of the EU.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of possible changes in the Treaties, consultation and involvement of the social partners is certainly important. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. It seems absurd to seek the opinion of this undemocratic and inefficient body on improving citizen participation in the European Union, especially since it is because of the Lisbon Treaty that European leaders are currently being led to question the functioning of the Union. As the EESC is not a European institution, it is difficult to see under what legitimacy it would evoke possible adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, as provided for in Article 137 of its Rules of Procedure, has been asked to approve a request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on the theme "Possible developments and corrections to the current institutional set-up of the European Union". The Economic and Social Committee may be consulted on general matters or on specific points. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with the rules of the Treaty of Lisbon, the Economic and Social Committee may be consulted by Parliament where it deems it appropriate, and it is for the parliamentary committees to require the European Economic and Social Committee to be consulted on general problems or on specific issues. I support the request of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs to consult the Economic and Social Committee on developments and possible adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union. Given the nature of its composition and being the body par excellence that promotes participatory democracy and helps to strengthen the role of civil society organisations by establishing a structured dialogue, I believe that its auscultation will be an added value for discussion and reflection on the matter.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request for consultation of the Economic and Social Committee on the possibility of improving the functioning of the European Union and any changes and adjustments in the institutional structure. Under Rule 137 of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, a committee may request that the Economic and Social Committee be consulted on general or specific matters and to set a time limit within which the Committee must give its opinion.  Considering, in particular, that this opinion will be important in order to deepen the aspects relating to the better protection of social and economic interests, I support the request for consultation.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I abstained in this vote, because although the procedure for consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee to deliver an opinion forms part of the normality of parliamentary activity and, in particular, the ordinary legislative procedure, voting in favour would imply the implicit recognition of the unequal importance attached in the Lisbon Treaty to institutions such as the Economic and Social Committee or the Committee of the Regions , as well as the secondary role of the European Parliament in many areas of the European Union in which it should appear at least as a co-decision on an equal footing with the Council.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this request as I believe that the European Economic and Social Committee, being one of the main EU institutions, should be consulted on the future report by the Committee on constitutional affairs that will deal with possible evolutions and adjustments of the current institutional set up of the European Union.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. In the context of the ongoing reflection in the Parliamentary Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO) on possible changes and adaptations of the institutional structure of the European Union, this decision proposes to consult with the European Economic and Social Committee, representing economic and trade union actors in the European Union. Considering that the various stakeholders, economic and trade union actors, have their place in this debate, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The European Union could work far more effectively and discussion of this is to be welcomed. I believe that Wales could make a huge contribution to a more relevant and efficient EU if nations like ours had a greater and clearly—defined role. It would make the EU more democratic.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation. Indeed, I formally challenge the role of the European Economic and Social Council, which is an undemocratic, unnecessary and costly institution.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We do not encourage illusions of any kind regarding the meaning of the 'possible developments and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union' at issue here. In the face of the profound crisis with which the process of European capitalist integration is being debated, what is intended, in an authentic escape forward, is the creation of others and better conditions to deepen its axes: federalism, neoliberalism and militarism. The intention is to take this deepening as far as possible, contrary to the interests and aspirations of the peoples and, of course, fleeing their scrutiny. For our part, we reaffirm our opposition to the Treaty of Lisbon and the institutional model that is taking place there. We reaffirm the proposal to enshrine the possibility of reversal of the Treaties by adapting the status of each country to the will of its people. We are not opposed to a consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee. But we are of course in mind - and here we denounce it - the sense of the background of this whole process.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I shall abstain in the vote on the request for consultation of the Economic and Social Committee because we have long considered this body to be completely superfluous.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The policy of grouping EU policies into a kind of European elite cartel, where the decision-making process is not the result of democratic processes, cannot be approved by us. I am voting against requests for consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee on "Possible developments and adjustments to the current institutional components of the European Union". The 'democratic' cloak of institutions and non-institutions simply exists as a pretext, but also as a mechanism for the consumption of Community funds necessary to combat poverty and to fuel sustainable development.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I approved the request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on ‘Possible evolutions and adjustments of the current institutional set up of the European Union’.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. The Economic and Social Committee has sent us the request for consultation on the important issue of 'Possible developments and corrections to the current institutional set-up of the European Union'. I voted in favour of this request, which is rightly justified by the use of Rule 137 of Parliament's Rules of Procedure. I would like to thank Mr Schulz for starting the consultation procedure. It will be very important to involve the Economic and Social Committee, which is the direct representative of European social, productive and trade union bodies, in this important process of discussion on the future of the EU.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this request as I believe it is appropriate that the Economic and Social Committee be consulted regarding possible evolutions and adjustments of the current institutional set—up of the European Union.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request to refer to the European Economic and Social Committee for consultation on possible changes and adjustments to the institutional framework of the European Union, as I believe that the opinion of the social partners is important in this case.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Vote for. Article 137 of the Regulation of the European Parliament provides the possibility of consulting different bodies of the European Union in order to improve the functioning of the Regulation.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the request to consult the European Economic and Social Committee on possible changes and adjustments to the current institutional set-up of the European Union on the basis that some aspects and procedures of the European Union need to be revised. In my view, in this context, the Opinion of the Committee may draw attention to the economic, social and civic aspects of the functioning of the European Union that can improve its structure, which are currently not fully taken into account. A dialogue should therefore be established to ensure a consensus that will serve the political, professional and public interest.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text to consult the European Economic and Social Committee on the theme 'Possible changes and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union'. I do not recognize the legitimacy or expertise of these committees, the effectiveness of which has yet to be demonstrated. Inaction and procrastination remain a key word for these European officials, belonging to an administration whose cost continues to rise. Finally, committees have a habit of publishing heavy and abstruse reports that few take into account. I am seeking, by my vote, to denounce the functioning of this European bureaucracy.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal for consultation with the EESC on possible changes and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the EU. This consultation will provide avenues for work in order to better evolve the European institutions.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Economic and Social Committee's request for consultation on the theme 'Possible changes and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union', on the basis of Article 304 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. I do not consider it justified to involve the Economic and Social Committee. It is an institution that creates duplications and higher costs for citizens without bringing real added value. I therefore reject involvement.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as it is only a technical vote to allow for consultation.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on 'Possible developments and corrections to the current institutional structure of the European Union' as I believe that it is an example of a democratic exercise. Requests for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee shall be submitted to Parliament for approval without debate pursuant to Rule 137 of the Rules of Procedure.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. Like the other Members of the National Front, I voted against the consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on the theme "Possible evolutions and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union" because I question the legitimacy, representativeness and usefulness of this Committee. I have, together with other Members, tabled a motion for a resolution to abolish this costly body.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the request for consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee on "Possible developments and adjustments to the current institutional components of the European Union", because this request is legitimate and is provided for by the relevant provisions of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament. In addition, this consultation process with the European Economic and Social Committee contributes to deepening the democratic functioning of the EU itself.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against it. As with the previous vote, we do not recognize the legitimacy, representativeness or usefulness of this Committee, and we believe that it should not be consulted.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on "Possible developments and adjustments to the current institutional structure of the European Union". It is good that a committee should be able to request that the Economic and Social Committee be consulted on both general and more specific matters. This system, like that of not discussing requests for consultation, tends to improve an integrated procedure.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against this motion because I believe that the involvement of the Economic and Social Committee in this legislative proposal would have no added value and I strongly oppose the UNanimity of the EU's extension of competences.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Under Article 137 of the Regulation, a committee may request that the European Economic and Social Committee be consulted on general issues or specific issues. The AFCO Commission asked for an opinion on the Verhofstadt report on "possible changes and adjustments to the current institutional whole of the European Union". The request was therefore forwarded to Parliament for approval.  But the AFCO committee did not find it useful to inform its colleagues about the reasons for this referral. To denounce these methods, I vote against.

name: Joëlle Mélin (NI)
text: In writing. We do not recognize the legitimacy or expertise of these committees, the effectiveness of which has yet to be demonstrated. Inaction and procrastination remain a key word for these European officials, belonging to an administration whose cost continues to rise. Finally, committees have a habit of publishing heavy and abstruse reports that few take into account. I am seeking, by my vote, to denounce the functioning of this European bureaucracy. So I voted against it.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the requested consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee as civil society involvement is vital to provide legitimacy if any decision is to be made regarding the institutional set—up of the Union.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported the request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on ‘Possible evolutions and adjustments of the current institutional set—up of the European Union’.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on 'Possible developments and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union', as I agreed to the analysis and evaluation contained in our joint project. This study, in addition to charting the path taken to date, could look forward and point out paths in relation to the future of the European Union.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This vote relates to the European Economic and Social Committee's (EESC) request for consultation on "possible changes and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the EU".  The EESC, which is the consultative assembly of European economic and social partners, should have no jurisdiction to advise given its pro-European orientation. Moreover, "the evolution of the institutional structure of the EU" should begin with the outright abolition of the EESC. So I voted against that request.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 As an alternate member of the committee initiating the consultation request, I voted for all the proposed consultations to discuss the future of the European Union, possible developments and adjustments to the current institutional structure of the European Union.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. In the end, I voted against this motion because the involvement of the Economic and Social Committee, whose raison d'etre is in any case questionable, will, in my view, bring little success in the specific case and will only contribute to the extension of the procedure.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I supported it because the subject needs to be reviewed.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanking the rapporteur for his work, I confirm my support for the request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ From time to time, it is good to look back and check how the systems we built work or how and how the operation of these systems can be improved. In the business world, this cycle is common practice, so it is not surprising that the european economic and social committee is consulted on possible changes and adjustments to the current institutional set-up. As the members of the Committee come from among employers, workers and other interest groups and represent a kind of bridge between the institutions of the European Union and civil society, insofar as the Committee's contribution to these matters is even more important in order to hear the voice of all those (in)indirectly concerned and the stakeholders to be influenced when seeking the changes at stake. I therefore welcome the request to consult this Committee in adopting proposals for changes that will enable the European Union and all its institutions to function more efficiently and serve all citizens of the European Union.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. At all levels, local, national European, economic and social (and sometimes environmental) councils are illegitimate and irresponsible institutions that cost a fortune and do not defend the public interest. They should be considered and certainly not continue to be sworn in. Moreover, only sovereign peoples should be allowed to decide on institutions. It is understandable that the institutions have been reluctant to consult peoples since they expressed their rejection of the changes imposed on them ten years ago in the French and Dutch referendums. It is time to finally respect democracy. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee on possible changes and adjustments to the current institutional set-up of the European Union based on the potential of the Lisbon Treaty, according to Article 37 of the Lisbon Treaty. Protocol of the European Parliament. The current structure of the European Union can only be improved by involving all stakeholders, and the European Economic and Social Committee plays one of the key roles in this process.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I voted for the proposed request to consult the Committee of the Regions on possible changes and adjustments to the current EU institutional set-up, as I think it is important to include in the decision-making process the bodies representing or representing the interests of local and regional authorities in the European Union.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This case is also one of those in which the procedure for requesting consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee must be initiated. This is a necessary act, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Economic and Social Committee's request for consultation on the theme 'Possible changes and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the EU', in order to hear the arguments of this body.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Economic and Social Committee (EEC) was established in 1957 as a discussion body on single market issues. The EEC gives European interest groups, including trade unions, employers' associations and farmers' associations, the opportunity to officially comment on eu legislative proposals. The opinions issued are addressed to the main European institutions, in particular the Council, the Commission and the European Parliament. With this request for consultation, provided for in Article 137 of the Rules of Procedure, it is intended to collect the views of representatives of employers, workers and other European interest groups on the possible development and adaptation of the current institutional structure of the European Union. I voted in favour.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. As recommended by the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO) of this House, I voted in favour of requesting an official consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on two initiative reports which this parliamentary committee is preparing: 'Improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the possibilities of the Lisbon Treaty' and 'Possible amendments and adjustments to the current institutional configuration of the European Union'. It is relevant to know the opinion of the European Economic and Social Committee on these two issues in order to strengthen the recommendations that may be issued to improve the functioning of the EU and its institutional configuration.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. As I supported the European Economic and Social Committee's request for consultation on the theme 'Possible changes and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union', I voted in favour of this report.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee because I believe it is essential that any changes and corrections to the current institutional structure of the European Union be addressed by consulting the body that best represents the European social and productive bodies.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I abstained, not believing that the consultation requested could provide interesting information on the possible evolution of the current EU structure.

name: György Schöpflin (PPE)
text: Writing. – As the People's Party Coordinator of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, I think it is important that other EU institutions can express their views and suggestions for the report entitled 'Possible changes and amendments to the current institutional structure of the European Union'. Under Rule 137 of the Rules of Procedure and Procedure, the European Parliament has the opportunity to consult on these important issues. I therefore voted in favour of the request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee, following the popular line.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in this vote, because although the procedure for consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee to issue an opinion is part of the normality of parliamentary activity and, in particular, the ordinary legislative procedure, voting in favour would imply the implicit recognition of the unequal importance attached in the Lisbon Treaty to institutions such as the Economic and Social Committee or the Committee of the Regions , as well as the secondary role of the European Parliament in many areas of the European Union in which it should appear at least as a co-decision on an equal footing with the Council.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted in support of the request for consultation of the European Economic and Social Committee on ‘Possible evolutions and adjustments of the current institutional set—up of the European Union’.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Such consultation is justified if we are to streamline the functioning of the European Union and the cooperation of its institutions. I therefore fully support the intensification of the European Parliament's cooperation with the European Economic and Social Committee.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this request to consult the European Economic and Social Committee on possible changes and adjustments to the current institutional set-up of the European Union, as I consider that interinstitutional dialogue is needed to improve and adapt the current institutional set-up of the European Union. I also believe that the expert opinion of institutions that can help address the current institutional set-up of the European Union should be taken into account

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which was a request for consultation of the Economic and Social Committee regarding possible evolutions and adjustments of the current institutional set—up of the EU.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The EESC is an advisory body of the European Union. Established in 1957, it provides expert advice to the main EU institutions (the European Commission, the European Council and the European Parliament). It does this by presenting "opinions" on proposed EU legislation, as well as "self-expressive opinions" on issues it considers need to be addressed. One of its main tasks is to bridge the gap between the European institutions and "organised civil society". It promotes participatory democracy in the EU and helps to strengthen the role of civil society organisations through inclusion in "structured dialogue" with these groups in EU Member States, as well as in other countries around the world.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The policy of grouping EU policies into a kind of European elite cartel, where the decision-making process is not the result of democratic processes, cannot be approved by us. The 'democratic' cloak of institutions and non-institutions simply exists as a pretext, but also as a mechanism for the consumption of Community funds necessary to combat poverty and to fuel sustainable development.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of consulting the European Economic and Social Committee in shaping the institutional future of the European Union, because the EESC has demonstrated in its operation that it is making a useful contribution to the development of common European solutions, particularly in the wake of the crisis, by integrating and directly representing the perspectives, interests and knowledge of the various economic operators. I consider this particularly important in the current period of economic governance and, in particular, in order to properly assess and enforce the economic aspects of member states outside the euro area. I have also taken into account the fact that the Treaty of Lisbon itself designates an important role for the European Economic and Social Committee, and I believe that it may also be useful to analyse and validate aspects other than those of government, council and political actors in order to realise the potential of the new institutional structure.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Economic and Social Committee's request for consultation on the theme 'Possible changes and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union'.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The National Front has always questioned the legitimacy, representativeness and usefulness of the European Economic and Social Committee, as well as the Committee of the Regions, two bodies of the European Union (not institutions) created by the Maastricht Treaty, which are supposed to represent civil society and local authorities. Moreover, consulting them on institutional issues is unthinkable. I'm voting against it.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. It is necessary to approve this request for consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee in accordance with Article 137 of the Rules of Procedure of this house.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in this vote, because although the procedure for consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee to issue an opinion is part of the normality of parliamentary activity and, in particular, the ordinary legislative procedure, voting in favour would imply the implicit recognition of the unequal importance attached in the Lisbon Treaty to institutions such as the Economic and Social Committee or the Committee of the Regions , as well as the secondary role of the European Parliament in many areas of the European Union in which it should appear at least as a co-decision on an equal footing with the Council.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We have deep reservations about the direction of 'strengthening the functioning of the EU' here. Even more so when this strengthening is defended 'on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon'. It does not mean anything other than an attempt to deepen the pillars of this capitalist integration: federalism, neoliberalism and militarism. A path that, in the face of the deep crisis facing the EU, the main political families – right and social democracy – have been rehearsing for some time.  The intention is to take this deepening as far as possible, within the limits (already obviously broad, although not as broad as some new leaps, desired by some, could demand) of the Treaty of Lisbon, fleeing the public, democratic, scrutiny of peoples, particularly through referendums. We reaffirm our opposition to the Treaty of Lisbon and the need for its repeal. We reaffirm the proposal to enshrine the possibility of reversal of the Treaties by adapting the status of each country to the will of its people.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against this motion because I believe that the involvement of the Economic and Social Committee in this legislative proposal would have no added value and I strongly oppose the UNanimity of the EU's extension of competences.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In no reference to the possibility of appeal by consultation with the European Economic and Social Committee, we reaffirm our total opposition to the European institutional model, its foundations and its implementation, considering that the process of European capitalist integration must be stopped. That's why we abstained.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting because, although the procedure for referring to the Committee of the Regions to issue an opinion forms part of the normality of parliamentary activity and, in particular, the ordinary legislative procedure, voting in favour would imply the implicit recognition of the unequal importance attached in the Lisbon Treaty to bodies such as the Economic and Social Committee or the Committee of the Regions , as well as the secondary role of the European Parliament in many areas of the European Union in which it should appear at least as a co-decision on an equal footing with the Council.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. The Committee of the Regions, established in 1994, was originally intended to allow sub-national powers to express themselves within the Union's institutions. EU legislation is increasingly being implemented at the local or regional level. But, like the Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions is a fiction of no use. I denounce the waste of public money in the operation of this committee and I therefore voted against this text.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this request for consultation because the Committee of the Regions is an EU advisory body that brings us valuable expertise.

name: Janice Atkinson (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I am against the existence of the Committee of the Regions; it is an expensive talking shop and this exercise will cost much taxpayers’ money for little, if any, real effect.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for consultation of the Committee of the Regions. Where the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU provides for consultation of the Committee of the Regions, the EP shall specify to the committee the time limit by which it is to deliver its opinion. Parliament shall approve the request to refer the matter to this committee for consultation without discussion.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The aim here is to seek its opinion from the Committee of the Regions, a body aimed at promoting direct dialogue between regions and the EU to the detriment of nations. This request for consultation concerns the improvement of the 'functioning of the European Union by taking advantage of the potential of the Lisbon Treaty'. As with the EESC, I can only vote against this request.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. The Committee of the Regions is an institution that is a direct channel of dialogue between Brussels and our territories. That is why I believe that consultation with it on the dossier 'Improving the functioning of the European Union by exploiting the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon' can bring positive ideas that take account of the real needs of our regions.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. As recommended by the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO) of this House, I voted in favour of requesting an official consultation of the Committee of the Regions on two initiative reports which this parliamentary committee is preparing: 'Improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the possibilities of the Lisbon Treaty' and 'Possible amendments and adjustments to the current institutional configuration of the European Union'. It is relevant to know the opinion of the Committee of the Regions on these two issues in order to strengthen the recommendations that may be issued to improve the functioning of the EU and its institutional configuration.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Cooperation with the Committee of the Regions, in particular through the committee responsible in the European Parliament, is institutionalised through the RULES of Procedure of the EP and necessary for the performance of the advisory function of that body.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this request for an opinion because I believe it is important to know the opinion of a body with great technical expertise such as the Committee of the Regions, especially on a subject of great importance such as the improvement of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The National Front I represent has always been opposed to the very existence of the Committee of the Regions, which is a supranational organisation to which I deny any legitimacy to give an opinion on the functioning of the Union's institutions. Regions can only be represented at the national level and not before the institutions of the European Union. That is why, opposed to everything that gives the Committee of the Regions political responsibility, I voted against this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. In this case, the request for consultation concerns the Committee of the Regions, a European institution which has a secondary role but which is for me an instrument of direct dialogue between Brussels and regions with legislative power, such as the Italian regions.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important to give a voice to the territories and their expression in Europe, as they can make important contributions to making the most of the opportunities that the Treaty offers for their direct involvement.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I preferred to reject this proposal for consultation with the Committee of the Regions on improving the functioning of the EU "by taking advantage of the potential of the Lisbon Treaty". Apart from the fact that the Committee of the Regions has no democratic legitimacy, let alone an institutional one, it also lacks the powers to judge the functioning and institutional structure of the EU.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, as provided for in Article 138 of its Rules of Procedure, has been asked to approve a request for consultation of the Committee of the Regions on the theme "Improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon". The Economic and Social Committee may be consulted on general matters or on specific points. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the rules of the Treaty of Lisbon the Committee of the Regions may be consulted by Parliament where parliament considers it appropriate and it is for the Parliamentary Committees to require the Committee of the Regions to be consulted on general problems or on specific issues. I support the request of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs to consult the Committee of the Regions on strengthening the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon. Given the nature of its composition and being the body par excellence that represents the sensitivity of regional structures and local authorities, I believe that its auscultation will be an added value for the discussion and reflection of the matter.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request for consultation of the Committee of the Regions on the possibility of improving the functioning of the European Union and any changes and adjustments in the institutional set-up. Under Rule 138 of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, a committee is empowered to request that the Committee of the Regions be consulted on general or specific matters and to set a time limit within which the Committee of the Regions must give its opinion.  Considering, in particular, that this opinion is an important tool for highlighting local and regional interests and improving the protection of the institutional framework of multi-level governance, I voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I abstained in the vote because, although the procedure for consultation with the Committee of the Regions to deliver an opinion forms part of the normality of parliamentary activity and, in particular, of the ordinary legislative procedure, voting in favour would imply the implicit recognition of the unequal importance attached in the Lisbon Treaty to bodies such as the Economic and Social Committee or the Committee of the Regions , as well as the secondary role of the European Parliament in many areas of the European Union in which it should appear at least as a co-decision on an equal footing with the Council.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. As part of the ongoing reflection in the Parliamentary Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO) on possible improvements in the functioning of the European Union by harnessing the full potential of the Lisbon Treaty, this decision proposes to consult with the Committee of the Regions, representing regional and local powers and actors within the European Union. Considering that the different levels of regional and local government have their place in this debate, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The European Union could work far more effectively and discussion of this is to be welcomed. I believe that Wales could make a huge contribution to a more relevant and efficient EU if nations like ours had a greater and clearly—defined role. It would make the EU more democratic.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation. I formally challenge the role of the Committee of the Regions, a federalist instrument designed to diminish the power and sovereignty of nation states.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We do not encourage illusions of any kind regarding the direction of "strengthening the functioning of the EU" here in question. Even more so when this strengthening is defended "on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon". It means nothing more than an attempt to deepen the pillars of this capitalist integration: federalism, neoliberalism and militarism. A path that, in the face of the deep crisis facing the EU, the main political families – right and social democracy – have been rehearsing for some time. The intention is to take this deepening as far as possible, within the limits (already obviously broad, although not as broad as some new leaps, desired by some, could demand) of the Treaty of Lisbon, fleeing the public, democratic, scrutiny of peoples, particularly through referendums. For our part we reaffirm our opposition to the Treaty of Lisbon and the need for its repeal. We reaffirm the proposal to enshrine the possibility of reversal of the Treaties by adapting the status of each country to the will of its people. We are not opposed to a consultation with the Committee of the Regions. But we are of course in mind - and here we denounce it - the sense of the background of this whole process.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the request for consultation of the Committee of the Regions, which continues to be an instrument of direct dialogue between Brussels and regions with legislative power, such as the Italian regions.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The Committee of the Regions cost the European taxpayer roughly 80 million euros in 2014 and will do so again in 2015. This money could be put to far better use, especially at a time when governments across Europe are cutting down on expenditure. Rather than engage in consultations with the Committee of the Regions, we should abolish it.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I approved the request for consultation of the Committee of the Regions on ‘Improving the functioning of the European Union building on the potential of the Lisbon Treaty’.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. The Committee of the Regions has sent us a request for consultation on the important theme 'Improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon'. I voted in favour of this request, which is rightly justified by the use of Rule 138 of Parliament's Rules of Procedure. I would like to thank Mr Schulz for starting the consultation procedure. It will be very important to involve the Committee of the Regions, which is the direct representative of the territorial authorities of the various European regions, in this important discussion process.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the requested consultation with the Committee of the Regions, given that the Committee, in its capacity as one of the main EU institutions, should be consulted on constitutional affairs that will deal with improving the functioning of the European Union and which will build on the potential of the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my Labour colleagues, voted in support of the request for consultation of the Committee of the Regions on ‘Improving the functioning of the European Union building on the potential of the Lisbon Treaty’.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Vote for. Article 137 of the Regulation of the European Parliament provides the possibility of consulting different bodies of the European Union in order to improve the functioning of the Regulation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text to consult with the Committee of the Regions on the theme 'Improving the functioning of the European Union by harnessing the potential of the Lisbon Treaty'. The Committee of the Regions, established in 1994, was originally intended to allow sub-national powers to express themselves within the Union's institutions. Indeed, EU legislation is increasingly being implemented at the local or regional level. But like the Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions is just a wind-brewing gas plant that no one hears or listens to. Recognising neither the legitimacy, nor the work, nor the effectiveness of the Committee of the Regions, I mean, by this vote, to denounce this functioning of the Union.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal calling for consultation with the Committee of the Regions on improving the functioning of the EU. This consultation will provide, in addition to those of the EESC, other avenues of work in order to make the European Union work better through the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Committee of the Regions' request for consultation on "Improving the functioning of the European Union by harnessing the potential of the Lisbon Treaty" on the basis of Article 307 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. I am voting against the involvement of the Committee of the Regions, as, due to its very limited mandate in the consultation on improving the functioning of the European Union, it cannot make any lasting useful contributions and will use this new function as a further assertion of legitimacy.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as it is only a technical vote to allow for consultation.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I supported the Committee of the Regions' request for consultation on 'Improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon'. In fact, pursuant to Rule 138 of the Rules of Procedure, where the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union provides for consultation of the Committee of the Regions, the President initiates the consultation procedure and informs Parliament thereof.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. Of course, I voted against the consultation of the Committee of the Regions on the theme 'Improving the functioning of the European Union by taking advantage of the potential of the Lisbon Treaty' because I question the legitimacy, representativeness and usefulness of this committee. I have, together with other Members, tabled a motion for a resolution to abolish this costly body. Is it also necessary to recall that the Lisbon Treaty, when it was still called the European Constitution, was democratically rejected by French and Dutch voters ten years ago?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the request for consultation with the Committee of the Regions on 'Improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the possibilities of the Treaty of Lisbon', because this request is legitimate and is provided for by the relevant provisions of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament. In addition, this consultation process with the Committee of the Regions contributes to deepening the democratic functioning of the EU itself.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this request. Like the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions is an advisory body created by the Maastricht Treaty to supposedly represent local authorities. We question the legitimacy, representativeness and usefulness of these advisory bodies. We are therefore against a consultation with this committee.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the Committee of the Regions' request for consultation on "Improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon". It is good that a committee should be able to request that the Committee of the Regions be consulted on both general and more specific matters. This system, like that of not discussing requests for consultation, tends to improve an integrated procedure.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against this motion because I believe that the CoR's involvement in this legislative proposal would have no added value and I strongly oppose the UNanimity of the EU's expansion of competences.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Under Section 138 of Parliament's Regulation, a committee may request that the Committee of the Regions be consulted on general issues or specific issues. The AFCO Commission has referred the matter to the Committee of the Regions for an opinion on the Bresso-Brok report on "improving the functioning of the European Union building on the potential of the Lisbon Treaty". Such a title deliberately incomprehensible puts us on alert. The request was therefore forwarded to Parliament for approval. But the AFCO Commission did not find it useful to inform its colleagues about the reasons for this referral. To denounce these methods, I vote against.

name: Joëlle Mélin (NI)
text: In writing. The Committee of the Regions, established in 1994, was originally intended to allow sub-national powers to express themselves within the institutions of the European Union. Indeed, EU legislation is increasingly being implemented at the local or regional level. But like the Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions is just a wind-brewing gas plant that no one hears or listens to. Recognising neither the legitimacy, nor the work, nor the effectiveness of the Committee of the Regions, I mean, by this vote, to denounce this functioning of the Union. So I voted against it.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request for consultation of the Committee of the Regions on "Strengthening the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon", because I consider it vitally important to monitor, study its course and future solutions. As the Committee wishes to strengthen the functioning of the EU within the last Treaty, I vote in favour of this request for consultation.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. As with the European Economic and Social Committee, it is a matter of seeking its opinion from the Committee of the Regions, a body aimed at promoting direct dialogue between the regions and the European Union, by bypassing the States. As with the EESC, I cannot vote in favour of a request to improve the functioning of the Union under the anti-democratic Lisbon Treaty. So I voted against it.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 As an alternate member of the committee initiating the consultation request, I voted for all the consultations proposed to discuss the future of the European Union, its proper functioning and the exploitation of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against this motion because the involvement of the Committee of the Regions, whose efficiency and usefulness is in any case questionable, will produce few positive results in the specific case and will ultimately only contribute to the extension of the procedure.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported because I consider a more efficient functioning of the EU to be important.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Committee of the Regions is the Advisory Body of the European Union as it conveys local and regional positions to the Institutions of the European Union, which in turn is of great importance to the EU, as differences in Member States, starting with the most economical ones, such as the difference in the administrative division of Member States, their area and population, to the more complex ones, such as administration regulation, self-sufficiency of a region , traditions, environment, economy, etc., large and should be taken into account. The Lisbon Treaty allows decision-making through consultations so that, in the process of decision-making, when it comes to a framework within the competence of the European Parliament, it requires consultation with the Committee of the Regions. The opinion of those closest to the electoral base and those who are in the function of ensuring good living conditions for every EU citizen is important because of the more effective resolution of specific issues to which this level of governance must be answered. On the other hand, through consultations, the European institutions are getting acquainted with the issues of regional authorities and bring citizens closer together, thus establishing greater citizens' trust in this large community of states. For all of the above, I supported the Decision to consult the Committee of the Regions on improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. The Committee of the Regions has no legitimacy, as the region is not a relevant level of representation. The French Republic knows only the national community and no opinion given by a committee of regions can be taken into account. Only sovereign peoples should be allowed to decide on institutions. It is also scandalous that we are trying to "optimize" the treaties, that is to say to overinterpret them in order to do without asking the peoples for the approval of the developments that technocrats want to impose on them. I am, of course, voting against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support consultation with the Committee of the Regions on improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Lisbon Treaty, as referred to in Article 38. Protocol of the European Parliament. The functioning of the European Union can only be improved through the involvement of all stakeholders, and the European Committee of the Regions plays one of the key roles in this process, as it represents the voice of citizens from all parts of the Union.
