name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the proposed request to consult the Committee of the Regions on improving the functioning of the EU based on the potential of the Lisbon Treaty, as I think it is important to include in the decision-making process the bodies representing or representing the interests of local and regional authorities in the European Union.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Also in Title V, Chapter 5, Article 138, the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament state that, where the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union provides for consultation of the Committee of the Regions, the procedure must be initiated. In this case, the request falls within the envisaged cases and I voted in favour of it.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I support the Committee of the Regions' request for consultation on "Improving the functioning of the European Union by harnessing the potential of the Lisbon Treaty" to hear the arguments of this body.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Committee of the Regions is an advisory body representing the local and regional authorities of the European Union. The Committee's role is to present regional and local views on European legislation, through opinions on the Commission's proposals, and thus adopt resolutions on current political issues.  The Commission, the Council and Parliament should also consult the Committee of the Regions before taking decisions on issues relating to local and regional administration (e.g. on employment, environment, education or public health policy).  With this request for consultation, provided for in Article 137 of the Rules of Procedure, it is intended to collect the views of local and regional authorities on strengthening the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon. I voted in favour.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. As recommended by the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO) of this House, I voted in favour of requesting an official consultation of the Committee of the Regions on two initiative reports which this parliamentary committee is preparing: 'Improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the possibilities of the Lisbon Treaty' and 'Possible amendments and adjustments to the current institutional configuration of the European Union'. It is relevant to know the opinion of the Committee of the Regions on these two issues in order to strengthen the recommendations that may be issued to improve the functioning of the EU and its institutional configuration.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. As I supported this request for consultation with the Committee of the Regions on "Improving the functioning of the European Union by harnessing the potential of the Lisbon Treaty", I voted in favour of this report.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Committee of the Regions has sent us a request for consultation on 'Improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon'. I voted in favour of the Committee of the Regions' request, which was justified by the use of Article 138 of Parliament's Rules of Procedure, because I believe it is essential that the issue of improving the functioning of the European Union be addressed by contacting the body that most represents local realities.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because the Committee of the Regions is, to its limits, an instrument of direct dialogue between Brussels and the regions.

name: György Schöpflin (PPE)
text: Writing. – As the People's Party Coordinator of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, I think it is important that other EU institutions can express their views and proposals for the report entitled 'Improving the functioning of the European Union by exploiting the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon'. Under Rule 138 of the Rules of Procedure and Procedure, the European Parliament has the opportunity to consult on these important issues. I therefore voted in favour of the request for consultation of the Committee of the Regions, following the people's party line.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting because, although the procedure for referring to the Committee of the Regions to issue an opinion forms part of the normality of parliamentary activity and, in particular, the ordinary legislative procedure, voting in favour would imply the implicit recognition of the unequal importance attached in the Lisbon Treaty to bodies such as the Economic and Social Committee or the Committee of the Regions , as well as the secondary role of the European Parliament in many areas of the European Union in which it should appear at least as a co-decision on an equal footing with the Council.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support closer cooperation between the European Parliament and the Committee of the Regions. Thanks to these consultations, the EP receives expert advice through opinions on proposed EU legislation from local and regional authorities in the EU. This cooperation thus allows for better connection, of us, of politicians, with organisations active in our countries. I consider the consultation on exploiting the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon to be very beneficial, as it can help us to improve the functioning of the EU as a whole.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this Request for consultation with the Committee of the Regions on improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the potential of the Lisbon Treaty, as I believe that in order to better fulfil the provisions of the Lisbon Treaty, there should be an interinstitutional dialogue and an appreciation of the expert opinion of the institutions which can help us improve the functioning of the European Union.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this request for the consultation of the Committee of the Regions regarding improving the functioning of the European Union building on the potential of the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Committee of the Regions is an advisory body representing local and regional authorities in the European Union. The role of the Committee of the Regions is to express local and regional positions on EU legislation by publishing a report ("opinion") on the Commission's proposals. The Commission, the Council and parliament must consult the Committee of the Regions before taking decisions at EU level on issues related to local and regional government (e.g. employment, environment, education or public health policy). Under the Lisbon Treaty, the European Commission must now consult local and regional authorities and their associations within the EU at the pre-regulation stage. The Committee of the Regions, as a representative of local and regional authorities, actively participates in this process. Once a legislative proposal has been drafted, the Commission must once again consult the Committee of the Regions if the proposal relates to one of a number of policy areas that have a direct impact on local and regional authorities.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report because I am convinced that the Committee of the Regions, as guardian of subsidiarity, is an indispensable player in the democratic and effective functioning of European integration. I also consider its participation in shaping ideas for the future of the European Union important because the Committee of the Regions played an important bridging role during the institutional crisis that preceded the adoption of the current EU institutional structure by strengthening the regional dimension of European cooperation, thereby contributing to maintaining its functioning. As an institution particularly close to its citizens, it can continue to strengthen the democratic content of the functioning of the Union. In my decision, I also took into account the fact that the opinion and expert support of the Committee of the Regions had previously been a valuable contribution in the development of the Treaty of Lisbon, and that the Treaty of Lisbon itself had appreciated the role of the Committee of the Regions and thus gave it a fresh mandate to exploit new institutional opportunities.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The policy of grouping EU policies into a kind of European elite cartel, where the decision-making process is not the result of democratic processes, cannot be approved by us. The 'democratic' cloak of institutions and non-institutions simply exists as a pretext, but also as a mechanism for the consumption of Community funds necessary to combat poverty and to fuel sustainable development.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Committee of the Regions' request for consultation on "Improving the functioning of the European Union by harnessing the potential of the Lisbon Treaty".

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The National Front has always questioned the legitimacy, representativeness and usefulness of the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions, two bodies of the European Union (not institutions) created by the Maastricht Treaty, which are supposed to represent civil society and local authorities. Moreover, consulting them on institutional issues is unthinkable. I'm voting against it.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. It is necessary to approve this request for consultation with the Committee of the Regions in accordance with Article 138 of the Regulations of this house.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting because, although the procedure for referring to the Committee of the Regions to issue an opinion forms part of the normality of parliamentary activity and, in particular, the ordinary legislative procedure, voting in favour would imply the implicit recognition of the unequal importance attached in the Lisbon Treaty to bodies such as the Economic and Social Committee or the Committee of the Regions , as well as the secondary role of the European Parliament in many areas of the European Union in which it should appear at least as a co-decision on an equal footing with the Council.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have deep reservations about the direction of "strengthening the functioning of the EU" here. Even more so when this strengthening is defended "on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon". Something else does not mean than an attempt to deepen the pillars of this capitalist integration: federalism, neoliberalism and militarism. A path that, in the face of the deep crisis with which the EU is struggling, the main political families – right and social democracy – have been rehearsing for some time.  The intention is to take this deepening as far as possible, within the limits (already obviously broad, although not as broad as some new leaps, desired by some, could demand) of the Treaty of Lisbon, fleeing the public, democratic, scrutiny of peoples, particularly through referendums. We reaffirm our opposition to the Treaty of Lisbon and the need for its repeal. We reaffirm the proposal to enshrine the possibility of reversal of the Treaties by adapting the status of each country to the will of its people.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against this motion because I believe that the CoR's involvement in this legislative proposal would have no added value and I strongly oppose the UNanimity of the EU's expansion of competences.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting because, although the procedure for referring to the Committee of the Regions to issue an opinion forms part of the normality of parliamentary activity and, in particular, the ordinary legislative procedure, voting in favour would imply the implicit recognition of the unequal importance attached in the Lisbon Treaty to bodies such as the Economic and Social Committee or the Committee of the Regions , as well as the secondary role of the European Parliament in many areas of the European Union in which it should appear at least as a co-decision on an equal footing with the Council.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. I challenge the bureaucratic functioning of the European administration, which, on the pretext of getting closer to the citizens, has set up institutions with opaque functioning. The advisory committees of the Community institutions are neither effective nor legitimate, but they are excessively expensive for the taxpayers of the Member States even though no one is taking their reports into account. It is no longer acceptable for French and European citizens to pay for inefficient administrative bodies at a time when the European Commission is calling on all Member States to take austerity measures.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this request for consultation because the Committee of the Regions is an advisory body of the European Union which brings us valuable expertise.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for consultation of the Committee of the Regions. Where the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU provides for consultation of the Committee of the Regions, the EP shall specify to the committee the time limit by which it is to deliver its opinion. Parliament shall approve the request to refer the matter to this committee for consultation without discussion.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This vote relates to the Committee of the Regions' request for consultation on "possible changes and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the EU".  Apart from the fact that this committee ignores nations in favour of a dialogue between the European Union and the regions that the Union promotes in the name of federalism, I believe that, as with the EESC, the institution should simply be abolished in view of its cost to taxpayers and excessive expenditure of staff in its budget. So I voted against that request.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. The Committee of the Regions is an institution that is a direct channel of dialogue between Brussels and our territories. That is why I believe that consultation with it on the dossier 'Possible changes and corrections to the current institutional structure of the European Union' can bring positive ideas that take account of the real needs of our regions; For these reasons, I supported the text we are voting on.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Cooperation with the Committee of the Regions, in particular through the committee responsible in the European Parliament, is institutionalised by the RULES of Procedure of the EP and necessary for the performance of the advisory function of that body.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this request for an opinion because I believe it is important to know the opinion of a body with great technical expertise such as the Committee of the Regions, especially on a subject of great importance such as the evolution and corrections of the current institutional structure of the European Union.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The National Front, which I represent, has always been opposed to the very existence of the Committee of the Regions, which is a supranational organisation to which I deny any legitimacy to give an opinion on the functioning of the Union's institutions. Regions can only be represented at the national level and not before the institutions of the European Union. That is why, opposed to everything that gives the Committee of the Regions political responsibility, I voted against this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. In this case, the request for consultation concerns the Committee of the Regions, a European institution which has a secondary role but which is for me an instrument of direct dialogue between Brussels and regions with legislative power, such as the Italian regions.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of consulting the Committee of the Regions on possible changes in the institutional structure of the Union as it is important that the body representing the territories should have a voice on this fundamental dossier.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I rejected this request for consultation with the Committee of the Regions on possible changes and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union. It should be remembered that the Committee of the Regions is merely advisory on issues that could have a real impact at the local and regional level, and does not judge the relevance of the functioning of the European institutions, the Commission or the Council.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, as provided for in Rule 138 of its Rules of Procedure, has been asked to approve a request for consultation of the Committee of the Regions on the theme "Possible developments and corrections to the current institutional structure of the European Union". The Committee of the Regions may be consulted on general matters or on specific points. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I rejected this request for consultation with the Committee of the Regions on possible changes and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union. It should be remembered that the Committee of the Regions is merely advisory on issues that are likely to have a real impact at the local and regional level, and does not judge the relevance of the functioning of the European institutions, the Commission or the Council.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the rules of the Treaty of Lisbon the Committee of the Regions may be consulted by Parliament where parliament considers it appropriate and the parliamentary committees should require the Committee of the Regions to be consulted on general problems or on specific issues. I support the request of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs to consult the Committee of the Regions on developments and possible adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union.. Given the nature of its composition and being the body par excellence that represents the sensitivity of regional structures and local authorities, I believe that its auscultation will be an added value for the discussion and reflection of the matter.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I abstained in the vote because, although the procedure for consultation with the Committee of the Regions to deliver an opinion forms part of the normality of parliamentary activity and, in particular, of the ordinary legislative procedure, voting in favour would imply the implicit recognition of the unequal importance attached in the Lisbon Treaty to bodies such as the Economic and Social Committee or the Committee of the Regions , as well as the secondary role of the European Parliament in many areas of the European Union in which it should appear at least as a co-decision on an equal footing with the Council.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. In the context of the parliamentary committee on constitutional affairs (AFCO) reflection on possible changes and adaptations of the institutional structure of the European Union, this decision proposes to consult with the Committee of the Regions, which represents the powers as well as regional and local actors within the European Union. Considering that the different levels of regional and local governments have their place in this debate, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The policy of grouping EU policies into a kind of European elite cartel, where the decision-making process is not the result of democratic processes, cannot be approved by us. The 'democratic' cloak of institutions and non-institutions simply exists as a pretext, but also as a mechanism for the consumption of Community funds necessary to combat poverty and to fuel sustainable development.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The European Union could work far more effectively and discussion of this is to be welcomed. I believe that Wales could make a huge contribution to a more relevant and efficient EU if nations like ours had a greater and clearly—defined role. It would make the EU more democratic.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because I consider the Committee of the Regions to be a forum that does not have to be and represents the logical culmination of the federalist drift of the European Union.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We do not encourage illusions of any kind regarding the meaning of the "possible developments and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union" concerned here. In the face of the profound crisis with which the process of European capitalist integration is being debated, what is intended, in an authentic escape forward, is the creation of others and better conditions to deepen its axes: federalism, neoliberalism and militarism. The intention is to take this deepening as far as possible, contrary to the interests and aspirations of the peoples and, of course, fleeing their scrutiny. For our part we reaffirm our opposition to the Treaty of Lisbon and the institutional model that is taking place there. We reaffirm the proposal to enshrine the possibility of reversal of the Treaties by adapting the status of each country to the will of its people. We are not opposed to a consultation with the Committee of the Regions. But we are of course in mind - and here we denounce it - the sense of the background of this whole process.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the request for consultation of the Committee of the Regions, which continues to be an instrument of direct dialogue between Brussels and regions with legislative power, such as those in Italy.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I approved the request for consultation of the Committee of the Regions on ‘Possible evolutions and adjustments of the current institutional set—up of the European Union’.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this request for consultation in order to have the opportunity to know in greater depth, with a view to true and effective subsidiarity, the opinions and proposals of all the regional and local specificities that make up Europe, so as to be able to evolve the institutional set-up with the greatest possible institutional and popular involvement.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. The Committee of the Regions has sent us a request for consultation on the important issue of 'Possible developments and corrections to the current institutional set-up of the European Union'. I voted in favour of this request, which is rightly justified by the use of Rule 138 of Parliament's Rules of Procedure. I would like to thank Mr Schulz for starting the consultation procedure. It will be very important to involve the Committee of the Regions, the direct representative of the territorial authorities of the various European regions, in this important discussion on the future of the EU.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this request, given that it is appropriate that the Committee of the Regions be consulted on constitutional affairs that will deal with possible evolutions and adjustments of the current institutional set—up of the European Union.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of seeking advice from the Committee of the Regions on possible changes and adjustments to the institutional structure of the European Union, as I believe that, in the light of my experience, regional structures in the Member States can offer effective solutions.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my Labour colleagues, voted in support of the request for consultation of the Committee of the Regions on ‘Possible evolutions and adjustments of the current institutional set—up of the European Union’.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Vote for. Article 137 of the Regulation of the European Parliament provides the possibility of consulting different bodies of the European Union in order to improve the functioning of the Regulation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text to consult the Committee of the Regions on the theme 'Possible evolutions and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union'. I would the one wish to denounce the bureaucratic functioning of the European administration, which, on the pretext of getting closer to the citizens, has set up institutions with opaque functioning and conclusions. The advisory committees of community institutions are neither effective nor legitimate, but they are excessively expensive for taxpayers even though no one listens to them. It is no longer acceptable for French and European citizens to pay for inefficient administrative bodies at a time when the European Commission is calling on all Member States to take austerity measures.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal for consultation with the Committee of the Regions on possible changes and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union. This consultation will provide, in addition to that of the EESC, other avenues of work in order to better evolve the European institutions.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Committee of the Regions' request for consultation on "Possible changes and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union" under Article 307 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. I am voting against the involvement of the Committee of the Regions, as, due to its very limited mandate in the consultation on the adjustments to the institutional structure of the European Union, it cannot make any lasting useful contributions and will use this new function as a further assertion of legitimacy.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as it is only a technical vote to allow for consultation.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I welcomed the request by the Committee of the Regions for consultation on 'Possible changes and corrections to the current institutional set-up of the European Union'. Requests for consultation of the Committee of the Regions shall be submitted to Parliament for its approval without debate pursuant to Rule 138 of the Rules of Procedure. Implementing the Union's prerogatives remains a priority for this Parliament.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. Like the other Members of the National Front, I voted against the consultation of the Committee of the Regions on the theme "Possible evolutions and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union" because I question the legitimacy, representativeness and usefulness of this Committee. I have, together with other Members, tabled a motion for a resolution to abolish this costly body. The recommendations of the Committee of the Regions are just as predictable as each other.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the request for consultation with the Committee of the Regions on "Possible developments and adjustments to the current institutional components of the European Union", because this request is legitimate and is provided for by the relevant provisions of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament. In addition, this consultation process with the Committee of the Regions contributes to deepening the democratic functioning of the EU itself.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against it. As with the previous vote, we do not recognize the legitimacy, representativeness or usefulness of this advisory body, which we believe should not be consulted for opinion.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the Request for consultation of the Committee of the Regions on "Possible developments and adjustments to the current institutional structure of the European Union". It is good that a committee should be able to request that the Committee of the Regions be consulted on both general and more specific matters. This system, like that of not discussing requests for consultation, tends to improve an integrated procedure.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against this motion because I believe that the CoR's involvement in this legislative proposal would have no added value and I strongly oppose the UNanimity of the EU's expansion of competences.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Under Section 138 of Parliament's Regulation, a committee may request that the Committee of the Regions be consulted on general issues or specific issues. The AFCO Commission has referred the Verhofstadt report to the Committee of the Regions on "possible changes and adjustments to the current institutional whole of the European Union". Is it the preparation of a new treaty? The request was forwarded to Parliament for approval. The AFCO Commission did not find it useful to inform its colleagues about the reasons for this referral. To denounce these methods, I vote against.

name: Joëlle Mélin (NI)
text: In writing. We wish to denounce the bureaucratic functioning of the European administration, which, on the pretext of getting closer to the citizens, has set up institutions with opaque functioning and conclusions. The advisory committees of community institutions are neither effective nor legitimate, but they are excessively expensive for taxpayers even though no one listens to them. It is no longer acceptable for French and European citizens to pay for inefficient administrative bodies at a time when the European Commission is calling on all Member States to take austerity measures. So the mp voted against it.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request for consultation of the Committee of the Regions on "Possible developments and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union", as I agreed to the constant analysis and evaluation of our joint project. This study, in addition to tracing the path taken to date, may look and point out paths in relation to the future.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This vote relates to the Committee of the Regions' request for consultation on "possible changes and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the EU". In addition to the fact that the Committee of the Regions is an institution with the aim of ignoring the state level to enable direct dialogue between the Union and local authorities, "possible adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union" should begin with an improvement in the deplorable management of the Committee of the Regions, since an excessive part of its budget is reserved for staff expenditure. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 As an alternate member of the committee initiating the consultation request, I voted for all the proposed consultations to discuss the future of the European Union, possible developments and adjustments to the current institutional structure of the European Union.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against this motion because the involvement of the Committee of the Regions, whose efficiency and usefulness is in any case questionable, will produce few positive results in the specific case and will ultimately only contribute to the extension of the procedure.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported because the subject needs to be reviewed.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In the business world, questioning the functioning of the system is a common practice, so it should not be surprising to consult the Committee of the Regions on possible changes and adjustments to the current institutional set-up of the European Union. From time to time it is good to look back and check the functionality of decisions and the established system and check if and how the system can be improved. Since the members of the Committee come from regional or local administrations and represent a kind of bridge between the institutions of the European Union and citizens living in a particular region, insofar as the Committee's contribution to these issues is even more important in order to hear the voice and all those concerned (in)indirectly and affected by them when seeking a solution. I therefore welcome the request to consult this Committee in adopting proposals for changes that will enable the European Union and all its institutions to function more efficiently and serve all citizens of the European Union.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. The Committee of the Regions has no legitimacy, as the region is not a relevant level of representation. The French Republic knows only the national community and no opinion given by a committee of regions can be taken into account. Only sovereign peoples should be allowed to decide on institutions. It is clear that the Committee of the Regions will seek to defend the region as a level of decision-making, thus further attacking the sovereignty of the peoples. I am, of course, voting against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support consultation with the Committee of the Regions on possible changes and adjustments to the current institutional set-up of the European Union based on the potential of the Lisbon Treaty, as referred to in Article 38. Protocol of the European Parliament. The current structure of the European Union can only be improved by involving all stakeholders, and the European Committee of the Regions plays one of the key roles in this process, as it represents the voice of citizens from all parts of the Union and can provide a comprehensive analysis of where adjustments and changes are needed to improve the union's current institutional set-up.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the proposed request to consult the EESC on possible changes and adjustments to the current institutional set-up of the European Union, as I think it is important to include bodies whose members represent a wide range of economic, social and cultural interests and whose main task is to bridge the gap between the European institutions and 'organised civil society'.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Committee of the Regions' request for consultation on "Possible changes and corrections to the current institutional set-up of the European Union" is also one of the cases provided for in Article 138 of Title V of the EP Regulation, for which I voted in favour.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I expressed my support for the Committee of the Regions' request for consultation on "Possible evolutions and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the EU" in order to hear the arguments of this body.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Committee of the Regions is an advisory body representing the local and regional authorities of the European Union. The Committee's role is to present regional and local views on European legislation through opinions on the Commission's proposals and adopt resolutions on current political issues.  The Commission, the Council and Parliament should also consult the Committee of the Regions before taking decisions on issues relating to local and regional administration (e.g. on employment, environment, education or public health policy).  With this request for consultation, provided for in Article 137 of the Rules of Procedure, it is intended to collect the views of local and regional authorities on the possible developments and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union. I voted in favour.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. The President of the European Parliament has proposed to consult the Committee of the Regions on the theme "Possible evolutions and adaptations of the current structure of the European Union". I approved this approach because I believe that the Committee of the Regions has an essential advisory role for the European institutions. Here, it would be a matter of profiling the future we want to give to the European institutional architecture. The regions have a say on the subject: they are, in my opinion, an essential step in linking the local and European levels. For too long we have allowed this link to break away, we must now pay special attention to it.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. As recommended by the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO) of this House, I voted in favour of requesting an official consultation of the Committee of the Regions on two initiative reports which this parliamentary committee is preparing: 'Improving the functioning of the European Union on the basis of the possibilities of the Lisbon Treaty' and 'Possible amendments and adjustments to the current institutional configuration of the European Union'. It is relevant to know the opinion of the Committee of the Regions on these two issues in order to strengthen the recommendations that may be issued to improve the functioning of the EU and its institutional configuration.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. As I supported this request for consultation with the Committee of the Regions on "Possible changes and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union", I voted in favour of this report.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request for consultation of the Committee of the Regions, as I consider it important and at the same time interesting that any changes and corrections to the current institutional structure of the European Union should be addressed by consulting one of the bodies that best represents European citizens and local realities more generally.

name: György Schöpflin (PPE)
text: Writing. – As the People's Party Coordinator of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, I think it is important that other EU institutions can express their views and suggestions for the report entitled 'Possible changes and amendments to the current institutional structure of the European Union'. Under Rule 138 of the Rules of Procedure and Procedure, the European Parliament has the opportunity to consult on these important issues. I therefore voted in favour of the request for consultation of the Committee of the Regions, following the people's party line.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting because, although the procedure for referring to the Committee of the Regions to issue an opinion forms part of the normality of parliamentary activity and, in particular, the ordinary legislative procedure, voting in favour would imply the implicit recognition of the unequal importance attached in the Lisbon Treaty to bodies such as the Economic and Social Committee or the Committee of the Regions , as well as the secondary role of the European Parliament in many areas of the European Union in which it should appear at least as a co-decision on an equal footing with the Council.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to make the Functioning of the European Union and the cooperation of its institutions more effective, consulting the Committee of the Regions can help the European Parliament. That is why I support it.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this Request for consultation with the Committee of the Regions on possible changes and adjustments to the current institutional set-up of the European Union, as I believe that there needs to be an interinstitutional dialogue and an appreciation of the expert opinion of the institutions that can help address potential adjustments and changes.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to allow this request for the consultation of the Committee of the Regions regarding possible evolutions and adjustments of the current institutional set—up of the European Union.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. The Committee of the Regions was established twenty years ago with the aim of bringing the European Union closer to citizens. The fact is that 70% of EU laws have direct regional and local influence. The importance of the Committee of the Regions is recognised in the Lisbon Treaty, which reflects its work through three main pillars: subsidiarity, accessibility and proximity to citizens, and partnership. The main mission of the Committee is to involve local authorities in decision-making at European level. Cooperation between European, national, regional and local levels is necessary to create a Union that will be as close as possible to citizens.  The institutional set-up of the European Union needs to be adapted, autonomy ensured for regional and local authorities and adequate financial resources should be provided so that they can carry out their duties. It is necessary to promote the principles of good governance and the decentralisation process. In addition, the harmonious and even development of all territorial areas of the European Union should be ensured. The Committee of the Regions through direct dialogue with the authorities at the local regional and European level is a bridge that connects citizens and institutions of the European Union, and as such participates in the creation of future legal regulations.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The policy of grouping EU policies into a kind of European elite cartel, where the decision-making process is not the result of democratic processes, cannot be approved by us. The 'democratic' cloak of institutions and non-institutions simply exists as a pretext, but also as a mechanism for the consumption of Community funds necessary to combat poverty and to fuel sustainable development.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report because I am convinced that the Committee of the Regions, as guardian of subsidiarity, is an indispensable player in the democratic and effective functioning of European integration. I also consider its participation in shaping ideas for the future of the European Union important because the Committee of the Regions played an important bridging role during the institutional crisis that preceded the adoption of the current EU institutional structure by strengthening the regional dimension of European cooperation, thereby contributing to maintaining its functioning. As an institution particularly close to its citizens, it can continue to strengthen the democratic content of the functioning of the Union.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Committee of the Regions' request for consultation on "Possible evolutions and adaptations of the current institutional structure of the European Union".

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The National Front has always questioned the legitimacy, representativeness and usefulness of the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions, two bodies of the European Union (not institutions) created by the Maastricht Treaty, which are supposed to represent civil society and local authorities. Moreover, consulting them on institutional issues is unthinkable. I'm voting against it.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. It is necessary to approve this request for consultation with the Committee of the Regions in accordance with Article 138 of the Regulations of this house.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained from voting because, although the procedure for referring to the Committee of the Regions to issue an opinion forms part of the normality of parliamentary activity and, in particular, the ordinary legislative procedure, voting in favour would imply the implicit recognition of the unequal importance attached in the Lisbon Treaty to bodies such as the Economic and Social Committee or the Committee of the Regions , as well as the secondary role of the European Parliament in many areas of the European Union in which it should appear at least as a co-decision on an equal footing with the Council.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have deep reservations about the direction of "strengthening the functioning of the EU" here. Even more so when this strengthening is defended "on the basis of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon". It does not mean anything other than an attempt to deepen the pillars of this capitalist integration: federalism, neoliberalism and militarism. A path that, in the face of the deep crisis with which the EU is struggling, the main political families – right and social democracy – have been rehearsing for some time.  The intention is to take this deepening as far as possible, within the limits (already obviously broad, although not as broad as some new leaps, desired by some, could demand) of the Treaty of Lisbon, fleeing the public, democratic, scrutiny of peoples, particularly through referendums. We reaffirm our opposition to the Treaty of Lisbon and the need for its repeal. We reaffirm the proposal to enshrine the possibility of reversal of the Treaties by adapting the status of each country to the will of its people.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against this motion because I believe that the CoR's involvement in this legislative proposal would have no added value and I strongly oppose the UNanimity of the EU's expansion of competences.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I gave my support to the report on benchmarks. I congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Cora van Nieuwenhuizen. The benchmark scandals in the recent past clearly demonstrate what unregulated benchmarks can lead to. Manipulating them amounts to stealing from investors and consumers and undermines confidence in markets.  The Commission fined the banks something like EUR 1.7 billion for this. This regulation will impact consumers’ daily lives, as financial benchmarks determine the level of the mortgage payments of millions of households in the EU. Banks, while stating that they cannot invest in the real economy, have made buffers to pay billions in fines for benchmark manipulation. The agreement that we voted upon in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs has a balanced and proportional outcome. Transparency and supervision on the benchmark process have been increased, and conflicts of interest have been tackled.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: Madam President, manipulating benchmarks is the same as stealing. That is why we need to restore confidence in benchmarks and we need to monitor their use well. The full volume of €500 billion of funding instruments shows how important transparency is.  Transparency in some data and methodology can resolve conflicts of interest. Benchmark interest rates are used, for example, to determine a variable part of a variable interest rate. This means that poor, unprotent or deliberately miscalculated benchmarks can increase the overall level of the consumer credit interest rate, ultimately putting consumers at a disadvantage. In Croatia, we had the opportunity to see this on the case of the Swiss franc, which brought many citizens and their families to the brink of collapse. It is important to establish a climate of trust to which this report should contribute, and that is why I supported it.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I abstained on this vote. The LIBOR rate-fixing scandal told us all we need to know about the ethics and morals of the finance industry at the very top. We should in fact be going much further than we are going, and the fingerprints of the industry are all over this legislation, as is the power of its lobbyists. Nevertheless, more could be done. I suppose this is better than nothing, but I abstained.

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, my party and I voted against the Commission proposals that were the subject of the report by Cora van Nieuwenhuizen on benchmarks and giving more power to the Commission. Benchmarks are an essential part of the financial sector and markets. Regulation is already covered in the UK by our own regulator. This regulation extends the scope to include commodities and on their benchmarks and we believe there should not be more reach and over-reach by the EU.  These regulations will result in fewer benchmarks and less price discovery, and give non-EU investment managers and businesses a competitive advantage over Europe and the UK. It will drive jobs out of Europe and lower economic growth. Once again, I will say ‘yes’ to the UK and ‘no’ to the EU, because once again, the EU is driving business out of Europe.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I supported today the adoption of a regulation on indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts, as a single approach is essential to prevent market fragmentation and the quality functioning of the single market is one of the key objectives at EU level.  The aim of quality and clear regulation is to act preventively and avoid penalties that occurred in December 2013 in the amount of EUR 17 billion, all for mis interpretation and manipulation of benchmarks.  This Regulation aims to improve the management system and avoid conflicts of interest and improve the quality of inputs and benchmarking methodologies, which is very important for the timely and quality management of claims in case of manipulation of benchmarks and input data.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialist delegation voted in favour of this report because it calls for strict regulation on the benchmarks used in financial contracts. We welcome the fact that the following socialist priorities have been included: - to extend the consideration of a critical index, allowing indexes below the nominal value proposed by the Commission and the Council to be declared critical; - include in the articulation the indices of raw materials, thus reinforcing their regulation and allowing them to also be declared critical; - ensure that national supervisors may require compliance with the requirements set out in the Regulation also for non-critical indices;  - improve the transparency and robustness of the methodology used for its elaboration; and - strengthen the role of ECA in monitoring critical indices. Our group's commitment is that doubts about the integrity of benchmarks will disappear altogether. That is why, in the negotiations now under way with the Council and the Commission, we will ensure that no handling rate is exempt from the application of this Regulation, and we will monitor in particular mortgage rates so that situations such as those in the past with the Euro-ebor are not repeated.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, as has been adopted, Parliament's position allows the European System of Central Banks (ESCB) to be exempted from compliance with the provisions of the Regulation. This report seeks to regulate the benchmark economic indices, following the very serious scandals of the bookboard and the eurobor that have allowed a real transfer of income to the banking sector for years and which have led to the execution of hundreds of thousands of evictions both in Spain and throughout Europe. We have requested separate votes to cancel the ESCB exemption which, in practice, leaves this legislation without effect. The majority groups of the European Parliament have been opposed to our request and prefer to maintain this exemption, which will allow the ECB to continue to operate without transparency in this area. For this reason, I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The UK has introduced its own legislation on these issues, which is working well enough. The concern about harmonisation, other than the obvious subsidiarity issue, is that it could potentially lead to lower standards in the UK.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because this proposed regulation allows for additional legislation, at least for the most frequently used indices, to improve governance and limit conflicts of interest and other weaknesses.

name: Janice Atkinson (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Regulation should be made by Member States, the UK has existing legislation which is more than sufficient. Furthermore, these regulations will include commodities benchmarks resulting in fewer benchmarks overall, less price discovery, and advantages for investment managers from outside the EU who will be able to access this information.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support postponing the vote on this proposal with a view to further discussions. It introduces new rules to increase the credibility of interbank interest rates that determine the price of loans. The draft new rules aim to prevent a conflict of interest that would affect the formation of benchmarks such as LIBOR (London interbank rate) or EURIBOR (euro interbank lending rate). These two interbank interest rates affect the value of financial instruments and contracts in excess of EUR 500 billion. this may directly lead to the stability of the EU's financial markets. It is proposed that all index administrators who collect, analyse and process non-publicly available data should register with the European Securities and Markets Authority and publish an 'index statement' indicating who is measured and reliable in relation to this index.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In the wake of the London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) scandals, raw materials and exchange rate criteria that resulted in millions of fines on several banks in Europe and the United States, the Commission published a draft regulation in September 2013 on a wide range of benchmarks, seeking to fill potential gaps at each stage of production and the use of benchmarks. The price of many financial instruments and contracts depends on the accuracy of benchmarks. Doubts about the integrity of the indices used as benchmarks can undermine market confidence, cause losses to consumers and investors, and distort the real economy.  That is why it was time to regulate this system, in particular by defining the indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and contracts. The Socialist Group, of which I am a member, has succeeded in broadening the scope of performance criteria, including for the role of national supervisors in defining essential benchmarks, qualitative and quantitative criteria and the inclusion of all entities, not just those that are supervised.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. – This Commission proposal seeks to create a regulatory framework at European Union level that avoids manipulation of reference rates such as eurybor or bookboard. From now on, supervision will be carried out by a council made up of national authorities and chaired by the European Securities and Markets Authority. Financial scandals uncovered in the wake of the crisis showed manipulations by some of the major banks to influence indices such as the Eurobor. The European Commission itself accused a large number of banks of infringement of competition rules, including J. P. Morgan, HSBC, Crédit Agricole, Deutsche Bank, Société Générale, The Royal Bank of Scotland and Citigroup, some of which had participated in a cartel involved in influencing the prices of products derived from euro interest rates , such as mortgages. At UPyD we have always stressed the impact and importance these indices have on European citizens and on the urgency of creating more transparent rules. We voted in favour of the proposal although we regret that it has been so delayed by the blockade of some political groups.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report relates to indices used as benchmarks in financial markets.  In the wake of the Libor scandal, we became aware of the importance of these indices but also of the need to control them. There are two types of indices: those resulting from objective contributions and those calculated from non-public information. Investors use them for their expectations. This report deals here only with major indices such as money market benchmarks such as Libor or Euribor. If these indices are distorted, there can be a negative impact on financial markets as we have seen.  I abstained on this text because even though the report calls for strengthening the power of the AEMF and the national authorities, I regret that it does not attack commodity market indices or third country indices.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialist delegation voted in favour of this report because it calls for strict regulation on the benchmarks used in financial contracts. We welcome the fact that the following socialist priorities have been included: - to extend the consideration of a critical index, allowing indexes below the nominal value proposed by the Commission and the Council to be declared critical; - include in the articulation the indices of raw materials, thus reinforcing their regulation and allowing them to also be declared critical; - ensure that national supervisors may require compliance with the requirements set out in the Regulation also for non-critical indices;  - improve the transparency and robustness of the methodology used for its elaboration; and - strengthen the role of ECA in monitoring critical indices. Our group's commitment is that doubts about the integrity of benchmarks will disappear altogether. Therefore, in the negotiations now under way with the Council and the Commission, we will ensure that no rate capable of manipulation is exempt from the application of this Regulation, and we will monitor in particular mortgage rates so that situations such as those in the past with the Euro-ebor are not repeated

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which consults on the common position on the Council and European Parliament regulation on indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial treaties. Benchmarks are essential for determining the price of cross-border transactions, thereby facilitating the effective functioning of the internal market for a wide range of financial instruments and services. Many benchmarks used as reference rates in financial contracts, in particular mortgages, are compiled in one Member State, but are used by credit institutions and consumers in other Member States. In addition, these credit institutions often cover their risks or receive funding to enter into these financial contracts in the cross-border interbank market. The scope of this Regulation should be as broad as possible to the extent necessary for the establishment of a preventive regulatory framework. The development and determination of benchmarks are discretionary and in itself give rise to certain types of conflicts of interest, which means that there are opportunities and incentives to manipulate those benchmarks. These risk factors are specific to all benchmarks and should therefore all be subject to appropriate management and control requirements.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this Report because it is well balanced around its key points and I think a good result has been achieved in this part. A fair balance has been struck between critical and non-critical benchmarks, which makes a good compromise in negotiations with the Council.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The proposed regulation on benchmarks is a response to the various scandals related to the manipulation of certain data. The most well-known case is the Libor case for which the banks involved were fined a record high. Indeed, manipulation of the index can have serious consequences on the activities of certain financial institutions. Given the size of the financial sums involved, we can only regret that this draft legislation does not cover with the same legal force all the truly systemic indices. That is why I wished to abstain on the vote on this text, which has been postponed.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote on the report signed by Liberal MP Van Nieuwenhuizen is positive. It is a legislative text that updates the rules on indices used as reference values in financial instruments in a more transparent way. Requests from some groups to delete certain parts of the text are improvements.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialist delegation voted in favour of this report because it calls for strict regulation on the benchmarks used in financial contracts. We welcome the fact that the following socialist priorities have been included: - to extend the consideration of a critical index, allowing indexes below the nominal value proposed by the Commission and the Council to be declared critical; - include in the articulation the indices of raw materials, thus reinforcing their regulation and allowing them to also be declared critical; - ensure that national supervisors may require compliance with the requirements set out in the Regulation also for non-critical indices;  - improve the transparency and robustness of the methodology used for its elaboration; and - strengthen the role of ECA in monitoring critical indices. Our group's commitment is that doubts about the integrity of benchmarks will disappear altogether. That is why, in the negotiations now under way with the Council and the Commission, we will ensure that no handling rate is exempt from the application of this Regulation, and we will monitor in particular mortgage rates so that situations such as those in the past with the Euro-ebor are not repeated.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Benchmarks are used to determine the value of financial instruments, financial contracts and the performance of investment funds. They therefore have considerable importance on the impact of the financial market on the real economy. Recent scandals have revealed the manipulation of EURIBOR and LIBOR, which are the UNION's most important benchmarks. Manipulation of benchmarks can cause significant losses to consumers and investors, distort the real economy and undermine market confidence. This regulation will therefore restore the integrity of benchmarks by making their management more transparent. The administrators of the benchmarks will have to register with the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) and will have to issue a declaration of compliance that specifically defines the use of their index and its reliability. They will also have liability constraints (code of conduct), record keeping and audit and review requirements. This type of regulation is very successful and will only exist in the European Union. In the negotiations, a system of equivalence and reciprocity with third-country benchmarks will have to be required. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on indices used as reference values in financial instruments and financial contracts.  The manipulation of LIBOR and currency reference values, as well as the alleged manipulation of other indices, have highlighted the importance of benchmarks as well as their vulnerability.  This report therefore aims to strengthen governance systems and rules, strengthen transparency by making more information available to users of all reference values and maintain supply and access to a wide variety of benchmarks by applying governance requirements in a proportionate manner. This would reduce the vulnerability to manipulation and abuse for widely used and systemically important reference values, increase the ability of users to choose consciously and ensure a level playing field for all administrators, both those in the EU and those located in third countries. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. There were some positive aspects to the report. However, there were a number of amendments tabled which aimed to broaden the scope and to include a wide number of benchmarks in the definition of critical benchmarks. Moreover, it was hoped that commodity benchmarks would be included. As these amendments were not incorporated, I tabled a negative vote.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the text voted on today is significantly improved on the European Commission's initial proposal, there are major weaknesses in some central points, including insufficient administrative sanctions and the exemption of central banks, public authorities, central counterparties and even the media. I therefore voted against this draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this report, which deals with the problem of the manipulation of reference indices and the scandals that this manipulation may have engendered. Of course, I support the measures recommended in the report to further compel banks to be transparent in order to avoid malfeasation. Thus, critical indices must comply with IOSCO rules, which amounts to imposing a code of conduct for their handling, including the enhanced communication of all elements to the supervisory authorities. I regret, however, that the final decision on whether an index is critical rests with the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) and not exclusively with the national authorities.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Manipulation of LIBOR and currency reference values, as well as alleged manipulation of other indices, highlighted the importance of reference values and their vulnerability. In response to these revelations, the EU amended the market abuse legislation to make it clear that the manipulation of reference values is illegal and to punish such conduct in criminal matters. In the light of these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on indices used as reference values in financial instruments and financial contracts. I believe, in fact, that it introduces important measures to improve the accuracy and reliability of the indices used in the financial field and, above all, fills a gap in European legislation by creating uniform treatment between the Member States. In particular, the aim of this Regulation is to achieve three fundamental objectives: to strengthen governance systems and rules in order to reduce vulnerability to manipulation and abuse; strengthen transparency, informing users and making available to them all the reference values so that they can make informed decisions; maintain supply and access to a wide variety of benchmarks, applying governance requirements in a proportionate manner, ensuring, among other things, a level playing field for all administrators, both those in the EU and those located in third countries. Therefore, in order to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market and improve its operating conditions, in particular financial markets, and to ensure a high level of protection for consumers and investors, I welcome the formulation of a regulatory framework for reference values at UNION level.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposed regulation introduces a common framework to ensure the accuracy and integrity of indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts in the Union. It applies to all published benchmarks that are used to reference a financial instrument traded or admitted to trading on a regulated venue, or a financial contract and benchmarks that measure the performance of an investment fund. The rapporteur has been successful in improving the proportionality of the regulation, and thus I am in favour of the report as adopted by the Committee on Economic Affairs.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts. Report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on indices used as reference values in financial instruments and financial contracts.   The vote was negative because, although Parliament's text is significantly improved on the Commission's initial proposal, there are still important issues, among which we stress an over-wide scope; the regulation exempts central banks, public authorities, central counterparties and even the media; some exemptions have been introduced for administrators of non-critical benchmarks with regard to governance, conflict of interest management, transparency and reporting violations. In addition, the thresholds for judging a critical benchmark are too high (EUR 5 billion) and administrative sanctions are too low.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report because, as has been adopted, Parliament's position allows the European System of Central Banks (ESCB) to be exempted from compliance with the provisions of the Regulation. This report seeks to regulate the benchmark economic indices, following the very serious scandals of the bookboard and the eurobor that have allowed a real transfer of income to the banking sector for years and which have led to the execution of hundreds of thousands of evictions both in Spain and throughout Europe. We have requested separate votes to cancel the ESCB exemption which, in practice, leaves this legislation without effect. The majority groups of the European Parliament have been opposed to our request and prefer to maintain this exemption, which will allow the ECB to continue to operate without transparency in this area. For this reason, I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the scandals that resulted in millions of euros in fines for several banks in Europe and the United States, the Commission published a draft regulation on a wide range of benchmarks (interest rates and raw materials) to address possible shortages at every stage of production and use of benchmarks. Doubts about the integrity of indices used as benchmarks can undermine market confidence, cause losses for consumers and investors, and distort the real economy. Thanks to a number of amendments, the Commission's text has been considerably improved, in particular with regard to the definition of non-critical benchmarks, which, in the first version, was too light, thus making the text too unbalanced. The vote in favour is for a text which is a sure good starting point for future negotiations with the Council.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts. The pricing of many financial instruments and financial contracts depends on the accuracy and integrity of such benchmarks. Doubts about the accuracy and integrity of indices used as benchmarks may undermine market confidence, cause losses to consumers and investors, and distort the real economy. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the accuracy, robustness and integrity of benchmarks and the benchmark setting process are of paramount importance.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the creation of a common framework to ensure the fidelity and integrity of benchmarks used in financial instruments and contracts. Considering that this text will improve financial governance in Europe, avoid conflicts of interest and strengthen the quality of data, methodologies used, controls and the protection of users of benchmarks, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The Regulation on benchmarks in the context of financial instruments and contracts is part of the revision of European market abuse policy. Such a text aims to prevent future scandals such as those caused by the manipulation of LIBOR and EURIBOR. These are benchmarks of interbank interest rates, set by the banks themselves. In order to ensure citizens' confidence in the financial markets, which are essential to the functioning of our economy, we need reliable indices. In the European Union, we must be able to avoid the manipulation of all benchmarks, whether in terms of interest rates, exchange rates, oil prices or macroeconomic forecasts. That is why the broad scope of this text is a good thing.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The Benchmarks Regulation is very important because the manipulation of benchmarks affects us all. The law came about following the scandal over the manipulation of the Libor interest rate benchmark, which is frequently used to determine interest rates for mortgages and bank loans.  I have voted in favour of the report as it is aimed to prevent the manipulation of financial benchmarks such as the London Interbank Offered Rate (Libor) and Euribor.  The new European legislation is a well-balanced as it lays down rules on how an index must be calculated and how possible conflicts of interest must be avoided.  The new draft law will introduce EU-wide rules to improve the reliability, representativeness and fitness for purpose of benchmarks.  Producers of major indices are placed under the direct supervision of financial supervisors and the law will also provide more information to users of benchmarks.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on benchmarks fits into the wider spectrum of those legislative measures designed to overcome the critical issues in the capital market. In particular, this report is relevant if we remember what happened in 2012 following the scandal over the manipulation of Euribor and Libor: it was a particularly serious act given the global impact on the financial markets.  In addition to dealing with the construction and implementation of legislative provisions with regard to the most important financial infrastructures, thanks to this proposal we are also able to solve the major problem related to index control. It was a very difficult negotiation, and some critical and fundamental points have therefore remained open. The two major issues relating to the recognition of third-country benchmarks and the definition of critical and non-critical benchmarks have been addressed through a highly pragmatic approach, but this has limited the scope of the proposal for a regulation.  I am voting in favour of this proposal, as the total absence of a regulation would lead to further critical issues on the financial markets, but I hope that the institutions will make greater efforts to include some of the outstanding issues in a balanced dimension.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. This European Parliament report aims to introduce strict regulation of benchmarks in the context of financial instruments and contracts. These benchmarks, calculated by data aggregation, may be related to interbank lending rates such as Libor and Euribor, oil or commodity markets. They are used to set the rates for many contracts and financial instruments.  In practical terms, it is a matter of subjecting the administrators of indices that have a significant impact on the financial markets to the supervision of a college of supervisors and the European Authority for Financial Markets. At the same time, rules on internal control and conflict of interest prevention will apply to non-critical index administrators. These provisions, which are a step towards the consolidation of the European financial system, must now be confirmed by the Member States.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. The scandals that erupted in the Libor and Euribor index manipulation cases showed the extent and seriousness of some fraud in the financial community. By emphasizing transparency around these types of so-called systemic indices, the proposed regulation is a new positive element of banking regulation, which I support. However, proposals to lower thresholds below the 500 billion euro outstanding financial products were not included in the report, making the proposal for a regulation timid and looser in terms of calculation method and transparency for indices considered non-critical. I therefore abstained in the vote on this report, which is incomplete and does not allow for advanced reform of banking regulation.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The manipulation of the Libor and foreign exchange benchmarks, as well as the alleged manipulation of other indices, has highlighted the importance of benchmarks and their vulnerabilities. Legislation of benchmarks, however, also has to consider that a great many businesses, as well as households, investors and financial institutions, rely on accessible benchmarks from all over the EU and beyond on a daily basis to efficiently conduct business, do trade, invest, hedge risks and provide or obtain credit.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Benchmarks for the pricing of cross-border transactions and for the pricing of a listed financial instrument operate restrictively for the single market in a wide range of financial instruments and services. They contribute to the fragmentation of the internal market, have a serious impact on financial stability and the real economy, strangle national economies, act, under union law, as a lever to pressure and limit national banking institutions and do not fully ensure the integrity and transparency of market or economic reality, and can potentially act as destabilising factors in the internal market and national financial activities. The imposition of cross-border benchmarks does not contribute to fully respecting the independence of the European Central Bank and the national central banks of the European System of Central Banks in the exercise of the powers, responsibilities and tasks conferred on them under the Treaties, as well as the independence of national central banks interwoven with the constitutional structures of the Member States or third countries concerned.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
