text: in writing. \u2012 The proposed objectives underpinning three key objectives: first, strengthening governance systems and standards, in particular in the case of comprehensively used benchmarks and systemic benchmarks, as well as reducing their vulnerability to manipulation and abuse; secondly, to increase transparency by making all benchmarks more available to users in order to enable them to make informed decisions; and, third, maintain the supply and access to a wide variety of benchmarks by applying governance requirements proportionately. Additional legislation should also take into account that many companies, households, investors and financial institutions rely on benchmarks accessible throughout the EU and abroad on a daily basis to carry out their business, commercial and investment activities, as well as to prevent risks or grant or obtain credits effectively. Therefore, the stability and efficiency of markets and the general economy also require legislative action to avoid restricting, as far as possible, the number and variety of benchmarks offered and used in the Union.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the scandals related to the manipulation of LIBOR and EURIBOR, the European Commission has expressed its intention to move forward with a legislative proposal seeking to regulate all activity related to the production and dissemination of benchmarks, with the aim of restoring market confidence. The Commission's proposal has chosen to treat all economic activities in the same way, which has raised criticism swells and concerns from various actors and sectors (notably commodity markets), which have recommended the application of the principle of proportionality, based on an assessment of data transparency, sources and the complexity of indices. As is well known, most of the benchmarks used in physical goods markets are calculated on the basis of transaction prices, through direct market observation. But the essential question concerns the credibility of these indices, or, strictly speaking, the lack thereof. Who builds them and how they do it. It is the most powerful interests, whose action should supposedly be regulated by the effect of these indices, which end up determining them, directly or indirectly.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Alleged manipulation of LIBOR interest rate benchmarks or foreign exchange benchmarks, as well as alleged manipulation of other indices, has led to a change in market abuse legislation to make such practices subject to criminal law. This pursues the achievement of three objectives. The first is to strengthen governance systems and rules for relevant benchmarks. The second is to enhance transparency by making information available to users of benchmarks. And the third is the application of the requirements for the management and management of the supply of a wide variety of benchmarks.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report signed by my Liberal colleague Van Nieuwenhuizen. It is a text that updates more transparently the rules relating to indices used as reference values in financial instruments.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the indicators used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts because they contribute to the fragmentation of the internal market. They have a serious impact on financial stability and the real economy, strangle national economies, act, under the cover of Union law, as a lever to pressure and limit national banking institutions and do not fully ensure the integrity and transparency of market or economic reality, and can potentially act as destabilising factors in the internal market and national financial activities. The imposition of cross-border benchmarks does not contribute to fully respecting the independence of the European Central Bank and the national central banks of the European System of Central Banks in the exercise of the powers, responsibilities and tasks conferred on them under the Treaties, nor does it contribute to the independence of the national central banks interwoven with the constitutional structures of the Member States or third countries concerned.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that, in this report, the S&D Group managed to ensure a fair balance of requirements between critical and non-critical benchmarks, as well as the inclusion in the scope of commodity benchmarks. I believe it is very important that a European legislative framework be established, in order to avoid the scandals and the market abuses that took place in the past. I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for the good balance reached in the text.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it calls for strict regulation on the benchmarks used in financial contracts and because important points defended by the Socialists have been adopted: - to extend the critical index consideration, allowing indexes to be declared critical indices below the face value proposed by the Commission and the Council; - include in the articulation the indices of raw materials, thus reinforcing their regulation and allowing them to also be declared critical; - ensure that national supervisors may require compliance with the requirements set out in the Regulation also for non-critical indices;  - improve the transparency and robustness of the methodology used for its elaboration; and - strengthen the role of ECA in monitoring critical indices. The socialists' commitment is that doubts about the integrity of benchmarks will disappear altogether. That is why, in the negotiations now under way with the Council and the Commission, we will ensure that no handling rate is exempt from the application of this Regulation, and we will monitor in particular mortgage rates so that situations such as those in the past with the Euro-ebor are not repeated.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it calls for strict regulation on the benchmarks used in financial contracts and because the following socialist priorities have been included: - to extend the critical index consideration, allowing indexes to be declared critical indices below the face value proposed by the Commission and the Council; - include in the articulation the indices of raw materials, thus reinforcing their regulation and allowing them to also be declared critical; - ensure that national supervisors may require compliance with the requirements set out in the Regulation also for non-critical indices;  - improve the transparency and robustness of the methodology used for its elaboration; and - strengthen the role of ECA in monitoring critical indices. My group's commitment is that doubts about the integrity of benchmarks will disappear altogether. That is why, in the negotiations now under way with the Council and the Commission, we will ensure that no handling rate is exempt from the application of this Regulation, and we will monitor in particular mortgage rates so that situations such as those in the past with the Euro-ebor are not repeated.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The index abuses used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts affect not only investors, but all European citizens. Unfortunately, self-regulation has not produced the desired results. Governance capable of effectively countering the risks of manipulation therefore seems indispensable to make these tools solid and reliable. That is why I voted 'yes' to the proposal for a regulation and I will continue to ensure that the principles of independence and protection of citizens remain the central points of this reform.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. The proposal that Mrs Cora van Nieuwenhuizen has presented to us on the regulation on indices used as reference values in financial instruments and financial contracts deserves attention. This is an extremely important measure, which aims to resolve those serious cases of manipulation of the reference values for the determination of interest rates, such as LIBOR and EURIBOR, and the reference values for currencies, which in recent years have caused considerable losses to consumers and investors, as well as destroying public confidence in the financial sector. I therefore wholeheartedly voted in favour of the proposal, which forms part of the many efforts that Europe is trying to make to restore confidence and rules to the economy.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP's position on the calculation of indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts as the fundamental objective of the legislative proposal is to increase transparency and reduce conflicts of interest, in particular for 'systemically important' indices such as LIBOR and EURIBOR.  Their influence on financial instruments and contracts – I am thinking, for example, of mortgages – is of great importance. Taken together, they are worth less than EUR 500 billion and could therefore jeopardise the stability of the financial markets in the European Union. Hence the need to create distinctions within them, between national or European indices of systemic importance, on which ESMA will be called upon to monitor, and non-systemic indices. The recent scandals involved European banks, duly sanctioned by the competent authorities, must set the precedent from which to arrive at legislation that ensures the integrity of the reference values; consequently, their directors should be required to implement adequate governance to control conflicts of interest and safeguard confidence in the integrity of the reference values. I hope that the negotiations with the Council will be brought to a successful conclusion as soon as possible.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on the proposed regulation on benchmarks in the context of financial instruments and contracts. This project is a response to various financial scandals such as the Libor, where the banks involved manipulated the price of this index. The proposed regulation is limited to improving the transparency of the way benchmarks are calculated and to communicate all the necessary elements to the supervisory authorities to ensure that their development is regular.  Nevertheless, this proposal does not remove the cause of the problem, namely the conflict of interest of some banks that are both in a position to publish the indices and benefit from the price changes they can anticipate in their favour.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Regulation has been approved without a vote, as it reaches its final stage after being negotiated and approved with the Council. It aims to make more stringent the regulation of indices used as a reference in investment products (benchmarks), such as the bookboard, following the scandal of the manipulation of this index by British banks. The text remains excessively lax for indexes that are not considered critical. That's why we would have voted against it.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my S&D colleagues, voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts. The new rules will contribute to the accuracy and integrity of benchmarks used in financial instruments and financial contracts by ensuring that contributors to benchmarks are subject to prior authorisation and ongoing supervision depending on the type of benchmark.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report presenting the European Parliament's proposals to the draft Regulation on Indices, which are used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts, as benchmarks. This Regulation establishes a common framework to ensure the accuracy and correctness of those indices. This contributes to the proper functioning of the internal market, while ensuring a high level of consumer and investor protection. The amendments aim to reduce the potential for manipulation and abuse of benchmarks, to ensure a greater diversity of benchmarks and thus to increase the transparency of this system.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialist delegation voted in favour of this report because it calls for strict regulation on the benchmarks used in financial contracts. We welcome the fact that the following socialist priorities have been included: - to extend the consideration of a critical index, allowing indexes below the nominal value proposed by the Commission and the Council to be declared critical; - include in the articulation the indices of raw materials, thus reinforcing their regulation and allowing them to also be declared critical; - ensure that national supervisors may require compliance with the requirements set out in the Regulation also for non-critical indices;  - improve the transparency and robustness of the methodology used for its elaboration; and - strengthen the role of ECA in monitoring critical indices. Our group's commitment is that doubts about the integrity of benchmarks will disappear altogether. That is why, in the negotiations now under way with the Council and the Commission, we will ensure that no handling rate is exempt from the application of this Regulation, and we will monitor in particular mortgage rates so that situations such as those in the past with the Euro-ebor are not repeated.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts. We have all seen the impacts of unregulated benchmarks and how their manipulation can lead to serious negative consequences for consumers. This proposal aims to avoid conflicts of interest and ensure improved management and governance controls. By enhancing transparency it helps to ensure adequate protection for consumers and investors using benchmarks. No legislator can ever ensure that there will not be attempts to manipulate indices and defraud customers. However the enhanced package that we now have, allied to the deterrent effect of the fines totalling EUR 1.7 billion that were imposed on banks by the EU Commission for the manipulation of interest rate benchmarks, should improve the current situation.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as this Regulation will address concerns about the integrity and accuracy of benchmarks in the EU. Importantly, it will put in place rules and standards which administrators of benchmarks, contributors to benchmarks and benchmark users will have to adhere to. Recent manipulations of different benchmarks have demonstrated the need to enforce adequate legislation in this area.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: Written. On Tuesday, we voted on the Cora van Nieuwenhuizen report on the proposal for a regulation on indices used as benchmarks for financial instruments and financial agreements. We voted in favour of the report, but would like to emphasise that it must not form the basis for legislation restricting or affecting freedom of the press and the citizens' right to free information.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The economic crash proved that our financial institutions need to be fully regulated. The LIBOR scandal emphasises that banks cannot be trusted to regulate themselves. The Commission proposal is therefore welcome in so far as it goes. Unfortunately Parliament has voted to weaken the proposal and that is to be regretted.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Regulation has been approved without a vote, as it reaches its final stage after being negotiated and approved with the Council. It aims to make more stringent the regulation of indices used as a reference in investment products (benchmarks), such as the bookboard, following the scandal of the manipulation of this index by British banks. The text remains excessively lax for indexes that are not considered critical. That's why we would have voted against it.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Regulation between the European Parliament and the Council on indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts, as I think it is important to establish a clear regulatory framework at European Union level to ensure protection for consumers and investors. In addition, some Member States at national level do not currently require ways of establishing benchmarks, while in others there are cases of manipulation of them. I therefore believe that it is necessary to improve the management and control of benchmarks, improve the quality of information and methodologies used by experts involved in this, prevent conflicts of interest, and increase transparency of all related processes.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This proposed regulation relates to benchmarks in financial instruments and contracts. After the various financial scandals that Europe has experienced since 2008, the Libor scandal for example, the legislator decided to take action against the banks manipulating the indices. This proposed regulation seeks to ensure transparency in the way benchmarks are calculated and that all necessary elements are communicated to the supervisory authorities responsible for ensuring their regularity. However, conflicts of interest are at the root of the problem as some banks publish indices and benefit from them by speculating on their value. It is therefore an offence to initiate. I abstained on this text.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text because the new Benchmarks Regulation will improve the functioning and governance of benchmarks used in the EU and ensure they are not subject to manipulation. The EU had to make sure no scandals over the manipulation of benchmarks, like Libor and Euribor, could ever happen again. Benchmarks affect all EU citizens. They define what citizens pay at the petrol station and the value of their pension. It was thus of outmost importance for the European Parliament to take the appropriate steps to address this issue. The new rules have strong requirements on how an index must be calculated, avert any possible conflict of interest and introduce prudential supervision.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Cora Van Nieuwenhuizen's report on benchmarks in financial instruments and contracts. These indices, such as LIBOR or EURIBOR, are benchmarks in the financial system. In order to compensate for the manipulation of these indices, which can cause significant losses to consumers and investors, this regulation restores the integrity of these benchmarks.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposed regulation on indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and contracts. Indeed, manipulating benchmarks can harm consumers, investors, and thus weaken the real economy and market confidence. The main objective of this regulation is therefore to establish a common framework to ensure the accuracy and integrity of these indices.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. I regretted that the rapporteur, Mrs Cora van Nieuwenhuizen, requested that the vote be postponed. The present draft has succeeded in this, uniting the various areas of tension around the important issue of benchmarking and offering useful, effective and open solutions to counteract the problem of lack of transparency and the risk of manipulation.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and contracts at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg. As the recent global financial crisis has shown, improvements in the supervision of the financial sector are needed, but it must be proportionate in order not to stifle market activity, promote competition and increase prices for financial products. I believe that the Text of the European Parliament respects these principles. Indices in financial markets are used to determine the price of financial contracts and instruments. The functioning of the financial market and fair competition require these indices to show the market value of financial instruments and contracts. The European Commission's proposal for a regulation seeks to improve the quality and reliability of indices following the euribor and LIBOR indices manipulation scandals. The amendments made by the European Parliament to the European Commission text provide for strict control of the most important indices, the impact of which on the market is very important, namely those indices with an impact on financial contracts and instruments of over EUR 500 billion. The determination of such significant indices will be monitored in the future by a dedicated commission.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as the text offers a good balance between critical and non-critical benchmarks and is a good compromise to be used in negotiations with the Council.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Curbing financial speculation is an absolutely welcome goal. Unfortunately, this solution bleeds from several wounds, at first glance it is extremely bureaucratic, and it also removes competence of the Member States. Moreover, the regulation does not address the problem at its roots, so it is unsuitable for the elimination of the rampant financial speculation, one of the symptoms of which we are witnessing today as the Greek crisis unfolds. The proposal is unacceptable because the present situation is unsustainable when the EU is part of the camps of debtors and creditors. It is very timely for the free flow of capital to be replaced by a controlled flow of capital, otherwise the basic objective of not plundering economically weaker Member States through financial manipulation cannot be achieved.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I supported the report put to the vote today. Pricing many financial instruments and contracts depends on the accuracy and integrity of the reference values. Serious cases of manipulation of these values show that these could be subject to conflicts of interest and have discretionary and unso solid governance regimes that are vulnerable to manipulation. In response, the EU amended the market abuse legislation to punish such conduct (updated vote under Article 61(2) de Regulation).

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Correct interpretation and use of benchmarks allow the effective functioning of the internal market. Their consistent and correct application is essential so that they are not affected by conflicts of interest, that they reflect the economic reality for which they are intended and that they are used in an appropriate manner. Effective control mechanisms must be put in place to prevent their abuse and to emphasise the illegality and criminality of such conduct. Benchmark administrators shall be obliged to put in place measures and mechanisms that increase confidence in and prevent any manipulation of benchmarks.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The manipulation of the Libor and foreign exchange benchmarks, as well as the alleged manipulation of other indices, has highlighted the importance of benchmarks and their vulnerabilities. In response to these revelations, the EU amended the Market Abuse legislation, to clarify that manipulation of benchmarks is illegal and to bring such conduct into the remit of criminal law.  However, a comprehensive approach to regulating benchmark manipulation has to go beyond the mere recognition of the illegality of such acts. It must also consider the macroprudential risks associated with the manipulation of widely—used benchmarks. Indeed, the continued extensive use of a limited number of very large benchmarks, even where the vulnerabilities and flaws of these benchmarks are known or suspected, underlines the importance of some benchmarks to the smooth functioning and stability of financial, commodities and other markets, as well as to the wider economy. These systemic considerations warrant and require additional legislative action, at least for the more widely-used benchmarks, to improve governance arrangements and mitigate conflicts of interest as well as other weaknesses.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote. While the idea of a stricter framework is appreciable, transparency alone will not be enough to prevent abuses. We regret that this text is limited to certain clues only and does not go any further, for example by suggesting constraints or sanctions. In these circumstances, I abstained.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation introduces a common framework to ensure the accuracy and integrity of indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts. The integrity of benchmarks is critical to pricing many financial instruments such as risk management, commercial and non-commercial contracts, loans and mortgages, etc. Any risk of benchmark manipulation can undermine market confidence, result in significant losses for investors, and distort the real economy. I voted in favour of this text because I believe that this EU regulation is necessary to improve the functioning and governance of benchmarks and to ensure that these benchmarks are robust, reliable, representative and not subject to manipulation. We now await negotiations with the Council on a widely shared final legislative text.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the draft Legislative Resolution on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the indices used as a reference in financial instruments and financial contracts. In recent years, we have seen the importance of these benchmarks and their vulnerability, so we need to make sure that there are ways to avoid their manipulation, as they depend on the financial security of our homes, companies, investors and financial institutions. We therefore need legislative action for the most widely used benchmarks in order to improve governance agreements and mitigate conflicts of interest, as well as other weaknesses.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I believe that, since the independence of the central banks and the European Central Bank system is maintained and the new regulations do not impose any restrictions on the work of the central banks and are therefore not applied to their work, I believe that this report is worthy of support.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. A benchmark is a value or indicator calculated on the basis of a representative set of data or information. It is used to value financial instruments or contracts, or to measure the performance of an investment fund. Examples of benchmarks include the London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) and the Euro Interbank Offered Rate (Euribor), which serve as benchmarks for interbank interest rates. Any risk of manipulation of benchmarks can undermine the confidence of the "market", cause significant losses for investors and, above all, distort the real economy. The Commission and Parliament's report propose to improve the control and governance of the reference process to avoid manipulation. The report stresses the need to combat conflicts of interest and ensure transparency. But these few efforts are meagre in view of the manipulations that these indices have already suffered in the past. Above all, the text does not propose the creation of alternative indices measuring the real economy rather than predictions of speculation. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The manipulation of libor and foreign currency interest rate benchmarks, as well as the alleged manipulation of other indices, has highlighted the importance of benchmarks and their vulnerabilities. In response to these revelations, the EU has made changes to EU market abuse legislation to clarify that such manipulation of benchmarks is illegal and to incorporate this matter into criminal law. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerns the proposed regulation to introduce a common framework to ensure the accuracy and integrity of indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts in the European Union. I chose to support the decision to allow the legislation to go on to first reading negotiations with the Council.

name: Bernard Monot (NI)
text: In writing. The Libor and Euribor manipulation scandal has damaged the credibility of the benchmarks and necessitated a reflection on their regulation. However, upstream supervision of index producers is one thing, effectively punishing as a deterrent is another. The record fines imposed on the banks concerned by The Liborgate, which amount to billions of euros, are clearly nothing compared to the profits generated. The regulations proposed here are complex to implement and above all to control, not to mention the upcoming Level 2 texts. The simple transparency that is proposed for most indices does not always detect manipulations. Genuinely deterrent sanctions would imply liability for the decision-makers' own assets, administrative prohibitions on guilty institutions and a ban on evidence-based products of pure speculation.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are serious cases of manipulation of interest rate benchmarks such as LIBOR, EURIBOR and foreign currency benchmarks, inflicting considerable losses on consumers and investors. These manipulations contribute decisively to the poor reputation of financial institutions and to the loss of confidence on the part of citizens, demonstrating that benchmarks can be the subject of conflicts of interest and have discretionary governance and regulatory regimes. I am voting in favour of this report safeguarding the independence of the European Central Bank and national central banks vis-à-vis the European System of Central Banks in the exercise of their powers, tasks and duties, and administrators should be obliged to adopt appropriate governance mechanisms to deal with a possible conflict of interest.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This vote relates to indices used as benchmarks in financial markets. In the wake of the Libor scandal, some have become aware of the importance of these indices and the need to control them. These are indicators on which investors base their expectations. There are two types: those resulting from objective contributions and those calculated from non-public information.  In this case, this report only addresses major or systemic indices, that is, which could lead to dangerous consequences (such as money market benchmark rates - Libor, Euribor, etc.). If they are distorted (e.g. through conflicts of interest), this can have a significant impact on financial markets.  The report envisages strengthening the power of the European Financial Markets Authority as well as national authorities. However, it is regrettable that it does not attack commodity market indices or third country indices (only AEMF approval is required). I have therefore decided to abstain on this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of postponing the vote on the text on restoring the integrity of benchmark financial indices in the European Union. Indeed, while it is important to restore market confidence after the recent scandals linked to the manipulation of EURIBOR and LIBOR, it is also necessary that an agreement between the Council and the European Parliament's Economic Affairs Committee on the choice of the competent supervisory authority be reached. The postponement of this vote will allow for further negotiations on this important text for investors.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the report on the proposal for a regulation on indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and contracts and particularly welcome it following the recent manipulations of LIBOR and other currency benchmarks, which have highlighted the importance and vulnerability of these values. We agree with the rapporteur in identifying the three main objectives of future regulation, such as strengthening governance systems and rules, increasing transparency and maintaining supply to a wide variety of benchmarks, ensuring a level playing field for EU and non-EU administrators.   In particular, we welcome the balance of requirements between critical and non-critical reference values, which we believe to be a good compromise that can best be used in negotiations with the Council. The requirements must include a proportionate approach that takes into account the different markets and economic realities concerned that use different types of data. It is necessary to establish a range of criteria valid throughout the Union, foreshadowing the possibility of determining values of critical references to Member States in cases where values are not displayed in more than one State.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts. This report allows for the correlation at European level of the indicators and instruments used by the financial market for the evaluation and presentation of financial offers, and introduces a number of rules that will allow for greater transparency and better verification of the financial market.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as we definitely need to regulate financial benchmarks after cases such as the LIBOR scandal. Banks and managers need to be subject to a certain level of standards and individuals should not be able to so freely manipulate financial indices and destabilise financial markets. I believe this report is a good balance between this need and the one not to interfere excessively in the financial self-regulation of the European markets.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. The report emphasises the independence of the national central banks as well as the system of the European Central Bank system. It is also a step towards greater security, traceability and transparency of financial instruments. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Indices directly or indirectly affect the majority of European citizens. The use of indices has affected all financial instruments. Many indices and benchmarks have become public goods. Their societal benefits should therefore be enhanced while the most stringent monitoring of the damage to the real economy and society as a whole from their possible improper organisation or manipulation of them to the real economy and society as a whole should be carried out. The reliability of benchmarks is crucial for the pricing of many financial instruments and commercial contracts and non-commercial contracts. Benchmark manipulation causes significant losses to investors with financial instruments the value of which is determined by reference to the benchmark. Where there are conflicts of interest in the determination of benchmarks and discretion can be exercised, but these conflicts and discretion are not properly managed or controlled, the benchmarks can be manipulated. Although the application of administrative and criminal sanctions for indices manipulation is already provided for in the Market Abuse Directive and regulation, it is necessary to regulate and prevent the risks of manipulation of indices. In order to protect investors, benchmarks are strong, reliable, fit-for-purpose and subject to proper management control.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. This Commission proposal seeks to create a regulatory framework at European Union level that avoids manipulation of reference rates such as the Euro-book or the bookboard. From now on, supervision will be carried out by a council made up of national authorities and chaired by the European Securities and Markets Authority. Financial scandals uncovered in the wake of the crisis showed manipulations by some of the major banks to influence indices such as the Eurobor. The European Commission itself accused a large number of banks of infringement of competition rules, including J. P. Morgan, HSBC, Crédit Agricole, Deutsche Bank, Société Générale, The Royal Bank of Scotland and Citigroup, some of which had participated in a cartel involved in influencing the prices of products derived from euro interest rates , such as mortgages. At UPyD we have always stressed the impact and importance these indices have on European citizens and on the urgency of creating more transparent rules. We voted in favour of the proposal although we regret that it has been so delayed by the blockade of some political groups.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it is necessary to ensure the accuracy, validity and correctness of the benchmarks and their detection process.  In order to achieve its objectives, the EU must establish and apply a regulatory framework for benchmarks that ensures the proper functioning of the internal market and guarantees a high level of consumer and investor protection. Greater attention must be paid to the protection of benchmarks against manipulation. It should be noted that such illegal activities may undermine market confidence, losses for consumers and investors, as well as distort the real economy.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. The proposed regulation on benchmarks is a response to the various scandals related to the manipulation of reference indices by those who published them. The most well-known case was Libor, the overnight interbank rate, for which the banks involved were fined a record $1.8 billion in the EU(1.8 billion) (Deutsche Bank alone, for example, paid $2.5 billion in the United States, SG, Barclays and RBS 1.8 billion in the EU). The magnitude of the sums involved may lead to regret legislation that does not in the same way embrace all the truly systemic evidence. It is fair to say that there were no exceptions to the scope, while some wanted to exclude professional indices from the scope of the regulation. However, to the extent that this is now an additional constraint for banks, it is not possible to vote against it. I therefore choose to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support my colleague van Nieuwenhuizen's report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts. Pricing many financial instruments and financial contracts depends on the accuracy and correctness of benchmarks. Serious cases of manipulation of benchmark interest rates, such as LIBOR, EURIBOR and benchmarks in the foreign exchange sector, and alleged manipulation of benchmarks in the energy, oil and foreign exchange sectors confirm that benchmarks may be subject to conflicts of interest and have discretionary rights systems and weak governance systems that are vulnerable to manipulation. The inaccuracy and malfunction of indices used as benchmarks, i.e. doubts about their accuracy and correctness, can undermine market confidence, cause losses to consumers and investors, and disrupt the real economy. It is therefore necessary to ensure the accuracy, stability and correctness of benchmarks and their identification process.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Benchmarking is a way or benchmarking to monitor developments in financial markets. Although these benchmarks are known and widely used, this does not mean that they are transparent and safe. That is why I voted in favour of tightening the rules contained in my colleague Cory van Nieuwenhuizen's report. It is not possible to continue to mislead citizens who believe that indexed values provide neutral and reliable information, while they can be calmly manipulated by several large players in the financial market. Among other things, we have seen this in recent years, when banks have grouped into illegal cartels to influence the level of interest rates at which they lend to each other on the European and London interbank markets. They thus influenced other interest rates used, for example, for consumer mortgage and savings banking products offered. I am therefore very happy that there will be stricter regulation, particularly for benchmarks with critical values, which will be supervised by the European Securities and Markets Authority.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that there was an objective need for a proposal, which I voted in favour of, to regulate the indices used as reference values in financial instruments and financial contracts. To date, supervisors exercise supervision only over financial instruments, but not on the production and governance of indices that determine the risk profile and economic value of these instruments. Since the use of indices is now indispensable as a reference for financial instruments, regulation was needed.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Following successive manipulations of benchmarks, including the EURIBOR and LIBOR indices, the European Union has decided to clarify the legislation in order to restore the integrity of the benchmarks. I voted in favour of this text to protect our businesses and our consumers.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. The indices are essential for pricing cross-border transactions and facilitate the effective functioning of the internal market for a wide variety of financial instruments and services. The vast majority of European citizens are therefore affected, directly or indirectly, by indices. Currently, different suppliers produce different reference indices, using different methodologies for this purpose. The benchmarks have in fact become public goods and must therefore be subject to close scrutiny. It is necessary to maximise its benefits and to take measures to prevent any damage resulting from their manipulation. This Regulation rightly introduces a common framework to ensure the high accuracy and integrity of indices used as benchmarks in the framework of financial instruments and contracts in the Union, contributing to this extent to ensuring the smooth functioning of the internal market and a high level of protection for consumers and investors. I voted, therefore, in favor.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Today, the European Parliament voted overwhelmingly on the report on parliament and Council's proposed regulation to make the benchmarks used to set the prices of mortgages, loans and bonds of EU citizens more reliable.  It is in response to scandals over the manipulation of some of these financial indices. Between 2005 and 2009, for example, large banks operating in the EU manipulated the Libor and Euribor indices, the rates at which banks lend themselves to each other, set daily by... banks themselves.  In manipulating these indices, banks have influenced the prices of our financial products to their own advantage. As a result, they have raised large sums of money from European consumers, businesses and investors.  The main objective of this regulation is to clean up the process of calculating benchmarks by reducing the conflicts of interest of the panel of European banks that determine the value of these indices. And it is to avoid further scandals of this kind and to restore confidence to citizens in the financial sector that a new, stricter regulation was passed this morning.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on indices used as benchmarks in the framework of financial instruments and contracts advocates three key aspects: the strengthening of governance systems and standards, greater transparency for users of all benchmarks and access to a wide range of benchmarks. I believe that benchmarks are fundamental in the pricing of cross-border transactions and in the functioning of the internal market, especially in terms of the protection of consumers and investors, and it is therefore essential to ensure that they are not handled by making it illegal and incorporating that matter into criminal law.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialist delegation voted in favour of this report because it calls for strict regulation on the benchmarks used in financial contracts. We welcome the fact that the following socialist priorities have been included: - to extend the consideration of a critical index, allowing indexes below the nominal value proposed by the Commission and the Council to be declared critical; - include in the articulation the indices of raw materials, thus reinforcing their regulation and allowing them to also be declared critical; - ensure that national supervisors may require compliance with the requirements set out in the Regulation also for non-critical indices;  - improve the transparency and robustness of the methodology used for its elaboration; and - strengthen the role of ECA in monitoring critical indices. Our group's commitment is that doubts about the integrity of benchmarks will disappear altogether. That is why, in the negotiations now under way with the Council and the Commission, we will ensure that no handling rate is exempt from the application of this Regulation, and we will monitor in particular mortgage rates so that situations such as those in the past with the Euro-ebor are not repeated.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament approved by 517 votes in the right vote, 146 against and 27 abstentions, a common position on the proposed regulation to strengthen governance in the formation of financial indices (benchmarks), paving the way for inter-institutional negotiations, with the Council already ready. With this vote, Parliament therefore intends to bring proportionality and impose stricter requirements on so-called critical indices, i.e. those that influence financial instruments and contracts with an average value of at least EUR 500 billion or which would have a significant negative impact on the stability of financial markets in Europe. Quality criteria have been added to determine which indices can be considered critical. The final decision on whether an index is critical would be the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) and national authorities.  However, a national authority could also judge a nationally administered index on its own territory critical if it has a significant impact on the domestic market. The calculation of critical benchmarks for at least two countries will be controlled by a college of supervisors, including the AEMF and other relevant authorities.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation on indices used as reference values in financial instruments and financial contracts, because I believe that excellent work has been done in drawing up this report. The report respects the objective we must set ourselves, in other words to restore confidence. If, in the face of the condemnable scandals, we were to activate a phenomenon of psychological terrorism, we would be abandoning the pursuit of our political task. In my opinion, this work has as its equilibrium point the excellent choice to identify what are the distinctions between critical indices and indices that cannot be considered as such. The approach adopted is the right one: the solution to the problem, not the activation of further terror, of further mistrust.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because it is a legislative text that brings greater transparency to the rules on indices used as reference values in financial instruments.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This Regulation has been approved without a vote, as it reaches its final stage after being negotiated and approved with the Council. It aims to make more stringent the regulation of indices used as a reference in investment products (benchmarks), such as the bookboard, following the scandal of the manipulation of this index by British banks. The text remains excessively lax for indexes that are not considered critical. That's why we would have voted against it.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, as has been adopted, Parliament's position allows the European System of Central Banks (ESCB) to be exempted from compliance with the provisions of the Regulation. This report seeks to regulate the benchmark economic indices, following the very serious scandals of the bookboard and the eurobor that have allowed a real transfer of income to the banking sector for years and which have led to the execution of hundreds of thousands of evictions both in Spain and throughout Europe. We have requested separate votes to cancel the ESCB exemption which, in practice, leaves this legislation without effect. The majority groups of the European Parliament have been opposed to our request and prefer to maintain this exemption, which will allow the ECB to continue to operate without transparency in this area. For this reason, I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ S&D MEPs voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts. The new rules will contribute to the accuracy and integrity of benchmarks used in financial instruments and financial contracts by ensuring that contributors to benchmarks are subject to prior authorisation and ongoing supervision depending on the type of benchmark.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Many indices and benchmarks have become public goods. It is therefore necessary to increase their social benefits and to limit the damage to the real economy and society resulting from their inadequate design or manipulation. Currently, supervisory authorities exercise supervision over financial instruments, but not on the design and management of indices that determine the risk profile, performance and economic value of those instruments.  Manipulations of benchmarks, to which millions of residential loans and citizens' savings relate, can lead to significant losses for consumers, and it is therefore necessary to ensure their accuracy and robustness and transparency in their determination procedures. The proposal for a regulation voted on is to remedy the shortcomings that have led to manipulation scandals in the past. Unfortunately, many amendments could make the situation even worse. For example, the Commission should leave responsibility for drawing up a list of critical benchmarks to national authorities and withdraw the requirement to disclose the information on which the benchmark calculations are based.  A large gap in the proposal for a Regulation is also represented by an amendment which excludes from the definition of a critical benchmark benchmarks whose calculations are based on regulated data obtained directly from trading venues.  In the vote, I therefore supported only those amendments that reduce the gaps in the proposal for a regulation and increase transparency and control of benchmarks.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In order to avoid manipulation of benchmark interest rates in the future, as was the case with LIBOR and EURIBOR, and to manipulate benchmarks in the business sector, which may lead to distortions of market confidence, loss of consumers and investors, and thus disruption of the economy, I support this Report as I consider it necessary to ensure the accuracy, stability and correctness of benchmarks and their determination process. For all this, it is important to lay down a regulatory framework for benchmarks at Union level, as this would make the market work properly. This Regulation would achieve transparency as to the purpose of the benchmark and inputs, effectively addressing any claims in accordance with national or EUROPEAN Union law. Since the accuracy and reliability of the benchmark in measuring the economic reality for which it is intended depends on the methodology used and the input data, it is necessary to accept a transparent methodology that ensures the reliability and accuracy of the benchmark.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which sets out new rules to promote the accuracy and integrity of benchmarks used in financial instruments and financial contracts.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The inaccuracy and malfunction of indices used as benchmarks, i.e. doubts about their accuracy and correctness, may undermine market confidence, cause losses to consumers and investors, and disrupt the real economy. It is necessary to ensure the accuracy, stability and correctness of benchmarks and the process of establishing them, so I support the report as adopted by ECON. Therefore, in order to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market and to improve the conditions of its functioning, in particular as regards financial markets, and to ensure a high level of consumer and investor protection, a regulatory framework for benchmarks at Union level should be established. The aim in the future is to avoid cases such as the LIBOR or EURIBOR scandals that undermine market confidence, hamper the economy, reduce profits for investors and take out mortgages and loans.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts. In the European Union, we have a problem with confidence in our markets due to manipulation of benchmarks. These practices should be discontinued. At the end of 2013, the European Commission fined eight banks a billion dollars for manipulations in setting Libor and Euribor, which are the basis for calculating consumer and residential credit. I support the establishment of stricter controls on the setting of these interest rates. I supported the report because it establishes more transparency.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report sets out regulatory provisions for supervising the implementation of these indicators and their control over the data they produce and the methodology used. It also mentions the effort to control any conflict of interest and the protection of investors. Despite all the above mentions, the report has failed to improve regulations so that, at the very least, systemic indicators can be sufficiently extended. Furthermore, the report fails to ensure that a conflict of interest is avoided. For the above reasons, we have decided to vote against.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Benchmarks for the pricing of cross-border transactions and for the pricing of a listed financial instrument operate restrictively for the single market in a wide range of financial instruments and services. They contribute to the fragmentation of the internal market, have a serious impact on financial stability and the real economy, strangle national economies, act, under union law, as a lever to pressure and limit national banking institutions and do not fully ensure the integrity and transparency of market or economic reality, and can potentially act as destabilising factors in the internal market and national financial activities. The imposition of cross-border benchmarks does not contribute to fully respecting the independence of the European Central Bank and the national central banks of the European System of Central Banks in the exercise of the powers, responsibilities and tasks conferred on them under the Treaties, nor does it contribute to the independence of the national central banks interwoven with the constitutional structures of the Member States or third countries concerned.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The manipulation of LIBOR indices and exchange rate indices, as well as the alleged manipulation of other indices, have highlighted the importance of indices and their weaknesses. In the face of these revelations, the European Union has revised the legislation on market abuse to clarify the illegality of the manipulation of indices and to register this type of behaviour in the field of criminal law. A large majority of European citizens are affected, directly or indirectly, by indices. All financial instruments are affected by the use of indices: derivatives, equities and bonds, as well as physical and commodity markets, the latter having recorded a considerable increase in the volume of commodity index funds over the last ten years.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which aims at putting an end to conflicts of interest and manipulation in the benchmark process for financial instruments and contracts by setting up a regulatory framework for the indices used. Over the last years we have witnessed many cases where we could doubt the integrity and accuracy of certain indices; even a doubt can undermine market confidence and distort the real economy. For this reason, the report sets four objectives as regards the benchmark process: improve governance and controls; improve the quality of the input data; ensure that contributors to the process are subjected to adequate controls; and assure consumers and investors protection. I am satisfied that the report maintains a broad scope of actions and addresses both critical, non-critical and commodity benchmarks, without denying their specificities.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the proposal for a Regulation between the European Parliament and the Council on indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts. A single framework and an effective governance system are necessary to prevent illegal activities when changing reference rates and to abuse them in favour of business policy.  We need to be aware of the real problems facing citizens, which are manifested in some Member States by high credit instalments and less and less by income. Such disproposition is a major burden, especially for those in charge to solve housing or existential issues. Likewise, the situation in the international financial market must be aligned with the opportunities in the internal market. Inaccurate and incorrect presentation of benchmarks, whether interest rates or commodity values, means manipulation of them, which ultimately causes a decrease in confidence and is manifested by negative trends in financial stability as well as the investment climate.  Many Member States have put in place self-regulatory measures for their own safety, but I support the Commission's proposal to extend the circle of action, the way to facilitate control and control over institutions.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Regulation has been approved without a vote, as it reaches its final stage after being negotiated and approved with the Council. It aims to make more stringent the regulation of indices used as a reference in investment products (benchmarks), such as the bookboard, following the scandal of the manipulation of this index by British banks. The text remains excessively lax for indexes that are not considered critical. That's why we would have voted against it.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ During the later stage of the financial crisis, the malpractices of many bank operators in the way financial benchmarks were defined came into the limelight. The LIBOR and EURIBOR cases, in which these manipulations were proven, made clear the necessity of a regulation that could tackle the system’s flaws. This is why I welcome this legislation, and I hope that a common agreement will be reached with the Council and the Commission in the coming months.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This Regulation has been approved without a vote, as it reaches its final stage after being negotiated and approved with the Council. It aims to make more stringent the regulation of indices used as a reference in investment products (benchmarks), such as the bookboard, following the scandal of the manipulation of this index by British banks. The text remains excessively lax for indexes that are not considered critical. That's why we would have voted against it.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted against this report which weakens European standards for controlling benchmarks. The biggest scandals consisted of the manipulation of the bookboard and the eurobor, but in Spain we have experienced the scam of mortgages referenced with the IRPH, in which the financial institution imposed abusive conditions. This Regulation has missed the opportunity to bury such privileges for financial institutions.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. On 19 May, the European Parliament adopted by a large majority a measure that was supposed to regulate at European level the indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments, the so-called benchmarks. This need arose as a result of the recent scandals over the manipulation of EURIBOR and LIBOR involving some large banks.  The aim of the regulation was to avoid any future manipulation of benchmarks in order to preserve consumers and the integrity of financial markets. Unfortunately, the text adopted will not achieve this because of the excessive and unjustified exemptions introduced. In fact, central banks, public authorities, central counterparties and even the media are excluded from the regulation.  However, exemptions have been introduced for some benchmark administrators on governance, conflict of interest management, transparency and reporting of breaches. Finally, the thresholds for judging a 'critical' benchmark have been set at too high a level (EUR 5 billion) and administrative sanctions are too low. We in the M5S have tried to improve the text, not only in the ECON Committee but also before the vote in plenary, at least by calling for all exemptions to be eliminated. But in vain. This is yet another proof of the unwillingness to give concrete answers to the problems of the real economy.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, as has been adopted, Parliament's position allows the European System of Central Banks (ESCB) to be exempted from compliance with the provisions of the Regulation. This report seeks to regulate the benchmark economic indices, following the very serious scandals of the bookboard and the eurobor that have allowed a real transfer of income to the banking sector for years and which have led to the execution of hundreds of thousands of evictions both in Spain and throughout Europe. We have requested separate votes to cancel the ESCB exemption which, in practice, leaves this legislation without effect. The majority groups of the European Parliament have been opposed to our request and prefer to maintain this exemption, which will allow the ECB to continue to operate without transparency in this area. For this reason, I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report as it is aimed to prevent the manipulation of financial benchmarks. The new European legislation is well-balanced as it lays down rules on how an index must be calculated and how possible conflicts of interest must be avoided. The new draft law will introduce EU-wide rules to improve the reliability, representativeness and fitness for purpose of benchmarks.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the scandals related to the manipulation of LIBOR and EURIBOR, the European Commission has expressed its intention to move forward with a legislative proposal seeking to regulate all activity related to the production and dissemination of benchmarks, with the aim of restoring market confidence. It follows that the Commission's proposal, by dealing with all economic activities in the same way, is creating major concerns with the agents dealing with commodity markets. IOSCO recommends that different situations be treated differently. In this sense, it proposes to apply the principle of proportionality on the basis of an assessment of data transparency, sources and complexity of indices. As is well known, most of the benchmarks used in physical goods markets are calculated on the basis of transaction prices through direct market observation. In this sense, and within the framework of the risk hierarchy provided by IOSCO, these indicators are at the bottom, i.e. minimal risk.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I believe that, since the independence of the central banks and the European Central Bank system is maintained and the new regulations do not impose any restrictions on the work of the central banks and are therefore not applied to their work, I consider this to be a report worth supporting.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts. This report comes with a comprehensive approach to the regulation of exchange rate benchmarks and LIBOR in the context of changes in European legislation as a result of disclosures related to their handling. The report in its content aims to take into account the stability and efficiency of markets and the economy in general.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The recent scandals over the manipulation of the value of EURIBOR and LIBOR involving some large banks have made it necessary to regulate benchmarks at European level. The aim of the regulation would therefore be to avoid the manipulation of benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts in order to preserve consumers and the integrity of the financial market.  Nevertheless, I did not support this report because, although Parliament's text is significantly improved on the Commission's initial proposal, important issues remain. Firstly, the scope is, in my view, too wide. The regulation exempts central banks, public authorities, central counterparties and even the media. In addition, some exemptions have been introduced for administrators of non-critical benchmarks with regard to governance, conflict of interest management, transparency and reporting of breaches. In addition, the thresholds for judging a critical benchmark are too high (EUR 5 billion) and administrative penalties too low.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support the European Parliament's legislative resolution on a regulation that would regulate the use of benchmarks in financial instruments and contracts. Indeed, the financial crisis in which Europe found itself after 2008 indicated that one of its causes was the manipulation of currency indicators and LIBOR indicators. It was assumed that over time the financial market itself would regulate these irregularities. This was bad, led to market chaos and encouraged speculation. As a result, it hits bank customers. Therefore, in my opinion, extending benchmarks to regulated activities rather than subjecting them to market play only is essential to restore customer confidence in the financial markets.  Published indicators, so important e.g. for borrowers, must be transparent. The point is that the public is not only aware of these indicators, but also of the methods on which exchange rates and LIBOR indicators are set. This will foster the predictability of financial markets and build confidence in them, which is crucial for investors and borrowers. I therefore support this resolution.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report. I congratulate all of those who were party to the report. We have got to make it absolutely clear that, if we are serious about reaching the goals that we have set internationally, then a fundamental part of that has got to be around ODA development and the commitment of 0.7%. That is especially the case in countries which have not attained that, including my own. As countries move from austerity to growth, we do need to continue our relentless focus on increasing our investment in overseas development.  The second issue that is contained in this report, namely helping those least developed countries in having a larger percentage of the development budget, is very important as well. We have seen significant progress in some developing parts of the world; but still, in sub-Saharan Africa and elsewhere we have not seen that progress. I think it is entirely appropriate that we should use a larger percentage of the development budget in those areas to attain the kind of goals we need to see.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it is deeply disappointing that we are nowhere near achieving the Millennium Development Goals, and many Member States are failing to provide as little as 0.7 % of their GNI to development assistance. I do believe it is high time that Member States stepped up their game. The costs in terms of human lives, as in terms of budget, will be much lower than what we are faced with when dealing with people fleeing poverty and the wars that poverty creates.  If the New York Summit in September is to come up with an agenda that is both stronger and more effective, we need a solid common position in the Addis Ababa high-level conference in July, with all the Member States speaking on one line, to the same tune. So this also means that we need to take real action to help developing countries raise their own resources and adopt policies that actually allow these countries to pick themselves up.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Madam President, 5 billion people continue to live in poverty and are deprived of health, education and living standards, especially in countries affected by conflicts and instability in their countries. This situation is not acceptable given the fact that there are sufficient resources in the world to gradually end this situation. This Report calls on the EU and the Member States to further commit to devote 0.7% of GDP to OFFICIAL DEVELOPMENT ASSISTANCE, but I also think it is important to take into account the economic situation in the context of defining deadlines for achieving the objectives.  The EU is the world's largest donor of development aid and is responsible for almost 60% of the world's official development assistance and these funds need to be used in the best possible way, which is not the case today. Official development assistance should primarily support the basic social services available to all and 'public goods' as well as the self-employment of local people in particular in agriculture, rather than sexual and reproductive rights, and therefore I voted to exempt this part from paragraph 28 of this report.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of the report on financing for development. There were positive aspects in this report, such as calling on high-income countries to contribute more to development, plus a need for greater transparency in the EU budget in terms of financing for development. Most importantly, the report deals with the role of women in development and strongly supports the principle of gender equality as it places this at the core of development activities. It targets investment in key sectors such as health and education, ensuring all development finances take full account of the situation of women and girls.  While Sinn Fein does not support extending the 1967 Abortion Act to the north of Ireland, we do support sexual and reproductive health and rights, as they cover a wide range of social, economic, cultural, civic, political and other rights.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – There is an important link between the financing of development aid and the debate on common European measures in the field of migration and asylum policy. The poverty of developing countries is directly linked to high levels of corruption and the practice of companies avoiding tax. I support the view that taxes should be paid where value is collected or generated. The level of the tax rate is a matter for a sovereign state to make, but spilling profits into tax havens is one of the main reasons for persistent poverty in many countries around the world. People risk their lives fleeing war and poverty. The pressure on the EU's southern border will only allow prosperity if the war is replaced by peace and poverty. However, I did not support the report because effective development aid and joint action by Member States to combat tax evasion and corruption are the conditions for eradicating poverty, not for financing reproductive rights and abortion.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it reflects positive aspects such as the requirement that the commitment to allocate 0.7% of GDP to development cooperation be fulfilled, it advocates strengthening public-private partnership in financing for development.  This report calls for the implementation in cooperation for the development of neoliberal policies in the EU, i.e. making public resources available to the private sector for the benefit of the private sector, protecting its investments and demanding reforms consisting of liberalization.     I believe that the pursuit of profit by multinationals is incompatible with sustainable development based on social justice, a development that requires that the basic pillars for the well-being of populations, such as education, health or the right to housing, be public services guaranteed by States, which are the only actors capable of ensuring their universality , quality and free.

name: Louis Aliot (NI)
text: In writing. This report is a half-confession of no control over the use of funds in third countries, which our delegation has strongly denounced since the beginning of the legislature. On the other hand, the author stresses the positive contribution of migrants to the development of countries of origin... An aberration in my opinion. In addition, the report recommends using PPPs as a lever for the development of developing countries, but it is well known that the only companies able to provide such financing methods are Western and not local. The Committee on Budgets has also warned that joint financing could lead to a debt bubble, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa and the Caribbean, where resources are limited. For this range of reasons, I voted against this report and spoke orally in plenary on it.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. – Is iomaí rud dearfach atá le fáil sa tuairisc seo cosúil leis an slí a ghlaotar ar na tíortha is saibhre níos mó airgid a thabhairt don fhorbairt, agus an gá a bhfuil ann do níos mó soiléireacht laisitgh de Bhuiséad na hEorpa maidir le maoiniú don fhorbairt. Ba chóir fáilte a chuir roimh na rudaí seo. É sin ráite, an rud is tábhachtaí faoi i mo thuairimse ná go bhfuil béim faoi leith curtha ar mná agus an baint tábhachtach atá acu san fhorbairt. Tugann an tuairisc seo tacaíocht do chomhionannas inscne. Cuireann sé togra chun tosaigh a iarann ar chomhionannas inscne a bheith mar chroí-lár de gníomhaíochtaí forbartha. ´Sé sin béim faoi leith a chuir ar infheistíocht i réimsí tábhachtach cosúil le sláinte agus an oideachais mar shampla . Déantar tagairt freisin den aird ar chóir diriú ar sláinte ghnéis agus atáirgthe. Cludaíonn seo réimse leathan de rudaí cosúil le cúram réimhbhreithe agus iarbhreithe, frithghiniúint agus galar gnéas -tarchurtha-rudaí atá thar a bheith tábhachtach.  Mar gheall ar na rudaí thuas luaite chaith mé vóta i bhfabhar an tuairisc seo.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This report sets out the European Union's development finance objectives. While the proposal reflects the lack of control over funds, it only addresses very superficially the real issues related to the issue of development, such as corruption practices in developing countries. Moreover, the report is a disaster in immigration policy. While OECD countries are facing a difficult fiscal position, public aid is being kept at a very high level. In addition, it is the pharmaceutical companies, which are already making huge benefits, that are taking advantage of these funds for scientific research.  As global poverty has changed in nature, a new paradigm must be found to respond to this reality, but this motion for a resolution responds hypocritically to development issues and could even contribute to the deterioration of the situation. So I voted against this report.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported Silva Pereira's report on development finance because it allows the European Parliament to contribute to the EU's position on official development assistance (ODA). Indeed, ODA is essential to carry out a European development policy and thus convince the countries of the South to fight global warming in the run-up to COP 21. The report notes the failure to meet the commitments made in 2005 by EU Member States (which were to spend 0.7% of their national income on ODA by 2015) and calls for multi-year budgetary timetables by 2020 to achieve this target. In addition, the report stresses the importance of innovative sources of development finance such as the Financial Transaction Tax and stresses the need to mobilize national resources in developing countries to manage public finances or fight corruption. I voted for this report because it is a matter of sending a message to the Member States and to the French government in preparation for COP 21 in December 2015.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to provide development aid. The EU is the world's 30th donor of development aid and accounts for almost 60% of the world's official development assistance. For the period 2014-2020, in addition to the EUR 2.2 billion foreseen for emergency aid, the commission will be 0.1% more than 2.2 billion in 2014-2020. An additional EUR 19.7 billion has been allocated to development cooperation. EUR 6.8 billion for humanitarian aid. The European Development Fund (EDF) amounts to EUR 30.5 billion. Eur 2.4 billion is foreseen in the 2015 budget. Eur 928.8 million for development cooperation commitments and EUR 928.8 million for development cooperation. Eur 100 million on commitments for humanitarian aid.
