I agree with the importance of setting clear spending priorities, with a particular focus on measures in the areas of health, education, energy, water supply and infrastructure.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This report prepares for the International Conference on Financing for Development to be held in Addis Ababa from 13 to 16 July 2015. The European Union is the world's largest contributor to development aid funding. It is essential that the EU continues to spend 0.7% of its GNI on development aid because it is our responsibility to support developing countries. The report goes in this direction and that is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report calls on EU Member States to meet their public development aid targets (up to 0.7% of GNI). It is a non-binding text that envisages the impossible and hopes to solve all the ills (poverty, famine...) that affect the planet. While it is clear that I want the development of the poorest countries and an improvement in living conditions (notably also through subsidies), I think it is more profitable to engage in a real policy of co-development, control of migration flows and support of governments in their fight against corruption or fundamentalism for stable countries that guarantee security and therefore economic growth.  Nevertheless, the EU tries to make itself aware in this text by often forgetting that it is these ultraliberal rules that impoverish countries. This report also calls for the fostering of public-private partnerships and the mixed funding that I oppose.  For these reasons I decided to vote against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is acceptable, balanced and has no critical issues. That is why I supported you with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. This report nurtures the EU's position for the Third International Conference on Financing for Development from 13 to 16 July in Addis Ababa. We call for the greatest degree of political and economic ambition for the construction of the new development framework, betting on creating the necessary conditions for the financing and implementation of the agenda after 2015. 2015 is a crucial year, with the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals and the agreement on global action against climate change. The main objective is the eradication of poverty suffered by 1.5 billion people, as well as to reduce inequalities and promote sustainable development. This can only be achieved by mobilizing sufficient and adequate resources. We call on the EU and its Member States to recommit to the 0.7% GNI target for ODO, rebooking at least 50% of their ODO and 0.2% of GNI for the least developed countries, as well as adopting multiannual budget timetables for the increase in ODO by 2020. On these main issues, among others raised in the report, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the European Union and its Member States, as the largest donor of development aid, must lead the process of financing development and help ensure a sound response to the challenges of financing development by ensuring pcdence on the development agenda for the post-2015 period. The European Parliament welcomes the commission's recent communication entitled 'A global partnership for poverty eradication and sustainable development after 2015', as it is comprehensive, focuses on policy coherence and confirms that the EU is committed to fully involved in the global partnership. However, this document does not sufficiently commit itself to establishing a timetable for the achievement of future funding objectives. In addition, it is necessary to ensure that the most vulnerable communities have development opportunities. Thus, when support is provided solely through government mediation, there is a risk that marginalised or vulnerable communities will be underfunded. The European Parliament also stresses the need to achieve the highest level of coordination in the European Union in order to ensure consistency with other EU policies (environment, migration, international trade, human rights, agriculture, etc.) and to avoid duplication of work and uncoordinated activities.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I would like to point out that official development assistance must give priority to basic social services for all and public goods that the private sector can provide less effectively, such as primary education, the social safety net, health care and sanitation, water and energy infrastructure, so that developing countries can reach their full potential. It is important that accessibility should be an essential criterion for international public funding in order to support universal and inclusive services and infrastructures. In line with the Fidesz-KDNP faction, I supported the adoption of the report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Although back in 2000 a plan was signed to drastically reduce the percentage of poverty by 2015, today we are still far from it. I therefore support this Report, which represents a new framework in what I hope is a better and more successful fight against poverty.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. – Is iomaí rud dearfach atá le fáil sa tuairisc seo cosúil leis an slí a ghlaotar ar na tíortha is saibhre níos mó airgid a thabhairt don fhorbairt, agus an gá a bhfuil ann do níos mó soiléireacht laisitgh de Bhuiséad na hEorpa maidir le maoiniú don fhorbairt. Ba chóir fáilte a chuir roimh na rudaí seo. É sin ráite, an rud is tábhachtaí faoi i mo thuairimse ná go bhfuil béim faoi leith curtha ar mná agus an baint tábhachtach atá acu san fhorbairt. Tugann an tuairisc seo tacaíocht do chomhionannas inscne. Cuireann sé togra chun tosaigh a iarann ar chomhionannas inscne a bheith mar chroí-lár de gníomhaíochtaí forbartha. ´Sé sin béim faoi leith a chuir ar infheistíocht i réimsí tábhachtach cosúil le sláinte agus an oideachais mar shampla . Déantar tagairt freisin den aird ar chóir diriú ar sláinte ghnéis agus atáirgthe. Cludaíonn seo réimse leathan de rudaí cosúil le cúram réimhbhreithe agus iarbhreithe, frithghiniúint agus galar gnéas -tarchurtha-rudaí atá thar a bheith tábhachtach.  Mar gheall ar na rudaí thuas luaite chaith mé vóta i bhfabhar an tuairisc seo.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the European Union's primacy in the field of development aid is one of our greatest merits and that this resolution is a further demonstration of European solidarity.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. This report takes stock of the European Union's financing of development. It acknowledges that the use of official development assistance is not sufficiently controlled by the External Action Service and that its effectiveness is not demonstrated. In addition, the report recalls the positive contribution of immigrants to the development of their country of origin through the growth of financial flows from the diaspora. It therefore shows that immigration pays more to the countries of origin than to the countries of destination. Finally, the report recommends using public-private partnerships as a lever for development. However, these private public partnerships risk strengthening the influence of the large CAC 40 companies on the African continent. Opposed in principle to the external action of the European Union, I voted against the report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 By adopting the post-2015 development agenda, which will replace the Millennium Development Goals, the international community will respond to the challenges facing today's world: eradicating poverty, achieving sustainable and inclusive development for present and future generations, and ensuring the promotion and protection of all fundamental human rights and values as a basis for peaceful and prosperous societies. I believe that this framework must be a universal one, based on universal values, such as human rights, good governance, the rule of law, support for democratic institutions, inclusion, non-discrimination and gender equality. I voted in favour of the report on development finance, taking into account the world conference in Addis Ababa and the eu's objectives, and a robust, transparent and accessible monitoring and accountability framework is needed for effective tracking and supervision of investments and progress.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 While I am sceptical about the real use of these resources and their effectiveness, I have always supported the principle of so-called 'let us help them at home'. In this respect, therefore, despite the fact that the text is, in our opinion, incomplete and sometimes not very concrete, I must support its founding principles.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The third international conference on development finance will be held in Ethiopia in July 2015. With this in mind, the European Parliament has passed a resolution calling on the EU and Member States to reaffirm their target of allocating 0.7% of GNI to official development assistance. Helping countries that need funding to develop is important for the European Union. The current international context calls for concrete action on development aid. The European Union must be a forerunner in this area. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on financing development today.  Indeed, I agree with the report, which welcomes the preliminary draft of the final document of the Third International Conference on Financing for Development in Addis Ababa, which has the ambitious task of setting the level of intervention in the next agenda on the subject.  I believe that the right conditions for the eradication of poverty and inequality can be achieved above all through a universal, holistic and integrated approach, which is also entrusted to the monitoring and monitoring by the Commission of the financing of aid programmes and projects on health, education, energy, water supplies and infrastructure. Every action involves the establishment of a proper economic framework, designed to combat corruption, avoid mismanagement and assert adequate political leadership in these processes.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls for the EU and the Member States to re-commit to the 0.7% of GNI target for Official Development Assistance and to commit additional climate finance (COP21, Paris). As such, Official Development Aid is still the main financing instrument. Other positive financing instruments concerned tax evasion and illicit capital flows and, furthermore, a commitment to cooperate with developing countries in counteracting aggressive tax avoidance practices. I believe that it is vital that the development agenda be kept alive. The most important impact of development aid in general is the political and public awareness on global structural causes of poverty. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report by my colleague Pedro Silva Pereira will represent the European Parliament's position at the third conference on development finance to be held in Addis Ababa from 13 to 16 July 2015. This conference will be a key step in supporting the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDOs) because it will have to create the conditions for the financing and implementation of the so-called post-2015 agenda. While the European Parliament's text reaffirms the commitment of The Member States made at the Monterrey Conference in 2002 to allocate 0.7% of gross national income (GNI) to development aid (ODA), it also supports the need to create new and additional sources of funding. I am therefore delighted to have voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which, in addition to the fact that it is part of an immigrationist logic, since it supports the supposedly positive share of migrants in the development of countries of origin, places itself out of all reality regarding development policy. Thus, the report proposes the rise of PPPs in order to finance local businesses, even though only Western companies are able to provide such services. Moreover, the report recalls the constant desire to increase development aid - $134.8 billion in 2013, a historic rate - without ensuring in return for the implementation of anti-corruption measures: a completely irresponsible lack of control of funds! Finally, nothing is specified as to the content of transparency standards for international financial institutions, which will allow them to continue quietly to conduct opaque financial transactions which, more often than not, are contrary to the interests of the people.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Public aid alone is not sufficient to cover all investment needs in developing countries and so the European Parliament calls for the EU to set up, together with developing countries, a regulatory framework that stimulates more responsible, transparent and accountable investment, contributing to the development of a socially—conscious private sector in developing countries. As the biggest donor of development aid, the EU has to play a leadership role in the Financing for Development process. The EU and its Member States must recommit without delay to the 0.7% of GNI target for Official Development Aid (ODA), with 50% of ODA and at least 0.2% of GNI reserved for least developed countries, and present multiannual budget timetables for the scaling-up to these levels by 2020. Domestic resource mobilisation is more predictable and sustainable than foreign assistance and must be a key source of financing. We are asking the Commission to enhance its capacity building assistance in the areas of tax administration, public financial management and anti-corruption, and the EU and Member States must actively crack down on tax havens, tax evasion and illicit financial flows.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has been and still is the world's largest donor of development aid, offering around 60% of public development aid worldwide.  The awareness that there are potentially sufficient resources to eradicate poverty at world level requires that funding be provided to ensure gradual but continuous development, including a wide dissemination of education and a general improvement in living standards. Long-term financial needs must be taken into account by setting up effective programming and promoting channels of cooperation between the various state entities.  That is why I believe it is important to focus on greater support from the Commission and Parliament in the areas of tax administration, financial governance and the management of public finances as well as in the fight against tax evasion. The mobilisation of national resources and international public funding is a key factor in ensuring that the European Union can play more effectively the role of promoting development at global level, which is inherent in its founding values. Having found many meeting points between the report under discussion and my views, I voted in favour.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D)
text: Written. The Danish members of the S&D Group are not in favour of increasing member states' contributions to the EU. It is therefore up to each Member State to finance an increase in development aid in such a way that the UN minimum commitment that development aid must amount to 0.7% of GNP is met. In this respect, the FTT may be a possible funding for those countries that choose to introduce one.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I do agree that the mobilisation of domestic resources and Official Development Assistance (EDF) are irreplaceable points on which development funding is based and which need to be strengthened. In view of the limited capacity of developing countries to mobilise domestic resources, external aid and support become a top necessity. It is remarkable that the EU is the world's largest donor of development aid and provides 60% of the world's official development aid, but it is neither adequately promoted nor made public. I believe that this important assistance should be provided on the basis of priorities. These priorities must be health, education, infrastructure and water supply and the most vulnerable groups must be able to access them. Development banks must also play a role by mobilising additional funds to reduce the gap in infrastructure financing and access to credit in developing countries through monitoring and impact assessment mechanisms. Targeted development financing in developing countries must continue to remain a key objective for the EU.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 2015 is a key year for global development efforts, with the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDRs), the Global Climate Action Agreement (both valid until 2030) and the third International Conference on Financing for Development, which will take place in Addis Ababa (Ethiopia) from 13 to 16 July 2015.  The Union is the world's largest development financier and its aid amounts to around 60% of the total. The current development budget allocates around €60 billion, divided between development cooperation (€19.7 billion), humanitarian aid for 2014-2020 (€6.8 billion), emergency aid reserve (€2.2 billion) and €30.5 billion from the European Development Fund (EDF).  However, many Member States have not committed to the target of 0.7% of gross national development income and, therefore, this measure urges them to present (taking into account budgetary limits) multiannual timetables in order to achieve this target by 2020.  In the light of these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The current year will be of the greatest importance on the Development agenda with the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals which should guide national policies and international cooperation activities over the next fifteen years, following the Millennium Development Goals, with the adoption of the agreement on global action against climate change and the International Conference on Financing for Development , which will allow the implementation of the post-2015 Agenda to be established and funded and implementing plans. As in the past, the European Union must play an important role in these negotiations and be at the forefront of the new development financing process. I support this report because It considers it vital to reconfirm the commitment to allocate 0.7% of gross national income to official development aid and to insist on a partnership with other public and private partners in this global desiderato. I would remind you that, in parallel with resource mobilisation, efforts should also be made to manage financial resources, combat corruption and tax evasion in the affected countries and that development aid should always be nuanced by principles of good governance and protection of human rights, with a particular focus on the most vulnerable groups.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 2015 is a key year for Europe's political leadership in establishing a framework for sustainable development and climate action. This is an ambitious objective, and as such it needs a strong and comprehensive partnership involving the use of various forms of funding.  I believe that the eradication of poverty and inequality can only be achieved through the mobilisation of sufficient and adequate resources, which guarantee targeted interventions in support of the most vulnerable groups.  In the light of these considerations, I have chosen to vote in favour of this report, so that the Member States maintain their role as major donors and, at the same time, urge the developing countries to share responsibilities.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ More than 1.5 billion people are still living in poverty with deprivation in health, education and living standards, notably in conflict-affected and fragile states. This is not acceptable, given that sufficient resources exist in the world to progressively end this situation. The EU is called on to set up a regulatory framework that stimulates responsible, transparent and accountable investment which contributes to the development of the private sector in developing countries

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report represents the European Parliament's position at the third conference on development finance to be held in Addis Ababa. The Addis Ababa Conference will be an important contribution to supporting the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDRs). In a context of financial crisis, where Member States are increasingly reluctant to honour their commitment at the Monterrey Conference (2002) to commit 0.7% of gross national income (GNI) to development aid (ODA), the report approved in the DEVE Committee sends a positive signal in terms of the objectives to be achieved for the conference, including the need to create new and additional sources of funding. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it reflects positive aspects such as the requirement that the commitment to allocate 0.7% of GDP to development cooperation be fulfilled, it advocates strengthening public-private partnership in financing for development.  This report calls for the implementation in cooperation for the development of neoliberal policies in the EU, i.e. making public resources available to the private sector for the benefit of the private sector, protecting its investments and demanding reforms consisting of liberalization.     I believe that the pursuit of profit by multinationals is incompatible with sustainable development based on social justice, a development that requires that the basic pillars for the well-being of populations, such as education, health or the right to housing, be public services guaranteed by States, which are the only actors capable of ensuring their universality , quality and free. Faced with the commitment to private investments of multinational companies in key sectors and services for the development and well-being of people, I defend another model of cooperation based on the financing and strengthening of public-public partnerships.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Millennium Development Goals, adopted in 2000 by world leaders to reduce poverty, were expected to be achieved by 2015. Unfortunately, we are still a long way from achieving them: 1.5 billion people are still living in poverty, especially in conflict-affected states; All this despite the fact that, at world level, sufficient resources are available to put an end to this situation.  Unfortunately, it should be noted that very few industrialised countries are fulfilling their commitment to allocate 0.7% of GNI as official development aid. That is where we must start again, making sure that the budgetary constraints imposed do not penalise this type of intervention and, at the same time, by stepping up the search for alternative sources and resources, including the tax on financial transactions. We must also learn from the past to build strategies based on correct analyses, which set politically acceptable and decisive global development goals for eradicating poverty. At the same time, the non-financial arrangements and means of implementation must be indicated. As the largest contributor to development aid, the EU must claim and play a leading role in this process.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the need for better EU support to developing countries via development aid. The aim of this report is to send a strong signal by calling on the EU and its Member States to lead by example. I voted in favour of this report, however I voted against parts of paragraphs 8 and 28 since I am of the view that a financial transaction tax and sexual and reproductive health rights are Member State competences.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider it beneficial to propose to run programmes to support the development of a private sector, attentive to social issues in developing countries, with a focus on supporting women and other vulnerable groups. One solution is appropriate information and training programmes on financial aspects, the use of banking and insurance products, as well as new technologies. On the other hand, it is important to develop micro-loan schemes, especially for women, in order to give them the opportunity to launch and run their own businesses.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. – 2015, the European Year of Development, is also the year of the third international conference on financing for development, to be held in Addis Ababa in July, at which the new sustainable development goals will be defined. The broad and cross-party support for the report on financing for development, in which Parliament made its contribution to the EU's position precisely in the run-up to the conference, demonstrates the importance of this issue for the european Union as a whole. Parliament strongly argues that the EU must continue to play a leading role in development policies and maintain that of the world's largest donor of development aid, renewing its commitments and calling for a genuine sharing of responsibilities between Member States. The EU, together with developing countries, will need to have a more incisive and responsible investment regulatory framework that takes into account innovative financing arrangements such as public-private partnerships that ensure a balance between risks to the private sector and guarantees offered by the public sector. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. In anticipation of the third international conference on post-2015 development funding and sustainable development goals, held next July in Addis Ababa, this report calls for an ambitious partnership to secure credible funding for the new development goals. Considering that it is necessary to facilitate the mobilization of national resources and to set priorities in the main development sectors while ensuring the establishment of credible mechanisms for monitoring and monitoring progress on the ground, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. We can be proud that 60% of global official development aid comes from the European Union and its Member States. I would like to reiterate, however, that there is a need to coordinate our development aid policy ever more closely with our migration policy, our agricultural policy, and also our environmental policy. I also stress the importance of the link between security and development. Taking this into account must lead us to adopt a comprehensive approach of supporting third countries, neighbouring or not, which are in the affected by conflict. On the strength of these considerations, European countries must be united and ambitious at the 2015 conferences in Addis Ababa and Paris.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although encouraged by the progress made over the last two decades in getting 660 million people out of poverty worldwide, recent World Bank data on poverty seriously remind us of the scale of the task still facing eradicating extreme poverty. The European Union must take action to strengthen the international community's commitment to the post-2015 development agenda. Erasing poverty, ensuring inclusive and sustainable development for current and future generations, promoting and protecting all human rights are the fundamental values for a peaceful and prosperous society.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Parliament calls on EU countries to honour their foreign aid commitments. First, at the financial level, states must meet their commitment to allocate 0.7% of their GNI to development. So far only four EU states have achieved this goal, namely Denmark, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and Sweden (Belgium is about to join this group). Secondly, it is important to think about innovative ways to finance development. Several initiatives have already emerged and need to be strengthened. I am thinking in particular of Unitaid, where more than half of the funds from the "airfare tax" finance access to HIV treatment in low-income countries. The idea of a financial transaction tax, which would generate funds for development, must also come to fruition. Finally, the EU and the States must implement "win-win" partnerships. The Addis Ababa International Conference for Financing for Development in July, which will define the first framework for the next global development goals, should be an opportunity for representatives of the international community to address all of these issues.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The third development finance conference will be held in Addis Ababa in July 2015. The conference brings together high-level political representatives, international actors, representatives of non-governmental actors and business players. It aims to decide on the level of money for international development and to support the implementation of the post-2015 EU and global development framework, including the SDGs, which are scheduled to be adopted in New York in September 2015. The aim of the report is to develop an international partnership to finance development, which effectively supports the aforementioned objectives. The report highlights the European Union's leadership in international development and stresses the importance of shared responsibility and calls on rising and middle-income countries to make significant commitments.  The report urges the European Union to immediately re-commit to the 0.7 percent GNI target for Official Development Assistance (ODA). At least 50 per cent of official development assistance and at least 0.2 per cent of GNI reserved for least developed countries and taking budgetary constraints into account. These objectives are in line with the direction pursued by the Fidesz-KDNP, in particular with regard to the settlement of the issue of migration. That's why I voted in favour.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Official development assistance (ODA) is a key instrument for financing development. In 2005, EU Member States committed to spending 0.7% of their gross national income (GNI) on ODA by 2015. This goal has not been achieved. That is why I agree with the political signal that Parliament, through this report, is sending to the Commission, the Council and the European States. By 2020, Member States must meet their target and effectively spend 0.7% of their GNI on ODA, with 50% of ODA and a minimum of 0.2% of GNI for least developed countries. However, the mobilization of domestic resources is more predictable and sustainable than foreign aid, which cannot be sufficient to cover all investment needs in developing countries. I therefore support the EU's call for a regulatory framework with developing countries that stimulates transparent and accountable investment and contributes to the development of a vibrant private sector in developing countries.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The third development finance conference will be held in Addis Ababa in July 2015. The conference brings together high-level political representatives, international actors, representatives of non-governmental actors and business players. It aims to decide on the level of money for international development and to support the implementation of the post-2015 EU and global development framework, including the SDGs, which are scheduled to be adopted in New York in September 2015.  The aim of the report is to develop an international partnership to finance development that effectively supports the aforementioned objectives. The report highlights the European Union's leadership in international development and stresses the importance of shared responsibility and calls on growing and middle-income countries to make significant commitments.  The report urges the European Union to immediately re-commit to the 0.7 percent GNI target for Official Development Assistance (ODA). At least 50 per cent of official development assistance and at least 0.2 per cent of GNI reserved for the least developed countries and taking budgetary constraints into account. These objectives are in line with the direction pursued by the Fidesz-KDNP, in particular with regard to the settlement of the issue of migration. That's why I voted in favour.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. ‒ Mr President, events of recent months in Nepal and the waters of the Eastern Mediterranean have reiterated the need for national governments in the EU to play a fair but effective role in supporting people living in poverty and disadvantage in less—developed countries across the world. There is, of course, a balance to be struck. Combating poverty among our own citizens is not a selfish aim, and this should be prioritised. However, there is also a time to step back, reflect on the generally high standard of living that we enjoy, and commit to helping those less fortunate than the majority of our citizens. This report calls on Member State to recommit to the 0.7% figure of GNI to development aid. This is a commitment that the UK’s national parliament supported in a vote earlier this year. We must take these matters seriously. However it also important to ensure that the allocation of this money is targeted, credible and based on identified need, in order to render it effective and conducive not only to supporting the end of poverty in the short term, but to equipping societies with the means to ensure lasting economic prosperity.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The report represents an important contribution by the EP to the position of the EU in July’s high-level international conference on Financing for Development (FfD) in Addis Ababa (Ethiopia), which is to create the necessary conditions for financing and implementing the post-2015 agenda for Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). It calls on the Member States to recommit to their ODA target of 0.7% of gross national income (GNI) by 2020; it urges the Commission to enhance its capacity—building assistance in the area of tax administration, public financial management and anti-corruption measures.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on financing development because I believe that Bulgaria as the poorest country within the Union can take advantage of the opportunities provided and raise the standard of living of its citizens.  Financing development would help Bulgaria emerge from the severe economic crisis that forced over 2 million Bulgarians to seek asylum abroad. I believe that through the various European programmes and the funded Bulgarian business can become competitive and actively participate in the European market.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We vote against. The same people who led us to the economic crisis, the same people who are trying to destroy third world countries to serve their interests are the ones who are now claiming to save us. Using, of course, the same means and methods that are proven to fail, except perhaps the possibility that they offer the rich to become even richer and permanently faithful to their ideologies that are destroying modern Western societies.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The third development finance conference will be held in Addis Ababa in July 2015. The conference brings together high-level political representatives, international actors, representatives of non-governmental actors and business players. It aims to decide on the level of money for international development and to support the implementation of the post-2015 EU and global development framework, including the SDGs, which are scheduled to be adopted in New York in September 2015. The aim of the report is to develop an international partnership to finance development, which effectively supports the aforementioned objectives. The report highlights the European Union's leadership in international development and stresses the importance of shared responsibility and calls on rising and middle-income countries to make significant commitments.  The report urges the European Union to immediately re-commit to the 0.7 percent GNI target for Official Development Assistance (ODA). At least 50 per cent of official development assistance and at least 0.2 per cent of GNI reserved for least developed countries and taking budgetary constraints into account. These objectives are in line with the direction pursued by the Fidesz-KDNP, in particular with regard to the settlement of the issue of migration. That's why I voted in favour.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which was adopted by a large majority. Ahead of the Third International Conference on Financing for Development, being held this July in Addis Ababa, it calls for  0.7% of GNI to be recommitted to development aid, despite many Member States being reluctant to do so. It also calls for the establishment of an intergovernmental body on tax matters, under the auspices of the United Nations, as well as international corporate tax rules including the principle that taxes should be paid where value is extracted or created. My constituents in Wales feel strongly about fair taxation, tax justice and countering tax evasion.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Addis Ababa conference, to be held this year in July, will be decisive in supporting the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals. The international situation, due to the financial crisis, led the Member States to question the commitment made at the Monterrey Conference in 2002, where it was decided to commit 0.7% of gross national income for development aid.  The report adopted in the DEVE Committee is a positive sign, as it sets concrete objectives to be achieved in the run-up to the Addis Ababa Conference, not least because it demonstrates the need to find additional sources of development funding. The report reiterates its commitment to aid: in essence, the EU is being asked to assert its political leadership with a view to establishing a framework for sustainable development, committing itself once again and without delay to achieving the target of 0.7% of gross national income for development aid. In addition, the EU is being asked to take serious action against tax havens, tax evasion and illicit financial flows, which undermine development assistance and contribute to the indebtedness of developing countries. I voted in favour.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. 2015 is a key year for global development efforts, with the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and an agreement on global action against climate change, valid until 2030. 1.5 billion people are still living in poverty, with health, education and living conditions shortages, particularly in fragile conflict-sour states. I believe that it will only be possible to eradicate poverty and inequalities by mobilising sufficient and adequate resources for all and specific measures for marginalised groups, including children, women, the elderly or people with disabilities. Three-quarters of the world's poorest people -- about 960 million people -- currently live in middle-income countries, with UNCUCED estimating the financing needs of developing countries for the new SDGs at about $3.9 billion a year, with the new SDGs currently missing $2.5 billion a year. The EU and its Member States must maintain their position as main donors of development aid while defending shared responsibility.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because it considers the massive reception of migrants to be an asset to development policy. However, it is quite the opposite: mass immigration leads to the impoverishment of European populations and also deprives the countries of departure of many of their living forces.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The approach to financing the development of development in this report ignores the framework of asymmetric interdependence relationships typical of globalized capitalism, which generate sunequal development on a global scale. Hence its great and unavoidable limitation. With economic inequality comes political dependence and subordination. There are several instruments that promoter the vicious circle of impoverishment, dependence and subordination. This is the case of foreign debt. On several occasions paid and nevertheless ever increasing, there will be no serious and effective development cooperation policy without addressing this issue or without the essential cancellation of this debt and the mechanisms that underpin it. This issue is simply ignored by the report. As are also the devastating effects of the interventions of the IMF and the World Bank – promoters of the drainage of endogenous resources to said donors, resources that go beyond the amounts of Official Development Assistance.  Official Development Assistance (ODA) is crucial and should increase, even in accordance with commitments made but not fulfilled. We value what the report refers to in this regard. But just as ODA alone (even at desirable levels) is not enough, so this positive aspect of the report is not enough to make it a good report. Far from it.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union and other developed countries have an unquestionably moral obligation to ensure climate finance so that they reach the goal of joint mobilisation of USD 100 billion per year by 2020. In addition, within the framework of the Global Partnership, there is also a need for new development goals and the associated financial framework, which is mainly aimed at eradicating poverty and respect for human rights and gender equality. It is precisely the reduction and eradication of poverty that is also the European Union's main development objective. Therefore, official development assistance should also give priority to the basic social services and public services provided by the private sector with less efficiency. These include, for example, primary education, social security networks, health, but also water and energy supplies.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report because, although it is not particularly innovative or critical of the past, it bears acceptable references to the Sustainable Development Goals in poor countries.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on financing development, because the same people who led us to the economic crisis, the same people who are destroying third world countries to serve their interests are the ones who now claim to save us, of course using the same means and methods that are proven to fail, except perhaps the possibility that they offer the rich to become even richer and permanently faithful to their ideologies that are destroying modern Western societies.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe the EU and its Member States must recommit without delay to the 0.7% of GNI target for ODA, with 50% of ODA and at least 0.2% of GNI reserved for least—developed countries, and present, taking into account budgetary constraints, multiannual budget timetables for the scale-up to these levels by 2020. I support the point of view adopted in the report where it states that domestic resource mobilisation is more predictable and sustainable than foreign assistance and must be a key source of financing.  Public aid alone is not sufficient to cover all investment needs in development countries. The EU must set up, together with developing countries, a regulatory framework that stimulates more responsible, transparent and accountable investment, contributing to the development of a socially—conscious private sector in developing countries.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The third development finance conference will be held in Addis Ababa in July 2015. The conference brings together high-level political representatives, international actors, representatives of non-governmental actors and business players. It aims to decide on the level of money for international development and to support the implementation of the post-2015 EU and global development framework, including the SDGs, which are scheduled to be adopted in New York in September 2015. These objectives are in line with the direction pursued by the Fidesz-KDNP, in particular with regard to the settlement of the issue of migration. That's why I voted in favour.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The third development finance conference will be held in Addis Ababa in July 2015. The conference brings together high-level political representatives, international actors, representatives of non-governmental actors and business players. It aims to decide on the level of money for international development and to support the implementation of the post-2015 EU and global development framework, including the SDGs, which are scheduled to be adopted in New York in September 2015. At least 50 per cent of official development assistance and at least 0.2 per cent of GNI reserved for least developed countries and taking budgetary constraints into account. These objectives are in line with the direction pursued by the Fidesz-KDNP, in particular with regard to the settlement of the issue of migration. That's why I voted in favour.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. Development cooperation is a staple of European Union policy in the world, even considering that nearly 1.5 billion people still live in poverty and suffer deprivation in health, education and living standards. The eradication of poverty and inequality will only be achieved through the mobilization of sufficient resources, so it is development funding that needs to be strengthened. The EU's contribution is more vital than ever. I voted for it.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is the world's leading donor of development aid. Proud of this primacy, However, I believe that we can and must try to make this aid more targeted and effective, with a view to greater subsidiarity.  A holistic approach is needed that integrates all the complexities of development issues into development funding. I would particularly like to highlight the two key challenges facing us in 2015: the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDOs) and the adoption of a global agreement on climate change and the fight against climate change, during COP 21 in Paris. I hope that the EU will not lose these two great opportunities to show the world real leadership based on concrete proposals.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. – 1.5 billion poor people: that is unacceptable in our day. That is why I offer my full support to Mr Pereira's own-initiative report on financing development, so that the Union can strengthen its commitment to support development policies not only through awareness-raising initiatives, exchange of best practices and support for the important work of NGOs, but also through more concrete actions and economic operations such as the transposition by member countries of 'international public funding' , an allocation of 0.7% of gross national income to the least developed countries, the creation of a sustainable development table and the promotion of a programme aimed at eradicating poverty and the priority objective of accessibility of basic social services for all.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP report on financing development, because I believe that the third Addis Ababa Conference to be held in July 2015 should create the conditions for the financing and implementation of the post-2015 development agenda. I therefore believe that it is essential for EU Member States to meet the objective of committing 0.7% of GDP to Official Development Assistance (APD) in such a way as to meet the commitments made by European states in 2005, even in a changed economic and financial situation. As recognised by the 2005 European Consensus on Development, there can be no sustainable development without peace and security; Nevertheless, after ten years, the number of people still living in poverty, suffering health, education and living standards, especially in fragile and conflict-affected states, has remained unchanged. This is not acceptable, since there are sufficient resources, at world level, to gradually end extreme poverty, with more targeted interventions according to an integrated approach towards the developing countries. Poverty reduction must be an EU priority, hence the need for the EU to maintain leadership in ODA policy.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as it contains very positive development funding elements. The report calls for strengthening the mobilization of domestic resources through the promotion of fair tax systems and the fight against tax evasion and illicit capital flows. The report also recognises the importance of developing a multilateral framework for sovereign debt restructuring based on responsible lending principles, and calls on Member States and the European Commission to contribute positively to the UN working group on this issue. In addition, the report uses very positive language in relation to gender equality and women's rights.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my Labour colleagues, voted in favour of this report because Labour has led the way for a progressive development policy to tackle poverty and inequality across the world. The Labour Party’s efforts led to a UK law to commit 0.7% of national income (GNI) to Official Development Assistance (ODA). Now is the time for other governments to commit, and for a strong new agenda to mobilise a range of finance to make the new Sustainable Development Goals a reality and end extreme poverty by 2030.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because the European Union must take a leading position in the fight against global financial challenges. We are those partners on the international stage who provide the greatest development support. We must therefore ensure that, in the parts of the world facing the greatest development challenges, the European Union helps to find answers to the problems that are emerging. We also need to coordinate very well for the sake of development between Member States in order to avoid duplication and to have access to EU aid to the most vulnerable communities.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Pereira's report on financing for development. There is no doubt that the ambitious challenges that set the new SDGs must have a strong basis in the form of an adequate level of funding. However, we must also bear in mind that, in view of the economic crisis, very few Member States are currently able to meet the commitment to allocate 0.7% (or 0.33% in the case of the new Member States) of gross national income to official development assistance. In view of the different economic situation of the different Member States, as well as the different traditions of development policy, I believe that it is right that the objective of allocating 0.7% of GNI to development policy should be treated globally, vis-60% of the European Union as a whole, and not with a distinction between Member States. I am also convinced that it is particularly important to ensure that the aid provided has the highest possible added value and is as effective as possible. In this context, it is necessary to comply with the commitments set out in the Busan Partnership.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The third development finance conference will be held in Addis Ababa in July 2015. The conference brings together high-level political representatives, international actors, representatives of non-governmental actors and business. It aims to decide on the level of money for international development and to support the implementation of the post-2015 EU and global development framework, including the SDGs, which are scheduled to be adopted in New York in September 2015. The aim of the report is to develop an international partnership to finance development, which effectively supports the aforementioned objectives. The document underlines the European Union's leading role in international development and stresses the importance of shared responsibility and calls on rising and middle-income countries to make significant commitments.  The report urges the European Union to immediately re-commit to the 0.7 percent GNI target for Official Development Assistance (ODA). At least 50 per cent of official development assistance and at least 0.2 per cent of GNI reserved for least developed countries and taking into account budgetary constraints. These objectives are in line with the direction pursued by the Fidesz-KDNP, in particular with regard to the settlement of the issue of migration. That's why I voted in favour.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is right to reiterate the call for Member States to commit to 0.7% of GNI to be spent on international aid. My party has committed to this target being enshrined in law in an independent Scotland and will continue to argue for it within the context of the UK.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as it contains very positive development funding elements. The report calls for strengthening the mobilization of domestic resources through the promotion of fair tax systems and the fight against tax evasion and illicit capital flows. The report also recognises the importance of developing a multilateral framework for sovereign debt restructuring based on responsible lending principles, and calls on Member States and the European Commission to contribute positively to the UN working group on this issue. In addition, the report uses very positive language in relation to gender equality and women's rights.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report which calls for long-term financial needs to be taken into account by opting for and adopting a more strategic, ambitious and universal approach in line with the sustainable development goals.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the development finance report because I believe that the EU and the Member States together need to foster joint responsibility as much as they can and fulfil their obligation to issue 0.7% of gross national income for official development assistance. Although the European Union is the world's largest donor of this assistance and contributes 60% of the shares, however, a small number of developed countries fully fulfil their commitment to allocate money. The EU should continue its efforts to reduce and ultimately eradicate poverty, protect human rights, and fight inequality.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. The Report on Financing for Development sets out the EU's objectives for financing development. The proposal highlights the lack of control over funds but does not sufficiently address the real issues related to the issue of development financing. More importantly, the report is a disaster in immigration policy, including strengthening cooperation between countries of origin and destination on migration policy. At a time when European and OECD countries are in serious fiscal difficulty, and austerity policies are multiplying, public aid is being kept at a very high level. In addition, these funds are very often collected by the pharmaceutical industry to fund its scientific research. There is a need to redefine development aid priorities as global poverty has changed in nature. This motion for a resolution is still too hypocritical about development issues and could further degrade the situation. I voted against this report for all of these reasons.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution sends a strong message to EU Member States and the Commission on the leading role the EU should play in the upcoming Third International Conference on Financing for Development in Addis Ababa. It is crucial that EU countries respect their Official Development Assistance (ODA) target of 0.7% of national income and set timetables for reaching it by 2020.  I believe it is important not only to provide financial aid but also to create an environment in developing countries which stimulates more responsible, transparent and accountable investment. Let us not forget that 1.5 billion people still live in poverty. The EU’s development aid focuses both on helping those in immediate need and on increasing the sustainability of the countries in question through capacity—building projects.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Pedro Silva Pereira's report on development finance. The report stresses the need for states to participate more actively in the development of emerging economies and thus maintain their ranks as world's leading donors in development aid. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on financing for development. 2015 will be a crucial year for global development action, notably with the third international conference on financing for development taking place next July. The EU must therefore promote ambitious sustainable development goals, taking into account new global challenges, while ensuring its financial commitment to this sector.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Billions of people still live in poverty, without access to healthcare and education. There is also a growing tendency to marginalise measures for women, children, the elderly and the disabled. The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) estimates that nearly $4 billion is needed annually to achieve the SDGs.  Although the European Union remains the largest donor of development aid in the world, we must step up our efforts and concentrate our efforts to bring tangible benefits. I support the position set out in the document in order to focus not only on quantity but also on the quality of development aid. When fighting for the protection of human rights and multifaceted equality, we must not forget access to the most basic services: sanitation and energy infrastructure, education, health services and fundamental social services. Consistency of aid with other policy areas (e.g. environment and agriculture) is equally needed. Supporting young, entrepreneurial people, supporting innovation and investing in new technologies will ensure economic growth.  The document also highlights the beneficial impact of migration of people from underdeveloped countries: citizens of these countries usually send money to their families, indirectly supporting the local development of their homelands. Only peace and security can guarantee sustainable development. Let us help those who need help.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. I reject the report because the current form of development aid is not efficient and, unfortunately, the desired successes are not achieved. In the current structure, there are all too often misallocations, money disappears into dark channels and does not reach the population sufficiently, which should benefit from development policies.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The key to the well-being of citizens is in constant development, which is why I voted in favour of the development finance report at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg. I believe that without specific objectives and an orderly funding system, it will be very difficult to achieve growth in Europe and globally. It is essential that the report calls for the development of ambitious cooperation and cooperation in terms of funding, stressing that without international cooperation, the objectives of sustainable development will not be achieved. The report comes at a very important time, as it is precisely this year that the updateding Sustainable Development Goals and the agreement on global climate change measures will be adopted. For development to really be at a high level and for Europe and the world to come closer to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals, fiscal cooperation and orderlyness at global level are, in my view, very important.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome the report. We need to find international solutions to finance development and negotiate a new framework of development goals. The Labour Party’s efforts led to a UK law to commit 0.7% of national income (GNI) to Official Development Assistance (ODA). Now is the time for other governments to commit, and for a strong new agenda to mobilise a range of finance to make the new Sustainable Development Goals a reality and end extreme poverty by 2030. The EU must continue to make sure that development aid is more effective and better coordinated.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
text: Written. The Danish members of the S&D Group are not in favour of increasing member states' contributions to the EU. It is therefore up to each Member State to finance an increase in development aid in such a way that the UN minimum commitment that development aid must amount to 0.7% of GNP is met. In this respect, the FTT may be a possible funding for those countries that choose to introduce one.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The third development finance conference will be held in Addis Ababa in July 2015. The conference brings together high-level political representatives, international actors, representatives of non-governmental actors and business players. It aims to decide on the level of money for international development and to support the implementation of the post-2015 EU and global development framework, including the SDGs, which are scheduled to be adopted in New York in September 2015.  The aim of the report is to develop an international partnership to finance development that effectively supports the aforementioned objectives. The report highlights the European Union's leadership in international development and stresses the importance of shared responsibility and calls on growing and middle-income countries to make significant commitments.  The report urges the European Union to immediately re-commit to the 0.7 percent GNI target for Official Development Assistance (ODA). At least 50 per cent of official development assistance and at least 0.2 per cent of GNI reserved for the least developed countries and taking budgetary constraints into account. These objectives are in line with the direction pursued by the Fidesz-KDNP, in particular with regard to the settlement of the issue of migration. That's why I voted in favour.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today with this vote we all affirm the will to achieve an ambitious global development partnership. As indicated in the UN Secretary-General's synthesis report, it is necessary to have a transformative, universal and holistic approach to achieving development objectives that are also integrated with an appropriate financial framework. The success of this ambitious partnership depends on specific objectives to be achieved, such as poverty eradication, the universality of human rights and gender equality.  I would like to stress the importance of maintaining our status as the EU as the world's largest donor of development aid – today we provide almost 60% of it – and I call for greater shared responsibility on the part of all Member States specifically in making significant economic commitments.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report because I believe that the EU and its Member States should maintain their position as a major donor of development aid. The EU contributes almost 60% of global official development assistance, but the eradication of poverty and inequality can only be achieved by mobilising sufficient and appropriate funds focused on poverty eradication, the universality of human rights and gender equality. Still, 1.5 billion people live in poverty and deprivation in health, education and living standards. They are most often in conflict-affected countries, where economic growth and security depend, to a large extent, on the country's ability to exercise its sovereign functions to safeguard the rule of law and provide basic public services.  I therefore believe that the European Union should focus, in addition to the resources available and on the need to establish favourable conditions for private enterprises and entrepreneurship in developing countries, especially MSMEs, as they play a key role as a driver of job creation and inclusive growth.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I supported Mr Pereira's report. Given that 2015 is a key year for global development efforts and that the mobilisation of national resources and official development aid (ODA) are irreplaceable foundations for its funding, I believe that they need to be supported and strengthened. This report urges the EU and the Member States to commit themselves without delay to the objective of achieving 0.7% of GNI (gross national income) to ODA, and also to boost commitments made on the provision of more, new and additional funding to combat climate change.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the non-binding resolution calling on EU Member States to meet the target of spending 0.7% of their national income on official development assistance (ODA), as a key instrument for financing development, and to set a clear timetable for achieving this target by 2020.  In voting in favour of this resolution, I, like the overwhelming majority of my fellow MEPs, wished to underline the need to mobilise national resources effectively in developing countries. These domestic resources, which are more predictable and sustainable than foreign aid, must be a major source of financing for the development of these countries.  This resolution underlines the European Parliament's desire to see the European Union assert its political leadership in the process of defining the sustainable development framework and to see it retain its position as the world's leading contributor to international development aid. We therefore also call on the European Commission, the Council and the Member States to do everything possible to ensure that the European Union plays a leading role in the negotiations that will be held soon at the addis Ababa International Conference on Financing for Development.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on financing for development, because this report is a half-confession of no real control over the use of funds. Paragraph 48, for example, states in a hushed manner that there is a problem with the transparent and effective implementation of aid and funding, that there is a problem of corruption and mismanagement, and that there is often a lack of "accurate, timely and comparable data" on revenues and expenditures. Paragraph 42, for its part, underlines "the positive contribution of migrants to the development of their countries of origin and calls for more effective and innovative cooperation on migration policy between countries of origin and destination; draws attention to the large and growing financial flows of remittances by the diaspora." This pro-immigrationist observation ignores the fact that emigration to Europe often represents a brain drain that is harmful to the countries of origin.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 2015 is a crucial year for global development efforts. The report calls for as much political and economic ambition as possible for the construction of the new development framework. This report nurtures the EU's position for the Third International Conference on Financing for Development, to be held in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, from 13 to 16 July 2015.  We are committed to creating the necessary conditions for the financing and implementation of the agenda for after 2015. The EU and its Member States are also asked to commit again without delay to the target of allocating 0.7% of GNI to Official Development Aid (ODP). For this reason, I voted for it.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The Resolution on Financing for Development contains numerous initiatives to achieve a global partnership so that those countries with higher incomes commit themselves to actions that promote the development of those most disadvantaged countries. Official development aid (ODP) is a mechanism with an important role in this area as it sets effective funding guidelines for development. Among other measures, I stress the importance of promoting initiatives on issues such as health, education or energy, which are a priority for the EU, all through coordinated action between Member States. At the same time, fiscal issues should be taken into account, avoiding financial crimes that impede the development of emerging countries. These projects should not forget the importance of human rights, taking into account the particularly vulnerable situation of women and girls in these countries. Finally, I agree that investment in research and measures to promote access to finance for SMEs and micro-enterprises in developing countries should be enhanced, all on the basis of principles of transparency and effective account supervision and control. I therefore support that resolution with my favourable vote.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the traditional idea that poor countries will be saved by development aid. It has been in place for decades and means only short-term assistance that does nothing to address the overall problem. On the other hand, there is also the hypocrisy of the EU, which does not allow poor countries to trade freely with Europe and also get rich.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Development Policy of the European Union is defined in Article 208 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which calls for the eradication of poverty in the world. The new Multiannual Financial Framework envisions €20 billion with the aim of developing cooperation between the European Union and third countries, €7 billion for humanitarian aid and an additional €2 billion in the event of emergency humanitarian aid.  The above funds make the European Union the largest donor, as 60 percent of the world's development aid to reduce the number of poor, ensure adequate health care, access to adequate education and infrastructure, comes from the European Union. I supported the European Parliament's resolution on financing development, as I believe that the role of the European Union in providing high-quality development assistance to developing countries is essential. Further efforts also need to be made to help developing countries create a better business environment, strengthen institutions and improve the efficiency of administration.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Poverty of 1.5 billion people living mainly in developing, politically and economically unstable countries causes these people to be denied basic conditions for a dignified life and to meet the most basic human needs. The poor suffer from food shortages, safe drinking water, lack of access to healthcare and education. This ultimately causes them to be socially excluded from the society in which they live. At the same time, however, poverty is a significant motivation for population migration, as pictured in the current situation in the south of Europe.  It is undeniable that the poor have the right to help. However, a solution to poverty as a global problem must also be sought in the countries where it occurs. There is material potential in these countries to tackle poverty. Therefore, the EU's role as a leader in supporting developing countries must also focus on the political and diplomatic level, and not only on economic and financial assistance.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of postponing the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on indicators used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts, following the proposal of the rapporteur of the report.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, which insists that the EU and its Member States should maintain their position as major donors of development aid.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against it. This report promotes migration by arguing that migrants contribute positively to the development of countries of origin because they cause financial flows between the diaspora and the country of origin. We are strongly opposed to this reasoning. Moreover, this report demonstrates a lack of control over the use of funds, which is intolerable.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on financing development because it is not acceptable that, even today, 1.5 billion people are living in poverty, suffering from deprivation in terms of health, education and living standards. There is a need to mobilise sufficient and adequate resources to deal with this situation, also considering that 2015 is a key year for global development efforts. A more strategic, ambitious and universal approach must be pursued, bearing in mind that the EU is the world's largest donor of development aid and provides almost 60% of official development aid globally.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The EU has dedicated this 2015 to development, and from Europe we must continue to maintain a constant and active effort to help internationally with the aim of eradicating poverty, combating the effects of climate change and improving living conditions and respect for human rights around the world. I support this motion for a resolution, in which the European Parliament calls for the EU and the Member States to continue to make the necessary efforts to maintain development aid, with the cooperation of the private sector.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I am opposed to the report on financing for development, because I do not consider development aid in its current form to be useful or efficient, and I do not believe that it will achieve the desired objectives. In addition, massive misallocations often occur, for example through corruption.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report on financing for development highlights the need to fight poverty and in favour of the Sustainable Development Goals set by the United Nations. The objectives are, of course, laudable.  This text thus recalls the central role that the United Nations must play in the establishment of orderly and cooperative international exchanges, the first milestones of which are laid down through "international tax cooperation" under the aegis of the United Nations, and an active crackdown on tax havens, tax evasion and illegal financial flows. Nevertheless, I remain opposed to certain elements of the report, such as the emphasis on public-private partnerships as levers of financing or the idea that better access to international markets is a condition for development. I vote for this text in support of these ambitious tax proposals, but I regret that, on any issue, the rapporteurs are forced to recite the mantras of liberal dogma which gives a stupid tone to their text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. Development finance is one of the key tools the EU has to help growth and help eradicate poverty and inequalities.  Only by mobilising sufficient and adequate financial resources for all and specific measures for marginalised groups, including children, women, the elderly or people with disabilities, will we succeed in tackling inequalities still existing around the world. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is unfortunate that an otherwise well-composed report included unacceptable references to sexual health and reproductive rights which may be interpreted as a right to abortion. That is why I could not support this report.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. This report is timely; it prepares the EU's position for the international conference on financing for development to be held in Addis Ababa in July 2015. I welcome the adoption of this report, which encourages the EU and its Member States to honour their contribution of 0.7% of GNP. This commitment must be met without delay. There is also a need to develop innovative sources and build capacity for developing countries to overcome aid dependency through the promotion of good governance and the development of effective tax systems. Sustainable development will only be possible if it is adequately funded and builds on the ability of developing countries to finance access to basic public services such as improving the health system. The promotion of good taxation, budgetary assistance, the development of banking, resilience to epidemics such as Ebola and the pooling of health risks, and the development of African countries' autonomous peacekeeping capacities are all topics that deserve special attention at the Addis Ababa conference.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ ‘Financing for Development’ is a very important non-legislative Report underlining the need for the EU and Member States to reaffirm their political leadership and to stick to their commitments regarding Official Development Assistance (ODA). As the biggest donor of development aid, the EU has to play a leadership role in the Financing for Development process. In recent months the situation of migrant smuggling and illegal migration in Europe has deteriorated dramatically. Therefore, the EU must continue to make sure that development aid is more effective and better coordinated. Hence, I have voted in favour of the Report. Nevertheless, there were a few provisions on sexual and reproductive health and rights and on financial transaction taxes which I didn’t support.

name: Bernard Monot (NI)
text: In writing. The report outlines the EU's objectives and commitments on development finance but fails to establish clear rules on anti-corruption, a logical counterpart to aid to the countries concerned.  The issue is all the more crucial given that 1.5 billion people live below the poverty line and suffer from health, education and standard of living deficiencies in EU-assisted countries.
