Secondly, the report rightly calls for more effective cooperation between countries of origin and emigration for flow management. Unfortunately, much more would be required and financial assistance would be conditional. It is known that most deportations cannot take place because the countries of origin do not agree to recognize their nationals as such. Finally, the report recommends the use of public-private partnerships in developing countries, which raises many concerns, particularly about the additional debt induced. For these reasons the vote is therefore negative.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is the world's largest donor of development aid, accounting for almost 60 % of public aid for development globally, and bearing in view of the current year is key to global development efforts, with the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and an agreement on global action against climate change , valid until 2030. The importance of the challenge of financing the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) requires a strong and comprehensive partnership and the use of all forms of funding (national, international, public, private and innovative resources) and non-financial means; private funding can complement, but not replace, public funding. I am voting in favour of considering that the European Union and its Member States, as major donors of development aid, should conduct the development finance process and contribute to a credible response to the challenges in this area, ensuring policy coherence for development under the post-2015 Agenda; and that other developing and emerging countries should follow the EXAMPLE of the EU.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This non-binding resolution is an alignment of good feelings. The rapporteur deplores the fact that 1.5 billion people live in the greatest poverty and plans to eradicate poverty...  To do so, it wants to urge EU Member States to meet their public development aid targets (up to 0.7% of GNI).  If we can only support the development of the poorest countries, including through subsidies, it must not be a "money laundering operation" of the EU in its promotion to the point of "happy globalisation". The extreme poverty in these countries cannot be deplored by casting a modest veil on the source of this situation.  In addition, the report calls for fostering public-private partnerships that would only worsen the situation, as well as mixed financing, which could lead to a debt bubble. Finally, it highlights the positive contribution of immigrants to countries of origin, which increase financial flows...  For these reasons I decided to vote against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Labour has led the way for a progressive development policy to tackle poverty and inequality across the world. The Labour Party’s efforts led to a UK law to commit 0.7% of national income (GNI) to Official Development Assistance (ODA). Now is the time for other governments to commit, and for a strong new agenda to mobilise a range of finance to make the new Sustainable Development Goals a reality and end extreme poverty by 2030.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which calls on Member States and other developed countries to maintain or increase their level of official development assistance. The aim is to help reduce global poverty by working for economic and social development and good governance, especially in fragile and conflict-ridred states. Over the period 2014-2020, the EU's contribution to development funding will amount to 19.7 billion euros for cooperation, 6.8 billion euros for humanitarian aid, plus 2.2 billion euros from the emergency aid reserve and a contribution from the European Development Fund (EDF) of 30.5 billion euros. Only the establishment of conditions conducive to the personal and collective development of people in their countries of origin will avoid tragedies such as those experienced by migrants who try to cross the Mediterranean and die at sea, kept in false hope of a better future in the European Union.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Report on Financing for Development, which calls for an ambitious global partnership as a condition for achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). EU Member States must meet their 2005 commitment to spend 0.7% of their national income on official development assistance and set a timetable to meet this target by 2020. Moreover, it is not enough to give money, it is necessary to mobilize resources effectively in developing countries. The report calls for an extension of the European Commission's scope of action to help build the capacity of the tax administration, the management of public finances and the fight against corruption. Finally, as this text mentions, official development assistance will not be able to cover all the financing needs of developing countries, the private sector must engage in these countries and invest more responsibly in them.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the report on development finance because we are convinced that, as the world's largest donor of development aid, the European Union has a duty to play a leading role in financing developing countries. The EU and its Member States have a moral obligation to fulfil their commitments and to allocate 0.7% of gross national income to official development aid, devoting between 0.15% and 0.20% of gross national income to the least developed countries.  It is crucial that the EU leads globally in this area, especially given that the use of public resources is more sustainable and predictable than ex post assistance. Too many countries need more support to introduce sound national systems, and the credit of political and moral influence that the European Union has built in recent years must be used for an effort in this direction. On the other hand, it should not be forgotten that public aid is not sufficient to cover the necessary investments, and it is important that the European Union has a regulatory framework that stimulates transparent and more responsible private investment in developing countries, contributing to the formation of a social conscience in the private sector as well.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report which reiterates the importance of financing development policies. As an MEP, a member of the ACP Delegation, as well as a academic specialising in development cooperation, I consider it absolutely vital to reform the system of financing development assistance. This requires a concentration of resources on key areas of development, such as education, health, nutrition and infrastructure, but also an efficiency of expenditure through a correlation of actions carried out by the EU and the Member States.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ Is iomaí rud dearfach atá le fáil sa tuarascáil seo, cosúil leis an tslí a n-iarrtar ar na tíortha is saibhre níos mó airgid a thabhairt don fhorbairt, agus an gá atá ann do níos mó soiléireachta laistigh de Bhuiséad na hEorpa maidir le maoiniú don fhorbairt. Ba chóir fáilte a chur roimh na rudaí seo. É sin ráite, an rud is tábhachtaí faoi i mo thuairimse ná go bhfuil béim faoi leith curtha ar mhná agus ar an mbaint thábhachtach atá acu leis an bhforbairt. Tugann an tuarascáil seo tacaíocht don chomhionannas inscne. Cuireann sé togra chun tosaigh a iarrann go mbeadh an comhionannas inscne i gcroílár gníomhaíochtaí forbartha. Is é sin béim faoi leith a chur ar infheistíocht i réimsí tábhachtacha cosúil le sláinte agus oideachas mar shampla.  Déantar tagairt freisin don aird ba chóir a dhíriú ar shláinte gnéis agus atáirgthe. Cludaíonn sé seo réimse leathan rudaí cosúil le cúram réamhbhreithe agus iarbhreithe, frithghiniúint agus galair ghnéas-tarchurtha – rudaí atá thar a bheith tábhachtach.  Mar gheall ar na rudaí thuasluaite chaith mé vóta i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Mr Pereira's report as I support the need for a stronger EU position in the upcoming international conferences on ODA, starting with the one in Addis Ababa. The current world economic situation is one of major discrepancies, and investing in development can lead to horizontal prosperity, increased trade, reduction in countless risk factors (security, migrants, poverty-fuelled extremism etc.), but we need to assume leadership here, as before. All Member States need to understand this and to prioritise their budgets accordingly so we can literally put our money where our words are.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The participation of the European Union and its Member States in humanitarian and development aid plays an important role in ensuring the living conditions of 1.5 billion people living in extreme poverty, maintaining international stability and promoting development on a global scale. In my view, it is particularly important that these aid should focus on eradicating poverty and ensuring basic public services such as education, health care, water and energy supplies. I consider it essential that the conditions for aid create favourable conditions for private companies and participation in development and build on the contribution of the civil sector.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. Investment in development would be good investment in peace and stability. In recent years, however, it has become clear that funding has often been ineffective. We need a greater sense of responsibility, not only for the sake of the countries in need, but also out of respect for our taxpayers. The report calls on the Member States to increase development aid, but lacks a clear strategy and traceability of which project money is being spent on. Furthermore, it is also incomprehensible whether financial resources have also been used wisely. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report sets out a European Union position for the International Conference on Financing for Development, to be held in Ethiopia in July 2015, which aims to prepare the agenda for post-2015 sustainable development.  The report calls on the EU to meet its investment and development aid commitments (at least 0.7% of GNI). The report supports measures such as taxes on financial transactions to finance development, condemns tax havens and emphasizes the role of civil society. Amendments from my group have also been adopted, notably on taxation or the place of women. I voted in favour of this report, which I thought was a good move.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The report gives an overview of the state of EU development aid. It considers, among other things, that the EU and its Member States should immediately re-commit themselves to the target of allocating 0.7% of GNI to OFFICIAL DEVELOPMENT, as well as the involvement of civil society, increasing funding for combating climate change and much more. Given that 1.5 billion people still live in poverty and in poor health, education and living standards, especially in conflict-affected and fragile countries, this situation is unacceptable because there are sufficient resources in the world to phase out this situation.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report submitted.  The EU is the world's 30-year donor of development aid. It is therefore essential that clear and transparent data on all budgetary resources allocated to EU development aid are kept clear and transparent.  It should be noted that the financing of the SDGs is a major challenge. In this context, greater attention must be paid to the global partnership. In addition, the use of all forms of financing and non-financial instruments should be encouraged. It should be noted that private funding can complement public funding, but in no case can it replace it.  Clear priorities for expenditure are essential to achieve the objectives set. I believe that the EU's strong commitment to focus more on the quantity and quality of development aid should also serve as an example to other public and private supporters who must keep their financial promises.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that 2015 is a key year for global development efforts, with the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDOs) and an agreement on global climate action, both valid until 2030; that 1.5 billion people are still living in poverty, suffering health, education and living standards, especially in fragile and conflict-affected states; that this is not acceptable, since there are sufficient resources, worldwide, to put an end to this situation gradually; that, as recognised by the 2005 European Consensus on Development, there can be no sustainable development without peace and security; I voted in favour.

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted 'for', because I believe that the European Union has and must assume responsibilities beyond its borders. Effective aid to countries on the EU border and not only helps to improve living standards for people living in those countries (and can lead to the avoidance of new waves of migrants to the EU).  The granting of any funding is and must, in my opinion, be conditional on the request and implementation, in the beneficiary States, of minimum standards which correspond to both European rules and values and give guarantees that the amounts received are used efficiently for the benefit of the people.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this development funding report because it aims to eradicate poverty and foster sustainable development. The role of the European Parliament is crucial in achieving sustainable development goals, but the economic situation and the competence of Member States must be taken into account when setting deadlines for the realisation of these objectives. All countries that can, should allocate resources and fight poverty. But funding in itself is not enough, but we need policies that will lead to the effective spending of money. The continuing tragedies in the Mediterranean warn us precisely that the help we are allocating is not directed in the best way and that this needs to be changed.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. This report suggests between the lines that development aid funds are not sufficiently controlled. Moreover, it advocates a perverse conception of development: in fact, it must not come from money sent by expatriates who send money back to the country or by public-private partnerships with Western companies that will further indebted developing countries. It is clear that these countries must create wealth themselves, as do the States of the European Union, which should finally have re-industrialisation policies to ensure growth and employment. The inability of the European institutions to understand how to create wealth is once again visible both inside and outside. In these circumstances, I am speaking out against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ 2012 is a crucial year for global development efforts due to the adoption of the SDGs and global climate action agreements, which will be in place by 2030. Also, the Third International Development Financing Conference, to be held in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, on 13-16 July 2015, should create the conditions for funding programmes for the post-2015 period. Statistics show that 1.5 billion people live in poverty. They are deprived of health, education and living standards, especially in countries affected by conflicts and fragile states. Eradicating inequalities can only be achieved by mobilising adequate resources and better targeting marginalised groups, such as children, the elderly or people with disabilities. The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) estimates that developing countries' financial needs for the new SDGs are approximately USD 3.9 trillion per year and that $2.5 trillion is currently missing annually, as ultimately the cost of sustainable development will be significantly higher. Such a challenge of financing the SDGs requires a strong and global partnership and the use of all forms of funding due to its scope, but it should be borne in mind that private funding can complement but not replace public funding. For these reasons, I give my full support to my colleague Pereira's report.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support MeP Pedro Silva Pereira's Development Finance Report, which is a crucial year in 2015 to create the conditions for funding and implementation of programmes globally. Taking into account the fact that a very small part of developed countries fulfil their commitment to allocate 0.7 % of gross national income to help 1 least developed countries, I consider this Report to play an exceptional role. I welcome that the EU is the main and largest donor of development aid. The EU should preserve this position while fostering shared responsibility in terms of encouraging developed countries to fulfil and make significant commitments. I also welcome the EP's call for Member States to convince public and private donors globally to help underdeveloped countries develop them, and one of the most important and primary objectives is the eventual eradication of poverty. An important fact is to emphasize the fight against tax evasion, which is one of the important items that reduces development aid and contributes to the development of debts of individual countries. Mobilisation of domestic resources should be one of the key sources of funding. The elimination of harmful subsidies in the fields of energy, fisheries and agriculture, as well as the importance of establishing favourable conditions in private entrepreneurship, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises that play a major role in the creation of new jobs, I also find very useful for Croatia.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am very glad that the vote has shown that the European Parliament is not reluctant to take its responsibilities towards the international community and, more specifically, developing countries. I supported this resolution because the forthcoming Addis Ababa Conference calls for a firm position for the European Union and its Member States. In particular, these need to be recalled for the objectives already committed in 2005 under ODA, which are currently met by only four Member States. Without development aid, we will not be able to find solutions to problems such as poverty, climate change, terrorism, as well as very current migratory pressures. Development aid cannot therefore be omitted. On the contrary, it must become more effective and we must ensure that it is best coordinated. If we fail to secure the necessary funding and negotiate a new framework for development goals, we will never be able to stop thousands of refugees risking their own lives to reach Europe.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is the world's leading donor of development aid. I believe, however, that it is increasingly important to have a holistic and integrated approach to long-term financing, ensuring that the EU is a leader in establishing a framework for sustainable development to be structured together with other actors such as the United Nations. All countries must commit themselves, including high-income, middle-to-high-income countries and also emerging economies, so as to share responsibilities, each in proportion to their own means, with the common objective of poverty eradication and sustainable development.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In preparation for the development finance conference in Addis Ababa in July, the European Parliament has adopted a report outlining the eu's modalities, means and opportunities for financing development. In particular, it stresses the importance of fighting poverty, defending human rights and encouraging access to education for the people concerned. I voted in favour of this text and support the union's role as a key contributor to international development.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. 2015 is a key year for global development efforts, with the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and an agreement on global action against climate change, valid until 2030. The third International Conference on Financing for Development, to be held in Alseababa (Ethiopia) from 13 to 16 July 2015, should therefore create the conditions for the financing and implementation of the post-2015 Agenda. In fact, 1.5 billion people are still living in poverty, with shortages in health, education and living conditions, particularly in fragile conflict-sour states.  This resolution considers that the EU and its Member States, as major donors of development aid, should conduct the development finance process and contribute to a credible response to development policy challenges under the post-2015 Agenda. The resolution also calls for the adoption of an international initiative to improve the quality of statistics, data and information in order to monitor expenditure, investment and progress on specific commitments and objectives. I voted in favour.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. 2012 0.7% of gross national income, a symbolic figure, a reasonable figure to help the countries of the South to develop and, yet, a figure still unattainable for 24 of the 28 Member States. In the light of the North-South imbalances, the unprecedented regional conflicts and the massive influx of refugees as a direct result, the 28 capitals would have a strong interest in meeting their commitment in 2005.  A target defined 45 years ago that has the full support of European citizens, to the tune of 85%, according to a Eurobarometer published in January 2015. This is another reason for the EU to spend 0.7% of national income on official development assistance, especially since 1.5 billion people still live in the greatest poverty. That is the message that the European Parliament has sent today by its vote.  Of course, other sources of funding, particularly private, will also be needed to achieve the new Sustainable Development Goals. However, public and private funding do not have the same roles and impact. And that is the major challenge we face: ensuring the best possible synergy between these different sources of funding.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which sets out the post-2015 guidelines for development finance, of which the European Union is the world's largest creditor. Overall, at the International Conference on Financing for Development, we support the proposals put forward by the Commission in its communication on the global partnership for poverty eradication and sustainable development after 2015. We also call for coordination of development assistance with the fight against climate change. Finally, we stress the importance of improving monitoring of global development financing to prevent misappropriation.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I congratulate and support this report for its approach to poverty eradication, human rights and gender equality. This approach can help to renew the hope of 1.5 billion people living in extreme poverty, with health and education needs. The Report on Development Finance does not solve everything, but it is a start to a new development model based on universality. We can't compartmentalized interests. The world's problems concern everyone.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. This report nurtures the EU's position for the Third International Conference on Financing for Development, to be held from 13 to 16 July in Addis Ababa. We call for the greatest degree of political and economic ambition for the construction of the new development framework, betting on creating the necessary conditions for the financing and implementation of the agenda for after 2015. 2015 is a crucial year in which the Sustainable Development Goals and the agreement on global action against climate change are to be adopted. The main objective is to eradicate poverty suffered by 1.5 billion people, as well as to reduce inequalities and promote sustainable development. This can only be achieved by mobilizing sufficient and adequate resources. We call on the EU and its Member States to recommit to the 0.7% GNI target for ODO, rebooking at least 50% of their ODO and 0.2% of GNI for the least developed countries, as well as adopting multiannual budget timetables for the increase in ODO by 2020. On these main issues, among others raised in the report, I voted in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. 2015 is a crucial year for global development assistance with the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals and an agreement on global climate action. I voted in favour of this report, which points out that the European Union is the world's largest donor of development aid and that this aid accounts for almost 60% of official development aid worldwide. This report also asks, and I welcome this, the European Union and its Member States to immediately reformulate their commitment to spend 0.7% of GNI on official development assistance, with 50% of development aid and at least 0.2% of GNI earmarked for the least developed countries.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to abstain from voting on the report presented by Mr De Clercq. Silva Pereira on financing development. The reasons for my choice depend on a proposed amendment concerning sexual and reproduction rights, an issue which, in my opinion, is not consistent with a development report.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because the text, although not particularly innovative, contains mostly acceptable references to the Sustainable Development Goals in poor countries through development funding.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report because it contains very positive elements in terms of financing for development. The report calls for strengthening the mobilization of domestic resources through the promotion of fair tax systems and the fight against tax evasion and illicit capital flows. The report also recognises the importance of developing a multilateral framework for sovereign debt restructuring based on responsible lending principles, and calls on Member States and the European Commission to contribute positively to the UN working group on this issue. In addition, the report uses very positive language in relation to gender equality and women's rights.

name: György Schöpflin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The third development finance conference will be held in Addis Ababa in July 2015. The conference brings together high-level political representatives, international actors, representatives of non-governmental actors and business players. It aims to decide on the level of money for international development and to support the implementation of the post-2015 EU and global development framework, including the SDGs, which are scheduled to be adopted in New York in September 2015. The aim of the report is to develop an international partnership to finance development, which effectively supports the aforementioned objectives. The report highlights the European Union's leadership in international development and stresses the importance of shared responsibility and calls on growing and middle-income countries to make significant commitments.  The report urges the European Union to immediately re-commit to the 0.7 percent GNI target for Official Development Assistance (ODA). At least 50 per cent of official development assistance and at least 0.2 per cent of GNI reserved for the least developed countries and taking budgetary constraints into account. These objectives are in line with the direction pursued by the Fidesz-KDNP, in particular with regard to the settlement of the issue of migration. That's why I voted in favour.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it reflects positive aspects such as the requirement that the commitment to allocate 0.7% of GDP to development cooperation be fulfilled, it advocates strengthening public-private partnership in financing for development.  This report calls for the implementation in cooperation for the development of neoliberal policies in the EU, i.e. making public resources available to the private sector for the benefit of the private sector, protecting its investments and demanding reforms consisting of liberalization.     I believe that the pursuit of profit by multinationals is incompatible with sustainable development based on social justice, a development that requires that the basic pillars for the well-being of populations, such as education, health or the right to housing, be public services guaranteed by States, which are the only actors capable of ensuring their universality , quality and free.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on development funding. It is important for the EU to have a global leadership role in promoting well-being in the less fortunate countries by seeking to achieve the ambitious target of transferring 0.7% of gross national income for development aid (ODA) by 2020, taking into account each state's budgetary limits.  I also appreciated the EU's firm position on the need to invite other developed partners, emerging countries and private donors from all over the world to increase their contribution and commitment as well.  Finally, in order to implement effective monitoring and control of development investments as well as progress in implementing specific commitments and objectives, I expect clear, transparent and accessible reporting instruments for aid programmes to be provided in subsequent agreements in order to prevent cases of corruption and mismanagement.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour has led the way for a progressive development policy to tackle poverty and inequality across the world. The Labour Party’s efforts led to a UK law to commit 0.7% of national income (GNI) to Official Development Assistance (ODA). Now is the time for other governments to commit, and for a strong new agenda to mobilise a range of finance to make the new Sustainable Development goals a reality and end extreme poverty by 2030.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – I consider EU development aid to be an investment that has become a very good tool for financing the development of less developed countries. In particular, I very much appreciate the fact that, in supporting developing countries, this share represents 60% of global official development assistance, which clearly ranks the EU among the largest and most singest donors of aid in the world. The EU and its Member States should maintain their status as major donors of development aid, thereby confirming for the future the EU's unchanging attitude and responsibility for the further development of less developed countries. I also support the resolution because it sends out important messages that can help ensure the inclusive growth and sustainable development of partner countries. I believe that this report will be a good signal to the citizens of Europe and will become a key factor in eradicating poverty and inequality. As not all developed countries fulfil their commitment to provide 0.7% of gross national income for official development assistance, I expect that development aid will improve its delivery and ensure higher quality in the next period.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \ 2012 The year 2015 is crucial for global development thanks to the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals and the Global Climate Action Agreement.  1.5 billion people still live in poverty, facing a lack of health, education and living standards. There are enough resources in the world to improve this situation. The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development estimates that developing countries' funding needs for the SDGs amount to approximately USD 3.9 billion per year and currently short of USD 2.5 billion per year. The cost of inaction will be significantly higher than the cost of decisive action for sustainable development. The development agenda is becoming ever wider and action beyond official development assistance should be encouraged by mobilising domestic resources and using innovative financial instruments. The potential of developing countries to mobilise domestic resources is considerable, as it is more predictable and sustainable than foreign aid, and must therefore be a key source of funding.  Public aid and domestic resources are not enough to cover all investment needs, and it is therefore also important to combine public and private funds that pursue sustainable and long-term objectives in the economic, social and environmental spheres. Since this report can serve as a financial pillar for achieving the objectives of the Post-2015 Development Agenda, I voted to support it.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU is the largest donor of development aid in the world. As the EU's share accounts for almost 60% of global ODA, it is important that the Commission provides clear and transparent data on the share of EU budget resources for development aid. Furthermore, the Commission should seek to make EU aid in developing countries more visible and appropriate and targeted communication and information tools should therefore be developed to make EU development aid more visible.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this Development Finance Report because I share the European Parliament's position on achieving the SDGs. While I believe that the EU and its members should continue to be major donors of development aid and foster shared responsibility, I appeal in particular to high-income countries, middle-income countries and the emerging economy to make their commitments as well and increase their share of development aid. It is also necessary to involve the private sector in financing sustainable development.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am proud of the UK Labour Party’s efforts in promoting a progressive development policy to tackle poverty and inequality across the world. Therefore, I strongly supported this report which urges the rest of the Union to take similar action. By mobilising a range of finance, Member States can make the new Sustainable Development Goals a reality and end extreme poverty by 2030.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this report because 2015 is a crucial year for the adoption of the SDGs and global action against climate change agreements to be in place by 2030. and that the Third International Conference on Financing for Development, to be held in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, from 13-16 July 2015, should create the conditions necessary to finance and implement the post-2015 programme, 1.5 billion people continue to live in poverty and are deprived of health, education and living standards, especially in fragile and conflict-affected countries. I therefore welcome the commission's latest and comprehensive Communication entitled 'Global Partnership for Poverty Eradication and Sustainable Development After 2015', as poverty eradication and inequality can only be achieved by mobilising sufficient and adequate resources. As the largest donors of development aid (the share accounts for almost 60 % of the world's official development assistance), the EU and the Member States must lead the process of financing development and help to find a reliable response to the challenges this funding brings and should preserve their position as a major donor, ensuring coherence of development policies under the post-2015 programme.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because I strongly disagree with the call on Member States to meet the target of allocation of 0.7% of their economy's gross national income to development aid. European Union development aid is significantly less effective than development aid from EU Member States and lacks a basic degree of self-reflection, as it is increasing despite its constant failures.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on financing development and finding new measures to eliminate poverty. The European Union is built on the foundations of solidarity and must continue to be the world's largest donor of development aid. The 1.5 billion people still living in poverty is unacceptable. Migrants and refugees are dying en masse in the Mediterranean. Many of these tragedies and deaths could have been prevented if people in their countries had more hope and chance of a better life. I therefore welcome the specific chapter in the report on the mobilisation of domestic resources and on international tax cooperation. I agree that domestic resources are more predictable and sustainable than foreign aid, and we therefore need, inter alia, to improve the collection of domestic taxes in developing countries, and the Commission must improve its assistance to these countries in capacity-building in the areas of tax administration and public financial management.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The issue of overcoming the crisis and creating growth is one of the most important issues. The neoliberal policies of harsh austerity, which deepen the recession, must end immediately. Although the Commission's report reinforces these measures, this is not the case with Parliament's report. The report stresses the importance of public funding, as well as the need for a fair redistribution of domestic resources and in particular the benefits of natural resources. It emphasises the financing system, rejecting lending as a means of development aid. Finally, it is very positive that it welcomes international efforts to exempt Ebola-affected countries from their international loan obligations. For the above reasons we voted in favour of the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The same people who led us to the economic crisis, the same people who are diving into third world countries to serve their interests are the ones who now claim to save us using of course the same means and methods that are proven to fail, except perhaps the possibility they offer the rich to become even richer and permanently faithful to their ideologies that are destroying modern Western societies.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the report is to develop an international partnership to finance development, effectively supporting the implementation of the post-2015 EU and global development framework, including the SDGs. The report highlights the European Union's leadership in international development and stresses the importance of shared responsibility and calls on rising and middle-income countries to make significant commitments. These objectives are in line with the direction pursued by the Fidesz-KDNP, in particular with regard to the settlement of the issue of migration. That's why I voted in favour.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. It urges the European Union to affirm its leading political role as it prepares to establish a sustainable development framework, a renewed agreement on development financing and other modalities of implementation, in line with the commitments and values enshrined in its founding treaties. We believe that the conditions for the provision of EU development aid should not be dictated by other donor partners.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution urging the EU and the Member States to respect their commitments in the development sector. Today, the EU is the world’s largest donor of official development aid. This gives responsibility for the EU in the negotiations to be held at the Third International Conference on Financing for Development in Addis Ababa. With this resolution, the European Parliament has sent a strong signal and demonstrated its total and full involvement in development policy across the world.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. 2015 is part of a unique year of international negotiations on development and sustainable development (3rd International Conference on Financing for Development in July, adoption of the new International Sustainable Development Goals in September, and COP 21 in December). Pedro Silva Pereira's report is the European Parliament's contribution to the European Union's position on official development assistance (ODA). It follows the debate that took place during the April plenary on member states' commitments on this issue. It also largely reflects the progressive values I stand for. Indeed, these three events are inseparable. The success of COP 21 in Paris will depend on the outcome of those who precede it. Above all, the commitments of developed countries - and therefore the EU - in terms of ODA, are one of the issues in the run-up to these three conferences. For there will be no binding and ambitious climate agreement in Paris without commitments from developed countries on ODA. In everyone's opinion, the issue of investment will be crucial in persuading the countries of the South to take their full part in the fight against global warming.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ When it comes to investing in developing countries, private sector roles, providing assistance as well as better coordination of different mechanisms are a key driver of growth and development. In my view, effective support for the development of a particular community can come primarily from a local level, which puts at the forefront the importance of supporting micro and small and medium-sized enterprises. Once again, I take the opportunity to highlight the need for transparency when it comes to the financing of projects by the Union, but also the transparency of the national part in their financing. I support the provisions of the Report which focus on fairer tax systems. Tax levies need to be more purposeful and sensitive to vulnerable groups in society. I think it is important to promote effective, balanced and stimulating tax systems so that the financial system can ultimately be directed towards supporting sustainable development, the thus creating the conditions for the implementation and financing of programmes in less developed countries. I voted for the Report because I believe that developing countries need outside assistance so that they can mobilise their national funds and achieve the SDGs.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. – I supported the report of the Committee on Development (DEVE), which calls for a global funding partnership, which is a prerequisite for achieving the new Sustainable Development Goals. Despite the need for shared responsibility, the European Union (EU) still has a leading role. In addition to other aspects, the report calls for a renewed commitment by the EU and its members to 0.7% development assistance (ODA), half of which should be allocated to the worst developed countries.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report as it contains very positive development funding elements. The report calls for strengthening the mobilization of domestic resources through the promotion of fair tax systems and the fight against tax evasion and illicit capital flows. The report also recognises the importance of developing a multilateral framework for sovereign debt restructuring based on responsible lending principles, and calls on Member States and the European Commission to contribute positively to the UN working group on this issue. In addition, the report uses very positive language in relation to gender equality and women's rights.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome and support this resolution. 1.5 billion people are still living in poverty with deprivation in health, education and living standards, notably in conflict-affected and fragile states; whereas this is not acceptable, given that sufficient resources exist in the world to progressively end this situation. Eradication of poverty and inequality can only be achieved through mobilisation of sufficient and appropriate resources for all, and the better targeting of marginalised groups, such as children, women, the elderly or persons with disabilities; whereas despite a significant reduction in extreme poverty, progress for children has been slower, making the need for investing in children – both through domestic resource mobilisation and international public financing – a key factor; Let me recall that unfortunately, few developed countries are fulfilling their commitment of providing 0.7 % of Gross National Income (GNI) as ODA, including 0.15-0.20 % of GNI to Least Developed Countries (LDCs); whereas the Member States which joined the EU in 2004 or later have committed to strive towards the target of 0.33 % of GNI, but none of them has yet reached this target. The time has now come to act and deliver!

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. This report is a half-admission of the absence of any control over the use of these funds, a finding denounced by the National Front since always. It highlights the positive contribution of migrants to the development of their countries of origin, which is staggering. They would contribute to the growth of financial flows between diasporas and countries of origin. The report supports the creation of funds for these diasporas and calls for additional efforts to reduce the costs of transferring capital as well as improving their effect on local development in countries of origin. The report also recommends that public-private partnerships, which are capable of providing these services, which are predominantly Western companies, should be used as a development lever for developing countries. The Committee on Budgets warns that these joint financings could lead to a debt bubble, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa and the Caribbean. If we want to fight immigration and promote the stability of continents as well as their autonomy, we should simply do the opposite.  I am, of course, opposed to this text.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report because it contains very positive elements in terms of financing for development. The report calls for strengthening the mobilization of domestic resources through the promotion of fair tax systems and the fight against tax evasion and illicit capital flows. The report also recognises the importance of developing a multilateral framework for sovereign debt restructuring based on responsible lending principles, and calls on Member States and the European Commission to contribute positively to the UN working group on this issue. In addition, the report uses very positive language in relation to gender equality and women's rights.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution concerning the Financing for Development. I find that it is vital that we, the representatives of the European citizens’, actively support and acknowledge the importance of financing developing countries. One of the main aims of the European Union is to promote economic and social progress and this is what the resolution ‘Financing for Development’ offers us to continue doing.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a key report to define the EU's position for the mid-July development finance conference in Addis Ababa. It is important to vote in favour of a report like this, geared towards ambitious targets for the EU in this area.

name: n/a
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it reflects positive aspects such as the requirement that the commitment to allocate 0.7% of GDP to development cooperation be fulfilled, it advocates strengthening public-private partnership in financing for development. This report calls for the implementation in cooperation for the development of neoliberal policies in the EU, i.e. making public resources available to the private sector for the benefit of the private sector, protecting its investments and demanding reforms consisting of liberalization. I believe that the pursuit of profit by multinationals is incompatible with sustainable development based on social justice, a development that requires that the basic pillars for the well-being of populations, such as education, health or the right to housing, be public services guaranteed by States, which are the only actors capable of ensuring their universality , quality and free. Faced with the commitment to private investments of multinational companies in key sectors and services for the development and well-being of people, I defend another model of cooperation based on the financing and strengthening of public-public partnerships.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because Labour has led the way for a progressive development policy to tackle poverty and inequality across the world. The Labour Party’s efforts led to a UK law to commit 0.7% of national income (GNI) to Official Development Assistance (ODA). Now is the time for other governments to commit, and for a strong new agenda to mobilise a range of finance to make the new Sustainable Development Goals a reality and end extreme poverty by 2030.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report provides an update on the financing of development aid in the European Union, on the implementation of the post-2015 development goals. The report reminds Member States of the commitment made in 2005 to increase their official development assistance (ODA) to 0.7% of gross national income (GNI). This target was to be achieved by 2015. At the end of 2014, the average commitment of Member States is only 0.47 per cent of GNI. Only five countries in the world have fulfilled this commitment, including four members of the European Union: Sweden, Denmark, the Netherlands and Luxembourg. This report condemns tax havens and tax evasion and calls for investment in key areas such as education and health, including the importance of sexual and reproductive rights despite the efforts of the right of the Chamber. These reminders are salutary, so I voted for this resolution, although I have no illusions about its impact, especially in France, a country that is constantly reducing its development aid, including in the poorest countries. At a time when the EU is making this issue one of the pillars of its migration policy, it is important to recall the hypocrisy of the Member States.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We endorse the pious intentions of this report. However, a very critical reading of the current situation is required. The millennium goals are far from achieving the goals. The contributions of rich states fall far short of all commitments. That's how it's been for decades, and it's important to understand why. The reason lies in the oppressive nature of the explorer of capitalism. While pretending to be humanist principles, it exploits developing countries, corrupts governments and does not hesitate to resort to force to defend the interests of large multinationals. In this way, we are witnessing the destruction of schools built with funds from international assistance, and we do not see a minimum of openness to contribute to solutions that guarantee the poorest countries the right to sovereign and autonomous development. It's all conditionality, greed and interest. Tax evasion and evasion promoted by multinational companies operating in developing countries exceeds international aid. Words for what...

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I am opposed to the report on financing for development, because I do not consider development aid in its current form to be useful or efficient, and I do not believe that it will achieve the desired objectives. In addition, massive misallocations often occur, for example through corruption.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I am a member of Labour Campaign for International Development (LCID) and Labour has led the way for a progressive development policy to tackle poverty and inequality across the world. The Labour Party’s efforts led to a UK law to commit 0.7% of national income (GNI) to Official Development Assistance (ODA). Now is the time for other governments to commit, and for a strong new agenda to mobilise a range of finance to make the new Sustainable Development Goals a reality and end extreme poverty by 2030.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I too supported the motion for a resolution on financing development. The EU is the world's largest donor of development aid and provides almost 60% of official global development aid. We should all intensify our efforts so that this action can bring even better results and be properly promoted internationally.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the own-initiative report on financing development. This report is the European Parliament's contribution to the EU's position in the run-up to the high-level conference on development finance to be held next July in Addis Ababa. I believe that the European Union and the Member States should continue to be the main donors of development aid, but at the same time they should push for shared responsibility, calling on high-income countries and emerging economies to make equally significant commitments. I will conclude by recalling the need to develop, at international level, a reliable and transparent regulatory framework to stimulate investment and contribute to the growth of a socially conscious private sector in developing countries.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I abstained from voting on this report. Development is fundamental, especially from the point of view of the poorest countries. International investment, education and civil society building, fair distribution of goods, health, fair trade relations are all conducive to development and should be supported. The European Union has an important role to play here, as do other international organisations.  However, when we talk about economic development, we must not lose sight of social and ethical issues. An ideology that infects every aspect of politics is also insuched here. Combining the issue of development with human sexuality is just such a negative manifestation of the influence of ideology. It not only gives rise to a general picture of the problem and distracts attention from the real causes of the current situation of third world countries, but also creates a false cause-and-effect link between abortion and economic development. This reasoning is wrong. Development detached from humanism and human rights never leads to lasting success. The right to life is undoubtedly a human right and should be strictly protected. Development detached from humanism and human rights never leads to lasting success. The right to life is undoubtedly a human right and should be strictly protected.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The approach to financing the development of development in this report ignores the framework of asymmetric interdependence relationships typical of globalized capitalism, which generate sunequal development on a global scale. With economic inequality comes political dependence and subordination. There are several instruments that promoter the vicious circle of impoverishment, dependence and subordination. This is the case of foreign debt. On several occasions paid and nevertheless ever increasing, there will be no serious and effective development cooperation policy without addressing this issue or without the essential cancellation of this debt and the mechanisms that underpin it. This issue is simply ignored by the report. As are also the devastating effects of the interventions of the IMF and the World Bank – promoters of the drainage of endogenous resources to said donors, resources that go beyond the amounts of Official Development Assistance.  Official Development Assistance (ODA) is crucial and should increase, even in accordance with commitments made but not fulfilled. We value what the report refers to in this regard. But just as ODA alone (even at desirable levels) is not enough, so this positive aspect of the report is not enough to make it a good report.

name: Jens Rohde (ALDE).
text: Madam President! Thank you very much and excuse my inattention. One of the major challenges we face in Europe is to ensure that we have more entrepreneurs and that we get to start teaching also about entrepreneurship in our education systems. With this in mind, to support that work, it is important to point out that we have Erasmus for young entrepreneurs that Member States can use.  In addition, if we are to support entrepreneurship in Europe, it is also important that we in the Member States should not be able to over-implement a large number of the EU initiatives that are coming and that the Member States themselves take the initiative to remove unnecessary or ineffective regulations that constitute market barriers. Of course, we must also ensure the consistent transposition of directives into national law, so that we have equal competition. It is indeed equal competition that ensures the best opportunities for our entrepreneurs, and that is what should animate young people to start doing business themselves.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, we voted in favour of the report on safer health care in Europe because it calls for the protection of citizens from health cuts, ensuring sufficient numbers of professionals. Let me draw attention to the health situation in my country, in Spain, until recently, one of the most effective health systems in the world. The policies carried out in my country by the People's Party have contributed to the degradation of health through privatizations in the management of health services and through cuts. Degradation has been especially aggressive in regions such as the Valencian Community or the Community of Madrid. Let me remind you, ladies and gentlemen, that the European project was based on an idea of democracy linked to social rights and public services. Those who degrade health not only degrade democracy, but also degrade the European project.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I supported the report on safer healthcare in Europe. It is of concern that around 10% of patients admitted to hospitals in the EU suffer from adverse events while receiving healthcare. At the same time we have to recognise that antibiotic resistance is growing. This means that about 4.1 million people are suffering from healthcare-related illness, which causes huge personal distress and also a significant cost. The good news is that 30% of these illnesses can be avoided and the EU can play a crucial role in helping us achieve this, alleviating the burden placed on national health systems, which are already ailing in many EU Member States, not least the UK. I therefore call on the Commission to promote the development of new antibiotics and regulate their use. Above all, it is crucial to realise that diseases do not stop at borders. Here the EU has the ability to achieve results that the single Member State cannot. So we have to ask the Commission to fully exploit this potential by developing initiatives to ensure better monitoring and data collection for healthcare-associated infections.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – I am convinced that this is one of the most important reports in this session. Antibiotic resistance poses an increasing threat, and it is therefore necessary for us to invest our time and resources in this area. Otherwise, we will have irreversible consequences. Antibiotics are not food or supplements, although it is clear that not everyone perceives it. I fully support the need to phase out the prophylactic use of antibiotics in animal husbandry, with a greater focus on disease prevention and hygiene. It is unacceptable that more and more animals are infected with antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which puts them at risk of transmitting this bacterium through infected food to consumers. It is necessary to support information campaigns aimed at farmers. I also believe that the sale and distribution of antibiotics to humans must be tightened up. In 2009, for example, in the event of a panic over swine fever in Lithuania, a massive purchase of medicines was launched. People who were not sick were able to buy antibiotics. Another aspect is the packaging of antibiotics.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Madam Presidents, health and pension systems are always a target for the austerity measures proposed by well-known consultants, international monetary institutions and various advisers to national governments. I am committed to rational business but not for savings that would call into question patients' rights and their safety, and that is why I supported this report. In 2012, the European Commission found that patient safety was compromised by austerity measures, including cost-cutting in health services that directly affected the quality of healthcare.  8% to 12% of hospital patients in the EU suffer as a result of the harm done to them in treatment, with hospital infections reaching up to 30% of that number. For example, the practice of issuing medications as therapeutic alternatives that cannot be determined until the end of their effectiveness, excessive or incorrect use of antibiotics, and inadequate implementation of therapies with the harmful consequences of irresponsible use of drugs cause costs of EUR 2.7 billion according to the latest data.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, I voted in favour of the report on safer health care in Europe, because it is complete and adequate. At the same time, I would like to report that in Greece, seven years after the imposition of the AMKA - the social security number by law thirty-six fifty-five-five thousand eight - hundreds of thousands of Greek citizens are illegally deprived of all health care, social benefits and pensions because, for reasons of religious conscience and the protection of their constitutional freedoms, they refuse to receive AMKA. Because they refuse to further number the human person, they are punished and excluded from the health system. Thus, they have to pay out of pocket for medicines, tests, surgeries, even if they have normally paid their insurance obligations. This is a social racism that must stop here and now and, for that reason, I will be intensified my fight here, too, in the European Parliament.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí áthas orm a bheith anseo sa Pharlaimint aréir agus muid ag déanamh díospóireachta ar an ábhar seo agus bhí seans agam labhairt ansin chomh maith. Dar ndóigh, tá na moltaí seo ciallmhar agus feictear é sin sa tslí a vótáil daoine inniu. 637 as 679 a vótáil ina bhfabhar agus mise in éineacht leo. Ach tá rud amháin ann ar mhaith liom a rá. Tá sé tábhachtach, dar ndóigh, má bhíonn daoine breoite nó tinn go ndéanfar gach iarracht iad a leigheas ach ba chóir dúinn níos mó béime a chur ar dhaoine a choimeád sláintiúil ar dtús. Dá bhrí sin níl dóthain béime á cur againn ar chúrsaí spóirt agus gníomhaíocht fhisiciúil go háirithe. Is cinnte gur chóir dúinn i bhfad níos mó infreastruchtúir a bheith againn do dhaoine chun seans a thabhairt dóibh dul ag snámh, dul ag siúl, dul ag rith nó dul ag rothaíocht. Chabhródh sé sin go mór leis an scéal.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I supported the amendment which asked the Commission to consider a legislative framework to encourage the development of new antibiotic drugs. In 2011, 25 000 patients died as a result of infections caused by resistant bacteria in the EU. All countries have significant problems in regard to antimicrobial resistance, including my own country, Ireland. Just six months ago a national group was set up to tackle this issue. Dr Tony Holohan from the Department of Health has said that urgent and immediate action is needed, as we are entering an era when simple infections could again become killer diseases. But what is really shocking is that, according to Dr Tony Cox of the Irish College of General Practitioners, nursing home residents in Ireland are more than twice as likely to be on an antibiotic than in any other European country. There is an urgent need to address this problem of over-prescription of antibiotics in Ireland, particularly for the elderly. Our health information and quality authority needs to take immediate action on this issue of over-prescription of antibiotics, because it is putting the health of the general population, including the elderly, at risk.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report aims to ensure improved patient safety by identifying and correcting health care factors that may pose an added risk to the health of the population. In particular, the report expresses concern about the misuse of certain medicines, such as antibiotics, whether by commercial pressure, insufficient public funding, lack of training or bad practices, against which it requires greater collaboration between States and increased legislative activity. It also criticizes livestock abuses, where indiscriminate use of antibiotics is an attack on public health.  It also recalls the importance of the prevention and good training of medical staff, as well as the good hygienic conditions of hospitals. In this sense, it criticizes the effects of austerity and calls for ensuring good funding of the health system. Since I share many of the report's conclusions and recommendations, I voted in favour.

name: Louis Aliot (NI)
text: In writing. The proposed text was unanimously supported by the ENVI Committee. In particular, it proposes better training of hospital staff, and wants to improve patient safety by encouraging the fight against antimicrobial resistance through a more responsible use of antibiotics in human medicine but also veterinary medicine. This proposal is generally in the right direction and although we regret that the amendments supported by our delegation have not been adopted, my colleagues and I have supported it.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. I welcome in particular that this report has highlighted the very serious issue of antimicrobial resistance, which is on the increase and is having worrying impacts on patients’ health across Europe. It is estimated that 10 million people will die every year in the world by 2050 because of this phenomenon. It is essential that serious efforts be undertaken now to halt the epidemic. This report is a timely reminder for the need for a coordinated approach to fighting antimicrobial resistance, in line with the One Health approach recommended by the World Health Organisation. It is also to be welcomed that the report highlights the negative effects austerity has had on Member States’ healthcare systems.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. A functioning, safe and effective health care is essential. Unfortunately, however, there are many preventable incidents across the EU, particularly in medical treatment. According to the progress report before the Commission, the Member States are on the right track, and in some countries, only in some countries are the austerity policies resulting from the economic crisis. This must be avoided and, despite the economic tense situation, continued to ensure investment, in particular in research into resistance in human and veterinary medicine. Given the importance of improving patient safety and curbing resistance to antimicrobials, I fully support this report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This proposal aims to improve care and, above all, to combat antibiotic resistance. The latter is mainly related to the misuse of these drugs. Antibiotic resistance leads to high mortality, currently 37,000 deaths in the European Union. This text aims to improve the training of hospital staff and to make better use of antibiotics in the medical and veterinary world. These treatments are also used to increase livestock production, although they have been banned in Europe since 2006. We would have liked more sovereignty, especially through border control, which allows for better management of contagions and less austerity, including training of health workers who are suffering from budget cuts. Despite these points of divergence, this text is generally moving in the right direction. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The UK has introduced its own legislation on these issues, which is working well enough.  The concern about harmonisation, other than the obvious subsidiarity issue, is that it could potentially lead to lower standards in the UK – in particular regarding antibiotics in animal feed. Nevertheless, I recognise the issues around antibiotics. The report fails to address some of the structural issues regarding reasons why pharmaceutical companies have done insufficient research in these areas.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it highlights the various factors that compromise patient safety, and which may, in some EU countries, lead to the alarming spread of certain deadly diseases.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to increase patient safety and resistance to bacteria. Healthcare-related infections affect between 8% and 12% of hospital admissions in the EU. According to the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, 1 in 20 hospitalised patients suffer on average in the EU, i.e. 4.1 million patients. over 37,000 people die every year in the EU. It is estimated that 20-30% of these infections can be prevented through intensive hygiene and control programmes. The threat to patient safety stems from austerity measures, which lead to cuts in healthcare costs. I support the proposals set out in continuing training, monitoring and prevention of medical and healthcare services in order to avoid a significant proportion of adverse events. It is also important to establish forms of redress, to assess how the presence of special preparations in the premises where patients are treated is regulated. Patients should focus on the prudent use of available antibiotics and on action at national and international level to limit the movement of patients infected with resistant bacteria.

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Between 8% and 12% of patients admitted to hospitals in the EU suffer from adverse events while receiving healthcare, and nearly half of these events could be avoided. The most common healthcare-related adverse events are healthcare-associated infections (HAIs), medication-related events and complications arising during or after surgical operations. The latest measures put in place by Member States, and especially the progress made by Member States in developing patient safety strategies and reporting and learning systems, are steps in the right direction. However, there is still uneven progress among Member States. With respect to antimicrobial resistance and prevention and control of HAIs, there is the need to call for responsible, well-targeted use of antibiotics in both human and veterinary medicine and global infection control strategies.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report entitled "Safer Health Care in Europe" needs to improve care and, in particular, antibiotic resistance. This phenomenon of antibiotic resistance is increasingly present because it is linked to misuses that are made by self-medication, poor prescribing or non-therapeutic use. Projections predict 10 million deaths per year in 2050 due to antibiotic resistance. To date, antibiotic resistance has killed 37,000 people in the European Union. This text proposes, among other things, to better train hospital staff, to put in place measures adapted to the disparity observed in the States and to make better use, more responsibly, of antibiotics in human medicine but also veterinary medicine.  Several amendments had been tabled by colleagues in my movement, but unfortunately they were not adopted, notably on austerity responsible for budget cuts in hospitals or even more training and recognition of health care workers. I have therefore decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I share the positions supported in Mr Pedicini's report; I believe that the Commission must make efforts to create a European health legislative framework that will increasingly put the citizen at the centre and, at the same time, provide a new impetus for pharmaceutical research aimed above all at developing new antibiotics for human use.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. According to the Eurobarometer, for 50% of Europeans, healthcare can be harmful to patients. 25% said they or their family members had experienced adverse events, and in 46% of these cases patients filed complaints in the period 2009-2014. More than 8% to 12% of patients hospitalized in the EU, some three million people are harmed or adversely transmitted (infections associated with healthcare, nosocomial or not). This report arises in response to the Commission's second assessment report on patient safety, which shows that there is a greater degree of awareness but significant differences persist between Member States in relation to patient safety strategies, their empowerment, the training of professionals and, in general, the prevention and control of nosocomial infections. Member States are requested to act on the sustainability of quality health systems, the development of patient safety strategies, control training and prevention of nosocomial infections or the promotion of research for new antimicrobials. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the theme of patient safety and the fight against drug resistance, in particular antimicrobial resistance. So, today, it is more important than ever to ensure that patient safety, i.e. the right of the patient not to suffer harm from therapeutic treatment, is an essential element of the health care systems. Unfortunately, however, the economic crisis has put increasing pressure on Member States' budgets, affecting patient safety, and many Member States have dramatically reduced the budget and staffing levels of healthcare systems without properly addressing the issue of effectiveness. In addition, the economic crisis has exacerbated the already existing disparities in access to healthcare. It is therefore necessary, first of all, to note that the threat to patient safety is due to austerity measures, which are subject to cuts in healthcare costs. These horizontal cuts directly affect the quality of treatment, which is certainly unacceptable. Thus, the essence of treatment must be the well-being of the patient, so the funds allocated to healthcare systems cannot be allowed to be unjustifiably cared for in order to save. Investment is needed in continuing training, monitoring of medical and healthcare services, early warning systems and prevention in order to avoid a significant proportion of adverse events, including those arising from the use of medicinal products.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Patient safety and the fight against drug resistance, in particular antimicrobial resistance, are not unheard of topics for those involved in the management of health systems. I am convinced that responsible and targeted use of antibiotics in both human and veterinary medicine, as well as global strategies to combat infections and affect all sectors of health (hospitals, long-term care and outpatient facilities), are cornerstones of effective interventions to prevent the selection and transfer of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.  I would like to draw particular attention to the need to ensure that health policies do not fall victim to the cuts resulting from the economic crisis and austerity measures, and that the objective of applying the highest possible standards of patient safety set by the EU is not jeopardised. On behalf of the Fidesz-KDNP faction, I supported the adoption of the report

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ A quality and safe health service is something that should be implied today. Unfortunately, we see from eurobarometer data that as many as 53% of Europeans fear that they could be further harmed during hospital care. This is a devastating figure, and that is partly based shows that 12% of hospitalised patients in the European Union fall victim to inadequate healthcare.  Damage caused by a deficient health service should be seen primarily in terms of protection of the individual, but also as a social problem. For example, doctors often prescribe antibiotics without being sure if they are necessary. Equally, patients are dissatisfied if they come out of the office without a prescription for an antibiotic. In this way, they participate in the development of antibiotic resistance, which is very dangerous in the long run. It is necessary to include patient safety in the education and training of healthcare professionals, and to work on action plans and strategies to combat infections.  In conclusion, I welcome the increasing involvement of Member States in implementing patient safety recommendations. This shows that at the political and professional level there is an increased awareness of the need for systematic work to increase the level of patient safety.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. I welcome in particular that this report has highlighted the very serious issue of antimicrobial resistance, which is on the increase and is having worrying impacts on patients’ health across Europe. It is estimated that 10 million people will die every year in the world by 2050 because of this phenomenon. It is essential that serious efforts be undertaken now to halt the epidemic. This report is a timely reminder for the need for a coordinated approach to fighting antimicrobial resistance, in line with the One Health approach recommended by the World Health Organisation. It is also to be welcomed that the report highlights the negative effects austerity has had on Member States’ healthcare systems.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
