text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important for the Union to address these two issues which affect citizens closely and which, therefore, are of enormous importance both for the present and, above all, for the future.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution is part of the joint work of the European Commission and Member States to improve care and, more specifically, antibiotic resistance. Patients' resistance to antibiotics is declining, which poses a real public health problem. Some projections predict up to 10 million deaths per year in 2050 due to antibiotic resistance. The proposed text includes better training of hospital staff and more responsible use of antibiotics in human medicine as well as veterinary medicine. As this is only a motion for a resolution, not a regulation, I voted in favour.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 We face several patient safety issues.  Firstly, because the economic crisis is putting pressure on healthcare budgets, and budget cuts in the health system have caused shortages of qualified staff. The exodus of medical staff from the countries of Eastern Europe is a reality that we are facing and for which the Member States should find a solution. Poor healthcare is one of the underlying causes of increased antimicrobial resistance. The patient's lack of information about the recommended medication is another factor influencing this process. According to statistics, more than 30% of European citizens are unaware that antibiotics have no effect in the treatment of virrhosis. In order to properly inform the patient, the Commission should require drug manufacturers to submit a summary of the product information in order to enable the patient to understand the usefulness and risks of administering the medicinal product. I voted in favour of the proposal for a report, because appropriate treatments and responsible consumption of medicines are essential elements for combating antimicrobial resistance.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. This is not the first report in which Parliament calls on the Commission to continue to follow consistently the progress of the Member States with regard to the recommendations made by Parliament itself and the Council, informing the public of all further progress in the field of patient safety and also in the development of new medicines that can help reduce the growth trend of adverse events in the EU.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The quality of health care in the European Union is of considerable importance. We have highly developed health care standards in Europe and we need to keep it that way. It is imperative that Member States continue to implement reforms to improve the efficiency of their health care systems. Patient safety must be a priority in this area. The report also calls on Member States to put in place measures to combat antimicrobial resistance. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report in order to improve health care and in particular to address the growing resistance to antibiotics, through a more responsible use of the treatments available and by promoting innovation. The current economic crisis has created strong pressure on national health budgets and has therefore had an impact on patient safety. It is estimated that between 8 and 12% of patients admitted to EU hospitals are victims of adverse events, such as related health infections, which cause 37 000 deaths per year and represent a heavy burden on limited health resources. Austerity measures that affect patient safety, staff or specialists in hospitals cannot be imposed. I call on the Member States to ensure that patient safety is not put at risk by austerity measures and that the health system remains adequately funded. I also find it unacceptable that 25 000 citizens die every year in Europe as a result of increasing resistance to existing antibiotics. We must therefore urge the pharmaceutical industries to invest in the development of new antimicrobial agents and ask the Commission to consider presenting a legislative proposal to stimulate research in this field.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The report was comprehensive and focused on solutions. However, on paragraph 80, amendment 2, I voted against as this amendment lacked clarity and it was unclear as to whether the Commission were being asked to consider a legal framework of incentives for antibiotics for human use, for example with extended market  exclusivity.  However, overall the report was positive and it was for these reasons that I voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The dossier suggests how to improve health care in the Union and, in particular, how to cope with the increasing resistance to antibiotics of humans and animals, through a more responsible use of the treatments available. At the same time, innovation is being promoted for a Union that is at the forefront of patient defence and care.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is part of a logic of improving care, particularly in the area of the fight against antibiotic resistance. This is indeed a major public health problem since many deaths are caused as a result of ineffective treatment of serious infections, the ineffectiveness of treatment stemming from antibiotic resistance. At the rate things are going, the forecast predicts 10 million deaths per year in 2050 as a result of this scourge. That is why the proposals in the report seem to me to be common sense: better training of hospital staff, measures tailored to Member States according to different standards and practices for each of them; and promoting more responsible use of antibiotics in human and veterinary medicine. I regret, however, that the amendments tabled by the Patriotic Members in the ENVI Committee have not been adopted, since they would have made it possible to position themselves in favour of measures necessary to contain this phenomenon, such as the reduction of austerity, which leads to dramatic budget cuts in hospitals, better recognition of health workers or the return to national control of borders to avoid contagion.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU must take action on different levels to greatly reduce health—related infections, which are putting an enormous strain on healthcare systems. Adequate resources must be invested in patient safety and the fight against drug resistance. Between 8% and 12% of patients admitted to hospitals in the EU were affected by infections contracted in healthcare institutions. This figure equals 4.1 million patients across the EU, this is very alarming indeed and we must not let those responsible turn a blind eye. Patient Safety is a major concern in Ireland as well as in the rest of Europe. According to the Commission’s Public Consultation Report on Patient Safety and Quality of Care, only 17% of the participating groups answered positively on whether the Council’s Recommendations from 2009 had been fully implemented in their respective countries. These are warning signs for the EU to review the process and ensure a more successful implementation on patient safety measures.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The safety of patients undergoing health care must be a continuous commitment and be at the heart of each Member State's political agenda. Even in times of crisis such as this, it is important to ensure sufficient financial resources to ensure, especially for the most vulnerable groups, access to health services. At European level, the Health for Growth programme has helped to strengthen coordination between Member States in order to identify innovative solutions to improve the quality, efficiency and sustainability of health systems.  But this is accompanied by an urgency: antimicrobial resistance, on which the Commission has focused its action since 2011 to raise awareness of a more careful and rational use of antibiotics. I am sure that European coordination of awareness-raising campaigns on this issue will achieve this objective.  The report voted on in plenary highlights this concern by identifying strategies for action to meet this new challenge.  For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The issue of patient safety and the fight against pharmacoresistance have been covered by both the European institutions (European Commission, Council, ECDC, EMA, EFSA) and the World Health Organisation (WHO).  According to available figures, as many as 8-12% of patients admitted to the EU (over 3 million people) suffer damage or adverse events, including healthcare-associated infections, nosocomials or not (IAAs), many of which (20-30%) considered as preventable.  As far as pharmacoresistance is concerned, the latest available data provided by ECDC, EMA and EFSA show that, overall, and despite some recent progress, ANTIMICROBIAL RESISTANCE is a growing public health problem in hospitals and the EU.  This report calls on the Commission to continue to monitor Member States' progress by communicating to the public all further progress on patient safety and also on the development of new medicines that can help reduce the growth trend of adverse events in the European Union.  In the light of these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I believe that this report on safe healthcare in Europe is of particular importance to all of us. Every year, around 25 000 patients in the countries of the European Union die from a serious infection with antibiotic-resistant bacteria, most of which patients are trapped in hospital. In this context, I believe that antibiotic resistance can only be combated with a holistic, cross-sectoral approach covering a wide range of disciplines (human and veterinary medicine, research, animal husbandry, agriculture, the environment, trade and communication).

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on safer healthcare in Europe aimed at improving patient safety and combating antimicrobial resistance. I welcomed the decision to return to an issue, that of health safety, which has already been addressed by the European institutions but which deserves constant attention and mobilisation, especially after the horizontal cuts suffered by health as a result of economic austerity measures. Indeed, I find it unacceptable that there are still tens of thousands of deaths in Europe as a result of healthcare-related infections: pressures on health budgets cannot and must not affect patient safety. I support the call for medical staff and pharmaceutical companies to use antibiotics more wisely, given that antimicrobial resistance in the world has grown considerably, leading to an increase in the failure of treatments on human and animal infectious diseases. I also share the desire to ensure adequate information for European citizens, both in terms of prevention and in terms of treatment and the possibilities offered in health institutions in the Member States. I hope that in the future we will be able to achieve a health system that guarantees patients their rights and restores their full confidence in health services.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ 8% to 12% of patients in EU hospitals suffer adverse events, such as healthcare-related adverse events and healthcare-associated infections (HAIs), medication-related events and complications arising during or after surgical operations. This results in 37 000 deaths a year and places a heavy burden on limited health service budgets. Almost half of such events could be avoided. The report suggests ways to improve patient safety, calling for the responsible use of antimicrobials in veterinary medicine, the responsible use of antibiotics, using today’s treatments more responsibly and promoting innovation. I have thus voted in favour of the report.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that we must put the patient at the centre of care and not let health systems suffer unjustified cuts in the name of austerity. We need to invest in continuing training, monitoring of medical and health services, alarm systems and preventive preparation actions to avoid an important part of adverse events, including those resulting from the use of medicines.  Over the years, it has become clear in all Western countries that it is necessary to have a risk assessment methodology based on the principle of 'reporting without punishment', which encourages the emergence of causes of adverse events or potential risks, but which certainly cannot leave the patient at risk or even of the damage caused by having received medical treatment , also deprived of possible means of protection aimed at compensating for what is immediately. I voted in favour because the report calls for an assessment of the introduction of rules to regulate the presence of product specialists in environments where treatment is administered. It also calls for the management of health facilities to be entrusted to selected persons on the basis of skills and merit and not on the basis of political affiliations or clientele.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The report aims to ensure improved patient safety by identifying and correcting health care factors that may pose an added risk to the health of the population. In particular, the report expresses concern about the misuse of certain medicines, such as antibiotics, whether by commercial pressure, insufficient public funding, lack of training or bad practices, against which it requires greater collaboration between States and increased legislative activity. It also criticizes livestock abuses, where indiscriminate use of antibiotics is an attack on public health.  It also recalls the importance of the prevention and good training of medical staff, as well as the good hygienic conditions of hospitals. In this sense, it criticizes the effects of austerity and calls for ensuring good funding of the health system. Since I share many of the report's conclusions and recommendations, I voted in favour.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Health care and, more generally, the health of citizens represent a major challenge in the construction and definition of a true European Union. Each individual element that is added is a fundamental step towards an organic and common vision of the European system, avoiding differences and imbalances in care.  In this sense, the report contributes to the assessment of how well Member States have implemented measures to improve patient safety, in particular with regard to the prevention and control of healthcare-associated infections (IAAs). Between 8% and 12% of patients admitted to EU hospitals still suffer from this type of effect. Every year, around 4.1 million patients are affected by these diseases and represent an additional cost to health services, a cost that could be reduced or avoided thanks to an effective prevention strategy. With regard to this, it is regrettable that once again there are important differences between the different Member States in the capacity and speed of adjustment. The Union must take action to significantly reduce these infections, which are putting a strain on health systems, including with adequate programmes and resources, to increase patient safety.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on Safer Healthcare in Europe. I support the amendments to encourage the development of new antibiotic drugs as I believe that this will have a positive impact and improve patient safety by fighting antimicrobial resistance and reduce the adverse impact of healthcare-associated infections caused by these organisms and will also reinforce measures where antibiotic use is carefully controlled in both human and animal diseases under one direction. This is particularly important in view of the mounting evidence that indicates that the link between antimicrobial resistance in animals and antimicrobial resistance in man is real and may possibly be on the increase.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that patient safety is at risk by economic austerity measures that require funding cuts in the healthcare sector and have a direct impact on the quality of treatments, I believe that Member States must ensure that, in this time of economic crisis, patient safety is not affected by austerity measures and that health systems continue to receive adequate funding. In particular, I believe that the most harmful measures, such as short-term savings, which would lead to high costs in the medium and long term, must be avoided, and instead focus on the further development of high-quality and efficient health systems.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report proposes to take stock of policies in Member States on the quality of care and health. The results are positive as the current reforms by Member States to improve the quality of health care in Europe are moving in the right direction and the rapporteur proposes ways of improving it. The report also addresses the crucial issue of combating antimicrobial resistance and calls on the Commission and Member States to increase the pace of research and development activities, with a view to developing new tools for control. Finally, the report makes recommendations on the use of antibiotics in human medicine and veterinary medicine in general, and in livestock farms in particular. Considering that this report is balanced, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. According to the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, one in twenty patients hospitalized in the European Union has a care-associated infection. It is important that citizens have confidence in their health care system. It goes without saying that hygiene and care must be beyond reproach in hospitals. As the report points out, patients also have a responsibility: they must follow the medical prescriptions that are done to them correctly. From this point of view, public health authorities must communicate in order to ensure adequate information, including to the poorest. Finally, Member States need to improve the collection and production of adverse event data. This is the prerequisite for establishing effective warning systems to prevent the spread of antimicrobial resistance.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: Written. – Access to efficient healthcare is a basic right in the EU. Although clear progress has been made since 2012, the battle has not yet been fought. By exchanging good practice and efficient solutions between Member States, we can only take the necessary steps forward. I have therefore supported this report.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this measure, patients admitted to European hospitals every year will be able to feel more protected from the damage they suffer as a result of antibiotic resistance and infections they contract in healthcare facilities. Antimicrobial resistance is on the increase throughout the world and is also affecting the European Union.  I voted in favour of this measure because the proposed measures aim to use existing medical treatments more carefully and responsibly.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. If public health policies fall within the competence and responsibility of states, the European Union can complement national policies by helping member countries achieve their common goals, meet global challenges and generate economies of scale. Today in Europe, between 8% and 12% of patients admitted to hospitals suffer from adverse events, of which almost half of these effects could be prevented and 25,000 people die each year due to increasing resistance to antibiotics. That is why the European Parliament, in its report on health in Europe, calls on pharmaceutical companies to invest in the development of new antimicrobial agents and calls on the Commission to consider the establishment of a legislative framework to encourage the development of new antibiotics.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The debate on health care in Europe is about a major issue: improving patient safety and antimicrobial resistance. Figures show that between 8 and 12% of patients hospitalized in the EU (more than 3 million people) suffer from adverse events, including care-associated infections (IAS). Every year in Europe, more than 25,000 people die from IAS caused by multidr disgusting antibiotic-resistant bacteria. This sad record is due in part to cuts in the health care sector, but above all from a series of aggravating factors, such as the lack of appropriate national programmes, the difficulty of reporting "undesirable events" and collecting data, the lack of alert and surveillance systems, inappropriate drug use, antibiotic packaging, etc.  As a result, many of these infections could be prevented. While public health is a competence of the Member States, the EU has room for manoeuvre. I voted for this report because I support the call for the governments of the 28 to invest in continuing education, monitoring of medical services, early warning systems and the search for new and effective products.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for the report on safer health care in Europe. The fight against antibiotic resistance is a worrying phenomenon that must be one of our priorities. As a member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I pay major attention to the risks involved. In order to avoid them, the aim is to reduce antibiotics consumed in both humans and animals, which enter the food chain. This also requires better patient information, for whom antibiotics are not always the solution of choice, as well as medical staff. These provisions therefore aim to make better use of antibiotics.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This own-initiative report seeks to establish the best practices and measures which Member States could implement in order to tackle the growing problems of Healthcare Associated Infections (HAIs) and Anti-Microbial Resistance (AMR) in the EU. There are many aspects of this report which the ECR is happy to support. We support the recognition of the role of vaccination, which can limit the use of antibiotics and the development of antimicrobial resistance. The report also endorses the ‘One Health’ concept as outlined by the World Health Organisation, recognising that human and animal health and ecosystems are interconnected, and that policies should be devised accordingly. Furthermore, we strongly back a call for greater incentives for public and private sector cooperation to reinvigorate antibiotic development R&D.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is frustrating that around 10% of patients in the EU suffer from disabilities caused by healthcare. It is believed that the main reason for this is the savings imposed by the Member States.  According to a world bank report, the Bulgarian citizen, for example, pays three times more for health than is normal, only 51% are taken over by the state. Ensuring a high level of human health protection is achieved at national level through national policies, but cooperation between Member States and the exchange of good practices can only be useful.  In Bulgaria there is a tendency to use many antibiotics and access to them is relatively easy. As the report points out, this leads to drug resistance and ultimately does not help, but harms.  Patient safety policies and programmes are needed. Let's put health at the forefront!

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Proposes measures to combat the reckless use of antibiotics which, even if we do not fully agree on everything, must be taken, since the current situation can be extremely dangerous to public health. We are therefore voting in favour.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on safer healthcare in Europe. It included a reference to targets for reducing the use of antibiotics and criticised high-intensity farming. With the decreasing effectiveness of antibiotics, it is important that we encourage responsible use and develop alternatives for both human and animal use. This is a very important issue for the health of the citizens of Wales.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's report on safer health care in Europe was proposed by the M5S through an own-initiative report.  The report deals with the issue of patient safety and the fight against pharmacoresistance, especially antibiotic resistance. It encourages research into antimicrobial drugs, in particular on antibiotics active against multi-pharmaco-resistant Gram-negative bacteria, which must be accelerated and financed immediately if the battle against bacterial infections, the incidence of which is increasing in Europe, is to be won.  The report aims to prevent member states' health systems from being hit by austerity measures and unsustainable economic cuts and calls for efforts to be focused on developing high-quality and high-performance health systems.  Another essential aspect of the proposal is the reduction and regulation of all forms and types of health conflict of interest by Member States, which are asked to ensure that health systems and health facilities are managed independently of policy choices and that managers are chosen on the basis of merit and not political affiliation. For the above reasons, I voted in favour.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The main dimension of the overall quality of healthcare is patient safety, the fundamental aspects of which are a culture of care safety and incident management that compromise patient safety. It is estimated that 8% to 12% of patients admitted to EU hospitals suffer from adverse events while receiving health care and that about half of these events could be avoided, as they are infections associated with such care, medication-related episodes and complications during or after surgical interventions. 30 to 50% of patients do not take the medicines prescribed by doctors or take them without prescribing them and it is assumed that by 2050 10 million people will die each year due to antimicrobial resistance. It is important that Member States ensure, in this period of economic crisis, that health systems are not affected by austerity measures and continue to be adequately financed and, in particular, to avoid the most harmful measures, such as short-term savings that will lead to high costs in the medium and long term, and to focus on the continued development of high-quality and efficient health systems.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it is part of a preventive approach to antibiotic resistance. Despite its imperfections, it is a step forward because it focuses on a key public health problem.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Between 8 and 12% of patients admitted to hospitals in the EU suffer from adverse effects while receiving medical care, the most common being healthcare-associated infections (HAIs), medication-related events and complications arising from surgical interventions. Almost half of these events could be avoided. IACS, in particular, is a preventable public health problem through intensive hygiene and control programs. Antimicrobial resistance has increased in the EU for pathogenic bacteria, which has led to an increase in HAIs caused by multidrug-resistant bacteria, a public health problem. The report comprehensively and documented this theme. It refers to the effects of disinvestment in public health services and their professionals as a result of so-called austerity policies and advocates the reversal of this path. Although we agree with the general meaning of the report, we believe that further progress could have been made in some areas. This is the case of the price of medicines and their implications for restrictions on access, patient safety and antimicrobial resistance (as a result of incomplete tomes, for example). This is also the case with the need to strengthen public capacities in the field of research and development of new drugs, discompeting the primacy of pharmaceutical multinationals.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 There is no doubt that health systems in individual Member States have undergone significant reforms in recent years and governments are trying to provide citizens with better healthcare. Nevertheless, 8-12% of patients hospitalised in the European Union experienced adverse events while providing healthcare. Around 4.1 million patients in the European Union receive a hospital infection every year and at least 37 000 die as a result of it, which are very alarming figures. It is very unfortunate that we have put us in a situation where it is becoming increasingly clear, however, that the level of care for patients and their safety is often hampered by various austerity measures and horizontal cuts, which is unacceptable, because the protection of human life and health must be an absolute priority and all economic indicators must be put aside in this case. Healthcare policies should not be subject to austerity measures and cuts, and relevant institutions should provide patients with the highest possible level of safety and protection of human life.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. 2012 I am voting in favour of this report, where Parliament calls on the Commission to continue to monitor consistently the progress of the Member States with regard to the recommendations made by Parliament itself and the Council in the field of health.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on safer healthcare in Europe because it proposes measures to combat the reckless use of antibiotics, measures which, even if I do not fully agree with everything, must be taken, since the current situation can be extremely dangerous to public health.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the EU must take action on different levels to greatly reduce health—related infections, which are putting an enormous strain on healthcare systems. Adequate resources must be invested in patient safety and the fight against drug resistance. I welcome the very positive aspects introduced in this report, such as the willingness to develop patient safety strategies on prevention, education, awareness-raising, diagnosis and treatment; the focus on the necessity to provide training of healthcare professionals in infection prevention and control; the inclusion of the need to ensure better monitoring and data collection of HAIs; the proper screening and isolation of patients transferred from other regions. This report also positively highlights the importance of the responsible use of antibiotics in the fight against drug resistance, and addresses scientific, regulatory and economic challenges to encourage R&D into new antimicrobials. I support the promotion of the One Health strategy and the link between human and animal health and the environment. Finally, I believe we must ensure adequate funding to provide high—quality healthcare systems throughout Europe.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. The fight against drug resistance, especially antibiotic resistance, is a topic widely studied by the potential public health problems it can bring. It is essential to ensure that the prescription of antibiotics for treatment is adequate and responsible. Similarly, it is imperative that health care systems continue to have adequate funding and, in particular, to avoid the most harmful measures, such as short-term savings, which will lead to high costs in the medium and long term. I voted for it.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Antimicrobial resistance has been increasing over the past two decades, resulting in almost 25 000 deaths a year in the EU alone. This is a global and priority public health problem for both developed and developing countries.  In addition to emphasising the importance of responsible use of antimicrobials, with this text we are encouraging pharmaceutical companies to develop new, more effective antibiotics, and we call on the Commission to reflect on a legislative proposal that can provide a regulatory framework conducive to the development of these products.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I agree with the thorough report on 'safer health care in Europe', a priority issue on which I am convinced that more resources need to be invested, both in terms of training and information policies adapted to citizens and in terms of European and national programmes capable of guaranteeing greater safety for patients, and in economic terms, because – in order to cope with the economic crisis – it is not precisely the health sector that has to pay the most expensive expenses, with cuts that could have bleak and dangerous repercussions, but rather continue to invest in research, because it is the source of hope for those suffering from any pathology. That is why I hope that the Union, through its efforts, will be able to transpose the risks of misuse of antibiotic therapies, both in human and animal medicine, by promoting their more conscious and responsible use in order to avoid the alarming phenomenon of pharmacoresistance. I welcome the excellent monitoring, data collection and analysis work that ECDC/EFSA and EMA have carried out in their integrated report, as well as the European Medicines Agency's continued commitment to the protection of human health.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the own-initiative report entitled 'Safer health care in Europe: improving patient safety and combating antimicrobial resistance'. Between 8% and 12% of citizens have suffered problems during hospital treatment, and around 4.1 million European patients suffer from health treatment-related diseases annually. This is a problem especially for vulnerable people, i.e. carriers of chronic diseases, immuno-depressed patients and cancer patients.  The recent progress report by the Member States confirms the diversity of national approaches, the lack of timely prevention and the lack of adequate financial resources to combat antibiotic-resistant micro-organisms available today. Action by the Commission is therefore needed to promote pharmacological research and the placing on the market of new antibiotics, together with the promotion of awareness-raising campaigns on the appropriate use of medicines and the reduction of the use of hospitalisation, without underestimating the obligation of Member States to check safety in the workplace for the health of health professionals. The EU must therefore act at all levels to reduce these infections, reinvigorate national health systems and invest the necessary resources for patient health.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Up to 25 000 people die each year in Europe due to antibiotic resistance. We need to change that. In the past, more and more resistances have developed as a result of the mishandling of antibiotics. Simple infections can no longer be treated effectively and thus become a serious danger for patients. In Europe, therefore, we must promote research into new active substances. In veterinary medicine, it is important to prevent prophylactic use of antibiotics. We need a more responsible use of medicines in Europe. Incidentally, we can all contribute to this. Antibiotic treatment, for example, should always be taken until the last tablet. We also need to develop solutions to treatment-associated infections. About one in ten patients admitted to hospitals in the EU is infected with such an infection during their treatment. More than 37 000 people die from this in the EU every year alone. It is precisely the economic crisis that has put pressure on the budgets of many Member States. This must not affect patient safety. Our health systems must continue to be adequately funded.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. •u2012 European health systems are envy outside Europe. This doesn't mean we shouldn't try to improve them. The report on which I am voting in favour today contains many points with which I fully identify myself: ensuring that health systems and health facilities are managed professionally by administrators appointed on merit and not on political affiliations;  exchange best practices among health professionals so that they are up to date with the latest technology and hospital hygiene best practices; ensure equal access to health services; and, in the face of increasing antibiotic resistance, stimulate the development of new effective antibiotics. We must continue to work to ensure that our health systems continue to be the flagship of our welfare state.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ As a member of the Committee for Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I am acutely aware of the need for a coordinated approach for controlling Healthcare Associated Infections (HAIs) and Antimicrobial Resistance (AMR).  I am pleased to see that this report calls for cooperation on a European level as well as antibiotic research and development. I welcome the inclusion in the report of continuous training for healthcare professionals, as preventing the spread of infection is more effective than curing it. The Conservative Party acknowledges that although healthcare should in principal remain a Member State competence there are some areas that require international cooperation, particularly in this field, so I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. I supported this project for safer care in Europe. The fight against antibiotic resistance is a major public health issue. Two points in this report are particularly close to my heart.  The first point is the responsibility of the Commission which imposes austerity, even at the cost of the lack of staff and resources in hospitals. The second point is that of intensive breeding. This practice is the result of globalist policies that the Commission applies and encourages: to produce more and more under increasingly questionable conditions. However, the results are clear: intensive breeding is the main source of antibiotic abuse and therefore antibiotic resistance.  I am therefore looking forward to seeing how the Commission intends to resolve its schizophrenia between the need to improve care and its productive excesses. In any case, I will not support binding measures for medical personnel if, at the same time, nothing is done to reduce the consumption of antibiotics on farms. I would add that country-by-country assessments would be essential for a differentiated and more effective policy.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this because we believe it is essential that Member States take measures to improve the quality of health care. Health cuts have resulted in increased antibiotic resistance and the spread of certain deadly diseases. We cannot allow health and health in the broad sense not to be one of the priorities of a responsible agenda.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my Labour colleagues, voted in favour of this report because it calls for action to improve patient safety and fight antimicrobial resistance, and to ease the burden this places on overstretched health systems.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on safer healthcare in Europe because I agree with the provisions set out here that any cuts to budgets for health systems caused by economic difficulties cannot lead to compromises in the area of patient safety. It is unacceptable that cuts in national health systems are at the expense of the quality of treatment. Savings need to be wise. National health systems need to be improved by investing in continuing training, monitoring of medical and healthcare services, early warning systems and, above all, prevention. This would make work more efficient and without endangering the lives of patients.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Hospital-acquired infections in Scotland are currently at an all-time low thanks to concerted efforts by both government and healthcare staff.  This has been brought about within the context of a publicly owned NHS and my party will continue to reject the privatisation of healthcare, where private profit comes before cleanliness and good health.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this because we believe it is essential that Member States take measures to improve the quality of health care. Health cuts have resulted in increased antibiotic resistance and the spread of certain deadly diseases. We cannot allow health and health in the broad sense not to be one of the priorities of a responsible agenda.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this document calling for investment in continuing training, supervision of medical and health benefits, alert systems and preventive preparation measures to avoid a significant part of adverse events, including those arising from the consumption of medicines. The patient should be the core of treatment and not let health systems suffer unjustified cuts in the name of austerity.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report. It acknowledges that some Member States have made significant progress. However, others have fallen behind and it points out that action should be taken in the following areas: ensuring adequate funding to provide high quality healthcare; providing training of professionals in infection prevention and control; proper screening and isolation of patients transferred from other regions.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Safer Healthcare Report in Europe: improving patient safety and combating antimicrobial resistance, as research shows that irrational use of antimicrobials, especially antibiotics, has been occurring over the past 25 years. According to eu estimates, 25 million people die annually from infections caused by resistant bacteria, an extremely high figure and cost in the public health system. Continuous training of healthcare professionals and investment in education, exchange of experience, knowledge and best practices should be encouraged, in order to introduce newer measures on general patient safety and the reduction of hospital infections, as there are major differences between Member States in the sector.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This proposal aims to improve care and, above all, to combat antibiotic resistance. The latter is mainly related to the misuse of these drugs. This resistance to antibiotics causes high mortality, as it is responsible for 37,000 deaths in the European Union. It also recommends improving the training of hospital staff in the better use of antibiotics, both in the medical world and in the veterinary field. Antibiotic-based veterinary treatments are still used to increase the profitability of farms, although they have been banned in the EU since the mid-2000s. However, simple and particularly effective measures are missing from the report. Better border control, which would have enabled better management of contagions, is a solution to be considered, as well as stopping public health budget cuts in order to strengthen medical teams and thus to operate on better patient follow-up would reduce the use of antibiotics. However, this text is going in the right direction, so I have decided to vote for it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this report as we feel it attempts to harmonise laws to the detriment of UK patients, UK companies and the UK health environment. The UK already has an excellent regime for regulating resistance to antibiotics, and we fear an EU scheme would undermine this via harmonisation. This regime is under constant and regular update, and only recently the UK Chief medical officer has initiated future requirements that would benefit the UK. This latest EU interference would put public health at risk, putting the emphasis on EU harmonisation before that of good medical practice, which is unacceptable to UKIP MEPs. A UK independent of the EU would work with the WHO and other international public health and government health bodies, as we feel they have a relevant legitimacy lacking of the EU. UKIP MEPs feel any developments in this field should be science—led, with the consultation and collaboration of parties directly impacted by any proposed changes.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Piernicola Pedicini's report on the need for safer health care in Europe. This report focuses on improving patient safety and combating antimicrobial resistance. It also highlights the need for further research on antimicrobials in order to best fight human and animal bacteria. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report to ensure safer health care in Europe. Its main objective is to improve patient safety and combat antimicrobial resistance. Nearly 10 million people die each year due to antimicrobial resistance. I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The health service has repeatedly been the biggest pain of many people and a nuisance to patients. It is very difficult to create a system that satisfactorily meets the requirements of patients, doctors and medical staff. And health is the most important thing. When the disease comes, the patient would like to find himself in the hands of the best specialists, to be surrounded by caring care, in the best possible conditions. These expectations are not always met, and sometimes even, as a result of various conditions, the patient suffers additional damage to health. The situation is not the same in all Member States and treatment standards vary on many levels, so it is our job to work to level the playing field in the provision of medical services in order to prevent unfortunate accidents. There are currently many neglects and dangerous practices in individual countries. Criticism, for example, requires replacing educated staff with less educated but cheaper labour or excessive, unjustified use of antibiotics.  Ensuring equal standards is particularly important with open borders and treatment options throughout the Union. It is also important to agree that health policy is not a good source of savings and that we should prevent a possible reduction in funding for the health service.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. While it is worth supporting and desirable to reduce the use of antibiotics in humans and animals, thereby reducing the cultivation of resistant strains, the report contains further and unjustifiable demands, the implementation of which would be an overstepping of competence. I therefore reject this report.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on safer healthcare in Europe at the European Parliament's plenary session in Strasbourg: improving patient safety and combating antimicrobial resistance. We are responsible for the measures adopted to improve health care and patient safety in the European Union. It is therefore important to make sure that the EU pays the necessary attention to healthcare. At the moment, statistics in this area are not encouraging.  For example, patients hospitalised in the EU, between 8% and 12% suffer from infections that result directly from healthcare in EU hospitals when receiving healthcare. This number could be reduced by about half if healthcare and patient safety were improved. The report stresses that increasing antibiotic resistance should also be taken into account and should be addressed. Given the importance of this subject, I voted in favour of this report because it proposes measures that could be a step closer to ordering the medical sector in the EU and being able to provide safe and high-quality health care for 500 million citizens.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. One of main objectives is to create an European e-health system. Here the current gap between Member States is biggest. In some MSs e-health usage exceeds 80%; in others it is lower than 5%. An interoperable e-health system would not only ease the life of patients, but would also provide for comparison of different health care systems to effectively detect and eliminate shortcomings in the healthcare systems.  Resistance to antibiotics is a growing concern, caused in some cases by irresponsible and too widespread prescription of antibiotics and by their usage both in human and veterinarian medicine. Prescribing antibiotics must be better justified and targeted. This applies especially to veterinarian medicine where systemic use of antibiotics has become part of normal economic development. Whereas Europe ranks very high on quality health care, still the complications caused by human factor are too high. Hospitals and healthcare facilities must make it their core business to minimise these complications. This must mean not only properly training all medical staff, who directly and indirectly come into contact with patient, but also fully informing patients about needed pre—care and after—care hygiene.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the report. There has been a worrying increase in healthcare associated infections and antibiotic resistance, with available figures suggesting 8-12% of hospital patients suffer harm or adverse events, of which 20-30% could be prevented. The EU must take action on different levels to greatly reduce health—related infections, which are putting an enormous strain on healthcare systems.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Eight to 12% of patients admitted annually to healthcare facilities across the EU will have an event directly related to healthcare provided. Half of these incidents can be successfully prevented in advance. Hospital infections, responses to poorly adjusted or selected medications and complications arising during or after surgery are among the most common dangers that occur to treated persons. A major problem is also the global increase in the incidence of bacteria resistant to both common and broad-spectrum antibiotics, which is currently reflected in the increase in cases of so-called hospital infections. My colleague Pedicini's report, for which I voted today (19 May 2015), is based on the premise that the patient's right not to be harmed or threatened in any way by the damage caused by medical intervention should be at the heart of the quality of the medical care provided. Furthermore, the report welcomes the latest measures put in place by the Member States, in particular the progress made in developing a strategy to improve patient safety. However, importantly from my point of view, the text presented strongly criticises the uneven progress made by individual Member States in improving patient safety and, above all, their apparent slowdown in the implementation of the recommendations provided because of the financial constraints resulting from the budget cuts made in recent years. The report expresses deep concern that these austerity measures have led to a reduction in the quality and quantity of cleaning and sanitation staff in health facilities.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Between 50% and 70% of meat products tested by European consumer organisations in 14 EU Member States were contaminated with antibiotic-resistant bacteria. If you fail to prepare food or become infected with such bacteria during your meal, there is a good chance that you will do so during a hospitalization or even a visit. Encouraging prospects. The proposal tries to find a way out of a situation that cannot be described as rosy in many, many points, and should therefore be supported. It would be helpful if the old Member States did not entice medical staff and researchers from the recently acceded countries with better salaries, which, by the way, are largely covered by the colonisation of the new Member States. They should be training their own specialists before the bacteria that are on the border win.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this vote we affirm the importance of the right of every human being to have safe health care. We have important tools for assessing patient safety, such as comparable indicators developed by the OSCE: let us use them to ensure quality and safety health services for all human beings. I urge everyone to take the necessary action to fully implement the Council's recommendations for improving patient safety. Within the security framework, the figure of the 'representative of the rights of the sick' is of considerable importance; citizens have the right to be informed about risks, preventive measures, but also, and above all, about their right to complain.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The aim of Mr Pedicini's report is to ensure better health care throughout Europe. The issue of improving public health conditions is one of the priority points on which the parliamentary work of the ENVI Committee focuses. I believe, in fact, that guaranteeing the safety and health of the patient is a vital element for an efficient health system, as every citizen needs proper treatment in full and absolute respect for his inalienable right to health. The current situation sees around 8-12% of patients admitted to the EU (over 4 million) suffer damage or even adverse events, including healthcare-associated infections, nosocomial or not (IAA), many of which (20-30%) considered as preventable. For these reasons, I have decided to support this report.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution to improve patient safety and combat antimicrobial resistance in the European Union.  Like the overwhelming majority of my colleagues, I voted in favour of this resolution which draws the conclusions of a worrying assessment, highlighted by the initiative report which was presented to the European Parliament and which estimates that between 8 and 12% of patients admitted to EU hospitals suffer from adverse side effects such as hospital-acquired infections, involving nearly 37,000 deaths per year , and placing a significant burden on Member States' health budgets.  In this context, we wanted to underline the need to tackle the growing resistance to human and veterinary antibiotics but also to promote pharmaceutical and medical innovation, in order to rapidly and sustainably improve patient safety in the European Union.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for the report "Safer Health Care in Europe: Improving Patient Safety and Combating Antimicrobial Resistance". I believe that a more reasonable use of antibiotics should be supported. The misuse of antibiotics (strictly unnecessary prescriptions to treat viral diseases, prescriptions for broad-spectrum antibiotics, etc.) has led to the emergence and selection of resistant bacteria. The rapporteur Piernicola Pedicini is therefore right to recommend a more careful use of antibiotics available in human and veterinary medicine, only when antibiotics are needed and according to appropriate prescriptions (dose, dosage intervals and duration of treatment). There is also a need to strengthen hygiene precautions, and research and development in antibiotics.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution because it seeks to improve the health of patients through realistic recommendations. For example, it recommends more reasonable use of antibiotics. It also has the merit of recalling that hospital leaders must be "appointed on the basis of merit and not their political affiliation".

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for it. The aim of this resolution is to improve care and, in particular, to combat antibiotic resistance. It is indeed a serious public health problem that causes many deaths due to lack of effective treatment for serious infections. To date, antibiotic resistance is responsible for 37,000 deaths in the European Union. While the United States is the largest user of antibiotics, it still has a high number of deaths but is lower than that of the European Union with 23,000 deaths. This is due to unit sales and a greater homogeneity of practices. The text proposes better training of hospital staff and calls for the application of appropriate measures respecting the existing disparity in states, as well as a more responsible use of antibiotics in human and veterinary medicine. Even if this text does not go far enough in defending sovereignty and controlling borders to avoid contagion, it should be supported.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. In accordance with available figures, between 8% and 12% of hospitalized patients in the EU (about 3 million people) suffer harm or adverse events (infections associated with healthcare, nosocomial or non-healthcare (IRAS)). The report calls on Member States to act in the following areas: sustainability of quality health systems; development of patient safety strategies; training for professionals in the control and prevention of nosocomial infections; collection of patient and IRAS data; monitoring and isolation of cross-border patients to prevent contagion. It also recalls the importance of responsible use of antibiotics to avoid developing antibiotic resistance and the promotion of research in search of new antimicrobials. Finally, it recalls the principle of "A Health", the link between human and animal health. Agreeing with these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This Resolution emphasizes the main function of regulating the health system at European level, which is to ensure patient safety. Taking this into account and following the consequences of the economic crisis, which have often made this priority un taken into account, the Resolution proposes certain measures to improve the European health care of the different States. Aspects such as a commitment to electronic health or increased investment in health research and development are some of the measures that are established. All these actions should be carried out in a coordinated and cooperative manner between States.  There is therefore a need to establish minimum legislation within the EU to ensure the safety of healthcare patients by collaborating with key bodies such as WHO or the Global Fund for Innovation. Since this Resolution presents measures guaranteeing safe health care in the EU, I give you my approval.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the report on health in Europe. In the context of this report, I draw attention to two aspects, namely the funding of research and the use of health infrastructure created by EU funding.  Firstly, health research, as rightly emphasised in the report, is one of the objectives of Horizon 2020. Unfortunately, due to the planned cuts in funding under this ESI Funds programme, there is a risk that these studies will not receive adequate financial support. Already, only 8% of applications for participation in a given health research project are likely to receive a grant or grant. A further reduction in the Horizon 2020 budget means that an even smaller proportion of good research and innovation projects in basic and applied research will have a chance of receiving financial support.  Secondly, I call on the Commission to support and monitor the functioning of eu-funded health infrastructure. In Poland, thanks to European support, one of the most modern research and medical institutions was established, which unfortunately cannot fully exploit its potential due to a number of financial and legal constraints related to the commercial use of this type of infrastructure. Therefore, it is extremely important to monitor such projects and take action to support implementation.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am afraid that such proposals can only bring more bureaucracy to medical facilities that are already oversued by administration. I also strongly disagree with the call for the influence of politicians on health care to be eliminated. Politicians are representatives of citizens, and it is not possible to give voters such control over how health care will be organized.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The report by Representative Piernicol Pedicine deals with the issue of incorrect use of antibiotics created by bacterial resistance, but also by the reactions of the human organism to the effects of antibiotics.  About 3 million people a year contract infections sustained during treatment. Prevention, more intensive hygiene controls and the correct prescribing of antibiotics could greatly reduce this number.  In Croatia, systematic monitoring of resistance at the national level began in 1996, and since 2006 it has been a member of the Croatian National Resistance Agency. Croatia actively participates in European projects and an interdisciplinary body has been established to coordinate all activities in the field of control of bacterial resistance to antibiotics (ISKRA) in accordance with the Council's recommendations.  I support mep Pedicini's report, which encourages that responsible and targeted antibiotic prescribing and a global infection control strategy should combat antimicrobial resistance to reduce the number of resistant bacteria that endanger citizens' health. Educating citizens through a five-year public campaign in France has led to a 25 percent reduction in outpatient antibiotic consumption in the country, so in the context of this we need to change our experiences and apply the best policy.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Antimicrobial resistance poses a serious threat to humanity and negatively affects public health. It puts the lives and health of people and animals at risk, while increasing the demands for health funding. The flat-rate use of medicines, especially antibiotics, has an impact on reducing their effectiveness, causing the spread of microbes and bacteria. In order to slow down the development and reduce the spread of antimicrobial resistance gene-containing bacteria, it is necessary that the Commission, in cooperation with Member States and professional institutions, take all measures to raise awareness among both the public and health professionals themselves. Measures must be directed towards the responsible and correct use of antimicrobials, which should lead to a reduction in the risks to human health and, at the same time, to a positive impact on public finances.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report and believe that the following areas of action should be tackled as a matter of priority: – careful use of the antibiotics available (in human and veterinary medicine), that is to say, only when an appropriate prescription (specifying the dosage, dosage intervals, and duration of the treatment) states that they are necessary; – national and cross-border measures to limit the movement of patients infected with resistant bacteria; – hygiene precautions to control the transmission of resistant strains between infected persons, including hand hygiene, screening for the transport of strains, and isolation of patients suffering from infections caused by resistant bacteria; – research and development focusing on antibiotics, with new ways of proceeding and new approaches to alternative treatments.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for this motion for a resolution. Although the amendments tabled by our Members have not been adopted, this resolution is rather well oriented. It proposes, among other things, better training of hospital staff and more responsible use of antibiotics in human and veterinary medicine.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the main elements of the quality of health systems is to ensure patient safety, preventing the patient from suffering harm or potential harm due to therapeutic treatment. According to the latest estimates, around 8-12% of patients admitted to the EU suffer damage or adverse events, such as healthcare-associated infections, many of which are preventable. It is therefore necessary to take action on this issue and encourage cooperation to ensure a high level of protection of human health, to ensure that health systems and health facilities are managed independently of policy choices and that managers are chosen on merit, to ensure basic training in infection prevention and control and to promote information campaigns for patients.  For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 At a time when one of the main consequences of austerity measures has been the reduction of health care and the conditions in which they are provided, it is important to say that patients are entitled not to be put at risk by medical treatments and that this has to be central to the quality of health care. That's why I voted for it.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. From the EU, we must promote measures to provide our citizens with safer healthcare. That is why I support this report, in which the European Parliament calls for action to enable more responsible use of existing treatments and also to boost innovation. Measures are also needed to reduce the number of infections among hospitalized patients and thus reduce the number of victims by implementing intensive hygiene and control programmes in health facilities.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against the report on safe healthcare in Europe because I do not consider the report as a whole to be useful – including the requirement that veterinarians should not prescribe or sell prescriptions, but also the call for a ban on the preventive use of antimicrobials.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. "Antibiotics are not automatic." Despite the French government's campaign, the prescribing of antibiotics is still too systematic, even unnecessary, as in the case of viral infections, in France, the EU and beyond. By 2050, ten million people worldwide could die each year because of antimicrobial resistance developed by the use of ever-increasing or broad-spectrum antibiotics. This report takes stock of this public health problem, compounded by austerity and budget cuts in health. In particular, he denounces the dangerous reduction of hygiene rules in hospitals or the reduction of funds for research and development of new types of antibiotics or alternative care. It proposes possible avenues for states to improve responsible use of antibiotics for both humans and animals. He defends small farms in extensive breeding that alone can reduce the use of veterinary antibiotics. In order to combat the conflict of interest between doctors and large pharmaceutical companies, it proposes, among other things, to separate the volume of sales from the remuneration paid for a new antibiotic. I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (NI)
text: In writing. This proposal aims to improve care and, above all, to combat antibiotic resistance. The latter is mainly related to the misuse of these drugs. Antibiotic resistance leads to high mortality, currently 37,000 deaths in the European Union. This text aims to improve the training of hospital staff and to make better use of antibiotics in the medical and veterinary world. These treatments are also used to increase livestock production, although they have been banned in Europe since 2006. However, we would have liked more sovereignty, especially through border control, which allows for better management of contagions and less austerity, including training of health workers who are suffering from budget cuts. Despite these points of divergence, this text is generally moving in the right direction. Therefore, I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The issue of patient safety and the fight against drug resistance, especially antimicrobial resistance, are certainly not unknown topics of those who deal with the management of health systems or who has attended in recent years the sessions of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety of the European Parliament.  This is a widely debated topic by both the World Health Organisation (WHO) and the European institutions, such as the Commission, the Council and the specialised agencies (ECDC, EMA, EESA). This draft report is based on the need for patient safety, i.e., the patient's freedom not to undergo actual or potential harm as a consequence of providing health care, to be an essential element for the quality of health systems. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it urges Member States to come together to define minimum patient safety standards and indicators for safety and quality of healthcare at EU level. It also calls on the Commission and Member States to work with all stakeholders to develop a multi-level, comprehensive and sustainable EU strategy for patient safety.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Access to effective health care systems is an essential part of our European societies. This effectiveness cannot be envisaged without increased patient safety. While much progress has been made in this area since 2012, this needs to be persevered, notably through the exchange of good practices and effective solutions between all Member States. That is why I strongly support this proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this non-legislative report evaluating how well the Member States have implemented the last Council recommended measures to be taken to improve patient safety, in particular regarding the prevention and control of healthcare-associated infections. The EU must take action on different levels to greatly reduce healthcare-related infections which are putting an enormous strain on healthcare systems. Therefore, I fully agree with investing adequate resources in patient safety.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Patient safety and the fight against drug resistance, especially antimicrobial resistance, are widely debated topics by both the World Health Organisation (WHO) and the European institutions, such as the Commission, the Council and the specialised agencies (ECDC, EMA, EFSA) and the European Parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. This draft report is part of the need for patient safety to be an essential element for the quality of health systems.  I am voting in favour of the report, given that I argue that the patient should be the centre of treatment and not allowing health systems to suffer unjustified cuts in the name of austerity.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The report entitled "Safer Health Care in Europe" aims to tackle the danger of antibiotic resistance. This phenomenon is primarily related to the excessive and/or misuse of antibiotics, which, let us remember, fight diseases of bacterial origin and not viral. Self-medication and poor prescribing encourage this growing public health problem. According to some projections, by 2050, "antibiotic resistance" could cause the death of 10 million people per year, compared to 37,000 at present.  This report is a step in the right direction as it promotes better training and awareness of hospital practitioners, rationalization and accountability in the use of antibiotics, including veterinary use. Although several amendments by my colleagues have not been accepted, notably on austerity as the cause of the crime of the public hospital service, I have decided to vote for this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it signals a call for action to improve patient safety and fight antimicrobial resistance, to ease the burden this places on overstretched health systems.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report on the safety of health care in Europe. In particular, measures are needed to combat antimicrobial resistance, which has become a major issue for both human and animal health. In the European Union, 25,000 people die each year from antibiotic-resistant bacteria. This text proposes to regulate and restrict the consumption of antibiotics at the end of the chain, but also to encourage the development of research in antibiotic therapy, made difficult by various economic, political or scientific barriers.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on safer health care in Europe. In the European Union, hospital-acquired infections have become a major public health problem; one in 20 hospitalized patients suffers from a hospital-acquired infection, or 4.1 million patients each year, and 37,000 people die as a result of a care-related infection. In this report, we propose measures to ensure safer use of existing treatments and to promote research and innovation.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome Mr Pedicini's report on safer health care, firmly convinced of the centrality of the issue in all EU Member States. Firstly, there must be a guarantee at Community level of any cuts in health that could be made as a result of the economic crisis and which would inevitably lead to a lowering of the level of patient safety standards. It is not acceptable that in the twenty-first century between 8 and 12% of patients suffer during their stay for diseases other than those that caused them. The European Union needs to take action at various levels to reduce hospital-related infections, which are becoming an increasingly significant problem for the health sector. We must also avoid as much as possible in the future the unpleasant distance in investment and performance that has occurred in recent years between the various Member States. In this respect, we must acknowledge the work carried out so far by the European institutions and the specialised agencies, which are entrusted with monitoring and coordination tasks.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Every year, 4.1 million patients are infected in healthcare across Europe and 37,000 die unfortunately. Together with the number of problems caused by errors in hospitals, this is between 8% and 12% of patients treated in the EU. It is disappointing that only a fraction of Member States have introduced the Council's proposals, despite the fact that 30-40% of the problems caused by errors and 20-30% of infections could be prevented. We're going to have to change that. I think it is important for the Member States to implement the Council's innovations, in particular in the area of patient rights, infection prevention and training of health workers. It is essential that work is continued on the creation of a central European classification system and the laying down of European directives in the field of patient safety. Safe healthcare is the basis for a well-functioning health system and every effort should therefore be made to ensure that safety forms the basis of EU structures in public health.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report which is about ensuring safer health care in Europe by improving patient safety and combating antimicrobial resistance. Statistics show that more than 10 million people a year will fall victim to anti-moccrobic resistance by 2050 unless clear action is taken to do so. Consequently, the report's proposals provide for more information, training of medical staff, communication with patients, prevention actions and identification of solutions for the future.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ Chaith mé vóta i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo. Cuirim fáilte roimh an tslí a leagtar béim ar fhrithsheasmhacht in aghaidh ábhair fhrithmhiocróbaigh. Is rud an-dáiríre é seo mar go bhfuil sé ag méadú agus bíonn tionchar tubaisteach aige ar shláinte othar ar fud fad na hEorpa.  Tá sé measta go mbásfaidh 10 milliún duine gach bliain faoin am a mbeidh 2050 bainte amach mar gheall ar an bhfeiniméan seo. Mar sin, tá sé an-tábhachtach go ndéantar rud éigin láithreach chun an eipidéim seo a stopadh. Cuireann an tuarascáil seo i gcuimhne dúinn go bhfuil cur chuige comhordaithe ag teastáil chun obair i gcoinne frithsheasmhacht in aghaidh ábhair fhrithmhiocróbaigh, díreach cosúil leis an gcur chuige One Health a mhol an Eagraíocht Dhomhanda Sláinte.  Ba chóir fáilte a chur freisin roimh an tslí a leagtar béim ar an tionchar diúltach a bhí, agus atá, ag an déine ar chórais cúraim sláinte sna Ballstáit.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the text adopted in this report as it represents an important step in a European approach to unified healthcare standards. We do need safer healthcare, focused on the patients, with better standards and adapted legislation in all Member States, and Parliament has adopted today a document opening many pathways for better cooperation in this field at Union level.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. Antibiotic resistance could endanger the lives of up to 10 million European citizens by 2050. The report presented contains reasonable and feasible proposals to minimise this risk. It is particularly important that patients are also provided with adequate information on the possible long-term effects of each treatment.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. Improving our health standards must always be supported. The report deals with better patient safety and the fight against resistance to drugs and antibiotics. Investments are needed in the development and monitoring of medical services, as more than three million people in Europe who are hospitalised suffer damage or undesirable consequences such as therapy-associated infections. I am in favour of sustainable and efficient improvement and targeted use of financial resources. As this report does not show any lasting improvements for me, I abstained.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report aims to combat the overly systematic prescribing of antibiotics, which generates a problem of resistance of bacteria, which can cause the death of millions of people in the coming years. The report proposes possible ways to improve the responsible use of medicines for both humans and animals.
