Austerity is identified as a nuisance to patient health and staff effectiveness, and vigilance is called on the CAP, especially at the level of antibiotics for animals, which are found in our diet and thereby affect humans. I share the findings and concerns expressed in this report, and I therefore support the recommendations it contains.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Given that human mortality due to antibiotic resistance is increasing every year and is becoming an increasing problem, this issue needs to be addressed, including increasing the opportunities for training doctors and enhancing information on the use of drugs.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report.  Patient safety is a key element of healthcare systems. The essence of treatment must be the well-being of the patient. It is therefore necessary to continuously improve patient safety and to remove obstacles to improving patient safety.  It should be noted that health care is becoming more complex and risky. Quality assurance and its continuous improvement, with a particular focus on health safety, are therefore an important challenge.  In particular, it is necessary to ensure adequate funding for health systems. The funds allocated to health care systems cannot be allowed to be unjustifiably cared through in order to save money. Austerity measures must not affect patient safety.  In addition, investment in continuing training, monitoring of medical and healthcare services, early warning systems and prevention should be encouraged.  In order to reduce the use of antibiotics, specific ambitious targets should be set.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that this report addresses a very sensitive issue, as the need to ensure maximum patient safety in not suffering harm as a result of treatment is a primary aspect in an appropriate health system.  The problem concerns the excessive, and in some cases unnecessary, use of antibiotics, the consequence of which is a reduction in the effectiveness of the antimicrobial, and ECDC, EMA and EFSA data show that this phenomenon is on the increase in EU hospitals. Further misuse of antibiotics takes place in the forced feeding of animals intended for human consumption.  While this practice was rightly banned in the EU in 2006, there is still a lack of adequate patient safety policies at national level as well as appropriate coordination between Member States. A new proactive impetus is needed for research and development of new alternative medicines.  It is unacceptable for austerity measures in Europe to undermine the quality of the health service. I hope that the Commission will continue its efforts to monitor Member States' progress in the field of patient safety and the development of new medicines.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas for the global quality of healthcare it is essential to ensure the safety of patients, whose essential aspects are the culture of health and the management of adverse events; that the volume of data available on the prevalence and incidence of adverse events in member states' health systems is currently limited, but constantly increasing, and that the latest available data date back to 2008; that it is estimated that between 8 and 12% of patients admitted to EU hospitals are victims of adverse events related to the treatment received, and that around half of the cases could be avoided; I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Healthcare should focus on patients and should not suffer from unfounded cost-cutting due to savings as this report warns, and that is why I supported it. Quality health service to our citizens depends on the quality and good organization of the system, investing in the education of doctors and research and development of medicines and equipment.  Seemingly the cheapest solutions are not always both the cheapest and the best for patients. The report also warns against inappropriate use of antibiotics that are often issued for viral infections that are not affected or prescribed in insufficiently clear and general diagnoses.  Due to inappropriate use of antibiotics, the number and types of resistant bacteria have increased. This is a serious growing health problem in hospitals across the EU and it is necessary to take long-term action to prevent the emergence, selection and transmission of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. This resolution is part of the work of the Commission and Member States to improve care and, more specifically, to combat the development of antibiotic resistance. This phenomenon is massive, dangerous and irreversible. The proposed text was unanimously supported by the ENVI committee. In particular, it proposes better training for hospital staff. It calls for measures adapted to the disparity in the states and a more responsible use of antibiotics in human and veterinary medicine. This proposal is broadly in the right direction, although I regret that the amendments proposed by my colleagues in committee have not been adopted. They proposed more sovereignty, less austerity (responsible for budget cuts in hospitals), control of borders to avoid contagion (including tuberculosis), more training and recognition of health workers, for example the efforts of French veterinarians to reduce the consumption of antibiotics. I vote for this text, which remains positive as a whole.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The main dimension of overall quality of healthcare is patient safety. The issue exists in the assessment that 8-12% of those hospitalised in the EU are victims of adverse healthcare-related events provided to them, and half of these better conditions could be prevented. Such adverse events are most often the result of hospital infections, effects of drugs and complications caused during or after surgical procedures.  Patient safety and quality of healthcare require more decent working and safety conditions but in today's conditions it is difficult to guarantee patient health safety, and the problem exists in the absence of staff employed in healthcare facilities. It is estimated that the total expenditure on the continuous issuance of sufficient quantities of medicines and the provision of health activities to prevent harmful effects amount to these burdens of the European Union budget by EUR 2.7 billion per year. Due to these arguments, I support colleague Pedicini's report.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the approach of the report, which gives priority to patient safety and its protection in not suffering harm as a result of therapeutic treatment, and which places it as an essential element for the quality of health systems. I do not believe that the measures put in place by the austerity regime justify cuts in the health system. On the contrary, it is necessary to invest in the continuous training of staff of health facilities, in new and clean facilities, in increasingly complete and performing machinery and in preventive preparation actions that can block harmful events for the patient. I think that the report raises the problem: the ultimate aim must be to ensure the highest possible level of patient safety standards in all health facilities in the EU.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In the face of a growing number of cases of patients contracting diseases in hospitals, the EU has decided to take action and strengthen patient safety in Europe. MEPs adopted a report on Tuesday on improving patient safety and combating antimicrobial resistance. I have spoken in favour of this text and I consider it now essential to strengthen cooperation between national systems and to encourage each Member State to step up its efforts to further protect patients.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Patient safety and the fight against drug resistance are a central place in the management of health systems. In fact, according to the available data, 8% to 12% of hospitalized patients suffer damage or adverse events, estimating that about half of these adverse events could be avoided. On the other hand, antimicrobial resistance to pathogens by pathogenic bacteria has increased worldwide, leading to an increasing prevalence of HAIs and failures in the treatment of infectious diseases. This report attempts to identify the various factors that compromise patient safety by identifying measures to be taken to ensure as high a standard of patient safety as possible. I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this report as we feel it attempts to harmonise laws. We feel the UK already has an excellent regime for regulating resistance to antibiotics, and fear an EU scheme would undercut this via harmonisation. This would put public health at risk, which is unacceptable to us. A UK independent of the EU would work with the WHO and other international bodies, as we feel they have a legitimacy the EU does not. We feel any developments in this field should be science—led, with the consultation of parties which are impacted by any changes

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. 2012 37,000 people in Europe, 3,000 in Belgium, these are the worrying figures, each year, of the number of deaths due to hospital-acquired infection or resistance to antibiotics. Across the EU-28, more than 3 million people are infected annually in health care facilities. The most common are urinary tract infections, pneumonia, infections in the area of the body that has been operated on and generalized infections, such as sepsis and bacteremia. The adoption by this lunchtime plenary of the Pedicini report on safer health care in Europe is important and provides an update on the spread of microbes, particularly in hospitals. I take two key proposals to curb the phenomenon: invest in the research of new effective antibiotics, especially against diseases particularly likely to be resistant to antimicrobials, such as K. pneumoniae, E. HIV, golden staph or tuberculosis; strengthen intensive hygiene and control programs, in particular early detection of resistance strains and isolation of patients with serious bacterial infections.  Clearly, the subject of hospital-acquired infections must become a public health priority.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union and the European Parliament itself should play an active role in the healthcare provided by their Member States. Improving patient safety and combating antimicrobial resistance are critical today. This motion for a resolution generally points to gaps that may exist in the environment in question and also warns of some care to be taken in national health systems. All Member States should invest in a national health system that is appropriate to the needs of their population. We must continue to invest in the field of research into new and effective drugs and, in this context, highlight partnerships with universities.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. According to the Eurobarometer, for 50% of Europeans, healthcare can be harmful to patients. 25% said they or members of their family had experienced adverse events, passing cases of patient complaints to 46% in the period 2009-2014. More than 8-12% of patients hospitalized in the EU, some 3 million people, suffer harm or adverse events (infections associated with healthcare, nosocomial or not). This report arises in response to the Commission's second assessment report on patient safety, which shows that there is a greater degree of awareness but significant differences persist between Member States in relation to patient safety strategies, their empowerment, the training of professionals and, in general, the prevention and control of nosocomial infections. Member States are requested to act on the sustainability of quality health systems, the development of patient safety strategies, training in the control and prevention of nosocomial infections or the promotion of research in search of new antimicrobials. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Yesterday, in the plenary session, we adopted by 637 votes in favour, 32 against and 10 abstentions a resolution in favour of safer health care. Deploring the negative effects of the economic crisis on national health budgets, the text of the resolution calls on Member States to ensure that patient safety is not affected. In addition, we have proposed measures to make antibiotics more responsibly used, such as prescription-only use, pre-prescription microbiological diagnosis, marketing practices to prevent conflicts of interest between producers and prescribers, better information and increased monitoring. We also called on pharmaceutical companies to invest in new antimicrobials and called on the Commission to put in place a legislative framework to encourage the development of new antibiotics. Finally, we advocated limited use of antibiotics in veterinary medicine, with this use limited for therapeutic purposes.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this initiative report, which makes recommendations to improve patient safety and combat antimicrobial resistance. Every year, 25,000 people die from antibiotic-resistant bacteria. In this sense, we must continue to support and stimulate research in this sector, particularly in antibiotic therapy. Despite the economic and financial crisis and the austerity measures that can be put in place, it is important that Member States ensure a sufficient level of funding for health systems.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Health care in Europe is an important issue, to which due attention must be paid. Even today, a considerable number of patients contract infections that can be associated with the care received; infections, which could be avoided through the adoption and implementation of hygiene standards and more effective control programs.  The report presented by Mr De Clercq, on behalf of the Committee on The Pedicini takes stock of the situation six years after the recommendation issued by the Council to identify the way forward to increase patient safety. While many Member States have followed these guidelines and taken effective measures, the economic crisis has slowed down the implementation of this regulation. We can only continue along this path, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour because I think it is a good thing that Parliament is asking the Commission to continue to monitor consistently the progress of the Member States in relation to the recommendations made by Parliament itself and the Council, informing the public of all further progress in the field of patient safety.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour because we believe it is essential that Member States take measures to improve the quality of health care. Health cuts have resulted in increased antibiotic resistance and the spread of certain deadly diseases. We cannot allow health and health in the broad sense not to be one of the priorities of a responsible agenda.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution dealing with various aspects of the safety of the healthcare provided. This is a serious issue that is closely linked to working conditions in the health sector in the context of its funding, to the training of health professionals, to the proper information of patients and the public about the various risks. The report also deals with the responsibility and role of pharmaceutical companies in the health system. The report deals with the important issues of antimicrobial resistance, the causes of its occurrence and preventive measures. Available antibiotics must be used with care and expediend. In the first place must clearly be the safety of the patient.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report aims to ensure improved patient safety by identifying and correcting health care factors that may pose an added risk to the health of the population. In particular, the report expresses concern about the misuse of certain medicines, such as antibiotics, whether by commercial pressure, insufficient public funding, lack of training or bad practices, against which it requires greater collaboration between States and increased legislative activity. It also criticizes livestock abuses, where indiscriminate use of antibiotics is an attack on public health.  It also recalls the importance of the prevention and good training of medical staff, as well as the good hygienic conditions of hospitals. In this sense, it criticizes the effects of austerity and calls for ensuring good funding of the health system. Since I share many of the report's conclusions and recommendations, I voted in favour.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Currently between 8 and 12% of patients admitted to health facilities in the European Union contract infections during treatment, many of which could be foreseen in advance and therefore avoided. As this is a particularly widespread problem, I welcome Parliament's report on safer health care in Europe.  In my opinion, our main objective must be to put the patient at the centre of the health system. Firstly, policies to reduce health budgets should not have a negative effect on citizens' health by undermining the possibility of ensuring the best safety standards during hospitalisation. In addition, in order to improve the control of infections in hospitals, responsible and targeted use of antibiotics in both the medical and veterinary field should be encouraged, so as to reduce antimicrobial resistance. Finally, I hope that the Commission will monitor Member States' patient safety policies on the basis of the recommendations made by this Parliament.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Health systems in the EU should be guided primarily by the patient's well-being. While this seems obvious, we sometimes see all sorts of actions that indirectly undermine this principle. Looking for savings in areas that have a direct impact on the quality of treatment can lead to undesirable effects.  Many of these undesirable factors are eliminateable, but it is important to ensure that the sector has an adequate number of qualified professionals who need to be provided with adequate working conditions so that they can effectively fulfil their duties. Care for hygiene is also particularly noteworthy – in this area we sometimes see the dismantling of posts in order to make savings. However, it should be borne in mind that such savings are depneous, as any compromise that hospitals make in the area of cleanliness can result in health complications for patients, the fight against which costs much more than the cost of hygiene.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs today voted to call for action to improve patient safety and fight antimicrobial resistance, and ease the burden this places on overstretched health systems.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 An estimated 10 million people worldwide will die every year by 2050 as a result of the emergence of new super bacteria resistant to all antibiotics. The alarming situation needs adequate solutions. For this reason, I voted in favour of adopting the resolution on safer healthcare in Europe.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – I supported the report on safer healthcare because I consider patient safety and the fight against drug resistance to be a very important role for the whole of the EU and individual Member States. Patient safety, as well as the right of the patient not to suffer harm as a result of the provision of healthcare, must be a crucial element in the quality of healthcare provision. According to available data, up to 8-12% of EU hospitalised patients will suffer harm or suffer an adverse event, including preventable healthcare-related infections. And that's what we're talking about with 3 million people with inaccurate and not always up-to-date data collection from health care providers. There is uneven progress in the area of patient safety in individual Member States. I am glad that Slovakia is 4-13% in the safer healthcare group. Paradoxically, patients are often also threatened by doctors themselves, who prescribe antibiotics in many diseases (e.g. viral diseases against which antibiotics have no effect), thus building patients resistant to common antimicrobials. Self-treatment with antibiotics should also be strictly prohibited, which should be preceded by a thorough outreach to medical staff, the media and perhaps an EU-wide explanatory campaign.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. In the last 70 years, antimicrobials have dramatically reduced the number of deaths from infectious diseases. However, excessive and improper use of these drugs has made many microorganisms resistant to them. According to 2011 data, 25 000 people die every year in the EU from infections caused by drug-resistant microbes. The cost of health care and the loss of productivity due to antimicrobial resistance are estimated to be EUR 1.5 billion per year. Less-aware people were found to be more likely to use antibiotics. As many as 30 to 50% of patients do not take medicines prescribed by doctors or take them without following instructions. One of the main causes of antimicrobial resistance is therefore the misuse of antibiotics and their overuse. Patients are under-informed about the possibilities of treating diseases without antibiotics. We have the wrong feeling that we don't do any harm with antibiotics, but we can benefit, so we quickly reach for antibiotics. Bacteria are old, adaptable creatures, so we need to be more prudent and use the means against them only when they are absolutely necessary.  As the report contains a series of proposals on how Member States can raise patient awareness of antibiotic use, I voted to support it.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Ensuring better healthcare and improving patient safety is a necessary step to improve the health system. Moreover, it is essential to streamline the use of funds, as well as to ensure a more responsible use of existing therapies and to promote innovation.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒It is estimated that between 8 and 12% of patients hospitalised in the European Union are victims of adverse health care events provided to them. Most often it is hospital infections, the effects of drugs and complications that arise during or after surgical procedures. Hospital infections are a major burden on health service budgets, which are put a lot of pressure on the current economic crisis, which is affecting patient safety, as many Member States cut budgets and staffing levels in health systems with severe cuts, rather than finding solutions to the issue of efficiency. As noted in the Report, the increased prevalence of hospital infections, and failure to treat infectious diseases occurs due to increased antimicrobial resistance of pathogenic bacteria caused by the systematic and incorrect use of antimicrobials. For all of the above, I agree with this Report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒  I voted in favour of this report as it urges Member States to improve patient safety and fight antimicrobial resistance, as well as easing the burden this places on overstretched health systems.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Safer Healthcare Report in Europe – improving patient safety and combating antimicrobial resistance, as the main dimension of overall quality of healthcare is patient safety whose fundamental aspects are healthcare cultures and managing undesirable effects of the medicine. Constant training of doctors and other healthcare professionals is essential to prevent adverse events. Electronic healthcare (eHealth) and treatment at home where everything is in the service of the patient have great potential to improve the quality and effectiveness of treatment while at the same time contributing to better provision of healthcare. Treatment at home can also help patients on a psychological level and achieve better results in providing healthcare. A multidisciplinary approach increases the chances of positive treatment outcomes.  It is of utmost importance to encourage pharmaceutical companies to invest and continue to invest in the development of new antimicrobials, especially active against diseases for which antimicrobial resistance poses a major danger and to develop other methods to fight hospital infections without using antibiotics. This can be achieved by stimulating R&D investments that focus on the greatest public health needs while protecting the sustainability of national health systems.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal because it calls on Member States, in particular, to cooperate more deeply in the field of health care and to disseminate best practices in its implementation, which can help.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on safer healthcare in Europe. It is a report that is of particular importance to all of us. It is of great concern that 8-12% of patients are victims of hospital-acquired infections. Every year, 25 000 citizens die from such infections. In light of this, I would like to draw attention to the infections in hospitals that make patients sick. Many hospitals have reduced the number of people who care for cleanliness and hygiene as a result of austerity, which should be given more attention. It's easier to take care of prevention than to limit the spread of infections in hospitals.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome a large number of the recommendations made in this report to improve patient safety and address the crucial issue of AMR.  In particular, the need for a greater emphasis on training all staff in infection prevention and control highlighted in this report: a comprehensive and team approach will ensure consistent good practices in infection prevention and control are present throughout our healthcare systems.  The report also rightly emphasises the growing gap between increasing antimicrobial resistance and the development of new antibiotics. I welcome calls to accelerate R&D activities in the field of antimicrobial medicines and to create greater incentives for public and private sector collaboration. Finally, the ʽOne Healthʼ approach to AMR is essential given that our human and animal health systems are interconnected and tackling AMR requires a cross-sector approach, with policies developed accordingly. We must however ensure that any future action to address the risks of AMR developing in animals is based on sound scientific evidence and expert advice.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We consider issues related to citizens' health to be very important. Therefore, general patient safety and healthcare-related infections, which are addressed in this Council recommendation, are of paramount importance. As demonstrated by the Commission's first report in 2012, there is a need for greater effort in many areas (e.g. education and training of nursing staff, strengthening patients' rights, developing a climate of error doctrine). Unfortunately, the impact of the economic crisis is also evident in this area, as the cuts, as the report acknowledges, have slowed down. Although the EU's neoliberal policies limit the applicability of a proper health policy, any individual effort in this direction must be based. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Proposes measures to combat the reckless use of antibiotics, measures which, even if we do not fully agree on everything, must be taken, since the current situation can be extremely dangerous to public health.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on safer health care, which helps prevent and combat healthcare-related infections. The report deals with the control of serious cross-border health threats, which I believe is in our common European interest. The report points to the sad phenomenon that between 8% and 12% of patients receiving hospital care in the EU experience adverse events in healthcare that could be avoided. I believe that, in the interests of patient safety and quality healthcare, it is essential that healthcare professionals can work in decent working conditions and in a safe workplace. Personally, I also welcome the improvement of the EU monitoring system for healthcare-related infections, and I regret that, in terms of patient safety, the relative development of Member States is uneven. I agree that austerity measures should not affect health systems and that an adequate level of funding for these systems should be maintained; Member States should therefore, in particular, avoid measures causing injury. The report calls on the Member States to ensure that a more patient-centred approach is introduced and that an adequate team of healthcare professionals is available to this end; it also encourages Member States, including Hungary, to ensure equal access to health services for patients in order to eliminate health inequalities.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am particularly pleased with the own-initiative report that Mr Pedicini has drawn up, negotiated and brought to the vote. At the basis of every diagnosis and treatment, both human and animal, there must be important and concrete considerations on the responsible and targeted use of antibiotics. But these considerations must be even stronger and more present when it comes not to care, but to farming practices. Antimicrobial resistance is also growing rapidly due to the misuse of antibiotics in livestock. The problem is global in scope and it is for these reasons that reiterating our opposition to these practices (although already banned in the EU) is also particularly important in preventing circumvention of these cornerstones in bilateral negotiations for free trade agreements such as TTIP.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Patient safety and the fight against drug resistance, in particular antimicrobial resistance, are certainly not unknown themes of the actors who manage health systems, nor of the people who have attended the rooms of the European Parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety in recent years. In this context, this initiative report is a good move.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which tackles a growing and concerning healthcare challenge for Europe: antimicrobial resistance. In this respect, I think we need to increase research and development on new antimicrobials to ensure the EU can provide an appropriate and timely response to this issue. It is also extremely important to have precise data on the use of animal microbials, and therefore I support the provision on the creation of a EU database on the matter. As regards the sales of antibiotics, I support the call to de-link it from the reward paid for a new antibiotic: we need to look for the right balance between a sufficient return on investment for the producing company and the purchaser having full control over the volumes he buys. Eventually the report calls on Member States to provide up-to-date trainings of healthcare professionals on the use of antibiotics for both human and veterinary medicine.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Health problems, i.e. the rise in infections as a result of inadequate healthcare and anti-microbial resistance require a multidisciplinary approach to provide adequate healthcare and patient protection in the Member States.  I support this Report because it highlights how the main backbone of healthcare is patient safety, with the consequences of medical errors at the hospital to be kept to a minimum. I welcome the recognition of the role of vaccines that can limit the use of antibiotics, including the development of antimicrobial resistance. When addressing such health issues with a direct impact on the quality of human lives, we can significantly reduce unnecessary costs and thus relieve already limited state budgets.  Free healthcare does not exist, so we can say that health also has a price. Therefore, I believe that only a multidisciplinary approach as well as cooperation with patients can ensure safer and more efficient healthcare. I agree that patients and other entities should be given a more significant role in the public policymaking process and that is why I supported this Report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i supported the report on safer healthcare in Europe. Between 8% and 12% of patients in the EU suffer from adverse events such as medically care-related infections, drug-related events and complications that occur during or after surgery. It would be possible to prevent as many as 20-30% of infections if hygiene standards and control programmes were stricter. The EU Council recommendation called on Member States to implement measures that would raise patient safety levels. The European Commission has published a second implementation report expressing concern about the progress made by certain Member States.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Making health care safer increases the chance of positive outcomes for treatment, helps prevent a large proportion of deaths and contributes to the breakthrough of the health industry in Europe.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this because we believe it is essential that Member States take measures to improve the quality of health care. Health cuts have resulted in increased antibiotic resistance and the spread of certain deadly diseases. We cannot allow health and health in the broad sense not to be one of the priorities of a responsible agenda.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The safety of people is one of the key issues when we talk about public health and therefore I am in favour of any proposal to help improving this – not just talking about giving good service. But also there is a significant percentage of people who self-medicate or do not take the pills of the doctor’s prescription. Resistance to antibiotics is increasing and the forecasts are not very encouraging for the future if we do not face this issue in the coming months.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. This resolution is part of the work of the Commission and Member States to improve care and, more specifically, antibiotic resistance. The latter phenomenon is massive, dangerous and irreversible. This resistance is due to the misuse of antibiotics that fight diseases caused by bacteria. These misuses are made by self-medication, poor prescribing, or non-therapeutic use. Worldwide, antibiotics are used in large quantities as growth factors for livestock (a practice banned in the EU since 2006 but allowed in the US). By natural selection, only resistant bacteria survive the treatment, only to escape it later. To date, 37,000 people have died in the EU and the projections are frightening. In particular, the text proposes better training for hospital staff. It calls for a more responsible use of antibiotics in human medicine as well as veterinary medicine. This proposal is broadly in the right direction. We proposed more sovereignty, less austerity, control of borders to avoid contagion, more training and recognition of health care workers, including the efforts of French veterinarians to reduce the consumption of antibiotics, but our amendments were rejected. I'm voting for it, though.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour because we believe it is essential that Member States take measures to improve the quality of health care. Health cuts have resulted in increased antibiotic resistance and the spread of certain deadly diseases. We cannot allow health and health in the broad sense not to be one of the priorities of a responsible agenda.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution concerning the ‘Safer healthcare in Europe’. The annual deaths of 37 000 patients in the EU caused by in—healthcare infections underlines the necessity of this resolution.  This resolution will succeed in improving patients’ safety, as it highlights the danger of tight healthcare budgets which have had an impact on patients’ and on hospitals’ staff safety.             I believe and hope that by supporting this resolution and also its proper implementation, the death of 37 000 patients will become a thing of the past in the near future.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 We are talking about a topic of great importance: health. Europe must continue to enjoy health systems with high safety standards, so I think it appropriate to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report aims to ensure improved patient safety by identifying and correcting health care factors that may pose an added risk to the health of the population. In particular, the report expresses concern about the misuse of certain medicines, such as antibiotics, whether by commercial pressure, insufficient public funding, lack of training or bad practices, against which it requires greater collaboration between States and increased legislative activity. It also criticizes livestock abuses, where indiscriminate use of antibiotics is an attack on public health.  It also recalls the importance of the prevention and good training of medical staff, as well as the good hygienic conditions of hospitals. In this sense, it criticizes the effects of austerity and calls for ensuring good funding of the health system. Since I share many of the report's conclusions and recommendations, I voted in favour.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ My European Parliament Labour Party colleagues and I voted in favour of this report because it calls for action to improve patient safety and fight antimicrobial resistance, to ease the burden this places on overstretched health systems.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 Improving patient safety and combating antimicrobial resistance are of the utmost importance. Access to efficient healthcare is a basic right in the EU. Although clear progress has been made since 2012, the battle has not yet been fought. By exchanging good practice and efficient solutions between Member States, we can only take the necessary steps forward. I have therefore supported this report.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Routine prescribing of antibiotics is causing a growing problem of public health and resistance of bacteria limiting the capacity of the remaining treatments. Building on the first joint report of three EU agencies on antibiotic resistance, the European Parliament regrets the uneven implementation of the Council's recommendation on patient safety, due in particular to state budget cuts in the area of health, austerity measures having consequences on patient health and working conditions in hospitals. He also denounces the link between the use of antimicrobials in agriculture and human health. To improve the use of antibiotics, this report proposes to strictly regulate their dosages and to separate the volume of sales from the remuneration paid for a new antibiotic, as well as compensation for patients who have suffered therapeutic harm. I therefore voted in favour of the European Parliament's report, which reminds Member States of their obligations in relation to a recommendation that goes in the direction of improving public health. But I remain under no illusions because of the current budget cuts.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The costs caused by drug-resistant infections amount to around EUR 1.5 billion each year due to increased health expenditure and productivity losses, whereas patients infected with resistant bacteria have to be isolated when treated in hospital and that this additional provision costs more than EUR 900 million and an additional 2.5 million days of hospital stay per year. These resistances stem from a fundamental contradiction that lies in the incompatibility between the moderate use of antibiotics and the needs of the pharmaceutical industry to maximize its profits and monetize its investments. Unfortunately, we haven't heard a word about this. In this way, no changes to this drama are envisaged.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against the report on safe healthcare in Europe because I do not consider the report as a whole to be useful – including the requirement that veterinarians should not prescribe or sell prescriptions, but also the call for a ban on the preventive use of antimicrobials.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. The report "Safe Healthcare in Europe" discusses recommendations for effective cooperation at European and international level in the fight against treatment-associated infections and antibiotic resistance. I support the recognition of the role of vaccination, which can limit the use of antibiotics and, therefore, the development of antibiotic resistance. The report refers to the World Health Organisation's 'One Health' approach and points out that human and animal health and ecosystems are interlinked. Health measures should be developed accordingly. My group, the ECR, supports the call for more cooperation between the public and private sectors in order to revitalise research and development in the field of antibiotics. I am happy to support the report's recommendation that the training of all health professionals is important in order to prevent the spread of therapy-associated infections. Infection control and prevention should not be the responsibility of unskilled skilled workers. In the end, my group was able to prevent the sale of antibacterial soap from being gradually banned in the EU. That is one of the reasons why the final version of the report is perfectly compatible with the political line of my group, and that is why I agree with it.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is the European Parliament’s response to a Commission report evaluating how Member States have implemented recommendations to improve patient safety and prevent healthcare associated infections (HAIs). It calls for Member States to take further action to ensure adequate funding, better monitoring of HAIs and on-going training for healthcare professionals to reduce infection rates. The report also encourages responsible use of antibiotics, and calls on Member States to highlight the dangers of antibiotic resistance. Labour MEPs voted for this report because it calls for action to improve patient safety and fight antimicrobial resistance, to ease the burden this places on overstretched health systems.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on ensuring safer health care in Europe: improving patient safety and combating antimicrobial resistance. I welcome the fact that the rapporteur has produced this report on the basis of the need to recognise patient safety, the patient's right not to suffer damage or potential damage as a result of medical treatment, as an essential element of the quality of health systems. It is important that the report also refers to the Commission's 2012 findings that patient safety is at risk by economic austerity measures that require horizontal funding cuts in the healthcare sector and have a direct impact on the quality of treatments. Another key element highlighted by the report concerns the slowdown in research into the finding of new alternative medicines.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this initiative. This report, inter alia, strengthens healthcare research taking into account the involvement of all official specialised organisations as well as the EU institutions. At the same time, it sets out conditions that should be considered for improving health services and patient safety, while strengthening dialogue on important health issues such as antibiotic resistance.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on safer health care in Europe. The report concerns the way in which Member States are implementing the Council's recommendations on how to increase patient safety. I think it is extremely appropriate to keep a high level of attention and ensure constant monitoring to minimise adverse events affecting patients during hospitalizations and the administration of medical services.  I would like to conclude by emphasising the need to promote research and development of new antimicrobials in order to counteract the worrying growth of multi-resistant bacteria.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In my opinion, this proposal is based on the need to ensure, above all, the safety of the patient, so that he does not suffer any harm to health care as a result of health care, and is essential for a quality health system. The alarming fact is that patient safety is often threatened by austerity measures that have an adverse impact on the quality of care, which I think is truly unacceptable. Above all, however, there are problems with the alerting of adverse events and the collection of similar data. For the reasons set out above, I am clearly in favour of improving the health system, which is primarily geared towards the safety and well-being of patients.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome today's result, thanks to which the European Parliament voted, by a large majority, for this important own-initiative report.  Increasing patient safety in health care and combating the threat posed by increased resistance to antimicrobial agents are, in fact, two fundamental objectives that Parliament, the Member States and the Commission, in close synergy, will have to commit themselves to pursuing with greater determination in the coming years. About 10% of hospitalized patients suffer damage or adverse events that could be avoided. It is therefore becoming increasingly urgent and necessary to undertake specific health policies to stem these phenomena, relying on specialised staff, and as far as possible prevent austerity measures from affecting patient safety standards. With regard to antimicrobial resistance, I am convinced that it is becoming increasingly urgent to make doctors and patients more responsible for the targeted use of antibiotics in both human and veterinary medicine; the cost to human and animal health as well as the impact on our economies of antimicrobial resistance is very high and coordinated efforts are therefore needed to raise international awareness of this serious issue.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Between 8 and 12% of patients admitted to hospitals in the EU suffer from adverse effects while receiving medical care, the most common being healthcare-associated infections (HAIs), medication-related events and complications arising from surgical interventions. Almost half of these events could be avoided. IACS, in particular, is a preventable public health problem through intensive hygiene and control programs. Antimicrobial resistance has increased in the EU for pathogenic bacteria which has led to an increase in HAIs caused by multidrug-resistant bacteria, a public health problem. The report comprehensively and documented this theme. It refers to the effects of disinvestment in public health services and their professionals as a result of so-called austerity policies and advocates the reversal of this path. We voted in favour.

name: Jens Rohde (ALDE).
text: Madam. President! I have now completely messed up because, just now, when dealing with health services and antibiotics, I came to say what I should actually be saying now. Fortunately, there are not very many, apart from the interpreters, who notice when you get to change the speeches. Maybe the President did too. It must have sounded strange in many people's ears.  Since things are not going to be more correct by being repeated, I shall refrain from repeating my speech before and then just leave it at that.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – I supported the adoption of this report because small and medium-sized enterprises must play a prominent role in the green economy. The global annual market for this economy is in the order of EUR 1 000 billion and could be double by 2020. Why is it important for small and medium-sized enterprises to play a fundamental role in this economy? Because the development of the economy cannot be an end in itself, and small and medium-sized enterprises receive 67% of jobs in the European Union. That is why they should also be assisted in this regard by lending and granting tenders. In this context, I find it particularly strange that the european fund for strategic investments extends the benefit to small and medium-sized enterprises to large firms with 3 000 people, so that it does not really help this group of job-creating enterprises.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Madam President, not only is it important that we address the issue of financing for SMEs, but also that we help them cut the cost of going green. In my region, the West Midlands, EU funding has been instrumental in driving forward the development of our region into one of the largest low-carbon environmental goods and services sectors, in terms of sales, in the UK. So it is imperative that we continue to build on this effort, given that nearly half of the SMEs in my region indicate that they are still struggling to access finance for these types of initiatives.  There is a real job of work to be done here. Crucial in getting my support for this were the points that were championed by my Group, namely including making sure that proper attention is given to micro—enterprises and start-ups, and tapping the full potential of funds by establishing industrial synergies, symbioses and clusters. We owe it to our SMEs to use the means at our disposal in the most efficient way possible. That is why I think it is a missed opportunity that this report stops short of offering concrete initiatives on these points.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the European Union, its science, technology and economy need a new strong incentive to grow and preserve its high position on the world market, and that is why I supported this report. However, this growth must include the benefits that the EU has while reducing unnecessary costs and outflows of funds such as energy and energy imports.  Policies such as green growth and the circular economy, coupled with serious sources of funding and private sector participation, are the answer to these efforts. However, Europe's leadership position in the economy is not and must not be its own purpose.  The purpose of a good economic situation is primarily the safety and satisfaction of our citizens. Data on small and medium-sized enterprises, which make up more than 98% of European companies, which provide more than 67% of total employment in the Union and make up 58% of gross value added, are telling us which strategy to take.

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE).
text: Madam. President! I have today supported the own-initiative report on green growth. It is a very good contribution to one of the growth initiatives that will benefit Europe in the future. I really hope that the Commission will closely read the report so that a number of these initiatives can be put on the agenda.  There is no doubt that we have an unfulfilled potential which will increase the competitiveness of European companies in the future. And this applies to both servicing and production. We have a large number of small and medium-sized enterprises that are currently competing on the international market for solutions that include both products and so-called green services, such as planting, installation, repair and management.  Here, too, it is really, really important, when we talk about development and marketing, that these green services should be included in future trade agreements, and I am thinking, above all, of the TTIP agreement.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, this is really where you see the racket exposed, this idea of defending green policies in economic terms. If you wanted to say: ‘there is a price to be paid for ecological goals, we should be prepared to suffer slower growth in order to slow global warming’, that is fine and that is a perfectly reasonable argument with good and sincere people on both sides.  But to say that this will, of itself, stimulate the economy is such a basic economic fallacy that I do not really believe the proponents believe it themselves. It is the exact equivalent of arguing that if the government employed more people, that would create more jobs and therefore they would pay more tax and therefore the economy would grow. It was tried in the Soviet system and we all saw where it led.  The reason it does not work is because of what Frédéric Bastiat calls the theory of seen and unseen costs. You are always taking more out of the economy to create these jobs than they can ever put back into it. The reality is that it is the other way round. It is not the green policies that create the growth. It is the growth that creates the green policies. We have cleaner air and water in developed countries because we can afford it. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí mé anseo arís aréir agus muid ag déanamh díospóireachta ar an ábhar seo. Thug an Coimisinéir an-chur síos ar na moltaí atá anseo agus dar ndóigh bhí an chuid is mó de na daoine ina bhfabhar arís. 519 as 672 ina bhfabhar agus mise ina measc chomh maith.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I supported this report on green growth initiatives and, in particular, the amendment which calls on the Commission to withdraw obsolete and overly burdensome legislation. In simple language, to cut red tape, or – in this case – maybe green tape. There is always a balance to be struck between proportionate and effective regulation. Regulation which can often be unworkable is hugely burdensome and, in many cases, does not even attain its own objectives. Time and time again, we hear politicians complaining about red tape and EU bureaucracy in their own Member States. They point the finger at the EU. It is usually a case of blaming Brussels. Yet, when we have the opportunity to support the Commission’s proposal to withdraw obsolete and overly bureaucratic legislation, many will vote against it. One cannot have it both ways.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Madam President, this report by colleague De Backer on green growth opportunities for SMEs relates to the efficient and sustainable use of energy resources and new technologies and highlights the need for what is of u u essence, which is transparent, quality information to entrepreneurs. The Green Growth Action Plan provides guidance to all Member States on how to help SMEs benefit from european union funding given with a view to moving towards a green economy.  SMEs that are the cornerstone of the economy and crucial to initiating growth and development need support and assistance in actively using opportunities open at EU level. That is why I supported my colleague De Backer's report on green growth as an incentive to turn environmental challenges into opportunities for sustainable growth and development with the aim of a better quality of life for all citizens of the European Union.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report correctly identifies ecological and environmental efficiency as one of the main challenges for SMEs in the coming years. Thus, it states that investment in research and development and adequate financing of SMEs should be prioritized to facilitate the transition to an environmentally sustainable economy, integrating both objectives into the Commission's programmes. However, the report is hostage to neoliberal assumptions, as it is more committed to entrepreneurship, foreign investment or deregulation than to public planning and the protection of workers and consumers as central axes of the transition to an environmentally and socially sustainable economy. It is also ambiguous in not specifying how 'green' growth can be reconciled with the proposal for a 'circular' economy. For all this, I abstained.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This project has positive aspects, such as the desire to reduce burdens and reduce business regulations or promote entrepreneurship in education curricula. These good ideas should not hide the reality of the project. Once again, the European Union is trying to interfere with the competences of States by encouraging the Commission to act, through standards, against states as well as for school curricula, which are a national competence. Neo-liberal deregulation is repeatedly highlighted. For these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed this measure as I believe that this should be a matter for national Parliaments not the European Union.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it highlights the great potential of green growth, which can only be fully exploited if certain fundamental conditions are met.  These conditions include, for example, the creation of a more entrepreneurial mentality, the definition of transparent rules conducive to innovation, the diversification of access to finance or the proliferation of opportunities for knowledge sharing.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to encourage SMEs to reap the benefits of green growth. Firstly, it is necessary to assess the potential of the green economy and to understand the difficulties currently faced by SMEs, in particular in the field of products, production processes, business practices and greening services. While the various public support systems can to some extent stimulate research, development and innovation, a stable and innovation-friendly regulatory and investment framework is a key driver. I agree that over-regulation and different interpretations of the various regulators increase the burden on SMEs and create obstacles to the functioning of the internal market, and this problem needs to be addressed urgently.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. It was important for Parliament to be able to position itself on this issue of the future of SMEs in Europe. I am pleased to see that we have been able to instil concrete measures on green growth among SMEs. Green growth sectors have economic and ecological benefits for SMEs in the EU and are expected to grow significantly in the coming years. The initial idea is that economic growth and environmental sustainability can go hand in hand. SMEs are the backbone of the European economy and are an important driver of economic growth and job creation. The vast potential of the green economy can only be fully exploited in the presence of a suitable framework for research, development and innovation.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The green economy holds great potential for the growth opportunities it offers to SMEs. There are many difficulties these companies face at all levels, both in terms of production, business practices or access to finance. According to the Central Directory of Companies (DIRCE), there are more than three million companies in Spain, of which 99.88% are SMEs. In the rest of Europe the scenario is the same and SMEs generate two out of three private sector jobs, as well as more than half of the total value added created by companies in the EU. The European Commission's Eco-Action Plan for SMEs envisages improving resource utilization, supporting green entrepreneurship, exploiting opportunities and facilitating market access. An excellent and properly implemented initiative will have a capital value for our companies.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report, which should promote green investment for SMEs with several objectives: supporting the various financing and development solutions of SMEs in the green economy, improving information for SMEs on available financing, demanding tax policies favourable to venture capital in the States, combating over-regulation and supporting the promotion of entrepreneurship in education programmes. While, of course, at first glance, we can agree with several objectives of this report, we can only deplore the lack of concrete and normative proposals in this report. It does not mention funding methods and worse, it encroaches on the competences of states such as regulation or education. Finally, the report contains a page devoted entirely to deregulation, which thus enshrines the ultra-liberal vision of the EU. I abstained on this report in light of the above elements.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although there are passages in this report that we seem to support, I believe that the vision of 'green growth' for SMEs that inspires the text being voted on is extremely optimistic and underestimates the real situation of the market and the economic crisis faced daily by small and medium-sized enterprises in Europe, and especially in Italy. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted against the De Backer report. Green growth is positive and small business is necessary. The problem is that this report has embedded completely different policy proposals in the text. Particularly negative are the wordingin support for general deregulation, which in the EU has often proved to be about undermining labour law, collective agreements and trade unions' position in the labour market. The report also proposes a new EU resource centre. But it is not more EUROPEAN bureaucratic institutions that are needed to boost green growth.  What is needed is a new green investment policy that invests in renewable energy and an expanded public welfare sector.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which underlines the economic and employment potential generated by green growth and the circular economy for SMEs, in particular in the exploitation of sectors such as renewable energy sources (in particular wind, solar, hydroelectric and geothermal energy), energy efficiency, resource efficiency, waste management , emission reduction, electrification and 'cradle-to-cradle' design. This will require improving the efficiency of SMEs in resource utilization; support green entrepreneurship; exploit the opportunities presented by greener value chains and the promotion of the circular economy; and facilitate market access for green SMEs for a greener internal market. This report complements the Green Action Plan for SMEs: allowing SMEs to turn environmental challenges into business opportunities, presented by the Commission, which sets out guidance and framework for how the EU, in cooperation with Member States and regions, will help SMEs take advantage of the business opportunities offered by the transition to a green economy.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are the backbone of the European economy and an important driver of growth and jobs. It is important that the potential of the green economy is fully assessed, understanding the difficulties currently faced by SMEs, in particular in the field of products, production processes, business practices and greening services. The Commission's Green SME Action Plan is a very welcome initiative to encourage SMEs to reap the benefits of green growth. As regards SME financing, one of the biggest difficulties in negotiating a credit agreement is the lack of information available to SMEs and creditors. Both sides agree that more communication would improve creditors' understanding of SME credit needs and improve the misunderstanding of the different credit facilities for SMEs. Venture capital, informal investors and crowdfunding should be more clearly distinguished as financing alternatives to normal bank lending. When preparing programmes, measures and initiatives, the Commission should take into account a wide range of financing needs depending on the product, company size, technology, innovation, etc. In particular, the green economy requires a wide choice of measures, as there is still uncertainty about return on investment due to new technologies and business models.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is known that more than 98% of EU businesses are SMEs, and these SMEs account for 67% of the total level of employment in the UNION and 58% of gross value added. It follows that SMEs are the backbone of the European Union's economy and are an important driver of long-term economic growth and job creation in the 28 Member States. It is important for policymakers to fully understand the potential of a green economy, while at the same time being familiar with the difficulties that SMEs are currently facing, in particular as regards the 'greening' of their products, production processes, business practices and services. The Commission's Green Action Plan for SMEs is an initiative aimed at further encouraging SMEs to expand the benefits of green growth. The huge potential of the green economy can only be fully exploited if the right framework is available for research, development and innovation (R&D&I). Although different public funding schemes can encourage R&D&I to some extent, the biggest incentive is an open, stable and innovation-friendly regulatory and investment framework. It is clear that green growth has great potential, but this potential can only be fully exploited if a number of basic conditions are met. These include a stronger emergence of entrepreneurial thinking, the development of open and innovation-friendly rules, the diversification of access to finance or the expansion of opportunities for knowledge sharing.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises are the drivers of economic growth and export policy of the Member States. This is also the result of newly created jobs. Nevertheless, they still have too often difficulties in accessing the fresh capital they need for investments and the expansion of production, mostly due to administrative barriers. That is why I supported the report on the opportunities for green growth for SMEs because it calls on the European Commission to adopt additional support measures, both to facilitate access to risk capital in the early stages and to link the urgently needed creation of specific programmes to link educational institutions with measures to support the green economy and entrepreneurship.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on green growth opportunities for SMEs, an integral part of the circular economy package, which is an important lever for creating a competitive and sustainable European industrial system. Efficient resource management is one of the main drivers of business competitiveness and represents on average 40% of the costs of European manufacturing industry. To date, however, too many SMEs are unaware of this potential and lack sufficient financial support in their efforts to achieve cost savings through better resource management. For this reason, an action plan for SMEs should be implemented as soon as possible, providing practical, advisory and support information on how to make resource management more efficient with a favourable cost-benefit ratio.  In order to achieve improvements in energy efficiency and resources, it will also be necessary to promote efficient green technology transfer mechanisms as well as facilitated forms of access to finance.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ This self-initiative report deals with ways to harness the potentials of "green" growth. A direct reason for producing the report is the European Commission's communication on a "green" economic growth action plan. The rapporteur focused on funding opportunities, resource efficiency, energy efficiency, circular economy and industrial synergies.  "Green" growth should take a broader view and should cover efforts used throughout the value chain and across the entrepreneurial ecosystem. This includes efforts by industrial producers to reduce the environmental footprint of their products, manufacturing processes, business practices and services. In conclusion, I support this report and hope that it will result in concrete moves by the EU.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, in my opinion, it is our duty to try to combine economic growth and environmental sustainability in order to ensure a prosperous future for our continent and our SMEs.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises with their products and services are a fundamental pillar of the European economy and we must guard this pillar and support it in the face of the challenges of the changing world. There is a change that affects us all, linked to a factor that is all too often overlooked: the environment. Environmental policy is not the enemy of development and growth.  Cross-sectoral collaboration, knowledge exchange and investment in research and development are the key to having better and better eco-friendly technologies. The new technologies and the reduction of the bureaucratic – often oppressive – constraints of the SME sector must be coordinated at Union level and must be supported through a European plan: because nowadays there can be no real and productive development in the long term unless this development is also eco-sustainable.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. This report calls on the European Commission to support the various financing solutions for the launch and development of the green economy and insists that states have tax policies favourable to venture capital. This motion for a resolution expresses many good feelings and urges the European Commission to act against the will of the Member States. Moreover, it largely encroaches on the exclusive competences of Member States such as education or deregulation. Finally, the report relays the advocates of the adoption of the TAFTA by using catch-all terms to better mask the scope of the text. Pending clarification, I abstained on the vote on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 SMEs are the core component of the EU economy, with significant long-term growth potential, and the area of sustainable development has a wide range of investment opportunities. By helping businesses invest in sustainable development, we are laying the foundations for an ecosystem that will then self-generate its own development resources. The heterogeneous nature of European SMEs gives them a high degree of adaptation and enables them to create new products. Promoting entrepreneurial culture and creating partnerships, as well as recovery measures in the event of failure, are key elements underpinning the functioning of micro-enterprises. I was in favour of this report because I am convinced that the development of the green economy and bilateral trade agreements will remove obstacles to the development of SMEs and create new opportunities for growth.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted to abstain. My position on sustainable development is based on the deep conviction that, with the right technological innovations, economic growth and environmental protection can be complementary rather than conflicting.  However, historical data show that only relative decoupling has been achieved. In fact, this vision of "green growth", which is also inspired by the report, misrepresents or underestimates the biophysical limits to human production and consumption traced by system dynamics and thermodynamics. In addition, growth and austerity are antithetial to each other, unlike what is repeated in the pro-European refrain, from which this report does not deviate sufficiently.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Green growth, like blue growth, represents significant economic opportunities. SMEs are the main players in the European economy and must therefore have a prominent place in growth plans allowing them to fully reveal their potential. This initiative report is the European Parliament's response to the European Commission's Green Action Plan for SMEs. We must take into account the specifics of SMEs in European legislation. Economic growth and respect for environmental standards are not inseparable. We will be able to find solutions that are both business-friendly and environmentally friendly. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the own-initiative report on green growth opportunities for SMEs to call for more funding, harmonisation of national regulations, bureaucratic simplifications and effective communication to encourage more environmentally sustainable small and medium-sized enterprises. We need more education in entrepreneurship. From the earliest years of school, young people need to be made aware of entrepreneurship and related issues. The spread of the Erasmus programme for young entrepreneurs must therefore be encouraged. Unlike multinational companies, SMEs often do not have access to information and knowledge networks to be updated on technological advances in the green economy. Cross-sectoral cooperation must therefore be actively pursued, offering the possibility of producing innovation and new opportunities for growth through the exchange of innovative ideas and knowledge, through systems of informal knowledge networks. Sectoral federations can play a strategic role in this area by providing appropriate information and advice on eco-friendly technologies, funding possibilities and related procedures.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 SMEs are the lifeblood of a large part of Italian society and anything that can favour them is therefore a priority. At the same time, environmental sustainability is one of our main concerns and an opportunity for growth that is linked to this aspect can only be welcome.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I objected to this report, which, while it has good intentions for the development of the green economy, offers no concrete proposals for project development assistance in this area.  On the other hand, while I am in favour of combating over-regulation and easing legislation on SMEs, this cannot involve an EU encroachment on the competences of Member States, particularly in the field of education, as proposed in the report. The Commission is the thus invited to take action against The Member States, in particular with regard to their fiscal policy, which is an attack on the sovereignty of European nations, which must be able to keep their control over their public policies. Finally, the text claims a neo-liberal philosophy in which the state is denied its role as a strategist. For all these reasons, I have therefore voted against this report.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In order to create more green opportunities for Small and Medium Enterprises in the EU we must take the lead on implementing green policies available to businesses and not burden them with heavy regulatory frameworks. SMEs count for 90% of all EU businesses, and around 45% of SMEs are considered to have a high environmental impact. The majority of these contribute, in some way, to reducing the environmental footprint, such as recycling and minimising waste. However, there are so many more measures that SMEs can be encouraged to take up. This is why it is important for the EU to offer specialised green investment plans to businesses across the EU.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Economic growth in the coming years is undoubtedly linked to the specific sector of the so-called green economy. Indeed, development can no longer ignore investments in eco-friendly products, processes and services. Regardless of environmental protection requirements, more efficient management of natural resources also reduces production costs and increases productivity. It is estimated that better use of resources could lead European industry to make savings totalling EUR 630 billion per year. The transition to a low-carbon economy is certainly a challenge for society, but it also offers new opportunities for growth and development for SMEs. The task of the Member States is to create a favourable environment that will facilitate their access to research and innovation, not only through ad hoc funding but also by streamlining the bureaucratic process to facilitate the placing on the market of innovative products. The report voted on in this House is a step in the right direction, and for these reasons I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I fully agree with highlighting the importance and value of SMEs to the economy of the European Union. Indeed, SMEs account for 98% of European enterprises, accounting for more than 68% of the Union's total employment and 58% of value added. Especially considering that nine out of ten enterprises are small businesses and employ 10 or fewer people and these micro-enterprises provide 53% of all jobs in Europe. They are the eu's main driver of economic growth. It is important that employment in the environmental goods and services sector in the period 2007-2011 increased by 20% despite the crisis . It is even noted that the global market for environmental goods and services amounts to EUR 1 trillion per year and it is projected that this amount will double by 2020 thus creating huge opportunities and opportunities for Europe's SMEs. The EU is right to focus on Green Development by taking initiatives in this direction. Today, the primary objective of all EU countries must be to 'green' their economies.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is based on the Green Action Plan and is an initiative aimed at further stimulating SMEs to develop the benefits of green growth.  While there is no shared definition of green growth at international level, there is consensus that this is a combination of economic growth and environmental sustainability. The resulting opportunities for SMEs are linked to different sectors such as renewable energy sources, in particular the economically sustainable exploitation of wind, solar, water and geothermal energy, energy efficiency, waste management, emission reduction and electrification.
