It was also noted the need for simple and accessible sources of information, the need to encourage start-ups through collaboration with research institutes, universities and vocational training institutes.  Green growth should therefore be part of a broader strategy to promote job creation and economic growth among SMEs.  In the light of these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 SMEs, micro-enterprises, social enterprises and green cooperatives form the backbone of the European economy and are also drivers of economic growth and job creation. Despite their potential, they still face many obstacles as regards their launch, the procedures for applying for European funds, which are still too bureaucratic and therefore prohibitive for some SMEs, or the rules on public procurement, including green and electronic procurement, which are not always clear and uniform at European level. I agree with my colleague, Mr De Backer, that we need to invest on several fronts: firstly, human capital, and therefore young people, by promoting the teaching of entrepreneurial skills and the functioning, as well as the interaction, of various factors such as the market, the economy, the financial system, new technologies and various funding opportunities, especially for the innovative and green sector. Secondly, it is necessary to make full use of the potential offered by the European budget, through its different programmes and funds, in order to allow SMEs access to international markets and to improve the design of more eco-friendly products, production processes, commercial practices and services.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Green growth sectors offer great economic and ecological benefits for SMEs in the EU, and is estimated to grow considerably in the coming years. SMEs and industry associations currently face problems related to financing, research and development and innovation, acquiring the right knowledge and the regulatory framework in place. The report underlines the diversity of SMEs in the EU and advises against one-size-fits-all models. The report also calls for the creation of a more entrepreneurial mind—set, strengthening of the entrepreneurial culture in the EU, developing open and innovation—friendly rules which alleviate regulatory burdens on SMEs, establishing more diverse access to finance and creating more knowledge sharing opportunities. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 SMEs are at the heart of europe's economic fabric and are at the heart of every Member State. I believe that everything parliament does to improve the administrative, regulatory and economic environment in which SMEs must act must be supported.  The report as a whole deals with many issues in an unclear and interpretable way, but it also emphasises many aspects related to the circular economy and resource efficiency. Specifically, I am particularly in favour of the concept reiterated in this dossier, which is linked to the need to shift the tax burden from labour to the use of natural resources. I believe that this is a prerequisite for the lasting success of SMEs in a world with biophysical limits that cannot be overcome. In the next revision of the Small Business Act, we must pay due attention to these considerations and perhaps imagine a Green Small Business Act to stimulate the adoption of business practices that will help the transition of the European economy as quickly as possible.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report correctly identifies ecological and environmental efficiency as one of the main challenges for SMEs in the coming years. Thus, it states that investment in research and development and adequate financing of SMEs should be prioritized to facilitate the transition to an environmentally sustainable economy, integrating both objectives into the Commission's programmes. However, the report is hostage to neoliberal assumptions, as it is more committed to entrepreneurship, foreign investment or deregulation than to public planning and the protection of workers and consumers as central axes of the transition to an environmentally and socially sustainable economy. It is also ambiguous in not specifying how 'green' growth can be reconciled with the proposal for a 'circular' economy. For all this, I abstained.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report because I share the view that the starting point is that economic growth can go hand in hand with environmental sustainability. This is a key concept which, in my opinion, should be strengthened: environmental sustainability can become a horizontal strategic criterion and act as an added value in the creation of wealth, development and long-term employment.  I would particularly like to stress the importance of the Structural Funds and the Commission's programmes (starting with Horizon 2020 and Cosme), which must work in synergy with the new European Fund for Strategic Investments and be used to the full to promote the competitiveness of SMEs, as part of the transition to a low-carbon economy based on recycling and recovery. Businesses must be able to make the best use of available funds, reducing administrative burdens and developing clear support strategies to encourage SMEs to invest and improve resource and energy efficiency.  However, and first of all, the Commission and the Member States must ensure that all arrears are paid in good time, enabling businesses and local authorities to act to achieve the objectives and strategy.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are the backbone of the European economy and are an important driver of economic growth and job creation.  The sectors involved in green growth offer significant economic and ecological benefits to EU SMEs and these benefits could increase in the coming years. This economic growth can go along with environmental sustainability, which is one of the most important challenges for the coming decades. The green economy has a lot of potential for SMEs, but for the time being these opportunities can only be partially exploited. SmEs have a long way to go before the production process, business practices and 'greener' of their services. The EU institutions and decision-makers in the Member States need to find a solution that effectively promotes the development of greener businesses, in addition to reducing the burden on SMEs, with equal opportunities in all Member States. Concrete initiatives are needed to encourage SMEs to expand the benefits of green growth at Member State level. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe that green economy sectors offer great economic and ecological benefits for SMEs in the EU. I am a promoter of alternative sources of funding for companies such as venture capital, business angels and crowd funding. The most important items here are cross-sectoral collaborations, the set-up of informal networks and the invaluable role that sector federations can and should play in this regard. The potential of female entrepreneurship and the need to create a more entrepreneurial mind-set should not be undermined and should be given paramount importance.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider it beneficial for small and medium-sized enterprises in the European Union to organise a campaign on the efficient use of resources, as well as the benefits and opportunities offered by European programmes.  I support the report's proposal all about better interinstitutional cooperation on the transfer of knowledge and best practices, including cross-border, through informal networks. At the same time, it is important to develop concrete initiatives with the aim of facilitating cooperation and resource management at cross-sectoral level.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report is based on the European Commission's Green Action Plan for SMEs and aims to encourage European companies to take greater advantage of opportunities arising from various sectors, such as renewable energy sources, and in particular the cost-effective exploitation of wind, solar, hydro and geothermal energy, energy efficiency, resource efficiency, waste management and waste management. , emissions reduction, electrification and recycling.  Considering that the gradual transition to a circular and more resource-efficient economy can create growth and jobs in Europe, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Small and medium-sized enterprises account for 98% of businesses in Europe. Many of them want to turn to eco-activities. But while the green economy could feed off many initiatives, they sometimes struggle to develop due to lack of funding. I voted in favour of this text for the European Union to support green investment by SMEs for two reasons. This corresponds in the first place to a common political commitment embodied by the energy-climate legislative package. Secondly, it is an economic opportunity not to be missed: eco-innovations are levers for growth, competitiveness and job creation for the future. In addition to facilitating access to financing for SMEs, we need to educate young people about entrepreneurship. This is particularly important for tomorrow's innovative projects.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: Written. – As rapporteur of this report, I have looked for where the growth opportunities lie for our European SMEs operating in the green growth sector. At the same time, I thought it was important to also clarify where the bottlenecks are: in access to finance, the administrative burden that SMEs have to bear, lack of knowledge and information and also the lack of courage to take risks and to take action. I am pleased that, supported by a large majority in Parliament, I can put these elements on the agenda.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) represent the connective tissue of the European economy, accounting for 99.8% of all EU businesses. Efficient resource management is one of the main drivers of these companies' competitiveness. With this action plan, the European Union wants to help SMEs take advantage of the opportunities offered by the green economy. Repair, maintenance, recycling and ecodesign have great potential to become tools for economic growth, job creation and support in addressing environmental challenges.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The sectors that support green growth have tremendous economic and ecological benefits for SMEs in the European Union and are expected to grow considerably in the coming years. The European Parliament calls on the Commission and the EIB to ensure that, during the implementation phase of the 'Investment Plan for Europe', green and innovative SMEs are among the main beneficiaries of the aid.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. The efficiency of resources and the circular economy provide many opportunities for European small and medium-sized enterprises. The Greens also want the European Commission to put in place strong support measures to help these SMEs in this transition. If the Greens have managed to have some concrete and positive proposals included in this resolution, the account is not there in the end. We have therefore rejected this report, which we cannot support the ideological approach of saying that legislation is the major obstacle to growth or that deregulation - the dismantling of European social and environmental standards - can benefit European citizens and SMEs. An adequate fiscal and regulatory framework is needed to support this transition to a circular economy, and to do so, legislation is a vehicle for change. Sme representatives are calling for a reduction in administrative burdens and a simplification of procedures, not a legal framework. We agree to ensure a Union that offers good standards of social and environmental protection and that if a legislative framework is needed in this area, it must be applied to all. Unfortunately, that is not how the majority of Parliament voted today.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. ‒ While I would air caution against focusing efforts at solely green SMEs, I do welcome the emphasis given in this report to removing much of the unnecessary, burdensome regulation – which is often gold-plated – that acts as a market barrier for all small and medium—sized enterprises.  The reality is that the green sector presents great economic opportunities. This cannot be denied. Renewable energy production and storage technologies are coming more and more to the fore. It is right that SMEs that share this focus are afforded the capacity to get involved in research and innovation, as well as to access finance that is all important yet often so difficult for small businesses to gain. While I would urge the UK Government to take primary responsibility for making the market a more hospitable place for these enterprises, I also believe that the EU, particularly through the latest round of Structural and Cohesion Funds, can play a pivotal role in providing SMEs with substantive opportunities to nurture and grow. This is especially important in my constituency, Northern Ireland, given the potential presented for projects to extend across our unique land border with the Republic of Ireland.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on the report on green growth niches for SMEs. Naturally, I am in favour of the development of SMEs, which requires an advantageous tax system. We must promote the qualities and know-how of French entrepreneurs, while encouraging them to produce more environmentally friendly. However, these objectives cannot be achieved by this report. It contains no novelty or sensible measures that allow it. Indeed, substantive ideas are hidden under an ideology of encroaching on national sovereignty. We cannot accept that. Abstention is therefore the most relevant vote to express my desire to achieve the above objectives, but take a radically different path.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The report stresses the opportunities arising from ‘green growth’ and the circular economy, in particular from renewable energy, energy efficiency, resource efficiency, waste management, emission reduction and electrification. It underlines that the global market for environmental goods and services is worth EUR 1 000 billion per year, and it is estimated that this amount will double or even triple by 2020. A strong emphasis is put on the challenges which face SMEs in the fields of financing, research and development, the legislative burden and enhancing cross-board cooperation in relation to green growth. Notably, it calls on Member States to use market-based instruments in their public support schemes.

name: Pascal Durand (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. The efficiency of resources and the circular economy offer many opportunities for small and medium-sized European enterprises. The Greens also want the European Commission to put in place support measures to help these SMEs in this transition.  If the Greens have managed to have some concrete and positive proposals included in this resolution, the account is not ultimately there. We have therefore rejected this report, which we cannot support the ideological approach of saying that legislation is the major obstacle to growth, or that deregulation - the dismantling of European social and environmental standards - can benefit European citizens and SMEs.  An adequate fiscal and regulatory framework is needed to support this transition to a circular economy and, to do so, legislation is a vehicle for change. SME representatives are calling for a reduction in administrative burdens and a simplification of procedures, not an exemption from a legal framework. We must achieve high standards of social and environmental protection. And if a legislative framework is needed in this area, it must be applied to all. Unfortunately, that is not how the majority of Parliament voted today.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 SMEs are the backbone of the European Union economy and are important drivers of economic growth and job creation. There is a very broad consensus that green growth provides a wide range of benefits.  The report is commercially oriented and invites the Commission not to create unnecessary red tape for SMEs in this field in order to stimulate their funding, research and development and innovation more efficiently. The acquisition and dissemination of correct knowledge that can only contribute to growth should also be well considered.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We vote against because, although we consider small and medium-sized enterprises to be very important for the development of the economy, we disagree with the way in which the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council approach. We believe that in other ways these businesses will be strengthened.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. I do not believe that deregulation and the dismantling of European social and environmental standards are in the interests of my constituents in Wales. I do not agree that legislation is a barrier for green growth. I have long called for cutting unnecessary and cumbersome red tape, because it is important to my constituents in Wales that the European Union is as effective, accountable, and efficient as possible. However, these proposals will not do that.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on green growth opportunities for SMEs because smEs are the backbone of the European economy and the fundamental engine for economic growth and job creation. The report supports the concept of green growth and the circular economy, linked to various important sectors such as renewable energy sources, in particular: widespread and sustainable use of wind, solar and water energy, energy efficiency, resource efficiency, waste management, emission reduction, etc.  There is great potential for the green economy, but this potential cannot be fully exploited unless several basic conditions are met first, such as, for example, creating a more entrepreneurial spirit by developing open, innovation-friendly rules, establishing more diversified access to finance and creating more opportunities for knowledge sharing. With regard to investment, the report also calls on the Commission and the EIB to ensure that, in the implementation phase of the 'Investment Plan for Europe', SMEs, including eco-friendly and innovative SMEs, are the main beneficiaries of support and reiterates that, in order to achieve this objective, it is necessary to strengthen the provision of resource efficiency and eco-innovation advisory services.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The sectors covered by green growth provide great economic and ecological benefits for SMEs, which are the backbone of the European economy and are important drivers of economic growth and job creation.  There is broad consensus that green growth offers numerous advantages. But there are also many problems associated with this growth identified by the companies themselves, namely the information gap between SMEs and lenders in the negotiation of a credit. In the development of programmes, instruments and initiatives, the Commission should take into account the wide range of financing needs, which vary depending on the product, the size of the company, technology, innovation, among others. Another key point in the development of green growth opportunities is the need for sharing and transmitting knowledge. For these reasons, this report departs a separate section on how SMEs can make the most of the knowledge available. The great potential of the green economy can only be fully exploited if the appropriate framework for research, development and innovation is established.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report first declares its support for the concept of green growth, the economically viable exploitation of wind, solar, hydro and geothermal energy, energy efficiency and resource use, waste management, the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, the circular flow of recycling and reuse of raw materials. It refers to the importance of the role of SMEs in this comprehensive framework for fostering job creation and economic growth. At first, we don't disagree. These are fair objectives, which are undoubtedly opportunities for the development of a wide range of small and medium-sized enterprises. But it is clear that the concept of growth here is that of capitalist growth, by nature unsustainable – however much they try to paint it green. Among other proposals and approaches on which we disagree head-on, the rapporteur encourages Member States to amend their bankruptcy legislation by speeding up the process, meeting the scarcity liberal concept of 'creative destruction'. It calls on the Commission to "alleviat the fear of bankruptcy" by promoting awareness-raising and education campaigns. Moreover, it challenges the scarcity of the apology of entrepreneurship and completely ignores the important role of the State in these areas – which if fully assumed would create other and better conditions for SMEs themselves.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to cope with the consequences of the global economic and financial crisis, the European Union must support small and medium-sized enterprises in every possible way, because these are the most active component of the European economy and create countless jobs. The green growth sector has the potential to grow actively over the next few years, and it is therefore important that we fully realise the potential of the green economy. Small and medium-sized enterprises must actively participate in the process of greening produced products as well as production processes, business processes and services. The European Commission should, in every possible way, encourage these efforts, aware of the benefits of green growth. The European Commission should actively participate in simplifying the different national systems of individual Member States, thus approaching a more uniform set of measures. According to recent developments, it is therefore clear that there is scope for relatively considerable ecological potential, and it is very important that we are able to exploit this potential in the maximum possible way and that small and medium-sized enterprises across the European Union benefit from it.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote will abstain because we believe in the value of the opportunities that SMEs can have with new technologies, but the report forgets, or rather omits, the negative effects that have occurred so far in the development of some green energy policies.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on green growth opportunities for SMEs because, although I consider small and medium-sized enterprises to be very important for the development of the economy, I disagree with the way in which the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council approach. I believe that there are other ways to achieve the strengthening of these enterprises.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the De Backer report on green growth opportunities for SMEs. I support much of the content, in particular its pro-business and competitiveness focus and its calls for the Commission to refrain from introducing proposals that would lead to unnecessary burdens for enterprises.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe it is very important, considering the growth potential for SMEs in the green sector, that Europe support them in the greening of their product lines, production processes, business practices and services, doing so within an adequate regulatory framework. I welcome the idea explained in the report that awareness of green entrepreneurship should be promoted in early education and that venture capital, business angels and crowd funding should be put forward as alternatives to regular bank financing. Considering the disparity of access to technology between SMEs and multinationals, we should focus on stimulating knowledge-sharing.  SMEs are the backbone of the European economy. Stimulating their green growth through a more entrepreneurial mindset, developing open and innovation-friendly rules while keeping the budget in check would have, in my opinion, a very positive effect on the growth of Europe’s green economy.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. The role of SMEs in the European economy is critical, even considering that they account for more than 98% of European enterprises and generate more than 67% of total EU employment. The environmental goods and services sector provides an opportunity for SMEs to increase the generation of economic activity and employment, as this sector is estimated to double or even triple by 2020, so they must have our full support. I voted for it.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises form the backbone of the Eu ropean Union economy. The success of SMEs means more growth, more work, more prosperity. That is why the EU must do everything possible to support them. Today we have dealt in particular with a great opportunity for them: the green economy.  I voted 'yes' to today's report because it points the way to solving the problems that prevent SMEs from reaping all the benefits of the green economy, recalling, in particular, the importance of cross-sectoral collaborations and informal networks, so as to fill the gaps that SMEs can have in competition with multinational companies in the field of knowledge. The strength of this text is not to close in on ideological approaches but, on the contrary, to propose an objective and pragmatic approach, open to the novelties and realities of European industry.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. Given the profound need to promote new innovative development actions that offer opportunities and alternatives to emerge from the crisis, I agree with and support the report on green growth opportunities for SMEs, convinced that in order to give new impetus to the economy it is necessary to support and guarantee young people, to make access to credit easier, more diversified and clearer. , to broaden the opportunities and platforms for the exchange of information and knowledge and, above all, to include the prospect of environmentally friendly growth in a framework that points to the simplification of regulation, investing in innovation and development, with a European approach that attempts to overcome, as far as possible, the fragmentation of the various Member States.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the own-initiative report on green growth opportunities for SMEs. The green economy represents an unmissable opportunity to achieve the sustainable growth required by Europe 2020, create new jobs, reshape the production system and protect the planet by damiting climate change. SMEs, which account for more than 90% of the European economy, must be the protagonists of green growth. To this end, it is essential to address some open issues. I would like to draw attention to the problem of financing, pointing out that SMEs need different sources of finance, involving risk capital, bank loans, financial instruments and public support. I share the concern about the transfer of knowledge and good practice and welcome European initiatives to promote cross-border sharing of ideas between SMEs and stakeholders. Green growth is also linked to the theme of research and innovation. It is necessary to help SMEs innovate processes and products and for there to be a strong link with the world of research in order to make full use of the potential of the green economy for European reindustrialisation.  Support for start-ups and entrepreneurship and the development of technical skills are other key themes for this sector.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Economic growth and environmental protection are not, in my view, at odds. On the contrary, European companies have great potential – including in the export market – in the green technology sector in particular.  In Europe, we have set ourselves the goal of increasing the share of industry in our economic output to 20% by 2020. The promotion of sustainable industry and green technology is a factor that should not be underestimated. More than 90% of EU companies are already working to operate in an environmentally friendly manner. We must continue to support this commitment. We should be at the forefront of global competition and consolidate our industrial lead with innovative and environmentally sound technologies. In particular, the export market still offers untapped potential for European companies. Especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, we need to improve export conditions here.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 Areas such as renewable energy, energy efficiency or waste management have significant economic and employment potential. It is therefore logical to ask the Commission to better integrate and rationalize existing policy instruments in order to ensure opportunities for SMEs and their participation in the green and circular economy. Given the predictions about population growth in the coming years and that our natural resources are limited, we must take advantage of new solutions to these challenges that are innovative, ecological and sustainable, including, as the Resolution that today supports, new products, production processes and business practices and services , which integrate, for example, , innovative digital technologies — as well as a new legal support framework. The so-called green economy is ultimately an opportunity for our companies. Making resource management more efficient can reduce production costs, and innovating in sustainable products opens the door to an emerging global market, increasingly interested in reducing unnecessary energy and resource consumption.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Comprehensive measures are needed for the EU to achieve its climate change targets, and I am pleased to see SMEs being considered as part of these measures. Green growth and SMEs are vital for future innovation and economic prosperity in light of the depletion of natural resources and climate change itself. With improved regulation being of considerable importance to SMEs, I am also pleased to see that these proposals are business focused. The Conservative Party always champions small businesses whilst striving to conserve and protect the environment.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the proposed resolution on green growth niches for SMEs. The proposal calls on the Commission and Member States to make it financially easier for SMEs operating in the green economy, including through the Juncker Plan. But if the intention is good, the means are derisory. No funding solution is really proposed. Encouraging Member States to implement favourable tax provisions for these SMEs is difficult in the current budgetary context, while also contradicting Europe's public accounts recovery targets.  The reference to the Junker plan is also inoperative, since this plan is not itself provisioned. As for encouraging Member States to attract foreign investors, this is a advice that applies to the economy as a whole and not just the green economy. Finally, the motion for a resolution calls on Member States to de-regulate to remove barriers to the internal market. However, the deregulations advocated by the European Union are all too rarely about red tape. They usually consist of weakening social or even environmental standards, which would be particularly unwelcome here, in the case of a so-called "green" economy.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in this vote on the view that, while the report is approaching some of the needs of European small and medium-sized enterprises incorporating processes and products from the green economy, the general approach on which it is developed responds to a market economy model with very little attention to other alternative production and consumption models to capitalist , such as that represented by companies in the social and solidarity economy

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my S&D colleagues, voted in favour of this report because the S&D group managed to include micro-enterprises and start-ups in the report and ensure that these businesses are covered by new initiatives focusing on green growth. The S&D Group also ensured that industrial synergies, symbioses and clusters are promoted within the text.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the opportunities for environmentally sustainable growth for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) because I am convinced of the need to reconcile the two strategically important strands of the EU: the green economy and the activities of SMEs. It is clear that SMEs are a potency that has real potential to screw up European economic growth and thus create the necessary jobs for Europeans. It is vital to understand and assess the potential of the green economy and to help SMEs overcome the challenges that arise from greener production processes, products and services. The Commission should also contribute here, which should provide financing tools for companies with these results. The Commission should consider how to fairly meet the different financing needs depending on the product, company size, technology, innovation. It is in this area that a wide range of measures need to be carefully considered, because in the green economy we cannot yet be sure of the return on investment in relatively new business models or technologies.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that economic growth and environmental sustainability should go hand in hand. SMEs are crucial to the European economy and the EU should be working hard to encourage all types of SMEs to engage in the green economy.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on increasing opportunities for SMEs in view of green growth, because I believe that the sector of the so-called green economy will grow dynamically and its potential for businesses must be well exploited.  SMEs are a pillar of the European economy, employ 68% of EU workers and are able to adapt well to change; are open to new, innovative solutions. Unfortunately, they still have worse access to finance compared to large companies. For small businesses, both the cost of obtaining loans and the complex and time-consuming procedures for applying for financing are a heavy burden. I therefore consider it a priority for the Commission and the Member States to support SMEs in their access to financial instruments so that they can implement green and green investments and innovative solutions.  To this end, procedures should be simplified as much as possible and advisory and technical support for enterprises should be introduced during the application process. Synergies and complementarity between cohesion policy, COSME and Horizon 2020 funds are also needed to maximise the environmental potential of SMEs. The new European Fund for Strategic Investments can also provide an opportunity for eco-innovation through public-private partnerships.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Scottish government has committed to Scotland being a global leader in developing a circular economy, and SMEs play a vital role in forwarding that agenda.  Nonetheless, I do not consider that regulation per se is a barrier to achieving a circular economy and I could not therefore support this report.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in this vote on the view that, while the report is approaching some of the needs of European small and medium-sized enterprises incorporating processes and products from the green economy, the general approach on which it is developed responds to a market economy model with very little attention to other alternative production and consumption models to capitalist , such as that represented by companies in the social and solidarity economy.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour, as I believe that economic growth can be accompanied by environmental sustainability. SMEs are the mainstay of the European economy and are important drivers of economic growth and job creation.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the report clearly points out that there is a large potential for green growth, but it cannot be fully exploited if several basic conditions are not fulfilled. Moreover, friendly rules are more needed, and diverse access to finance as well.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Green Growth Opportunities Report for SMEs, as I think we need to give great importance to innovative "green" solutions due to the challenges ahead. The world's population is becoming more and more numerous, by 2050 9 billion inhabitants are expected on the planet, which means that the world economy must use natural resources very carefully. Renewables are not only of great natural importance, but open up opportunities for economic growth and employment. When financing SMEs, the Commission should take into account the different programmes, useful instruments and future business models in the green economy, as there is actually no single model to suit all SMEs. I believe that much more can be done to inform SMEs, entrepreneurs and organisations about green initiative, possible support, knowledge management, strengthening cross-sectoral cooperation and resource management, and that there are certainly extremely high potentials in this area.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This green growth project for small and medium-sized enterprises has many positive aspects, as it advocates lower costs and lower regulations, or the promotion of entrepreneurship in secondary education. But other aspects are much less defensible. Indeed, the Union, through this text, is still interfering in the competences of the Member States: the aspect concerning school curricula, while laudable on the merits, is an intrusion into the area of competence of the Member States. It is still a text that will weaken States in the face of deregulated globalization, in a context of crisis where only protectionism will be able to defend their interests. For all these reasons, I have decided to vote against this text.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Philippe de Backer's report on green growth niches for SMEs.  This report urges the Commission to support European SMEs involved in environmental sustainability, which is a real driver of growth, through the Horizon 2020 budget. SMEs are the backbone of the European economy and an important engine of growth and job creation.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on promoting the green economy for SMEs. In order to make the green economy a real vehicle for job creation and growth, it is necessary to define clear and transparent rules, allowing SMEs to easily access financing opportunities, as well as to establish an appropriate European framework for research, development and innovation.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 People in Europe are increasingly aware of the risks posed by environmental pollution, as well as more concerned about their health and trying to lead the right lifestyle. As conscious consumers, they choose the greenest solutions and support green businesses. Such companies are already the driving force behind the economy, but at the same time moving towards the development of ecology is a unique opportunity for them. "Greening" products, production processes, business practices and business services requires many new solutions and money, so it is a big challenge for such small businesses.  The task for us in government is to facilitate and streamline this process. Research enabling the development of innovative technologies and the acquisition of relevant knowledge should be possible. It is also necessary to create a system of co-financing for companies taking the initiative in order to enable them to implement innovative solutions that will benefit society as a whole. In order to exploit all the potential of the green economy, we should first of all ensure that there is an appropriate regulatory and legal framework that will make it easier for entrepreneurs to address this challenge.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. This report is balanced and presents Green Growth as an opportunity for growth for the economy without directly influencing decision-making at company level. This is not about regulation, but about creating incentives, accepting opportunities and not imposing additional burdens on small and medium-sized enterprises. Maintaining entrepreneurial freedoms while creating incentives and creating opportunities is absolutely to be supported, so I agree with this report.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on green growth opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg. SMEs are an important driver of Europe's economic growth and jobs, so the initiative to help SMEs to acquire green growth opportunities is very welcome. The report is based on the European Commission's Green Action Plan for Small and Medium-sized Enterprises, which is an initiative to further stimulate SMEs' benefits from green growth. The report focuses on the growth potential of the circular and green economy, as well as the importance of resource efficiency and the creation of a friendly environment for the creation of new businesses. Consequently, I believe that the report is a good start to support small and medium-sized enterprises on the road to green growth and the circular economy, as it is SMEs that most often face the greatest difficulties in their green business practices.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report. Although I would like to have seen it more ambitious, I am happy the S&D Group managed to include micro-enterprises and start-ups in the report and ensure that these businesses are covered by new initiatives focusing on green growth. Our group also ensured that the Commission is encouraged to come forward with concrete initiatives on cross-sectoral cooperation and resource management.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 SMEs are very important for so-called green growth (sustainable economic growth). They are the main driver of eco-innovation and key players in the emerging greener industry. They represent 98% of businesses in the EU and provide more than two thirds of jobs. In July 2014, the Commission published its Green Action Plan for SMEs and the report we voted on yesterday (19.5.2015) endorsed the Commission's initiative to stimulate SMEs in developing the benefits of green growth, welcoming and promoting the concept of circular waste management overall. However, SMEs face other challenges in the context of this green growth, such as a complex approach to finance, complicated research and development, a nonsensical bureaucratic burden or a shortage of skilled labour, etc. In my opinion, both the action plan and the report itself do not adequately reflect these problems. That is why our faction has tabled a number of amendments precisely with a focus on solving these problems. Unfortunately, most of our proposals have not been adopted. We were not granted this either, which is why I had to abstain from voting.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Excellent statistics show that more than 98% of EU businesses are SMEs and that these SMEs account for 67% of the eu's total employment level and 58% of gross value added. Despite this, the majority of subsidies and tax breaks are pocketed by large multinationals. Perhaps the most tangible element of the proposal is to call on the Commission and the EIB to ensure that SMEs, including green and innovative enterprises, are the priority beneficiaries of the support provided under the proposal during the implementation phase of the Investment Plan for Europe. I fully support any solution that can carve out something of the disadvantages of small businesses over multis, such as this one.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr De Backer's report, which is based on the Commission's Green Action Plan for SMEs, as it is an initiative aimed at further stimulating small and medium-sized enterprises to develop the benefits of so-called green growth. Aware of the need and importance of sustainable development of industry, I hope for an improvement in resource efficiency, including through collaboration with research institutes, universities and vocational training institutes.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. This Backer report entitled "Green Growth For SMEs" calls for encouraging green investment in SMEs through means such as supporting the financing and development of SMEs in the green economy, better information on available financing solutions, simplifying regulations, a tax policy promoting venture capital, or an awakening to entrepreneurship in secondary education. This report is an alignment of vague intentions and proposals, some of which are already being applied in the Member States. While some of them can be subscribed to, others bite on the competences of Member States such as proposals on education or environmental regulation. Moreover, this report is marked by a neoliberal patina and calls for ever more deregulation. I have therefore decided to abstain in the vote on this report.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained. This proposal calls on the Committee to support financing policies for the development of SMEs in the green economy, using a variety of means. Member States are therefore asked to have favourable tax policies for these SMEs, to improve their information on the financing available in connection with the green economy, to favour these SMEs in the Juncker plan, to act to limit regulation at the national level and to promote entrepreneurship in education programmes. However, this resolution has the disadvantage of not proposing much concrete, in particular on the development of aid instruments for the development of projects in this area. Moreover, as is often the case, it tends, in spirit, to want to limit the competences of states that we consider exclusive, as is the case with education. It even encourages the Committee to take action against Member States, particularly in the area of regulation, which is of course unacceptable. This is because this proposal is part of the neo-liberal logic, which is the dogma of the European Union.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. This is an initiative report in response to the Green Action Plan for SMEs: allowing SMEs to turn environmental challenges into business opportunities. The Green Action Plan sets out guidance and framework for how the EU, in cooperation with Member States and regions, will help SMEs take advantage of the business opportunities offered by the transition to a green economy. The report includes a reference to micro-enterprises and start-ups so that they are covered by new green growth-focused initiatives. The report also mentions industrial synergies and includes requesting concrete initiatives on cross-sectoral cooperation and resource management from the Commission. Agreeing with these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This Resolution highlights the close relationship between the establishment of ecological practices, a circular economy and the consequent business economic benefits of this. Given that the world's growing population and resource scarcity is an alarming situation for all States, companies must be aware and work together to realize viable growth, even changing their business culture where necessary. I must stress the difficulty of financing such enterprises (SMEs), especially during the early stages of their growth. Appropriate measures and sources of venture capital should therefore be established in this regard, all by carrying out a coordinated and transparent activity and trying to remove all kinds of barriers between the different Member States. Measures such as increased investment in research, increased exports or an initiative to accept a unitary European patent by all Member States are some of the actions to be taken to achieve this proposed ecological growth. I therefore consider this resolution to be positive and I therefore give my approval.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am against states meddling in the business of companies. The state should not determine which business is better or worse, and on that basis help one at the expense of the other. Overall, I am against any selective incentives for selected companies.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 SMEs make up around 99% of all European businesses and provide around 75 million jobs, making them a cornerstone of the European Union's economy. In order to ensure their sustainable and inclusive growth, it is essential to support, in a targeted and conscious manner, the increasingly sustainable and resource-efficient implementation of the green economy. Member States, in cooperation with the European Commission, need to look for tools to support the business and legal environment in terms of access to project finance, public procurement and other public policy instruments that enable SMEs to exploit environmental challenges for the benefit of economic growth.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on this report on green growth opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises because it is not sufficient and comprehensive.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Green growth sectors offer great economic and ecological benefits for SMEs in the EU, and are estimated to grow considerably in the coming years. The starting point is that this economic growth can go hand in hand with environmental sustainability. SMEs are the backbone of the European economy and are important drivers for economic growth and job creation.  It is important that policy makers fully understand the potential of the green economy, while at the same time being aware of the difficulties that SMEs currently face, in particular regarding the greening of their products, production processes, business practices and services. The Commission’s Green Action Plan for SMEs is a welcome initiative to further stimulate SMEs to develop the benefits of green growth.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote. There are certainly some good ideas in this report but the result goes the wrong way and does not bring any concrete proposals or new ideas. It is therefore wiser to abstain.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on green growth opportunities for SMEs, sources of innovation and job creation, real drivers of European growth, the backbone of the EU economy, representing 98% of European businesses.  The great potential of the green economy must be fully exploited, particularly in the field of innovation, research and development. We need to make our economy more environmentally friendly, increase female entrepreneurship, raise consumer awareness and measures to support entrepreneurship in general, develop open and innovation-friendly rules, establish diversified access to finance and create more opportunities for knowledge sharing.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report lists well the challenges facing MSEs, however it is poor in the solutions. It is well known that one of the main problems of mSS is access to finance. Programmes such as COSME or H2020 are essential, but more needs to be done, such as facilitating access to other types of finance such as microcredit. That's why I abstained in the vote

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. European SMEs have great potential for growth in the field of the green economy, and the EU needs to adopt the right policies so that our entrepreneurs can take advantage of green growth sectors. That is why I support this proposal, which should serve to redouble efforts to make the activity of our SMEs, in all areas, greener. To do this, these companies also require funding, research and development and innovation. We therefore have a lot of potential for ecological growth, but to take advantage of it we must work to foster a more entrepreneurial mindset, develop open and pro-innovation standards, further diversify access to finance and create more opportunities for knowledge dissemination.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because of the opportunities offered by environmentally sound growth for the economy without directly influencing decision-making at company level.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report clearly identifies the problems facing SMEs, including the difficulty of access to finance, access to research and development spending, international pressure and competition. It shows the potential of the environmental sector and also supports the circular economy. The answers, however, are part of the usual neo-liberal recipes. The report "calls on the Commission to step up its efforts to deal with over-regulation with the various Member States". The report even proposes to include "green services" in the negotiations on the large transatlantic market (TTIP). Inept propaganda for a system that doesn't work. I am voting against this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (NI)
text: In writing. This project has positive aspects, such as the desire to reduce burdens and reduce corporate regulations or promote entrepreneurship in education programmes. These good ideas should not hide the reality of the project. Once again, the European Union is trying to interfere with the competences of States by encouraging the Commission to act, through standards, against States (point 17) as well as for school curricula which are a national competence (point 22). In addition, neo-liberal deregulation is repeatedly highlighted. For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 SMEs account for more than 98% of European companies and account for more than 67% of total employment in the Union and 58% of gross value added. SMEs are the pillar of the European Union economy and are the key drivers of long-term European economic growth and the creation of sustainable employment opportunities in the 28 Member States.  We must support the concept of green growth and the circular economy. The opportunities arising from this cover multiple areas of significant importance, such as renewable energy sources – and in particular the economically viable exploitation of wind, solar, hydro and geothermal energy – energy efficiency, resource efficiency, waste management, emission reduction, electrification and the circular flow of recycling and reuse of materials.  Green growth should be part of a broader strategy to foster job creation and economic growth in SMEs. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it emphasises the need for the European Union to support SMEs in remaining up to date with the ever-developing world of green technology and financing opportunities. SMEs do not have the same level of access to knowledge-networks as large businesses and also struggle to reach out to potential investors and clients. It also stresses the need to avoid a one-size-fits-all approach to finance, as this would have a detrimental effect on SMEs involved in the green economy.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Making Europe's economy more sustainable is essential. An effective strategy cannot be understood without unconditional support for SMEs, the lung of our European economy. The action plan proposed by this document aims to promote the greening of European businesses while supporting the development of green entrepreneurship. It will also allow for better exploitation of resources, thus ensuring a certain increase in competitiveness in the long term. At a time when the European economy needs to recover, it is more vital than ever that it moves towards a more cost-effective and sustainable model.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the measures adopted in this non-legislative report that looks into different ways of exploiting the potential for green growth in response to the Commission communication on the green action plan for growth and focuses on financing opportunities, resource efficiency, energy efficiency, the circular economy and industrial synergies.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: Writing. With the adoption of the own-initiative report "Opportunities for Green Growth of SMEs", we have today laid the foundations for a forward-looking growth policy for small and medium-sized enterprises in Europe. For these companies in particular, topics such as resource conservation, the circular economy and environmental compatibility can not only be factors for reducing costs, but can also serve as promising business models. There is a great potential for growth and employment in this area, but it has hardly been used up to now, because of the lack of funding, research opportunities and funding, and the bureaucratic hurdles are still too great. The own-initiative report by my colleague Philippe De Backer seeks to remedy precisely these shortcomings and to promote environmentally sound initiatives better. I consider this report to be extremely effective, as it seeks improvements for SMEs in the environmental sector along the entire value chain and calls for environmentally sound growth of SMEs to be integrated into all existing EU support programmes and instruments. This creates an opportunity for Europe to strengthen our economy, while at the same time promoting the sustainability that we need in order to achieve the climate and environmental objectives that we have set ourselves.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) are the pillar of the European Union economy and are the drivers of economic growth and job creation in the 28 Member States. It should be added that SMEs account for more than 98% of European businesses, account for more than 67% of total employment in the Union and 58% of gross value added. I support this report and vote in favour of this legislative initiative because I believe that green growth is of major economic importance in our European economy. This is due not only to the economic activities associated with the green economy (e.g. renewable energy, forest, waste management) but also to the amount of jobs that could be generated in the future. I would like to stress the importance of financing green initiatives, the knowledge management of projects previously developed and the interest of the Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme to increasingly support this type of economic activity.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This Backer report entitled "Green Growth For SMEs" calls for encouraging green investment in SMEs through means such as supporting financing and the development of SMEs in the green economy, better information on available financing solutions, simplifying regulations, a tax policy promoting venture capital, or an awakening to entrepreneurship in secondary education.  This report is an alignment of vague intentions and proposals, some of which are already being applied in the Member States. While some of them can be subscribed to, others bite on the competences of Member States such as proposals on education or environmental regulation. Moreover, this report is marked by a neoliberal patina and calls for ever more deregulation. I have therefore decided to abstain in the vote on this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that overall the report could have been more ambitious, as the text focuses heavily on issues related to financing for SMEs and not enough attention is devoted to concrete initiatives for further sustainability, resource efficiency, energy efficiency and the circular economy. However my colleagues in the S&D Group managed to include micro—enterprises and start-ups in the report and ensure that these businesses are covered by new initiatives focusing on green growth. In addition, the S&D Group also ensured that industrial synergies, symbioses and clusters are promoted within the text. Finally, the S&D Group ensured that the Commission is encouraged to come forward with concrete initiatives on cross-sectoral cooperation and resource management.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which encourages SMEs to take advantage of green growth. These include making more efficient use of available resources, promoting simple and accessible sources of information, and facilitating start-ups by encouraging them to collaborate with research institutes, universities and vocational training centres. This text also emphasizes the importance of women's entrepreneurship, which I support.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Green Growth Slots for SMEs report, which is based on an action plan proposed by the Commission to encourage SMEs to take better advantage of green growth. Many questions raised by stakeholders during the consultations have been incorporated into this report of great importance for the future of Europe. Indeed, the sustainable growth model of green growth represents a huge potential for international markets, and European small and medium-sized enterprises must be given access to them. It is also by facilitating the launch of young start-ups and spin-off companies that we can combat unemployment, especially that of young people. At European level, resources exist, and now they need to be used more efficiently.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the report on green growth opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises because we are aware that the sectors related to eco-friendly growth offer tangible benefits not only ecological, but also economic, and that in the coming years we will see strong growth in the sector. Political leaders need to realise the potential of the green economy and have the simplest possible regulatory framework. This report effectively identifies the main issues and opportunities, and leaves a general optimistic impression on the green future of SMEs. The green economy has enormous potential, but it must be managed with care and, above all, it must be stimulated and facilitated by the EU institutions, which must commit themselves both to facilitating the financing of companies that decide to throw themselves into the green economy and to speeding up the sharing of knowledge and best practices. It is appropriate, as the report points out, that the rules should not be excessively strict and divergent between countries: over-regulation and lack of harmonisation are among the main opponents of an SME that wants to move towards the green economy. It should also be stressed that it is also necessary to raise consumer awareness and develop measures to support small and medium-sized entrepreneurship in general.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report on green growth opportunities for SMEs. The report builds on the concept of green growth whereby concentrating resources and stimulating private initiatives at European level could generate new jobs and develop a new economic model based on innovation and products with high added value. To achieve this, the report mentions the need for further investment in research, in the training of specific competences or in the regularisation of the green economy.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because our group is one of the leading proponents of green alternatives for SME development, and this path of investment should be the new norm in my view. In fact, soon we should stop referring it as the ‘green’ economy, but as the economy, as the term ‘green’ should be absorbed into every single aspect of life. SMEs can be a driving factor in this change, as through small and medium entrepreneurship new technologies, work ethics and economic activities can be best brought forward.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because, in my opinion, efforts to give SMEs greater access to finance for 'green innovation' need to be encouraged. Existing EU programmes such as COSME and Horizon 2020 do not contribute sufficiently to green innovation and the 'circular economy', although I think these areas are a social priority. Funding from these programmes should therefore focus more, for example, on supporting funding to improve the design and effectiveness of products. I also consider it necessary to find a quick and lasting solution to the extraordinary backlog of payments from the European Structural and Investment Funds over the last programming period, so that SMEs, as project partners, are not discouraged from participating in new programmes and projects because of payment delays.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The changing environment, the emergence of a smart and green economy, is a challenge and an opportunity for all actors. The situation of small and medium-sized enterprises is particularly important as they are significant employers, but they can also be a breakout chance for many people. These businesses adapt flexibly and creatively to market changes and are able to move significant intellectual capital. Among the proposed instruments, research and innovation and training and regulatory rationalisation in particular appear to be promising.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. The promotion of sustainable industry and green technologies in Europe is a not to be underestimated contribution to achieving the target of 20 percent industrial share of economic output in Europe by 2020. More than 25 percent of European SMEs offer green technology products and services, and more than 90 percent of EU companies work to be as environmentally friendly as possible. I welcome this promising potential and voted in favour.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Green Growth for SMEs Initiative Report identifies issues affecting SMEs, including difficult access to finance, access to research and development funds, competition pressure and environmental sector issues. However, despite support for the COSME programme, no response is really satisfactory, making competitiveness and the removal of regulatory barriers the priority of the Union's action, without any other concrete support being proposed. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It aims to provide a clear direction and framework to demonstrate how the EU, in cooperation with Member States and regions, can help SMEs to take advantage of the opportunities created by the transition to a green economy.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. The green economy has great potential for the growth opportunities it offers SMEs. There are many difficulties these companies face at all levels, both in terms of production, business practices or access to finance. According to the Central Directory of Companies (DIRCE), there are more than three million companies in Spain, of which 99.88% are SMEs. In the rest of Europe the scenario is the same and SMEs generate two out of three private sector jobs, as well as more than half of the total value added created by companies in the EU. The European Commission's Eco-Action Plan for SMEs envisages improving resource utilization, supporting green entrepreneurship, exploiting opportunities and facilitating market access. An excellent and properly implemented initiative will have a capital value for our companies.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. It should be noted that SMEs will play an important role in the circular economy, as these enterprises are the backbone of the European economy and an important driver for growth and jobs. It is therefore necessary to help SMEs turn environmental challenges into business opportunities. In particular, it is necessary to facilitate the financing of SMEs and to remove existing barriers to the lack of information available to SMEs and creditors. In addition, it is necessary to establish a wide range of financing instruments, as there is still uncertainty about the return on investment due to new technologies and business models. I support the proposal that it is necessary to withdraw outdated or excessively burdensome legislative proposals. The regulatory burden must be reduced. Over-regulation and different interpretations of the various regulators increase the burden and create obstacles to the functioning of the internal market.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas enabling SMEs to turn environmental challenges into economic opportunities, and at the same time acting in a sustainable way, is one of the principles of the Small Business Act, although there has been no significant political progress and although SMEs often have to cope with inconsistent policies when starting an economic activity and implementing environmental standards; that the compliance of SMEs with regard to the growing number of environmental standards will be favoured by both the market and the legislation; that the EU and the Member States should minimise administrative burdens in new and existing rules, and aim to avoid creating additional costs for businesses in meeting these rules; that new initiatives have been proposed to reduce the regulatory burden on SMEs and other sectors, which should be implemented by the Commission and the Member States; I voted in favour.

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted 'for', because I believe that the report presented can create the prerequisites for easier access for SMEs to finance, but also because it can contribute to the achievement of ambitious objectives for a sustainable future at EU level.  Last but not least, it highlights the major contribution of SMEs in areas such as research, development and innovation in general, especially in environmental protection and the efficient use of the limited resources at our disposal. I believe that these areas are essential for increasing the competitiveness of the European economy as a whole.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Focusing our efforts on new technologies that separate economic growth from energy and raw material consumption coupled with channelling sufficient and achievable opportunities towards SMEs are the right path for the EU to take. I supported this report because it underlines that the concept of green growth and the circular economy should be part of a broader strategy to boost job creation and economic growth of SMEs. The European Commission should therefore create instruments to address unnecessary administrative burdens on SMEs and develop common guidelines for national public support schemes for green investment projects in order to create a more even set of measures. Developing entrepreneurial skills should be included in the education system and it is necessary to change unsustainable consumption patterns and promote changes in consumer behaviour. I am committed to providing assistance to micro and start-ups moving towards sustainable green growth and to foster green entrepreneurship.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. This resolution, like many in this House, aligns good feelings without concrete proposals, new ideas for funding programmes or aid for project development. In addition, it largely encroaches on the exclusive competences of states such as education (point 22) or regulation. In the latter area, it urges the Commission to take action against the States (point 17). Finally, this text is a neo-liberal profession of faith in its drafting (a full page is devoted to the promotion of deregulation). Nevertheless, some of the proposed measures are rather good, such as those aimed at improving THE information of SMEs on the financing available in connection with the green economy or asking the Commission to support the various financing solutions for the start-up and development of SMEs in the green economy. That is why I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ SMEs account for more than 98 % of European companies, provide more than 67 % of total employment in the Union and 58 % of gross value added; whereas the fundamental economy of the European Union is also a key driver of europe's long-term economic growth and sustainable job creation opportunities in the 28 Member States. Employment in the organic goods and services sector grew by 20% from 2007 to 2011, despite the crisis, providing the sector with an even greater start-up of economic activity and job creation, including areas characterised by emigration and an ageing population. Also, nine out of 10 SMEs have 10 or fewer employees and these microenterfies represent 53% of all jobs in Europe. All this data shows the extraordinary potential for green growth of SMEs, which form the backbone of the European economy. I agree with the rapporteur, who warns in particular of insufficient access to adequate risk capital sources, especially in the early stages, as one of the biggest constraints on the creation and development of growth-oriented enterprises, the appropriateness of the Commission Action Plan on improving SMEs' access to finance for only a small number of SMEs, and the alternatives to financing should be developed by the private sector. I hope that possible funding will be used through the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support the Green Growth Opportunities Report for SMEs. Green growth as a means of uniting economic growth with a sustainable environment offers many opportunities for SMEs, accounting for 90% of all EU businesses as well as 2/3 of the private sector. Half of SMEs have a major impact on the environment through air pollution through energy use and waste disposal. All sectors may at least partially apply environmentally friendly production and recycling methods. More than 90% of SMEs already apply at least one way to preserve the environment either by saving energy, minimising waste or caring for water. The biggest obstacle is an insufficient number of specialists with knowledge of the application of environmentally friendly methods. Currently, 26% of businesses in the EU offer "green" products or services. Enabling SMEs to turn environmental challenges into business opportunities - the Commission has proposed a number of measures to harness the benefits of green growth. Such measures as the use of renewable sources, eco-innovation, unhindered market entry can potentially reduce costs by EUR 630 billion per year.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 More than 98% of European businesses are in the small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) category, which provide more than 67% of total employment in the Union and 58% of gross value added. The green growth sector offers significant economic and environmental benefits to SMEs in the EU and can be expected to flourish in the coming years. I believe that the green economy has enormous potential, but SMEs wishing to take this prospective path face a number of challenges, particularly in the areas of financing (obtaining credit), research and development (limited access to knowledge networks), acquiring the necessary knowledge or in relation to the existing regulatory framework. We know that the long-term pain of entrepreneurs is too complicated regulation, which is even more apprehensible to promoters of innovative approaches. However, quality legislation cannot be prepared without detailed knowledge of the regulated environment, which is why Parliament has called on both the Member States and the Commission to take into account specific market failures or problems to be addressed by the regulation when preparing new proposals. I am clearly of the opinion that governments should channel far more support into greening the economy and that they should focus globally on promoting advanced, cost-effective technologies. SMEs are their most important partners in this regard.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 SMEs in the EU are certainly the basis of the economy and are certainly crucial for growth and job creation. SmEs that accompany economic growth while respecting environmental sustainability are welcome. That is why I believe that the EU should facilitate access to credit for SMEs and that the Commission should develop further programmes and instruments aimed especially at those companies that propose eco-friendly structures.  I fully support this report, in the hope that the Commission will simplify the various divergent national systems and that the governments of the Member States will increasingly push for our economy to be eco-friendly, making full use of the full potential of the green economy.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR)
text: Writing. SMEs do not need new regulations, but first and foremost one thing: fewer rules, not only at national level, but also at EU level. In fact, this approach is too often forgotten in all efforts to reach SMEs. SMEs in particular suffer disproportionately from the regulatory frenzy of all levels of government.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, economic activities are increasingly affected by new environmental concerns. Thus, the European Union encourages companies and economic actors to develop more environmentally friendly production methods while remaining competitive. In this context, the European Parliament has adopted a report on green growth and business opportunities for SMEs. I am pleased to have voted in favour of this text. It is important to support the green growth of SMEs and to identify opportunities to combine SME competitiveness and environmental preservation. In particular, this text stresses the importance of prioritizing energy efficiency and informing companies more about the various European projects and financing.
