But, I say, we must at all costs avoid adding to the burden on our businesses, when our competitors do not. That would be catastrophic for our competitiveness.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. SMEs account for more than 98% of European businesses and account for more than 67% of total employment in the Union and 58% of gross added value, thus being the pillar of the EU economy and a key driver of their long-term economic growth and the creation of sustainable employment opportunities in the 28 Member States.  The global market for environmental goods and services is estimated to be €1 trillion per year and this amount is expected to double, or even triple, by 2020, thus creating huge opportunities for European SMEs and eu economic growth in general. It is therefore important to support green growth and to tackle the main problems faced by SMEs in this area today. This involves, inter alia, the creation of a greater culture of entrepreneurship, the development of open and innovation-friendly standards, the establishment of access to more diversified funding and increased possibilities for knowledge sharing.  I voted in favour.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. As 98% of businesses, SMEs play a vital role in the European economy. I voted in favour of this report on green growth and the circular economy. It is important to remember that the EU is the world leader in the import and export of environmental products. We need to encourage SMEs in this sector. European programmes and funds must be in line with European climate strategies and, more generally, with its environmental policies, without creating additional administrative burdens. The EU needs to rethink its entrepreneurial culture to encourage business creation, particularly in the area of sustainable development. Finally, I welcome the creation of a European centre of excellence for the efficient use of resources: innovation is one of the essential components of green growth and European competitiveness on the international stage.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. This report calls on policymakers to fully understand the potential of the green economy in SMEs, considering that they now account for more than 98% of European businesses and account for more than 67% of total employment in the Union, one of the pillars of the European economy, long-term economic growth and the creation of sustainable employment opportunities in the 28 Member States. Given the importance of SMEs, it is essential that we are all aware of the various problems they currently deal with and relate to funding, research and innovation, the acquisition of appropriate knowledge or the existing regulatory framework. Unlike multinational companies, SMEs often do not have the same ease of access to knowledge networks in order to keep abreast of new technologies or to convey their message to potential customers and investors. Drawing up a set of guidelines to overcome some of these difficulties and rationalise and unify the various divergent national systems will undoubtedly be very positive.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which underlines the economic and employment potential generated by ecological growth and the circular economy for SMEs, through the exploitation of renewable energy sources (in particular wind, solar, hydroelectric and geothermal energy), energy efficiency, resource efficiency, waste management , emission reduction, electrification and 'cradle-to-cradle' design. To realize this potential, it will be necessary to improve the resource-utilization efficiency of SMEs; support green entrepreneurship; exploit the opportunities presented by greener value chains and the promotion of the circular economy; and facilitate market access for green SMEs for a greener internal market. This report complements the Commission's Green Action Plan for SMEs: allowing SMEs to turn environmental challenges into business opportunities, which sets out guidance and framework for how the EU, in cooperation with Member States and regions, will help SMEs take advantage of the business opportunities offered by the transition to a green economy.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report, which I voted for, is based on the Green Action Plan for SMEs launched by the European Commission, a genuine initiative to encourage SMEs to take greater advantage of green growth. Many of the 183 amendments put to the vote focused on supporting the green and circular economy and growth opportunities in these areas. In particular, I voted in favour of provisions that emphasized the importance of using resources more effectively, and those aimed at facilitating the start-up of start-ups and spin-off enterprises by collaborating with research institutes, universities and vocational training centres.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on green growth opportunities for SMEs presented in plenary follows the Commission's Green Action Plan, which is an initiative to further stimulate SMEs to develop the benefits of green growth, in particular the importance of support for the green and circular economy and potential growth in these sectors.  I have chosen to vote in favour of this proposal, mainly because it stresses the need to improve the efficiency of resources, to prepare simple and accessible sources of information and to encourage start-ups and spin-offs through collaboration with research institutes, universities and vocational training institutes.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to abstain because, although I consider environmental protection to be fundamental, I believe that the growth model advocated in this text has some problematic points in terms of their viability.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained in this vote by considering that, while the report is approaching some of the needs faced by European small and medium-sized enterprises incorporating processes and products from the green economy, the general approach on which it is developed responds to a market economy model with very little attention to other alternative production and consumption models to capitalist , such as that represented by companies in the social and solidarity economy.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report correctly identifies ecological and environmental efficiency as one of the main challenges for SMEs in the coming years. Thus, it states that investment in research and development and adequate financing of SMEs should be prioritized to facilitate the transition to an environmentally sustainable economy, integrating both objectives into the Commission's programmes. However, the report is hostage to neoliberal assumptions, as it is more committed to entrepreneurship, foreign investment or deregulation than to public planning and the protection of workers and consumers as central axes of the transition to an environmentally and socially sustainable economy. It is also ambiguous in not specifying how 'green' growth can be reconciled with the proposal for a 'circular' economy. For all this, I abstained.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on green growth opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). SMEs account for 98% of European enterprises and provide more than 67% of jobs in the Union. In order to successfully transform environmental challenges into opportunities for economic growth, the Union must put in place programmes, tools and initiatives to encourage SMEs to develop more environmentally friendly products, production processes, practices and commercial services.  Let us remember, however, that SMEs, when they decide to seize the opportunities for green growth, face a number of problems related to the raising of funding, the use of new technologies, knowledge and the implementation of the current regulatory framework. In this regard, I believe that we need to provide an effective response that includes creating more opportunities for knowledge sharing, tax mechanisms to boost credit and policies to support entrepreneurship. The potential for growth offered by the green economy is many and could, in my opinion, bring great benefits not only to SMEs, but also and above all to society in general.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. In the face of the employment crisis and the lack of sustainability in employment, small and medium-sized enterprises have a social role and added value that deserves our full attention. These companies, as far as possible, should have green or blue approaches in the case of marine enterprises. Combining concepts such as circular economy, regionalisation, knowledge, innovation, the latest digital technologies, debureaucratisation, entrepreneurship and microcredit, we will be fostering a more equitable, transparent, fair and inclusive society. I have seen several good examples of this approach in the maritime world of Europe. We are faced with a new generation of companies that do not seek profit at any cost, but rather the happiness and quality of life of those who lead them, who work in them and who enjoy their services. This is the future I am looking for for Europe and that is why I have voted positively for this proposal.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ S&D MEPs voted in support of this report as green growth sectors offer great economic and ecological benefits for SMEs in the EU, and are estimated to grow considerably in the coming years. The starting point is that this economic growth can go hand in hand with environmental sustainability. SMEs are the backbone of the European economy and are important drivers for economic growth and job creation.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on green growth opportunities for SMEs. I agree with the ECR's position that green growth sectors provide great economic and ecological benefits for SMEs in the EU, and they are expected to grow significantly in the coming years, based on the fact that this economic growth can be linked to environmental sustainability. I consider SMEs to be an important driver of economic growth and job creation in all EU countries.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the Green Growth Opportunities Report for SMEs, although I agree with the need to develop a green economy, as the draft Report is non-specific and ideologically written in relation to the action plan on which it should have been based. I note that legislation is not the only barrier to growth as the Report states, and that removing legislation would contribute to citizens of the European Union, as well as small and medium-sized enterprises. An appropriate fiscal and regulatory framework is needed to support the circular economy and the Report should have amended the message calling for the withdrawal of the circular economy package. Nor do I agree with parts of the Report requesting the acceleration and ratification of the Transatlantic Trade Agreement TTIP. Resource efficiency and circular economy are an opportunity for SMEs. It is necessary to provide strong measures to assist these companies with a view to the transition to a circular economy and I support concrete proposals that we have been able to include in the resolution on behalf of the Greens/ESS Club.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – Small and medium-sized enterprises form the back of the European economy, as they make up around 99% of all European businesses and provide around 75 million jobs. Therefore, supporting SMEs at EU level, but also of Member States for easier access to finance, is essential for the adoption of greener technologies and for investments in sustainable business practices. It is important that local and regional authorities provide SMEs with adequate information and analysis of production sectors and structures within which SMEs can advance green growth. I consider it important on the part of the EU authorities to remove obstacles that make absorption impossible, while at the same time minimising the administrative burden for small and medium-sized enterprises. EU programmes do not currently make a significant impact on eco-innovation and the circular economy, so the Commission needs to better focus funding from COSME and Horizon 2020 on the development of green and innovative solutions by SMEs.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report voted on was created under the Circular Economy programme and relates to the Green Action Plan for SMEs, which encourages SMEs to take advantage of the business opportunities that the transition to a green economy allows. The plan focuses on actions at European level that are consistent with existing green initiatives to support SMEs at national and regional level and will be implemented under the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework. The measures take into account the potential of resource efficiency and access to green markets for businesses.  From the point of view of the Greens/EEAS Group, the report is unfortunately too specific and too ideological, focusing in particular on reducing the regulatory and administrative burden of stimulating the growth of SMEs and increasing access to finance and markets.  I did not support this report and the amendments in the vote, as the latter, in particular, call for a reduction in the regulatory burden and call on the Member States to avoid over-transposing legislation and to eliminate any redundant and ineffective regulations that constitute market barriers. In addition, the Commission should withdraw outdated and restrictive legislative proposals such as the Circular Economy 2014 programme.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to ensure the sustainability and competitiveness of European economies, it is important to focus on resource efficiency and energy efficiency. I would like to stress that small and medium-sized enterprises make up around 99% of all European businesses and employ around 75 million workers. In order to create sustainable conditions, it is necessary to simplify firms' access to finance, to support people in setting up businesses, to simplify the rules for doing business and to reduce the administrative burden. One of the tools that can motivate people to do business is the adoption of the One-Person S.r.o. Directive, which allows you to start a business in the EU through online registration and with a minimum capital of EUR 1. The European Union should take all steps to ensure that this directive is adopted.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on green growth opportunities for SMEs, which will have a positive impact on businesses across the European Union.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report because of its high importance in the development of SMEs - SMEs account for more than 90% of European companies, provide more than 67% of total employment in the Union and 58% of gross value added, employment in the organic goods sector grew by 20% between 2007 and 2011.  The global market for organic goods is currently estimated at EUR 1 000 billion per year, this amount should triple by 2020, with particular growth expected in the European Union, for which green growth is projected to be boosted for SMEs. The focus is mainly on high-tech companies that directly achieve green innovation, but other companies also need to be supported to comply with environmental regulations. I support the idea of green growth and the circular economy and the use of renewable energy sources.  Green growth should encourage start-ups (startups) and make it easier to set up such companies by working with technology and research institutes, universities and vocational training institutions. I believe that women's entrepreneurship needs to be strengthened in green growth and especially in rural areas.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because I do not agree with the visions and proposals of the submitted report. The present report points to a fundamental misunderstanding of the functioning of the market, the creation of economic growth and job creation. The report thus points out how measures to redistribute taxpayers' money will help growth or job creation, but does not show that the jobs and growth thus achieved are achieved only at the expense of possible even more growth and employment, or at the expense of creating more sustainable growth and employment.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on opportunities for green growth for small and medium-sized enterprises. Small and medium-sized enterprises are the economic framework of the European Union, representing around 99% of all European businesses and providing around 75 million jobs. Green growth allows us to move into a more sustainable economy. If our consumption continues to be the same, we will need 40% more energy in 20 years. I also support the opinion of the Committee on Budgets, which emphasises the added value of the EU budget, which helps SMEs access finance and international markets, especially under Horizon 2020 and the European Structural and Investment Funds.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Although the report is presented as a policy of support for SMEs, the text completely ignores the unaffordable neoliberal harsh austerity measures imposed on SMEs and, by extension, the many problems they face. Instead, the reason for the non-development of SMEs is their personal inability to take advantage of new technologies, information and new forms of organisation, particularly in relation to green development.       As regards the objective of environmental sustainability, it is not, as mentioned, promoted in order to protect the environment by ensuring a better quality of life for people but is used to achieve the ultimate objective of developing the EU's competitiveness.       We cannot support a text which promotes the transfer of taxation of labour from the shoulders of employers to the shoulders of consumers, which will of course serve large enterprises and large capital, nor can we support proposals to promote changes in education in order to serve market needs and private interests.   More importantly, however, the report fails to propose measures to genuinely support SMEs.      For the above reasons, we have decided to vote against.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Although we consider small and medium-sized enterprises to be important for the development of the economy, we disagree with the approach of the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council. We believe that the strengthening of these businesses will be achieved in other ways.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on green growth opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), as I consider the role of SMEs in the green economy to be important. The report points out that more than 98% of EU businesses are SMEs and that these SMEs account for 67% of the total level of employment in the EU and 58% of gross value added. The report supports the vision of green growth and the circular economy and draws attention to the significant economic and employment potential in these areas for different sectors. It emphasises the need to look at green growth from a broader perspective, an approach which I believe is lacking in many Member States. I regret that the Hungarian Government does not have this perspective and that it is not exploiting the potential of green energy. Among the report's recommendations is that the EU needs to radically change its entrepreneurial culture so that more people start their own businesses and look for more business opportunities, especially in the area of green growth. In this process, the added value of the EU budget is given priority in supporting SMEs, micro-enterprises, social enterprises and cooperatives in order to gain access to finance and access to international markets (both in terms of operation, R&D, start-ups, deregulation and, for example, knowledge management). I hope that the report's recommendations will be implemented in Hungary as soon as possible.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises are the engine of the European economy, representing 99% of all EU companies and responsible for creating 85% of new jobs in the last five years. In order to ensure long-term economic growth in Europe and create sustainable jobs, SMEs should be guaranteed the best possible living conditions within the European single market. Moreover, SMEs can also play a key role in transforming growing environmental challenges into significant economic opportunities.  However, in order to make this possible, a number of measures should be introduced to minimise the administrative burden resulting from both the new and existing regulations. Only then will SMEs be able to compete in the global economy with entities outside the European Union. That is why I voted in favour of the report, which calls for concrete measures to increase opportunities for SMEs in relation to green economic growth.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 SMEs are at the heart of the European economic fabric and are at the heart of every Member State. However, the business environment varies greatly from country to country and many times also from region to region: there is much to be done to achieve effective and harmonised support, going beyond a few percentages of funding or some promise of funds or guarantees for investment.  Everything parliament does to improve the administrative, regulatory and economic environment in which SMEs need to act must be supported. The report as a whole deals with many issues in an unclear and interpretable way, but it also emphasises many aspects related to the circular economy and resource efficiency. Specifically, I am particularly in favour of the concept reiterated in this dossier, which is linked to the need to shift the tax burden from labour to the use of natural resources. I believe that this is a prerequisite for the lasting success of SMEs in a world with biophysical limits that cannot be overcome. In the next revision of the Small Business Act, we must pay due attention to these considerations and perhaps imagine a Green Small Business Act to stimulate the adoption of business practices that will help the transition of the European economy as quickly as possible.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Financing of environmental activities within SMEs must be a priority of the Commission's strategic thinking for the period ahead. If it is a sector that needs to be helped to grow in a competitive environment in Europe, then it is the SME sector. Through a targeted effort in this sector to encourage green activities, recycling, eco-tourism, landscaping or waste generation prevention, we can help maintain a clean environment for future generations. Environmental protection cannot be done without sustainable investment, public information and the active involvement of the most relevant economic sector in the EU: SMEs and micro-enterprises. The financial support of environmentally friendly SMEs can mean a new beginning in establishing a consistent balance between generating profit and growth and protecting resources efficiently and rationally. The responsibility for maintaining an attractive framework for SMEs in the green sector lies with us. We must not miss this opportunity, which also attracts new SMEs to European funding programmes, which generate absorption in the Member States and, at the same time, the prerequisites for maintaining a clean and healthy environment.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The sectors that support green growth have tremendous economic and ecological benefits for SMEs in the European Union and are expected to grow considerably in the coming years. The initial idea is that economic growth and environmental sustainability can go hand in hand. SMEs are the backbone of the European economy and are an important driver of economic growth and job creation.  It is important for policy makers to fully grasp the potential of the green economy, while being aware of the difficulties SMEs face, particularly in terms of greening their products, production processes, business practices and services. The Commission's Green Action Plan for SMEs is a positive initiative, which will encourage SMEs to further strengthen the benefits of green growth.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which sets up a Green Action Plan for SMEs. Objectives of green growth and circular economy must be part of the strategy of job creation and economic growth and, in this respect, SMEs are on the frontline and must not be left behind. The transition to a green economy can only be beneficial to SMEs if their specificities are acknowledged and the right incentives provided. The report pursues four objectives that I find legitimate: improve ressource efficiency of SMEs, support green entrepreneurship, exploit the opportunities of green value chains and facilitate market access for green SMEs. I also fully support the provisions on helping start-ups to move towards green growth and on ensuring no administrative burden is added.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Green Growth Opportunities Report for small and medium-sized enterprises that are certainly not using their full potential in Croatia. I come from a country where the entrepreneurial and investment climate is severely damaged and whose citizens witness the collapse of the national economy every day. In my view, micro- enterprises as well as SMEs have the key to an economic recovery that can be exploited by eliminating barriers in the internal market, resulting from excessive regulation and bureaucratic procedures.  I therefore support a proposal calling on the Commission to refrain from further legislative provisions that will lead to unnecessary administrative burdens for businesses, and for Member States to approach the interpretation of the rules responsibly and clearly so that the green economy can fully achieve development and overcome barriers to funding and research, development, legal constraints and interstate cooperation. Therefore, it is important to start changing the entrepreneurial culture of the past as soon as possible and inform and teach citizens about green entrepreneurship and the availability of green technologies.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, which is based on the Commission's Green Action Plan, for small and medium-sized enterprises. Most amendments support the green economy. It is important that we be cautious when adopting 'green growth' policies, as these can be the biggest obstacle for MSPs rather than opportunity.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in this vote on the view that, while the report is approaching some of the needs of European small and medium-sized enterprises incorporating processes and products from the green economy, the general approach on which it is developed responds to a market economy model with very little attention to other alternative production and consumption models to capitalist , such as that represented by companies in the social and solidarity economy.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ SMEs account for over 98% of European enterprises and generate more than 67% of total EU employment and 58% of gross value added. They are the backbone of the economy of the European Union. The market for environmental goods and services creates exceptional opportunities for European SMEs and growth of the whole EU economy. I am in favour of this report because Member States must help these small businesses, the main creators of jobs, but also the Commission has to address further funding for this purpose.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. This resolution aligns good feelings and abstract proposals without new ideas for funding or programmes, or even the development of aid for the development of projects in this sphere. It also largely encroaches on the exclusive competences of states such as education. I chose abstention.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained in this vote by considering that, while the report is approaching some of the needs faced by European small and medium-sized enterprises incorporating processes and products from the green economy, the general approach on which it is developed responds to a market economy model with very little attention to other alternative production and consumption models to capitalist , such as that represented by companies in the social and solidarity economy.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, although it introduces some interesting element on the efficiency of the resources allocated by the Commission, the report does not provide for the use of aid and subsidies to reduce the environmental impact of business activities, and states that environmental issues are an unnecessary burden on businesses.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on green growth of small and medium-sized enterprises, as I believe that one of the main competitive advantages of the EU is the capacity for sustainable growth and innovation of European SMEs. The potential for green growth lies in resource efficiency to reduce the environmental footprint. In this context, the EU and the Member States should promote measures related to energy efficiency, RES, waste management and emission reductions. Environmental sustainability in the activities of SMEs can be developed through instruments such as ecodesign, the single European patent in the field of green technologies, eco-innovation in rural areas, etc.  Green growth of SMEs is directly linked to ensuring an adequate set of financial instruments as well as access to European funds and programmes such as COSME and Horizon 2020. Given that 90% of EU businesses are micro-enterprises, this funding should be available to them as well as to innovative start-ups. Developing entrepreneurial skills in young people is key to the future of the green economy. Erasmus+ and Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs offer a very good opportunity for students and young people to develop entrepreneurial skills through the financing of traineeships and exchanges of experience.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution concerning the ‘Green growth opportunities for SMEs’ as I agree that the real prosperity of the Union can be ensured through the support of the private sector and in particular of European SMEs. Particularly, the green approach that this resolution offers will allow us to recycle products into resources and take advantage of the opportunities that the circular economy offers. I strongly support this resolution as the opportunities addressed to small businesses will increase, and therefore we will enjoy a more competitive European economy.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. It is important to continue to support SMEs, which are a basic tool of the productive fabric of European countries for job creation and wealth. Sustainable and ecological use of materials, as well as recycling, can help SMEs become more competitive and generate greater growth. Initiatives in this regard are always welcome.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report correctly identifies ecological and environmental efficiency as one of the main challenges for SMEs in the coming years. Thus, it states that investment in research and development and adequate financing of SMEs should be prioritized to facilitate the transition to an environmentally sustainable economy, integrating both objectives into the Commission's programmes. However, the report is hostage to neoliberal assumptions, as it is more committed to entrepreneurship, foreign investment or deregulation than to public planning and the protection of workers and consumers as central axes of the transition to an environmentally and socially sustainable economy. It is also ambiguous in not specifying how 'green' growth can be reconciled with the proposal for a 'circular' economy. For all this, I abstained.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my S&D and EPLP colleagues, I voted in favour of this report because the S&D Group managed to include micro-enterprises and start-ups in the report and ensure that these businesses are covered by new initiatives focusing on green growth. The S&D Group also ensured that industrial synergies, symbioses and clusters are promoted within the text.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I wholeheartedly supported the report by Open Vld colleague Philippe De Backer. European SMEs active in the green growth sector have various opportunities for growth, but also bottlenecks such as knowledge, lack of investors who want to bear risks, etc. It is important that these elements are put on the agenda and that Europe can think about how it can respond to various aspirations of these SMEs.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This initiative report highlights the difficulties small and medium-sized enterprises face in the face of international competition and the lack of financing they suffer. This applies to access to research and development. But, in response to this observation, the report merely rehashes the same old neoliberal recipes without questioning the policies of the European Union and the famous '2020 strategy'. So yes, it is more necessary than ever to support SMEs, but no, we will not solve their problems with "flexisecurity". It is time to finally draw the consequences of the crisis. We need to provide sustainable financing and support solutions for socially and environmentally responsible development of SMEs. "Green growth" is merely an ideological cover-up that does not respond to the social and environmental challenges that arise today. Nevertheless, I chose to abstain on this text, considering that the observation of the difficulties of SMEs was unfortunately a reality but that the proposed solutions could not constitute adequate answers.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report supports the concept of green growth, the economically viable exploitation of energy, wind, solar, hydro and geothermal, energy efficiency as well as resource use, waste management, emission reduction, circular recycling and reuse of materials and refers to the importance of the role of SMEs in this comprehensive framework for fostering job creation and economic growth.  The rapporteur encourages Member States to amend their bankruptcy legislation "to allow people to start new businesses immediately after the bankruptcy of a previous company". It goes further by addressing the Commission to "alleviat the fear of bankruptcy" by promoting awareness-raising and education campaigns.  It is therefore an apology for the creation of the company itself, the search for business opportunities in the field of green growth and that bankruptcy is accepted as a risk to be taken.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because of the opportunities offered by environmentally sound growth for the economy without directly influencing decision-making at company level.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. This report deals with growth opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). As always, this report has light and shadow. Nevertheless, I voted in favour of it with regard to group discipline. Unfortunately, the report also includes, for example, the call for certain standards to be included in TTIP. On the other hand, it is positive to point out that the Member States should not create obstacles to the internal market and should not over-regulate in this sense. The EU has tightened the regulatory screw far too tightly. This is particularly damaging to SMEs, which, unlike large companies, cannot employ expensive legal departments to exploit the enormous amount of potential loopholes in the rules in force throughout Europe. Deregulation is therefore, above all, a programme for disempowering large companies and serves to revitalise competition, which can benefit SMEs in particular.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my S&D and EPLP colleagues, I voted in favour of this report because the S&D Group managed to include micro-enterprises (e.g. social enterprises) and start-ups in the report and ensure that these businesses are covered by new initiatives focusing on green growth. The S&D Group also ensured that industrial synergies, symbioses and clusters are promoted within the text.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on green growth opportunities for SMEs. I welcome the rapporteur's initiative to focus his legislative initiative on the potential for green economic growth for the SME sector. The report underlines the added value of the EU budget in supporting SMEs, micro-enterprises, social enterprises and cooperatives to facilitate access to finance and international markets, in particular through the COSME Programme and under Horizon 2020 and the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds). It also calls on the Commission to include green services in the negotiations currently taking place on the agreement on environmental goods, but also in bilateral trade agreements such as TTIP, with the aim of reducing barriers for European SMEs and service providers who want to assert themselves internationally.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on green growth opportunities for SMEs. SMEs are the backbone of the European economy and are important levers for economic growth and job creation. The green economy can indeed offer new opportunities for SMEs in the EU, as long as the funding resources for this transition are found and the appropriate framework for research, development and innovation is ensured.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have today approved the own-initiative report on green growth opportunities for SMEs, which calls for more funding, harmonisation of national regulations, red tape and effective communication to encourage more environmentally sustainable small and medium-sized enterprises. First of all, we called for more effective communication on alternative forms of financing to bank lending, such as risk capital, business angels and collective financing, as the green economy needs a wide range of instruments.  All too often SMEs also face too strict bankruptcy laws which do not allow a new business to start up without difficulty after the bankruptcy of an economic activity. It is also important to share knowledge and disseminate it: the most important points are cross-sectoral collaborations, the creation of informal networks and the incalculable role that industry federations can and should play in this regard. Particular attention should also be paid to excessive bureaucracy, which entails additional burdens and obstacles to the functioning of the internal market: the various national systems, which are often too divergent, should be simplifyed and more harmonised measures ensured.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on green growth opportunities for SMEs. It is an own-initiative report in response to the Commission communication on the Green Growth Action Plan and focuses on funding opportunities, resource efficiency, energy efficiency, the circular economy and industrial synergies.  I think it is extremely appropriate to explore all the growth opportunities for SMEs, given that they account for more than 98% of European businesses and provide over 67% of total employment in the Union and 58% of gross value added. I will conclude by pointing out that SMEs are the backbone of the Eu ropean Union economy and are a key factor in European economic growth in the long term.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The starting point for my support for this initiative is that SMEs are an important part of the European economy and job creation. The Commission's Green Action Plan for SMEs is a welcome stimulus, which is a further stimulus for the beneficial development of green growth. Sharing and dissemination of knowledge is a key prerequisite for developing green growth opportunities. In my opinion, the most important factor is interdisciplinary cooperation, the creation of informal networks, which are the main sources of information in this regard, from technology to suppliers to State aid programmes and other aspects. It is clear that green growth has considerable potential.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome today's vote because I believe that the green economy can offer businesses, especially small and medium-sized ones, considerable economic and ecological benefits. SMEs must learn to identify and exploit the opportunities for green growth that the market is now able to offer, not least in view of the fact that the green economy sector and the market for environmental goods and services have not been affected by the crisis that has hit the European economy in recent years. Of course, as the rapporteur has pointed out, we cannot fail to recognise the existence of a whole series of difficulties faced by SMEs every day. It is therefore essential for the legislator to identify and address these issues in order to create a harmonised framework in support of entrepreneurship that allows even small companies to make full use of the potential of the sector.  In particular, access to credit must be facilitated, including through alternative methods of financing, efforts must be made to progressively reduce bureaucracy, provide for a regulatory framework capable of meeting the challenges that new technologies have put in place, encourage shared investment in research and development and greater sharing and dissemination of knowledge.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report first declares its support for the concept of green growth, the economically viable exploitation of wind, solar, hydro and geothermal energy, energy efficiency and resource use, waste management, the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, the circular flow of recycling and reuse of raw materials. It refers to the importance of the role of SMEs in this comprehensive framework for fostering job creation and economic growth. At first, we don't disagree. These are fair objectives, which are undoubtedly opportunities for the development of a wide range of small and medium-sized enterprises. But it is clear that the concept of growth here is that of capitalist growth, by nature unsustainable – however much they try to paint it green. Among other proposals and approaches on which we disagree head-on, the rapporteur encourages Member States to amend their bankruptcy legislation by speeding up the process, meeting the scarcity liberal concept of 'creative destruction'.  It calls on the Commission to "alleviat the fear of bankruptcy" by promoting awareness-raising and education campaigns. For all this we have not been able to follow the meaning of the report.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on green growth opportunities because, overall, it introduces monitoring of the results of the Green Plan for SMEs, which will make it possible to take swift and effective corrective measures if the strategy proves to be deficient. So far, it has not been possible to monitor the performance of SMEs which have had access to green innovation funding and which have only partly become a real saving for the company. Our vote was instrumental in calling on the Commission to include, in the circular economy package, the extension of the eco-design instrument in order to bring it within the resource efficiency dimension. Some doubts remain as to whether legislative proposals could be put forward which would place an unnecessary administrative burden on SMEs. Overall, however, this was a step forward, so I voted in favour.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for the joint discussion on the CSDP (Article 36 of the EU Treaty) on: - The report by Arnaud Danjean, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the implementation of the common security and defence policy (according to the Council's annual report to the European Parliament on the Common Foreign and Security Policy) (2014/2220(INI) (A8-0054/2015), - the report by Eduard Kukan and Indrek Tarand, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on Budgets, on the financing of the Common Security and Defence Policy (2014/2258(INI) (A8-0136/2015), and - Ana Gomes' report, on behalf of the Committee on foreign affairs, on the impact of developments in European defence markets on security and defence capabilities in Europe (2015/2037(INI) (A8-0159/2015).

name: Arnaud Danjean
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Madam High Representative, never since the launch of the European Common Security and Defence Policy 16 years ago has Europe faced so many simultaneous crises on its borders and on its soil, as well as multifaceted threats to its external and internal security: regional conflicts, civil wars, terrorism, migration dramas. nuclear and conventional proliferation.  The immense geopolitical recomposition underway poses unprecedented challenges to our continent, particularly in its eastern and southern flanks, if not in their nature - wars and terrorism, we have known them for a long time - but, in any case, in their magnitude.  In the face of these dramatic developments, the European Union and its member states have a dual duty to act: to act to protect themselves and to act in our environment to reduce instability. Unfortunately, we must recognize that the impression that prevails among our fellow citizens but also outside our borders is that of a European powerlessness: in Ukraine, Syria, Iraq, the Middle East, Libya, the Horn of Africa, the Sahel. There are very few crises and conflicts today in which Europe, collectively or through its Member States, plays a truly decisive role in the measure of its interests, its values and its diplomatic, economic and military weight. Even where the action of some Europeans seems the most assertive and robust, such as that of France in the Sahel, the scale of the diplomatic, military and economic task, our budgetary constraints and our capacity limits leave no illusions about the very relative impact of what is being undertaken by a few. In this context, the common security and defence policy could and should be a major instrument for Europe to finally assume its responsibilities for its own security and that of its environment. I am a realist, so I am not saying that this common policy is the only possible one because national policies as well as multilateral partnerships such as the Atlantic Alliance are permanently essential structures for the defence of the continent and our nations. That is recognized in the treaties. Similarly, the common security and defence policy is not and will not be a genuine defence policy in the near future. It is an instrument, a crisis management policy, and we must first consider it as such.  The problem is that the crises are there. They are always more intense, ever closer, and our "management" is less and less up to these challenges.  The guidelines that you are proposing, Madam High Representative, with the defence ministers you met yesterday in Brussels for the European Council in June are a step in the right direction, and I congratulate you on the determined action you have taken since you took office. These guidelines are based on the same observation that I have just made, of dissatisfaction, inadequacy and urgency. You pointed out that the European Union is currently deploying 11 civilian missions and five military operations. The professionalism and dedication of our civilian and military personnel is remarkable, and we must salute them. But the respect we owe to these personnel, who are deployed in difficult theatres on behalf of the European Union, also obliges us to recognise that these missions and operations all too often become forms of alibi for our presence. I will say that our visibility sometimes takes a step on our effectiveness in our judgment on these missions. Therefore, I hope that you will carry out this evaluation work. In conclusion, because time is running out and there would be a lot to say also industrially and with capacity, of course, I would just like to point out that today we do not need creativity, inventiveness or imagination. We need to know how to read. Everything we need in terms of security and defence is in the Treaty: enhanced cooperation, permanent structured cooperation, flexibility with Article 44, financing and solidarity mechanisms, all of this is in the Treaty.  We are counting on you, High Representative, to remind the Member States.

name: Eduard Kukan
text: Rapporteur. – Today's debate on the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) is taking place at a time of unprecedented challenges and risks to our defence and security. Today, more than ever, we can feel the consequences of conflicts and instability in the immediate vicinity of our borders. We are debating at a time that is not the most favourable to the Union. In addition, we know that defence and security spending has been limited for a long time within the EU. We must therefore look at how we can deal with these funds more efficiently, more flexibly, but also more transparently. We need to start seriously addressing the vision of European defence by improving the coordination of our military and civilian missions, raising the issue of more flexible financial procedures and improving the setting up of structures responsible for broadcasting and operating our missions. In this sense, I am also directing a call on you, the High Representative, and the representatives of the Member States to give full use of the relevant part of the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular Article 44 on the entrustment of the implementation of the mission to the Group of Member States and Article 46 on permanent structured cooperation. As regards saving and improving efficiency, I would like to welcome the fact that some financial procedures relating to civilian missions have been shortened. It has also been possible to identify measures that will lead to an investigation. However, many situations require the rapid deployment and operationality of missions where financial flexibility and efficiency are needed. There are still problems. The Shared Service Centre , together with an integrated resource management system, could contribute to the improvement. As far as possible, we should also expand the operation of the permanent CSDP warehouse – CSDP warehouse – and allow existing mission to be fully utilization. Another challenge is greater coherence and complementarity in the functioning of civilian and military missions and operations. We need to improve coordination in the areas of logistics, transport, health security and mission protection. At the same time, we should pay greater attention to the coordination and interconnection of areas such as industry, the common market, research and development. As regards the financing of military operations through the Athena mechanism, it is essential that the philosophy of its operation is gradually changed. We need to move towards a better distribution of the financial burden among the Member States and certainly ensure long-term financing of military operations. The rapid deployment of missions and their effective functioning are proving increasingly problematic. In order to improve their funding, we need to start looking at the issue of opening Athena for contributions from third countries and international organisations. The next European Council, which will address security issues, should also be used to reform and improve the setting up of financial mechanisms for missions and operations. Finally, High Representative, the CSDP is an increasingly pressing issue. You need to be fully in control of it and ensure better coordination between Member States, European institutions and organisations such as NATO. You are surely well aware that, at the moment, we simply cannot afford to neglect the key issues of European defence and security.

name: Indrek Tarand
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, let me first of all inform you and Vice-President Mogherini what a great pleasure it was to work with a connoisseur like Mr Kukan. Everything we wanted to say is written in the report. Please allow me to paint a small illustration about the things we are really talking about, knowing very well that security threats to Europe are triangular. They come from the south, the east and the south-east.  I will concentrate on the Baltic Sea. In recent months, Russian military ships have been harassing and sabotaging the crews that are laying the NordBalt power cable between Sweden and Lithuania. This cable would enable the Baltic states to reduce their dependence on Russian energy, which clearly is not in Russiaʼs interests, not only for financial reasons but because Russia likes to wield energy as a political weapon. This is a prime example of how the absence of an effective CSDP has negative spillover effects into other important European policy areas such as the energy union. Russia is effectively sabotaging European energy security and the energy union by disrupting the creation of new energy interconnections. We are also in a situation in which France has two Mistral-class warships that have been built but are now collecting dust as their delivery to Russia would constitute a significant security threat to the EU. Due to underfunding and lack of political will up to now, the European Union has not yet been able to purchase these ships. This must now change.  These ships would make an effective contribution to the CSDP naval branch and could be used in a variety of ways. For instance, they could be of critical help in solving the crisis in the Mediterranean, particularly close to the coast of Libya, or they could patrol in the Baltic Sea and offer support to the crews laying the NordBalt cable. This does not mean that the ships would need to engage with the Russian vessels currently harassing the crews. Their mere presence would be enough.  Right now it is the mere absence of any European forces that allows Russian warships and fighter planes to perform these demonstrations of force whenever they please. So actually what we have discovered is that the European Union’s budget is an incredibly useful tool. If we create a budget line, the political goals will eventually be achieved, and that is why we suggest bringing a lot more order to the current financing of the common security and defence policy.  Let us be brave and forget about the dogmas. The European Union’s common defence will be based on physical facts, one of them – most importantly – being the European common defence force. That is why I am one of the supporters of Mr Juncker’s new proposals. So let us create the budget line and start with the things which need to be done. Otherwise our children will have little reason to be grateful to us.

name: Ana Gomes
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Madam High Representative, yesterday's Decision by the Council to launch a naval mission in the Mediterranean under the Common Security and Defence Policy is a decisive step and in the right direction, but it must be justified by the imperative to save lives and thus prevent the founding principles and values of the European project from sinking. Only then to dismantle the slave networks that instrumentalize the tragedies that drive refugees and immigrants to Europe.  It is deplorable in this context that some governments refuse to accept quotas for the reception of people in need of protection. This is a slow-moving mission, the tragedy of the Mediterranean did not begin yesterday and it is a problem for everyone in Europe and not just a few states on the front line. It is with a strategic sense and coherence between all internal security and external action policies, including development, trade and energy supply policies, that the European Union must act on all fronts to help peoples resolve conflicts, get rid of oppressive regimes and to tackle other causes of migration flows, such as poverty. Opening up legal avenues for migrants is indispensable to take profit from traffickers and give opportunities to those who are desperate for them, and Europe, in demographic decline, must assume that it needs immigrants. It is necessary not to take longer and to put eunavfor Mediterranean at sea. Development security work and support for governance in the neighbourhood, in the south, in particular Libya, Syria and Iraq, must also be done. It is shocking that there is no coordination between Europeans, with military supplies to forces in Iraq and Syria to form fighters against the Islamic State. On the other hand, it is urgent to prepare a compromise that will have to be long-term. I speak of Libya where we have special responsibilities for action and omission and where we have strategic interests and even have today the vital interest of not letting it become a terrorist sanctuary on our doorstep. European commitment to capacity building, including in the organisation of the security sector, needs to be programmed on the assumption that the UN Special Representative Bernardino Léon is able to forge an agreement for a government of national unity. But if it does not succeed and the state failure in Libya continues and worsens, let us agree that we will need to intervene for our own security and defence, and we must work now to seek support from the United Nations Security Council. For this mission in the Mediterranean, we have made progress without a security council warrant and, despite the efforts of the High Representative recently in New York, it is in fact a matter, as I said, to protect, save lives and combat the slavers. But this failure highlights the pressing need for reform of the United Nations Security Council. This has to be put on the European agenda: it is time to demand the reform of the Security Council and to re-refer to a mandate, a permanent membership for Europe. For EUNAVFOR Mediterranean to be operational as soon as possible, as the Council wants, Member States need to make human resources and equipment available, because the Union does not have its own civilian or military resources.  Now, in the report that I am the author and which we will look at today, we demand precisely a drastic change in the culture of our governments. It is essential that Member States, under the guidance of the High Representative, cooperate more in the field of the acquisition of military equipment and equipment. It is essential that they articulate their policies and weapons options. It is essential that they invest in pooling and sharing, and that a plan of needs and objectives in the field of joint military equipment is drawn up, which actually responds to the needs and allows us, as the Union, to fulfil our obligations. Let us recognize that good intentions do not serve when we know in advance that it will take months before EUNAVFOR Mediterranean is operational. The price to pay is too expensive. We cannot allow the soberant illusion and protectionist opacity of some governments to curb the Action of the European Union in a matter so fundamental to the collective security and credibility of the Union. We therefore ask the Commission to invest in monitoring the implementation of the two internal market directives in the field of procurement and transfers of defence equipment and equipment, and to require member states to comply with the new rules.  In place of having a functional internal market in this area, it is crucial that the corrupt and opaque practices that undermine the sector, which prevent possibilities for cooperation, competition and technological development, and are, moreover, a bad return on taxpayers' money invested in national budgets of Defense. The good implementation of these directives is fundamental to the defence industrial and technological base, which, as the Council also identified yesterday, is the key part of the Union's strategy for collective security and defence.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, let me start by thanking everyone, and in particular the four rapporteurs, for the excellent work done on the reports – this is my personal opinion – but also for the very clear, determined way in which you have worked and also presented the reports today, but even more than that, for the ambitious approach.  This is what we need at this moment. We all start by saying never before have we needed a more ambitious approach than we do now. Well, I think it is time to translate this analysis, which is right, into action and I find your words, your work, your reports, and the overall attitude of this Parliament in this respect extremely helpful in supporting an ambitious approach, including openly addressing some of the shortcomings that are the basis for changing and for delivering more of this sense of openness, of frankness, concerning the shortcomings and the needs we have to increase our level of ambition. It is also my approach, and that level of ambition that your reports are expressing is also my level of ambition in this field. As Members have said, Europe is facing multiple security challenges today and there is no doubt that we need to step up our common efforts in Europe. I would say, in one sentence, that we need more defence in our European work and we need a more European approach in defence. This is the substance of what we are discussing here this afternoon.  CSDP and defence cooperation are crucial, yet they only work fully, they only unfold their full potential, if they are part of a comprehensive strategy, of a comprehensive policy, using all the instruments that we have as Europeans, linking the external and internal dimension of our policies in an intelligent way. Not only that – this is not the issue for debate this afternoon – we also need to use the tools that we have, including CSDP, not only in reaction to events, but also in a strategic way to build security.  Building security is not only defence, it is also building the conditions for security worldwide and in particular in the regions around us: conflict prevention, development cooperation, promotion of human rights and democracy, coherence, economic and trade policies, including our own ones, even prevention and management of natural disasters and climate change. All of this is building security in the world, in the key areas in our neighbourhood and, at the end of the day, our own citizens’ security. This is going to be tackled in a systematic way when we discuss, in the European Council at the end of June with Heads of State and Government, not only CSDP but also our need for a new strategy, our strategic review. I will present in June the assessment I was asked and tasked to present on the global challenges we have in front of us, on the EU role in facing this. I hope that from there we will define and decide whether – or rather how – we need to develop a new European strategy to tackle the different and more challenging environment facing us.  I think that the need to put together all the instruments we have is more obvious than ever in the challenges that we are facing in tackling the human tragedies that we see in the Mediterranean Sea. Some of you mentioned that. Finally we have started to mobilise all our efforts to prevent further loss of life at sea. I say finally, and I say finally in the European way.  As one of these efforts, the European Council at the end of April asked me to prepare a CSDP operation to disrupt the business model of human trafficking networks across the Mediterranean. Yesterday, at the Joint Council meeting of Foreign and Defence Ministers which I chaired, all Member States agreed to establish a CSDP operation to disrupt trafficking and smuggling networks. We took the decision yesterday to activate an operational headquarters and appoint an operational commander.  There is still obviously some work to be done before the launch of this mission, namely on operational planning and on force generation. But let me say that the decision on establishing the operation being taken less than one month after the European Council was asking, or tasking, for preparation on that is an absolute record. I was told that it normally takes six to ten months to take the decision to establish an operation. I know that time is not in itself an element of evaluation, but in this case time is an element of urgency that we need to face, especially when summer is coming.  So I have to say that I think that this is the best way of addressing the issue of better and more effective CSDP in Europe, specifically using the instruments we have on the basis of the situations we are facing on a day-to-day basis. Let me remind you in this Hemicycle that it is exactly one month today since we faced that tragedy in the Mediterranean Sea when 700 to 800 hundred people died.  It is still not enough, we still have a lot more work to do in different areas, but I think that for the first time we can say that we have a quick and European response to this crisis.  Still, the preparation of a CSDP mission in the Mediterranean and the reinforcement of the existing CSDP mission, especially the one in Niger that was decided last week, are only two elements, important ones but only two elements of our strategy to tackle this challenge.  Last week the Commission presented the European Agenda on Migration – which this House will be debating tomorrow – outlining the immediate measures to respond to the crisis in the Mediterranean, both on the humanitarian and on the security side, and the steps to be taken, both immediate ones and the long-term ones. Let me stress here that no Member State can be left alone – should not be left alone – to face the huge migratory pressure, as this is a European responsibility. I think that finally we are beginning to realise that. The way forward is, and will still be, hard and long, but we are probably now starting to realise that.  We are finally proposing a European response which has never been the case before: combining internal and external policies, working together as Europeans on the immediate humanitarian emergency, on the security situation, as well as the root causes in countries of origin and transit. Tackling the root causes means tackling poverty, unequal access to resources, be they natural or financial, tackling conflicts, crises and the violation of human rights; conflicts and crises, starting obviously with Libya, and the support we are giving to the dialogue led by Bernardino León. This is specifically what ‘comprehensive approach’ means. To me the point is to make this comprehensive approach – which I understand is also sometimes criticised in the Danjean report – real, to make it happen, to make it work, using all the instruments that we have – and they are many – and achieving more coherence among the different instruments and the way we are using them. We need that more than ever. Since December 2013, when the European leaders took some decisions on security and defence, you have all said that the security situation in and around the European Union has changed dramatically. It has clearly not changed in a positive way. The concurrency, intensity, frequency and complexity of conflicts and crises in our neighbourhood is unique and the speed with which this has happened is even more unique. That is also why we need to seriously rethink our way of building security while we manage the urgency of current crises. That is also why we need a strategy to move ahead.  The demand for the European Union to act as a provider of security is increasing and will, most probably, continue to increase. We will only be able to respond to this demand in a credible way if we make the CSDP more effective and if we make sure we have the right kinds of capabilities, which in turn needs a solid, defence industrial base. The European Council in June will be an occasion to take stock of progress in this regard and to show the way ahead.  I have just presented my report to the Foreign Affairs Council, ahead of the June Council, and simultaneously the Commission delivered its report on the implementation of its 2013 Defence Communication. Both documents register progress in most areas where the European Council in 2013 set tasks, and point to areas where we need, and we can have, further progress. I would say we need, we can and we must have further progress. We worked on this just yesterday, as you mentioned, with the defence and foreign ministers together, putting together – this is also a comprehensive approach – different sides of our CSDP work. Among the achievements I can mention, we have the adoption of the EU’s first comprehensive maritime strategy and action plan, or the cyber policy framework. I would like to mention specifically one element: the security development nexus.  On this, I think we learned an important lesson from the CSDP training missions in Somalia, in Mali and in Niger, which is that the troops we train must often be supplied with equipment – tents, uniforms, radios, basic infrastructure. At the end of April the Commission adopted a joint communication based on my proposal to enable the European Union to train and equip the forces of local partners. It was addressed to the Council and to Parliament and I count on your support to take this forward, as it would be an extremely relevant and precious step. Being completely frank, as you are, there are also areas where the picture is much less encouraging. I am thinking of rapid response where the lack of political will has so far made it impossible to move. I know this is frustrating for many Members of this Parliament. It is frustrating for me, as well. Force generation, too, is problematic. I raised this with Ministers yesterday in a very clear and open way. If we take decisions then we need to translate them into action. This is a matter of being operational, this is also a matter of credibility, and this means taking responsibilities in the Member States with concrete decisions to follow up on force generation.  I also know that some of you are very eager to see the full potential of CSDP-related articles of the Lisbon Treaty fully used. The relevant sections of Mr Danjeanʼs report are very precious in this regard and let me say that I am completely determined to work with your support, with your help, to build the political conditions for having this done. Progress has also remained limited on CSDP financing more broadly. Indeed, the tension between our level of ambition and the level of resources has grown even bigger. The Kukan and Tarand report rightly raises a number of issues for both civilian and military CSDP financing. On cost saving and efficiency measures in civilian missions: we will continue working with the Commission to facilitate a faster deployment of civilian missions and improvements in the financial management. In that context, I would like to stress the importance of sufficient payment appropriations for the CFSP budget. On financing of military operations, the review of the Athena mechanism took place recently. A new Council decision was adopted at the end of March. While largely inconclusive, these debates will continue. I am ready, and most of all I am willing, to support and to lead the debate among Member States and, I hope, to lead it to some results. This is going to be key. The question of burden-sharing among Member States, which is what this question is, is crucial and needed if we are to face a future – and hopefully also a present – CSDP that really works. As the demand for CSDP will remain high, we also need to fill our defence capability gaps. At a time of reduced public spending, the pooling and sharing of capacities and resources, especially of high-end capabilities, is more than ever a recipe that can reconcile possibilities and needs in this regard.  We have made some important steps toward implementing collaborative projects. We agreed back in 2013 on air-to-air refuelling capacity, remotely piloted craft systems, satellite communications and cyber. Their development, notably on the first of these projects, is now in an advanced stage but I made it very clear to the Ministers yesterday that we also need to embark on new collaborative projects. We have to bring forward the ones that we already have, and we need to put new ones on the table. This Parliament has calculated – as you said, we do not need to be imaginative, we need to read the things that we already know and make them real – that the cost of non-Europe in defence amounts to some EUR 26 billion per year, an enormous amount of money, especially in these times, and more than that, as we are all politicians in this room, 70% of European citizens support more integration in defence. This is the clearest call for action that we could receive and I count on your support. Count, please, on my full determination to make this real, to have more European integration in defence.  We also need to spend better, and better together. This is a crucial point, especially in these times of austerity, and we need to focus on the output. We need to invest too in our partnerships. The one with NATO – that is essential. Hybrid, non-linear risks: I have put a premium on enhanced cooperation and contingency planning. If the old debate on a NATO-EU rivalry ever had any sense it does not anymore; it does not make any sense in these times.  I was happy to welcome the NATO Secretary-General, Jens Stoltenberg, yesterday at our ministerial meeting, just as I was happy to be at the Foreign Ministers NATO meeting last week in Antalya. Our cooperation is increasing, not only our cooperation at the highest political level, but staff-to-staff cooperation is also going on very well. We are different in nature, but we have some common points on the agenda that we can coordinate and cooperate on. The other extremely relevant cooperation we have to invest in is the one with the United Nations. All Member States have just agreed on a new action plan to announce EU support for UN peacekeeping, and the UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon will be at the Foreign Affairs Council on 22 June. We need to work on different aspects on different levels, as your reports clearly identify.  The Gomes report on the impact of developments in European defence markets on the security and defence capabilities in Europe indicates that the competitiveness of the European defence industry is a priority, and I fully support this. A strong competitive European defence industrial base needs more cooperation between Member States, a more efficient internal market, more robust security of supply guarantees, competitive and integrated supply chains, and support for research and innovation.  A healthy industrial base is indeed key in support of any credible defence policy as, among others, it generates cutting-edge programmes, innovation with spillover effects into the civilian domain and vice versa, and a highly skilled workforce that accounts for 400 000 direct and 960 000 indirect jobs across Europe. At the same time, our industry faces a wide range of challenges both at the global and at the European level: increasingly globalised supply chains, increased defence of said demands, global shifts in defence spending.  Our ratio regarding R&D investment is 1:7 as compared to the US but, and this is the news, 1:3 in comparison with the so-called BRICs. The plunge in defence R&D since 2006, more than 29% in real terms, is detrimental to much needed innovation in Europe and puts at risk our capability in producing defence equipment and the competitiveness of our industry.  The European industrial landscape remains characterised by a fragmented demand side, a plethora of national programmes and variance of equipment, generating high costs for industry. Increasingly integrated civilian military supply chains with a growing reliance on civilian technologies means that companies more and more rely on civil production in terms of turnover and revenues. If nothing is done, we could face the risk in the longer term of having a lower level of technological sophistication due to slower rates of innovation. We could also face decreasing competitiveness with the ultimate loss of production capacities and jobs and thus increasing dependence on foreign supplies – and we are talking about the European Union.  The Gomes report also highlights the need for a full and correct implementation of the two Defence Directives of 2009 with a view to opening up the defence market chains for companies from all over Europe. An open and transparent European defence equipment market is a precondition for our defence companies to access European supply chains in view of building strategic and sustainable alliances with European partners. I fully share the objective to ensure the effective implementation of the Defence Procurement and the Defence Transfers Directives. The Commission has started evaluating the Defence Directives and in 2016 will report to Parliament and Council on their implementation and on whether they have achieved their objectives.  In December 2013, Heads of State and Government called for more investment in cooperative research programmes, more synergies between defence and civil research, as well as for a preparatory action on CSDP-related research to be set up. Here we have three avenues. First, collaborative defence R&T. The European Defence Agency (EDA) has a longstanding track record in defence R&T projects and programmes. Second, dual-use research, and third, the establishment of the preparatory action on CSDP-related research, a potential game-changer testing the viability of defence-oriented and CSDP-related research at European Union level.  The Commission has the lead here, but the EDA, having long experience in defence R&T, can provide support. Joint Commission-EDA workshops with stakeholders to discuss the modalities, content and the process to establish such a preparatory action, are paving the way.  Another potential game-changer could be the Council mandate on developing a European Union-wide security and supply regime. Security of supply is essential for the sustainment of operations, the development of long-term planning and cooperation, and the functioning of the internal market for defence. We expect the roadmap for the comprehensive EU-wide security of supply regime in early 2016.
