To conclude, let me thank you for the work you have done, for the work of this Parliament in general on CSDP, and also on the preparation for the June Council. I know you have been working very hard and intensively on this and this is extremely helpful.  Let me conclude by mentioning those 7 000 men and women who are currently deployed under the EU flag in military and civilian missions under dangerous and difficult conditions, from Afghanistan to Somalia, from Mali to the Central African Republic. I want to end my comments today by saluting the work of men and women deployed in the field under the EU flag and thank them for what they are doing. This is what we should remember all the time: that our discussions, our decisions, are then translated in their work on a daily basis, in very difficult conditions, for the security of our citizens, the stability of the regions where they are deployed and peace in our world. (Applause)

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – I would also like to thank the High Representative for her thoughts. Indeed, the defence policy issue is an important issue, and the migration issue is no longer knocking on the door, but is already in the living room waiting to be answered. Nevertheless, allow me not to deal with this issue, but precisely to talk about the conditions of protection and the importance of creating it, as the rapporter of IMCO on this issue, with a particular focus on the subject. At the end of her speech, Madam High Representative touched on the very important issues, such as the transposition of the Defence Directive. I fully agree with this, it is very important that the Member States trans implant this directive. Only in this way can we be able to talk about an integrated internal market, and this fragmentation that we have had can be reduced. All the more so because, let us be honest, our previous measures to unify demand have not been very successful. I can also say that, for example, the European Defence Agency's capability development plan has not produced any results either. I look forward to the decision of the June Summit, its conclusions and the actual work.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – I think there is a need to strengthen the European defence industry by strengthening the single market. We have a difficult situation with a reduction in defence spending - I think that on this issue budgetary rigour has gone beyond all limits, that is to say it has become counterproductive - we have a poor distribution of reduced defence spending at the expense of research and at the expense of the supply of weapons systems, we are behind the United States of America and so our strategic autonomy is lost or restricted. Of course we agree on most issues, but there is always the possibility of disagreement or the possibility of wrong choices that we are forced to follow. We are also concerned about new threats: for example, the NATO Parliamentary Assembly held in Budapest and in which I took part. The reflection was around Russia's defence programme, which is extremely ambitious. We also have new global players, such as the People's Republic of China.  I therefore believe that the time has come - and this is the message both from the Gomes report and from what we have heard today from the remarkable rapporteurs - for a better distribution of European defence spending, for a basic European approach and opportunities for both the protagonists and small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Ioan Mircea Pașcu
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the judgement that, in view of the deterioration of the current security environment both around and within Europe, the EU will have to appeal more and more frequently to the CSDP is both correct and the realistic. The problem is that the CSDP, as mentioned by Mr Danjean, is only a crisis management instrument conceived for use primarily outside Europe and in obvious need of more flexible implementation procedures. It does not provide for the defence of either the EU Member States, who rely for that on NATO, or the EU non—NATO Member States who, in absence of NATO membership, have to rely exclusively on the EU for their defence.  The truth is that in view of the intensity, complexity and localisation of the current crisis, the UN and NATO have a mutual need of each other more than at any time before. Past mistrust, and even competition between the two organisations, is not warranted any longer. These have to be replaced by substantive cooperation across the board. I am glad to hear that just confirmed by the High Representative.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Madam High Representative/Vice-President of the European Commission, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Schwab, for his excellent report. I wanted to thank all the rapporteurs for their hard, innovative work, which is undoubtedly a valuable achievement in the debate ahead of the important European Council meeting in June, which is to be devoted to the common security and defence policy. It is difficult to address all the issues raised, allow me, therefore, to focus on paragraph 42 of the Arnaud Danjean report, which raises the need for increased spending, increased defence burdens by the Member States of the European Union in achieving nato targets, namely to reach 2% of GDP (for several countries it is already more than 2% of GDP), but also to spend 20% of their expenditure on important defence, on major armaments and also on research and development.  My people, my compatriots, but also representatives of the societies of other central and eastern European countries saw integration in the European Union not only as an accession to the sphere of prosperity, but also as an additional aspect of increasing security. So we also care about this component of the functioning of the European Union, but we think that we need a higher culture, a greater willingness to cooperate in bearing the burden, a common perception of the threats we face – whether it is the South and terrorism that threatens our territories, or the Russian Federation. These matters must first and foremost be the subject of our considerations.

name: Jozo Radoš
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Madam President, Ms. High Representative, colleagues and colleagues, at the beginning I would like to congratulate Mr. Danjean, Mr. Kukan, Tarand and Mrs. Gomes on very clear and open reports, and I think it is important to note that similar views contained in the reports are also expressed by the Council of the European Union in its conclusions yesterday, which was also discussed by Ms. High Representative, to whom I congratulate at the same time on the open and stimulating communication she has within the Council of the European Union.  I will state only the council's most important conclusions, namely that security circumstances in Europe have changed dramatically in recent years, that there is a need for a stronger and more effective European security and defence policy, and the Council underlines the importance of a new strategic approach to European foreign and security and defence policy. I will list only one practical, concrete point of the Council conclusions concerning the objectives set by the European Defence Agency in 2007 with regard to cooperation in the field of joint and overall procurement and research. It should be noted that none of these conclusions and objectives of the European Defence Agency in terms of joint and overall procurement and investment in research has been achieved.  Therefore, everything is said and everything has been said for a long time. Therefore, the European Council in November 2016 should be expected to set the foundations for a stronger, new and more efficient European defence and security policy.

name: Sabine Lösing
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her All three reports outline a steady deterioration in security worldwide, especially in Europe's neighbours to the south and east. There seems to be only one consequence here: more armament, more money for the arms industry and arms research, more so-called robust EU operations and, best of all, everything paid for from the EU budget. But what is cause, what is effect? If one does not debate the causes and one's own share of them – of course, then the spectrum of consequences is logically small, a change of policy is not an issue. For example.B the impact of the EU's external economic policy, which has led to disastrous trade balances, including in the Countries of the Southern Neighbourhood Policy. The pursuit of one's own geostrategic interests, the creation of sales markets, access to resources: when one's own interest is at the top, when countries are even regarded as the power-political backyards, conflicts arise. In order to counter this, military resources are needed. The rapporteurs find a further conclusion from the threats in a concoathing of internal and external security, which thus also makes military operations in The European country possible. This is a huge problem for democracy. We are talking about more armaments cooperation, more spending on defence and the use of civilian funds for military purposes, e.B. for the development of drones, on the grounds that it would increase security and save money. Wrong! Constant structured cooperation, pooling and sharing and battlegroups, all of this does not serve to relieve the burden on state budgets. These measures, and this has been demonstrated, do not save money. And the veto rights of parliaments in decisions on wars and arms spending are being undermined. A peace union does not create a huge subsidy programme for the arms industry, for example.B by exempting them from VAT, but is equipping it.

name: Bodil Ceballos
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Mrs Mogherini, I often agree with you, but as far as the military operation decided by the Council the other day to stop the traffickers is concerned, I certainly do not. Militarising migration policy is completely the wrong way to go. The only thing we can achieve with such an effort is that people die elsewhere and that the smugglers find new ways. As long as their market exists, they will continue to shoe themselves to people's misfortune. The only way we have to take out their market is to combat the root causes of people fleeing. It is better to get a decision in the Security Council to end the conflict in Syria than to try to get a decision to enter Libyan waters to sink boats. It is not worthy, as a Nobel Peace Prize winner, to look more at one's own internal interests than to work towards more peaceful development in the world around us. It is not the people who are fleeing to us who are a security problem, but the wars in our neighbouring countries that are. Then, with regard to the reports we are talking about today, we Greens believe that they have too much focus on the military rather than the civilian one. They talk more about territorial security rather than human security. Not least, we have a major problem with the proposal that all Member States should spend 2% of their GDP on defence. Quantity is not the same as quality. We may have many aircraft, ships, tanks and other munitions, but if we cannot afford to man them, or even personnel for them, there is only one winner, namely the arms industry. We believe that we need to be much better with pooling and sharing and better cooperation. We are also critical of certain very vague wordings that can be interpreted as allowing military operations to be financed in part through aid. That is paragraph 25 of Mr Danjean's report.  We have put forward a number of proposals for change. We haven't gotten through much of them. We will see how we stand tomorrow, but we will try to push through the deletions of points that we think are wrong.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Given that the Union does not have any troops, these considerations are reminiscent of impotent advice on how to make children. Fortunately, there have long been no threats: in all the arms countries I know, they are made in terms of how to develop the economy of a region, how to take as much bribe as possible for armaments. Even in these reports, as we look at, there is no word on how to give the best weapons to soldiers. We can only see which region will earn and what will develop. That would be a disgrace, fortunately we are still not in danger. Of course, if one day Vladimir Putin changes policy from imperial to national, or nationalists overthrow Mr Putin, then Estonia, Latvia, maybe even Lithuania may feel threatened, but this is a problem for NATO and not for the European Union. That is why I believe that the European Union should be destroyed.

name: Michael Gahler (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you, High Representative, for embracing the European Parliament's level of ambition in european defence. Would the foreign and defence ministers have the same ambition! It is a pity that yesterday in the Council they squandered another opportunity to question more closely the actions and omission of their own defence bureaucracies and the Commission. Personally, I am satisfied with one thing, namely the preparatory action on CSDP defence research. That's going pretty well. However, Parliament and industry are not getting tired of calling on the Commission to finally make it clear that we are moving on a legally sound basis with EU funding for defence research. I am dissatisfied when I read again that we welcome the Policy Framework for Systematic and Long-Term Defence Cooperation. Unfortunately, this paper only describes existing procedures. I would like to ask: where is the courageous step of pointing out the way towards the establishment of permanent structured cooperation, as provided for in the Treaty of Lisbon? CSDP financing: In the current conclusions I read: "There is scope for further discussion on the issue of GSDP financing." This statement is extremely thin. I ask: what have our governments and our defence bureaucracies done to make progress on the issue of joint funding? It is not enough for the Council to sell us that the review of the Athena mechanism has been completed. This review has only resulted in the actual application of existing decision-making rules. I do not see a clear commitment by the Member States to greater solidarity and the establishment of joint funding as a standard for jointly agreed CSDP missions.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank my colleague Danjean for their excellent cooperation on the report. The dramatically altered security environment along Europe's 15 000 km borders puts increasing responsibility before the European Union to ensure stability and security in its environment, without seeking further alibis and shifting or avoiding accountability. We need more efficient coordination of internal and external policies, upgrading existing instruments and innovative defence technology. In short, it is high time for a better common security and defence policy, which until now has most often been a dilemma space. I welcome the Council's readiness, expressed in yesterday's conclusions, to cooperate more intensively between Member States and with international partners. I hope that the determination expressed on paper will turn into concrete actions in practice. In these turbulent times when local crises can quickly escalate into regional and global crises, we have a unique opportunity to revise and strengthen our common foreign and security policy. The global security system founded in San Francisco in 1944 and helsinki in 1975 is looking for a new upgrade.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Madam President, mention of the CSDP invariably leads to a heated discussion of national sovereignty, particularly in my country the UK, which is a major military power. Such debate is, of course, legitimate considering the importance of defence and sovereignty.  We must not let ideology blind us to the potential benefits of the CSDP and should instead seek to take a more pragmatic approach. I have always argued that the CSDP must not be pursued to the detriment of NATO by causing duplication of effort or the decoupling of European defence from that of the United States or Canada – rather it should be developed as a complementary alternative in scenarios for which NATO is ill-suited.  For instance, the successful anti-piracy EUNAVFOR Atalanta naval mission was able to coordinate with the Indian navy which, as a non-aligned movement country, was unable to contribute meaningfully to NATOʼs Operation Ocean Shield, also in the Indian Ocean. This is one example where CSDP can offer real added value without, of course, undermining NATO. But defence resources are scarce in the climate of austerity today, so smart defence and pooling and sharing are great ideas, but ultimately, our priority is for every EU Member State to spend 2% of their national budgets on defence.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I am in favour of increased European defence cooperation, there are many good arguments for this, and one argument is also the one mentioned by Mr Mogherini, that is to say, it can also save money. We need a fairer burden-sharing in the financing of operations. The financing is now mainly provided by those involved in these operations. This will make it difficult for small countries, if they mainly have to pay for the operations themselves, to participate in these operations, among other things. Secondly, joint operations are for the security of the whole of Europe, so then joint funding should also be organised.  Secondly, I would like to emphasise that more cooperation should be done between civilian crisis management and military operations. Of course, I know that military operations have a slightly different nature from civilian operations many times, but surely there are also opportunities to see what can be done together. Thirdly, very briefly: the financing process should be speeded up, but the transparency of the financing of operations must also be maintained in the future.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, I miss in the report a critical assessment of the participation of the Union or countries of the European Union in military operations, particularly in the Arab world, which have resulted in the arrival of both refugees and migrants, as well as an increase in insecurity within the borders of the European Union. In the circumstances, I would be content if you would ensure that in the future the operations involving the Union or countries of the Union will adhere to the principles of the Charter of the United Nations and international law, because, as we all know, this has not always been the case.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her High Representative, you have proudly reported on the EU military action in the Mediterranean, which was decided yesterday. On the other hand, I am concerned that this is a military adventure rather than a contribution to the fight against the refugee disaster. Instead of providing clarity, Mrs Mogherini, you have been talking about the problem at various points. They reflect the unity of the Member States over three stages of escalation, which we all know does not exist. They ignore the fact that it is already possible to destroy angry smugglerships on the high seas. That is why there is no need for military action. They did not clearly stipulate that a mandate from the UN Security Council would be absolutely necessary in phase two and all subsequent phases. And you have completely ignored the fact that actions directly on the coast of Libya, or even on land, would put the EU at the wrong level of involvement in the Libyan civil war. If we want to make EU military policy, then at least with clarity!

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI).
text: Madam President, we are talking about a common European security and defence policy. The terms are already distorted. It is, in fact, a shared defence and security policy, as the report implies, with NATO and with America. The report wants the European authorities to take defence issues seriously in the run-up to the June summit. But what is the seriousness of wanting a common defence policy when our geopolitical options are decided elsewhere? The European defence policy has become that of the United States, it is no longer that of European citizens in its common dimension. The true French patriots are currently rejecting this European security policy, which is a policy of European insecurity and chaos.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: Madam President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I believe – if I may say this as a preliminary point, Madam Vice-President – that I very much support your attempts in connection with the tragedy in the Mediterranean and also the attempts to hinder and put an end to the gangs that lure people onto their boats. And on the report itself, I would like to thank Mr Danjean for his report, and I believe that it comes at an important time, namely in preparation for the June European Council. When I look at the discussions in some Member States, when I discuss with the diplomats, I have the impression that things are not going very ambitiously. I do not see any clear commitment in the preparations for permanent structural cooperation – this is a contract mandate that has not yet been set in motion after five years in order to bring about a coalition of the willing. And I believe that it is important that this is brought to the fore and that it does not last for another five years, and I would ask you to see something happening in this area and to be expressed more clearly – with all the limitations necessary for the final decision. However, we must also see that the link is not yet in place and that the real synergy effects cannot be created, including pooling and sharing, many cooperations, including national cooperation with joint associations. Nato's demand for 2% sounds like a litany of the Millennium Goal: it is not credible! As European nations, we are spending EUR 186 billion on defence , with very little result. And if we do not reach common positions here, we will waste our taxpayers' money. And I believe that this must be expressed at the summit.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to focus on some important issues. Commissioner and High Representative, we are facing some old peculiarities, which I might call strange. I am referring to the European Defence Agency, and this is mentioned in one of the reports. While this European Defence Agency is headed by you, it remains under the authority of the Council and is fully funded from outside the Union budget. These kind of things have to be settled in the end, because this mechanism does not function in reality. At the same time, I am referring to the cooperation between the European Union and NATO. Considering the current challenges and threats to our common security and defence, we need by all means to strengthen cooperation between the two organisations.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – The policy and development of the European Union should be governed by a simple principle: as many common competences of the institutions as common values of interests. The paradox is that, at a time when we have talked so much about the common security and defence policy, about a common foreign policy, we have resigned as a community from those undertakings that were intended to strengthen our security. I am talking about issues such as, for example, the abandonment of the Construction of the Nabucco pipeline. It was a European project to make central Europe independent of dependence on Russian energy resources.  We must always remember that the only right of our cooperation is to strengthen the independence of our countries. Without this, only their incapacitation will remain. Thank you very much.

name: Fernando Maura Barandiarán (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, the geopolitical situation of the European Union has changed dramatically in recent years. The serious events that occur every day at our borders challenge our fundamental values and principles, and jeopardize the liberal and open character of our society. We cannot stand aside and continue to defend individualistic ideas and concepts in the times they run; we need to take a step forward in integrating our foreign and security and defence policy.  We must define common threats; strengthen the possibility of anticipation of attacks against our territory; strengthen our ability to stabilize our neighborhood. In short, we must work in solidarity on the basis of the principles of the European project. Only together can we deal with the current situation. However, we are a long way from much-needed coordination. Our structural shortcomings in the development of a true common security and defence policy must be corrected and directed towards a plan for the creation of a common defence of the European Union, a common defence leading us to European armed forces integrated into a European army. Europe has postponed the idea of common defence for more than fifty years. We can't postpone it anymore.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, it is sad for me to read the Council's conclusions on common security and defence policy. Sad, because I find the European attitude in the neighbourhood crisis irresponsible; irresponsible, for seeking security and defense solutions to political problems. We are paying to have preferred American friendship to the trust of our neighbors; we are paying to have helped destroy large countries like Iraq, Syria or Libya. In the Sahel, in Ukraine or in Libya we have responsibilities in problems that we have helped to create. And we're not going to solve those problems with more militarization, denouncing hybrid wars where there is induced chaos, with a battle group, or with a NATO that threatens neighbors. We're not going to end the gunned-out emigration drama. The solution is in a new regional approach to peer cooperation, which should start, above all, by not bombing or threatening our neighbours.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI). – The reports under discussion, as well as the decision of the Foreign Affairs Council, are literally war communiqués of the European Union and its governments against the peoples. Your aim is to strengthen the link with NATO, the European Union's autonomous interventions by setting up a regular Euro-army and to strengthen military forces to conduct aggressive wars in competition for the interests of monopolies. The immediate increase in armaments at NATO levels says it all: it is pure hypocrisy that willing alliances against the jihadists that NATO, the United States of America and the European Union have raised, or the so-called fight against slave traders in the countries where the European Union and its allies have set on fire. We condemn this policy, which is fully co-signed by the Greek Government and calls for a new NATO base in the Aegean for Euro-Nato needs. Only the peoples with their struggle can thwart these nightmarish imperialist plans so as not to pay too much for them with their blood.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE).
text: – Madam Vice-President, High Representative Mogherini, colleagues and fellow rapporteurs Danjean, Kukan, Tarand and Gomes, I thank you for the input you have done over the past months to which I have contributed myself as one of the shadow rapporteurs.  I believe that today's emancipation of the Common European Security and Defence Policy theme is the right time given the numerous global, security and political challenges of crises that are not only worldwide but especially the immediate neighbourhood of the European Union where the entire credibility of our political project is being questioned unless we are effective towards crises in our eastern neighbourhood and that of the Mediterranean. Therefore, I welcome this naval mission, which was established at Council level yesterday. I believe that we must prevent the issue of illegal migration in the strongest possible terms and as close as possible to the source of that problem - it is the southern coast of the Mediterranean, and I would also like to hear from our High Representative what are the further reflections within the Council at the initiative of the Ukrainian Foreign Minister who very clearly and explicitly sought the possible establishment of a European security and defence policy mission in Ukraine - we cannot ignore this issue given the circumstances in which we are today and the possible correlation with the OSCE mission. I welcome all that we have said in these reports on more efficient financing of European security and defence policy and the development of our industrial and technological base.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it is very important that the High Representative has really strong support from this Parliament before the summit. The spirit of readiness for more solidarity and more decisive action is very important. I want to stress the other side. We are now facing, from the east – from Russia – and from the south – from ISIS – forces which are using not only military, but also so-called soft policies. We know that they are addressing young people and minorities in countries. They are preparing them for provocations and participation. We need Europe to have a stronger soft policy and a stronger information policy. In this situation we have to have our messages. We have to have our value-based understanding and our readiness to protect democracy and human rights. This has to be visible and understandable, not only among ourselves but also, more and more, outside. I very much hope that we will also have a common information policy in this context.

name: David Campbell Bannerman (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I would like firstly to thank my colleague, Geoffrey van Orden, who has important defence meetings today, for his tireless work opposing an EU single army. Regrettably, the reports on integrating defence policy and defence industries seek again to invent EU defence roles that are not wanted and not desirable. Yesterday’s Council agreed ambitious operations in the Mediterranean. Of course, it is right to make every effort to save lives, but the question is what are the consequences of such well-intentioned but flawed measures. Certainly they will not end mass migration. For that you may need an Australian approach: they turn boats around after giving them food, water and ensuring they will not sink. They went from 800 boats and 50 000 migrants a year to zero now. But in the light of what was agreed there are two major questions: firstly, why was the major NATO Joint Force headquarters at Naples – already very well equipped for operations in the Mediterranean – not involved? Why must the EU always duplicate and undermine NATO? Secondly, what is the cost of this duplication and who will pay?

name: Florian Philippot (NI).
text: Madam President, the report on European security and defence policy is crying out for uniformity in the foreign policy positions of European countries. No effective common foreign policy has been put in place. European countries each have their own history with a large H, their geography, and therefore a different perception of interests and understanding of the world. Therefore, such a foreign policy needs an external unifier, as General de Gaulle had prophesied, which explains NATO's quote in this report. The irresponsible and go-to-war positions of this Parliament show us how a European army would lead us to disaster. Who would control such an army and to defend what interests? Can we reasonably think of sending our French soldiers to be killed in a war if my people are opposed to it? You can die for your homeland, but you can't die for the Brussels Commission. Is it reasonable to imagine that a nuclear power like my country, France, is delegating this responsibility to irresponsible technocrats? To delegate the spirit of defence is to kill the raison d'être of the nations and, for that, France will never accept it. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Arnaud Danjean
text: rapporteur, question "blue card." Madam President, Mr Philippot, grandiloquence is one thing, precision is another. I would just like to ask you, since we are discussing a specific report today, what chapter of this report do you refer to when you talk about the 'European army' because, of the 56 articles in this report, that expression is not mentioned anywhere?

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: "blue card" answer. When we talk about common defence and if we listen carefully to each other's speeches, up to extremely concrete and precise proposals from the European army that have recently come from the European institutions, you know very well that this project is in the pipeline. Fortunately, it was rejected at the beginning of European integration, with the EDC in 1954, and I fear that it will come back today, much to the great misfortune of the European peoples.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: –  Madam President, it was five years ago that Robert Gates observed that demilitarisation of Europe, where large sections of the general public and political elites are unfavourable to military force, has changed from a blessing in the 20th century to an impediment to providing reliable security in the 21st century. We have entered a completely new, volatile international situation, and it is a matter of utmost urgency to adequately address the newest security challenges which will, in all likelihood, become more powerful and threatening. I am very much encouraged by your address, Ms Mogherini, and also the message from yesterday’s Foreign Affairs Council. I feel that we have a strong common ground on mutual understanding and complementarity. We face the situation as it is and it gives hope to all of us.  Our message to the European Council should be, first of all, to take practical steps – no more declarations. Instead of abstaining from further cutting of defence expenditure, we must have a clear decision to increase. The European Council should encourage – to put it mildly – recalcitrant Member States to put more resources into defence. I am encouraged that the Foreign Affairs Council has reached a conclusion that a sufficient level of expenditure is needed.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Madam President, in the amendments that I tabled to the different reports, I underlined my belief that we need more transparency in the common European security and defence policy. This also means more responsibility by the Member States, which have to respect their financial engagements which are needed to fulfil EU ambitions and objectives. In order to implement European actions in terms of security and defence, we need more coherence and complementarity between EU operations and financial resources, as well as more efficiency and new ideas for initiatives that can generate the support of Member States. Personally, I believe that today we need more awareness by the Member States that we need a true common European policy. Today we can no longer be undecided and hesitant. We have to be prepared to act against those who attack the European democratic model. We need to be coherent and fair with our international and transatlantic partners. We need the EU to respect its civil engagements. We need a common security and defence policy, and for that we need a common financing system supported by all Member States.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, in considering this report on the common security and defence policy, I was disappointed. I come to the conclusion that it was written by people with no military background, and probably without a specific objective. There is enormous confusion on a number of issues, basic concepts and objects, resulting in the loss of our strategic aspirations. I mention, for example, the confusion between military and non-military missions and military assistance and direct action operations.  The questions are many and essential. Do the existing treaties allow the implementation of what the report says? Can Member States implement the commitments proposed, bearing in mind that not all European Union states and NATO members are? It is wrong to think that the economic means of diplomacy are capable in themselves of achieving an outcome. There is no adequate infrastructure for the collection and sharing of equipment, as there is panspermia of materials, interoperability problems but, above all, different specific needs, priorities and objectives. Strategic redefinition, EU solidarity, land-based planning and joint action are needed, concepts that are currently non-existent when we consider the case of Cyprus where part of it is still illegally occupied by Turkey.

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today's debate certifies to us how much the common foreign and security policy is one of the pillars of the European Union and that in these times of crisis, with the war in Ukraine, the conflicts in Syria and Iraq, the advent of Isis and the crisis in Libya, Europe's responsibility and therefore our responsibility as Members of the European Parliament is stronger than ever.  We know very well, however, that Parliament cannot do it alone. The Council must also address this emergency with the greatest possible determination. In December 2013, the Council recognised the need to strengthen defence capacity and strengthen industry. Unfortunately, however, not much has been done in practice, the European Union's missions seem to be a formal fact, sometimes an ideal fact. That has to change.  We need more funding: without money it is difficult to be effective. We must coordinate with the other international institutions – the UN, NATO, the African Union, the OSCE – if we are to have a chance of success.  We all know that the security of the whole of Europe is at risk. War is on our borders and therefore it is not possible for only a few countries to participate in the military operations conducted by the European Union. We as Members of the European Parliament are debating today, and then we will, I hope, approve the excellent report presented by Mr Danjean and others, which contains some of these concerns. We expect, Vice-President Mogherini, that the Council will finally take concrete measures in such a way as to make this common foreign and security policy a reality and not just words in the wind. Knowing her, I know that she will reverse this, she has already done so in recent days, she will do so in the next few days, I know its concreteness and we really hope to be concrete. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Are you seriously suggesting, sir, that the security of continental Europe is at stake if it is left in the hands of NATO, as opposed to this move for a common security and defence policy?

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE)
text: answer to a "blue card" question. I am saying that there is a need, as I have said very precisely, to coordinate the world institutions more closely in order to deal with the issue of security.  But let us be clear: we need more concreteness in Europe, because in this period, in recent years, we have really not seen concreteness. I have seen it in recent days, in the action of Vice-President Mogherini in set up a mission in a few days and in any case in responding to a huge problem that we have, which mainly affects some Mediterranean countries. Maybe it's not about your country, it's about us.  I therefore believe that coordination between Europe and the other institutions is essential.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, common security and defence policy plays an important role in realising EU international security goals. To date, we have not realised its full potential. The EU has never before faced such a convergence of security crises on its doorstep. Therefore, the CSDP needs to be improved to enable Europeans to shoulder their international security responsibilities more effectively. Although defence policy remains a matter of national sovereignty, we can make European defence more efficient through European solidarity. The future of European defence is to have the real capability to prevent and respond to crises as part of a comprehensive and bold EU strategy: a strategy that comprises diplomatic, development, humanitarian and defence expertise; a strategy that applies to all phases of the conflict cycle – preventing, managing and stabilising; and a strategy that is done in tandem with other partners, having a complementary and mutually reinforcing role. They should not be in competition with each other. Let us work together for a safer Europe.

name: Sophie Montel (NI).
text: Madam President, this report is moved by the weak mutualisation and solidarity of the countries of the European Union in defence. But the modest nature of military operations under the common security and defence policy is only a reflection of the deep differences of interest that exist between the various Member States. The idea of a federalised European army is therefore a dream that only Europeanist minds can believe to be prescient. The divisions over the war in Iraq or even the intervention in Libya bear witness to this. Moreover, this mutualisation is motivated by cuts in national defence budgets. One wonders if Brussels does not impose austerity to promote the European army and thus satisfy the attitude of the belligerent Mr Juncker, whose ideas have not thawed since the end of the Cold War. The only interests that a European army would serve are those of external federalism, denounced in its time by General de Gaulle, I mean the United States and its armed arm, NATO.  It is also outrageous that this report proposes to finance military interventions on the European Union budget, when this is clearly prohibited by Article 41, paragraph 2, of the Treaty on the European Union.  This report is therefore the work of Europeanists for whom there can be no salvation outside the Union. In the face of these glories, it is urgent that France's defence budget share be reduced to 2% of GDP and that bilateral, targeted and temporary cooperation should be promoted.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – Twenty years ago, I was at the debate on the common security and defence policy in the Convention on the Future of Europe. Unfortunately, the direction and dynamics of the debate at the time following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon were not followed by an appropriate dynamic of implementation, but in between the security situation in our neighbourhood changed significantly. It turns out that we had a lot of wrong strategic assumptions and estimates about it, and that we were not strong enough in preventive activities. They met the concept of soft and hard power. We already have a conflict on European soil in Ukraine. If we do not act rightly and in time, we will get the next one in the Western Balkans. It is not just the European Union-friendly forces that are at work there.  I would like to thank the Vice-President/High Representative and the rapporteurs for such a rich basis for today's debate. The President has agreed to raise a question by raising a blue card in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear Mr. Peterle, you only mentioned in one sentence what I intended to say later if I get catch the eye, but it is never safe, and that is why I want to ask you if you really agree with me that we should also coordinate this security and defence policy in some way with the countries of the Western Balkans or if nothing else at least seriously consider everything that goes on in the unstable Balkans in the form of the security policy of the European Union.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. – I would like to reply to Mr Jakovčič that I agree, of course, that this must be done in a close link, in the institutional framework available, that we develop in the common interest that, of course, must include a credible European perspective for all the countries of this area, and in this context, particular attention must be paid to security and defence policy.

name: Victor Boștinaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, when we are discussing these reports today, we find that everything we knew and believed about the European Union's security and defence strategy is deeply affected by major security crises and not only, in the immediate eastern neighbourhood of the European Union, as well as in the southern neighbourhood of our Union. If this is the context, we must recognise that, until recently, our Union has responded weakly, vaguely, hesitantly and, in any case, not to the expectations of our citizens. In order to support effective european Union action in the field of the common security and defence policy, we need new civilian and military capabilities, as well as coherent investments in research and development, as well as to increase, I repeat, the increased role of medium and small states in defining this policy. I conclude with a remark - not rhetorical - we must answer honestly the question: how common is our security and defence policy and how much security and defence does it produce for the Union?

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI).
text: Madam President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, this report by Arnaud Danjean actually encourages the stripping of our sovereignty in favour of a European army chimera. Whether or not the term is used, that is the goal. European security must, on the contrary, be based on the willingness of states to develop their own army. France, the United Kingdom and Italy, too, are still making a special effort. They must maintain this effort, increase it even in the case of France, which sees its army destabilized year after year. When Germany announces that it wants to make a particular defence effort, I can only rejoice because, indeed, it is not acceptable for Europeans to let their guard down in the face of Asia and the Islamic world, which is increasingly militarized quantitatively and qualitatively. But European defence must not consist in building a new wall to the east of the Union against Russia, it must not have as its objective the establishment of a transatlantic army in place of the European armies. Any other logic will make the European Union not a promise of peace but a promise of war. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
text: blue card question. – You spoke of the responsibility of the states and the desire to defend their own territory. Have you not noticed that this is precisely what has led to the great waste and weakness that the European Union has caused in the area of security, and to the fact that we have a great deal of waste, particularly in the arms purchases, in the garrisons we use and so on. Would it not be a common policy that would bring more added value?

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: "blue card" answer to Liisa Jaakonsaari. Madam, there are currently 500 million Europeans whose overall defence budget represents only one third of the defence effort, while the United States, a sovereign nation, alone contributes 50%.  What I am simply saying is that it is the nations that can effectively organise the overall defence of Europe through enhanced cooperation and cooperation with variable geometry. Today, in any case, the logic of European defence is in full failure and the report of Mr Arnaud Danjean, despite his good will and his strategic knowledge, will only amplify this defeat.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for your A secure Europe is a demand today rather than a reality. In the first place, this demand is due to the fact that for years Europe has been safe: it has developed economically well, it has had no immediate risks. Secondly, it is also a time of crisis that has triggered austerity, most often these savings are made primarily in defence, but also in culture, for example. Today we know that looking for security savings in defence is a mistake.  I am not convinced by such very simple demands to increase defence spending to two per cent of GDP. That's not enough. It is important what this funding will be spent on and what the cooperation between the European defence industry and defence will look like, but it is also important how this expenditure will be built in individual European countries. Thank you very much, Mr Arnaud Danjean, because his report, in my opinion, is extremely specific, extremely accurate, very cost-effective in terms of words, but very precise in terms of diagnosis. I am also pleased that one of my demands is in this report, this request, which concerns taking into account the importance of the Galileo and Copernicus satellite systems. For me, it is important today to move on from these reports to action.

name: Jens Geier (S&D).
text: Madam President, Vice-President Mogherini, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am speaking here today as a member of the Committee on Budgets. I, too, would like to see more European cooperation in foreign and security policy. However, I fear that the Member States will continue to be prepared to do so only in exceptional cases. However, I also fear that the Member States will be happy to respond to the financing offer made by the Kukan and Tarand report in Articles 26 and 27. The EU budget is chronically underfunded. Every year, the Committee on Budgets of this House fights largely unantogether to finance the European Parliament's civil priorities. The European Union's payment crisis has, over the past two years, made the European Union's humanitarian aid almost incapacitated. And in this situation, do we want to issue a blank cheque to the Council in order to finance the common security and defence policy? I believe that the EU budget is not there for this, the resources are not enough for this, and that is simply not acceptable to the German Social Democrats.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: – Madam President, if we are to achieve a true common security and defence policy within the European Union, we need at least two things. We need a vision and we need a new strong common security strategy to guide and deliver upon that vision. In my view, Russia once again constitutes a primary security and defence challenge for Europe. It is a challenge to the fundamental value of Europe whole and free, where the sovereignty of every country is respected and where every country can freely choose its partners and pursue membership of the EU and NATO without a veto or even violent attacks from Russia. I therefore ask you, Madam Vice-President, how is the work on the unified EU-Russia strategy progressing? When will you be able to present it to Parliament? How and to what extent can we push for even harder, enhanced NATO-EU cooperation within the strategy? NATO remains the backbone of European defence and security, but Europe can also take a more active and dominant role.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: Madam President, Madam High Representative, I would like to first of all welcome the work of our rapporteur, Arnaud Danjean. Yes, his report is moving in the right direction: we need to develop a common security and defence policy given the context we are experiencing. Yes, we need a clear line, a clear strategy, as the report says, to strengthen Europe's defence. Two out of three Europeans are in favour of developing a genuine common security and defence policy.  Unfortunately, we see that the missions of the PSDC are now tragically weak. Let us take the example of the new EUMAM RCA mission, which is too weak: only 60 people, 20 of whom are proposed by France. This mission is not about training but about advice. Madam High Representative, we are counting on you. You have created a movement that we have all welcomed over the past few months. The European summit in June is important and we are counting on your pugnacity to enable the Heads of State to move in line with the proposal that you are making and that we are making in this Parliament with the Arnaud Danjean report.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, we are discussing the common security and defence policy this afternoon in a report to which I have tabled a number of amendments. And I would like to focus this debate on the real humanitarian crisis we are experiencing in the Mediterranean, where thousands of people are dying daily in search of a better future in Europe.  I certainly support your initiative to combat the illegal trafficking of people, but we cannot forget that what makes these people entrust their lives, and often those of their children, to real traffickers, is nothing but the flight from war, despair and hunger. And, therefore, security policy needs to incorporate a clear vision, solidarity and fraternity with Africa and the southern Mediterranean in order to give these countries a stable future.  I would also like to support the system of quotas for asylum seekers which the Commission has proposed and deeply regret the insolidary position of the Government of Spain, which is questioning the small number of people we have to welcome.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: – ... Thank you, Mr President, not armed conflicts of crisis and stability. The widespread violations of human rights also occur near the borders of the European Union give rise to many concerns. Then there is the terrorist threat and therefore easily deduced that the security of the European Union as a whole. At risk it is not European, it still fails to act as a decisive decisive decisive decisive player. The new challenges facing Europe highlight an absolute need for Member States to work together within the framework of truly coordinated joint action within the framework of the common security and defence policy. I therefore hope that the Defence Council in June will be able to make real progress in this direction, improving the European Union's capacity for defence and its ability to contribute to the management of crises, further factors of concern arising from the lack of coordination of the Member States' defence budgets and the fragmentation of the market. Defence, which leads to a growing dependence of the European industry in this sector on extra exports. The Council should commit itself to a more integrated market which would make it possible to limit the duplication of defence research programmes and activities and to increase European competitiveness in this area.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: In the catch-the-eye procedure that follows, I shall, for reasons of time, allow only one speaker from each group to speak. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – Today, instability in our neighbourhood is growing.  It is caused by countries that threaten the financial stability of the Euroregion and, consequently, the European Union. It is caused by terrorists, to which Europe has become an increasingly real and potential target for their attacks. It is caused by a new Russian imperialism that, in mockery of international law, anecdotes part of a neighbouring country. We are also causing it because we are not responding properly and in the right time to crisis hotspots in the neighbourhood, not in the east or in the Balkans. For example, we have not been a date for Macedonia to start negotiations to join the European Union for 10 years. And we left it alone, it became vulnerable, and some of the actors who had been clutching their claws for it a hundred years ago, they reactivated. So we bear the blame as if we have learned nothing from history. Dear Sirs, that the Balkans will not be a barrel of mesw at night again, it deserves all our active engagement. Dear High Representative for the Common Security and Defence Policy, the move is on your side.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the world's balance is changing very rapidly. The geopolitical changes in Africa, the instability in the Middle East and the Ukrainian crisis require the Union to take urgent, concrete and firm action on the common security policy and defence. Because we are lagging behind, we have to tell the truth, and strategically aiming for prevention could have an effective impact where hotspots are now more than inflamed. Without a long-term strategy, European security policy will be as weak as our future international credibility, and I would like to thank the High Representative for the firmness with which he has carried out the need for a mission in the Mediterranean in recent days.  But a European security policy must have a sharing in deeds and not just in words, an approach that is not hostage to vetoes and arms of iron or to a false indifference that is strategic and that not even hundreds of deaths affect. Unfortunately, what is happening on the issue of quotas on the immigration agenda is self-commenting.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the situation set out in these reports corresponds to reality and is impossible to dispute. Indeed, Europe has failed in realising its desire and ambition to be an indispensable stakeholder in addressing the world's security crises. The conflict in Ukraine is besoling the devastating fact that European foreign policy has made no progress at all in the past 25 years. In this case, member states treated the Russian invader as well as the aggressor to Croatia in the early 1990s – unconsced, selfish and above all indecisive. It is clear that large states defend their interests when it comes to relations with former colonies or trading partners. I could also say that this is understandable and natural, but let's not pretend to be something we are not and spend huge taxpayers' money on programs that, while the character of this community is as it is, will always offer only partial solutions.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Europe does not belong to federalists or Eurosceptics. It belongs to Europeans, and they need peace and security. We must act accordingly and reflect real needs. Indeed, the European Union needs to take practical and effective steps towards a well-functioning common space of security and defence. We need to be able to react properly and in a timely way to tackle emerging risks and especially to prevent them from happening. There is no risk that the EU, by strengthening its common security and defence policy, will become a hard power and a risk to its neighbours. The European Union is a democratic structure and is run by the rule of law. I believe our discussion today will help us to go in this direction, and indeed to build this common space of security and defence on our continent.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). – I find it scandalous that the report we are discussing today on European defence and security policy mentions, among the challenges facing the Union, the terrorist threat in the Horn of Africa and forgets the occupation by foreign troops of part of the territory of the Union, namely Northern Cyprus. It also forgets the Turkish threat against Greece for war if it exercises its sovereign right, under international law, to extend territorial waters to 12 miles. In such circumstances, the so-called "common defense" is a bad joke. What is even worse is that the excessive defence spending of Greece and Cyprus to deal with the Turkish threat, on the one hand, is becoming an over-gain of the defence industry of other European states and, on the other hand, it is being charged against the budget deficit and public debt. I call on you to stop this hypocrisy and show real solidarity with the Member States of the Union threatened by Turkish aggression.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – Despite the important decisions taken in recent years, it is clear that Member States still lack greater concentration on this issue. Let us be honest – almost all Member States are currently looking at each other and expecting who will take care of their safety. Or think only about the security of your country. We cannot wait, we must already know today what concrete measures we will take together in the event of any internal and external challenges. Proper coordination, clear planning, a stronger focus on crisis prevention and preparedness, adequate funding for the implementation of security and defence policy are what we lack. There is no doubt that increased funds also require greater transparency, and I fully support the need for an evaluation of the effectiveness of 17 European missions abroad. But not only funding is a problem. Eloquent fact: not all Member States are involved in the Union's military operations. It is time to finish making sound declarations and to start working mainly on European security and defence.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear Mrs Mogherini, the last time I spoke to you, President Schulz gave me a 7-day suspension because I told the truth: I said that you did not count an emeritus '..." – I do not say the dirty word or I will take 7 more. So I find myself here to tell you that, since you come from the Communist Party – you were a member of the Communist Party as a child, were you? – then perhaps you have in mind what Mao Tse-tung said, namely that if there is so much confusion under the sky, the situation is perfect. Does it mean that the confusion in Europe, which does not have a fair policy, where there is nothing definitive and there is no security for us Europeans, is its communist strategy taken by Mao Tse-tung? I think that you Communists like poverty, insecurity and disaster so much that you want to reproduce it again in this Europe. So I say to you – and I am no longer saying the dirty word because I gave it to Schulz – it is not that you do not count an emeritus c..., you do not count a blissful bitch.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Thank you. Thank you also for the fact that you no longer use swear words. (End of catch-the-eye process)

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative. – Madam President, as I spent a lot of time at the opening of our debate, I will now just take the opportunity to comment on some of the very relevant issues that were raised and make more general remarks. Firstly, on defence spending, I think those who raised this matter are quite right. There is not only the target, for those Member States which belong to NATO, of 2% of GDP, there is also the fact that 12 Member States have already increased – or are currently planning to increase – defence spending. However, there is a need to focus not only on how much has been spent. I think many of you were right to raise this. The other real point is how we spend, if we manage to spend together in a coordinated way, and how we manage to spend the money we invest in defence better. This means looking at the output of our investments in defence. This is obviously very much a national debate, but there are components of this debate which are European – especially when we look at incentives on defence spending. There is work on the way, especially in view of the June Council.  Many of you raised the issue of EU-NATO cooperation, and some of you raised the need to strengthen the relations or the coordination. Let me say that this is already being done in a very fruitful way. I see no risk, at this historical time, that increasing our own defence and security policy can in any way be to the detriment of NATO. On the contrary, we have a complementarity on which we can work even more, especially when we tackle the hybrid threats. Strategic communication was mentioned. There are a variety of tools in respect of which putting together different elements of our work can be extremely helpful for us both, keeping in mind the fact that we are completely different in nature – as I said several times – and that we obviously have different decision-making and agendas on many issues. But still, strong cooperation is not only a need for the future – it is also already a reality. I do not see the danger of duplication that someone mentioned. I see rather the need to fill the gaps we have in common. This is a problem the European Union has, but also one that NATO has. One timely question was raised by Mr Plenković about the possible CSDP operation in Ukraine. Let me say that we discussed this at length inside the European Union with the Member States and obviously with the Ukrainian authorities. We already have a civilian mission in Ukraine, which is assisting with the reform of the security sector. We are ready to increase that kind of support which is, as I said, civilian work and a non-executive mission on security sector reform. We will also continue to channel our support for the full implementation of the Minsk Agreement through the OSCE. We commonly believe that this is the path we have to follow in full support of the efforts that, especially in the Normandy format, are continuing to be made. Let me close with some general remarks. Many of you in this room – and I mention them in good faith and with no purely domestic audience purposes – referred to the need to move on, to go beyond mere declarations and take concrete steps. Some, quite rightly, made reference to the fact that not all the instruments in the Lisbon Treaty are being used, and that the security situation calls for this. I think I was the first, on 6 October 2014, in my hearing in front of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, to mention this. To me, one of the challenges of my mandate in these five years is to make full use of the instruments of the Lisbon Treaty. It requires hard work to create the political conditions for doing this. Let me also say that when we in this room – or outside of this room – translate this, it rightly highlights that there are still gaps and still limits in our action. I am the first to recognise this. When we move this to the point of saying that Europe does not have a policy, that Europe is divided, that Europe is not acting, that Europe is not Europe – as someone said in this room – I understand that this is a narrative we are used to. But sometimes this does not reflect reality. I said in my opening remarks that today we are talking about CSDP, as yesterday the 28 – united in less than a month – took the decision to establish an operation. The two things, the narrative and the reality of these days, do not match. This does not mean that we have solved all the limits that we still have in our CSDP – not at all – but to me the most concrete way of having a real CSDP, a real common security and defence policy, is by specifically using the instruments, by specifically building the political conditions for making decisions in the Council, and by having the operations and the missions we need, when we need them and in the way we need them. This is work that we have to do together, because Europe is not an abstract entity existing somewhere. Europe is what we make of it, all of us – the Member States, the European Parliament. Each of you has a political family, a political party, a Member State of nationality, and we have a common responsibility to build the political conditions for making full use of all the instruments we have, and to recognise – when we are taking steps that are going in that positive direction – to say that this is a step, take responsibility and move forward with the difficult work of realising what the European dream, but also need, is about.  This means a lot of consistency. I will not go back over many of the details that I discussed in my opening remarks, especially about the last decisions we have taken, except for one point. Pablo Iglesias mentioned the need for all our missions and operations to fulfil the requirements of international law. For me, that is the basic starting point and is natural. For me, the reference to international law obviously means full respect for, and working fully in, the framework of the United Nations. That is why we are developing such strong cooperation with the UN and with the UN system, and, particularly in this case, when we talk about the situation in the Mediterranean, the work with the UNHCR. This is the basis for our work, because these were the principles and the values on which Europe was based. These are the principles and values that have to be at the basis of the European Union missions and operations around the world.

name: Arnaud Danjean
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Madam High Representative, let me tell you that the words you have just said on the concrete aspect of what should inspire us are perfectly in line with the philosophy of the report that I have presented and which my colleagues, I thank them for, have been willing to enrich with their contributions. I believe that the debate has shown this, on the whole, well today, through the positive reception that has been given to it.  The question we need to answer today is how can we do better together in relation to security challenges that are unprecedented in scale and complexity?  Let me tell you that those of us who have intervened in a very ideological way, with postures sometimes totally devoid of reality in relation to what is in this text, are mistaken. To those who fear or to those who hope for a European army, for example - it has been discussed today - I say that they are wrong about the debate. That is not the purpose of this report and this discussion, or even the Council which will take place in June. The goal is to find out how at twenty-eight we can collectively face challenges. Because these challenges, no Member State alone can face them. It's as simple as that. The answers are, indeed, first in the treaty.  I appreciate the fact that you are using your institutional and political influence to push this philosophy, which is a pragmatic philosophy of flexibility. That is what we need today. We won't be able to do everything at twenty-eight. Perhaps we do not have to do everything at twenty-eight in terms of security and defence because the reality in Europe is heterogeneous. But we must, politically, make sure that those who want to do more and go further in terms of the integration of defence policy can do so. I think that the tracks you are proposing and the ones we are proposing are completely compatible, complementary, and are moving in the same direction. I hope that they will be heard by the Member States.

name: Indrek Tarand
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, in the beginning I was speaking in the capacity of rapporteur, but now I would like to draw attention to some of the thoughts of my Group, the Green Group. We have some problems. Firstly, reducing Horizon 2020 money does not seem such a good plan to us. Secondly, we do not think it is a good idea to use the EU budget to compensate European defence companies who cannot export their production on account of sanctions and embargos against third countries. Finally, there is the idea of value-added tax reductions or exemptions for defence capability cooperation. So you can see that we will have a very interesting vote tomorrow, and therefore I urge everyone in this Chamber to look at the big picture, forget about dogmas and vested interests, and if possible, colleagues, please share the big picture proposed by a modest MEP who comes from a very small country whose airspace is from time to time policed by the Italian air force, and share the picture or vision that an EU common defence is a must and not a nuisance, and it will bring us closer together than we can ever imagine.

name: Ana Gomes
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Ms Mogherini, for her substantive comments on our reports, and mine in particular on the Defence Markets Directive implementation. I would simply like to urge a strategic direction – in the College of the Commission as well – in implementing these Directives, in order to avoid totally contradictory decisions, such as Commissioner Vestager’s recent one. On the implementation of these directives, which enable a country like mine, Portugal, to go on with the dismantling of crucial Portuguese shipyards that have been producing for our navy, and then rubber-stamping that in a very distorted interpretation of the Directive. They also allow, or give the ‘Amen’ of the Commission to the selling of critical defence technology companies or even critical infrastructure, such as the Port of Piraeus, to companies controlled by other foreign powers, namely China. We in this Parliament definitely support your endeavours to push the Member States to deliver on the common financing of CSDP missions, namely military missions, because this is not just about facilitating fairer burden-sharing, it is about the only way to encourage the generational forces. Equally important is overcoming the bureaucratic and political barriers which prevent cooperation between Member States and the Union, and even among EU specialised agencies, to ensure a more synergetic use, by civilian and military CSDP operations, of the existing capacities. Do you know, High Representative, that the European Maritime Safety Agency, which is based in Lisbon, is actually providing very crucial information for the Atalanta mission? It could also do this for the Mediterranean mission. Yet they do not have a mandate for that. Is this not stupid? Should we not actually acknowledge and actually make full potential of that contribution? Ultimately, I just want to make your point. Indeed, we need more defence, more European defence, because facing the challenges we have no single country... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 21 May. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. – We support the European Union's Common Defence and Security Policy but believe that this policy should be strengthened and transformed into a more effective security and defence policy that should not be limited to small-scale missions and financing of peacekeeping operations. Indeed, the moderate nature of CFSP interventions is not a substantial contribution to peacekeeping and enforcement. The EU must be able and effective to intervene at all levels of crisis management and not be limited to intervening only after any crisis. The CFSP is indeed part of the wider foreign policy and dimension of the CFSP, where this key arm needs to evolve into a real and effective Common Foreign Security and Defence Policy for the EU. We believe that it is time for the EU to focus on trying to achieve the CFSP objective because the European Union is not understood, however much it expresses other common policies, when it lags behind in the most important area being the Common Security and Defence Policy. The European Union, through a strong CFSP, has an obligation to safeguard and guarantee the EU's borders as well as the airspace and EEZs of its member countries.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – We are seeing more and more situations resulting in a deterioration in the level of security both within and in the immediate vicinity of the Union. The political and economic instability of the countries in eastern and southern Europe, as well as the increase in the terrorist threat within the Community, are causing concern among its people. In this situation, it is justified to increase efforts to strengthen the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP).  In recent years, the level of funding for CSDP missions has decreased, there are delays in the execution of contracts, as well as difficulties in recruiting new ones and maintaining experienced, skilled staff. It is therefore necessary to create an appropriate strategic framework that takes into account effective cooperation between Member States and allows for the planning of coordinated, long-term actions and a rapid response to potential threats.  Consideration should also be given to the functioning of defence companies: appropriate legal and financial systems will make it possible to improve their competitiveness and the smooth implementation of projects. Increasing the transparency of procurement will allow for their democratic control and increase the credibility of the authorities. In accordance with Article 21 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, european citizens must be provided with peace and security. Mutual trust and harmonisation of activities, a sustainable resource management system, security of supply are essential elements of a smooth and coherent defence market. Solidarity and joint initiatives are the EU's greatest strength.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, the current degree of uncertainty at borders and in the EU's immediate neighbourhood has been unprecedented since the late 1990s. With the large number of persistent and emerging security challenges, it is clear that no Member State can cope alone, which requires strengthening the CSDP. The Union and the Member States must urgently adapt to new challenges through the effective use of existing CSDP instruments and through security and defence cooperation with other international institutions, in particular the UN, TOR and the OSCE. Of course, we cannot ignore the fact that the financial crisis has had a serious impact on national defence budgets, but Member States need to take more responsibility for collective security and work to strengthen the European defence industry and the European defence and industrial base. More resources need to be invested in defence and we need to focus on those areas of crisis management where the EU can really add value. Member States need to express greater readiness in relation to EU military operations. Make an appropriate contribution from the resources and capabilities they have to improve cooperation and coordination, especially in the areas of counter-terrorism, organised crime, cyber defence and migration.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE)
