text: in writing. – In critical times such as the ones we face today, the EU and its Member States must act together in order to counter all security threats. We must respond with one voice and robustly to conflicts in our neighbourhood. I strongly believe that the economic crisis cannot be an obstacle and lead us to abandon our defence policy efforts. I urge Member States to meet NATO spending targets: 2% of their GDP for defence. The intensity of the current military crisis has only proven that EU and NATO are in mutual need. The competition between EU and NATO should be replaced by cooperation! We have postponed our common security defence plan for more than 50 years after the failure of the European Defence Community. It is now time to step forward, and to use all the legislative instruments laid down in the Lisbon Treaty, such as the solidarity clause and the mutual defence clause. The clear sign of support is that 75% of our citizens want EU integration in defence! What other better incentive are we waiting for? The EU belongs to its citizens, so let us be responsible and ensure them peace and security!

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – In order to create and apply a common pro-active strategy regarding security and defence in Europe, it is of utmost importance for there to be enhanced cooperation and coordination among EU Member States and between Member States and partner countries with regard with security and defence matters, on counter-terrorism and on combating organised crime. Having in view the current international context, characterized by international groups and interreligious conflicts, especially in the Middle East area, and terrorist actions carried out including inside European states’ territory and apparently motivated by religious reasons, we urgently need to constructively cooperate between the Member States and also with external partners against any target implied in terrorist actions. A greater coordination on analysing and disseminating EU intelligence and information will improve our capacity to prevent and react to crises with more efficient results.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – The EU armed forces, despite their joint participation in different contingents, are organised on a strictly national basis. If countries worked more closely together at European level in the area of the common security and defence policy, they would save between EUR 26 billion and EUR 130 billion per year. The higher costs stem from the lack of a transnationally integrated defence procurement market, to which the common market does not apply. The existence of 28 fragmented national markets, each regulated separately, hinders competition and results are a missed opportunity for administrative economies of scale for industry and production. There is a need to improve transparency and openness in the defence market and to improve synergies between civil and military research and development. Savings need to be sought here, which could be a source for a better common security and defence policy.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. - Russian aggression in eastern Ukraine and conflicts in Syria and Iraq, combined with the emergence of the terrorist organisation ISIS, the Crisis in Libya and the threat of terrorism, pose a direct threat to the security of the European Union.  In particular, the fight against terrorism and organised crime, cyber defence and migration need to be increased. The European Union must encourage Member States to build on NATO's objective of allocating at least 2% of GDP to defence spending. The downward trend in defence budgets in the EU Member States must break down as it no longer reflects the real security policy situation. The EU must also strengthen both civilian missions and be prepared for military missions, including the use of EU combat teams, which has not been done so far.  I support further steps to speed up the financing of civilian missions and to simplify implementation procedures so that the EU can be more flexible in intervening in crises in a timely manner. And, of course, cooperation between NATO and the EU must finally be normalised.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – A number of foreign policy topics were on the agenda of this plenary session, but I would nevertheless place particular emphasis on the security and defence policy of the European Union, as the occupation of Ukraine has not yet ceased, and there are still ongoing conflicts in Syria and Iraq that are a direct threat to the security of the Union. We must be ready to adequately respond to modern security challenges by establishing a coordinated common security policy involving all EU members, regardless of size and economic strength. United in diversity has been the motto of the Union since 2000, and regardless of our differences, I am convinced that there are far more similarities that connect the PEOPLES of the EU that are the key to cooperation and the establishment of a common position when it comes to the Union. The security of our citizens and the safe environment is a priority for the Union, although it is very difficult to delineate external and internal security in a turbulent environment, so we must be consistent in coordinateing our strategies both inside and outside the EU using existing instruments to respond more effectively to humanitarian demands, as the fight against terrorism and organised crime has no borders.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. – I am very concerned about the security situation in the EU and its eastern and southern neighbourhood. These territories are becoming less and less stable as a result of the large number of migrants and the emerging security problems. The conflict in eastern Ukraine, the conflicts in Syria and Iraq, together with the rise of the Islamic State, the Libyan crisis and the terrorist threat in Africa undoubtedly directly threaten the security of the EU's borders and thus of european citizens themselves. The EU and its Member States need to take responsibility for their own security and defence. I would like to draw attention to the need to strengthen the common security and defence policy and to streamline and intensify capacity development. I call on High Representative Federica Mogherini to take a leading role in the effort to move forward with the CSDP. In this sense, I would very much appreciate the greater effort to establish an effective link between the EU institutions and agencies in the field of internal security, such as Frontex, Europol, ENISA.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The common security and defence policy has been in place for 16 years. Common – unfortunately mainly in declarations. This was not dangerous in a stable Europe and in a stable European environment. Unfortunately, in recent years, this environment has changed very dynamically. Moreover, it changes to the disadvantage. The deepening crisis in the south and east poses a growing threat to the European Union. The problem is that the EU's response to these threats is too weak and, in principle, is delayed, as we see today when every day a wave of irregular migrants tries to reach Europe. The individual countries that make up the European Union are not able to deal with these threats on their own. I am strongly in favour of increasing the role and financial resources for the common security and defence policy. There needs to be fewer declarations and more cooperation, more real military and civilian capabilities at the disposal of the European Union.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the situation in Hungary (2015/2700(RSP)). I would like to welcome the Prime Minister of Hungary, Mr Viktor Orban. Welcome, Prime Minister. Ladies and gentlemen! I will tell you briefly how I want to organise the procedure for the sitting. I shall first give the floor to the Council and the Commission on the statement by the Council and the Commission on the situation in Hungary, in accordance with the usual rules. I shall then give the floor in a first round to the chairmen or speakers of the political groups who have been reported and to a representative of the non-attached Members. I will then give Mr Orban the opportunity to speak in the context of this debate. After that, ladies and gentlemen, let us continue in the usual debate. I have agreed with Mr Orban that if he wishes to speak again at the end of this debate – this can be made dependent on the course of the debate – he should signal this to me. Then I will give him the floor again, but then again to the group chairmen on what Mr Orban said, if he so wishes for this second intervention. Otherwise, the rules remain as usual, including the catch-the-eye procedure at the end of the normal debate.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me start my intervention today by recalling the basics. The European Union is not only an economic and political union, providing its citizens with an opportunity of freedom of movement and a single market. It is also the Union of shared fundamental values. These fundamental values are set out in the Treaties and reflected in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. These rights, freedoms and principles are also enshrined in the European Convention on Human Rights to which all EU Member States are party. In this respect, all the institutions have their role, as defined in the Treaties. Parliament has an important and valued role, not least to call the attention of the Commission and the Council to specific situations. Being the forum of European pluralistic democracy, Parliament has always been particularly attached to the preservation of democratic values. The Council has always valued your opinions. As you know, the Council has not discussed the situation in Hungary. Nor has it agreed any position on the issue. However, I would like to recall that the Presidency, and the Council as a whole, attaches great importance to ensuring that EU fundamental values are fully respected throughout the Union in all policies. Promoting tolerance and diversity is the most effective response to the evolving human rights challenges or threats to fundamental freedoms. At the same time, let me express our gratitude to Parliament for giving the Hungarian authorities, as the party directly concerned, an opportunity to take part in the debate. The Presidency is also grateful to the Hungarian authorities for being with us today. I am not in a position to say more at this stage. The Council will follow this debate closely and pay due attention to the views that will be expressed.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank, through you, the European Parliament for putting this topic on the agenda, as two recent developments in Hungary have given rise to important concerns. Let me start with the debate launched by Prime Minister Orbán on the reintroduction of the death penalty.  President Juncker and I have already made clear statements on this, and these represent the official position of the Commission. Article 2 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights prohibits, explicitly and clearly, any person from being condemned to death or executed. In addition, the European Court of Human Rights has ruled that the death penalty is a violation of the European Convention on Human Rights. The abolition of the death penalty is a condition which States are required to meet in order to become members of the Council of Europe or of the European Union. This is part of our common values.  As far as the Commission is concerned, there is no doubt that the reintroduction of capital punishment would be contrary to the EU’s fundamental values. A reintroduction of the death penalty by a Member State would, therefore, lead to the application of Article 7 of the Treaty of the European Union.  The mechanisms of Article 7 relate to the values referred to in Article 2, including human dignity and respect for human rights. As you know, the Treaties do not foresee suspending or withdrawing the membership of a Member State of the European Union. However, Article 7 provides for a far-reaching sanction mechanism specifically designed to ensure respect for the fundamental values of Article 2.  More specifically on the situation in Hungary, let me make the following comments. President Juncker stated on 30 April that Prime Minister Orbán should immediately clarify that it is not his intention to reintroduce the death penalty. If that were his intention, and I quote, ‘it would be a fight’. The Commission has in the meantime understood that the Hungarian Government does not have concrete plans to take any steps to introduce the death penalty, and that Prime Minister Orbán has assured you, President Schulz, that the Hungarian Government will respect and honour all European Treaties and legislation. I refer to the press release you gave President Schulz on 30 April. However, if the Hungarian Government were to take steps to reintroduce the death penalty, let me underline that the Commission is ready to use immediately all the means at its disposal to ensure that Hungary, as well as any other Member State, complies with its obligations under Union law and respects the values of the Union enshrined in Article 2. We will not hesitate for one second in such a case.  On the public consultation on immigration announced by the Hungarian Government – the second subject – let me make the following comments. In general, the Commission considers that public consultation can be an important tool of governments and other public authorities to develop policies that can count on support of the population. However, and I repeat what I already stated earlier, a public consultation based on bias, on leading and even misleading questions, on prejudice about immigrants, can hardly be considered a fair and objective basis for designing sound policies. Framing immigration in the context of terrorism, depicting migrants as a threat to jobs and the livelihood of people, is malicious and simply wrong. It will only feed misconceptions and prejudice.  We cannot, and should not, close our eyes to the sometimes serious challenges posed by migration in our societies. But in doing so, we should never lose sight of our fundamental values and of the need to preserve a pluralistic and diverse society based on mutual respect and equal treatment of every single individual.  The European Union and its Member States are developing common answers to the current challenges, as Europe is based on mutual respect, solidarity and sincere cooperation. We need political leaders who are willing to explain EU policy to the citizens in an open, fair and balanced manner, and who will stand firm for joint and common European values. This is the only way we can make progress together in Europe. The Commission will continue to monitor the situation closely, and I thank the European Parliament explicitly for its continued support in these important matters. (Applause)

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr Vice-President, Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, I would like to say thank you that Viktor Orban is here. When we discuss Hungary, the Prime Minister comes – that shows his willingness to exchange ideas, to be present, and also to respect the European Parliament. Thank you for that. And I would like to begin by saying once again that six months ago, the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, we asked that we talk about the scandalous electoral events in Romania, where Ponta ensured that hundreds of thousands of people were unable to vote in the presidential election. The left-wing side of this House has said that we do not need to talk about the issue, that it is not important for Europe. I would like to say that, for the fifth time, in the presence of Viktor Orban, we are now discussing Hungary issues. And this clearly shows for me that the PPE-DE is ready to discuss, but the left is blind to its failures on the issues that we unfortunately have in Europe. (Applause) When we talk about Hungary today, I think of something quite different from the issues that we are obviously discussing, namely.B that Hungary, with an economic growth rate of 2.8%, is a growth engine in Europe, that Hungary, with 6.8% unemployment, is much better off than many left-wing states in this European Union. And It strikes me that Viktor Orban has been confirmed in office by his constituents since 2010 with more than 50% each. Fidesz recently won 51% of the European elections. Obviously, it does not suit many here on the left to look at the political situation in this country, which is expressing strong support for Viktor Orban. This for the analysis of the situation in Hungary. And now to the problems, to the questions. We are discussing the issue of the death penalty today. For us as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, it is part of the civilisational success of our continent, alongside democracy, the rule of law, the right to strike and many other points, that we have banned the death penalty and banned it from this continent. That is why a debate on the death penalty is harmful to us as the European Union. We reject it, we do not want it to be reintroduced. And I would like to thank Viktor Orban for clarifying that he is not taking any initiatives in this direction. We would seriously damage Europe if we were to have this debate. The second thing we are discussing is how we deal with citizen participation. First of all, it is positive to see that Hungary is questioning its citizens; it is now evidently being consulted for the third time. But I too would like to take up the point raised by Frans Timmermans. If it is said in the wording, Prime Minister, 'the one in Brussels and we in Budapest', then that is a mood that is not good, which is not supported by the PPE-DE either. In other words, there is a lot of explosives in the wording, which many in my group do not like either. However, I would like to say again to the left side of the House: we can argue about the wording, but we have to talk about the things that Viktor Orban is addressing and which he is going to address today. Z.B. the fact that the repatriation of rejected asylum seekers in this European Union is not working, that two thirds of all applicants in Europe have been rejected and that they must be repatriated from this European Union in order for law to be implemented: this is an issue that Viktor Orban rightly raises. And he is also right to say that it cannot be the case that, as in my own region in Bavaria, one of the highest numbers of refugees from acceding countries to the European Union in the Balkans is now coming, with which we are currently negotiating accession. It cannot be right that asylum seekers come to Europe from countries with which we are in accession talks. These questions, dear party friends, ladies and gentlemen, must also be addressed. And then we should listen to the substance, not the wording, but the substance, Viktor Orban.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the national consultation on immigration and terrorism (as if the two phenomena were linked), the invocation of the death penalty as a deterrent, provocations on the merits of supposed illiberal democracy are some of the points that Timmermans rightly mentioned. I will stop there because that is only part of what President Orbán said recently.  Our debate, of course, does not stem from prevention of President Orbán, from dislike, from the fact that President Orbán belongs to a political family other than the one to which I belong, from a biased calculation or from a claim to give lessons. The point is that President Orbán has exceeded the bounds of decency with these statements, and the seriousness of his statements cannot be underestimated.  I say to Mr Weber that we do not exorcise the problems by passing the responsibility on to others, who have a different political shack. I repeat: I do not discuss these things because Orbán belongs to the people's family, of which I have the greatest respect and also great cooperation. I discuss these matters because they are inslaiving the plenum of values and ideals on which the European Union is founded, and we will not compromise and monitor that. In Hungary, the real stakes, as it seems to us, are not the attack on democracy in the classic forms we know but the emptying of democracy through its trivialisation. An empty democracy in which everything is said and then refuted, in which words, even the most important ones, such as democracy and freedom, are abused and turned into empty and meaningless slogans, a sort of confusing state in which democracy becomes a low-level spectacle, a game in the mud that legitimizes the return of the most extreme forces – and this should worry all of us! Like the fascists, the Nazis.  What worries me most is not only the seriousness of the statements, but the gloomy climate that these statements create, and it is at this time the news of the death threats made to a homosexual activist in Budapest to whom I and our solidarity go.  But that also reveals something else. I believe that your provocations are also weapons of mass distraction, that is to say, you want to divert the attention of hungarian citizens from the real problems that Hungary is experiencing, which are very serious and very profound economic and social problems. I will conclude: I have a great deal of sympathy and affection for the Hungarian people; As an Italian, I remember the years when a Prime Minister undermined the credibility and prestige of our country, and I do not think you should do the same, Mr Orbán. Hungary is a great country and deserves more, it cannot turn into a stage where everything is allowed, in which even the values of our living together become games to risk a few votes. And if he has no respect for the values of the European Union, he has respect for the dignity of his people.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Mr Leader of the Parliamentary Group! I respect your work, you are the leader of the European People's Party, the largest parliamentary group, which is why I would like to ask you what you think of the sentence: "I think that Europe does not exist now, there is a botched institutional system called the European Union, which has long been little like the one that the founding fathers created, and there is no longer a community of values." No, this was not said by a politician of one of the extreme political forces, but by the President of the Hungarian Parliament, one of the leaders of fidesz, about this institutional system the other day. Let me ask you, Mr. Weber, what do you think? One of the leaders of a botched institutional system?

name: Manfred Weber (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I do not understand the background to the question, because there are many such voices throughout Europe, unfortunately, in many areas, including in the Socialist Group, including in other political families that exist in Europe. What we are discussing today is the question of how we deal with Hungary. Hungary, I have to tell you, is a country that is economically one of the model countries, and we are dealing with a country where the citizens are obviously satisfied with their government, otherwise they would not have received so much support in democratic elections. These are the facts.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Blue card question. "Mr President, I did not really want to ask you a question, but if you have addressed me, I would be very happy to ask Mr Pittella, if only in the spirit of balance: Mr Pittella! You are so delicate out there... (The President interrupts the Member) I'm going to keep going. It's a bit of a complicated debate, but it's such an interesting and colourful story. Mr Pittella, how do you feel about Mr Timmermans, who specifically threatened us because he said that Article 2 would be used against us. Mr. Pittella, aren't you a believer in talking openly and publicly about topics? Mr. Pittella, do you have a list of taboo topics? Share these with me, because then I don't know what kind of parliament I'm in. Can't you talk about the death penalty? Is this a taboo subject? Can't we talk about the fact that there are migration issues and that needs to be resolved? What can we talk about then? Where's that list? I'd like to know.

name: Gianni Pittella (S&D)
text: answer to a "blue card" question. Mr Gáll-Pelcz, what I think of Timmermans I say to you straight away: Timmermans is a person who enjoys my full esteem, friendship and high regard. I believe that he has an esteem that goes far beyond myself and also this Hemicycle.  We are not trivialising the debate here. It is clear that we can discuss immigration – we always do, we too, there are different thoughts. The problem here is to question the fundamental principles of the European Union: the abolition, the non-application of the death penalty is a fundamental principle of the European Union.  Now, if a head of government, who is not just any ordinary citizen who stands in the middle of the street and speaks at the bar, says that he wants to abolish the death penalty in a country that belongs to the European Union, that must make us worry. We are not exploiting anything. If a head of government in a country of 28 members of the European Union refers to a so-called illiberal democracy, should we not worry? This is not said by a person sitting in the bar but by a head of government from one of the 28 countries that belong to the European Union.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: One thing we have to say here now is that when the Vice-President of the European Commission says that he wants to make use of Article 2 for the Commission in the event of a breach of the Treaty, that is not a threat, but a simple statement of a situation. In this respect, I absolutely cannot accept this expression, Mrs Géll-Pelcz.

name: Timothy Kirkhope
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, as members of the European Union we have signed up to a core set of democratic principles and rights. The Members of this House are entitled to all kinds of varied and many opinions, political and ideological beliefs. This House is a platform for examination, for debate and – we hope sometimes – for solutions. But when did this Parliament become judge, jury and executioner for those who held a point of view different to their own? You can dress this debate up as being about protecting fundamental rights; you can claim it is about helping internal monitoring of the application of the Treaties, but the request for this debate is what it is: the Left of this Parliament is taking another swipe at the centre Right because some Member States dare to talk about issues which concern their own electorate. Member States have a right to debate issues, even issues not included on the list of pre-approved topics of certain people in this room, Mr Pittella. And why does this Parliament always have to present its arguments as a standoff between the European Parliament and one of its Member States?  This tarnishes the reputation of the Member States and of this Parliament. Here in the European Union we are meant to be each other’s partners, not each other’s keepers. The people of Hungary and the people of Europe do not want to see important issues related to fundamental rights and the rule of law reduced simply to another opportunity for political point-scoring in this Chamber. Conversations are taking place between the Hungarian Government and the Commission, as is proper. A debate has been held in our Justice and Home Affairs Committee, and much discussion takes place – again quite rightly – in this forum. But I asked myself, in this context, why are we here today? Why are we holding this debate? This is a debate, Mr President, which does no-one any favours.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Blue card question. " I would like to ask you a very short question. Would you, Mr Kirkhope, like the Prime Minister of your country to say that he wants to build an illiberal democracy in your country? Would you agree with your Prime Minister?

name: Timothy Kirkhope (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – At the end of the day, Sir, that is a matter for me and that is a matter for the electorate of my country, in the same way as it is a matter for the electorate in Hungary, and they have spoken clearly enough about whether they approve of the leader they have.

name: Sophia in ’t Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I think that, in itself, the presence of Prime Minister Orbán in Parliament is very welcome. But I hope I will not disappoint him by not spending too much speaking time on him because, like in the Carly Simon song, this debate is not about him. The Council’s non-statement for me signals the moral bankruptcy of the Council and the fact that you are completely detached from the Treaties. (Applause) Yes, colleagues, we can have a debate about the death penalty and it can be very short. I reject it completely, my Group rejects it completely. It has no place in Europe, it has no place in Egypt, it has no place anywhere in the world – end of debate.  But the death penalty issue is just a distraction from a much more serious issue and that is the immigration questionnaire. That, Commissioner, is official government policy, it is not just somebody’s opinion. So what will the Commission actually do? Has the Commission undertaken a legal analysis of its compatibility with the Charter of Fundamental Rights, and has it checked how it sits with the agreed asylum and immigration policies of the European Union? The Commission has a duty to act. I much agree with your very critical blog, but I expect more of the European Commission.  Now, as for the EPP, having listened to Mr Weber, to me it is crystal clear. EPP: you may choose critical words but you are squarely behind Prime Minister Orbán and his policies. That is your right but at least the people know where the EPP stands now. There is no more doubt and, to be clear, ALDE rejects the policies of Mr Orbán and his government. Now the situation in Hungary only underscores the urgent need for a mechanism to monitor the state of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in all Member States because – and there I agree with you, Mr Weber – we need a mechanism to fill the gap between weak legal tools on the one hand, and the nuclear option of Article 7 on the other hand, and that is why my Group, the ALDE Group, has proposed a democratic governance pact, and I know that in other groups people are also considering mechanisms for the enforcement of fundamental rights, because we urgently need that.  I know, Commissioner Timmermans, that you say that fundamental rights, the rule of law cannot be measured or quantified, but I think they can. I think this Parliament should, as a joint exercise, develop proposals for such a mechanism and I hope that I will find the Commission and the Commissioner on my side, to jointly defend the values that you and I hold dear, Commissioner. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I was very interested by your blanket rejection of the death penalty within the EU – it is just totally rejected. Does that mean that you do not believe in a full democracy? What if a parliament voted, reflecting the will of the people, to restore the death penalty in a completely fair and democratic election – would you still say that it should not be allowed within the EU?

name: Sophia in 't Veld (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – It is very clear. If any country in the European Union votes to restore the death penalty, well they have the right to vote that way, but they cannot be a Member of the European Union at the same time, that is very clear for me. (Applause)

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, once again we are debating the situation in Hungary. We hear the same cries of gold to the right of the Chamber. No doubt Mr Orbon will tell us again that others in the European Union are violating human rights, regardless of the political colour of their government. He'll be right. Governments across the European Union are playing with populism. This is not a right-left debate but Hungary is a kind of condensed, a bad collection of what not to do. Since our last debate last October, Amnesty International has pointed out that NGOs have been subjected to unprecedented repression; the Commissioner for Human Rights pointed out that hate speech and acts were increasing against Roma, Jews, LGBT, asylum seekers, the homeless, and that media freedom should be strengthened. There is this famous questionnaire, which links migration to terrorism, and there are statements on the death penalty. These are not just proposals for debate, as we were told in the LIBE committee. On 8 May, Mr Orbon declared that the reintroduction of the death penalty should once again become a national competence and that if the protection of citizens did not work without the death penalty, it should be restored. How far are we going to go without reacting other than by words? Section 7 is a decoy, it is unenforceable, it is not even a deterrent. When are infringement procedures in this area as effective as they are in economic matters? We must act, and not just in Hungary. If not, what is the meaning of Article 2 of our treaties?

name: Rebecca Harms (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Almost everything has been said to the horror that has gone through the whole of the European Union on the occasion of the new news from Hungary. I must say that I could not believe this at first and, when I listened to the debate on the death penalty in Hungary, I wondered whether it would really be possible for a European head of government today – in 2015 – to be prepared to reintroduce the death penalty: that is a question I would like to ask you seriously. Because, as Sophia and others have said, that would be the declared end to membership of the European Union. The second topic concerned this questionnaire on refugee policy. The style of this questionnaire, the language of this questionnaire – this is not a serious contribution to solving this major problem of refugees, which the European Union must tackle together, but is simply a contribution to the incitement of a nation, not to the solution, but to incitement. In Germany, the term "well poisoning" used to be coined for this. With both debates, Mr Orban, you have set yourself apart from the fundamental values and rights of the European Union. That is why we are not just talking about Viktor Orban and Hungary, but we are talking about ourselves. What does this mean when Member States seek distance from basic values? Accession to the European Union simply means an obligation to these fundamental values and to the fundamental rights on which we have agreed. It is simply inconceivable that the European Union project can function without these fundamental rights being fully respected. In my opinion, a policy of interests in which we put the economy ahead and otherwise dominate nationalist currents would very quickly lead to the end of the European Union. I think it is important that the European Union does not pinch itself in this dispute – like the Latvian Presidency – but that the European Union, based on the disputes that Viviane Reding has had with a number of Member States, not just Hungary, on freedom of the press, agrees on the mechanisms we need to ensure that not only our robust interests in terms of budget and stability are asserted. , but how we can enforce in Europe that the values that we have established and which mark the end of barbarism in Europe can be guaranteed to our citizens in the long term. We have seen lately: demonstration rights in Spain – I was thinking of a police state when I read about it. I have read what security laws are being made in France. I was dismayed by this. It is high time that we were able to defend our values and our internal rights. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I would like to ask Mrs Harms – because you have spoken so beautifully about the values of the discussion about expatriates – why do we not hear in this House an equally passionate, emotional discussion about what is happening in Germany. As we know, in recent months we are dealing with a series of arson fires of asylum seekers' homes, we are dealing with a protest of the population of cities, etc. You know exactly what the situation is in Germany and how socially the current movement of expatriates is not accepted. This, too, should be the subject of our discussion, but somehow I do not see here willing to discuss the situation in France or Germany. On the other hand, we are very keen to deal with a country like Hungary.

name: Rebecca Harms (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. If you follow the discussion in Germany, you will see that this is a very important issue, and all these crimes that happen there are prosecuted in accordance with the law. At the same time, Germany is currently advocating an offensive refugee policy and supporting the idea of the quota – too late, I think, but Germany supports this position. Let me say something about this: especially in refugee policy, in the way Europeans deal with it ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, putting the death penalty on the agenda, declaring that liberal states are successful and working better than democracies and would therefore be models to be imitated: these are just the latest statements by President Orbán that leave no room for imagination and are in addition to laws that gag freedom of expression and the press. , which undermine the independence of the judiciary and deprive the Constitutional Court of its role as a guarantee. And as if that were not enough, Orbán has also launched a shocking and tendentious public consultation that feeds prejudices on immigrants.  That's enough. The time has come to demand that respect for the fundamental rights that are in the DNA of the European Union be guaranteed by the Member States not only at the time of accession but also ex post, always. It is unacceptable to ignore this undemocratic drift in the heart of Europe and to wash our consciences, as do ostriches who put their heads in the sand.  Everyone must play their part, starting with the Commission, which must promote an absolutely essential monitoring of respect for fundamental rights, country by country. As rapporteur for the report on fundamental rights in the European Union, I have proposed the establishment of a mechanism to guarantee a higher level of protection in this regard. The Union must develop a proactive action plan defining the actions to be taken to ensure the full realisation of all rights and principles protected by the Charter of Fundamental Rights.  We also need to create a database on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union and in the individual Member States, and finally we need to extend the European Union's justice scoreboard to the assessment of criminal justice systems and respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law. All this is necessary to prevent the risks from being translated into concrete violations, as is probably happening or could soon happen in Hungary.  Today, in fact, we are not discussing statements by a naïve politician that disperse in the wind of propaganda, but about the positions of a European Prime Minister who has never had any qualms about reforming his country's Constitution in order to bend it to his populist and authoritarian design. Europe will open its eyes and take action before it is too late. (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Blue card question. – I have a very short question: what makes a national consultation in which every Hungarian citizen is asked about an important issue that no one here disputes, the refugee question, is shocking?

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: Answer to a blue card question. What is shocking is not public consultation per se, which is certainly an instrument of democracy, what is shocking is the subject of public consultation.  At a time when a Member State, the Prime Minister of a Member State, is activating a public consultation on the reintroduction of the death penalty, we are returning to the law of the cut, we are returning to those primordial laws of the eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth.  That is what is shocking, because in the European Union the rights of democracy and fundamental rights are at the basis of the european Union's permanence and existence.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – When I saw the title 'Situation in Hungary' in the proposal on the agenda, I did not know the reason. As a representative of the Jobbik Movement for Hungary, I do not know of any event that would justify this agenda. I am now convinced that you, the European Parliament, do not respect your own values: freedom of expression. Why shouldn't a social debate be initiated in a country, for example, on the issue of immigration, which we are debating here tomorrow? Why can't we talk about a taboo subject based on the needs of society? You also want to tell me what a government asks you when asked. The special thing is that I myself would not spend 1 billion forints on it, and I would have found a different form of this. But this is not a violation of European values. By the way, I can reassure you that the Orban government is going down the path that Hungary took at the time of the Treaty of Lisbon, which leads to a deeper integration, unspoken, towards the 'United States of Europe'. The FIDESZ, when it enters the People's Party, represents exactly this here in this Parliament. President Barroso commended Viktor Orban for the six-month Hungarian Presidency when he did much to introduce economic governance. When Viktor Orban talks about the situation in Ukraine, autonomy is the most important thing for Hungarians, and the Foreign Minister says in the official forum that the integrity of Ukraine is paramount. Rest assured, despite some domestic political rhetoric, this administration is meeting your expectations.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. Mr Balczó, in your country there is a former member of your party, György Gyula Zagyva (I apologise for the ruling), who physically threatened a young person simply because he is a gay activist. And this activist, since last July, has been living under the threat of death and there are sites that offer 10 000 euros as a bounty on his head. I would like to know, with regard to opinions – because you spoke of opinions – what your opinion is on this, whether you intend to condemn your former colleague and these threats that are being made. While we are, since he will be speaking shortly, I would also like to hear from President Orbán.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Blue card answer. "On Monday, you may have said a sgalent in the debate on the agenda here. He named that the Jobbik Movement for Hungary had threatened homosexual people to death. I looked into that, nothing like that happened. There's no word on that. I do not know what kind of private information you bring here, the Jobbik Movement for Hungary has never made any such threat. At the very least, it was occasionally said that the excessive propagation of this, which is in the public eye, was opposed to it, but never, in any way, against those who were homosexuals.

name: Viktor Orbán
text: Hungary prime minister. - Dear Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I came to you today because today you are talking about my country, Hungary, here in Strasbourg. I am always honoured to have MEPs to hold a debate on the situation in Hungary. And for me, it is a commanding duty to speak Hungary of my country, the People and the Hungarian people. I would like to remind you that the Hungarians voted in favour of membership of the European Union in a referendum, and we have been proud of this decision ever since. Mr President, we should also think – it would be logical – that we are here today because Europe is curious about the successes of Hungarians, curious about what Hungary has achieved and how it has achieved over the last five years. There's something to talk about. In 2010, Hungary was 21st out of 28 Member States in terms of the growth rate of total national product and was 2nd last year. While public debt is rising elsewhere, we have reduced it from 85% to less than 77% in Hungary. And in 2010, unemployment was well above 11%, and now it is below 7%, and within three years I hope to achieve full employment. Ladies and gentlemen, however, you have called this debate day because I understand that you want to talk about political issues under the label 'Hungarian situation', especially the issue of immigration. As far as political issues are concerned, I would like to inform you that Hungary is considered to be the most frequently reviewed Member State by X-rays of the rule of law of the European Union. At the same time, I welcome the fact that you are on the agenda on important issues that really concern the people of Europe: legal order, public security, immigration. These issues are a matter of destiny for our common future. Answering these questions may depend on what Kind of Union we will leave to our children. But these problems are not Hungarian problems, but Europeans. And yet the only reason they come up today in connection with my country is that Hungarians generally like to talk straight about difficult things. That's who we are, we don't like talking or talking. We like to talk straight or not. So we talk directly about the death penalty, about immigration, and we also feel that the discourse that many people have been "p.c." They say it's politically correct, it hasn't brought us Europeans any closer to a solution.  Ladies and gentlemen, we are also talking straight and openly about saying our opinion that we Hungarians want Europe to remain european, and we want to preserve Hungary as a Hungarian country. Both of our goals are legitimate goals, and I believe that both are fully in line with europe's core values and the intentions of the Union's founders. Ladies and gentlemen, I propose that we make a sharp difference between free movement within Europe and the free movement of labour from migration from outside Europe. And within the latter, let us also make the case for refugees different from the case of immigrants who come here only because they want to live in a higher standard of living and prosperity than their home country would offer. Pain, Commissioner Timmermans, the situation in Hungary is that we cannot give jobs to immigrants. We'd better talk about this honestly and straight.  Ladies and gentlemen, we want to tackle the issue of livelihood immigration in our own way in the first place. Hungary and the European Union have good reason to address the issue of subsistence immigration. Ladies and gentlemen, I am convinced that what we now know as a proposal from the European Commission is absurd, in our straight language, close to what we might call madness. I am convinced that it is a dangerous attitude to say that there is no problem here, open the gates wide and come whoever you want. The facts are clear, there is huge migratory pressure on Europe today. Compared to 2010, illegal immigration in Europe has tripled. In Hungary, the number of illegal border crossings has increased 20-20 times in a short period of time.  We openly believe that the current conventions should be revised, revised and the right of EU countries to defend their own borders should be returned to a nation-state competence. We believe this would be a sober, humane and realistic position. I say this with due respect, but I am convinced that the proposal to allow refugees into Europe and distribute them on the basis of some artificially defined quota is crazy. Ladies and gentlemen, I am convinced that the quota will only encourage people smugglers, lure more people to Europe and encourage them to attempt to reach EU territory by dangerous sea crossings. I am therefore convinced that it would be more fortunate if the regulation of immigration was would be delegated to the commission. My position is that I am pleased that the debate has started on this, that instead of a quota, individual Member States should be allowed to decide on this issue themselves. We Hungarians want to decide for ourselves whether or not we want immigrants in Hungary.  We are a Christian, we are a national government, we have mercy in our hearts, and we have always accepted refugees, real refugees, and we will continue to do so in the future. Immigrants, however, are not refugees. They want a better life, and that's why they're coming. We understand that, but we can't accept it. Illegal border crossing is a criminal offence that needs to be combated. Hungary must also protect its legal order and its borders. We do not want Hungary be a destination for illegal immigrants. There are countries that have decided that they want to live with this problem. They decided they wanted immigration policy. We respect that decision. That is why we have launched a consultation on immigration. We see it as fair and fair to ask our citizens about it.  I would like to say to one of the contributors that there is no consultation on the death penalty in Hungary at this moment, there may be some fatal misunderstanding here.  Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to remind you that Hungary has not signed any agreements or agreements with anyone on what cannot be discussed in Hungary or what can be said. We have also not signed an agreement on what we can and cannot consult on. Our Association Treaty with the Union does not contain any sycathing provisions on the fact that certain things should not be discussed or raised in the Member States of the European Union. Therefore, we consider it a violation of the EU Treaty if anyone tries to have a say in what we Hungarians can or cannot comment on.  Ladies and gentlemen, if you look at the number of asylum seekers as a proportion of the national total per capita, Hungary the 2nd most-touched Member State after Germany. If we look at the number of asylum seekers per 1 000 inhabitants, we are also in second place after Sweden. It is here that I draw your attention to the fact that insufficient attention is paid to the Western Balkans region in the European Commission's migration arm. In the first quarter of 2015, 24,000 of the 43,000 asylum applications made in Hungary came from Kosovans. Cooperation with countries along the Balkan migration route and the development of their migration, asylum and border management capacities are therefore essential. And the Crisis in Ukraine, I ask you not to ignore it, because this ordeal is still ahead of us.  Ladies and gentlemen, as far as the death penalty is concerned, I believe that Europe must not bury its head in the sand. In no case would I like us to return to the Middle Ages, and again there are issues that are forbidden to be talked about. In fact, this debate is not about the death penalty, but about the issue of thought, opinion and freedom of expression. I insist on talking about the death penalty. We have a constitutional basis, and the rules can only be changed in line with the European Union. Ladies and gentlemen, the principles, conventions and rules of the European Union are not engraved on stone, not brought by gods and inspired by them. They were made by humans, which is why people can change them at any time. This is freedom and this is democracy. Ladies and gentlemen, everyone's opinion on these subjects is the opinion of one person and no more, whoever he is. Whether you are a philosopher, a European Commissioner, a prime minister or a party chairman. Your opinion is the opinion of a European citizen. It's not holies, it's not dogma, it's not superior truth. Therefore Hungary will continue to stand up for freedom, stand up for the idea of free expression and its European value. Thank you for your attention.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Surely there are no divine commandments in the EU Treaties, Prime Minister. But I know a divine commandment, that is, tint shall not kill. (Applause)

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, some groups have wanted to bring a debate on Hungary to the House. We do not object to discussing anything in this Parliament. What we do oppose is that, for political reasons, a member of the European Union should be stigmatized. Let me tell you, first of all, that for the People's Party the death penalty is a matter that can never be debated again, because it is an issue that is completely clear and determined, such as democracy, fundamental rights or that all Europeans have overcome the worst of our past.  Let me tell you below that we have no doubt that Hungary will comply with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which expressly prohibits the death sentence, and let me also thank Prime Minister Orbán for coming here, that he has given his face, that he has spoken before this Parliament and that he has defended his positions before all of us.  Ladies and gentlemen, immigration is a very serious problem; It is also a problem in which politicians have to be very careful, because we are all against xenophobia and racism, and we are all also against the guilt of Brussels.  Hungary is not the only country where racism and xenophobia are growing: they are growing across Europe; and Hungary is not the only country in which Euroscepticism is growing: it is growing across Europe.  We would be wrong if we considered what a European problem is a Hungarian problem, because political discourses against immigrants and political discourses against Europe are in France and Britain, Germany, Spain, Italy, all over Europe.  It is not a question of discussing Hungary's guilt; it is about discussing our own guilt for not being able to make the European project and European values respected throughout our territory. This Parliament is not designed to judge any Member State and we, if we judge a Member State from this Parliament, can also make mistakes that end up affecting the fundamentals of the European Union.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: – Mr President, you may find this strange, but I must say that I am not happy that the Hungarian Prime Minister is here in Parliament. I am not happy about it, because every time he came here, all five times, it was always about the same shameful politics that this government is following, and the shadow of that policy is unwittingly projected on my country. Even now, the Prime Minister painted an insensitive, inhumane, xenophobic image of Hungary in his speech. And I want to assure Parliament that this is not Hungary, this is not my country.  This government is constantly and consciously constantly opposing the fundamental values of the European Union, the values on which this Union is built. Illiberal democracy, the success of autocratic political systems, the debates around democracy, which the Prime Minister called, I must say that there is, of course, no solidarity in this Hungary, of course there is only the deception of the people, the incition of fear and the arousing of anger. And all because far-right voters are being hunted by the government, that's what the prime minister is after. His original supporters are out, and now he needs the far right. I must say that the European Union cannot finance, support, this type of policy, it must be made clear that it Hungary not sitting on the bench of shame, but the policy of the Hungarian Government.

name: n/a
text: – Mr President, I wanted first to hear Mr Orbán before intervening in this debate. But I have to tell you that what he is coming to do here is simply to continue the provocations that we have heard these last months in Hungary and outside Hungary. An ‘illiberal state’ was the first provocation. The deal that he made in the middle of the crisis in Ukraine, making an energy deal with Mr Putin, was the second provocation. Then the death penalty was the third provocation. You do not have to change your opinion, Mr Orbán: you said on 1 May on public radio in Hungary that in fact what you want is for every Member State to decide for itself on the reintroduction of the death penalty, and that this is not a European issue, and you confirm it now! Well, it is a European issue. It is not an issue for Member States, it is an issue for the whole European Union and the whole of European civilisation. (Applause) And lastly, you confirmed it again here, again a provocation. You say ‘yes, we are only doing a national consultation on this migration project’. A national consultation? Is this a national consultation? You have to literally read the different questions that are put forward. Question number 7: ‘Would you support the Hungarian Government in the introduction of more stringent immigration regulations, in contrast to Brussels’ lenient policy?’ So it is Brussels that is the cause! Or another one, number 3 (and this is incredible!): ‘There are some who think that mismanagement of the immigration question by Brussels may have something to do with increased terrorism.’ So it is Brussels and Europe that is responsible for increased terrorism, and you are confirming it here! Is that a national consultation? I call these rhetorical questions! The answer is already in the question, it is not necessary to answer the question. Finally, think about one thing if you attack migrants. Think a little bit about the many Hungarian refugees who left their country because of the Communists in 1956 and how they were received with open arms by the other peoples of Europe. (Applause)

name: Judith Sargentini (Verts/ALE).
text: – Words can be like petals, but words can also be like bullets and we are all politicians here and what we do is work with words.  Well, Mr Orbán's words are not petals. It's a lot of bullets. It doesn't always have to be petals from me, but you do have responsibility for what you say, and the moment words become bullets, other people will react, perhaps not with words but with deeds. And that is the danger that we create when you start talking about the death penalty or the moment you are having a very coloured consultation of your people. That is also what happens when you explain here what you think of migration and the European Commission's plans. If you say we shouldn't open the floodgates.  That kind of word provokes aggression and is irresponsible for a prime minister of a country. That's the kind of responsibility I expect from you.

name: Georg Mayer (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would say, Mr President, if you want to make a political statement, do so from the plenary, not from above, from your position, and look for speaking time, as we all do. I would like to start by saying one thing: for us, there is no question of banning the death penalty. But what are we actually discussing here today? Internalize that once. We are talking about something that is not taking place that was never planned. That is what we are talking about. In this respect, this is a very hysterical reaction, which can be experienced here, especially from the left side of the Chamber. From the other side, you are really concerned with something quite different. You are concerned that a right-wing government does not suit you and that you do not like it. That is what we are talking about in the background. That is the real scandal, if you ask me. This is not the first time, in the case of Hungary, that these matters have been debated and that we want to interfere in a sovereign state. As a neighbour in Austria and as an Austrian who has had very bad experiences with such interference, I can tell you: leave it! If you want to get involved somewhere, get involved with your comrade Tsipras in Greece. He might need any help. However, I am afraid you are the wrong person to advise him.

name: József Szájer (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I think that in this debate we are in the same place as before: no one listens to anyone. Mr Verhofstadt, you deliberately let go of Viktor Orbán's phrase that, as a Christian, as a Christian-Democrat, you want to take in all persecuted people. Did you deliberately let those words go in the debate next to your ear? Because if he did, he lied, and the 56-year-old abused refugees in this case, using their misery for low and petty political purposes.  Dear Mr Verhofstadt, do you consider yourself a Democrat? You are waving questions about this questionnaire here. Do you think that asking every Hungarian citizen, every hungarian citizen of legal age, a question on an important matter, such as what you have quoted, whether the regulation is stricter in something, how is it undemocratic? These are rhetorical questions, and I know you're letting these go, too, so you don't have to answer them.  But I think that the dialogue between the deaf continues, and I would add that I understand the remorse of a good number of those who have spoken so far on the left, of those who have attacked us, because they come from countries that had great colonial empires and, as a result, have a very different culture of accepting people. Hungary s different. There has been no immigration in Hungary in recent times. As a result, you do not know what our problem is. What is it when refugees, persecuted and persecuted in masses at the border, cannot be distinguished in that they are economic refugees or are fleeing political persecution. Hungary sweden is the 2nd country to accept the most refugee applications in recent times.  In order to bring our experience into European legislation, what is your problem? I see Mrs in 't Veld shaking her head that I said something terrible by saying that your culture is different in terms of immigration. Indeed, you made 20 years ago, 30 years ago, bad decisions that we do not want to make, because we want to have a different culture, different customs, and the Hungarian population must be very careful in preventing xenophobia in Europe. Peaceful coexistence is a fundamental issue for Europe. Consequently, we must create the conditions for this to be possible.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for his work One could almost get the impression that you have made your controversial statements in order to appear again in the European Parliament. Honestly, you need such performances. As soon as you have spoken provocatively, you are weakening what has been said. You are a master of Doublespeak, a master of the approximate. But this House is not a theatre stage, we expect clear statements here. How do you really feel about the EU, of which Hungary is fortunately a member? What are you doing to combat the appallingly high level of corruption in your country? How do you explain why so many Hungarians work in other Member States? And what do you want to contribute to creating a climate of reconciliation in your country? We ask you these questions because we are friends of Hungary and because we so much appreciate the historic contribution of the Hungarian people to our freedom in Europe.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, Mr Orbon, you say that you like frankness, so I will speak frankly.  You are dragging your country into an autocratic drift that is totally incompatible with our European humanist and democratic values. The arithmetic majority is a necessary condition of democracy, but it is not and will never be a sufficient condition. In reality, you practice what is called majority tyranny. You have a majority and you allow yourself the right to do everything, including to bully minorities, to undermine the voices that oppose yours. Your comments on the death penalty, your questionnaire that manipulates and suggests complacent answers that are supposed to give legitimacy to your preconceptions of detestable are all manifestations of methods that are in total contravention of the spirit and letter of our treaties. You insidiously and demagogicly misguide the very concept of an honourable tool of democracy and the rule of law. You criminalize migrants and the homeless, you encourage racism, xenophobia and intolerance. You glorify a mortal identity withdrawal, you advocate authoritarian regimes, you reduce the freedom of the press and the independence of the judiciary. You also practice a dangerous form of bullying. In fact, Mr Orbon, you are slowly burning our values for authoritarian purposes. You are unrestrainedly flouting the most sacred principles of the European Union and the rule of law. You drive a beautiful people backwards from history. Yet Hungarians have already paid dearly for the price of totalitarianism.  So, Mr Timmermans, how many outrages will European humanists still have to endure from a head of government who constantly humiliates our institutions to cynically flatter his vanity and a dubious taste for an increasingly absolute power?

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, let me say two things first. This should not be a debate about left or right: it should be a debate about fundamental rights and values in this European Union. This should not be from whichever party, but from every one of us. As Greens, we even criticise our own governments, so this is also not about left or right. This is about basic values in this common European Union.  I would like to talk about this immigration questionnaire which you, Mr Orbán, have been putting to your citizens and which is really promoting prejudice and anti-European sentiment. Mr Weber and you have talked about the significant economic growth that your country has had, but why then have around 500 000 people left your country over the last couple of years trying to find a job, or even a better life, in other EU Member States? That is double the number of citizens who fled the dictatorship in 1956. Why are you trying to prevent people, students, from leaving your country and telling them they have to pay back the tuition fees if they do not stay in their own country? Should you maybe put a questionnaire to your citizens trying to find out how you can keep people in your country, to work for your own country, instead of leaving it?

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I think that it is always very important to stand up for the common European acquis and to respect the values of our society over many years. At the same time, it is also important that we do not lose the tradition of one of the most fundamental and oldest European values, the free culture of debate. The European Union is also one of the most envied regions in the world because we resolve differences of opinion through a debate based on objective facts, respect for the positions of the parties and the power of persuasion.  This is a huge value and I think it has been perhaps the most important guiding principle for the gradual progress of integration. I'm convinced it stayed that way. That is why I do not want to forget this and turn the discussion of issues of paramount importance that are the conditions of our lives into a simple political give-and-take, in which we put individual governments and countries on a bench of shame.  We must also remember that we always base our debates on facts and the arguments that lead to them, otherwise we can easily lose credibility. And, Mrs Lunacek, 3 million citizens have left Romania, but Romania is not still on the agenda, and we asked for it last year, where citizens are punished for the use of the mother tongue and nationaled instead of defending legal property. And Slovakia is not on the bench of shame, even though people are collectively punished there (Beneš Decree, language law), but there are socialist governments there.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am Hungarian and a European social democrat. That is why I would like to say very strongly that Hungary not the same as the Orban government has shown about it in recent times. It is a shame for the Orban government for everything it paints of us, and I would like to join the colleagues who indicate that Hungary has other faces. So let's clear the air.  It is not the issue of the death penalty that concerns the Hungarian Prime Minister, it is not the problem of immigrants, it is not a national consultation, it is merely a national mind-altering system, a goebbels technology, which is maintained every year out of tens of millions of euros, in which they try to lead the Hungarian people. But not everyone asks for it, Prime Minister, for example, do not speak for me, do not speak for the hundreds of thousands of Young Hungarians who have left the country, and do not speak for those who, for example, sent me their questionnaire and asked me to tear it up here in Parliament, because this is not a real questionnaire, it is a provocation and a change of consciousness.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr How long will the Orbán government continue to send shockwaves across the EU following a succession of undemocratic discriminatory moves and proposals, and for what time in order are we discussing Hungary today? I have to ask you, Mr Orbán, do you take pleasure in challenging the values and values on which this Union has been built? The latest calls to reinstate the death penalty and to send out xenophobic forms to citizens are nothing more than a provocation. Hungarians are EU citizens. I assure you that there are many of us in this House who are doing everything possible to guarantee their fundamental rights, even if you, Mr Orbán, and your government are doing everything possible to undermine these rights. For your own reading, I would like to recommend Sándor Máraj, one of Europe's great 20th century writers, as well as Hungarians. If he had lived today, he would have been brought before your censorship authority. He should serve as a moral example to you, because he speaks of the fundamental value and fundamental rights of every human being. He should serve as a moral example to you and your government.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, in order for your European partners to condone the increasingly spectacular ups and downs of common European democratic values, you have been persuing them for years that Fidesz is the barrier to the advance of the far right in Hungary. But in his race with the far right, he may not have noticed for himself how he had increasingly conjointed himself to those from whom the official version was that he wanted to take away the political space. Your speech today has not dissienated this suspicion either, and I think that, slowly, Mr Weber, you, too, must face up to this fact.  The only thing that adds to the problem is that the strategy has failed. Instead of seducing voters with his increasingly radical voice, he used his own ideas that Jobbik had been voicing for years. And these voters, when it became clear to them that the only consistent element of your governance was perennal, institutional corruption, and now they are migrating there without an internal barrier. You personally paved the way for them to do so. Prime Minister, you would like to see yourself as one of the most prominent Hungarian leaders, but there will only be one historical example: narrow-minded political cynicism.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE).
text: – I am very sorry that you did not allow the use of the Blue Card, because then you could have reacted to all the mistakes, slips and lies that have been made, so I can only say very quickly that there is no consultation on the introduction of the death penalty, Mrs Ferrara, and I hope you are listening: this is a serious mistake. We do take care of the refugees, Mr Verhofstadt, we take them in and we distinguish between refugees and illegal economic migrants, Mr Verhofstadt.  We consider free work and free movement to be a common European achievement, Mrs Lunacek, and if we consider this to be a common European achievement, I do not understand why the Prime Minister is being subjected to people living in free employment and free movement. I do not understand the basis on which you are morally allocating us, Mrs Wikström, on what basis it is possible to morally judge some people in this Chamber. In the meantime, I would just like to say that because the number of illegal border crossings in Hungary has suddenly increased in such a large number, 20 times, it is no wonder that people are concerned about these issues. In this questionnaire, the questions are formulated as they are, as these questions appear to them. In each case, it is added that you 'agree', 'disagree', so you can decide whether to agree or disagree with the issues that you have raised. We think this is an opportunity for a democratic response. Yes, people on the street do not ask questions or express their fears in the style of fair speech adopted in the brussels corridors, but I think it is important that we finally listen to the way these people speak on the streets. I regret, Mr President, that you have not read the letter representing the voices of hundreds of thousands of Hungarian people that you have been asked to do today. (the President interrupts the speech)

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D).
text: – Mr President, unfortunately, Viktor Orbán has not come here to provide clarification, much less to confirm his allegiance to human rights and European values. He came here to evade the issues, intending to confuse genuine threats to fundamental rights in Hungary with the exercise of freedom of expression and democracy. And it is absolutely deplorable that you do so with the complacency of some in this Parliament, including the largest political group, the European People's Party. Viktor Orbán confirmed here the willingness to debate the replacement of the death penalty, confirmed a xenophobic view on immigration and cannot confuse values with taboos. You can hold the debates you want in Hungary, but if you do, you will do so with the political condemnation of this European Parliament and, if you follow that path of violation of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the founding Treaties of the European Union, you will get the answer you deserve from the European institutions.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, the protection of life and the promotion of general human values is a policy of the Hungarian Government, which it has also incorporated into the Hungarian Constitution. The introduction of the death penalty is contrary to my values but also to the values that the official Hungarian Government promotes, so I reviewed Mr Orban's statements and found no statement that was charged to him. From this I can conclude that malicious structures are deliberately created and the reason for this is the weakness of those who cannot defeat Viktor Orban in the elections because the Hungarian people respect him because he protects their interests and does so without reservation. I have not even seen a statement that the door will close for migrants and asylum seekers, but said he would ask citizens what they thought of the European Union's Migration Strategy. I am surprised that the Hungarian Government is being given a model of public debates and consultations with citizens on important issues for Hungary, because such democratic communication could be seen by many other prime ministers who come from the Socialist ranks who do not want to call a referendum or when 1/3 of the voters ask them to do so.

name: Boris Zala (S&D).
text: – I am very surprised in this debate by the position of Mr Weber of the EPP, who tried to justify Mr Orbán's undemocratic practices by the fact that Hungary has economic growth. It is the same as saying that massive human rights violations in China are justifiable because China has high economic growth. I think this is ridiculous. For the entire Government of Mr Orbán, from the point of view of the European Union, we have seen the abuse of the constitutional majority, very little has been said about the use of minorities in neighbouring countries to destabilise situations – I think he was very clearly in agreement here with Russian President Putin, who abused minorities until the military use of minorities against a neighbouring state. It is therefore quite clear that Mr Orbán has undemocratic tendencies from the outset, and if it were not for the european Union's inhibitions, Viktor Orbán now reigns with a despotic... The speaker was interrupted by the President.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – I will not talk about the death penalty, because this is just an excuse for attacks on Hungary, and we have heard it very clearly a few times. President Timmermans quoted Article 2 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, and quoted it quite precisely, because the first paragraph of this article makes it clear that respect for life, for the right to life, should be a principle of the European Union. This right to life is widely denied in most European Union countries.  Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Do you remember that, at the time when the Treaties of Rome were signed, there was not a single democratic state in Europe that would tolerate the killing of the unborn? If you are so passionate about excluding and triggering Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union, then you can first run it against yourself.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, one always answers the most important questions with one's whole life. The phrase is attributed to Sándor Márai, the great Hungarian writer. It was contrary to both communism and Nazism. Cosmopolitan, liberal, humanist. He escaped communist Hungary and was welcomed into the United States. I don't think I could stand Orbán's Hungary. To ask whether there is a connection between immigration, Brussels immigration policies and the rise of terrorism is to question in an obtuse and xenophobic way the great questions of our time. I learned to love Hungary with the eyes of Sándor Márai. I absorbed his love of hungarian language and freedom. Your book Earth, Earth! I was comforted when I was persecuted, to murder myself, by identity fanatics in my land, the Basque Country.
