Seeing the political decline and social manipulation promoted by Hungary's leaders sincerely terrifies me. Mr Weber of the European People's Party should be honest and not use tricks in such a serious situation. Do not devalue the political life of a great European political party, Mr Weber.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, listening to everyone, yes, also Prime Minister Orbán, but if it is to hear expressions and proposals like the ones we have just heard, attention and respect become serious concern: death penalty, connection between xenophobia and terrorism, serious risk to freedom of expression. It is difficult to understand the attitude of the People's Group in this House, which seems to justify or ignore attacks on democracy on the basis of the alleged good running of the Hungarian economy: absolutely unacceptable; as much as the explicitly xenophobic campaigns that certain Candidates of the People's Party carry out in our country within the framework of local elections.  It therefore makes perfect sense for this Parliament to deal with this debate on Hungary. We do this continuously to deal with resolutions on human rights violations anywhere in the world. How can we not do that when we find out we have the problem inside the house? We have not only the right, but the obligation to do so, here and in other countries where basic democratic issues are also at risk; as in my country, Spain, with the so-called "gag law" and with the limitation of the right to decide of its citizens in Catalonia.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Orbán, it seems clear to me with you in government that Hungary is going through a regressive and autocratic phase. We started by suppressing the freedom of the press, by suppressing the activities of non-governmental organisations, by means of discrimination. We have now moved on to announcing the reintroduction of the death penalty. What are we going to do next time? Do we prepare the Holy Inquisition or are we aiming for a witch hunt? Well, in this climate what happens is that a young Italian, my age, named Andrea Giuliano, is threatened with death, even put a bounty of 10 000 dollars by a former MP from Jobbik – they are his far-right friends – and as if that were normal he publishes it on his website. This boy's name is Andrea Giuliano and he lives in a truly paranormal situation in the European Union.  I ask you, since you are here, Orbán, to do something at least to protect the safety of this boy.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: This completes the catch-the-eye process. (End of catch-the-eye process) Mr Orban, would you like to speak again? I offered you that if you wanted to. You're welcome!

name: Viktor Orbán
text: Hungarian Prime Minister. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to say in advance that I thank you for your contributions, we have heard Italian, French, Scandinavian, German here. I would just like to say to you at the outset that I would never dare speak with such a voice about your country, people and nation. (The President interrupts the Prime Minister until interpretation is restored) Mr President, we have heard French, Italian, German, Scandinavian, Baltic. Without mentioning them by name, I would just like to say that I would never dare speak with such a voice about your country, people and nation. I simply cannot account for my own conscience, so allow me to pay tribute to the countries represented here by people who attacked Hungary, Hungary and the Hungarian people.  Allow me not to respond to comments from Hungarian Members of Parliament, because I do not want to turn our country into a pathetic Hungarian sausage or make our country look like this. I understand that Hungarian MEMBERS of Parliament are attacking their country here, and indeed there have been those who have proposed nothing less than to withdraw financial support from Hungary because it does not deserve it. Well, let's get their souls on it.  Ladies and gentlemen, some of you mentioned illiberal democracy, we do not have time to explain this, I would just like to say that, in my view, liberal economic and social organisational principles failed during the 2008 financial crisis, which is why we are in the crisis we are in today. Ladies and gentlemen, I was pleased to hear that many people have read Sándor Márai here, but do you not feel a little perverse that you want to explain to us what, how, in what spiritual way our great national poet wrote?  I welcomed the comment made by my fellow Member Louis Michel, who edd me out of democracy. I would like to inform him that I have run six times as a candidate for Prime Minister, I have lost three times, I have won three times, I probably will, and I do not see this as evidence of undemocraticism or the autocratic system.  Likewise, allow me to respond to the President of the Liberals. Mr President, I think that I understand your situation and your motivations, because in Hungary liberals were once a big party, they played a major role in the fight against communism, yet they almost disappeared from public life. I understand that this angers european liberals, but I ask you not to be angry with the Hungarian electorate, including myself.  Ladies and gentlemen, those who object to our consultation questionnaire must give you one information: the President of the Liberals does not consider it appropriate to ask whether you would support the Hungarian Government to introduce stricter immigration rules in the face of Brussels' permissive policy. Here's the dog buried, that's the point. Until 2012, we did not have such Hungary problem, ladies and gentlemen, Hungary had Hungary national regulation and we were able to detain refugees at their borders and provide them with due process. In 2012, the European Union forced us to change the Hungarian rules. Since then, livelihood immigrants have been pouring in. If you had not forced Hungary to change the rules, we would be fine today. I understand that the European Union wanted to try a new regulation in Hungary. It's been a few years, it hasn't been good. Please allow us to defend Hungary ourselves. Finally, ladies and gentlemen, this will be a long debate, whether it is the death penalty, the issue of refugees or the issue of subsistence immigrants. I am pleased that we have achieved our goal here today: the debate has begun. Even if it is a long road, europe has taken the first important step today.

name: David Borrelli (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, respect for human rights, freedom of information and expression and the independence of the judiciary are the very foundations on which the European Union is based and based. Within respect for human rights, the abolition of the death penalty is a precondition for staying in the European Union. Mr Orbán, you spoke of pragmatism. Well, then as a pragmatin I really cannot understand one thing: what is the point of talking to the citizens of a Member State about the death penalty if it is explicitly prohibited by the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union? Why step back rather than look forward? Pragmatic. It must be clear that there are fundamental values and issues in the European Union on which we cannot joke with the sole aim of gaining electoral support.

name: Rebecca Harms (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In the end, it is the citizens of Hungary who have to decide whether or not they want to follow the ideas that Viktor Orban is currently presenting. I believe – because I have also dealt a little with Hungarian history – that hungarians still know why they have chosen European freedom and against what is now the democratic origin in the debate. For all of us, however, it must be worrying – and I would like to join Mr Weber in this – that something is happening in this catalogue of questions that is really dangerous for Europe. For it is not only in a hurtful and degrading language, but also in a hateful language, that the methods used by national socialists in my country are being used, causing great disaster for the whole continent. We should be able to stand out from this together in the European Union in 2015. This applies to Hungary, but it also applies to many other countries where we have similar problems.

name: Gabriele Zimmer (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to make a clear point in opposing you, Mr Orban. None of us here criticises Hungary as a country. None of us criticises the population of a Member State. What we criticize is your policy, are your statements, is your person, is your appearance, is your game that you are playing here again. I have the impression that you are coming here because you want to use the European Parliament again to send the message home: I, the Prime Minister, I am defending you before these European institutions and in front of these Members who are daring to criticise me. We criticise you, not the citizens of your country. We want the citizens of your country to be able to decide on their membership, their lives and their future in the same way that we have all done and will all do. We want the citizens of Hungary to be able to deal with refugees in the same way that we can do so in solidarity. But we do not want you to present them with questionnaires in which there is pure cynicism from the outset. And what you have been doing here is sheer cynicism. I am sorry, it is sheer cynicism, it has nothing to do with democracy. I would like to say today that we continue to reject these positions. (Applause)

name: Guy Verhofstadt (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I should ask the Commission to scrutinise everything Mr Orbán has said here, because there are some problems with a number of the answers that he has given in this debate. Secondly, to go further, in that idea to have democratic governance back, we are not going to repeat these debates here eternally. It is now time to conclude! That means that the Commission should come forward with an initiative to the Council and the Parliament and say we have to deal with these problems in the following way. We cannot continue such debates anymore. On a second point, you did not respond, unfortunately, Mr Orbán, to the various remarks that were made on the question. For example, you say that it is Mr Timmermans who is responsible for terrorism – it is in your question No. 3 here. You did not respond to that. Well, in the end, what you are saying is an enormous argument, yet there are no liberals in Hungary. How dare you intervene in the debate! There are no liberals. No, we lost them, because you were there and so was Fidesz. What is Fidesz? Do you know what Fidesz is? It is a student organisation of the Liberal Party. That is what it means, Fidesz. The only reason why you changed camp is because you lost the election and wanted to return to power, and so you became a nationalist. That is your responsibility, and I can tell you one thing: even without Liberals in Hungary, we shall fight for liberal... (the President cut off the speaker)

name: Timothy Kirkhope (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I have been in politics for quite a long time, and there are two things that I have always believed in – and still believe in – passionately. One is freedom of expression. The second is freedom for those people who live in countries like Hungary to be able to make their own decisions as to what government they wish to have to govern them. I have heard nothing this evening that has really changed that view. I do not like the rhetoric that we have heard, particularly from the left-wing representatives. I would like to conclude my remarks by alluding to Mr Verhofstadt's remark just a moment ago. He says it is time to conclude the debate on Hungary. I have to say clearly to Mr Verhofstadt that we should never have started this debate in the first place.

name: Gianni Pittella (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Orbán, do not say that we have spoken badly about the Hungarians and Hungary, because that is simply not true. There are recordings of the debate. We don't want to say what a government has to do. We do not want to impose anything on anyone, except respect for the fundamental values on which the European Union is based. We do not suffer from "orbanite", that is, a form of allergy to her, we have nothing personal towards her, absolutely. We want to discuss the political struggle, including immigration, which is a matter of political struggle, not about democracy. What concerns democracy and membership of the European Union is the death penalty, it is the idea of an illiberal democracy. On these points, you are free, let us be clear, to say what you want, but you must also tell your fellow citizens that this opens the door to an outcome that we want to avoid, namely Hungary's exit from the European Union. We want to avoid this; You, on the other hand, if you continue like this, take Hungary out of the European Union.

name: Manfred Weber (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to thank you for the discussion and also for the exchange, and I have to say once again that in many areas the left criticises what is to be criticised – which I too did as a representative of the PPE - but is once again excessive. When Mrs Harms makes comparisons with Nazi methods, if Mr Verhofstadt assumes dull nationalism here, then excessively excessive is being done. And Mrs Zimmer then shoots the bird by saying that we need to end the Orban debate. After all, who asked for the debate? It was her group that asked for this. It shows that everything that is on the table in terms of criticism sits now excessive. Today, we have heard little about the real issues that Viktor Orban raised in the migration debate, that Hungary is a model for the issue of taking in migrants in Europe. Many of the Member States that have spoken here, from the left, could cut off a slice of Hungary. We have not heard anything about it. However, prime minister, Mr Viktor Orban, I have one thing to say very clearly on the question of the principles of the European Union: everything can be talked about in Europe, but freedom of speech always goes hand in hand with responsibility. That always belongs together. And when we speak out in the debate, it must be clear that we are also responsible, including for what has been achieved in civilisation on this continent, namely that the state does not murder and does not kill. Everyone must discuss this principle very responsibly, and we, as European politicians, must defend it.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr. President, I have a few comments to make on what was said, if I may. First of all, of course it is very important and interesting to hear of the economic success of Hungary, and I know Prime Minister Orbán is a formidable campaigner, who has won some of the most astonishing election victories and therefore has a huge democratic mandate. But neither economic success nor democratic mandate can weaken the position of the rule of law in any Member State of the European Union. You cannot use an electoral victory or economic success as a sort of condition to say ‘we do not then have to observe the rule of law in a Member State’. So I am interested in hearing the stories about economic success and electoral success, but it is neither here nor there in this debate, frankly. This debate is about the rule of law.  Secondly, this debate in my perception is not about party politics. I respect everybody who wants to make it a debate about party politics but for the Commission it is not, and I am sure that many in the ALDE Group would be surprised to be categorised as left-wing today, but this is a completely different matter. Thirdly, I am all in favour of freedom of speech, it is one of the fundamental values we cherish. It is one of the values Mr Orbán fought very hard for when he was in opposition against the Communist regime before the end of the European divide, because that is when I got to know him and, indeed, he was a Liberal at the time. But this freedom of speech is also limited by the rule of law. If you say: ‘I want to have a debate on abolishing the death penalty’, of course you can have a debate on that, but the consequence of having a proposal on the abolishment of the death penalty would be a violation of international and European obligations. Now the Prime Minister has said it is incompatible with membership of the European Union. Prime Minister Orbán has been very clear about this. He is never intending to put a proposal forward to do that. Well, my political question is: if you never intend to make a proposal, why then have a debate? What is then the reason for the debate? But that is a different matter, and let me also sometimes pose a rhetorical question like this. And finally, if we have a debate – and I salute Prime Minister Orbán, I respect the fact that he comes here because he knows exactly what is going to happen here; he comes here, he stands for his position, he defends it, and I as a democrat respect that.  But my respect would be bigger if the proposals of the Commission were not put forward as a caricature, as has been done by Prime Minister Orbán today. Where, Prime Minister, in the proposal of the Commission, does the Commission propose to have an open-door policy for migration into the European Union? Where is that, please tell me? Where in the proposals of the Commission, the migration proposals that we have presented, do we propose to have freedom for all economic migrants to come here? Where do we do that?  On the contrary, we want to have a much firmer policy so that people who do not have the right to asylum must return where they came from. That is part and parcel of the Commission’s proposals. And if we have the issue of quotas, it is in very, very limited, very serious cases of a very serious crisis, in a situation where a very, very high number of asylum requests are indeed attributed as they are because they come in this case from Syria or Eritrea, where we know that these people are fleeing war and conflict. But this quota idea is for a very, very limited number of people, and it would help the debate, honestly, if we did not make a caricature of the proposals of the Commission, because it would also help to have the European public better informed of what we intend to do. And indeed, we need to do something to prevent masses of people coming to Europe who do not have the right to asylum. We should help them stay in the countries where they belong. We should help them stay in the region where they belong. And this is all part of the Commission proposal. I make this point so strongly because I do believe that the only way forward in the migration debate is to be honest and clear about each other’s intention and each other’s plans.  So my plea from the bottom of my heart to the Hungarian Government is, and to everybody else, do not make a caricature of the plans of the European Commission, because we are on the same page in terms of fighting illegal migration. But we are also advocating a humane approach in full accordance with values we share. Values, Prime Minister, that you fought for as a young man when your people and country were being oppressed by Communism. Those values are values we share in the European Union, and you participate in the debate because you know full well that we are entitled to address each other about these values. You cannot say ‘nobody from an outside EU Member State can talk about the situation in my country’. It is part and parcel of being members of the European community of values that we do address the internal situation in each other’s countries. We should do it with respect, I fully agree with you, Prime Minister, but you cannot be excluded from debating the situation in a Member State simply because you are not a national of that Member State. That is also being part of the community of values that is the European Union. Let me end on this, talking about the very, very difficult case of refugees. I think of the country I know best, my country of origin the Netherlands: Németh, Szass, Tóth, these are now Dutch names. These are now names of sometimes the most successful people in Dutch society. These are people or children of people who had to flee Communist oppression when the Soviet Union crushed Hungary’s wish for liberty in 1956. And I as a Dutchman am proud of having Németh, Tóth, Szass and all the other Hungarian names as part of the Netherlands, as part of our community of values.  And they could do that because the Dutch people and many other Europeans in 1956 knew that the desperate people fleeing from Hungary needed a place to go, and they opened their hearts, they opened their homes, they opened their societies, and this is an example that we should follow. This is an example that tells us what European values are really, really about. (Applause)

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I do hope that today’s face-to-face exchange of views has assisted in better understanding each other’s position. I have listened carefully to the range of views expressed during the course of this debate. As I said at the outset, the European Union is a union of shared fundamental values, equally binding on all EU institutions and Member States. The abolition of the death penalty is just one example. It is a fundamental condition for EU membership. The EU has gone a very long way to enshrine this principle in the Treaties. We cannot forbid anyone from having a debate, but, at the same time, we hope that the outcome of this debate will reconfirm the commitment to this fundamental principle. Freedom of expression is our common fundamental value but it has its limits. Extremist speech is forbidden. I have not heard in this debate today that anyone in this room disagrees that the right to work, the right to a fair trial, and the right to free and fair elections are not among the European Union’s core values. At the same time, there should be caution when choosing the means for defending our own values. Extreme measures may not produce the expected results. I believe we shall continue our debate until we convince each other, even if it does not happen today. As I have already mentioned, I speak as the Presidency of the Council and therefore in the name of all 28 of its members. It is a difficult task. Since the subject of today’s debate has not been discussed in the Council, my choice of words is very limited. However, I most certainly commit to transmitting your views to the members of the Council.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: That concludes the debate. The vote will take place in June. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. What right does the European Parliament have to question the decisions taken by a democratically elected government of a sovereign country, in this case Hungary? Wasn't Mr. Orban democratically elected by his people? Are the elections in Hungary not in line with the basic principles of democracy that the European Union claims to defend? The European Union was much less demanding in the days of so-called popular democracies!.... We want the European Union to respect an essential principle of democracy: the sovereignty of peoples, which is its fundamental framework.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. – This afternoon, two debates touched on the migration problem: the first tone was thought-in, albeit critical, and demonstrated that we cannot be satisfied with the performance so far. By comparison, the tone of this debate is offensive, with the prime minister of a country and its prime minister in the crosshairs of a country that perceives the real problems and speaks openly about them instead of superficially negotiating them, and invites more than 8 million Hungarian citizens to consult. The reasons for today's debate were very much in demand, and MEPs from the Hungarian opposition parties also chewed the plenary contributions in the mouth. I believe that the EP has gone down a dangerous path with these debates, as it has become a political tool, unfortunately not for the first time. In Hungary, today's plenary session in Strasbourg has become a plaything for unsuccessful opposition parties.  Indeed, the migration threat is enormous. As most of the speakers have pointed out, the immigration statistics in Hungary speak for themselves. So let's not have fake debates, it's not the right way. Hungarian opposition parties should win the favor of their voters at home. Let us acknowledge the seriousness of the situation and do not abandon the Member States with their migration problems. It is time to find a common answer: illegal livelihood immigration is not the solution to Europe's demographic problems, the right answer can only be to further expand family policies.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – In recent years, we have been discussing the situation in Hungary several times. As early as June 2011, we drew attention to the problematic wording of the Hungarian Constitution, which referred to Hungary's responsibility for all Hungarians, the single Hungarian nation, collective rights, self-governments abroad on an ethnic basis, the granting of voting rights to foreign Hungarians. Viktor Orbán's government has changed the Constitution several times, laying down provisions on students, the homeless, restricting freedom of speech, discriminating against churches and, above all, restricting independent justice. Today, we are also discussing again, in the presence of The Prime Minister of Hungary, Viktor Orbán, the situation in Hungary with regard to his statement on the possible reintroducal of the death penalty in the country and the public consultation on immigration. I want to make my position very clear against the introduction of the death penalty in any EU country. Judicial errors in many states may be a warning sign for the reintroduction of the death penalty. I consider the comments made by the Prime Minister of Hungary to be a litmus paper and an inquiry into electoral preferences among my constituents in Hungary. But such a serious subject as the introduction of the death penalty is undoubtedly, it should not be a survey of preferences or a distraction from social and financial problems.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. Some demagóly quote the Bible and European principles and judge on this basis. Jesus, on the other right, teaches, "Do not judge, that you may not be judged." (Mt. 7,1). For the sake of party politics, the militant voices of the left-wing parties have been once again trying to put Hungary on europe's shame bench for years. For example, the current debate has been provoked by false accusations and slanders that the Hungarian government, personally, Prime Minister Viktor Orban is pursuing a racist and xenophobic asylum policy, wants to "close" the border to refugees and lead them to a "labour camp".  It is fair to say that this political witch-hunt, which takes place on the scale of general anti-Hungarianism, could not take place without the complicity of the hungarian national opposition parties. But for former Communists and pseudo-liberals who have lost political and economic power, nothing is expensive in their prey-taking and government-overthrowing endeavors. In the knowledge of their own weakness and incompatitiveness, this is why they call on the "exoneration armies" of their malicious or misguided Western "comrades". It is safe to say that the accusations made in the debate are untrue, targeted and distorted. It is not immigrants that need to be protected from Hungarians, but rather Hungary – and the whole of Europe – from the flood of economic refugees. Hungary not stigma, but on the contrary: it deserves solidarity and support from the Union.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen! I now have a message to make to you. The following candidates have been proposed under Rule 15 of the Rules of Procedure for the post of Vice-President of the European Parliament, which has become vacant following the resignation of Mr Olli Rehn: the EFDD Group proposes Mr Fabio Massimo Castaldo. The ALDE Group proposes Mrs Anneli Jäätteenmäki. The election will take place tomorrow, Wednesday, 20 May, at 12 noon.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Recommendation of the Committee on Justice and Home Affairs at second reading: Preventing the use of financial systems for money laundering or terrorist financing (05933/4/2015 - C8-0109/2015 - 2013/0025(COD) (Rapporteur: Krišjānis Karižš, Judith Sargentini (A8-0153/2015).

name: Krišjānis Kariņš
text: Rapporteur. – We conclude today and tomorrow's vote a procedure that has lasted almost two years. In particular, we have developed the new anti-money laundering legislation. First of all, I would like to thank, of course, Mrs Sargentini, the co-rapporteur from the LIBE Committee, my colleagues as shadow rapporteurs, the European Commission, of course, and also the Italian Presidency, with whom we had the opportunity to conclude a final agreement between Parliament and the Council. Then the question is, what have we done in these two years? Firstly, the European Commission, as we know, came forward with a proposal to improve anti-money laundering legislation so that the law can keep up and even ahead of the criminal world. A number of valuable proposals came from the European Commission, which have been approved, namely that a risk-based approach to catching criminals will now be taken, say, money transfers, where the European Commission will play a very important role and will also help banks to carry out their work, find out what their customers really are or not, and, of course, a so-called blacklist will be created to help law enforcement banks, etc. understand in which cases an in-depth study of potential customers or money transfers should be carried out. But we have also introduced a novelty from Parliament that has finally received support, and that is, as an additional means of creating a European Union-wide register of beneficial owners in the fight against money laundering. What is this register? So far, we have a business register in all Member States indicating the structure of the owners of the company. But we know that there can be individuals and can be firms, companies where the owner can be another firm, etc., and so-called out-of-chains are formed, even within the European Union, and finally no one can understand who then ends up behind which company. Now our proposal, which is supported by the new law, will, along with business registers, create a requirement in all Member States, with all companies, to disclose the true beneficiary, hence to the individual who benefits from it. What does that mean? This means that in this chain of outlining, which makes law enforcement work very difficult, we will make it open that we will finally be able to see who is behind the company and whether or not its money or money transfers are legal. This will even help in terms of tax collection, since such schemes are probably used not only to launder the proceeds of crime, but also simply to avoid tax. So this is an innovation that will make the criminal world react realistically. What will it do? This will make these schemes increasingly difficult, which in turn will mean that the criminal world will have to move further away from the European Union. But in Europe, we have everything our heart might want : we have the power of law, we have secure banks, so the financial system. We also have, of course, all the properties, etc., that anyone might want. This means that, with this change in the law, we will not only make money laundering much more difficult, but we will push the criminal world, squeeze slowly beyond the borders of the European Union, forcing them to operate in jurisdictions where the rule of law is not so important. Thank you everyone for your cooperation! I call for support for this bill in tomorrow's vote.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, thank you to my co-rapporteur, Mr Kariņš, to the shadows who have helped us in this term and in the previous term, to the Chair of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, Roberto Gualtieri, and thanks to the Council, particularly the Italians, and the Commission.  It has been a very long process. We started in the previous term and we managed to conclude last December, and let me remind you that we had a plenary vote before the elections that gave Mr Kariņš and myself a mandate that was very strong: 643 votes in favour of a public register for ultimate beneficiary owners and 30 against. It gave us a mandate that did not allow us to backtrack, and that I really appreciate. We acted on that and my motivation has always been to deal with tax avoidance and tax evasion.  We had Thabo Mbeki visiting this House and he said that the amount of money fleeing out of Africa because multinationals are not paying their taxes in the country where the work is done is immense. We had the scandal with the son of the former President of the Ukraine, who put the money he stole from the Ukrainian people into a shell company in the Netherlands and then we had LuxLeaks. That helped to clarify why we are doing this.  The FATF and the Commission made tax offences a predicate offence, which is good, which helped us work, and then we created this public register on ultimate beneficiary owners. It is Article 30. We agreed to have 28 registers. There are countries that do not have an ultimate beneficiary ownership register at the moment and they are now obliged to have one. In future, these 28 registers will be interconnected, allowing people to search from shell company to shell company, from country to country. Who can look at these registers? Well the authorities, of course, they have full access, the obligatory entities – banks, casinos, etc. – but also anybody who has a legitimate interest, anybody who can show they have an interest in looking at them because of money-laundering, terrorism and issues like corruption, tax crime and fraud. So in the near future journalists and NGOs and every citizen in Europe will be able to look at the register and make sure that we collectively clean up our act, that we do not allow shell companies to steer away funding, to steer away tax money that can be used for education, for health, for everything we need in our society.  I am proud of that, and if Member States want to go further than that, if they want to add more causes, they can, and I think they should. We cleaned up the data protection and may I thank Commissioner Jourová, because as soon as the file moved from DG Markt to DG Justice we got a better hearing on the issue of data protection. So we made sure that the data subject, the person who wants to know something – perhaps they have a feeling that something went wrong with their data – has rights to redress, without tipping off criminals, but they have the right to redress. We respect data retention rules. Data retention is set at five years and I am happy to have that. That is Article 40.  So let us make this an example for other countries in the world. Would it not be fantastic if the USA were to follow us, would it not be marvellous in our fight against tax avoidance and tax evasion? I want everyone to help us reach that.

name: Timothy Kirkhope
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, with anti-money laundering, if you cut off the flow in money, you cut off the long reach of criminal groups and terrorists and help better protect the stability of our economy as a whole and individuals in it. The damage that money laundering can cause should never be underestimated. Where criminal activity in our economic markets is concerned, transparency is a powerful weapon. Therefore, the opportunity presented to myself, my fellow rapporteurs and shadows to right the wrongs of past legislation has been both a challenge and a privilege. Throughout the process, we have looked at international standards, at FATF, and at the need to combat money laundering beyond the borders of the EU and in full cooperation with the rest of the world. The ability to follow money across borders and seize back assets is important, and so is the space in which criminals are able to operate.  I believe that this package will help both to diminish that space for criminals and also to assist us in our ability to follow the money across those borders. For years, both consumers and businesses have run into difficulties with implementing previous legislation on this subject. Our aim has been to create, this time, a sensible, proportionate and effective way forward in the fight against money laundering. I have to say that the second Anti—Money Laundering Directive – with which I and others here were concerned – was interpreted ultimately and implemented in my own country, in the UK, in a way that made life almost intolerable for small investors and those who desired a normal, balanced relationship with their financial institutions.  This kind of undue burden must not be recreated with an even tougher new regime. The need to create fuller transparency, balanced with considering the wider impact upon privacy and the need to provide data protection, has also been a key element of our work. The terms ‘proportionality’ and ‘necessity’ are brought up time and time again in our work here in Parliament, never more relevantly than in our work on this package. Previous directives have had the effect of providing an excuse, sometimes, for institutions, including banks and building societies, to move their decision-making further away from their consumers and to introduce totally proscriptive and impractical ways of assessing customers. Businesses and financial services need to know what they are looking for and how to address the problem. There needs to be an effective reporting and supervisory system, but equally countries need to comply with, and not just sign up to, international principles and methods, as well as to ensure good cooperation with third countries. If businesses and our trading partners around the world are going to continue to invest in Europe, and if the single market is to grow and prosper, it is essential we have the right legislative tools and European cooperation in place in order to prevent and prosecute financial crime. Above all else, I hope we have delivered something which is consistent and workable here. For me the ability to effectively implement the package was at the forefront of my mind when I was dealing with the section that I was responsible for. You can have the best laws in the world, but if they are not well implemented, you gain nothing. I now believe, thanks to this package, we will be gaining a lot. I would like finally to thank all those involved as far as my work is concerned: my co-shadow Mr Simons, the shadow rapporteurs and the other co-rapporteurs. I hope that the vote tomorrow is the start of a new era in the fight against money laundering, using common sense, but also bringing public acceptance at the same time.

name: Peter Simon
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is estimated that approximately USD 1 600 billion of money is laundered every year. This represents almost 3% of annual economic output. In the EU alone, one trillion euros is lost each year through tax fraud and tax avoidance – a sum higher than the EU's seven-year financial framework. We, as the European Union, as the European Parliament, must therefore take the lead in the fight against money laundering as well as in the fight against tax evaders. That is why it was of the utmost importance and urgency to revise the old, third anti-money laundering directive of 2005. We Socialists and Democrats have always supported constructively the Proposals of the European Commission in the fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive and the accompanying regulation on the transmission of information on the payer in the event of money transfers and have worked towards the timely introduction of the new EU anti-money laundering legislation. Both legislative texts take a risk-based approach at European level, introducing increased due diligence for high-risk areas. This risk-based approach is also reflected in the scope of the Directive. In the future, casinos and gambling providers will also be included. In our opinion, however, the key point in the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing is transparency and thus the identification of the beneficial owners and the true beneficiaries behind nested, often opaque corporate structures and letterbox companies. That is why, in our view, it is a great success in the fight against money laundering that the European Parliament, under pressure from us Social Democrats and other central public business registers, has been able to impose detailed information on the beneficial owners of companies, trusts, foundations and holdings. Transparency is the best weapon against criminal activity in secret. However, the introduction of these registers was not self-sufficient, as they go well beyond the Commission's original proposal. The Member States in the Council have also long resisted this. However, the European Parliament was ultimately able to prevail with this central demand. These registers are freely accessible to all obliged entities, such as lawyers, notaries, banks and tax authorities, as well as to anyone who can demonstrate a legitimate interest, such as journalists. So far so good. However, we Socialists and Democrats would have liked an EU-wide link between these national registers not to be put on the back burner and only in four years' time, but to be launched immediately. Transparency and the flow of information must not stop at national borders. In addition, we Social Democrats would also like to see the standard of central registers of beneficial owners, which has now been established, applied to third countries as well. Such a transparency offensive would expose obscure practices, and the fight against money laundering, tax evasion, and tax havens could be conducted even more effectively. At the insistence of the European Parliament, however, the final legislative text provides for a list of EU third countries that have shortcomings in the fight against money laundering compared to the EU. Obliged entities must exercise increased due diligence when dealing with states on this list. Contrary to the Council's ambitions, we, as a Parliament, are involved in the drawing up of this list through delegated acts, which is updated every three months. We would have liked us to move on at some points. However, it should be noted that by establishing a central public register, we have been able to achieve our priority. This, coupled with other achievements, is certainly a success of the directive. But much remains open and therefore work for us over the next five years.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the adoption of the fourth Anti—Money Laundering Directive and the Regulation on the information accompanying transfers of funds, which are strategic texts for the European Union, will represent a significant step towards the improved effectiveness of our efforts to combat the laundering of criminal proceeds and to counter the financing of terrorist activities.  I would like to express my gratitude to Parliament and in particular to the two co—rapporteurs, Mrs Sargentini and Mr Kariņš, as well as the shadow rapporteurs, for the strong support which they gave this file and all their hard work. The consecutive presidencies also put a lot of effort into this, especially the Italian Presidency under which the work and the trilogue negotiations were finalised in December last year. I am convinced that today we have a result which we can be satisfied with. Tomorrow’s vote marks another step closer to stronger rules to combat money laundering and terrorist financing. In light of the recent terrorist attacks in Europe and the adoption of a European security agenda, it is crucial that these rules become operational as soon as possible. We now have the tools at hand to better detect and trace billions of euros which come from criminal proceeds or financial flows which support terrorist groups and activities.  Enhancing beneficial ownership transparency has also been at the heart of the international agenda. I particularly welcome the ambitious approach adopted by both Parliament and the Member States to introduce registers of beneficial ownership for companies and legal arrangements. Work must now begin to ensure that this framework, which focuses on greater effectiveness and improved transparency, is quickly put in place. The Commission will work with Member States to speed up the process of implementation of the new anti-money laundering requirements. I would like to encourage Parliament to give its final assent by its vote, which will mark the adoption of a stronger framework to combat money laundering and to counter terrorism financing.

name: Емил Радев
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Dear Mr President, money laundering costs around 2.7% of global GDP, or around $1.6 trillion a year, according to the UN. In fact, the cost is much higher because organised crime and terrorism, which are funded through money laundering, affect the lives and fates of millions of people around the world. The European Union's fourth anti-money laundering package is therefore extremely important. It will lead to more transparency in an increasingly complex financial system that, without this package, would provide many opportunities for fraud. Agreements reached on a central register of beneficiaries of a company, on the inclusion of tax offences in the scope of the package, on stricter controls on financial transfers, on the obligation of intermediary payment intermediaries to cooperate with competent authorities are important innovations in European legislation. They will make it possible to clarify the ownership of companies and to have more transparency in business relations, which will lead to a strengthening of the functioning of the European Union single market. At the same time, it will facilitate the fight against organised crime and terrorism, and in particular, the follow-up of their funding, which is relevant in the current terrorist threat situation over Europe and has been reaffirmed as a priority in the European Security Agenda presented at the end of April. Ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the fourth anti-money laundering package takes into account current and future threats to European security and provides adequate tools. (The President took away the speaker's word)

name: Ana Gomes
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, as shadow rapporteur in the negotiation of the IV Anti-Money Laundering Directive, I believe that it creates a more robust regime to combat financial crime, to which, I hope, Member States pool capable and sufficient human and technical resources. The biggest novelty is the creation of central registers with detailed information on the effective ownership of all corporate structures set up in the European Union, by which this Parliament was fought. I have to say, however, that in the aftermath of so many financial scandals, the European Union falls short of promises of transparency, as member states have blocked the parliamentary proposal to ensure a single system of public access to registration. Instead, it will be up to the Member States to decide on who and under what conditions journalists, researchers, NGOs and citizens will be able to access the data by creating 28 different access systems, which reduces the easing scope of the Directive. Furthermore, trusts are outside this scheme and public access to their last beneficiaries is not allowed.  The link between this legislation and the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion is clear. The creation of a public register can be a powerful tool in the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion by multinational companies. It is a concern for all citizens of Europe, especially those most affected by the economic and financial crime that the crisis has exposed in recent years. A public register, even without changing tax laws, would certainly help expose fictitious and opaque corporate schemes and structures used to avoid and evade taxes. I would like to call on the Member States to transpose the Directive, ensuring broad, effective and rapid public access, and to establish efficient cooperation mechanisms. We must also promote this pattern of registration in third countries, with a concerted diplomatic strategy in the ttip negotiation, the G20 and other for a, in order to put an end to tax havens once and for all.  The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question – Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – Madam Member, in your speech, you drew attention to many mistakes that can be dangerous here with regard to the application of the directive, and you mentioned, as a last word, that action against tax havens. What do you think is the reason why the European institutional system – and this is my question – is the reason why you think the European institutional system is still ind with the exact definition of tax havens?

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I believe this because there is denial and the lack of will from Member States and also from the Commission to actually tackle the absolute need for tax harmonisation, without which we do not have real competition, healthy competition in the internal market. That is exactly the job we are trying to achieve through our tax committee, and I am pretty sure that if we in Parliament do our job we will be able to make that case with governments and the Commission.

name: Beatrix von Storch
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which We are talking today about improved measures to combat money laundering. The reasons sound reasonable: the fight against terrorism, undeclared work, tax evasion. But when we talk about it, another issue is slowly emerging on the horizon, and that is the abolition of cash as a whole. Should we not make all payments cashless so that they are transparent in the fight against terror? And shouldn't we eventually abolish and ban cash? Peter Bofinger, the German economist, and Willem Buiter, chief economist at Citibank, are already calling for this, albeit for other reasons. Should the state and its officials be able to read our entire lives in our bank statements? The state would know which pub I was drinking my beer in and when I went home by taxi in the evening. Is anonymity a protection for terrorists and criminals, or is anonymity a fundamental right of freedom for us citizens? Can the use of freedom by some for crime lead us all to lose that freedom? If you ask me: Never! Let's get the cash!

name: Nils Torvalds
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr As we know, money laundering is a serious problem. It is a major source of income for criminal organisations, and it is very damaging to our economy. We worked on this bill for quite some time. I would like to thank the rapporteurs, who proved extremely cooperative. I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs who have worked on this. Firstly, we started from risk analysis. The fact that a careful risk analysis is a background is, of course, a prerequisite for bringing about decent legislation. The second important question was about the real owner. Perhaps the greatest victory we managed to achieve during the trialogue was that we now have a register of the actual owners. When we know how complex structures we can have in relation to casinos, for example, and money laundering, it was of the greatest use. Then I am particularly pleased that we also managed to solve some of the problems that we so easily encounter, that we are creating legislation that pulls everyone across a comb. This puts money laundering criminals on the same line as social enterprises in Finland, for example. For this reason, I would like to thank my colleagues and my fellow Members once again for achieving a bill that we can defend at home, of which we can be proud, and which we also believe solves the problems before us.

name: Rina Ronja Kari
text: gue/NGL Group. Mr President! As shadow rapporteur for the group, I would like to thank my colleagues for their very good cooperation. I think we must be able to say today that we have actually come a long way, so thank you very much for that.  It is also an extremely important issue that we are discussing. For example, with regard to developments in the south of the world, the United Nations has said that African countries alone are losing around USD 50 billion a year because of tax fraud and money laundering. In other words, that is almost twice as much money as it receives in development aid.  In the fight against illegal capital flight, transparency is the crucial weapon. It is important that the authorities and the public can uncover the shell companies and fraud funds that multinationals use to launder their money and to store their profits so that they do not, so to speak, to contribute to the community through tax. That is why we have also supported the introduction of a public register to enable the public to follow the trail of shell companies back to the real owner of the companies. However, frankly, we do not believe that only the authorities should have access to this information. Ordinary citizens and journalists and NGOs should also have this access. After all, it is thanks to their efforts that scandals such as Lux Leaks have come to light.  Unfortunately, it has not been possible to obtain a full public register this time. This is because there have been strong forces both within the Commission and among individual governments in the Council that did not want this transparency. I would therefore call on the governments, including my own from Denmark, which supported the introduction of a full public register, to go further, which we have given them the opportunity to do.

name: Eva Joly
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to commend the decisive work of the rapporteurs, and I am thinking in particular of Judith Sargentini. Despite the many pressures, we will vote tomorrow on the creation of registers on the actual beneficiaries of offshore companies. It's a hard-won victory. Indeed, some Member States have done everything possible to limit this progress as much as possible. As a result, the United Kingdom obtained the non-publicity of trust registers. We will also have to be vigilant about how some Member States will define NGO and journalists' access to other registers at home. That is why tomorrow's vote is only the first step in our march against opaque and illicit financial flows, which serve the interests of wealthy individuals, multinationals or criminal or terrorist networks. Tomorrow we will show that the status quo is not inevitable and I hope... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there are thousands of organised criminal groups in Europe that often use companies with offices in different countries, linked together like Chinese boxes, to hide and clean up the proceeds of their activities. The provision for an assessment of money laundering and terrorist financing risks affecting the internal market, as well as greater cooperation and exchange of information with third countries, are also significant aspects of the objectives to be pursued. Combating money laundering means combating evasion, corruption, crime, terrorist financing and other illegal and distorting phenomena of the legal economy.  Transparency in this battle plays a key role. In addition to improving the traceability of transfers of funds within the European Union, every effort must be made to make the activities of companies and other bodies with legal personality transparent, so that we can identify who benefits from these activities, who has the property and who has effective decision-making powers. It is essential to establish public registers where this kind of information can be collected, updated and stored and made accessible to as many people as possible. Although progress has been made in the regulatory framework in this area, there are still loopholes and loopholes to be closed. For some legal institutions, such as trusts, conditional access to information does not facilitate the fight against important financial transactions that can conceal money laundering and evasion. While safeguarding data protection safeguards, the way forward is to avoid any form of data access restriction that contradicts the very idea of transparency that you want to promote.

name: Mario Borghezio (NI).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems to me that this report lacks, or at least is very nuanced, one of the issues that I believe should have been at the heart of this report, given the situation of very serious dangers that we are running, namely the risk of financing through opaque financial channels – we are thinking only of the expansion of Islamic finance.  Above all, however, we think of the fact that there is a vast network of call centres, Islamic butchers, food shops, etc., activities or investments whose origin can never be understood. And I do not think that these modest instruments solve the problem of a slow but constant penetration, perhaps of a much wider scope than we think, of capital that leads back to obscure interests, probably linked also to organizations not only criminal but also terrorist. So let us ask ourselves: do we finally want to work to identify who still protects these illegal circuits today? ...  (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Eva Paunova (PPE).
text: – Mr President, for our economy to prosper, we need two ‘T’s in place – trust and transparency. In Europe each year, the volume of laundered money reaches EUR 600 billion. This is double the funds we need for the Juncker plan. This is money that we could now be investing in innovation, in education and in research. With these two proposals today, we want to reverse this negative trend through improving traceability in the transfer of funds. This is how we will improve the integrity, proper functioning, reputation and stability of the financial system. The new measures on due diligence are very much needed. They will ensure a better knowledge of customers and a better understanding of the nature of their business. The creation of central registers for information on beneficial ownership will enhance transparency and improve the trust of our citizens in the financial system. Data privacy of subjects on the register, though, must be respected. These are rules we cannot do without at European level. Money laundering and terrorist financing cannot be tackled by individual states. Together we stand strong in fighting financial fraud. This type of legislation creates trust: trust in our financial system; trust that we put our money to good use; and trust that Europeans can thrive and develop in a fair environment that rewards initiative and prevents unlawful practices.

name: Elisa Ferreira (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to begin by thanking the team of shadow rapporteurs and rapporteurs for the effort and quality of the work that has enabled such an important agreement, still achieved in the Italian Presidency. It is, in fact, a key dossier for preventing tax fraud and tax evasion and, above all, the use of the financial system for money laundering and terrorist financing. The identification of beneficial owners, or rather the real owners in business transactions in the European Union, is a key step in this direction. But the Group of Socialists and Democrats is particularly pleased to see the establishment of a public and European register of these beneficial owners, although it is sorry that access to such information is no longer free or organised at European level.  In fact, where legislation limits access to such a register to the recognition of a so-called legitimate interest, and a legitimate interest is a vague concept, the legislation ends up putting in the hands of the least demanding Member States on transparency the possibility of seriously limiting access to that information in practice. In addition, the additional possibility for Member States to further limit access to such information in cases considered exceptional, in particular where the beneficial owner is a minor or disabled, but also where there is a risk to the beneficiary of being the victim of fraud, blackmail, abduction, violence or intimidation, which are very difficult to anticipate in a precise way.  So in short, the legislation we are going to vote on is an essential step, a fundamental improvement on the path of transparency, but it is a first step. In the aspects where it has not been possible to go further, the need for compromise prevailed in a text which, as a result, is, as I say, clearly positive. It is an important step and we now trust that member states will continue in the same way...  (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker.)

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In 2004, following the Madrid attacks, the Member States of the European Union pledged to do everything in their power to combat the financing of terrorism, both acts of terror and terrorist networks. Unfortunately, the threat level of terrorism has not decreased since then. Legal, administrative and financial tools have proved insufficient. That is why tomorrow's vote, a package to combat the financing of terrorism, is a real milestone in the functioning of the European Union. I would like to thank everyone who contributed to its creation.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank all of those involved on Parliament’s side for their strong stand during the trilogue negotiation. For me, this directive underlines the importance of Parliament in the legislative process. The idea of a public register of ultimate ownership, which is key in this regulation, came from Parliament and we strongly defended it throughout the trilogue. The agreement we reached last December reflects the legitimate public demand for more transparency and marks a significant step forward in the fight against money laundering. However, there is still room for improvement when it comes to the accessibility of the public register, but the directive leaves the door open for those Member States which are ready to move forward and widely interpret the notion of legitimate interests. After Parliament’s vote, it will be time for Member States to take responsibility and swiftly and fully implement the new EU anti-money laundering and transfer of fund rules. I strongly encourage them to use the available flexibility to provide unrestricted public access to public registers with access to beneficiary ownership information to companies and trusts.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). – Money laundering is a huge wound to the economic life of the European Union. The minimum direct cost of organised crime exceeds EUR 166 billion per year, according to Europol estimates. This means less money for development, less money for social benefits and, ultimately, an uplift in social inequality and injustice. But why has money laundering not been effectively combated by European law to date? The answer is simple: because never before has there been the necessary political will to do so. Herein lies the usefulness of the two pieces of legislation we are debating today. Looks like something's finally starting to move. The proposals from the European Commission come with improvements in relation to what is already in force. Keeping records with the final beneficial owners of legal entities, including trusts, which will be open for review to those who demonstrate a legitimate interest, is a first step towards establishing a transparency regime. However, decisive steps are needed to ensure transparency in financial transactions. This is the real and great structural reform that we need and not the deregulation of the labour market for the benefit of the capital promoted in every way by the political forces currently dominant in the Union.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this fourth anti-money laundering package certainly makes progress in relation to the previous situation, even though, in my view, we are still a long way from having an effective, efficient and concrete instrument to combat what is a very far-reaching phenomenon.  As Mr Chrysogonos rightly said, this is a scourge, but it is also something very convenient for those who see these fresh capitals of dubious origin, indeed of certain illegal origin, coming on to their market.  Well, I believe that this directive has been somewhat watered down or watered down by the negotiations that have taken place with the Council, which have unfortunately been negotiated downwards. It is in danger of being a beautiful framework, but it must be filled by the different States in a different way, and we cannot be sure that the different States will do so in the most appropriate way or in any case in a compliant manner. I mean, I think we missed an opportunity to move forward.

name: Steeve Briois (NI).
text: Mr President, any strengthening of legislation against money laundering and the financing of terrorism is, on the face of it, going in the right direction. However, such a reinforcement should not result in the sacrifice of state sovereignty, as it is the Member States that are best placed to effectively combat these mafia networks. Moreover, this legislation must be accompanied by a strengthening of controls on the entry of capital into the EU internal market. We must not be naïve, money laundering and terrorist financing networks take advantage of the absence of borders between Member States. Indeed, the free movement of capital and people and the freedom of establishment in the twenty-seven countries have created a legal ground for the development of these criminal acts.  That is why, in the absence of increased police and judicial cooperation between Member States, the application of the Schengen Agreement and the principles of free movement must first be suspended.

name: Thomas Mann (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Every year, a total of between EUR 615 billion and EUR 1.5 trillion is laundered worldwide. Criminals and terrorists use money laundering to make assets appear lawful. These include letterbox companies, offshore accounts and often difficult-to-see manipulations on the internet. These massive threats to our entire coexistence affect the soundness and stability of credit institutions, jeopardising confidence in the entire financial system. National action is not enough for effective countermeasures. EU legislation must take into account international standards and new technological developments in order to respond effectively. We do indeed need the central public register to make information on the economic ownership of companies available to competent authorities and reporting agencies. The EU Commission should carry out a supranational risk assessment. Full traceability of money transfers is also required. Transparency yes, but legislation must always be in line with European data protection, with the protection of fundamental rights enshrined in the Charter. Personal data may not, of course, be used for any commercial purposes. International cooperation and coordination are therefore vitally important. It must be possible to deal appropriately and purposefully with money laundering and the financing of terrorism. Thank you very much, Mr Krisjonis And the other rapporteurs. You did a great job!

name: Roberto Gualtieri (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to say that the one that led us to the approval of the anti-money laundering package was a fine page in European parliamentary democracy, a success for this Parliament, which owes a great deal to the tenacity of the rapporteurs, the negotiating team and also to the positive role played by the Italian Presidency.  The result brings Europe not up to the most advanced international standards but ahead of these standards. Other than a watered-down compromise: Parliament has improved the proposal, it has taken a very significant step forward, that of the public register of business beneficiaries, including trusts. And I would like to add that recital 14, the one linked to Article 30, adds that the legitimate interest concerns not only anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism but also related crimes, such as corruption, tax crimes and fraud. In this respect, Parliament has really been a step forward from the original scope of the proposal and has linked this action to the greatest initiative we are taking on the issue of tax evasion and tax crimes. So this is really an important step forward.  I agree with the rapporteur that this should be a model to which Europe should ask others to adapt and, above all, this Parliament will not only legislate well but will also monitor the .... ... (The President cut the rapporteur off)

name: Stanisław Ożóg (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent Dear! At the present time, terrorist financing and money laundering are becoming a growing problem. I am pleased that the proposed legislative package takes into account the wide range of tasks incumbent on both the European Commission and the authorities and institutions of the Member States to combat these phenomena. I believe that areas in need of particular reinforcement have been correctly identified, especially as patterns of criminal activity are constantly changing. In all this, however, particular care must be taken with regard to the costs of action and guided by the principle of proportionality and rationalisation, and payment service providers, to whom certain measures could, after all, seriously impede the provision of those services.  It is also important that the guidelines resulting from the protection of the international financial system and on the implementation of possible actions at national level are uniform and consistent. Thank you very much.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to congratulate Parliament, which has worked and done a really good job. The progress is clear and there are many of them. Unfortunately, on a number of points – and I repeat unfortunately – the Council, pressed by some Member States, has managed to water down, I repeat, the excellent work and text that this Parliament has done. Our main concerns relate to the restrictions on access to the central register of beneficial owners of trust companies and other legal structures and the wide margin of discretion left to the Member States. In particular, access to central registers will not be transparently open to the public, as requested by Parliament and civil society, but will be restricted to the authorities and to those who can prove that they have a legitimate interest, a criterion that is not clearly and unambiguously defined. In addition, most trustees will remain outside the central register. The identification of beneficial owners is also complex and in any case limited to those who own or control more than 25% of the share capital. Finally, although there is nothing to prevent a State from taking even more stringent measures, we know that the risk of further watering down in terms of transposition is very high. Wide discretion at national level also risks leading to uneven implementation between Member States by creating new loopholes and the possibility of regulatory arbitrage.  We must, in fact, be very careful about this issue of trusts because we have seen how organised crime often recycles through these instruments.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – The framework of monetary union, banking union and the common fiscal policy also includes the common fight against the illegal transfer of funds, which often serves criminal purposes, without respect for the rules and across national borders. In this context, I welcome the agreement that Parliament and the Council have brought into line without major complications. At a time when we are talking about foreign policy strategy and the common security and defence policy, such regulations also fall in defence of the integrity of the Union and its citizens. We know that illegal financial flows often end up in tax havens, so it is also the Responsibility of the Union to increase the pressure on those countries that allow such opportunities to participate in the fight against such illegal financial flows and to improve transparency. In this context, it is also important for the Union to conduct accession processes in such a way as to converg candidates towards the same principles of preventing criminal and illegal financial flows.

name: Илияна Йотова (S&D).
text: – Three legislative packages have so far been adopted in the battle against money laundering. Unfortunately, the results are much weaker than we expected. Crime is flexible and always one step ahead of us. Something has to change. We need a new, holistic policy with binding laws and a common approach to fighting corruption, organised crime and money laundering. Europe should be a leader in the fight against tax havens, not turn a blind eye to them. The European Commission is currently monitoring two countries, Bulgaria and Romania, for progress in the field of the fight against crime, but this mechanism is exhausted and not working.  Commissioner Malström's corruption report shows huge amounts in all countries. We need common European legislation, convergence of criminal standards in the Member States, so that cross-border criminal networks do not benefit from differences and loopholes in national laws. We expect this policy to be the main part of the new security strategy by 2020.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: – Money laundering costs the global economy EUR 1 300 billion a year, a huge sum of illegally obtained money, for example obtained through people smuggling and drug trafficking. And that is now being brought into the mainstream economy. I think that's unfair. With this new legislation, we can better tackle money laundering and the financing of terrorism, by making economic property and risks clear. I support that. This will benefit fair trade. Tackling fraudulent practices also does justice to entrepreneurs and other citizens who simply comply with the law, as they should. One caveat on data protection. Can personal data obtained for money laundering not be used for other purposes, for example commercial? I would like the Commissioner's answer to that, because she really needs to keep her finger on the pulse here. Wash money launderers' ears, but make sure that citizens and their data are well protected.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the Money Laundering Directive is taking a step forward, but it is not annihilating all the channels through which our money flows into the suitcases of criminals or takes the path of terrorism and funds acts of terrorism in which people die. For example, the directive requires companies to have the data of the beneficial owners, the data of the people who profit from the activity of the companies, but access to this data is allowed to the press and citizens only if they prove a serious and legitimate interest. Therefore, we have a barrier to public lygating the beneficial owners of these companies. Further, phantom companies are not eliminated by this directive. Next we have giant companies that make huge profits in tax havens. Sure, it's not these companies to blame, they go where they make a bigger profit. It is us in the European Union because we allow tax havens, such as Luxembourg, within the Union. This means billions of euros lost in our citizens' money because these companies do not pay taxes as they do in other countries. Further, casinos - the place where money is laundered frequently and night after night, night after night - are exempt from checking the identity of customers. Another problem is that tax fraud is only a subsidiary crime for money laundering. I want to make a call to colleagues... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the enormous efforts of my fellow rapporteurs and also the Italian Presidency. After lengthy negotiations, Europe is about to take a step forward in the fight against money laundering, corruption, organised crime and tax evasion. Of particular importance is the establishment of a centralised and compulsory public register for each Member State in which data on the effective ownership of companies and trusts will have to be recorded. Of course, we would have liked more courage on the part of the Council in guaranteeing, as we requested, open access to registers, and not just to those who show a legitimate interest. But this is a good start and it will be essential to ensure access for journalists and NGOs.  Transparency is crucial to protecting the legal economy – it is estimated that 70% of corruption cases involve ghost companies – but also to combat organised crime and the scourge of tax evasion, which costs hundreds of billions a year in Europe, and even more so in developing countries. It's a global problem and we need global solutions.  We hope that this directive will be a first step on a long road.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! I am in favour of cost-effective regulation, but on this matter, on the fight against money laundering, I have no doubt that the European Union should not hesitate and establish effective regulation. We need to be decisive, firstly, in the creation of organisational instruments to combat money laundering – and I must say that not only am I pleased that a register of beneficial owners is being created, but I also do not share this belief that it is intended to jeopardise privacy. Let us not hesitate to create instruments that combat the worst forms of crime, in this case money laundering. Let us not use the personal data protection argument.  Finally, we need to implement what we have adopted – unfortunately in many countries the international recommendations of the UN, the Council of Europe on the fight against money laundering, the confiscation of property are not yet implemented. I would like the Commission to keep an eye on and ... (The President has received the speaker's vote)

name: Julia Pitera (PPE).
