text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The money laundering practice, which has been known for years, is mainly linked to the functioning of organised crime. This phenomenon affects the international financial system and the global economy. The United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime said in its research report in 2011 that the annual value of revenue from this crime could reach up to 2.7% of global GDP and is estimated to increase every year. This is facilitated by the process of globalisation, the complexity of global markets and technological developments, as well as the free movement of capital and the diversity of financial instruments. This is also undoubtedly facilitated by the anonymity and confidentiality of the bank's customer data, which, in particular, facilitates the concealment of sources of income in online banking services. And these sources, in addition to organised crime, also fund global terrorism.  Carrying out terrorist attacks usually requires considerable financial and preparation and implementation. Therefore, the proposed registers to prevent the use of the financial system for money laundering or terrorist financing, I hope that they will prove to be an effective way of reducing the ability of criminal and terrorist groups to operate and open the way for further improvement of the system of combating the criminal world.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, honourable rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs, first of all, let me thank you for your excellent work on this directive. I am glad and proud that it is the Czech Commissioner who has brought this key document among us, which is moving Europe further in the fight against illegal trade and money laundering. The sum that has fallen here and which is estimated to be related to money laundering is very alarming. But even more serious is the fact that none of us is able to determine with certainty where and where such money is coming from and to whom it serves. I therefore consider it essential that such transactions be monitored carefully and in the long term, but also transparently. Personally, I am also a supporter of a cashless economy, and, unlike my colleague von Storch, I believe that it is the cashless economy that can make a significant contribution to europe's progress in the fight against money laundering.  One thing I would like to mention at the end, which no one mentioned here. These illegal activities are characterised by international scale, rapid development and an unforeseen direction. Therefore, we must not only be content to introduce measures at European Union level, this is only the beginning, but to seek close links and cooperation between all our partners.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE).
text: – Honourable Commissioner, honourable report-takers, I would like to thank you for your support. First of all, I would like to thank you for your work. You've done an excellent job. Today, money laundering has become one of the most profitable and high-end businesses. Of course, legislation exists, it will be newer and newer, but the movement of criminal networks is very difficult to follow. This is a very significant and challenging task.  I agree with the finding that foreign entities must comply with the requirements of the transparency of information in that country. I also agree that the functioning of business registers needs to be improved so that we have information about the final owner. This is not an easy task, the Member States have a lot of work to do here, and by the way, the European Union itself. If I see the ultimate goal, I think it can be an excellent tool.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the inclusion in this report of our group regarding the setting up of a public register on beneficial owners. Access to the public register on beneficial owners is subject to a legitimate interest. This formulation will allow those Member States which wish to be more transparent to adopt a broad definition of legitimate interest. Then Member States may provide for an exemption to access to all or part of the beneficial ownership information on a case-by-case basis in exceptional circumstances, if this would expose the beneficial owner to the risk of fraud, kidnapping, blackmail, violence or intimidation, or if the beneficial owner is a minor or otherwise incapable. The Fourth AMLD will provide a sound basis for providing maximum transparency in respect of beneficial ownership of corporate structures across the European Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, intra-group transactions have given multinationals the opportunity to avoid tax because they are not taxed where their profits are generated, but in tax havens. And that means the loss of billions of euros from the countries of Africa or the countries of the European South. At the same time, many large multinational companies operating in Greece are escaping tax, having settled tax either in the Netherlands or in Luxembourg, which we also had the well-known 'Lux Leaks' scandal. The practice of off-shore companies contributing to money laundering must also be beaten. Finally, measures must be taken to combat the jihadists financed by the sale of oil to the countries of the West. That is why we agree with the keeping of central public records for the real owners of businesses. However, there must be guarantees for the use of personal data. However, we disagree with the exclusion of casinos and gambling from the application of the legislation.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, Madam Commissioners, fellow rapporteurs, I would certainly like to welcome the new legislation and I would like to say that this is a great step forward. But I think it's just one step forward. So something that is certainly positive, something that shows that we want to deal with those who launder money, finance terrorism, steal our citizens, our economy, our budgets and I think it's a great initiative and we have great solutions. However, what I see as a problem are two things: 1. the fact is that everything will now depend in some way on the activities and wishes of the Member States and their success in the fight against this crime, money laundering and terrorist financing as well as the problem of third countries. There we must be absolutely clear - we will not solve this problem if we do not actively cooperate with third countries.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – So both the documents, and the directive and the regulation, are in the right direction. Of course, this is not a reason to open up champagne, because money laundering poses a real real threat to the stability of the financial system. Therefore, if we wash more than 1,000 billion each year in this way, if we avoid taxes, so if we are also establishing the conditions in Europe itself for tax avoidance, that is not a good thing, of course, and I hope that these new rules, when they come into force, will take a step in the right direction. Transparency in all these things is also emphasised, including the register, which should be made public, because I fully agree with transparency, of course, as some have said, that it is like the Holy Grail, that you know, of course, that it exists, but you cannot achieve it in any way.  However, I think that, of course, this area of money laundering is actually one of the biggest challenges, so that we can stabilise the economy and finances further.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – I would like to begin by congratulating my colleague Kariņš and his fellow rapporteurs on their excellent work. We have already heard today that the global economy is losing 5% of its output as a result of money laundering, which, of course, has a direct impact on poverty, because only criminals and terrorists benefit from this evil. Can you imagine a situation where all this money would be invested in human capital? What would this mean especially for poorer countries? The new European legislation introduces effective action by the police, tax offices and other bodies to eradicate this social evil. The introduction of the registration of financial actors and the blacklist measure for third countries at high risk of money laundering seem to me to be a good measure in the fight against money laundering. Last but not least, the global problem requires a global and, of course, holistic approach. I believe that we are well on our way and that in this way we will make it more difficult for criminal gangs to clean up the financial economy.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the discussion I have just heard gives me quite a strong impression that tomorrow’s vote could help things happen and help to achieve all the positive results which we spoke about that we need to achieve through this new package of two pieces of legislation.  I heard Members speaking also about criminal law and about data protection, so let me also tell you in a few words about these angles from which we can look at the problem of organised crime. I would like to tell you that we are taking a very comprehensive approach to combating crime in the criminal law sphere. We are now strengthening the functions of, and cooperation between, the Eurojust and Europol agencies, especially in relation to strengthening security in Europe. Members also spoke about third countries and the necessity to enlarge our activities there and to focus on third country nationals, so I would like to inform you that also under the security agenda we plan to enlarge the ECRIS register, which is the register of criminal offenders for third country nationals, which can also help us to have a better information flow regarding suspects and probable perpetrators. The second thing Members mentioned was data protection. I am very glad that I am responsible also for this new regulation. The data protection reform which we are now preparing – and hopefully finalising this year in the Council, followed by the trilogue in the next year – is a real revolution, because it replaces 28 national regimes by one strong pan-European regime for protection of personal data.  So speaking about data protection in relation to the Anti-Money Laundering Directive and related things in the new legislation, I can say that we pay very high attention to protecting fundamental rights and especially the right to privacy and the right to the protection of personal data. These two pieces of legislation are very compatible and they can work together very well when they are introduced in practice.  As for the package itself, I am happy that I heard here that Members find the package a practical, reasonable, necessary and proportionate set of rules for combating crime in the financial sphere. Besides that, it is to combat organised crime such as money laundering, tax evasion and other related crimes, but also – many times mentioned here – terrorism. It is not here only to save money and to prevent money from going into a black hole somewhere, but to use the money for much better purposes, which was said several times. It is not only about saving money, it is, I may say, about saving human lives, because financial transactions are usually, or very often, the first signs that a terrorist attack or some terrorist action is being prepared, so this has an essential role for strengthening security in Europe.  I would like to thank Parliament once again for its support. I hope tomorrow’s vote will push us forward.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš
text: Rapporteur. – Once again, thank you to everyone for their cooperation in this directive.  Many have been said in the debate, but in fact the views of the factions are very united. That is, the factions of the European Parliament are indeed determined to support this directive, which will indeed improve the fight against money laundering by establishing, in particular, this register of real beneficiaries at European Union level. Thanks everyone!

name: Judith Sargentini
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, many of my colleagues pointed out that the public register would not be ‘public’ because you have to have a legitimate interest. I would like to point out that we made sure that in the proposal it says that the authority has to clarify whether you do or not, so they have to prove that you do not have a legitimate interest.  I would like the first journalist who has been told he or she does not have a legitimate interest to go to court, clarify it and, at the same time, open up the public register and make it even more public. I do not think any authority can say that you, as a citizen, do not have a legitimate interest to look into a register to look for fraud, corruption and anti-money laundering issues. You will get that access.  It is also a self-fulfilling prophecy: if we start saying here that it has its limitations, it will have its limitations. If we say here, ‘let us try it out’, we will open up that register even more.

name: Timothy Kirkhope
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, it has been a most interesting debate. I thank the Commissioner particularly for her comments both at the beginning and after the debate. I would just like to point out that my primary aim in my part of this has been to try and get the fourth Anti—Money Laundering Directive just about right. I heard some concerns and if I may just say on the issue of trusts and wills: trusts and wills contain some of the most private and personal information that there is about a person, and we are a parliament that respects data privacy, hence disclosure for trusts has to be proportionate within our proposals.  New payment methods are emerging every day with increasingly sophisticated technological capabilities by criminals, individuals and groups in the digital and in the cyber world, as has been expressed by a number of people. We do indeed face a very tough challenge, but I think we have dealt with most of the concerns. I think we have found workable solutions and addressed concerns generally. So I want to again express my thanks to all those involved and I hope that we will have a successful outcome in the vote.

name: Peter Simon
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the I, too, would like to thank all those involved once again for their cooperation and conclude by saying that we can, on the whole, be satisfied with the compromise reached, in particular with the introduction of the public central registers, with the register containing all the information on the beneficial owners behind opaque company structures. However, we must also be aware that the fight against money laundering and fraud must be constantly relaunched, because the methods of money launderers are constantly evolving. That is why, as legislators, we must not only react beyond tomorrow,beyond the vote, but also act and act ambitiously. That is why the compromise reached with the Council is a further, further important step, but it must be followed by others in the future. We must be vigilant that the requirements of the new EU Money Laundering Directive are effectively implemented and that Member States, in particular, do not unnecessarily impede or hinder access to the central registers for persons with legitimate interests. We must also facilitate the cooperation of national investigators by linking national registers as quickly as possible. It is and remains difficult to understand why we should wait four years for the national registers to be linked, even though the information is theoretically available, but this prevents the exchange of information. I believe that we must all start here together, because the fight against money laundering and fraud knows no borders and must be conducted at European and global level.

name: Preşedinte –
text: The debate has been closed.  The vote will take place tomorrow, 20 May 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. – We welcome the approval of this second reading agreement on the prevention of the use of the financial system for the purposes of money laundering or terrorist financing. In our fight against organised crime, we must ensure that the transparency of the financial system will be a serious obstacle to financing criminal activities and terrorist operations. These rules improve the traceability of payments, so important in preventing and detecting money laundering and terrorist financing when transferring funds. They also regulate payment service providers to send information on the payer throughout the payment chain for the purposes of prevention, investigation and detection of money laundering and terrorist financing. We need to strengthen the EU’s repressive response to money laundering as well as harmonise criminal law for this offence. One effective way to fight terrorism is by cutting their sources of funding. We can achieve this by increasing transparency in financial transfers and strengthening the EU financial system.

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE)
text: Writing. – The new money laundering directive aims to combat tax crimes and the financing of terrorist organisations. The new rules, which will improve the traceability of remittances, are also expected to be approved. The European Parliament has succeeded in getting the actual owners of businesses to be registered in the central registers of EU Member States, which will be available to both competent authorities and persons with a legitimate interest in this information, such as investigative journalists. The draft law includes a requirement for the establishment of a single register of beneficial owners in the EU. It will be a powerful weapon that will prevent the criminal community from hiding behind the anonymity of the ofstors, and it will give law enforcement a new tool for effective anti-money laundering as well as tax fraud schemes. The register will make it possible to find out who and where taxes should be paid, promote fair competition and, consequently, improve the investment climate in the Member States. The bill stipulates that law enforcement authorities, as well as banks, lawyers, auditors and other bodies provided for in the draft law, will have access to information on beneficial owners throughout the EU. The Single Register of True Beneficiaries will have to become operational within two years of the entry into force of the Law. The bill establishes a blacklist for third-country jurisdictions with loopholes in money laundering. As a result, companies or individuals from blacklist countries will be rigorously tested.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. We have been negotiating the legislative texts for two years now. During these two years, offshore leaks and lux leaks have become known, and there are also estimates that show us the enormous scale of tax evasion and money laundering: the European Union alone loses EUR 1 trillion in taxes every year; a total of between EUR 615 billion and EUR 1.54 is laundered worldwide. Transparency is essential for effectively combating money laundering and tax evasion. This compromise creates corporate transparency and will reveal the identity of actual beneficiaries, beneficial owners of letterbox companies. This success of the European Parliament is an important step in the fight against tax evasion and money laundering. However, the review of cooperation between Member States will only take place in four years' time. An unnecessarily long time! The extension of the business register to third countries on the basis of a blacklist is also a positive development. Here too, however, we could achieve more and should push for an extension of the business register to third countries.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The importance of mobilisation of domestic resources has become a recurring theme in development cooperation discussions and a stated EU objective. The positive role of taxes that increase state revenues to finance sustainable and equitable development that reduces poverty and inequality is increasingly recognized. However, it is common practice to use anonymous legal entities to lay down illicit profits. It is estimated that up to 2.7% of world GDP is money laundered from criminal activities. The World Bank estimates that more than 70% of large-scale corruption cases involve anonymous companies. Decent people will no longer be content with simple hard words against money laundering that are not accompanied by concrete actions. The current system and the rules imposed so far by legislators fail to stop these illicit flows. It is time for a change, it is time for concrete and effective measures against money laundering.

name: Preşedinte. –
text: The next item is the debate on the recommendation for second reading of the Committee on Legal Affairs on insolvency proceedings (16636/5/2014 - C8-0090/2015 - HYPERLINK "http://www.europarl.europa.eu/oeil/popups/ficheproceduredure.do?lang=fr&reference=2 012/0360(COD)" 2012/0360(COD)) (Rapporteur: Tadeusz Zwiefka) ( HYPERLINK "http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?type=REPORT&reference=A8-2015-0155&language=RO" A8-0155/2015)) and the Commission Statement on the Review and Extension of the Commission Recommendation of 12 March 2014 on a new approach to the bankruptcy and insolvency of undertakings, ( HYPERLINK "http://www.europarl.europa.eu/oeil/popups/ficheprocedure.do?lang=en&reference=2015/2701(RSP)" 2015/2701(RSP).

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. The Insolvency Regulation, which entered into force in 2002 in all Member States of the Union except Denmark, regulates the choice of law applicable to the proceedings of jurisdiction and the recognition of judgments. Since the regulation adopted so many years ago proved insufficient in the context of the economic crisis and in the face of the bankruptcy of many companies in the Union, during the last parliamentary term we started working on amending this regulation in the European Parliament. The report was drawn up by our colleague Klaus-Heiner Lehne and provided an excellent basis for subsequent negotiations with the Council already under way during this term of office.  The positions of the two institutions were close to each other – and most importantly, we had a common objective: to create a legal framework for cross-border insolvency proceedings that would, on the one hand, give the creditors a chance to be satisfied, but on the other hand, these honest entrepreneurs will allow for proper restructuring and thus will not allow companies to go bankrupt and jobs to be lost.  The main objective of the reform was to try to reduce the so-called bankruptcy tourism. The European Court of Justice has pointed out that there are no adequate safeguards against such conduct under the Insolvency Regulation. This is an interpretation of the term 'principal centre of business' – the so-called COMI, which is necessary for determining the jurisdiction of the court having jurisdiction to open insolvency proceedings. A change of jurisdiction entails the need to bring your claims before a court in another country. This, in turn, leads to proceedings in a different language, as well as other procedural rules, which in turn lengthens the process, increases costs and reduces legal certainty. In the current situation, legal certainty in the european Union's economic activity seems to be extremely important to us. Therefore, in order to eliminate the possibility of forum shopping, Parliament has proposed to introduce into the DEFINITION OF COMI the following solutions: a transitional period of three months during which the debtor's company cannot open insolvency proceedings after a possible transfer of its registered office to another country. We have adopted a different deadline, namely six months, in the event of consumer bankruptcy. This difference is due to a very important fact. It is much easier for a natural person to move than a legal person. In the event of a consumer bankruptcy within that six-month period, it is the debtor's responsibility to command that his principal place of residence is where he declared it.  Secondly, we have proposed a new system of insolvency coordination for a group of companies, which will be an optional or non-coerceal instrument. Within 30 days of receiving the information on the request for the opening of coordination proceedings, the insolvency trustee of each company may decide to exercise the opt-out option and exit the coordination if he considers that this will be beneficial to the company he or she is representing. We will examine the effectiveness and effectiveness of this mechanism five years after the entry into force of the amendments to the regulation. Thirdly, an EU insolvency register is established, which I believe is very important, to monitor insolvency proceedings throughout the European Union. I am convinced that this register will prove to be very useful for both citizens and EU businesses. On this occasion, I would like to thank you very much for your excellent cooperation with the Council, especially the Italian Presidency, as well as my fellow shadow rapporteurs, in particular Mr Cofferati. Thank you very much.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the vote tomorrow will conclude a two-year-long negotiation process on the recast of the Regulation on insolvency proceedings. I want to pay tribute to the rapporteur Mr Zwiefka and to the Committee on Legal Affairs for their most efficient work on what I see as only a first step in this area.  Honest entrepreneurs deserve help when running into difficulties. The improved tools on jurisdiction will increase legal certainty and put in place effective safeguards against abusive forum shopping. I know that this issue was particularly important for Parliament.  The establishment of a system of interconnected insolvency registers will increase the transparency of insolvency proceedings for creditors. This is a very tangible benefit of the reform and it will foster a cultural change in the business community across Europe.  The revised regulation covers also preventive insolvency proceedings, which aim at rescuing businesses, as well as a larger range of personal insolvency proceedings. It clarifies jurisdiction rules. Synthetic secondary proceedings avoid duplication of proceedings. The revision also provides the first legal framework for coordinating the proceedings of members of groups of companies.  Of course, our work is not finished with the adoption of the regulation. We will spare no efforts so that practitioners and citizens can properly apply the new instrument by the time it replaces the old regulation.  The Commission has also followed up on your goal, and last year adopted a recommendation on a new approach to business failure. The Commission is currently assessing the actions the Member States have taken in response to the recommendation.  It is obvious that we need modern and efficient insolvency rules that help rescue viable businesses and give entrepreneurs and consumers a second chance. Let me give you several illustrative figures. Today in Europe, half of all businesses do not survive the first five years of their existence. In the EU, 200 000 firms go bankrupt per year, that is 600 a day, resulting in 1.7 million direct job losses every year. Around a quarter of these bankruptcies concern businesses that work cross-border, and the latest crisis has led to a surge in non-performing loans in all Member States without exception.  Last month we held a conference in Riga to look at the way ahead. It was a useful first occasion to gather views and brainstorm about the next steps. The Capital Markets Union project, which the Commission adopted recently, also contains a clear reference to the need for modern insolvency regimes as a gateway to a flourishing business and investment climate.  We are interested in Members views when starting to map out the next steps. I understand that consumer insolvency is of particular concern to some of you. I would like to recall that the principles laid down in the Commission recommendation are also relevant in this regard. In particular in its recital 15, the Commission urges Member States to consider applying the principles of the recommendation also to consumers.  The Commission has carried out a specific study on over-indebtedness of European households and families. The findings are clear. People who lose their jobs and incomes have a higher probability of falling into the debt trap, as do people confronted with accidents of life no one can anticipate. Bad financial choices come down to two basic scenarios: a credit which is too short-term, or interest rates which are too high, often to be explained by inadequate financial advice by lenders.  In the framework of this study, the most frequently—named best practice reported by stakeholders relates to legislative steps to make insolvency proceedings more readily available. However, the situation is not homogeneous across the EU. For example, in a number of Member States consumers do not have access to personal insolvency proceedings, and in many others the discharge periods are much longer than the recommended three-year period provided for in the Commission recommendation.  As regards next steps, besides the evaluation of the recommendation and the already existing material, the Commission is carrying out a comprehensive comparative legal study in the 28 Member States regarding consumer insolvency procedures. It will be completed in mid-January 2016 and this will provide us with a good basis to discuss next steps. I would like Parliament to be fully involved in this process.

name: József Nagy
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Unfortunately, in the new Member States, we are becoming aware of a growing number of broken big companies who are going through people without responsibility, only by looking for profit. All in a way that their process is legal, but not moral.  In my country, Slovakia, for example, such is the case of the company Váhostav, in which the large entrepreneur, with the help of the current ruling party, abandons thousands of people, hundreds of entrepreneurs and plers them into uncertainty and misery.  I very much welcome the new legislation on insolvency proceedings. Indeed, the eu's four freedoms can be used by clever con artists to build cross-border fraud networks. The only way to combat fraudsters is to work in concert and eliminate opportunities that company managers can take advantage of at the expense of their small creditors and subcontractors.

name: Enrico Gasbarra
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank my fellow rapporteur, Mr Zwiefka, for the work he has done, for concluding the agreement with the Council on a measure that was long overdue by consumers and businesses in Europe – the rapporteur and the Commissioner, whom I thank, recalled the uncertainty surrounding this sector and the rules. It is no coincidence that two years ago the Commission tried to propose a comprehensive reform of the whole sector. The safeguards included in this first important step are fundamental, in particular, of course, the one that seeks to limit so-called forum shopping, not least because in too many cases companies and debtors suddenly moved their headquarters before insolvency or bankruptcy proceedings began.  This regulation introduces a legal framework that is finally certain and protective, as well as the ability of courts to assess whether the move is genuine or not, and this is a very important step.  I shall therefore vote in favour of the regulation, of ratifying the agreement which, as we said earlier, is an important step forward. Above all, however, I am comforted by what the Commissioner has said, because it is the first of other steps that Europe must take in this area.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Dear Mr President, it is common ground that the severe economic crisis has led to difficulties for economic operators in the Member States. Large corporations are struggling, small and medium-sized enterprises are in a difficult situation, many citizens face literally the inability to cover even their elementary costs. It is therefore logical and perfectly normal to discuss the possibility of improving insolvency proceedings and unifying insolvency proceedings. Of course, we cannot miss the fact that member states' legal systems regulate this procedure differently, but a common framework can still be introduced. This would be useful for the common market as well as for increasing the level of competition and would have a beneficial effect. I agree with the thesis of some of my colleagues that it is right and necessary to think about the introduction of the status of "bankruptcy of the family and the individual". It cannot and is wrong for a man to be permanently and forever a slave to his creditors. This practice has long been denied in the Member States. Alas, the current practice shows otherwise. I therefore declare myself in favour of the idea of Community regulation of the bankruptcy procedure for individuals. This has its legal and of course life logic. Many may not like this idea, but it would definitely be fair and would benefit citizens of the Member States.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Europe was conceived as a project in the service of peace and well-being, at the service of freedom and quality of life. Today and now, that forces us to devote to rescuing people as much determination and urgency as we have dedicated to rescuing financial institutions. Many banks were victims of their own voracity. This greed has taken many business projects and many life projects of individuals and families who, for the most part, were in good faith. Therefore, it is mandatory to offer them a second chance. Because it's a matter of justice. But it is also another tool at the service of the real economy and employment.  This review of insolvency proceedings and the Commission's recommendations set out very clear principles to be met by all Member States and should also apply to individual debtors. They are neither the inequality of legal weapons between creditor and debtor, nor the time limits for recourse, designed at the service of the powerful, nor the inhumane vetoes of the payment, which condemn individuals and families trapped in unfair mortgage proceedings.  They are the faces and eyes of the crisis. And in 90% of cases we can alleviate your situation with consistency and determination. I therefore call for a European guarantee for this principle of second chance and a determined use of infringement procedures for States such as Spain, which are set out in red by the European Courts for their resistance to changing their laws in this direction.

name: Jiří Maštálka
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, it is a pity that there are so few of us here on such a serious subject, but I hope that those who do not participate are not in insolvency.  Seriously, I consider the revision of the regulation governing insolvency proceedings to be an important step towards modernising insolvency law. In particular, I believe that we should increase the protection of employees who are most affected by the possible bankruptcy of their employer. Unfortunately, the risk of company bankruptcies is high nowadays, for example, in the Czech Republic, the number of insolvency proposals has increased from 5,300 to more than 35,000 per year in the last six years. That is why we need a broader debate on how to protect companies from possible bankruptcy.  I see another problem in the so-called insolvency tourism and the submission of bullying insolvency proposals in order to eliminate competition. Companies that do not really owe anyone anything also get into the insolvency register. According to statistics, one in ten companies have encountered such practices. I don't have to add that this is damaging the company in question. I therefore support the modernisation of insolvency law.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I am glad that we can have this debate. I would like to thank Mr López and the other Members for their possible efforts that we can talk about the issue of consumer and people insolvency today.  Commissioner, this is an issue that needs to be resolved. You have said that, in some cases, the recommendations are not being complied with. I would like them to be a little more diligent in their implementation, but I believe that the legal framework we have at European level is not enough.  We have an extremely serious problem: evictions continue, many people are losing their homes because they are not given this second chance. I believe, of course, that we must move towards much greater protection at European Union level and also enforce those judgments in which it is noted that some countries, such as Spain, do not comply with the legislation in this area. Clearly, we need a more powerful European instrument in this regard, which can cover issues such as blackberry, such as payment giving — which is not yet recognised at European level. Because I believe that, in many of these cases, we must implement policies that help people and, in this respect, these second-chance policies are absolutely fundamental.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI).
text: Mr President, this text amends the Community regulation of 29 May 2000 on insolvency proceedings.  It aims to protect creditors in cases where a company's insolvency is cross-border. It has the merit of assigning jurisdiction to the courts of the Member State in which the debtor company has the centre of its main interests. The reality of the company's place of activity is thus used as a criterion for the allocation of competences, which allows the shopping forum to be excluded, i.e. the abusive search by cross-border debtors of the most favourable national jurisdiction.  This text, however, fails to over-marginalize the creditor's ability to initiate secondary proceedings before the courts of his own state if the debtor owns property there. That is why I am hostile to it.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I welcome this amendment to the regulation governing insolvency law issues. As Minister of Justice, I myself was responsible for the new insolvency law in the Czech Republic and I know how important this is a social issue. These are not only technical professional standards, but the quality of insolvency law has a very significant impact not only on the business sector, but also on the functioning of the company as such.  We have dealt with the issue of the length of insolvency proceedings in the Czech Republic, now we are rather addressing the question of how to strengthen the undiquid forms of resolution of the debtor's situation. However, this proposal, which is here, concerns cross-border insolvency proceedings. I am convinced from my own experience in the Czech Republic that this is a very good regulation and it is good that after ten years you are carrying out a revision that removes some problems, such as clarifying the jurisdiction of the insolvency court in order to avoid the aforementioned insolvency tourism, where the place where insolvency law is somewhere best for the debtor, not for the creditors, is chosen. It is also very good that you are currently extending the scope of this proposal and that in the future not only liquidation forms of bankruptcy, but also eliminated forms of bankruptcy, will fall within this regulation. And the third thing I want to mention is the issue of the compulsory insolvency register. I think that this is absolutely crucial and if we want european effective insolvency proceedings in the future, we need to have one public register.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to thank you, Commissioner, for the work done by the Commission, but also, of course, to our rapporteur, Tadeusz Zwiefka. From the point of view of the Social Democrats, the S&D amendment is particularly important to me, so that, in order to avoid forum shopping, there is just a three-month cooling-off phase. I also need a recital, namely the right to preferential satisfaction for workers. The fact that this recital is inward will hopefully make it possible, in the next revision of the regulations, to take even more far-reaching measures. Then, so to speak, I would not only like to praise your work, but also ask you to tackle the next hot iron, namely private insolvencies. Half of all insolvencies that exist are not those of companies, but also those of private individuals. We could spare ourselves a great deal of suffering from people who are going into private insolvency if the Commission were to tackle this issue as well. Because there are not all the countries of the European Union that have such rules.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, as has been said, today we are also dealing with the request of my group, and my own, to be able to extend the framework of reference we have of the insolvency of companies to a framework of reference for personal insolvency, which is absolutely necessary in order to ensure minimum protection for individuals. Something that is economically effective and absolutely socially just. Why is this framework of people's insolvency necessary? Firstly, because we have very different legislation within Europe in this area, from the insolvency commissions in France to the model of rehabilitation in Britain, which allow hundreds of thousands of people - 150 000 a year in Britain or 50,000 in France - to have a well-deserved second chance.  But unfortunately, in some countries we do not have this necessary legal door, this escape from a situation that has caused a social disaster. Spain is a paradigm in this. We have had 570,000 foreclosures during the economic crisis, hundreds of thousands of first home evictions; a social disaster, as I said, but also a moral collapse: the one we see on TV news when police drive old ladies out of their homes. That is why it is necessary — because no one stops paying the debts because they want to – to find a European legal door by extending this insolvency to families, because honest citizens also deserve a second chance.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as you have seen, we have come to the end of the debate with a broad consensus on the solutions that are being proposed. This is due to a positive relationship between the rapporteurs, for which Mr Zwiefka is to be thanked in the first place. There are a few aspects worth highlighting. The first, which I have just heard, is the one we agreed on extending the scope of the directive, that of hybrid procedures and restructuring. After all, what we need is to anticipate the risk of bankruptcies, which is often overlooked because the less contentious we have, the better for the citizens of Europe. The extension of the scope gives us an additional legal instrument in relation to the existing ones, which will greatly reduce the conflict. In the same way, it was important to identify the main focus: the phenomenon of finding the place where the procedure is activated is a negative phenomenon. The shopping of the forum must be reduced, where possible, even eliminated. I believe that the conditions are in place here to be able to do so. The procedures for coordinating insolvency for corporate groups, which Parliament has already indicated, are also a good step in the right direction. Finally, it remains the issue of workers or creditors. We have introduced a rule which is that of the provision of a preferential right: these are the weakest, who are often penalised by decisions by others who fall on them. There is a positive novelty for them too.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I believe that the framework regulation of insolvency proceedings must include clearly defined rules for individuals, self-employed persons and consumers. With regard to the harmonisation of the laws of the Member States, a sector which is not yet unified is precisely this, the insolvency of natural persons. I believe, in so far as this Regulation can give the framework rules in which to carry out this type of debt recovery, it is advisable to do so. Last but not least, I would like to highlight the Social Democrat group's effort to include preferential rights for employees who are affected by insolvency proceedings in harmonisation measures. Let us not forget, however, that employees, natural persons and self-employed persons must enjoy the same basic rights as legal persons in the case of extensive insolvency proceedings, be protected by framework rules and be able to recover financially, like a company. It is very important that the harmonisation of insolvency measures takes into account the needs of natural persons who are properly represented in the case of such... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, austerity in Europe has created armies of the poor and unemployed and this has led to over-indebted households. We have thousands of complaints that in Spain people are losing their homes because banks are throwing them out. In Greece, the memorandum led to a huge over-indebtedness of households. Unemployment reaches one and a half million of our fellow citizens, 40% of the population lives below the poverty line, there are over-indebted households that owe banks housing and consumer loans. In Greece we had a process of suspending auctions. But the troika, Mrs Jourová, because that is where the Commission is involved, wants this protection to stop, namely the suspension of first home auctions. The troika, that is to say the Commission, does not agree with the regulation of red loans, and Mr Draghi has refused this arrangement that we are asking for. Measures must therefore be taken to protect over-indebted households in Greece and throughout Europe. (Applause)

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, Mr. Rapporteur, we need European regulation when we talk about bankruptcies and insolvency of families, i.e. individuals. There are different experiences in our Member States, but the result is the same - people are desperate. Either they lose their jobs because of irresponsible owners who are often at least in new countries, new democracies ripped off businesses or, as you said respected commissioners, fell for inadequate advice and today have loans with too high interest. Your message is absolutely clear. Unfortunately we have a situation where people no longer know how to move forward. And that is why I support this regulation because I am convinced that in this way we show the need to introduce in Europe and all Member States an institute of personal bankruptcy and a chance for every individual in Europe.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). – Today's proposed amendment to the European rules governing bankruptcies with cross-border implications proves once again that we are trying to tackle a problem in a fire-fighting way, without undoing its roots. More and more businesses are going bankrupt today because Europe has been plunged into economic stagnation for at least five years and because the countries most affected by the economic crisis have not taken the necessary measures to support societies. It is clear that the recipe for austerity is bringing recession. The recession drains liquidity and the weakest companies end up going bankrupt. It is therefore not enough to discuss how to manage bankruptcies. We must do our utmost to support the real economy through public and private investment, with growth and with stimulus measures, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the Council Regulation establishing a European framework for cross-border insolvency proceedings. This would determine which Member State has jurisdiction for opening insolvency proceedings, establish uniform rules on applicable law and provide for the recognition and enforcement of insolvency—related decisions, as well as for the coordination of main and secondary insolvency. Our S&D amendment managed to avoid forum shopping by introducing the additional criterion of a three-month cooling-off period. The regulation now also allows for coordination of the proceedings for corporate groups and calls for the future introduction of preferential rights for employees. I wish to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for the very good job they have done.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the House for the positive approach which I heard in the vast majority of the speeches. As we understand it, the vision here is to encourage those honest entrepreneurs who do business in good faith and often get into debt and trouble through no fault of their own. I am glad that Parliament sees this in a similar way to us, and I hope tomorrow’s vote will reflect this positive approach. I would like to confirm here, once again, that I do not regard this as finished work because we want to continue, we want to bring in solutions – balanced solutions – which are good for debtors and creditors, and which will also cover the situation of individuals, because, as was also mentioned here, there is a very strong feeling in many Member States of unfairness in insolvency proceedings. People feel unsafe, and you know perhaps from your own experience – at least I have had such experience – that if you have troubles in your private life you can easily get into big problems in terms of finance. Human life stands on three legs of a chair – health, family and job – and once you have problems in two of these three you can be sure you will have big problems in relation to finance. We are now assessing the recommendations we gave to the Member States and we are looking at the possibilities of introducing pan-European legislation for better insolvency rules, not only for companies but also for individuals. That is the plan for the next steps. In addition, we are taking other action in this field: I would mention the recently announced country specific recommendations, in which we recommended that three Member States improve insolvency proceedings in their countries. We are also running several campaigns to raise awareness about consumer credit because many people in Europe take out credit and then are not able to pay back the money. In many cases this is because they simply did not read the contractual conditions. It is proper to inform people of the risks they undertake when they take out consumer credit. So thank you, once again. I am looking forward to further cooperation with Parliament on the next proposals.

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka
text: Rapporteur. – I, too, would like to join in the words of thanks to my colleagues who wished to take part in this debate today, a very important debate. I regret to say that when we talk about real legislative solutions – and yet the introduction of a regulation is a real legislative change in the European Union, touching on the substance of the matter, the lives of the citizens of the European Union and the functioning of businesses – this debate takes place in the late evening. And when we have a discussion club, when we only exchange views and opinions, it sometimes takes us whole meetings until noon and I think it would be worth changing something here.  But back to the essence of the matter. First of all, we can be pleased that these changes, which we will confirm with tomorrow's vote in the European Parliament, will significantly support the functioning of European companies, those who have failed because of dishonesty or total inadmissibility, but all sorts of events, a weave of all sorts of causes. And for this reason, we can be pleased, because when it comes to this bankruptcy of companies, it seems that we are going the right way.  However, it was clear from this discussion that we have a lot of work to do in the event of consumer bankruptcy. Here I am pleased with Commissioner Jourova's announcement of further legislative action, but above all of one fact that you wanted to raise in your speech – the awareness-raising measures. Because it is a huge role that the European Commission and the Member States should make their citizens aware of what legal instruments we are giving them, what we should respect them against, which we should pay particular attention to, because very often mistakes are made out of ignorance, and ignorance can be minimised by us – at least to some extent – and make both citizens and businesses able to use this instrument and pay attention to those things that we still need to do. Once again, thank you very much to everyone.

name: Preşedinte –
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, 20 May 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. – I would like to express my satisfaction at the debate in this plenary session on the creation of a European framework for the prevention of over-indebtedness and resolution of insolvency, not only for businesses, but also for consumers and self-employed people. Thanks to the initiative of socialist MP Javi López, this issue has been integrated into the European institutional agenda and that the Commissioner for Justice, Consumer Affairs and Gender Equality, V. Jourová, announced the conduct of a promising comprehensive comparative study on consumer insolvency proceedings in the 28 Member States, which will be delivered in January 2016 and will serve as the basis for discussing the extension of these measures , as proposed by the European Socialists. The Commissioner acknowledged that Europe needs modern insolvency regulation not only for businesses but also for individuals, among other reasons because the situation is different in each Member State, as there are countries, such as Spain, where consumers do not have a legislative framework to turn to when they are in this situation. The European Socialists will continue to work to make the regulation of this common framework a reality as soon as possible.

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: in writing. – Colleagues, everyone deserves a second chance. This is especially true for entrepreneurs. The fear of bankruptcy in the EU must be overcome. I welcome the extension of the scope of the Regulation and believe that focusing on national procedures that provide for restructuring of the company at a pre-insolvency stage and lead to the recovery of businesses, as well as giving entrepreneurs a second chance, are key to having a viable economy in the EU. I believe that requiring Member States to publish information on cross-border insolvencies in a publicly accessible electronic register will improve information on participating creditors and courts and prevent parallel insolvency proceedings from opening. The new regulation will allow to avoid incentives for parties to transfer assets or legal proceedings from one Member State to another in order to obtain a more favourable legal position to the detriment of insolvency creditors. It will provide more clarity in the provisions on jurisdiction to open insolvency proceedings, on the recognition and enforcement of judgments in such proceedings, on applicable law, and on the coordination of insolvency proceedings. Only in this way will cross-border insolvency proceedings act efficiently and effectively and help realise one of our top priorities – promoting growth in Europe.

name: n/a
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question on maternity leave, addressed to the Council and the Commission by Arena Maria and Iratxe García Pérez, on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality ( HYPERLINK "http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?type=OQ&reference=O-2015-000049&language=RO" O-000049/2015– B8-0119/2015, HYPERLINK "http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?type=OQ&reference=O-2015-000050&language=RO" O-000050/2015 - B8-0120/2015)).

name: Maria Arena
text: Author. Mr President, the last debate we had in this Chamber on maternity leave was last July. Almost a year has passed and what has happened since then? You could say, "not much." Finally if, however, a little: Frans Timmermans plans to withdraw the directive "maternity leave" and put it in REFIT; The Council is deaf to the community; and we, at Parliament level, when we are not obliged to do so, but we are committed to it, we are building bridges to the Council, unfortunately without any success. So, once again, I here publicly denounce the Passivity of the Council, but also the precedent that this represents: two institutions are speaking, but the Council does not deign to give its position, even if it is far from the other two. It's unacceptable. This is of course unacceptable on an inter-institutional level and it is disrespectful to the other two European institutions that we represent here this evening, but it is also unacceptable, above all, for the millions of mothers and children who are thus deprived of social justice. Where is the Triple A Commission announced by Mr Juncker? It is not by throwing the "maternity leave" directive into oblivion or in the trash that we will achieve this objective. In what Europe do we live - I ask the Council - when those who give life are penalised by the simple fact that they become mothers? What Kind of Europe do we live in if married is synonymous with poverty? The resolution that we will put to a vote tomorrow aims to make this Europe, through women but also mothers, a true Europe of triple A on the social level. Let's not wait any longer! Since 1992, the date of the first maternity leave directive, things have not progressed. 1992! Today is 2015! We were saying this morning that if Europe has to wait 20 years to pass laws, the situation will soon be difficult, especially when it comes to social laws. What we are saying to Parliament, the Council and the Commission is that these women can no longer wait. These women must be able to balance their private and professional lives. These women should not choose between motherhood and careers. These women must be able to take responsibility as women, as workers and as mothers. These women should no longer be the victims of wage or pension gaps in relation to men, they should no longer be the victims at all, simply because they are mothers, because they "risk" - and that is the word we hear today - to be mothers one day. Imagine! In Europe today, being a mother is a "risk"! A risk to the employer, to politicians and to society. What kind of society do we live in? We can no longer bear it and we clearly ask again in this resolution that all this disappears, that these women be protected, that these mothers have maternity leave, that they can be paid with dignity so as not to fall into poverty, that they can reconcile their private and professional lives, that they can, finally, be all they are. , that is, women, mothers and workers, and that they occupy their place in our society with dignity. Commissioner, I know that, on this subject, you are committed. I am counting on you so that this debate does not wait another ten years, so that we can give this opportunity to these European mothers. I am counting on you and it is on the Council, of course. But I must confess that, since it has been said, I have been tired of repeating to the Council what we are currently asking for. So let's do this duet with the Commission. Let us try to find the solution so that, as soon as possible, these women are respected.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for this opportunity to address the state of play as regards the Commission’s proposal to revise the Maternity Leave Directive. During the past few months, the Presidency has met with Parliament’s representatives on several occasions to discuss this subject. As you know, the Commission has expressed its intention to withdraw the proposal if there is no tangible progress on unblocking the negotiations by the summer. I shall be very honest with you: the proposal as it stands clearly does not enjoy support in the Council. The Council’s position does not leave any room for further manoeuvre. We must also be realistic about the fact that Parliament’s position on, and expectations from, the proposal are fundamentally different from the Council’s. We respect that stance. However, we must face the fact that the current state of affairs will not allow us to progress on the issue. Allow me to stress one thing: the Council’s position was not arrived at easily. It is the result of profound and complex reflection. Tremendous effort and good will was invested by the previous Presidencies. The Presidency cannot act on its own: it is bound by the will of the Member States, just as the Parliament is bound by the will of its Members. Despite the difficulties that have surrounded this issue, I believe that the Council and Parliament remain united in their commitment to advancing the well—being of Europe’s women – and of working mothers in particular. The Council has repeatedly stressed the importance of supporting women and men in the struggle to reconcile work, family and private life. Promoting women’s full participation in the labour market is not only a matter of equality but also an important factor contributing to overall economic growth. With that overall objective in mind, after seven years of efforts that have not brought us to an agreement, we would very much welcome a fresh start on this subject. A new initiative would provide a better basis for the Council and Parliament to work jointly towards improving the reconciliation of work and family life, for both women and men. This should, of course, include the protection of pregnant and breastfeeding women. I hope that Parliament will be able to share the Council’s view on the need to take a more comprehensive and forward-looking approach. Thank you for your attention.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM) for their engagement and especially for their efforts in relation to the Commission’s proposal to revise the Maternity Leave Directive. In particular I would like to pay tribute to the rapporteur, Mrs Arena, and to the Chair of the FEMM Committee, Mrs García Pérez, and to their efforts to find a way out of the stalemate. The Commission is strongly committed to gender equality and the protection of pregnant women and new mothers. The Commission recognises the need for women and men to be able to balance working life so they can combine it with their family life. The Commission has stressed on many occasions its readiness to facilitate negotiations between Parliament and the Council. We have engaged in continuous efforts to break the deadlock. My services have worked closely with previous and current Presidencies and with this House to try to find a realistic solution acceptable to both sides. Thanks to Mrs Arena, we recently had the opportunity to explore new possibilities for compromise, particularly on the question of pay, which we know was difficult for Member States in times of economic crisis.  The Commission has facilitated informal talks between Parliament and the Council, requested a discussion in the Council and has advocated concrete discussions on the basis of the rapporteur’s proposals in order to move towards an agreement. We have insisted that the Presidency bring this back for discussion in the Council on the basis of the rapporteur’s proposals in order to unblock the negotiations and try to move towards an agreement.  When the file came back to the Council at political level recently, the Commission recalled Parliament’s position and readiness to engage. Unfortunately, a solid group of Member States remains opposed to any further negotiations on this file. Many of them agree that there is a strong case for action in this field, but they are not convinced that this proposal, preparations for which started almost 10 years ago, will solve the issues faced by working parents in 2015 and beyond. Overall, there is a majority in favour of a fresh start in the Council. I remain open to continued discussion with the co-legislators, but as things stand now the Commission sees no reason to depart from its intention, as announced in the work programme, to withdraw the proposal and replace it with a new initiative if no agreement can be found within six months. A fresh start now appears likely to be the best way forward. Society and the labour market have undergone significant changes in the recent period. The Commission is committed to improving the situation of working parents in the EU. I am therefore open to start looking into a new approach to tackle the challenges faced by them. We know that it is mainly women who are hit by what the economists call ‘the motherhood penalty’. They see their potential, and even their ability to participate in the labour market, fall when they become parents.  The gender pay gap, which is almost non-existent before child-bearing age, remains, still, at 16% and the gender pension gap stands at 39%. At the same time, we know that Europe faces a demographic time bomb that risks becoming a serious economic and social problem, as well as a fiscal problem for the EU, and as the economy starts to pick up, Europe needs to make best use of all our talents to compete in the global marketplace.  Women are more highly qualified than ever before, more highly qualified on average than men. We cannot afford to continue to neglect this talent pool at a time of shrinking populations and growing worldwide competition. Women and men have to be able to balance working life so that they can have the family they want. They need to have a choice.  Men should also be encouraged to live up to their family responsibilities. Many men would like to spend more time with their children but face difficult circumstances in the workplace. Creating conditions that allow a proper work-life balance will help families, businesses and our societies as a whole and will promote more gender equality at all levels.  The challenges for working parents start with the arrival of a new baby, but they do not end there. Parents also need a certain level of flexibility throughout the childhood and teenage years. There needs to be a decent level of childcare and care-services infrastructure in place to give people a meaningful choice, and we must not forget the challenges of caring for elderly or infirm dependants faced by today’s sandwich generation. But all this needs to be done in a smart way so that this does not suffer the same fate as the previous, or still current, proposal.  That is why I intend to look, together with my colleagues Vice-Presidents Timmermans and Dombrovskis, as well as with Commissioner Thyssen, more broadly at the EU regulatory and policy framework and how it can be improved, given the real needs of parents and businesses in our changing world, and to propose up-to-date solutions to meet these needs. The Commission will stay in close contact with Parliament in order to reflect together all aspects that should be taken into account.  We will also carry out a public consultation and will consult the social partners in accordance with their specific role in the field of social policy as laid down in the Treaty. We will consider the full range of possible actions, both legislative and non-legislative measures, in order to have the most effective impact. I look forward to hearing Members’ views and I count on their support.

name: Anna Záborská
text: for the PPE Group. – Today, we are not talking about the maternity leave directive, but about a document that addresses health and job protection for pregnant and breastfeeding women. Today, Member States must give women 14 weeks off, with 2 weeks mandatory. At the same time, the woman remains in her job and must receive a salary or remuneration at least equal to the sickness benefit. This is guaranteed by the 1992 Directive, which still applies today. In 2008, the Commission prepared a proposal for an amendment to this Directive. However, At first reading, Parliament adopted a position on which the European Council refuses to negotiate. The Directive on women's health and safety has made it a tool to promote a kind of European family policy in the interests of gender equality. The Council has been blocked and women have once again fallen victim to political ambitions. I am in favour of extending maternity leave to 18 weeks. Of which 6 weeks are mandatory, because the World Health Organisation is asking for it. I am in favour of a woman who is due to be at home for six weeks to receive a full salary for this period. I am all the more disappointed to see that the proposed resolution, which was supposed to ask the Council to return to the negotiating table, repeats the same mistake. In the text, which was intended to be limited to protecting the health and improving the working conditions of pregnant people, we want to dictate to the Member States how to implement family policy. As shadow rapporteur for the EPP, I must say that if the text of the resolution passes as proposed, my colleagues will abstain. The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – As you were the shadow rapporteur, do you not think that it is time for the Council to engage in dialogue and start negotiations with Parliament on the Maternity Leave Directive, taking responsibility for refusing improvements in the safety and health at work of pregnant workers and workers who have recently given birth or are breastfeeding?

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Colleague, thank you very much for the question. I am in favour of the wording you have said. I am in favour of the Council returning to the negotiations, to start negotiations with the European Parliament and the European Commission on improving the working conditions of pregnant women – pregnant workers – who have given birth and who are breastfeeding. Precisely to stick to the name of the directive put forward by the European Commission.

name: Javi López
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, the Council told us today that it was going to speak frankly. We're going to do it too, and we're going to say what happened here. The Council, and in particular the Presidency on duty, has consciously and deliberately decided, from the first minute, to kill this proposal and this Directive. Parliament has said from the outing point that we wanted to be flexible, to negotiate, that it was an old proposal, that we wanted to talk to the Council. And the Council has not deigned or come to Parliament. That's what's happened in this process. Moreover, it is a directive which we know to be a directive on equality, obviously in the field of gender equality, and which affects the labour market a lot, which affects our demographic challenges and which, of course, should be part of the economic recovery. Worst of all, knowing some of the Council's members, I am not surprised, because the President of my country last week dared to say that women collect fewer pensions because, voluntarily, they do not work to have children. That's what he said. Knowing some of those who sit on the Council, I am not surprised what they are doing.

name: Julie Girling
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, it is no coincidence that the safety and health at work of pregnant workers, those who have recently given birth or are breastfeeding, has become known as the Maternity Leave Directive. This is no mere linguistic convenience. This directive has been hijacked by the issue of 20 weeks’ maternity leave on full pay and paternal paid leave. This has been consistently opposed by a significant minority of Member States, and in my opinion quite rightly. This is opposed on grounds of subsidiarity, and now it is time for the Commission to stick to its word and withdraw it. This whole saga has left the European Parliament looking foolish and this oral question simply emphasises that point. Perhaps if the European Parliament had agreed to the original proposal along the lines of the International Labour Office’s maternal protection recommendation, better conditions for women could have been achieved five years ago. It is the stubbornness of many Members that has led to no progress for over five years, so I encourage the Commission to take this off the table and end this monumental waste of time. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria Arena (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. Madam, the maternity leave directive on the protection of women in the workplace has been in place since 1992. It is a directive on the health of women who are pregnant, lactating and giving birth. The directive, which was proposed by the European Commission, is a revision of the 1992 directive.  Therefore, when you talk about a principle of subsidiarity, I do not understand what you are referring to, since 1992, the Commission has had the power to take that action.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – Presumably the question (if I understood correctly) is about my understanding of the directive. There was no actual question there, but let me say this: it is absolutely clear that this recast proposal has eaten away at Member States’ sovereignty, has eaten away at subsidiarity, and has taken on itself to try to do far more than was, and is, currently sensible for legislation at European level. There is no question in my mind, or indeed in my Group’s mind, that maternity leave is extremely important. There is no question that the rights of women should be upheld. The question is whether this is the right place to do it, and whether this proposal, with its absolute demands and with no flexibility, is the right approach.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner Jourová, Mrs Kalnina, do you remember what you were like and where you were in 1992? I do. I remember very well, because the following year my son was born and changed my life and, since then, the whole world has changed, the whole society has changed, women, the work environment, the economy... Everything has changed and the Europe of the 28 cannot afford a Europe of 12 directive. It is our responsibility and we have to respond to the real needs of citizens with something that solves what affects them and what concerns them. Other countries around us do react and implement initiatives that improve systems, give more protection and more equality. In the meantime, what does Europe do? The European Parliament was able, almost five years ago, to adopt a proposal that was more ambitious and more realistic than the Commission's original proposal. And what happened to the Council? That in these five years he has not said a word, nor has he made a single proposal or counterproposal, nor has he spoken on one or the other. It has been a blockade in every rule which leads us to believe that we are facing infringement of the co-legislator principle referred to in the Treaties.  And we, the European institutions, cannot afford to break the rules we have endowed ourselves with. I ask the Council for responsibility, interinstitutional respect and European sense, and I also ask the Commission, please do not take a passive role, it has to do more than shrug in the face of the Council's blockade. It cannot arbitrarily dismiss a proposal that was put forward precisely because it was necessary. You have to tell us the criteria that are used for the REFIT program. I think I speak for my colleagues if I tell them we're open to negotiation. If there is a new beginning, as you say, Commissioner Jourová, tell us when, because there we will be responding to our mandate from citizens and actually transferring their concerns and proposals.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, this is probably one of those matters that most nakedly lays the nature of the European Union. Let's see, decision on cutting wages and social rights by pressing national budgets, there is no problem here, there is agreement. Let countries be held hostage by the usury of banks and loans, there is no doubt about it either. Sending the boats now to Libya, the military means, it is in a month that everything is decided quickly, they are already underway. Now, protecting and elevating the rights of working women, guaranteeing them a minimum of twenty weeks fully paid, is not asked that much either, here we hope, we hope... There is an uncomfortable silence, but it is a silence that will quickly end an administrative process, indeed, as the Commissioner has just said she would carry out. But this is a political decision, not an administrative decision. The Commission can insist on this if it so chooses. And when the Commissioner says she's ready for a fresh start, a fresh start, what exactly does that mean, a fresh start? Why, if this proposal was non-negotiable for the Council, does a fresh start mean diminishing the rights of working women? It is because this does not seem to us to be a fresh start, that seems to us—but it is a step backwards from the position that the European Parliament has adopted, which you and the European institutions say is the home of democracy. But now it seems that it is not the home of democracy, because when it is no use it is still the home of democracy. It is not we who judge you, it is working mothers and workers who want to be mothers who will judge this policy of double weights and two measures, when to give social rights you can see what you do well.

name: Monika Vana
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the On the part of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to say that we cannot understand the way in which the Council and the Commission are proceeding. For us, the announcement of the withdrawal of the Maternity Directive is not only a slap in the face for mothers and fathers, but above all a blow to social Europe. How can you explain to the citizens outside that you are standing up for their concerns when one of the few concrete proposals for improving social protection in Europe, which has been under negotiation for years now – as you yourself said – is so obviously being derailed by you? We Greens certainly do not want to and will not accept this. I am also thinking of the ignorance of democratic decision-making in this House: it is now four years since this House has clearly spoken out in favour of improvements in maternity protection and also in paternity leave – an essential step, by the way: it is not just about mothers, it is also about fathers and fathers' protection. Here we expect the Council to clearly assume its responsibilities and to continue to negotiate seriously on improving social protection in Europe.

name: Daniela Aiuto
