text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are well aware that one of the European Union's problems is the low rate of birth rate and fertility. There are alarming figures that affect all Member States, and 'old Europe' only manages to have negative growth rates thanks to the contribution of immigration. But it seems that we are not succeeding in putting into practice policies to encourage births and, after years of deadlock, we are moving towards the withdrawal of the directive on maternity leave. By all means we have opposed it and we will oppose this scandal. The Council has never put this issue on the agenda, and recently the Latvian Presidency did not even deign to come and discuss it in the FEMM Committee. It is clear that, on the subject of maternity leave, which is not a holiday, there are also considerable differences between the various Member States to date, and perhaps we should lower the expectations that Parliament has set itself, but it is urgent to bring home a result and give concrete and immediate answers to European women. No more discrimination, which employers are often forced to do, although they do not want to, because of deficient policies, and that is enough with the discrimination between women who can become mothers and afford it and women who, on the other hand, live the period of pregnancy and breastfeeding as an antechamber to their dismissal or the end of expectations for their careers.  We were all in agreement, in the various forums of discussion, on a text which only provided for a unanimous oppose to withdrawal, without requiring a new legislative initiative in advance. I would like to ask the rapporteur, Mrs Arena, but also my colleagues in the other groups, why we are voting on a resolution which, as it stands, actually provides an assist to the Commission in order to find a justification for withdrawing the directive.  Why do you want to ask for a new legislative proposal now, when we already have a basic proposal on which the debate was to be reopened and which, I understand, you want to abandon, taking it for granted? As far as we are concerned, we will support the Greens' amendments and the report in its entirety.  I wonder what the other groups will do and, if so, what the change of course is due to.

name: Vicky Maeijer (NI).
text: – For years, there has been talk of a maternity leave directive. It is not only the Commission that is trying to dictate the law to the Member States, but also the European Parliament is also cheerfully dictating. The debate on the right to 20 weeks, 16 weeks or perhaps 40 weeks of leave should take place in the national parliaments, not in this parliament. This directive is a typical example of unnecessary European interference and interference in national affairs. The Commission promised fewer rules and less interference through akela Timmermans. For the time being, a lot of shouting and little wool.  I call on the Commission to fulfil its promise, to withdraw the proposal and, above all, not to come up with a new proposal. Sovereign states are perfectly capable of setting their own rules that take into account the interests of men, women and children. As far as I am concerned, the resolution that is on the table today can go straight into the trash.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: –  Mr President, the time has come to talk about shared parental leave, not maternity leave. To support working mothers we have to involve fathers in taking responsibility for their babies, not oblige women to stay at home.  That is why I welcome the Commission’s intention to withdraw the proposed Maternity Leave Directive. The way to equality would not be to have only mothers at home. The directive would be a setback, not a way forward for mothers. Women should have the same rights and opportunities as men to achieve work—life balance. To improve equality for women we need to stop considering women as the sole parent responsible for children and encourage both parents to take care of their kids.  ʽWhen and howʼ should not be a decision taken at European level. Why? Because we should respect the fact that we are different. There are major differences in Europe in family policies and we cannot impose a one-size-fits-all solution of, for instance, 18 weeks mandatory leave at European level. Should women be obliged to stay at home when their partners can take leave instead, as is the case in the Nordic countries where they can have 480 days? It is a paradox that the Swedish Left and Greens are now pushing for the Maternity Leave Directive and for a separate Paternity Leave Directive for ten days, clearly discriminating between women and men.  Let us leave this Maternity Leave Directive and move forward instead to push for ending stereotypes and having parental leave.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: – Mr President, some colleagues in this House do not seem to know what we are talking about yet. We are talking about legislation that ensures the protection of the health of working mothers women fully compatible with subsequently developing legislation that advances the reconciliation between family and work life and incorporates paternity leave. On this directive, the European Parliament was placed in 2008. With big differences we were able to agree. This debate today should not be taking place. The directive should already be a reality. The representative of the Council says that Parliament's position is far from the Council's position. But what is the Council's position if they have not been able to say what approaches they are defending? It is disrespectful to the need to promote policies that ensure the health of working women, but also the reconciliation of family and work life. We are talking about women's rights in Europe.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! The deep demographic crisis is affecting Europe, in particular my homeland, Poland. Therefore, decisive action is needed to provide real support for motherhood and the family. It is true that family policy is mainly the responsibility of the Member States, but the European Union can and should support good solutions.  Parliament's proposal to extend maternity leave to 20 weeks is precisely the desired solution – although not because, as in the opinion of the resolution we will vote on tomorrow, it is intended to increase women's professional activity, but because it will help to solve the much more serious problem – of Europe's ageing populations. Without a coherent and comprehensive family policy, we will not respond to the aspirations of young people who want to start a family and have children. We will not stop the demographic crisis and the associated problem of the ageing of our societies. We must invest in the family and appreciate the women who, by raising future citizens and citizens, contribute to the building of a strong society and the common good.  I therefore ask the Council to clarify the reasons for blocking the Maternity Leave Directive for five years, which was, after all, supported at first reading by a large majority of Parliament.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to give you a figure here: in five years alone, cases of maternity bullying in Italy have increased by 30%. In the last two years alone, 800 000 women have been dismissed or forced to resign, precisely because of the choice of motherhood. Now, I find it shameful that the Council has basically not expressed its opinion and that the Commission intends to withdraw its proposal, not because I believe that women are the subject to be protected or protected or that we must protect or protect the family. We must guarantee the right of women in Europe to self-determination. That is the point: to guarantee the right to self-determination. The choice before us today is essentially a non-choice, and we think that the adoption by this House of a text such as the one proposed to us by Mr Beazley is not a choice. Tarabella is a desire not to see, not to see that there is a gender pay gap, that there is very strong discrimination against women in Europe.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the European Union has set out five growth targets by 2020. I will refer to two: the first, to guarantee an employment rate of 75% – which necessarily implies increasing the number of working women ; the second, reduce the number of people at risk of social exclusion— which directly affects women, the main victims of this exclusion.  And we ask the Commission and the Council: how do you plan to achieve these two objectives without a directive that protects women who have been mothers and allows them to make their family and work life compatible?  President Juncker has repeatedly said that austerity is over and that european institutions must be put to work for citizenship. Here's a perfect opportunity to prove you really want to do it. Defend the Maternal and Paternal Leave Directive, defend all European families and defend the work of this Parliament, which has reached a very broad consensus with a proposal for minimums which we cannot reduce. We don't want to waste any more time. We don't need any new proposals. If they block this proposal, they are not meeting their objective and are abandoning European women.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). – One of the most serious problems facing modern societies is under-birth. This problem occurs with particular intensity in those countries whose economy is not in good shape. In Greece, which suffers from the painful and burdensome conditions of the memorandum, the number of deaths was, for the first time in 2013, higher than the number of births. So while in Europe under-birth is a fact, while the countries of Europe are being overwhelmed by a number of illegal immigrants at the risk, in the near future, of becoming minorities in our countries, the Council does not approve the extension of maternity leave to 20 weeks, because there will be economic costs. This is tragic, not only to say it but even to think about it. Motherhood is a very serious matter and we need to look at it with due care and seriousness. We do not have the right, both to the nation and to the state, to deny the continuation of his life in the future. We must support motherhood at all costs. We have no right to deny our descendants either to see the light of life or, if they are born, not to be able to live as free and civilized people.

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this Directive aims to implement measures to improve the health at work of pregnant workers, those who have given birth, and those who are breastfeeding. It is a directive that helps women within society. That is why I do not understand the Council's silence in something affecting so many women who neither want nor should give up their right to have children and be able to maintain their jobs. Children should not be a decline in their rights to worthy pensions and to develop a stable working life.  I know it's not easy to move forward in a working universe where maternity leave varies so much from country to country. But that's our obligation: to work to achieve it. This was the view of this Parliament, which made it clear that it was necessary to review the working conditions of pregnant women. And you know why? Because supporting motherhood and the family means supporting progress and growth for this Europe in which the lack of co-responsibility of parents in carrying family burdens , which for the most part fall on women – and also the uncertainty they feel about their work future means that fewer and fewer children are born. I know that it is our duty to set all the conditions for this trend to change, and I therefore ask the Commission and the Council to join forces with those already made by Parliament, in order to find the best solution to help working women.

name: Anna Hedh (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The principle of non-discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy and maternity leave has a long history in the EU. It was established in 1958. Since the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the recognition of the principle of non-discrimination on grounds of pregnancy and maternity leave was further extended. Nevertheless, discrimination against women is still very present, both in the workplace and at home, which is an incentive for us to have to discuss maternity leave from a broader perspective. Today, the gender pay gap is 16% and the pension gap between men and women is 39%. If we look at the EU27, 19% of all women are at risk of poverty, and 34% of single mothers of working age are in the same risk zone. In addition, women are very over-represented when it comes to temporary and part-time employment. The situation in europe today shifts women into the home to do unpaid work, such as child rearing and caring for relatives. European women need better, law-binding protection against discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy and maternity leave. For me, this is a matter of solidarity with our sisters in Europe who are now facing setbacks when it comes to economic self-determination, release and participation in the labour market because of their possible pregnancy.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR).
text: – The proposal concerning the extension of maternity leave has certainly been tabled and amended with the best of intentions. With a view to creating better conditions for women and children on maternity leave, with the intention of helping women return to the labour market after its completion. However, a long seven years have passed and we have not been able to reach a compromise that is acceptable to all Member States. It's time to admit that you need to start over. However, as part of the next debate on this subject, I would like to stress that the future and satisfaction of European families depend not only on the length of maternity leave. I know from interviews with young families that, in addition to decent maternity leave, they also need enough preschool places, affordable housing and adequate tax benefits. However, whether such policies will be created does not primarily matter to us, but to the governments of the Member States.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I will not repeat the arguments on the irresponsibility and guilt of the Council on this whole issue. But I do want to focus on the Commission's proposal , reaffirmed today by the Commissioner, that they do intend to withdraw this proposal for a Directive. If you withdraw this proposal for a Directive, you will make two very serious mistakes. The first is to throw away the rights of workers, workers, mothers, fathers and their labour rights, and I do not believe that a Commission which seeks to boost social Europe can afford that. If you do, your role as a guarantor institution of social Europe will be called into question. The second mistake is to set a very serious precedent, which is that the Council does not give its opinion and from there you withdraw a proposal. In legislative dynamics, however, that would be a very serious mistake.  That is why I believe that you must, with our support, continue to press the Council to take this directive forward and, of course, if you finally decide to withdraw it, this Parliament must keep the possibility of going to the Court of Justice, because I do not know under what legal capacity you can do that. In any case, it's very, very dubious.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: Mr. President, of course the Council should take responsibility and speak up. The real phenomenon is that it's been this many years, after the first directive, without coming to a consensus.  It is also surprising that the Commission is looking for a fresh start. What could a new proposal or a new directive bring - I don't think there's anything new to add without continuing negotiations on the current proposal. However, we know that social and family policy is mainly the responsibility of member states. It depends a lot on the economic situation of the Member State on how it will resolve the issue. However, it seems to me, when I looked at this statistic, that the worse the state stands economically, the better the social rights. In Croatia, from which I come, women are entitled to 26 weeks of maternity leave with full pay and for the next 6 months with a fixed, lower salary, and men can decide whether they will take on the role of maternity leave. Therefore, I think that Member States really need to speak out in the Council, but if they are not already able then at least with the new directive to support the views of the Member States.  (Speaker agreed to answer the question "blue card" (Article 162(8) of the E.S. regulation)).

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mrs. Šuica, first of all I thank you for accepting the blue card. You mentioned Croatia and I'm glad because I wanted to talk about how we have good examples in our European Union and means that Croatia can set a good example. I ask you if you agree with me that it is almost unbelievable that some member states that are certainly far richer than Croatia are blocking further access and further solving this very important problem for all of us who sit here late at night, because we want this very difficult situation to finally be resolved when it comes to the rights of women and mothers?

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. Jakovčić, you are on the threshold of what I was talking about that the inversely proportional situation is related to the growth and economic strength of society in relation to the social policy we have in Croatia.  That is why I think the Council needs to think and answer this question, and the Commission also cannot ask for a fresh start, as this needs to continue. Discrimination against women is out of the question; today is about equality, about equality in the labour market and we must have the strength to adopt a common compromise and conceptual proposal that will allow women to be equal in today's free European society.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I want to return to the behaviour of the Council, which has been quite appalling in this instance. It has been over five years, as previous speakers have said, since this directive went through the European Parliament. We, and a majority of the House, passed this, and the Council has quite simply ignored it; they have blocked it. There has been a very significant minority that has blocked the directive. One has to ask oneself why? Why has this been going on? Why have there been enough Member States to delay this for five years? The only conclusion one can sensibly come to is that there are members of the Council – Member States – who do not want this legislation, who do not want gender equality and who do not want to see pregnant women protected at work. This is not only unacceptable, as a point of view, it is actually very short-sighted, because the directive would allow women to enter the labour market, would boost our economic performance and would be very beneficial indeed for the whole of the European Union.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which We are talking today about maternity protection and what the EU could do if the Council were to play along, which it does not do. But nevertheless, in principle: it is good, or better, completely self-evident that expectant mothers who have to go to work must be protected. Of course they have to! However, I reject the Commission's approach for two reasons. Firstly, the directive only ever sees the mother-to-be as one worker. The EU always regards pregnancy only as a problem for the labour market. This is a deeply Marxist approach: motherhood as something detrimental to the retrieval of female work. But motherhood is not a burden for the economy, but an opportunity – an opportunity for children, for family, for society, and so ultimately for the economy. In short, motherhood makes business possible. But secondly, the EU does not have competence for children and the family, it has no competence to regulate this. Only the Member States themselves can do this. I wish they did.

name: Lara Comi (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, first of all, this is a fundamental issue: we are talking about safety, about women's health at work at a crucial time, when they generate life and bring children into the world. Secondly, the current European context is characterised by a falling birth rate, as my colleagues have already mentioned earlier. Faced with this, the European legislator should legislate quickly, quickly, and instead we have been witnessing for years an incomprehensible blocking of negotiations, a block that always and constantly comes from the Council. The interests involved are different and a fair balance must be struck. European legislation must be adopted in full respect of the principle of subsidiarity, the different national cultural traditions must also be taken into account, but what must not be tolerable, is not tolerable, is a stagnation that goes on without a perspective. We cannot stop at this only on personal interests and not on women's and human rights.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like, first of all, to thank our rapporteur, Maria Arena, for her tenacity on an issue which, regrettably, is not sufficiently taken into account today in terms of the issue of rights for all women in Europe. Many have stressed the urgent need for a European framework on maternity leave to end the overt discrimination in this area. Why is the Council so unsealed of our repeated calls for constructive dialogue? Why has the Latvian Presidency remained deaf to the repeated requests of our rapporteur to discuss this issue?  I believe that the Council has completely breached its duty as co-legislator. Let him take full responsibility for his position rather than wait for the Commission to send this text to oblivion, and to be responsible to the citizens of Europe.  On another register, to those who oppose us on this issue, as many others, the question of the costs of this measure, I mean that we must never underestimate the costs of a non-measure. How much in social budgets does the burden of pathological leave taken by women who see only this possibility to extend too short maternity leave? I'd like to know your answers.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE).
text: Mr President, I think it is absolutely essential to have a European text that protects women in the workplace, including in the maternity dimension. It is at all about our logic of worker mobility, social protection and equality of citizens. Excuse me, but in 2008 we knew we were falling into a rut when the vote took place in Parliament. Therefore, I believe that our responsibility to all is committed: that of Parliament, that of the Council and that of the Commission. What do we really want? Tonight, I have not heard unanimity and convergence on our will. Today, in my opinion, we must turn the page and get back on a good footing because it is not with a discussion like tonight that we are able to build real European legislation that finally protects women in the workplace. Yes, women have excellent training. Yes, they have a right to work. Yes, they were victims of the crisis. We must therefore, by a new text, take them out of this rut completely. It's our responsibility. You must not hide behind your little finger and blame others.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I too think it is very good to modernise family policy and also to promote the participation of fathers. However, maternity protection is occupational health and safety! And it is all about the protection of mothers and children, before and after birth. For me, simply removing an unwelcome proposal from the European Parliament in this way is a threat to mothers and children and a disadvantage for women in society and in the labour market. The minimum maternity protection standards of the International Labour Organisation must also apply to Europe.  We need a common high level of protection for all women in Europe and also social protection. With improved maternity protection, Europe can send a clear signal for social and labour law progress.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE).
text: – Qed inħarsu lejn din id-Direttiva purament f ́termini li se tagħti lin-nisa aktar ġimgħat ta'maternity leave qisu xi rigal. Dan l-aspett ħafna drabi jnessina r-realtajiet so大joekonomiikei u l-prin大ipji tal-Membri Stati u anka tal-Unjoni.  Ma nistgħux nitkellmu fuq din id-Direttiva u ninsew is-segwenti: Data demografika turi bi大-ikear li l-popolazzjoni Ewropea hija waħda anzjana u li r-rata tat-twelid hija baxxa.   Hemm diffikultajiet biex nattiraw nisa fl-impjieg jew li nżommuhom fl-impjieg meta jsiru ta' childbearing age.   Kontinwament ngħidu li nemmnu li n-nisa huma sieħba so大jali ugwali u kontributuri fid-dinja politika, so大jali u ekonomika.  Niddikjaraw li lkoll favur l-ugwaljanza bejn is-sessi.  Niddikjaraw li rridu kundizzjonijiet tajbin ta ́xogħol inkluż li jkunu jistgħu jgawdu bilan大 bejn il-ħajja u x-xogħol. Imbagħad i nistgħux naqblu fuq politika pubblika sabiex tindirizza dawn ir-realtajiet. Vera li l-proposta tal-Kummissjoni biex tirtira dan id-dossier i ddoqqx ħelu, anka fid-dawl tad-deadlock fil-kunsll. Però i nistgħux nieqfu hemm u ninsew il-prin大ipji. Hemm bżonn proposti ta ́miżuri oħra bl-istess għan, biex ngħid hedge minflokk ngħaddu mill-bieb ngħaddu mit-tieqa.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: – We all know that the first weeks after the birth of a child are crucial. In those early weeks it is determined to what extent the father can help in the household and whether the mother can return to work full-time. Well-arranged maternity leave determines the life of both the father, mother and child, and therefore also determines our ageing economy and the competitiveness of the future. It is therefore very disappointing to see that the Council sees pregnant women as a mere cost and that the Commission simply wants to withdraw the proposal without taking into account the ruling of the European Court. We in Parliament have been flexible and have shown a willingness to reach a common position in good consultation. That is why we are asking the Council and the Commission to respond to this. Unilateral withdrawal is not a credible option in this case. Europe, as the founder of the principle of equal pay for equal work, must really give women the opportunity to catch up.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a Europe that really wants to grow is a Europe that supports an idea of development capable of promoting rights and dignity, fair access and equal opportunities. Freeing and putting women's human capital to good use means, precisely, building truly conciliatory policies and sharing parental and care responsibilities.  The issue of maternity and also paternity leave crosses the challenge of growth and development through a new culture of work and its quality, which does not exclude anyone from the challenge before us and which is that of promoting a just Europe that also sees women as protagonists. The council's delaying attitude on the issue of maternity leave is unacceptable, not least because it is supported by reasons which I consider to be absolutely spurious. I therefore share, and therefore endorse, the commitment and considerations in support of the resumption of dialogue. We must do it quickly and we must also do well.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am lucky enough to come from the Czech Republic, from a country that has one of the longest maternity leave, it is 28 weeks and it gives mothers 70% of their previous salary. However, I know that this is different in the European Union, which is why I agree with the ambition to have a common minimum standard. Also because we have a common European area open to the movement of people and services, and the need for comparable conditions is also linked to this. In any case, good care for mothers and support for families with children is in the interest of the Member States and of the European Union as a whole. It's our joint investment in the future. I want the new measures of the European Commission to really support mothers in their parental and professional roles, and I wish the Commissioner to fulfil these ambitions.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we talk so much about fairness, rights, gender equality, sexual and reproductive rights, but the political weight of this institution does not seem to be strong enough to ensure that women reconcile family and working life. I want to thank Maria Arena for her tenacity and determination.  It seems that not everyone in Europe agrees to guarantee mothers a period of paid leave before and after pregnancy. But what more do we ask of women? To wait until the Heads of State or Government, mostly men, graciously grant them the right to look after their children, without losing their jobs or their wages? In short, is it not European law to be a mother?  Unacceptable, and I would add incredible, is the stalemate in the directive on parental leave, which testifies to the very serious lack of political will to look after working mothers. In the event of failure, Mr Juncker has announced that the Commission will present a more modern initiative. The terms are unknown and we are all looking forward to meeting them. In the meantime, women's problems and difficulties are the same as ever.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, there is more bilingualism in the European Union. The troika in Greece, with the participation of the Commission, during the Memorandum imposed a reduction in wages, the abolition of social rights and the dissolution of industrial relations. Now, because the Council disagrees, the Commission and Mr Timmermans are withdrawing the legislation on the harmonisation of maternity leave in the European Union. Thus, in the name of the so-called 'improvement' of legislation, the Commission throws maternity leave in the bin. But women, like young people, are the big victims of the crisis. Without protection for women who become mothers, there can be no equal opportunities for women at work. At the same time, the withdrawal of the directive will intensify the under-birth crisis in Europe and especially in the memorandum countries. In impoverished Greece, births fell by 6.21% in 2013, while, according to a report by Doctors of the World in Greece, 4 out of 10 women will give birth to a child less than planned. At the same time, the troika sees children as a presumption that increases the tax burden on the family.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the Council must unblock the revision of the Maternity Leave Directive and should reflect on what it usually contributes to the construction of Europe. I understand their difficult role, but this and other basic issues should encourage them to have another attitude, which we need if we really believe in the European Union. It is an anachronism that the Council continues to function as a club of friends, more concerned with maintaining outdated power structures than looking for reality: listening to people and solving problems. With this way of acting, many problems like this remain unanswered. It is not a problem of women and mothers: we need this proposal to deal with our demographic decline. This blockade opposes equality and harms fundamental rights, devalues the European social model and significantly reduces our competitiveness. In short, it puts a better future at risk for all. Has the Council ever wondered how much inequality costs us? The only thing he proposes and tells us today is that expectations are different. What are the Council's expectations? I'd like to hear them.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). – The overall EU general work policy and the rejection of the Maternity Leave Directive by the governments and institutions of the European Union demonstrate their barbarity as they even sacrifice it to reduce labour costs. This is the so-called reconciliation of work and family life! This reinforces employer terrorism by firing women due to maternity before, during, and after pregnancy. All this will mean a setback, even in Member States where there is more leave, such as Greece, which has already abolished the childbirth allowance. Working women in young couples have nothing to expect from negotiations and promises. Now organize the fight in every country for effective protection of motherhood, women's health in the workplace, steady work with rights, restoration of benefits, prohibition of redundancies and maternity leave commensurate with the needs of mother and child, exclusively public and free health and social services for the popular family.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Dear Mr President, despite numerous calls from the European Parliament in recent months to open negotiations with the Council on the Maternity Leave Directive, we are once again at a dead end today. It is high time that the Council and the Member States took responsibility for the apparent refusal to improve the situation of women who give birth and go on maternity leave in Europe. I believe that this is the time for the Commission to play its role as balancer and help to reach a compromise between the positions of the co-legislators. Do you consider it normal that European Union legislation in this area has not changed in the last 20 years? Does it meet the social progress of our societies and can we afford to sacrifice European social standards for the sake of better administrative governance? The Council's position not only compromises the safety and health of pregnant women and mothers. The withdrawal of the Directive must be seen in the context of an ageing population in Europe. The demographic crisis brings to the fore the need to stimulate the birth rate, which will also be ignored if we delay the adoption of this text indefinitely.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Mr President, Mrs Arena, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. All contributions except for the contribution from the Czech Republic were and are a slap in the face to every mother, some fathers – a naughty thing! What is work? In nurseries, kindergartens and children's homes, people are paid for services that mothers usually provide free of charge. Maternity leave, that is not leave. This is to be paid for, as elsewhere. An educational salary, a parental wage. This would create real freedom of choice. A new beginning – the Council and the Commission, you have the courage to make a real new start! Parental leave is working time, this is not a holiday. An educational salary is money that remains in the region. I stand for a European family strategy. Employers should not experience parental leave as a loss. It is certainly a matter for the European Parliament. Because if parents get a salary, it is employment, and then it belongs to the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Mothers - parents - are our most important workforce in our demographics.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I thank you very much for the discussion that has now taken place here, because for me it is a source of very strong inspiration, but also of what is called encouragement in English and for which I do not have a very good word in Czech. I have thought a lot about what you have said when you spoke about women's rights legislation. I ask: Is having children a woman's hobby? Is it a luxury that women dare to either have or not have? Is having children something that women need, or does society need it? How is it possible that women work so much time in their lives and not only during childcare, but throughout their lives work for free? And is it the job they need, or is it the job society needs?  I believe that we need to find a new paradigm for the new beginning that I have committed to come up with, that looking at this area only from the position of women's rights is just that. I think and feel it on myself when I promote and promote gender equality policy, that the arguments that speak of fair equality, about non-discrimination, about women's rights, those arguments seem to fall under the table, because they are just gender issues. And I think that is also something on which the Maternity Leave Directive is failing and on which it has been failing for several years. Because for so many years, the directive has not been implemented and approved. We all know that one of the reasons we are talking about this today in relation to withdrawal is precisely the length of the blockage. Why don't the arguments of fairness and non-discrimination drag, and rather, as it seems to me, pull economic arguments? That's a question perhaps rather philosophical, but I'm prepared to use those arguments. Someone here said it was a Marxist argument. I don't know, but for me, it's a cynical argument that we need women to give birth to taxpayers. But that's right! It's a cynical, unfair argument, but it pulls, it has its power when we work with that argument. But the other economic argument is this: women are too burdened, and by having this burden, they are already holding back the European economy, they cannot get involved so much, they cannot contribute to growth, they cannot get involved in work. That is why, in fact, the situation we are in today is a drag on the European economy. Let us please use all possible arguments, including these economic ones, but with a strong awareness that those arguments that emphasize fairness and equality are and should be stronger. Now to the directive itself. Of course, we have two options, and we still do, to push the directive that has been here since 2008, a directive that – and I dare to quote Mrs Aren now – "solves at least something and before something new". I agree with this, if we were to enforce this directive, at least we have something that will bring better protection for female mothers. And perhaps ultimately better social recognition, even if it is perhaps a little strong, to want this from the directive. In any case, as Commissioner, it might be easier for me to try to persuade a part of the Member States, even if there is a real large majority, to change their position. I was really trying to get this directive to the Council meeting and reverse the blocking, but not because it is easier for me, but because, in line with Mrs Aren and many others, I wanted to have 'at least something'. The other option is to come up with something new. I would like to say something about the directive before I start talking about something new that many say we don't know what it will be. I had the impact of the Maternity Leave Directive on growth and employment analysed immediately after coming to the Commission, and I found that the legislation thus built did not have the direct, strong impact. This, in turn, is rather a purely economic statement. Secondly, I must say that since 2008 a number of Member States have already adopted legislation that brings enhanced protection for women, and this, too, may have been one of the reasons why the Directive may have been blocked in the Council – but I do not want to speak for the Council and, frankly, I am glad that I do not have to speak for the Council here today. What's going to be the "new"? It's a very complex mathematics. I have ambition, and that is why we are planning to withdraw the directive, to bring something that is stronger, more ambitious in two things. We will try to address the reconciliation of private and working life throughout our lives, not just motherhood, and we want to draw men into family care and shared care. In other words, so that even men can afford the luxury, now take it a little with exaggeration, stay at home and join the care of family members. Meanwhile, women are affording themselves that luxury, and the result is an increasingly open-cutchirk in economic status and women's poverty in Europe. So it is a complex mathematics, when we talk about reconciling private and working life, we are not only intervening in the area of non-discrimination, but we are also intervening in labour and family law, we are also facing very diverse attitudes in the Member States, which are rooted in cultural traditions and the different positions of women in the Member States, which are really deeply rooted. I myself come from a country where the view that when a woman goes to work too early from a child, she's a bad mother, and that's judgmental. I think in some other countries it is quite the opposite. So we are also treating such complex diversity within Europe, and last but not least, we need to do a very good legal analysis of the competences that the European Commission has. Because, as has been said many times in plenary, these are shared competences where we do not wish to go beyond and violate the principle of subsidiarity.  So when did the question come up, when are we going to come up with the proposal? We are working on a new proposal by analysing the situation, drawing on fresh data and working on this with my colleague Marianne Thyssen, who is in charge of employment issues, and, of course, we will also be working with First Vice-President Timmermans and Vice-President Dombrovskis, because the issue is clearly also about work and social dialogue. So I do not want to log on to specific data here, but I can see realistically that in the second half of this year we could have an initial proposal that would go into evaluating the impact of legislation on the so-called impact assesment.  Thank you for the patience with which you have listened to this long exposé of mine, but I felt it necessary to comment further on this and I look forward to working with you. I feel a strong motivation here to deal with this matter, and I think we all understand that such new legislation is really intended to bring about social change, not just what we here consider important, and that is to improve conditions for European mothers. Because we need rules not just for mothers, but for Europe, for its growth. Thank you for your attention.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, a lot of criticism has been levelled at the Council during the debate tonight; I shall disagree. For more than seven years, we have been trying to find support for this file, and the lack of support for the current legislative proposal by the Commission should not be interpreted as a lack of will to protect the rights of working parents.  Actually, as a representative of a Member State offering a generous system of paid parental leave where the parents can choose who will take care of the child – the mother or the father – and the rights to stay home are for 18 months, I can assure you of our strong commitment to the fundamental principle.  What is at the heart of the problem is a lack of support for the very concrete legislative proposal. So let us not overdramatise the situation. We welcome the Commissionʼs intention to come up with a better proposal that would be more realistic and more modern. I would like to use this opportunity to thank Ms Corazza Bildt and Ms Morin-Chartier for their comments and position in wanting to have a modern parental leave system and to avoid pointing fingers, which will not help to find a solution. Actually, the Council understands very well the importance of parental leave provisions for Europeʼs families, and maternity leave should not be seen in isolation. Other helpful measures can include, for example, accessible care services with flexible working hours, paternity leave and so on, as well as a more equal sharing of care responsibilities between women and men. Flexible working arrangements and a reconciliation-friendly culture are also relevant in our modern societies. There are plenty of ideas to be inspired by.  To make a child needs a woman and a man, so why do we speak only of maternity leave in the context of childbirth? I am worried by the rhetoric used in the context of this debate. Men must have an equal right to participate in the upbringing of children. So I would like to use this opportunity to invite Madam Commissioner, when working on the new proposal, to prepare a good modern one where both parents can share responsibility and can use the opportunity to take care of the child. I think that could be of real use in the European Union. The Council is a co-legislator whose opinion on the current proposal is clear. Hence, we have to make a choice: we can continue to disagree on the existing legislative proposal for another five years or we can try to find an agreement on the basis of a new proposal. The Council has made its choice. We are looking forward to having an agreement in the foreseeable future. I believe all parties concerned can and will contribute to positive developments in this important policy area.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The debate is closed. I have received a motion for a resolution, in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure, to conclude this debate.* The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 20 May. * See Minutes. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – Although it has been almost five years since the European Parliament adopted its position on the revision of the Maternity Leave Directive, the Council has in no way been able to reconcile its official position between Member States and this directive of mutual interest has come to an end. Today, it has certainly not been accepted that some Member States are not only delaying the adoption of a directive that aims to facilitate the adoption of a directive aimed at facilitating the raising of children by mothers and fathers, but also offer those better opportunities to be abolished. It is also unacceptable that the Commission may not support the proposal to revise the Directive through the Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme (REFIT). If this is ultimately the case, we in the European Parliament call on the Luxembourg Presidency to take immediate further action, namely the launch of a legislative initiative to revise Council Directive 92/85/EEC in order to improve the safety and health of pregnant workers and workers who have recently given birth or are breastfeeding, thereby addressing demographic problems while reducing gender inequalities. This directive is very important precisely now that Europe's demographic situation is very poor, with birth rates falling every year in almost all Member States and our population is growing very rapidly. The proposal to repeal the directive is not a compromise, but an attempt to avoid important decisions. What signal will we send today to people, young families in Europe, who are waiting for new developments?

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. – I call on the European Commission not to withdraw the proposal to revise the Maternity Leave Directive and thus deprive millions of women of their rights. We need European legislation that protects women and respects their rights. The Maternity Leave Directive aims to set better standards for all pregnant women in the European Union and to extend maternity leave to 20 paid weeks, and the withdrawal of the proposal is a direct attack on the values that the European Union is promoting. I call on the Council, Parliament and the Commission to work together to unblock the situation on the directive whereby all women in Europe will have equal rights. It is time for the European Commission to put an end to this deadlock, which has been going on for too long.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The case of the Maternity Directive leaves the state of this European Union and what its people can expect. An instrument and vehicle for imposing deep social setbacks – wage cuts, attacks on the state's social functions in health, education and social security, reduction of social and labor rights, privatizations, etc. – is, at the same time, a buffer to any small measure, which is small, which is to improve living conditions; a modest advance, that is, towards social progress. The Council, which so readily understands the setback, does not agree to increase the protection of working mothers and their children by guaranteeing them a minimum of 20 weeks fully paid for maternity leave. And in the face of this, the European Commission (said to be the bearer of a new progressive impulse) decides to send its proposal into the bin and disguises the decision – deeply political – by dealing it with a mere administrative act.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. Combating all forms of social discrimination: between the commitments and constituent values of the European Union, the principle of equal treatment, capable of disregarding sexual, religious, political, cultural or ideological identities, is undoubtedly one of the fundamental values of our pro-European feeling.  But the data do not always comfort us with regard to the objectives of social and labour policies that Europe is trying to guarantee. This is therefore the huge gap that we still find between the economic treatment of women's and men's employment, partial or precarious temporary contracts for women and stable for men, and the consequent treatment of women's pensions, which even reaches peaks of 39% less than that of men.  All the necessary action must be taken immediately to ensure that discrimination is definitively overcome by allowing men and women equal access to the world of work, equal economic treatment and equal conditions, and not last but not last, the possibility of reconciling private and professional life by guaranteeing adequate maternity leave, which would also mean the drive to enlarge families and have more children. , ensuring mothers and families have a future with less uncertainty.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Legislation guaranteeing a better reconciliation of family and professional life is extremely important, especially in view of the ageing of our continent and the low growth in most European countries. I regret that the Council has blocked the Maternity Leave Directive. Member States should now return to the negotiating table as soon as possible. The Commission, on the other hand, should make every effort to break this deadlock and find a compromise between the position of Parliament and the Council. In Poland, the rules on the length of maternity leave and the remuneration during maternity leave are more favourable to mothers and fathers than those proposed in the Directive. I hope that the EP resolution will encourage the governments of other Member States to adopt similar measures. Young people in Europe want to start families, but most of them do not currently have the conditions to do so. Our role as MEPs is to legied a law that encourages young people to start a family.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The proposal to revise the Maternity Leave Directive has been the subject of discussions since 2010 and has reached a dead end in the negotiation process. The impact assessment of the proposal states that extending motherhood and strengthening the rights of women returning from maternity will contribute to ensuring equality between women and men in terms of labour market opportunities and balancing work and family life. I think the proposed amendments would be a small step towards equality, given that working women continue to receive lower pay and pensions. I also believe that we cannot afford to seek to lower the administrative burden at the expense of social justice. We cannot afford to make European women choose between work and children, especially against the backdrop of an ageing Europe. I therefore hope that the Maternity Leave Directive will be amended in line with the standards established by the UN International Labour Organisation.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE)
text: Written. – Like so many colleagues today, I appeal for a negotiated solution to the Maternity Leave Directive. This is an important directive that would improve the minimum duration of maternity leave and the level of compensation in the EU. The directive would be a minimum harmonization and would not prevent Member States from providing for a better level of maternity leave. In addition, the directive is important for the internal market. It would create more equal conditions of competition for European industry. An increase of 1% in women's employment rates is enough to cover the costs of the directive. The birth rate is highest in those European countries where good family leave and childcare facilities equalised the burden on children. In the same countries, women have the highest employment rate. In high-income countries, higher birth rates improve economic growth. The proposal for a directive requires maternity leave to be counted as a period of employment when calculating pensions. Thus, the directive would narrow the gap between the income development of women and men.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Writing. The Commission must finally withdraw the so-called maternity directive, thereby making its announcement to ensure the efficiency and efficiency of European legislation followed by action. The attempt to standardise maternity protection rules throughout Europe has failed. Apart from the fact that family law issues are still better resolved in the hands of the Member States, we are not creating fair harmonisation at EU level simply because of the 28 different social security systems. However, the debate is not about maternity protection or against maternity protection, as the Greens and Socialists like to see. There will already be minimum standards at European level – and that is a good thing. I think that further harmonisation is the wrong way to go. Alignment and unification must not always be the last resort of wisdom. As a result, we are only deprived of design possibilities – social, economic and family policy options. We do not have to pack everything into a European corset.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. "I speak now as a father of four. I am convinced that it would be irresponsible to simply abandon the maternity leave directive. The 20 weeks previously proposed by Parliament, I think, are absolutely realistic for the child, the mother, the family, the workplace and society. This is the most important minimum time in the life of the infant, which he must spend with the mother, in which the family with the new member is connected to each other. However, it is not such a long time that the mother's relegation from the labour market would indeed have radical consequences. Moreover, there is the possibility for women to take only the mandatory six weeks of maternity leave if this time is considered too much individually. If someone were to choose this solution, we could help him with a system where, because of his decision, he could use the amount of the childcare allowance remaining in the state cot for the costs of the nursery or the childminder. Parliament must protect this directive from falling victim to the Commission's efforts to make it more regulatory.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I would like to stress here the importance of facilitating work-life balance, especially for pregnant women and young mothers. And let's add the urgency. That is why the announcement by the European Commission of the directive on the extension of maternity leave is regrettable. This protection measure was approved by the European Parliament in 2010 and is now being undermined by the executive. This decision is no more or less a regression. The discussion must be quickly restarted by giving new impetus to the inter-institutional dialogue. It is this renewed dialogue that I call for. It is necessary to update the positions and to bring them together so that they respond as best as possible to the realities of the different Member States. In terms of social protection, of which maternity leave is certainly a part, progress is needed and immobility is no longer allowed! I will pay particular attention to the progress of this issue. Thank you for your attention.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Similarly to numerous colleagues I would like to raise my deepest concerns regarding the deadlock in the Council regarding the Maternity Leave Directive. Proposed measures, such as 20 weeks of paid maternity leave and 2 weeks of paternity leave cannot be underestimated considering the deep demographic crisis experienced by quite a few EU Member States. Furthermore, measures to protect women who give birth to a baby and return to work are of ultimate importance in the context of protection of the rights of families and working mothers. Discrimination of parents raising minor children and discrimination due to family-related obligations are widespread in Europe. The situation around the Directive is especially notorious provided we are taking seriously our commitments of gender mainstreaming and gender equality. In a number of Members States, maternity leave with full pay has already proved its efficiency and triggered an increase in births and facilitated equal treatment and working resocialisation of mothers (and in some countries also fathers).

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D)
text: Written. – The Maternity Leave Directive has been blocked in the Council since 2010. This is unacceptable in view of the democratic majority in Parliament. It is important that mothers throughout the Union are protected when pregnant. The directive is about more than rest after childbirth, including dismissal protection, anti-discrimination measures and health aspects. It is retaliatory that the Council is failing to reach an agreement and is hiding behind false arguments such as subsidiarity when the real reason for the number is the alleged cost. This is yet another example of a broader pattern in which the Council is putting economic arguments on protection and workers' rights first. I call on the Council to break this pattern and to work urgently to protect the rights of mothers (in order). This will contribute to the equal opportunities of men and women in the labour market.  Finally, I would also like to argue for the right to paid paternity leave, even more so, I want to make this compulsory. This is the best way to avoid pressuring fathers not to take their right to paternity leave and boosting fathers' involvement with their newborn child.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the Commission statement on the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, people with disabilities must be enabled to participate fully and equally in society and the economy. I am entirely committed to achieving this objective.  The Commission’s work programme for 2015 stands as testimony to our pledge to put equal opportunities for people with disabilities at the heart of the Union’s policies and legislation, in full observance of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. This Commission has a clear agenda for creating jobs and growth for all, promoting fairness and creating a society where discrimination has no place and where no one is left behind.  European law offers protection against discrimination in employment on the grounds of disability, age, sexual orientation and religious belief. The Commission is keeping a careful eye on national developments, including in any new legislation or national case law. I am prepared to use all means at my disposal to ensure correct application of the law in all Member States. Moreover, the Commission hopes the Council will soon adopt our proposal for a horizontal Equal Treatment Directive, a proposal put forward in 2008, which extends this protection beyond the field of employment. Its adoption is a priority for the Commission and we will seek to convince national governments to give up their current resistance in the Council.  Europe still has a long way to go to achieve equal opportunities for persons with disabilities. Significant gaps persist, notably in employment and education. It is simply not acceptable that the employment rate for workers with a disability is 24% lower than that for others. Of course we should do more together – not only the Parliament, the Council and the Commission, but also the social partners and other stakeholders – to fight discrimination and make the labour market more open to the most vulnerable people in society. We must offer them appropriate ongoing support to remain economically active.  The European Social Fund invests in measures to promote equal opportunities and to combat discrimination. European law underpins this and requires employers to adapt workplaces and working arrangements to ensure they facilitate inclusion and diversity. Improving access to employment on the open labour market is certainly one way to enable full and equal participation, but empowering people with disabilities to enjoy their rights fully also means that persons with disabilities should not live in institutions.  The current regulatory framework for structural and investment funds has been reinforced, as you know, in order to promote the shift from institutional to community-based care. Member States are asked to demonstrate the existence of the administrative capacity for the implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and a thematic ex-ante conditionality requires that national strategies for reducing poverty, aiming at active inclusion, include measures to support the shift to community-based services. Only those actions which help to establish the conditions for independent living, in line with the United Nations Convention, should be supported.  This exchange with you today is taking place at a particularly timely moment. Last summer, the European Union submitted a report to the United Nations on how we are implementing the United Nations Convention. It highlights several positive developments, such as the new requirement on Member States to prove their capacity to implement the Convention as a precondition for accessing European structural and investment funding. We are now engaged in a dialogue with the United Nations on our implementation of the Convention. In September, the United Nations will provide their assessment of the Union’s progress. The Commission will take this evaluation into account in our mid-term review of the European Disability Strategy, assessing whether it is fit for purpose and seeing what urgent issues remain to be tackled at European level.  Implementing the Convention is a shared task, shared by all European institutions. I welcome the European Parliament’s commitment and the proactive role it plays in promoting the rights of persons with disabilities. This commitment has been renewed recently by the decision to re-establish a Disability Intergroup and to create a Cross-Sectoral Task Force. Making the United Nations Convention a reality is also a task shared between the European Union and the Member States. We must work in tandem, reinforcing and complementing each other’s efforts in a coordinated way. The Commission will continue to promote exchange and dialogue with all those concerned by the implementation of this Convention, including Member States, European institutions and organisations of persons with disabilities. This Commission believes in a European Union where no person is left behind, irrespective of his or her abilities, and where discrimination is not tolerated. You can count on my personal commitment to help build such a Europe.

name: Ádám Kósa
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – We are in a unique historical situation where the UN is examining the European Union for its appropriate implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The European Commission sent its report to the relevant UN committee in June last year, which was examined in April this year, and on this basis 45 new questions were formulated. This is called the "list of issues". The European Commission will have to formally respond to this.  I firmly believe that the European Parliament, as the only democratically elected institution in the European Union, the European Parliament, as the only member of the EU Framework that monitors the implementation of the UN Convention, which complies with the Paris standards, cannot be missed by the European Parliament itself in sending a reply to the UN Commission.  Firstly, I would like to urge the three Member States that have not yet ratified the UN Convention to do so as soon as possible. These countries are the Netherlands, Finland and Ireland. And I urge the Commission to... (sorry, interpreter error...) therefore, those who have already ratified the UN Convention, and I urge those who have already ratified it, to implement the UN Convention as quickly as possible, including the European Union.  Finally, I urge the European Commission to formally involve the European Parliament in a constructive dialogue with the UN and to finally draft the long-awaited European accessibility package.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is the first convention to which the European Union has acceded as a joint organisation. This shows the importance the EU attaches to the enforcement of the rights of persons with disabilities. The Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, must therefore respect this EU political commitment and do everything in its power to bring forward and adopt important legislation such as the Anti-Discrimination Directive or the Accessibility Act. 80 million citizens of the European Union are waiting for this.  Another important issue today is the supervision of the implementation of the United Nations Convention on Persons with Disabilities. The European Union, as a party to the Convention, faces an internal institutional problem. The European Parliament, an institution directly elected by our people, is not properly and formally involved in the preparation of reports and monitoring the implementation of the Convention. Yes, the Commission is designated as the main body designated to answer the list of questions of the Committee on Persons with Disabilities in accordance with Article 33 of the Convention. However, the same Article 33 of the Convention states that Parliament is a very important part of the structure of the European Union entrusted with the promotion, protection and control of the implementation of the Convention for the Protection of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The institution directly elected by the people cannot in any way be excluded from monitoring the implementation of legislation, which is certainly not in line with democratic principles.  However, in our institutional struggles, we cannot forget what we are fighting for. The petitions received by Parliament's Committee on Petitions, which inform people with disabilities that they have faced discrimination on the grounds of their disability when looking for work, self-employment, public and educational services, are constantly reminding us that we have not done so yet. Commissioner, I ask you very responsibly that the European Parliament should be involved in preparing its replies to the United Nations Committee on the implementation of this Convention.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. I would like to thank the Commissioner for her presence this evening, also for her continued commitment to promoting the rights of people with disabilities. I am also grateful for the many efforts that the Commission has already made in this area, but there is still a lot of work to be done.  I would encourage the Commission to commit to the full implementation of the UN Convention. It goes without saying that Parliament must be involved in this process and also be consulted for more. This is therefore not only in the formulation of the so-called ruse of issues, but also in terms of its reporting, monitoring and implementation. We therefore trust that the Commission will invite all EU framework members to formally participate in the constructive dialogue with the CRPD Committee in Geneva in August. I would also like to thank colleagues who have joined forces across party lines to put the rights of people with disabilities higher on the agenda. Last week we organised a public hearing with the EU Human Rights Agency and the European Ombudsman, among others, and the message was very clear there. This UN Convention is an extremely important document for people with disabilities. It also imposes a legal obligation on signatories, including the EU. The hearing also showed the need for cooperation between all the levels involved. A coherent approach is therefore the only way to ensure that people with disabilities can also fully enjoy the freedom of movement of people, which is a fundamental right for all EU citizens. The introduction of, for example, a European accessibility regulation could represent a major step forward. After all, people with disabilities in Europe still experience too many obstacles when they want to use goods or services. A single European market is not yet a reality for them. People with disabilities, like you and I, must be able to participate in our society, and that is why the implementation of the UN Treaty is so crucial, so important. I am counting on all of you to turn the fine words of the report into action.

name: Marian Harkin
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the EU has ratified the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and that brings with it significant responsibilities for all EU institutions, as indeed for all the Member States that have ratified it. In this context, I would agree with my colleague Adám Kósa, and strongly ask my own country, Ireland, to ratify this Convention. Yes, I know there are legal difficulties, but we have to get on with it. People with disabilities need to be able to assert their rights today – not next year or the year after. The resolution this evening expresses the views of Parliament, but because of time constraints I have the opportunity to mention only one or two issues. First of all, we are calling on the Commission to present an ambitious proposal for a European accessibility act, and I am pleased to hear what the Commissioner has to say about that. But we are also strongly calling on the Council to speed up its work on the Directive on the accessibility of public sector bodies’ websites for persons with disabilities, and also on the Commission to explain in full how, in both current and future legislation, we can ensure that persons with disabilities will be guaranteed equal access and equal opportunities.  Finally, I am asking for support for our amendment which urges Member States to work towards the adoption of the EU Anti-Discrimination Directive, because it seeks to protect persons with disabilities against discrimination in social protection, healthcare, rehabilitation, education and access to the supply of goods and services such as housing, transport and insurance. If we could make progress here, that would be a major step forward.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – The Commission - as a member of the troika - bears a huge responsibility for the deterioration of the lives of the disabled in Greece: it has proposed cuts that have crushed basic rights for the disabled. There are many people who no longer have access to the health system, others have been excluded from the labour market. Unemployment among people with disabilities reaches even ninety per cent in Greece and, for the past year, institutions hosting children with severe disabilities are threatened with closure because there is no money to pay their staff. So what does the actual implementation of the UN Convention mean, five years after its adoption?  It means, among other things, that the Commission, the Council and every Member State that proposes austerity programmes cannot ignore their impact on disabled citizens. Disabled people do not need wishes and sympathy, but policies that make up for the freedom that nature or bad luck has deprived them of. If we offer people with disabilities even one centimetre of the support that the Institutions of the European Union provide to banks and policies, then we will have taken a step towards improving their quality of life. That is why we need a mechanism that records disabilities and monitors how the UN Convention is applied in each country, because if we do not put binding rules of compliance of each state and every European institution of the European Union into this convention, neither do we respect the disabled or ourselves. [applause]

name: Ulrike Lunacek
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, as rapporteur in this House for the Equality Directive, I also very strongly support the resolution we now have on the table. I hope that the request from this Parliament for the Commission to involve us in properly answering the questions that have been put to us by the United Nations receives strong support, not just from my side but from the House as a whole. Let me tell you, as rapporteur for the Equality Directive, which includes access to goods and services and many other things for people with disabilities, that I very much appreciate the Commission having made it a priority. We just need to move on and get it done.  We see that people with disabilities still face restrictions when it comes to their rights to cast their vote and to be elected, especially as parliamentarians, and we should take a strong interest in getting movement on that front. We see that people with disabilities do not have the same access to goods and services as, for example, people discriminated against on grounds of race. The latter can go to the courts; people with disabilities are not allowed to.  We therefore need to get the Equality Directive moving, and I very much hope that I will have strong support for the amendment we have tabled to include this request in the resolution before us. As I have already said, we have to step up inclusion policies for people with disabilities. That is why I am asking the Commission to involve Parliament in answering the questions the United Nations has put to us.

name: Eleonora Evi
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too am pleased that there is a joint motion for a resolution expressing this Parliament' s opinion, where a number of issues have rightly been highlighted, including that relating to the integration of people with disabilities into the world of work and that relating to the unblocking of the anti-discrimination directive.  However, as a member of the Committee on Petitions, I would like to give voice to a problem that is little discussed: the situation of family caregivers, that is, those who care full-time for a family member who is not self-sufficient. Some European countries have legally framed this figure, thus giving it the right rights and duties. Unfortunately, however, there are other countries, including my own, Italy, where family caregivers are left completely alone in their daily family care activities.  I do not think it is acceptable that what appears to be a very wearisome job should not receive the necessary social security, health and insurance protections, especially if the model we want to strive for is that of caring for people with disabilities in the family rather than in institutions of shelter. We therefore hope that those countries that have not yet recognised the figure of the family caregiver will be able to remedy this as soon as possible, given the importance of a truly holistic approach to the issue of disability.

name: Marek Plura (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. I am very pleased and thank you that, despite this late debate, this debate is taking place and is taking place in such a serious tone. At the same time, I congratulate and thank my colleagues in the disability intergroup that this debate has been brought to this debate today. I believe that it is essential for the implementation of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in the European Union to enable the declaring of a disability by the persons concerned to be declared equally throughout Europe. Of course, we cannot imagine today that disability case law should be uniform in Europe, but we already have a good idea for many years that allows the Member States to recognise these rulings. It is the European Disability Charter, the European Disability Charter. It will enable those citizens of the European Union with disabilities to exercise their civil rights. In the presence of the Commissioner, I would like to ask whether, in the Commission's view, this solution will be an important step towards the implementation of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and does the Commission envisage its implementation as soon as possible?

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, gender equality and disability issues need, among many other things, greater visibility. I would like us not to close any session of the European Parliament for future speeches and forthcoming discussions. I welcome, of course, the review of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and to emphasize, in particular, the need to advance employment rates and accessibility. But no less important is to work cross-cuttingly on all European Union policies, and the unblocking of the anti-discrimination directive is essential for this. In this regard, my group has tabled an amendment which has been supported by all the groups in this House, with the exception of the People's Group, to which I ask that tomorrow vote in conscience and make it possible for us to move that message to the Commission so that this necessary anti-discrimination directive is definitively unlocked. On the other hand, we have also echoed a claim that the European Disability Forum has been making to us. It is a very striking claim and occurs in many Member States, and refers to the need to remove those restrictions made to article 12 of the Convention, in particular the right to vote and to be elected, with a very restrictive interpretation of legal capacity.
