I therefore hope that this Parliament will also support this initiative tomorrow, that we will transfer it to the Commission so that it can also be endorsed, and that we will achieve that necessary full citizenship of all persons with disabilities. Finally, I would like to ask, as has already been done here, for the European Parliament's greater participation in disability issues, because that would involve cross-cutting action in all the policies that are brought to this House and, therefore, greater participation and sensitivity on this issue.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR).
text: – Even five years after the European Union's accession to the Convention, persons with disabilities do not have free movement, they face various physical and social barriers, as well as prejudices that persist. It is important to break down these barriers not only so that they can move freely, study or travel for work, but also, when necessary, make seamless use of healthcare in another Member State. Today, I received this scarf that I am wearing from Slovak muscular dissofectors. You see how people who have disabilities can do great things. Let's not leave these people on the fringes of society. None of us have chosen whether to be born healthy or disabled, whether they lose sight, hearing or stay in a wheelchair during their lifetime. That is why it is important that we do not break down barriers not only on paper, but also in reality.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, people with disabilities campaigned for this convention, so they need to be included in monitoring and implementation. This resolution calls for the Commission formally to consult all relevant bodies, including Parliament, in its response to the Convention Committee. Now, more than ever, this inclusive approach is vital. The economic crisis and cuts to services have caused deterioration in the rights and independence of people with disabilities. Organisations caring for people with a learning disability, such as Destined, in Derry, are carrying out hugely valuable work in difficult circumstances. In Carlow and Kilkenny only 27% of people with a disability are at work, and people with disabilities are much more likely to live in poverty. The situation is worsening due to Irish enforced austerity and British Tory cuts. Proper implementation of this convention can bring about a dramatic improvement in the lives of millions, and that is why we need to get this process right.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the integration of people with disabilities into the labour market is one of the biggest challenges facing social and labour policies, in a context where the employability rate of these people is 20% lower than the rest. In addition to having an ethical and social obligation to ensure the implementation of the UN Convention, in order to remove the discrimination and barriers that prevent the exercise of their rights on an equal basis with the other, we must develop differentiated mechanisms in the most diverse areas. That is why I call on the European Commission to adapt to all its regulations, platforms and instruments to enshrine fairness in the treatment of these people. Special attention should be paid to education, and it is urgent to develop early intervention programmes in all Member States and provide them with decent human, material and financial resources, which can lead to effective skills development and minimisation of existing limitations, ensuring that all children with disabilities have an inclusive education, even before pre-school education, based on a curriculum appropriate to their learning skills. But at a time when we have the largest research and innovation programme, it is important that there is a strengthening in the dissemination of your opportunities and that we are involved in the areas of science and technology applied to disability. European people with disabilities can no longer have to resort to centres of excellence outside the European Union. The mere differentiation of conditions is now insufficient. Our aim must be essentially to guarantee this group of people the full enjoyment of human rights in an inclusive society, as well as the protection and assistance necessary for both themselves and their families, with a view to the full and equitable exercise of the rights of persons with disabilities.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the When we talk about people with disabilities, we talk about people with different talent and needs. For too long, they have only looked at their shortcomings and have not really included them in political considerations and decisions. And we are, in fact, still a long way from genuine inclusion. What is certain is that the poverty rate of people with disabilities is well above average, only one in two people is in employment and only one in three young people with disabilities goes to school. Just over a month ago, we discussed the introduction of employment quotas in Brussels. It is no secret: self-determined life and social participation can be made possible above all through integration into the labour market. In Germany, more than 111 000 companies employ disabled people, and this is a first success. These companies have understood that both sides can benefit from this. In the software sector, for example.B, people who are autistic are used very successfully, because their analytical talent is needed and promoted here. The Member States must be made much more accountable to promote inclusion in all areas of society. I would ask the Commission, and I expect it, to finally put forward a binding proposal on how people with disabilities and disabilities are involved in all the legislative procedures affecting them through good regulation, so that they really arrive in the middle of life.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht Koch (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is now more than four years since the European Union ratified the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. With its ratification, the European Union has become an independent party to the first ever international treaty on human rights.  It is intended to ensure that people with disabilities are treated equally in the exercise of their rights and no longer as sick people, but rather as equals. To this end, it is urgently necessary to create appropriate structures and to remove barriers that still exist in order to raise awareness of the need for action. There must be room in our society for all people, and especially for the 80 million people living with a disability in the EU. It must be ensured that, like all other people, they also have access to and the right to education, training, adequate health care, employment, social protection, equality and participation and access to buildings, transport and information, as well as the right to live a self-determined life in society. The current review of the EU strategy by the UN is an important moment, which also allows us to publicise, evaluate and revise the current rules, measures and procedures. The first steps have been taken. Let us also take the next steps together!

name: Soraya Post (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It is a milestone in the work on human rights that the EU has acceded to this Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. It is also very important for Parliament to take an active part in the review of the implementation of the Convention. That is why the resolution on which we are going to vote tomorrow is also very important. Of course, the EU has a great deal left to do to ensure that people with disabilities can lead a life on the same terms as other people in the EU. The fact that the Council has not been able to develop a position on the discrimination directive presented by the Commission in 2008 effectively conceals protection against discrimination against people with disabilities and other persons in vulnerable situations.  I would like to make two points in relation to the implementation of the Convention in the European Union. The first is that we need to see people with disabilities as individuals from different backgrounds, culture, gender, belief and ethnicity. It is therefore extremely important that we pay attention to the fact that people with disabilities may also be subjected to other forms of discrimination. We must also see that people with disabilities have different needs in order to live an active and independent life in our society. It is not reasonable for a disability to restrict a person in things that others take for granted, such as where you choose to live, what education you want, where you want to work, what you want to do in your spare time, what goods and services you want to use. In this place, the EU can play an important role by developing guidelines. However, the starting point must always be that the obstacle exists in the environment and not in man.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Commissioner, I have listened with interest to your speech, and I very much point out that the issue of disabled people is an important issue. I would say almost a key issue for your agents and also for the European Commission's agenda. Let me make a few comments on the debate that has already taken place here. First of all, I would like to join those colleagues who say here that it is very sad that three Member States of the European Union have still not ratified this Convention. I would therefore like to call on you, if there is anything that can be done on the diplomatic field by the Commission, for these three States to join the international convention, so that you can please do so. The second thing I want to emphasise, which I liked in your speech, is that the issue of full inclusion of disabled people is not only about their employment and education, although these are very key agendas and there is a great deal of work to be done on this matter, but there are other things, such as the reflection on the proposal for a directive on the accessibility of public bodies' websites. I very much respect that. I used to be a member of the Czech government, I was in charge of citizens' access to public administration, to justice, and I know how difficult it is for people with disabilities to communicate with the authorities, to communicate with the judiciary. If they were able, at least in the field of information, to have access to this and to have access to information provided by public bodies in alternative formats, then I think that would be a great deal of work. So I support and thank you.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The ratification of the Convention has been a qualitative step forward in the enforcement of EU interests, but more action is needed to protect the rights of persons with disabilities. What can we do? Member States are warned and reminded that disability must be looked at in the light of human rights. Secondly, disabled people should be seen as useful, self-ordained and equal citizens of society. Thirdly, the effectiveness of the measures taken so far must not only be reviewed by the authorities, but also involved in civil society, all those who fight for the rights of people with disabilities.  The EU should continue to emphasise inclusive education for people with disabilities in order to prevent the risk of poverty and encourage social engagement. And, of course, further accession to human rights conventions is also necessary. Thus, everyone can live as equal citizens in the European Union.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities has been a starting point, it has been a watershed for the approach of politics and institutions to the problems of disabled people. By influencing decision-making processes and placing the issue of disability at the heart of the national and European political agenda, it has given rise to a kind of domino effect. The Member States and the EU institutions have significantly changed their policies and implemented reforms, so the rights of disabled people are now included in every area. We are rightly no longer talking about transport, tourism, employment, education, infrastructure and participation in public life without devoting specific measures to accessibility for disabled people.  But much remains to be done. There are still substantial differences in treatment between Member States and we should start by creating minimum standards to which all States should begin to adapt. For example, there are 80 million disabled people in Europe, and it is right that they should all have the same treatment, the same opportunities and the same rights everywhere.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). – In the European Union, the distance between reason and action is chaotic. We have heard great words today from the Commission about its intention to promote the protection of people with disabilities. In fact, the austerity policies that the Commission serves and imposes with religious fanaticism, especially in the memorial countries, are brutally affecting the disabled. For example in Greece, the disabled have experienced drastic wage and pension cuts, unaffordable tax increases and a dramatic deterioration in public health and welfare services. Many tens of thousands of people suffer months of exam delays at the Disability Certification Centres, causing survival problems for those living solely on benefits. The table of irreversible diseases lacks insusive diseases, such as diabetes, haemophilia, seropositive. The new disability grade assessment regulation halves benefits. The prescription ceiling is borne by chronically ill patients with unaffordable own costs. Cancer patients bear huge costs of taking medications and tests, while their condition is exacerbated by exterminating waiting lists for treatment. You're only interested in money, not people.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, human dignity must be respected and protected in accordance with Article 26 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and, according to that article, the Union and its Member States must respect the rights of people with disabilities and must take measures to ensure their participation in the labour market and in social life. In Europe, 80 million people face some form of disability, while in Greece, people with disabilities account for 10% of the population. People with disabilities were targeted by the troika that reduced disability pensions. Thus, memoranda and austerity lead people with disabilities to social exclusion and, at the same time, the lack of staff in disability care institutions are intensifying their already difficult social situation. I hope that the new Greek government will immediately redress these injustices imposed by the troika. We must therefore finally put an end to austerity in Europe and violent fiscal adjustment because they seriously harm vulnerable social groups, especially the disabled.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, transparency of accountability, also derived from the obligations of signing the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in the functioning of the European institutions themselves, is indeed essential. And it is necessary that, contrary to what exists today, this information is accessible to all and clear. But it's not enough! To be consistent with this Convention would, for example, not encourage and support cuts in public education systems affecting people with disabilities. In my country, Portugal, within the framework of troika and post-troika politics, which are one and the same, the numbers of special education teachers have been brutally reduced and in many schools there is not a single teacher. There are students who for lack of support in school are advised to stay at home, finding their parents completely desperate and without any solution. They are children and young people who have been removed from the right to education. Does this have anything to do with the Convention which here, at least in terms of words, is defended?

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission – I have listened carefully to all your comments. I note that you are rightly very ambitious and I can tell you that you find a partner in the Commission. I would like to assure you once again that we want to work with this Commission to ensure an inclusive Europe without barriers and without discrimination. That is why we will continue to work to implement the commitments that we too have made by acceding to the UN Convention. I would like to reiterate the call to those countries that still see barriers to ratifying accession to the Treaty, to do so and to remove them. We will continue our efforts to persuade the Member States to remove the barriers in the Council in order to finally adopt the proposal containing a general anti-discrimination regime. I would like to call for dialogue with the United Nations to be seized as a welcome opportunity. An opportunity, because this dialogue allows us to subject the actions of the past years to a critical review, but also because it is now a reason for us here to exchange views on the results achieved and the input that will come and will come from the European Parliament, from the representatives of the people with disabilities and from civil society. These are all things that are useful for sharpening the priorities, including our disability strategy. I would once again like to welcome Parliament's initiative to provide valuable input, including the dialogue with the United Nations itself, through the hearing on 12 May, through this debate and through the resolution on which you are voting tomorrow. I can assure you that I have asked my department to remain in close contact with Parliament and with the other members of the European framework in the preparation of the answers to the United Nations.  Ladies and gentlemen, you yourself have said, there are about 80 million people with disabilities today. This trend is also more likely to increase due to the ageing of the population. That is why it is all the more important both for our society and for our economy that everyday products and also services, for example our transport systems and information and communication technologies, are accessible to everyone. That is why we are working on a European accessibility act. Some of you have insisted on continuing with this. I interpret that call as your support for the work we are doing. The crisis has indeed hit hard, especially among vulnerable groups. Some of you have also pointed this out. I would like to point out that we have only completed the European semester, that is, the Commission has proposed the country-specific recommendations, which the Council has yet to adopt. Through that semester, supported by our funds, we are incentling the Member States to modernise their social insurance systems. We want the European Union to be made up of inclusive and activating welfare states that enable people to participate in the labour market and in society. That is a line we have also taken in our proposal on the employment guidelines. You have rightly pointed out that all policy areas should be addressed to people with disabilities. This is certainly the case for the areas within my competence: the fight against unemployment, the mobility of people and the building of skills. These also need to be approached from the perspective of people with disabilities. That is what we will do. In this respect, I look forward to continuing to work with the parliamentary bodies that have recently been set up, the task force and also the intergroup for people with disabilities. Finally, you can count on me to continue to inform you of the outcome of the dialogue with the United Nations. I look forward to future exchanges, including on the disability strategy, and I thank you once again for this useful debate, also because it has once again put the issue at the top of the agenda.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The debate is closed. I have received a motion for a resolution, in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure, to conclude this debate.* The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 20 May. * See Minutes Written statements (Article 162)

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Parliament has addressed the issue of integration and the rights of people with disabilities. Among Europeans, 80 million have a disability. Unfortunately, they too have been hit hard by the crisis and austerity policies. In terms of employment, accessibility or education, for example, there is still a lot of work to be done to accelerate their integration. The Commission has developed its 2010-2020 strategy for the integration of people with disabilities, based in particular on employment and education. But austerity has significantly mitigated its effects. In the meantime, the European Union has joined the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. It must now apply its principles. It must strengthen its work in favour of employment, training, social integration or education for people with disabilities by devoting the necessary budgets. But the Commission must also present as soon as possible a legislative proposal to make them accessible to goods and services in the Union. Similarly, it is essential that the Council of European Ministers lift its blockade on the cross-cutting anti-discrimination directive. Finally, representative associations such as the European Disability Forum should be consulted throughout this work.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – There are 80 million persons who live with a so called ‘disability’ within the European Union. We ignorantly and sometimes even arrogantly label them ‘disabled’, disempower and ultimately disrespect them simply because we do not understand what it means to live with different abilities than the ones that we were born with. Persons with different abilities deserve the same treatment and opportunities as anyone else. In an age where it is more than evident that everyone can contribute to our societies in some way, we must truly recognize our duty to change our current policies. Ensuring basic rights are adhered to, and assisting persons with disabilities in the field of access to employment can ensure an independent living module to all those who seek it. This, combined with a move from institutionalisation to community—based care, a good educational basis for children with disabilities – both physical and intellectual – based on the concept of ‘different abilities’ rather than ‘disabilities’ can help us fight the social stigma that persons with a disability still face in this day and age. These measures need to be implemented and monitored as we must ensure that Member States are living up to their obligations.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. – I call on all my fellow Members to support parliament's resolution on the application of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. We must send a clear and overwhelming signal to our fellow disabled people that we are doing everything we can to put their rights into practice. I consider it of the utmost importance that the EU be able to provide a full and credible report to the UN Committee on Disability on how it transposes the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities into everyday life. We must send a strong call to Those Member States that have not yet transposed into their internal law the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. I also urge the Commission to formally involve Parliament and the members of the EU framework in a constructive dialogue with the UN and to draft the long-awaited European accessibility legislation.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. – In the EU, around 8% of people 16 years of age and older report severe disability and about 18% moderate disability. The EU and most Member States have signed the Convention, and many of the Member States have ratified it in their national laws. The Convention establishes an international monitoring system through the designation of governmental agencies responsible for implementation issues, and also provides that civil society will be integrated and participate in the follow-up process. As a result, the EU Disability Unit was set up, which produced a report on the implementation of the Convention, in relation to which the United Nations presented a "list of issues" to which the Commission must now respond. As one of the European Parliament's implementers for the implementation and follow-up to the Convention, I have considered a resolution that highlights the need for coordination between the various European institutions, the need to adopt the European Accessibility Law and Parliament's support for the Commission in drawing up the response, and in which Parliament also expresses some unease that the Commission has not relied more on him for the preparation of the report.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – This Convention is an important step in levelling the playing field for people with disabilities. The document discusses the rights of persons with disabilities, the role of their advocates and the cooperation structures. Around 80 million people with disabilities live in eu countries and one in six Europeans has limited mobility. In line with the 2010 European Strategy on This Issue, Europe is to become a continent without barriers by 2020. Adopted in Poland in 1997 The Disability Charter identifies the most important areas where intensive action is needed to ensure that people with disabilities do not feel discriminated against. The so-called "black book" presents m.in. architectural, technical barriers in places of education and work and communication barriers. In recent months, The Polish Railways has regulated legal assistance for people with disabilities when boarding and getting off the train. However, the lack of financial security for carers of people with disabilities is worrying, most often for women who give up work to care for a disabled person. Unfortunately, the current low benefits for this purpose are unfortunately being tried even further. The positively assessed JUNIOR programme on the professional activation of graduates with disabilities enables them to take up traineeships and subsequent employment. A novelty was the translation of the information text prepared by UNESCO, in a child-friendly version, under the name "You have the right".

name: Julia Pitera (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, done at New York on 13 December 2006, is the first international piece of legislation that comprehensively addresses the rights of persons with disabilities. Its essence is to promote, protect and ensure the full and equal enjoyment of all human rights and fundamental freedoms by all persons with disabilities and to promote respect for their inherent dignity. Despite the increasing number of educational and organisational activities carried out in many EU countries, there are still many barriers that prevent the implementation of basic efforts, such as the possibility of full participation in civic and social life. It is therefore necessary to introduce an obligation to remove all obstacles which hinder persons with disabilities from fully and effectively participating in society, on the basis of equality with others. The implementation of such regulations should also be monitored and the provisions adopted should be disseminated in the minds of all citizens.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. – It is estimated that around 80 million people in the European Union have a disability. It should be one of our top priorities as Members of the European Parliament to ensure that the equal rights, dignity, equal treatment and full participation of persons with disabilities in society is a fact and not a mere wish.  As members of the Committee on Petitions, we receive plenty of cases dealing with discrimination on the grounds of disability in access to employment, self-employment, public services and education. According to the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights, discrimination and barriers while exercising their rights are part of everyday life for persons with disabilities.  It is essential to underline that this is not a homogeneous group and therefore the policies and actions should reflect the various needs of women, children or people who need more intense support. Furthermore, I am hopeful that the Commission is going to take this matter deeply into consideration and will come up with an ambitious proposal for a European accessibility act, ensuring the full involvement of persons with disabilities throughout the legislative cycle while having regard to the proper level of accessibility to goods and services for all European citizens.
